CHAPTER 1<br><br><br><br>Loomings.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Call me Ishmael.  Some years ago--never mind how long<br><br>precisely--having little or no money in my purse, and nothing<br><br>particular to interest me on shore, I thought I would sail about a<br><br>little and see the watery part of the world.  It is a way I have of<br><br>driving off the spleen and regulating the circulation.  Whenever I<br><br>find myself growing grim about the mouth; whenever it is a damp,<br><br>drizzly November in my soul; whenever I find myself involuntarily<br><br>pausing before coffin warehouses, and bringing up the rear of every<br><br>funeral I meet; and especially whenever my hypos get such an upper<br><br>hand of me, that it requires a strong moral principle to prevent me<br><br>from deliberately stepping into the street, and methodically knocking<br><br>people's hats off--then, I account it high time to get to sea as soon<br><br>as I can.  This is my substitute for pistol and ball.  With a<br><br>philosophical flourish Cato throws himself upon his sword; I quietly<br><br>take to the ship.  There is nothing surprising in this.  If they but<br><br>knew it, almost all men in their degree, some time or other, cherish<br><br>very nearly the same feelings towards the ocean with me.<br><br><br><br>There now is your insular city of the Manhattoes, belted round by<br><br>wharves as Indian isles by coral reefs--commerce surrounds it with<br><br>her surf.  Right and left, the streets take you waterward.  Its<br><br>extreme downtown is the battery, where that noble mole is washed by<br><br>waves, and cooled by breezes, which a few hours previous were out of<br><br>sight of land.  Look at the crowds of water-gazers there.<br><br><br><br>Circumambulate the city of a dreamy Sabbath afternoon.  Go from<br><br>Corlears Hook to Coenties Slip, and from thence, by Whitehall,<br><br>northward.  What do you see?--Posted like silent sentinels all around<br><br>the town, stand thousands upon thousands of mortal men fixed in ocean<br><br>reveries.  Some leaning against the spiles; some seated upon the<br><br>pier-heads; some looking over the bulwarks of ships from China; some<br><br>high aloft in the rigging, as if striving to get a still better<br><br>seaward peep.  But these are all landsmen; of week days pent up in<br><br>lath and plaster--tied to counters, nailed to benches, clinched to<br><br>desks.  How then is this?  Are the green fields gone?  What do they<br><br>here?<br><br><br><br>But look! here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and<br><br>seemingly bound for a dive.  Strange!  Nothing will content them but<br><br>the extremest limit of the land; loitering under the shady lee of<br><br>yonder warehouses will not suffice.  No.  They must get just as nigh<br><br>the water as they possibly can without falling in.  And there they<br><br>stand--miles of them--leagues.  Inlanders all, they come from lanes<br><br>and alleys, streets and avenues--north, east, south, and west.  Yet<br><br>here they all unite.  Tell me, does the magnetic virtue of the<br><br>needles of the compasses of all those ships attract them thither?<br><br><br><br>Once more.  Say you are in the country; in some high land of lakes.<br><br>Take almost any path you please, and ten to one it carries you down<br><br>in a dale, and leaves you there by a pool in the stream.  There is<br><br>magic in it.  Let the most absent-minded of men be plunged in his<br><br>deepest reveries--stand that man on his legs, set his feet a-going,<br><br>and he will infallibly lead you to water, if water there be in all<br><br>that region.  Should you ever be athirst in the great American<br><br>desert, try this experiment, if your caravan happen to be supplied<br><br>with a metaphysical professor.  Yes, as every one knows, meditation<br><br>and water are wedded for ever.<br><br><br><br>But here is an artist.  He desires to paint you the dreamiest,<br><br>shadiest, quietest, most enchanting bit of romantic landscape in all<br><br>the valley of the Saco.  What is the chief element he employs?  There<br><br>stand his trees, each with a hollow trunk, as if a hermit and a<br><br>crucifix were within; and here sleeps his meadow, and there sleep his<br><br>cattle; and up from yonder cottage goes a sleepy smoke.  Deep into<br><br>distant woodlands winds a mazy way, reaching to overlapping spurs of<br><br>mountains bathed in their hill-side blue.  But though the picture<br><br>lies thus tranced, and though this pine-tree shakes down its sighs<br><br>like leaves upon this shepherd's head, yet all were vain, unless the<br><br>shepherd's eye were fixed upon the magic stream before him.  Go visit<br><br>the Prairies in June, when for scores on scores of miles you wade<br><br>knee-deep among Tiger-lilies--what is the one charm<br><br>wanting?--Water--there is not a drop of water there!  Were Niagara<br><br>but a cataract of sand, would you travel your thousand miles to see<br><br>it?  Why did the poor poet of Tennessee, upon suddenly receiving two<br><br>handfuls of silver, deliberate whether to buy him a coat, which he<br><br>sadly needed, or invest his money in a pedestrian trip to Rockaway<br><br>Beach?  Why is almost every robust healthy boy with a robust healthy<br><br>soul in him, at some time or other crazy to go to sea?  Why upon your<br><br>first voyage as a passenger, did you yourself feel such a mystical<br><br>vibration, when first told that you and your ship were now out of<br><br>sight of land?  Why did the old Persians hold the sea holy?  Why did<br><br>the Greeks give it a separate deity, and own brother of Jove?  Surely<br><br>all this is not without meaning.  And still deeper the meaning of<br><br>that story of Narcissus, who because he could not grasp the<br><br>tormenting, mild image he saw in the fountain, plunged into it and<br><br>was drowned.  But that same image, we ourselves see in all rivers and<br><br>oceans.  It is the image of the ungraspable phantom of life; and this<br><br>is the key to it all.<br><br><br><br>Now, when I say that I am in the habit of going to sea whenever I<br><br>begin to grow hazy about the eyes, and begin to be over conscious of<br><br>my lungs, I do not mean to have it inferred that I ever go to sea as<br><br>a passenger.  For to go as a passenger you must needs have a purse,<br><br>and a purse is but a rag unless you have something in it.  Besides,<br><br>passengers get sea-sick--grow quarrelsome--don't sleep of nights--do<br><br>not enjoy themselves much, as a general thing;--no, I never go as a<br><br>passenger; nor, though I am something of a salt, do I ever go to sea<br><br>as a Commodore, or a Captain, or a Cook.  I abandon the glory and<br><br>distinction of such offices to those who like them.  For my part, I<br><br>abominate all honourable respectable toils, trials, and tribulations<br><br>of every kind whatsoever.  It is quite as much as I can do to take<br><br>care of myself, without taking care of ships, barques, brigs,<br><br>schooners, and what not.  And as for going as cook,--though I confess<br><br>there is considerable glory in that, a cook being a sort of officer<br><br>on ship-board--yet, somehow, I never fancied broiling fowls;--though<br><br>once broiled, judiciously buttered, and judgmatically salted and<br><br>peppered, there is no one who will speak more respectfully, not to<br><br>say reverentially, of a broiled fowl than I will.  It is out of the<br><br>idolatrous dotings of the old Egyptians upon broiled ibis and roasted<br><br>river horse, that you see the mummies of those creatures in their<br><br>huge bake-houses the pyramids.<br><br><br><br>No, when I go to sea, I go as a simple sailor, right before the mast,<br><br>plumb down into the forecastle, aloft there to the royal mast-head.<br><br>True, they rather order me about some, and make me jump from spar to<br><br>spar, like a grasshopper in a May meadow.  And at first, this sort of<br><br>thing is unpleasant enough.  It touches one's sense of honour,<br><br>particularly if you come of an old established family in the land,<br><br>the Van Rensselaers, or Randolphs, or Hardicanutes.  And more than<br><br>all, if just previous to putting your hand into the tar-pot, you have<br><br>been lording it as a country schoolmaster, making the tallest boys<br><br>stand in awe of you.  The transition is a keen one, I assure you,<br><br>from a schoolmaster to a sailor, and requires a strong decoction of<br><br>Seneca and the Stoics to enable you to grin and bear it.  But even<br><br>this wears off in time.<br><br><br><br>What of it, if some old hunks of a sea-captain orders me to get a<br><br>broom and sweep down the decks?  What does that indignity amount to,<br><br>weighed, I mean, in the scales of the New Testament?  Do you think<br><br>the archangel Gabriel thinks anything the less of me, because I<br><br>promptly and respectfully obey that old hunks in that particular<br><br>instance?  Who ain't a slave?  Tell me that.  Well, then, however the<br><br>old sea-captains may order me about--however they may thump and punch<br><br>me about, I have the satisfaction of knowing that it is all right;<br><br>that everybody else is one way or other served in much the same<br><br>way--either in a physical or metaphysical point of view, that is; and<br><br>so the universal thump is passed round, and all hands should rub each<br><br>other's shoulder-blades, and be content.<br><br><br><br>Again, I always go to sea as a sailor, because they make a point of<br><br>paying me for my trouble, whereas they never pay passengers a single<br><br>penny that I ever heard of.  On the contrary, passengers themselves<br><br>must pay.  And there is all the difference in the world between<br><br>paying and being paid.  The act of paying is perhaps the most<br><br>uncomfortable infliction that the two orchard thieves entailed upon<br><br>us.  But BEING PAID,--what will compare with it?  The urbane activity<br><br>with which a man receives money is really marvellous, considering<br><br>that we so earnestly believe money to be the root of all earthly<br><br>ills, and that on no account can a monied man enter heaven.  Ah! how<br><br>cheerfully we consign ourselves to perdition!<br><br><br><br>Finally, I always go to sea as a sailor, because of the wholesome<br><br>exercise and pure air of the fore-castle deck.  For as in this world,<br><br>head winds are far more prevalent than winds from astern (that is, if<br><br>you never violate the Pythagorean maxim), so for the most part the<br><br>Commodore on the quarter-deck gets his atmosphere at second hand from<br><br>the sailors on the forecastle.  He thinks he breathes it first; but<br><br>not so.  In much the same way do the commonalty lead their leaders in<br><br>many other things, at the same time that the leaders little suspect<br><br>it.  But wherefore it was that after having repeatedly smelt the sea<br><br>as a merchant sailor, I should now take it into my head to go on a<br><br>whaling voyage; this the invisible police officer of the Fates, who<br><br>has the constant surveillance of me, and secretly dogs me, and<br><br>influences me in some unaccountable way--he can better answer than<br><br>any one else.  And, doubtless, my going on this whaling voyage,<br><br>formed part of the grand programme of Providence that was drawn up a<br><br>long time ago.  It came in as a sort of brief interlude and solo<br><br>between more extensive performances.  I take it that this part of the<br><br>bill must have run something like this:<br><br><br><br><br><br>"GRAND CONTESTED ELECTION FOR THE PRESIDENCY OF THE UNITED STATES.<br><br>"WHALING VOYAGE BY ONE ISHMAEL.<br><br>"BLOODY BATTLE IN AFFGHANISTAN."<br><br><br><br><br><br>Though I cannot tell why it was exactly that those stage managers,<br><br>the Fates, put me down for this shabby part of a whaling voyage, when<br><br>others were set down for magnificent parts in high tragedies, and<br><br>short and easy parts in genteel comedies, and jolly parts in<br><br>farces--though I cannot tell why this was exactly; yet, now that I<br><br>recall all the circumstances, I think I can see a little into the<br><br>springs and motives which being cunningly presented to me under<br><br>various disguises, induced me to set about performing the part I did,<br><br>besides cajoling me into the delusion that it was a choice resulting<br><br>from my own unbiased freewill and discriminating judgment.<br><br><br><br>Chief among these motives was the overwhelming idea of the great<br><br>whale himself.  Such a portentous and mysterious monster roused all<br><br>my curiosity.  Then the wild and distant seas where he rolled his<br><br>island bulk; the undeliverable, nameless perils of the whale; these,<br><br>with all the attending marvels of a thousand Patagonian sights and<br><br>sounds, helped to sway me to my wish.  With other men, perhaps, such<br><br>things would not have been inducements; but as for me, I am tormented<br><br>with an everlasting itch for things remote.  I love to sail forbidden<br><br>seas, and land on barbarous coasts.  Not ignoring what is good, I am<br><br>quick to perceive a horror, and could still be social with it--would<br><br>they let me--since it is but well to be on friendly terms with all<br><br>the inmates of the place one lodges in.<br><br><br><br>By reason of these things, then, the whaling voyage was welcome; the<br><br>great flood-gates of the wonder-world swung open, and in the wild<br><br>conceits that swayed me to my purpose, two and two there floated into<br><br>my inmost soul, endless processions of the whale, and, mid most of<br><br>them all, one grand hooded phantom, like a snow hill in the air.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 2<br><br><br><br>The Carpet-Bag.<br><br><br><br><br><br>I stuffed a shirt or two into my old carpet-bag, tucked it under my<br><br>arm, and started for Cape Horn and the Pacific.  Quitting the good<br><br>city of old Manhatto, I duly arrived in New Bedford.  It was a<br><br>Saturday night in December.  Much was I disappointed upon learning<br><br>that the little packet for Nantucket had already sailed, and that no<br><br>way of reaching that place would offer, till the following Monday.<br><br><br><br>As most young candidates for the pains and penalties of whaling stop<br><br>at this same New Bedford, thence to embark on their voyage, it may as<br><br>well be related that I, for one, had no idea of so doing.  For my<br><br>mind was made up to sail in no other than a Nantucket craft, because<br><br>there was a fine, boisterous something about everything connected<br><br>with that famous old island, which amazingly pleased me.  Besides<br><br>though New Bedford has of late been gradually monopolising the<br><br>business of whaling, and though in this matter poor old Nantucket is<br><br>now much behind her, yet Nantucket was her great original--the Tyre<br><br>of this Carthage;--the place where the first dead American whale was<br><br>stranded.  Where else but from Nantucket did those aboriginal<br><br>whalemen, the Red-Men, first sally out in canoes to give chase to the<br><br>Leviathan?  And where but from Nantucket, too, did that first<br><br>adventurous little sloop put forth, partly laden with imported<br><br>cobblestones--so goes the story--to throw at the whales, in order to<br><br>discover when they were nigh enough to risk a harpoon from the<br><br>bowsprit?<br><br><br><br>Now having a night, a day, and still another night following before<br><br>me in New Bedford, ere I could embark for my destined port, it<br><br>became a matter of concernment where I was to eat and sleep<br><br>meanwhile.  It was a very dubious-looking, nay, a very dark and<br><br>dismal night, bitingly cold and cheerless.  I knew no one in the<br><br>place.  With anxious grapnels I had sounded my pocket, and only<br><br>brought up a few pieces of silver,--So, wherever you go, Ishmael,<br><br>said I to myself, as I stood in the middle of a dreary street<br><br>shouldering my bag, and comparing the gloom towards the north with<br><br>the darkness towards the south--wherever in your wisdom you may<br><br>conclude to lodge for the night, my dear Ishmael, be sure to inquire<br><br>the price, and don't be too particular.<br><br><br><br>With halting steps I paced the streets, and passed the sign of "The<br><br>Crossed Harpoons"--but it looked too expensive and jolly there.<br><br>Further on, from the bright red windows of the "Sword-Fish Inn,"<br><br>there came such fervent rays, that it seemed to have melted the<br><br>packed snow and ice from before the house, for everywhere else the<br><br>congealed frost lay ten inches thick in a hard, asphaltic<br><br>pavement,--rather weary for me, when I struck my foot against the<br><br>flinty projections, because from hard, remorseless service the soles<br><br>of my boots were in a most miserable plight.  Too expensive and<br><br>jolly, again thought I, pausing one moment to watch the broad glare<br><br>in the street, and hear the sounds of the tinkling glasses within.<br><br>But go on, Ishmael, said I at last; don't you hear? get away from<br><br>before the door; your patched boots are stopping the way.  So on I<br><br>went.  I now by instinct followed the streets that took me waterward,<br><br>for there, doubtless, were the cheapest, if not the cheeriest inns.<br><br><br><br>Such dreary streets! blocks of blackness, not houses, on either<br><br>hand, and here and there a candle, like a candle moving about in a<br><br>tomb.  At this hour of the night, of the last day of the week, that<br><br>quarter of the town proved all but deserted.  But presently I came to<br><br>a smoky light proceeding from a low, wide building, the door of which<br><br>stood invitingly open.  It had a careless look, as if it were meant<br><br>for the uses of the public; so, entering, the first thing I did was<br><br>to stumble over an ash-box in the porch.  Ha! thought I, ha, as the<br><br>flying particles almost choked me, are these ashes from that<br><br>destroyed city, Gomorrah?  But "The Crossed Harpoons," and "The<br><br>Sword-Fish?"--this, then must needs be the sign of "The Trap."<br><br>However, I picked myself up and hearing a loud voice within, pushed<br><br>on and opened a second, interior door.<br><br><br><br>It seemed the great Black Parliament sitting in Tophet.  A hundred<br><br>black faces turned round in their rows to peer; and beyond, a black<br><br>Angel of Doom was beating a book in a pulpit.  It was a negro church;<br><br>and the preacher's text was about the blackness of darkness, and the<br><br>weeping and wailing and teeth-gnashing there.  Ha, Ishmael, muttered<br><br>I, backing out, Wretched entertainment at the sign of 'The Trap!'<br><br><br><br>Moving on, I at last came to a dim sort of light not far from the<br><br>docks, and heard a forlorn creaking in the air; and looking up, saw a<br><br>swinging sign over the door with a white painting upon it, faintly<br><br>representing a tall straight jet of misty spray, and these words<br><br>underneath--"The Spouter Inn:--Peter Coffin."<br><br><br><br>Coffin?--Spouter?--Rather ominous in that particular connexion,<br><br>thought I.  But it is a common name in Nantucket, they say, and I<br><br>suppose this Peter here is an emigrant from there.  As the light<br><br>looked so dim, and the place, for the time, looked quiet enough, and<br><br>the dilapidated little wooden house itself looked as if it might have<br><br>been carted here from the ruins of some burnt district, and as the<br><br>swinging sign had a poverty-stricken sort of creak to it, I thought<br><br>that here was the very spot for cheap lodgings, and the best of pea<br><br>coffee.<br><br><br><br>It was a queer sort of place--a gable-ended old house, one side<br><br>palsied as it were, and leaning over sadly.  It stood on a sharp<br><br>bleak corner, where that tempestuous wind Euroclydon kept up a worse<br><br>howling than ever it did about poor Paul's tossed craft.  Euroclydon,<br><br>nevertheless, is a mighty pleasant zephyr to any one in-doors, with<br><br>his feet on the hob quietly toasting for bed.  "In judging of that<br><br>tempestuous wind called Euroclydon," says an old writer--of whose<br><br>works I possess the only copy extant--"it maketh a marvellous<br><br>difference, whether thou lookest out at it from a glass window where<br><br>the frost is all on the outside, or whether thou observest it from<br><br>that sashless window, where the frost is on both sides, and of which<br><br>the wight Death is the only glazier."  True enough, thought I, as<br><br>this passage occurred to my mind--old black-letter, thou reasonest<br><br>well.  Yes, these eyes are windows, and this body of mine is the<br><br>house.  What a pity they didn't stop up the chinks and the crannies<br><br>though, and thrust in a little lint here and there.  But it's too<br><br>late to make any improvements now.  The universe is finished; the<br><br>copestone is on, and the chips were carted off a million years ago.<br><br>Poor Lazarus there, chattering his teeth against the curbstone for<br><br>his pillow, and shaking off his tatters with his shiverings, he might<br><br>plug up both ears with rags, and put a corn-cob into his mouth, and<br><br>yet that would not keep out the tempestuous Euroclydon.  Euroclydon!<br><br>says old Dives, in his red silken wrapper--(he had a redder one<br><br>afterwards) pooh, pooh!  What a fine frosty night; how Orion<br><br>glitters; what northern lights!  Let them talk of their oriental<br><br>summer climes of everlasting conservatories; give me the privilege of<br><br>making my own summer with my own coals.<br><br><br><br>But what thinks Lazarus?  Can he warm his blue hands by holding them<br><br>up to the grand northern lights?  Would not Lazarus rather be in<br><br>Sumatra than here?  Would he not far rather lay him down lengthwise<br><br>along the line of the equator; yea, ye gods! go down to the fiery pit<br><br>itself, in order to keep out this frost?<br><br><br><br>Now, that Lazarus should lie stranded there on the curbstone before<br><br>the door of Dives, this is more wonderful than that an iceberg should<br><br>be moored to one of the Moluccas.  Yet Dives himself, he too lives<br><br>like a Czar in an ice palace made of frozen sighs, and being a<br><br>president of a temperance society, he only drinks the tepid tears of<br><br>orphans.<br><br><br><br>But no more of this blubbering now, we are going a-whaling, and there<br><br>is plenty of that yet to come.  Let us scrape the ice from our<br><br>frosted feet, and see what sort of a place this "Spouter" may be.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 3<br><br><br><br>The Spouter-Inn.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Entering that gable-ended Spouter-Inn, you found yourself in a wide,<br><br>low, straggling entry with old-fashioned wainscots, reminding one of<br><br>the bulwarks of some condemned old craft.  On one side hung a very<br><br>large oilpainting so thoroughly besmoked, and every way defaced,<br><br>that in the unequal crosslights by which you viewed it, it was only<br><br>by diligent study and a series of systematic visits to it, and<br><br>careful inquiry of the neighbors, that you could any way arrive at an<br><br>understanding of its purpose.  Such unaccountable masses of shades<br><br>and shadows, that at first you almost thought some ambitious young<br><br>artist, in the time of the New England hags, had endeavored to<br><br>delineate chaos bewitched.  But by dint of much and earnest<br><br>contemplation, and oft repeated ponderings, and especially by<br><br>throwing open the little window towards the back of the entry, you at<br><br>last come to the conclusion that such an idea, however wild, might<br><br>not be altogether unwarranted.<br><br><br><br>But what most puzzled and confounded you was a long, limber,<br><br>portentous, black mass of something hovering in the centre of the<br><br>picture over three blue, dim, perpendicular lines floating in a<br><br>nameless yeast.  A boggy, soggy, squitchy picture truly, enough to<br><br>drive a nervous man distracted.  Yet was there a sort of indefinite,<br><br>half-attained, unimaginable sublimity about it that fairly froze you<br><br>to it, till you involuntarily took an oath with yourself to find out<br><br>what that marvellous painting meant.  Ever and anon a bright, but,<br><br>alas, deceptive idea would dart you through.--It's the Black Sea in a<br><br>midnight gale.--It's the unnatural combat of the four primal<br><br>elements.--It's a blasted heath.--It's a Hyperborean winter<br><br>scene.--It's the breaking-up of the icebound stream of Time.  But at<br><br>last all these fancies yielded to that one portentous something in<br><br>the picture's midst.  THAT once found out, and all the rest were<br><br>plain.  But stop; does it not bear a faint resemblance to a gigantic<br><br>fish? even the great leviathan himself?<br><br><br><br>In fact, the artist's design seemed this: a final theory of my own,<br><br>partly based upon the aggregated opinions of many aged persons with<br><br>whom I conversed upon the subject.  The picture represents a<br><br>Cape-Horner in a great hurricane; the half-foundered ship weltering<br><br>there with its three dismantled masts alone visible; and an<br><br>exasperated whale, purposing to spring clean over the craft, is in<br><br>the enormous act of impaling himself upon the three mast-heads.<br><br><br><br>The opposite wall of this entry was hung all over with a heathenish<br><br>array of monstrous clubs and spears.  Some were thickly set with<br><br>glittering teeth resembling ivory saws; others were tufted with knots<br><br>of human hair; and one was sickle-shaped, with a vast handle sweeping<br><br>round like the segment made in the new-mown grass by a long-armed<br><br>mower.  You shuddered as you gazed, and wondered what monstrous<br><br>cannibal and savage could ever have gone a death-harvesting with such<br><br>a hacking, horrifying implement.  Mixed with these were rusty old<br><br>whaling lances and harpoons all broken and deformed.  Some were<br><br>storied weapons.  With this once long lance, now wildly elbowed,<br><br>fifty years ago did Nathan Swain kill fifteen whales between a<br><br>sunrise and a sunset.  And that harpoon--so like a corkscrew now--was<br><br>flung in Javan seas, and run away with by a whale, years afterwards<br><br>slain off the Cape of Blanco.  The original iron entered nigh the<br><br>tail, and, like a restless needle sojourning in the body of a man,<br><br>travelled full forty feet, and at last was found imbedded in the<br><br>hump.<br><br><br><br>Crossing this dusky entry, and on through yon low-arched way--cut<br><br>through what in old times must have been a great central chimney with<br><br>fireplaces all round--you enter the public room.  A still duskier<br><br>place is this, with such low ponderous beams above, and such old<br><br>wrinkled planks beneath, that you would almost fancy you trod some<br><br>old craft's cockpits, especially of such a howling night, when this<br><br>corner-anchored old ark rocked so furiously.  On one side stood a<br><br>long, low, shelf-like table covered with cracked glass cases, filled<br><br>with dusty rarities gathered from this wide world's remotest nooks.<br><br>Projecting from the further angle of the room stands a dark-looking<br><br>den--the bar--a rude attempt at a right whale's head.  Be that how it<br><br>may, there stands the vast arched bone of the whale's jaw, so wide, a<br><br>coach might almost drive beneath it.  Within are shabby shelves,<br><br>ranged round with old decanters, bottles, flasks; and in those jaws<br><br>of swift destruction, like another cursed Jonah (by which name indeed<br><br>they called him), bustles a little withered old man, who, for their<br><br>money, dearly sells the sailors deliriums and death.<br><br><br><br>Abominable are the tumblers into which he pours his poison.  Though<br><br>true cylinders without--within, the villanous green goggling glasses<br><br>deceitfully tapered downwards to a cheating bottom.  Parallel<br><br>meridians rudely pecked into the glass, surround these footpads'<br><br>goblets.  Fill to THIS mark, and your charge is but a penny; to THIS<br><br>a penny more; and so on to the full glass--the Cape Horn measure,<br><br>which you may gulp down for a shilling.<br><br><br><br>Upon entering the place I found a number of young seamen gathered<br><br>about a table, examining by a dim light divers specimens of<br><br>SKRIMSHANDER.  I sought the landlord, and telling him I desired to be<br><br>accommodated with a room, received for answer that his house was<br><br>full--not a bed unoccupied.  "But avast," he added, tapping his<br><br>forehead, "you haint no objections to sharing a harpooneer's blanket,<br><br>have ye?  I s'pose you are goin' a-whalin', so you'd better get used<br><br>to that sort of thing."<br><br><br><br>I told him that I never liked to sleep two in a bed; that if I should<br><br>ever do so, it would depend upon who the harpooneer might be, and<br><br>that if he (the landlord) really had no other place for me, and the<br><br>harpooneer was not decidedly objectionable, why rather than wander<br><br>further about a strange town on so bitter a night, I would put up<br><br>with the half of any decent man's blanket.<br><br><br><br>"I thought so.  All right; take a seat.  Supper?--you want supper?<br><br>Supper'll be ready directly."<br><br><br><br>I sat down on an old wooden settle, carved all over like a bench on<br><br>the Battery.  At one end a ruminating tar was still further adorning<br><br>it with his jack-knife, stooping over and diligently working away at<br><br>the space between his legs.  He was trying his hand at a ship under<br><br>full sail, but he didn't make much headway, I thought.<br><br><br><br>At last some four or five of us were summoned to our meal in an<br><br>adjoining room.  It was cold as Iceland--no fire at all--the landlord<br><br>said he couldn't afford it.  Nothing but two dismal tallow candles,<br><br>each in a winding sheet.  We were fain to button up our monkey<br><br>jackets, and hold to our lips cups of scalding tea with our half<br><br>frozen fingers.  But the fare was of the most substantial kind--not<br><br>only meat and potatoes, but dumplings; good heavens! dumplings for<br><br>supper!  One young fellow in a green box coat, addressed himself to<br><br>these dumplings in a most direful manner.<br><br><br><br>"My boy," said the landlord, "you'll have the nightmare to a dead<br><br>sartainty."<br><br><br><br>"Landlord," I whispered, "that aint the harpooneer is it?"<br><br><br><br>"Oh, no," said he, looking a sort of diabolically funny, "the<br><br>harpooneer is a dark complexioned chap.  He never eats dumplings, he<br><br>don't--he eats nothing but steaks, and he likes 'em rare."<br><br><br><br>"The devil he does," says I.  "Where is that harpooneer?  Is he<br><br>here?"<br><br><br><br>"He'll be here afore long," was the answer.<br><br><br><br>I could not help it, but I began to feel suspicious of this "dark<br><br>complexioned" harpooneer.  At any rate, I made up my mind that if it<br><br>so turned out that we should sleep together, he must undress and get<br><br>into bed before I did.<br><br><br><br>Supper over, the company went back to the bar-room, when, knowing not<br><br>what else to do with myself, I resolved to spend the rest of the<br><br>evening as a looker on.<br><br><br><br>Presently a rioting noise was heard without.  Starting up, the<br><br>landlord cried, "That's the Grampus's crew.  I seed her reported in<br><br>the offing this morning; a three years' voyage, and a full ship.<br><br>Hurrah, boys; now we'll have the latest news from the Feegees."<br><br><br><br>A tramping of sea boots was heard in the entry; the door was flung<br><br>open, and in rolled a wild set of mariners enough.  Enveloped in<br><br>their shaggy watch coats, and with their heads muffled in woollen<br><br>comforters, all bedarned and ragged, and their beards stiff with<br><br>icicles, they seemed an eruption of bears from Labrador.  They had<br><br>just landed from their boat, and this was the first house they<br><br>entered.  No wonder, then, that they made a straight wake for the<br><br>whale's mouth--the bar--when the wrinkled little old Jonah, there<br><br>officiating, soon poured them out brimmers all round.  One complained<br><br>of a bad cold in his head, upon which Jonah mixed him a pitch-like<br><br>potion of gin and molasses, which he swore was a sovereign cure for<br><br>all colds and catarrhs whatsoever, never mind of how long standing,<br><br>or whether caught off the coast of Labrador, or on the weather side<br><br>of an ice-island.<br><br><br><br>The liquor soon mounted into their heads, as it generally does even<br><br>with the arrantest topers newly landed from sea, and they began<br><br>capering about most obstreperously.<br><br><br><br>I observed, however, that one of them held somewhat aloof, and though<br><br>he seemed desirous not to spoil the hilarity of his shipmates by his<br><br>own sober face, yet upon the whole he refrained from making as much<br><br>noise as the rest.  This man interested me at once; and since the<br><br>sea-gods had ordained that he should soon become my shipmate (though<br><br>but a sleeping-partner one, so far as this narrative is concerned),<br><br>I will here venture upon a little description of him.  He stood full<br><br>six feet in height, with noble shoulders, and a chest like a<br><br>coffer-dam.  I have seldom seen such brawn in a man.  His face was<br><br>deeply brown and burnt, making his white teeth dazzling by the<br><br>contrast; while in the deep shadows of his eyes floated some<br><br>reminiscences that did not seem to give him much joy.  His voice at<br><br>once announced that he was a Southerner, and from his fine stature, I<br><br>thought he must be one of those tall mountaineers from the<br><br>Alleghanian Ridge in Virginia.  When the revelry of his companions<br><br>had mounted to its height, this man slipped away unobserved, and I<br><br>saw no more of him till he became my comrade on the sea.  In a few<br><br>minutes, however, he was missed by his shipmates, and being, it<br><br>seems, for some reason a huge favourite with them, they raised a cry<br><br>of "Bulkington!  Bulkington! where's Bulkington?" and darted out of<br><br>the house in pursuit of him.<br><br><br><br>It was now about nine o'clock, and the room seeming almost<br><br>supernaturally quiet after these orgies, I began to congratulate<br><br>myself upon a little plan that had occurred to me just previous to<br><br>the entrance of the seamen.<br><br><br><br>No man prefers to sleep two in a bed.  In fact, you would a good deal<br><br>rather not sleep with your own brother.  I don't know how it is, but<br><br>people like to be private when they are sleeping.  And when it comes<br><br>to sleeping with an unknown stranger, in a strange inn, in a strange<br><br>town, and that stranger a harpooneer, then your objections<br><br>indefinitely multiply.  Nor was there any earthly reason why I as a<br><br>sailor should sleep two in a bed, more than anybody else; for sailors<br><br>no more sleep two in a bed at sea, than bachelor Kings do ashore.  To<br><br>be sure they all sleep together in one apartment, but you have your<br><br>own hammock, and cover yourself with your own blanket, and sleep in<br><br>your own skin.<br><br><br><br>The more I pondered over this harpooneer, the more I abominated the<br><br>thought of sleeping with him.  It was fair to presume that being a<br><br>harpooneer, his linen or woollen, as the case might be, would not be<br><br>of the tidiest, certainly none of the finest.  I began to twitch all<br><br>over.  Besides, it was getting late, and my decent harpooneer ought<br><br>to be home and going bedwards.  Suppose now, he should tumble in upon<br><br>me at midnight--how could I tell from what vile hole he had been<br><br>coming?<br><br><br><br>"Landlord!  I've changed my mind about that harpooneer.--I shan't<br><br>sleep with him.  I'll try the bench here."<br><br><br><br>"Just as you please; I'm sorry I cant spare ye a tablecloth for a<br><br>mattress, and it's a plaguy rough board here"--feeling of the knots<br><br>and notches.  "But wait a bit, Skrimshander; I've got a carpenter's<br><br>plane there in the bar--wait, I say, and I'll make ye snug enough."<br><br>So saying he procured the plane; and with his old silk handkerchief<br><br>first dusting the bench, vigorously set to planing away at my bed,<br><br>the while grinning like an ape.  The shavings flew right and left;<br><br>till at last the plane-iron came bump against an indestructible knot.<br><br>The landlord was near spraining his wrist, and I told him for<br><br>heaven's sake to quit--the bed was soft enough to suit me, and I did<br><br>not know how all the planing in the world could make eider down of a<br><br>pine plank.  So gathering up the shavings with another grin, and<br><br>throwing them into the great stove in the middle of the room, he went<br><br>about his business, and left me in a brown study.<br><br><br><br>I now took the measure of the bench, and found that it was a foot too<br><br>short; but that could be mended with a chair.  But it was a foot too<br><br>narrow, and the other bench in the room was about four inches higher<br><br>than the planed one--so there was no yoking them.  I then placed the<br><br>first bench lengthwise along the only clear space against the wall,<br><br>leaving a little interval between, for my back to settle down in.<br><br>But I soon found that there came such a draught of cold air over me<br><br>from under the sill of the window, that this plan would never do at<br><br>all, especially as another current from the rickety door met the one<br><br>from the window, and both together formed a series of small<br><br>whirlwinds in the immediate vicinity of the spot where I had thought<br><br>to spend the night.<br><br><br><br>The devil fetch that harpooneer, thought I, but stop, couldn't I<br><br>steal a march on him--bolt his door inside, and jump into his bed,<br><br>not to be wakened by the most violent knockings?  It seemed no bad<br><br>idea; but upon second thoughts I dismissed it.  For who could tell<br><br>but what the next morning, so soon as I popped out of the room, the<br><br>harpooneer might be standing in the entry, all ready to knock me<br><br>down!<br><br><br><br>Still, looking round me again, and seeing no possible chance of<br><br>spending a sufferable night unless in some other person's bed, I<br><br>began to think that after all I might be cherishing unwarrantable<br><br>prejudices against this unknown harpooneer.  Thinks I, I'll wait<br><br>awhile; he must be dropping in before long.  I'll have a good look at<br><br>him then, and perhaps we may become jolly good bedfellows after<br><br>all--there's no telling.<br><br><br><br>But though the other boarders kept coming in by ones, twos, and<br><br>threes, and going to bed, yet no sign of my harpooneer.<br><br><br><br>"Landlord! said I, "what sort of a chap is he--does he always keep<br><br>such late hours?"  It was now hard upon twelve o'clock.<br><br><br><br>The landlord chuckled again with his lean chuckle, and seemed to be<br><br>mightily tickled at something beyond my comprehension.  "No," he<br><br>answered, "generally he's an early bird--airley to bed and airley to<br><br>rise--yes, he's the bird what catches the worm.  But to-night he<br><br>went out a peddling, you see, and I don't see what on airth keeps him<br><br>so late, unless, may be, he can't sell his head."<br><br><br><br>"Can't sell his head?--What sort of a bamboozingly story is this you<br><br>are telling me?" getting into a towering rage.  "Do you pretend to<br><br>say, landlord, that this harpooneer is actually engaged this blessed<br><br>Saturday night, or rather Sunday morning, in peddling his head around<br><br>this town?"<br><br><br><br>"That's precisely it," said the landlord, "and I told him he couldn't<br><br>sell it here, the market's overstocked."<br><br><br><br>"With what?" shouted I.<br><br><br><br>"With heads to be sure; ain't there too many heads in the world?"<br><br><br><br>"I tell you what it is, landlord," said I quite calmly, "you'd better<br><br>stop spinning that yarn to me--I'm not green."<br><br><br><br>"May be not," taking out a stick and whittling a toothpick, "but I<br><br>rayther guess you'll be done BROWN if that ere harpooneer hears you a<br><br>slanderin' his head."<br><br><br><br>"I'll break it for him," said I, now flying into a passion again at<br><br>this unaccountable farrago of the landlord's.<br><br><br><br>"It's broke a'ready," said he.<br><br><br><br>"Broke," said I--"BROKE, do you mean?"<br><br><br><br>"Sartain, and that's the very reason he can't sell it, I guess."<br><br><br><br>"Landlord," said I, going up to him as cool as Mt. Hecla in a<br><br>snow-storm--"landlord, stop whittling.  You and I must understand one<br><br>another, and that too without delay.  I come to your house and want a<br><br>bed; you tell me you can only give me half a one; that the other half<br><br>belongs to a certain harpooneer.  And about this harpooneer, whom I<br><br>have not yet seen, you persist in telling me the most mystifying and<br><br>exasperating stories tending to beget in me an uncomfortable feeling<br><br>towards the man whom you design for my bedfellow--a sort of<br><br>connexion, landlord, which is an intimate and confidential one in the<br><br>highest degree.  I now demand of you to speak out and tell me who and<br><br>what this harpooneer is, and whether I shall be in all respects safe<br><br>to spend the night with him.  And in the first place, you will be so<br><br>good as to unsay that story about selling his head, which if true I<br><br>take to be good evidence that this harpooneer is stark mad, and I've<br><br>no idea of sleeping with a madman; and you, sir, YOU I mean,<br><br>landlord, YOU, sir, by trying to induce me to do so knowingly, would<br><br>thereby render yourself liable to a criminal prosecution."<br><br><br><br>"Wall," said the landlord, fetching a long breath, "that's a purty<br><br>long sarmon for a chap that rips a little now and then.  But be easy,<br><br>be easy, this here harpooneer I have been tellin' you of has just<br><br>arrived from the south seas, where he bought up a lot of 'balmed New<br><br>Zealand heads (great curios, you know), and he's sold all on 'em but<br><br>one, and that one he's trying to sell to-night, cause to-morrow's<br><br>Sunday, and it would not do to be sellin' human heads about the<br><br>streets when folks is goin' to churches.  He wanted to, last Sunday,<br><br>but I stopped him just as he was goin' out of the door with four<br><br>heads strung on a string, for all the airth like a string of inions."<br><br><br><br>This account cleared up the otherwise unaccountable mystery, and<br><br>showed that the landlord, after all, had had no idea of fooling<br><br>me--but at the same time what could I think of a harpooneer who<br><br>stayed out of a Saturday night clean into the holy Sabbath, engaged<br><br>in such a cannibal business as selling the heads of dead idolators?<br><br><br><br>"Depend upon it, landlord, that harpooneer is a dangerous man."<br><br><br><br>"He pays reg'lar," was the rejoinder.  "But come, it's getting<br><br>dreadful late, you had better be turning flukes--it's a nice bed;<br><br>Sal and me slept in that ere bed the night we were spliced.  There's<br><br>plenty of room for two to kick about in that bed; it's an almighty<br><br>big bed that.  Why, afore we give it up, Sal used to put our Sam and<br><br>little Johnny in the foot of it.  But I got a dreaming and sprawling<br><br>about one night, and somehow, Sam got pitched on the floor, and came<br><br>near breaking his arm.  Arter that, Sal said it wouldn't do.  Come<br><br>along here, I'll give ye a glim in a jiffy;" and so saying he lighted<br><br>a candle and held it towards me, offering to lead the way.  But I<br><br>stood irresolute; when looking at a clock in the corner, he exclaimed<br><br>"I vum it's Sunday--you won't see that harpooneer to-night; he's come<br><br>to anchor somewhere--come along then; DO come; WON'T ye come?"<br><br><br><br>I considered the matter a moment, and then up stairs we went, and I<br><br>was ushered into a small room, cold as a clam, and furnished, sure<br><br>enough, with a prodigious bed, almost big enough indeed for any four<br><br>harpooneers to sleep abreast.<br><br><br><br>"There," said the landlord, placing the candle on a crazy old sea<br><br>chest that did double duty as a wash-stand and centre table; "there,<br><br>make yourself comfortable now, and good night to ye."  I turned<br><br>round from eyeing the bed, but he had disappeared.<br><br><br><br>Folding back the counterpane, I stooped over the bed.  Though none of<br><br>the most elegant, it yet stood the scrutiny tolerably well.  I then<br><br>glanced round the room; and besides the bedstead and centre table,<br><br>could see no other furniture belonging to the place, but a rude<br><br>shelf, the four walls, and a papered fireboard representing a man<br><br>striking a whale.  Of things not properly belonging to the room,<br><br>there was a hammock lashed up, and thrown upon the floor in one<br><br>corner; also a large seaman's bag, containing the harpooneer's<br><br>wardrobe, no doubt in lieu of a land trunk.  Likewise, there was a<br><br>parcel of outlandish bone fish hooks on the shelf over the<br><br>fire-place, and a tall harpoon standing at the head of the bed.<br><br><br><br>But what is this on the chest?  I took it up, and held it close to<br><br>the light, and felt it, and smelt it, and tried every way possible to<br><br>arrive at some satisfactory conclusion concerning it.  I can compare<br><br>it to nothing but a large door mat, ornamented at the edges with<br><br>little tinkling tags something like the stained porcupine quills<br><br>round an Indian moccasin.  There was a hole or slit in the middle of<br><br>this mat, as you see the same in South American ponchos.  But could<br><br>it be possible that any sober harpooneer would get into a door mat,<br><br>and parade the streets of any Christian town in that sort of guise?<br><br>I put it on, to try it, and it weighed me down like a hamper, being<br><br>uncommonly shaggy and thick, and I thought a little damp, as though<br><br>this mysterious harpooneer had been wearing it of a rainy day.  I<br><br>went up in it to a bit of glass stuck against the wall, and I never<br><br>saw such a sight in my life.  I tore myself out of it in such a hurry<br><br>that I gave myself a kink in the neck.<br><br><br><br>I sat down on the side of the bed, and commenced thinking about this<br><br>head-peddling harpooneer, and his door mat.  After thinking some time<br><br>on the bed-side, I got up and took off my monkey jacket, and then<br><br>stood in the middle of the room thinking.  I then took off my coat,<br><br>and thought a little more in my shirt sleeves.  But beginning to feel<br><br>very cold now, half undressed as I was, and remembering what the<br><br>landlord said about the harpooneer's not coming home at all that<br><br>night, it being so very late, I made no more ado, but jumped out of<br><br>my pantaloons and boots, and then blowing out the light tumbled into<br><br>bed, and commended myself to the care of heaven.<br><br><br><br>Whether that mattress was stuffed with corn-cobs or broken crockery,<br><br>there is no telling, but I rolled about a good deal, and could not<br><br>sleep for a long time.  At last I slid off into a light doze, and had<br><br>pretty nearly made a good offing towards the land of Nod, when I<br><br>heard a heavy footfall in the passage, and saw a glimmer of light<br><br>come into the room from under the door.<br><br><br><br>Lord save me, thinks I, that must be the harpooneer, the infernal<br><br>head-peddler.  But I lay perfectly still, and resolved not to say a<br><br>word till spoken to.  Holding a light in one hand, and that identical<br><br>New Zealand head in the other, the stranger entered the room, and<br><br>without looking towards the bed, placed his candle a good way off<br><br>from me on the floor in one corner, and then began working away at<br><br>the knotted cords of the large bag I before spoke of as being in the<br><br>room.  I was all eagerness to see his face, but he kept it averted<br><br>for some time while employed in unlacing the bag's mouth.  This<br><br>accomplished, however, he turned round--when, good heavens! what a<br><br>sight!  Such a face!  It was of a dark, purplish, yellow colour, here<br><br>and there stuck over with large blackish looking squares.  Yes, it's<br><br>just as I thought, he's a terrible bedfellow; he's been in a fight,<br><br>got dreadfully cut, and here he is, just from the surgeon.  But at<br><br>that moment he chanced to turn his face so towards the light, that I<br><br>plainly saw they could not be sticking-plasters at all, those black<br><br>squares on his cheeks.  They were stains of some sort or other.  At<br><br>first I knew not what to make of this; but soon an inkling of the<br><br>truth occurred to me.  I remembered a story of a white man--a<br><br>whaleman too--who, falling among the cannibals, had been tattooed by<br><br>them.  I concluded that this harpooneer, in the course of his distant<br><br>voyages, must have met with a similar adventure.  And what is it,<br><br>thought I, after all!  It's only his outside; a man can be honest in<br><br>any sort of skin.  But then, what to make of his unearthly<br><br>complexion, that part of it, I mean, lying round about, and<br><br>completely independent of the squares of tattooing.  To be sure, it<br><br>might be nothing but a good coat of tropical tanning; but I never<br><br>heard of a hot sun's tanning a white man into a purplish yellow one.<br><br>However, I had never been in the South Seas; and perhaps the sun<br><br>there produced these extraordinary effects upon the skin.  Now, while<br><br>all these ideas were passing through me like lightning, this<br><br>harpooneer never noticed me at all.  But, after some difficulty<br><br>having opened his bag, he commenced fumbling in it, and presently<br><br>pulled out a sort of tomahawk, and a seal-skin wallet with the hair<br><br>on.  Placing these on the old chest in the middle of the room, he<br><br>then took the New Zealand head--a ghastly thing enough--and crammed<br><br>it down into the bag.  He now took off his hat--a new beaver<br><br>hat--when I came nigh singing out with fresh surprise.  There was no<br><br>hair on his head--none to speak of at least--nothing but a small<br><br>scalp-knot twisted up on his forehead.  His bald purplish head now<br><br>looked for all the world like a mildewed skull.  Had not the stranger<br><br>stood between me and the door, I would have bolted out of it quicker<br><br>than ever I bolted a dinner.<br><br><br><br>Even as it was, I thought something of slipping out of the window,<br><br>but it was the second floor back.  I am no coward, but what to make<br><br>of this head-peddling purple rascal altogether passed my<br><br>comprehension.  Ignorance is the parent of fear, and being completely<br><br>nonplussed and confounded about the stranger, I confess I was now as<br><br>much afraid of him as if it was the devil himself who had thus broken<br><br>into my room at the dead of night.  In fact, I was so afraid of him<br><br>that I was not game enough just then to address him, and demand a<br><br>satisfactory answer concerning what seemed inexplicable in him.<br><br><br><br>Meanwhile, he continued the business of undressing, and at last<br><br>showed his chest and arms.  As I live, these covered parts of him<br><br>were checkered with the same squares as his face; his back, too, was<br><br>all over the same dark squares; he seemed to have been in a Thirty<br><br>Years' War, and just escaped from it with a sticking-plaster shirt.<br><br>Still more, his very legs were marked, as if a parcel of dark green<br><br>frogs were running up the trunks of young palms.  It was now quite<br><br>plain that he must be some abominable savage or other shipped aboard<br><br>of a whaleman in the South Seas, and so landed in this Christian<br><br>country.  I quaked to think of it.  A peddler of heads too--perhaps<br><br>the heads of his own brothers.  He might take a fancy to<br><br>mine--heavens! look at that tomahawk!<br><br><br><br>But there was no time for shuddering, for now the savage went about<br><br>something that completely fascinated my attention, and convinced me<br><br>that he must indeed be a heathen.  Going to his heavy grego, or<br><br>wrapall, or dreadnaught, which he had previously hung on a chair, he<br><br>fumbled in the pockets, and produced at length a curious little<br><br>deformed image with a hunch on its back, and exactly the colour of a<br><br>three days' old Congo baby.  Remembering the embalmed head, at first<br><br>I almost thought that this black manikin was a real baby preserved<br><br>in some similar manner.  But seeing that it was not at all limber,<br><br>and that it glistened a good deal like polished ebony, I concluded<br><br>that it must be nothing but a wooden idol, which indeed it proved to<br><br>be.  For now the savage goes up to the empty fire-place, and removing<br><br>the papered fire-board, sets up this little hunch-backed image, like<br><br>a tenpin, between the andirons.  The chimney jambs and all the bricks<br><br>inside were very sooty, so that I thought this fire-place made a very<br><br>appropriate little shrine or chapel for his Congo idol.<br><br><br><br>I now screwed my eyes hard towards the half hidden image, feeling but<br><br>ill at ease meantime--to see what was next to follow.  First he takes<br><br>about a double handful of shavings out of his grego pocket, and<br><br>places them carefully before the idol; then laying a bit of ship<br><br>biscuit on top and applying the flame from the lamp, he kindled the<br><br>shavings into a sacrificial blaze.  Presently, after many hasty<br><br>snatches into the fire, and still hastier withdrawals of his fingers<br><br>(whereby he seemed to be scorching them badly), he at last succeeded<br><br>in drawing out the biscuit; then blowing off the heat and ashes a<br><br>little, he made a polite offer of it to the little negro.  But the<br><br>little devil did not seem to fancy such dry sort of fare at all; he<br><br>never moved his lips.  All these strange antics were accompanied by<br><br>still stranger guttural noises from the devotee, who seemed to be<br><br>praying in a sing-song or else singing some pagan psalmody or other,<br><br>during which his face twitched about in the most unnatural manner.<br><br>At last extinguishing the fire, he took the idol up very<br><br>unceremoniously, and bagged it again in his grego pocket as<br><br>carelessly as if he were a sportsman bagging a dead woodcock.<br><br><br><br>All these queer proceedings increased my uncomfortableness, and<br><br>seeing him now exhibiting strong symptoms of concluding his business<br><br>operations, and jumping into bed with me, I thought it was high time,<br><br>now or never, before the light was put out, to break the spell in<br><br>which I had so long been bound.<br><br><br><br>But the interval I spent in deliberating what to say, was a fatal<br><br>one.  Taking up his tomahawk from the table, he examined the head of<br><br>it for an instant, and then holding it to the light, with his mouth<br><br>at the handle, he puffed out great clouds of tobacco smoke.  The next<br><br>moment the light was extinguished, and this wild cannibal, tomahawk<br><br>between his teeth, sprang into bed with me.  I sang out, I could not<br><br>help it now; and giving a sudden grunt of astonishment he began<br><br>feeling me.<br><br><br><br>Stammering out something, I knew not what, I rolled away from him<br><br>against the wall, and then conjured him, whoever or whatever he might<br><br>be, to keep quiet, and let me get up and light the lamp again.  But<br><br>his guttural responses satisfied me at once that he but ill<br><br>comprehended my meaning.<br><br><br><br>"Who-e debel you?"--he at last said--"you no speak-e, dam-me, I<br><br>kill-e."  And so saying the lighted tomahawk began flourishing about<br><br>me in the dark.<br><br><br><br>"Landlord, for God's sake, Peter Coffin!" shouted I.  "Landlord!<br><br>Watch!  Coffin!  Angels! save me!"<br><br><br><br>"Speak-e! tell-ee me who-ee be, or dam-me, I kill-e!" again growled<br><br>the cannibal, while his horrid flourishings of the tomahawk scattered<br><br>the hot tobacco ashes about me till I thought my linen would get on<br><br>fire.  But thank heaven, at that moment the landlord came into the<br><br>room light in hand, and leaping from the bed I ran up to him.<br><br><br><br>"Don't be afraid now," said he, grinning again, "Queequeg here<br><br>wouldn't harm a hair of your head."<br><br><br><br>"Stop your grinning," shouted I, "and why didn't you tell me that<br><br>that infernal harpooneer was a cannibal?"<br><br><br><br>"I thought ye know'd it;--didn't I tell ye, he was a peddlin' heads<br><br>around town?--but turn flukes again and go to sleep.  Queequeg, look<br><br>here--you sabbee me, I sabbee--you this man sleepe you--you sabbee?"<br><br><br><br>"Me sabbee plenty"--grunted Queequeg, puffing away at his pipe and<br><br>sitting up in bed.<br><br><br><br>"You gettee in," he added, motioning to me with his tomahawk, and<br><br>throwing the clothes to one side.  He really did this in not only a<br><br>civil but a really kind and charitable way.  I stood looking at him a<br><br>moment.  For all his tattooings he was on the whole a clean, comely<br><br>looking cannibal.  What's all this fuss I have been making about,<br><br>thought I to myself--the man's a human being just as I am: he has<br><br>just as much reason to fear me, as I have to be afraid of him.<br><br>Better sleep with a sober cannibal than a drunken Christian.<br><br><br><br>"Landlord," said I, "tell him to stash his tomahawk there, or pipe,<br><br>or whatever you call it; tell him to stop smoking, in short, and I<br><br>will turn in with him.  But I don't fancy having a man smoking in bed<br><br>with me.  It's dangerous.  Besides, I ain't insured."<br><br><br><br>This being told to Queequeg, he at once complied, and again politely<br><br>motioned me to get into bed--rolling over to one side as much as to<br><br>say--I won't touch a leg of ye."<br><br><br><br>"Good night, landlord," said I, "you may go."<br><br><br><br>I turned in, and never slept better in my life.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 4<br><br><br><br>The Counterpane.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Upon waking next morning about daylight, I found Queequeg's arm<br><br>thrown over me in the most loving and affectionate manner.  You had<br><br>almost thought I had been his wife.  The counterpane was of<br><br>patchwork, full of odd little parti-coloured squares and triangles;<br><br>and this arm of his tattooed all over with an interminable Cretan<br><br>labyrinth of a figure, no two parts of which were of one precise<br><br>shade--owing I suppose to his keeping his arm at sea unmethodically<br><br>in sun and shade, his shirt sleeves irregularly rolled up at various<br><br>times--this same arm of his, I say, looked for all the world like a<br><br>strip of that same patchwork quilt.  Indeed, partly lying on it as<br><br>the arm did when I first awoke, I could hardly tell it from the<br><br>quilt, they so blended their hues together; and it was only by the<br><br>sense of weight and pressure that I could tell that Queequeg was<br><br>hugging me.<br><br><br><br>My sensations were strange.  Let me try to explain them.  When I was<br><br>a child, I well remember a somewhat similar circumstance that befell<br><br>me; whether it was a reality or a dream, I never could entirely<br><br>settle.  The circumstance was this.  I had been cutting up some caper<br><br>or other--I think it was trying to crawl up the chimney, as I had<br><br>seen a little sweep do a few days previous; and my stepmother who,<br><br>somehow or other, was all the time whipping me, or sending me to bed<br><br>supperless,--my mother dragged me by the legs out of the chimney and<br><br>packed me off to bed, though it was only two o'clock in the afternoon<br><br>of the 21st June, the longest day in the year in our hemisphere.  I<br><br>felt dreadfully.  But there was no help for it, so up stairs I went<br><br>to my little room in the third floor, undressed myself as slowly as<br><br>possible so as to kill time, and with a bitter sigh got between the<br><br>sheets.<br><br><br><br>I lay there dismally calculating that sixteen entire hours must<br><br>elapse before I could hope for a resurrection.  Sixteen hours in bed!<br><br>the small of my back ached to think of it.  And it was so light too;<br><br>the sun shining in at the window, and a great rattling of coaches in<br><br>the streets, and the sound of gay voices all over the house.  I felt<br><br>worse and worse--at last I got up, dressed, and softly going down in<br><br>my stockinged feet, sought out my stepmother, and suddenly threw<br><br>myself at her feet, beseeching her as a particular favour to give me a<br><br>good slippering for my misbehaviour; anything indeed but condemning<br><br>me to lie abed such an unendurable length of time.  But she was the<br><br>best and most conscientious of stepmothers, and back I had to go to<br><br>my room.  For several hours I lay there broad awake, feeling a great<br><br>deal worse than I have ever done since, even from the greatest<br><br>subsequent misfortunes.  At last I must have fallen into a troubled<br><br>nightmare of a doze; and slowly waking from it--half steeped in<br><br>dreams--I opened my eyes, and the before sun-lit room was now wrapped<br><br>in outer darkness.  Instantly I felt a shock running through all my<br><br>frame; nothing was to be seen, and nothing was to be heard; but a<br><br>supernatural hand seemed placed in mine.  My arm hung over the<br><br>counterpane, and the nameless, unimaginable, silent form or phantom,<br><br>to which the hand belonged, seemed closely seated by my bed-side.<br><br>For what seemed ages piled on ages, I lay there, frozen with the most<br><br>awful fears, not daring to drag away my hand; yet ever thinking that<br><br>if I could but stir it one single inch, the horrid spell would be<br><br>broken.  I knew not how this consciousness at last glided away from<br><br>me; but waking in the morning, I shudderingly remembered it all, and<br><br>for days and weeks and months afterwards I lost myself in confounding<br><br>attempts to explain the mystery.  Nay, to this very hour, I often<br><br>puzzle myself with it.<br><br><br><br>Now, take away the awful fear, and my sensations at feeling the<br><br>supernatural hand in mine were very similar, in their strangeness,<br><br>to those which I experienced on waking up and seeing Queequeg's pagan<br><br>arm thrown round me.  But at length all the past night's events<br><br>soberly recurred, one by one, in fixed reality, and then I lay only<br><br>alive to the comical predicament.  For though I tried to move his<br><br>arm--unlock his bridegroom clasp--yet, sleeping as he was, he still<br><br>hugged me tightly, as though naught but death should part us twain.<br><br>I now strove to rouse him--"Queequeg!"--but his only answer was a<br><br>snore.  I then rolled over, my neck feeling as if it were in a<br><br>horse-collar; and suddenly felt a slight scratch.  Throwing aside the<br><br>counterpane, there lay the tomahawk sleeping by the savage's side, as<br><br>if it were a hatchet-faced baby.  A pretty pickle, truly, thought I;<br><br>abed here in a strange house in the broad day, with a cannibal and a<br><br>tomahawk!  "Queequeg!--in the name of goodness, Queequeg, wake!"  At<br><br>length, by dint of much wriggling, and loud and incessant<br><br>expostulations upon the unbecomingness of his hugging a fellow male<br><br>in that matrimonial sort of style, I succeeded in extracting a grunt;<br><br>and presently, he drew back his arm, shook himself all over like a<br><br>Newfoundland dog just from the water, and sat up in bed, stiff as a<br><br>pike-staff, looking at me, and rubbing his eyes as if he did not<br><br>altogether remember how I came to be there, though a dim<br><br>consciousness of knowing something about me seemed slowly dawning<br><br>over him.  Meanwhile, I lay quietly eyeing him, having no serious<br><br>misgivings now, and bent upon narrowly observing so curious a<br><br>creature.  When, at last, his mind seemed made up touching the<br><br>character of his bedfellow, and he became, as it were, reconciled to<br><br>the fact; he jumped out upon the floor, and by certain signs and<br><br>sounds gave me to understand that, if it pleased me, he would dress<br><br>first and then leave me to dress afterwards, leaving the whole<br><br>apartment to myself.  Thinks I, Queequeg, under the circumstances,<br><br>this is a very civilized overture; but, the truth is, these savages<br><br>have an innate sense of delicacy, say what you will; it is marvellous<br><br>how essentially polite they are.  I pay this particular compliment to<br><br>Queequeg, because he treated me with so much civility and<br><br>consideration, while I was guilty of great rudeness; staring at him<br><br>from the bed, and watching all his toilette motions; for the time my<br><br>curiosity getting the better of my breeding.  Nevertheless, a man<br><br>like Queequeg you don't see every day, he and his ways were well<br><br>worth unusual regarding.<br><br><br><br>He commenced dressing at top by donning his beaver hat, a very tall<br><br>one, by the by, and then--still minus his trowsers--he hunted up his<br><br>boots.  What under the heavens he did it for, I cannot tell, but his<br><br>next movement was to crush himself--boots in hand, and hat on--under<br><br>the bed; when, from sundry violent gaspings and strainings, I<br><br>inferred he was hard at work booting himself; though by no law of<br><br>propriety that I ever heard of, is any man required to be private<br><br>when putting on his boots.  But Queequeg, do you see, was a creature<br><br>in the transition stage--neither caterpillar nor butterfly.  He was<br><br>just enough civilized to show off his outlandishness in the strangest<br><br>possible manners.  His education was not yet completed.  He was an<br><br>undergraduate.  If he had not been a small degree civilized, he very<br><br>probably would not have troubled himself with boots at all; but then,<br><br>if he had not been still a savage, he never would have dreamt of<br><br>getting under the bed to put them on.  At last, he emerged with his<br><br>hat very much dented and crushed down over his eyes, and began<br><br>creaking and limping about the room, as if, not being much accustomed<br><br>to boots, his pair of damp, wrinkled cowhide ones--probably not made<br><br>to order either--rather pinched and tormented him at the first go off<br><br>of a bitter cold morning.<br><br><br><br>Seeing, now, that there were no curtains to the window, and that the<br><br>street being very narrow, the house opposite commanded a plain view<br><br>into the room, and observing more and more the indecorous figure that<br><br>Queequeg made, staving about with little else but his hat and boots<br><br>on; I begged him as well as I could, to accelerate his toilet<br><br>somewhat, and particularly to get into his pantaloons as soon as<br><br>possible.  He complied, and then proceeded to wash himself.  At that<br><br>time in the morning any Christian would have washed his face; but<br><br>Queequeg, to my amazement, contented himself with restricting his<br><br>ablutions to his chest, arms, and hands.  He then donned his<br><br>waistcoat, and taking up a piece of hard soap on the wash-stand<br><br>centre table, dipped it into water and commenced lathering his face.<br><br>I was watching to see where he kept his razor, when lo and behold, he<br><br>takes the harpoon from the bed corner, slips out the long wooden<br><br>stock, unsheathes the head, whets it a little on his boot, and<br><br>striding up to the bit of mirror against the wall, begins a vigorous<br><br>scraping, or rather harpooning of his cheeks.  Thinks I, Queequeg,<br><br>this is using Rogers's best cutlery with a vengeance.  Afterwards I<br><br>wondered the less at this operation when I came to know of what fine<br><br>steel the head of a harpoon is made, and how exceedingly sharp the<br><br>long straight edges are always kept.<br><br><br><br>The rest of his toilet was soon achieved, and he proudly marched out<br><br>of the room, wrapped up in his great pilot monkey jacket, and<br><br>sporting his harpoon like a marshal's baton.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 5<br><br><br><br>Breakfast.<br><br><br><br><br><br>I quickly followed suit, and descending into the bar-room accosted<br><br>the grinning landlord very pleasantly.  I cherished no malice towards<br><br>him, though he had been skylarking with me not a little in the matter<br><br>of my bedfellow.<br><br><br><br>However, a good laugh is a mighty good thing, and rather too scarce a<br><br>good thing; the more's the pity.  So, if any one man, in his own<br><br>proper person, afford stuff for a good joke to anybody, let him not<br><br>be backward, but let him cheerfully allow himself to spend and be<br><br>spent in that way.  And the man that has anything bountifully<br><br>laughable about him, be sure there is more in that man than you<br><br>perhaps think for.<br><br><br><br>The bar-room was now full of the boarders who had been dropping in<br><br>the night previous, and whom I had not as yet had a good look at.<br><br>They were nearly all whalemen; chief mates, and second mates, and<br><br>third mates, and sea carpenters, and sea coopers, and sea<br><br>blacksmiths, and harpooneers, and ship keepers; a brown and brawny<br><br>company, with bosky beards; an unshorn, shaggy set, all wearing<br><br>monkey jackets for morning gowns.<br><br><br><br>You could pretty plainly tell how long each one had been ashore.<br><br>This young fellow's healthy cheek is like a sun-toasted pear in hue,<br><br>and would seem to smell almost as musky; he cannot have been three<br><br>days landed from his Indian voyage.  That man next him looks a few<br><br>shades lighter; you might say a touch of satin wood is in him.  In<br><br>the complexion of a third still lingers a tropic tawn, but slightly<br><br>bleached withal; HE doubtless has tarried whole weeks ashore.  But<br><br>who could show a cheek like Queequeg? which, barred with various<br><br>tints, seemed like the Andes' western slope, to show forth in one<br><br>array, contrasting climates, zone by zone.<br><br><br><br>"Grub, ho!" now cried the landlord, flinging open a door, and in we<br><br>went to breakfast.<br><br><br><br>They say that men who have seen the world, thereby become quite at<br><br>ease in manner, quite self-possessed in company.  Not always, though:<br><br>Ledyard, the great New England traveller, and Mungo Park, the Scotch<br><br>one; of all men, they possessed the least assurance in the parlor.<br><br>But perhaps the mere crossing of Siberia in a sledge drawn by dogs as<br><br>Ledyard did, or the taking a long solitary walk on an empty stomach,<br><br>in the negro heart of Africa, which was the sum of poor Mungo's<br><br>performances--this kind of travel, I say, may not be the very best<br><br>mode of attaining a high social polish.  Still, for the most part,<br><br>that sort of thing is to be had anywhere.<br><br><br><br>These reflections just here are occasioned by the circumstance that<br><br>after we were all seated at the table, and I was preparing to hear<br><br>some good stories about whaling; to my no small surprise, nearly<br><br>every man maintained a profound silence.  And not only that, but they<br><br>looked embarrassed.  Yes, here were a set of sea-dogs, many of whom<br><br>without the slightest bashfulness had boarded great whales on the<br><br>high seas--entire strangers to them--and duelled them dead without<br><br>winking; and yet, here they sat at a social breakfast table--all of<br><br>the same calling, all of kindred tastes--looking round as sheepishly<br><br>at each other as though they had never been out of sight of some<br><br>sheepfold among the Green Mountains.  A curious sight; these bashful<br><br>bears, these timid warrior whalemen!<br><br><br><br>But as for Queequeg--why, Queequeg sat there among them--at the head<br><br>of the table, too, it so chanced; as cool as an icicle.  To be sure I<br><br>cannot say much for his breeding.  His greatest admirer could not<br><br>have cordially justified his bringing his harpoon into breakfast with<br><br>him, and using it there without ceremony; reaching over the table<br><br>with it, to the imminent jeopardy of many heads, and grappling the<br><br>beefsteaks towards him.  But THAT was certainly very coolly done by<br><br>him, and every one knows that in most people's estimation, to do<br><br>anything coolly is to do it genteelly.<br><br><br><br>We will not speak of all Queequeg's peculiarities here; how he<br><br>eschewed coffee and hot rolls, and applied his undivided attention to<br><br>beefsteaks, done rare.  Enough, that when breakfast was over he<br><br>withdrew like the rest into the public room, lighted his<br><br>tomahawk-pipe, and was sitting there quietly digesting and smoking<br><br>with his inseparable hat on, when I sallied out for a stroll.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 6<br><br><br><br>The Street.<br><br><br><br><br><br>If I had been astonished at first catching a glimpse of so outlandish<br><br>an individual as Queequeg circulating among the polite society of a<br><br>civilized town, that astonishment soon departed upon taking my first<br><br>daylight stroll through the streets of New Bedford.<br><br><br><br>In thoroughfares nigh the docks, any considerable seaport will<br><br>frequently offer to view the queerest looking nondescripts from<br><br>foreign parts.  Even in Broadway and Chestnut streets, Mediterranean<br><br>mariners will sometimes jostle the affrighted ladies.  Regent Street<br><br>is not unknown to Lascars and Malays; and at Bombay, in the Apollo<br><br>Green, live Yankees have often scared the natives.  But New Bedford<br><br>beats all Water Street and Wapping.  In these last-mentioned haunts<br><br>you see only sailors; but in New Bedford, actual cannibals stand<br><br>chatting at street corners; savages outright; many of whom yet carry<br><br>on their bones unholy flesh.  It makes a stranger stare.<br><br><br><br>But, besides the Feegeeans, Tongatobooarrs, Erromanggoans,<br><br>Pannangians, and Brighggians, and, besides the wild specimens of the<br><br>whaling-craft which unheeded reel about the streets, you will see<br><br>other sights still more curious, certainly more comical.  There<br><br>weekly arrive in this town scores of green Vermonters and New<br><br>Hampshire men, all athirst for gain and glory in the fishery.  They<br><br>are mostly young, of stalwart frames; fellows who have felled<br><br>forests, and now seek to drop the axe and snatch the whale-lance.<br><br>Many are as green as the Green Mountains whence they came.  In some<br><br>things you would think them but a few hours old.  Look there! that<br><br>chap strutting round the corner.  He wears a beaver hat and<br><br>swallow-tailed coat, girdled with a sailor-belt and sheath-knife.<br><br>Here comes another with a sou'-wester and a bombazine cloak.<br><br><br><br>No town-bred dandy will compare with a country-bred one--I mean a<br><br>downright bumpkin dandy--a fellow that, in the dog-days, will mow his<br><br>two acres in buckskin gloves for fear of tanning his hands.  Now when<br><br>a country dandy like this takes it into his head to make a<br><br>distinguished reputation, and joins the great whale-fishery, you<br><br>should see the comical things he does upon reaching the seaport.  In<br><br>bespeaking his sea-outfit, he orders bell-buttons to his waistcoats;<br><br>straps to his canvas trowsers.  Ah, poor Hay-Seed! how bitterly will<br><br>burst those straps in the first howling gale, when thou art driven,<br><br>straps, buttons, and all, down the throat of the tempest.<br><br><br><br>But think not that this famous town has only harpooneers, cannibals,<br><br>and bumpkins to show her visitors.  Not at all.  Still New Bedford is<br><br>a queer place.  Had it not been for us whalemen, that tract of land<br><br>would this day perhaps have been in as howling condition as the coast<br><br>of Labrador.  As it is, parts of her back country are enough to<br><br>frighten one, they look so bony.  The town itself is perhaps the<br><br>dearest place to live in, in all New England.  It is a land of oil,<br><br>true enough: but not like Canaan; a land, also, of corn and wine.<br><br>The streets do not run with milk; nor in the spring-time do they pave<br><br>them with fresh eggs.  Yet, in spite of this, nowhere in all America<br><br>will you find more patrician-like houses; parks and gardens more<br><br>opulent, than in New Bedford.  Whence came they? how planted upon<br><br>this once scraggy scoria of a country?<br><br><br><br>Go and gaze upon the iron emblematical harpoons round yonder lofty<br><br>mansion, and your question will be answered.  Yes; all these brave<br><br>houses and flowery gardens came from the Atlantic, Pacific, and<br><br>Indian oceans.  One and all, they were harpooned and dragged up<br><br>hither from the bottom of the sea.  Can Herr Alexander perform a feat<br><br>like that?<br><br><br><br>In New Bedford, fathers, they say, give whales for dowers to their<br><br>daughters, and portion off their nieces with a few porpoises a-piece.<br><br>You must go to New Bedford to see a brilliant wedding; for, they<br><br>say, they have reservoirs of oil in every house, and every night<br><br>recklessly burn their lengths in spermaceti candles.<br><br><br><br>In summer time, the town is sweet to see; full of fine maples--long<br><br>avenues of green and gold.  And in August, high in air, the beautiful<br><br>and bountiful horse-chestnuts, candelabra-wise, proffer the passer-by<br><br>their tapering upright cones of congregated blossoms.  So omnipotent<br><br>is art; which in many a district of New Bedford has superinduced<br><br>bright terraces of flowers upon the barren refuse rocks thrown aside<br><br>at creation's final day.<br><br><br><br>And the women of New Bedford, they bloom like their own red roses.<br><br>But roses only bloom in summer; whereas the fine carnation of their<br><br>cheeks is perennial as sunlight in the seventh heavens.  Elsewhere<br><br>match that bloom of theirs, ye cannot, save in Salem, where they tell<br><br>me the young girls breathe such musk, their sailor sweethearts smell<br><br>them miles off shore, as though they were drawing nigh the odorous<br><br>Moluccas instead of the Puritanic sands.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 7<br><br><br><br>The Chapel.<br><br><br><br><br><br>In this same New Bedford there stands a Whaleman's Chapel, and few<br><br>are the moody fishermen, shortly bound for the Indian Ocean or<br><br>Pacific, who fail to make a Sunday visit to the spot.
