I am sure that<br><br>I did not.<br><br><br><br>Returning from my first morning stroll, I again sallied out upon this<br><br>special errand.  The sky had changed from clear, sunny cold, to<br><br>driving sleet and mist.  Wrapping myself in my shaggy jacket of the<br><br>cloth called bearskin, I fought my way against the stubborn storm.<br><br>Entering, I found a small scattered congregation of sailors, and<br><br>sailors' wives and widows.  A muffled silence reigned, only broken at<br><br>times by the shrieks of the storm.  Each silent worshipper seemed<br><br>purposely sitting apart from the other, as if each silent grief were<br><br>insular and incommunicable.  The chaplain had not yet arrived; and<br><br>there these silent islands of men and women sat steadfastly eyeing<br><br>several marble tablets, with black borders, masoned into the wall on<br><br>either side the pulpit.  Three of them ran something like the<br><br>following, but I do not pretend to quote:--<br><br><br><br>SACRED<br><br>TO THE MEMORY<br><br>OF<br><br>JOHN TALBOT,<br><br>Who, at the age of eighteen, was lost overboard,<br><br>Near the Isle of Desolation, off Patagonia,<br><br>November 1st, 1836.<br><br>THIS TABLET<br><br>Is erected to his Memory<br><br>BY HIS<br><br>SISTER.<br><br>_____________<br><br><br><br>SACRED<br><br>TO THE MEMORY<br><br>OF<br><br>ROBERT LONG, WILLIS ELLERY,<br><br>NATHAN COLEMAN, WALTER CANNY, SETH MACY,<br><br>AND SAMUEL GLEIG,<br><br>Forming one of the boats' crews<br><br>OF<br><br>THE SHIP ELIZA<br><br>Who were towed out of sight by a Whale,<br><br>On the Off-shore Ground in the<br><br>PACIFIC,<br><br>December 31st, 1839.<br><br>THIS MARBLE<br><br>Is here placed by their surviving<br><br>SHIPMATES.<br><br>_____________<br><br><br><br>SACRED<br><br>TO THE MEMORY<br><br>OF<br><br>The late<br><br>CAPTAIN EZEKIEL HARDY,<br><br>Who in the bows of his boat was killed by a<br><br>Sperm Whale on the coast of Japan,<br><br>AUGUST 3d, 1833.<br><br>THIS TABLET<br><br>Is erected to his Memory<br><br>BY<br><br>HIS WIDOW.<br><br><br><br>Shaking off the sleet from my ice-glazed hat and jacket, I seated<br><br>myself near the door, and turning sideways was surprised to see<br><br>Queequeg near me.  Affected by the solemnity of the scene, there was<br><br>a wondering gaze of incredulous curiosity in his countenance.  This<br><br>savage was the only person present who seemed to notice my entrance;<br><br>because he was the only one who could not read, and, therefore, was<br><br>not reading those frigid inscriptions on the wall.  Whether any of<br><br>the relatives of the seamen whose names appeared there were now among<br><br>the congregation, I knew not; but so many are the unrecorded<br><br>accidents in the fishery, and so plainly did several women present<br><br>wear the countenance if not the trappings of some unceasing grief,<br><br>that I feel sure that here before me were assembled those, in whose<br><br>unhealing hearts the sight of those bleak tablets sympathetically<br><br>caused the old wounds to bleed afresh.<br><br><br><br>Oh! ye whose dead lie buried beneath the green grass; who standing<br><br>among flowers can say--here, HERE lies my beloved; ye know not the<br><br>desolation that broods in bosoms like these.  What bitter blanks in<br><br>those black-bordered marbles which cover no ashes!  What despair in<br><br>those immovable inscriptions!  What deadly voids and unbidden<br><br>infidelities in the lines that seem to gnaw upon all Faith, and<br><br>refuse resurrections to the beings who have placelessly perished<br><br>without a grave.  As well might those tablets stand in the cave of<br><br>Elephanta as here.<br><br><br><br>In what census of living creatures, the dead of mankind are included;<br><br>why it is that a universal proverb says of them, that they tell no<br><br>tales, though containing more secrets than the Goodwin Sands; how it<br><br>is that to his name who yesterday departed for the other world, we<br><br>prefix so significant and infidel a word, and yet do not thus entitle<br><br>him, if he but embarks for the remotest Indies of this living earth;<br><br>why the Life Insurance Companies pay death-forfeitures upon<br><br>immortals; in what eternal, unstirring paralysis, and deadly,<br><br>hopeless trance, yet lies antique Adam who died sixty round centuries<br><br>ago; how it is that we still refuse to be comforted for those who we<br><br>nevertheless maintain are dwelling in unspeakable bliss; why all the<br><br>living so strive to hush all the dead; wherefore but the rumor of a<br><br>knocking in a tomb will terrify a whole city.  All these things are<br><br>not without their meanings.<br><br><br><br>But Faith, like a jackal, feeds among the tombs, and even from these<br><br>dead doubts she gathers her most vital hope.<br><br><br><br>It needs scarcely to be told, with what feelings, on the eve of a<br><br>Nantucket voyage, I regarded those marble tablets, and by the murky<br><br>light of that darkened, doleful day read the fate of the whalemen who<br><br>had gone before me.  Yes, Ishmael, the same fate may be thine.  But<br><br>somehow I grew merry again.  Delightful inducements to embark, fine<br><br>chance for promotion, it seems--aye, a stove boat will make me an<br><br>immortal by brevet.  Yes, there is death in this business of<br><br>whaling--a speechlessly quick chaotic bundling of a man into<br><br>Eternity.  But what then?  Methinks we have hugely mistaken this<br><br>matter of Life and Death.  Methinks that what they call my shadow<br><br>here on earth is my true substance.  Methinks that in looking at<br><br>things spiritual, we are too much like oysters observing the sun<br><br>through the water, and thinking that thick water the thinnest of air.<br><br>Methinks my body is but the lees of my better being.  In fact take<br><br>my body who will, take it I say, it is not me.  And therefore three<br><br>cheers for Nantucket; and come a stove boat and stove body when they<br><br>will, for stave my soul, Jove himself cannot.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 8<br><br><br><br>The Pulpit.<br><br><br><br><br><br>I had not been seated very long ere a man of a certain venerable<br><br>robustness entered; immediately as the storm-pelted door flew back<br><br>upon admitting him, a quick regardful eyeing of him by all the<br><br>congregation, sufficiently attested that this fine old man was the<br><br>chaplain.  Yes, it was the famous Father Mapple, so called by the<br><br>whalemen, among whom he was a very great favourite.  He had been a<br><br>sailor and a harpooneer in his youth, but for many years past had<br><br>dedicated his life to the ministry.  At the time I now write of,<br><br>Father Mapple was in the hardy winter of a healthy old age; that sort<br><br>of old age which seems merging into a second flowering youth, for<br><br>among all the fissures of his wrinkles, there shone certain mild<br><br>gleams of a newly developing bloom--the spring verdure peeping forth<br><br>even beneath February's snow.  No one having previously heard his<br><br>history, could for the first time behold Father Mapple without the<br><br>utmost interest, because there were certain engrafted clerical<br><br>peculiarities about him, imputable to that adventurous maritime life<br><br>he had led.  When he entered I observed that he carried no umbrella,<br><br>and certainly had not come in his carriage, for his tarpaulin hat ran<br><br>down with melting sleet, and his great pilot cloth jacket seemed<br><br>almost to drag him to the floor with the weight of the water it had<br><br>absorbed.  However, hat and coat and overshoes were one by one<br><br>removed, and hung up in a little space in an adjacent corner; when,<br><br>arrayed in a decent suit, he quietly approached the pulpit.<br><br><br><br>Like most old fashioned pulpits, it was a very lofty one, and since a<br><br>regular stairs to such a height would, by its long angle with the<br><br>floor, seriously contract the already small area of the chapel, the<br><br>architect, it seemed, had acted upon the hint of Father Mapple, and<br><br>finished the pulpit without a stairs, substituting a perpendicular<br><br>side ladder, like those used in mounting a ship from a boat at sea.<br><br>The wife of a whaling captain had provided the chapel with a handsome<br><br>pair of red worsted man-ropes for this ladder, which, being itself<br><br>nicely headed, and stained with a mahogany colour, the whole<br><br>contrivance, considering what manner of chapel it was, seemed by no<br><br>means in bad taste.  Halting for an instant at the foot of the<br><br>ladder, and with both hands grasping the ornamental knobs of the<br><br>man-ropes, Father Mapple cast a look upwards, and then with a truly<br><br>sailor-like but still reverential dexterity, hand over hand, mounted<br><br>the steps as if ascending the main-top of his vessel.<br><br><br><br>The perpendicular parts of this side ladder, as is usually the case<br><br>with swinging ones, were of cloth-covered rope, only the rounds were<br><br>of wood, so that at every step there was a joint.  At my first<br><br>glimpse of the pulpit, it had not escaped me that however convenient<br><br>for a ship, these joints in the present instance seemed unnecessary.<br><br>For I was not prepared to see Father Mapple after gaining the height,<br><br>slowly turn round, and stooping over the pulpit, deliberately drag up<br><br>the ladder step by step, till the whole was deposited within, leaving<br><br>him impregnable in his little Quebec.<br><br><br><br>I pondered some time without fully comprehending the reason for this.<br><br>Father Mapple enjoyed such a wide reputation for sincerity and<br><br>sanctity, that I could not suspect him of courting notoriety by any<br><br>mere tricks of the stage.  No, thought I, there must be some sober<br><br>reason for this thing; furthermore, it must symbolize something<br><br>unseen.  Can it be, then, that by that act of physical isolation, he<br><br>signifies his spiritual withdrawal for the time, from all outward<br><br>worldly ties and connexions?  Yes, for replenished with the meat and<br><br>wine of the word, to the faithful man of God, this pulpit, I see, is<br><br>a self-containing stronghold--a lofty Ehrenbreitstein, with a<br><br>perennial well of water within the walls.<br><br><br><br>But the side ladder was not the only strange feature of the place,<br><br>borrowed from the chaplain's former sea-farings.  Between the marble<br><br>cenotaphs on either hand of the pulpit, the wall which formed its<br><br>back was adorned with a large painting representing a gallant ship<br><br>beating against a terrible storm off a lee coast of black rocks and<br><br>snowy breakers.  But high above the flying scud and dark-rolling<br><br>clouds, there floated a little isle of sunlight, from which beamed<br><br>forth an angel's face; and this bright face shed a distinct spot of<br><br>radiance upon the ship's tossed deck, something like that silver<br><br>plate now inserted into the Victory's plank where Nelson fell.  "Ah,<br><br>noble ship," the angel seemed to say, "beat on, beat on, thou noble<br><br>ship, and bear a hardy helm; for lo! the sun is breaking through; the<br><br>clouds are rolling off--serenest azure is at hand."<br><br><br><br>Nor was the pulpit itself without a trace of the same sea-taste that<br><br>had achieved the ladder and the picture.  Its panelled front was in<br><br>the likeness of a ship's bluff bows, and the Holy Bible rested on a<br><br>projecting piece of scroll work, fashioned after a ship's<br><br>fiddle-headed beak.<br><br><br><br>What could be more full of meaning?--for the pulpit is ever this<br><br>earth's foremost part; all the rest comes in its rear; the pulpit<br><br>leads the world.  From thence it is the storm of God's quick wrath is<br><br>first descried, and the bow must bear the earliest brunt.  From<br><br>thence it is the God of breezes fair or foul is first invoked for<br><br>favourable winds.  Yes, the world's a ship on its passage out, and not<br><br>a voyage complete; and the pulpit is its prow.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 9<br><br><br><br>The Sermon.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Father Mapple rose, and in a mild voice of unassuming authority<br><br>ordered the scattered people to condense.  "Starboard gangway,<br><br>there! side away to larboard--larboard gangway to starboard!<br><br>Midships! midships!"<br><br><br><br>There was a low rumbling of heavy sea-boots among the benches, and a<br><br>still slighter shuffling of women's shoes, and all was quiet again,<br><br>and every eye on the preacher.<br><br><br><br>He paused a little; then kneeling in the pulpit's bows, folded his<br><br>large brown hands across his chest, uplifted his closed eyes, and<br><br>offered a prayer so deeply devout that he seemed kneeling and praying<br><br>at the bottom of the sea.<br><br><br><br>This ended, in prolonged solemn tones, like the continual tolling of<br><br>a bell in a ship that is foundering at sea in a fog--in such tones he<br><br>commenced reading the following hymn; but changing his manner towards<br><br>the concluding stanzas, burst forth with a pealing exultation and<br><br>joy--<br><br><br><br>"The ribs and terrors in the whale,<br><br>Arched over me a dismal gloom,<br><br>While all God's sun-lit waves rolled by,<br><br>And lift me deepening down to doom.<br><br><br><br>"I saw the opening maw of hell,<br><br>With endless pains and sorrows there;<br><br>Which none but they that feel can tell--<br><br>Oh, I was plunging to despair.<br><br><br><br>"In black distress, I called my God,<br><br>When I could scarce believe him mine,<br><br>He bowed his ear to my complaints--<br><br>No more the whale did me confine.<br><br><br><br>"With speed he flew to my relief,<br><br>As on a radiant dolphin borne;<br><br>Awful, yet bright, as lightning shone<br><br>The face of my Deliverer God.<br><br><br><br>"My song for ever shall record<br><br>That terrible, that joyful hour;<br><br>I give the glory to my God,<br><br>His all the mercy and the power.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Nearly all joined in singing this hymn, which swelled high above the<br><br>howling of the storm.  A brief pause ensued; the preacher slowly<br><br>turned over the leaves of the Bible, and at last, folding his hand<br><br>down upon the proper page, said: "Beloved shipmates, clinch the last<br><br>verse of the first chapter of Jonah--'And God had prepared a great<br><br>fish to swallow up Jonah.'"<br><br><br><br>"Shipmates, this book, containing only four chapters--four yarns--is<br><br>one of the smallest strands in the mighty cable of the Scriptures.<br><br>Yet what depths of the soul does Jonah's deep sealine sound! what a<br><br>pregnant lesson to us is this prophet!  What a noble thing is that<br><br>canticle in the fish's belly!  How billow-like and boisterously<br><br>grand!  We feel the floods surging over us; we sound with him to the<br><br>kelpy bottom of the waters; sea-weed and all the slime of the sea is<br><br>about us!  But WHAT is this lesson that the book of Jonah teaches?<br><br>Shipmates, it is a two-stranded lesson; a lesson to us all as sinful<br><br>men, and a lesson to me as a pilot of the living God.  As sinful men,<br><br>it is a lesson to us all, because it is a story of the sin,<br><br>hard-heartedness, suddenly awakened fears, the swift punishment,<br><br>repentance, prayers, and finally the deliverance and joy of Jonah.<br><br>As with all sinners among men, the sin of this son of Amittai was in<br><br>his wilful disobedience of the command of God--never mind now what<br><br>that command was, or how conveyed--which he found a hard command.<br><br>But all the things that God would have us do are hard for us to<br><br>do--remember that--and hence, he oftener commands us than endeavors<br><br>to persuade.  And if we obey God, we must disobey ourselves; and it<br><br>is in this disobeying ourselves, wherein the hardness of obeying God<br><br>consists.<br><br><br><br>"With this sin of disobedience in him, Jonah still further flouts at<br><br>God, by seeking to flee from Him.  He thinks that a ship made by men<br><br>will carry him into countries where God does not reign, but only the<br><br>Captains of this earth.  He skulks about the wharves of Joppa, and<br><br>seeks a ship that's bound for Tarshish.  There lurks, perhaps, a<br><br>hitherto unheeded meaning here.  By all accounts Tarshish could have<br><br>been no other city than the modern Cadiz.  That's the opinion of<br><br>learned men.  And where is Cadiz, shipmates?  Cadiz is in Spain; as<br><br>far by water, from Joppa, as Jonah could possibly have sailed in<br><br>those ancient days, when the Atlantic was an almost unknown sea.<br><br>Because Joppa, the modern Jaffa, shipmates, is on the most easterly<br><br>coast of the Mediterranean, the Syrian; and Tarshish or Cadiz more<br><br>than two thousand miles to the westward from that, just outside the<br><br>Straits of Gibraltar.  See ye not then, shipmates, that Jonah sought<br><br>to flee world-wide from God?  Miserable man!  Oh! most contemptible<br><br>and worthy of all scorn; with slouched hat and guilty eye, skulking<br><br>from his God; prowling among the shipping like a vile burglar<br><br>hastening to cross the seas.  So disordered, self-condemning is his<br><br>look, that had there been policemen in those days, Jonah, on the mere<br><br>suspicion of something wrong, had been arrested ere he touched a<br><br>deck.  How plainly he's a fugitive! no baggage, not a hat-box,<br><br>valise, or carpet-bag,--no friends accompany him to the wharf with<br><br>their adieux.  At last, after much dodging search, he finds the<br><br>Tarshish ship receiving the last items of her cargo; and as he steps<br><br>on board to see its Captain in the cabin, all the sailors for the<br><br>moment desist from hoisting in the goods, to mark the stranger's evil<br><br>eye.  Jonah sees this; but in vain he tries to look all ease and<br><br>confidence; in vain essays his wretched smile.  Strong intuitions of<br><br>the man assure the mariners he can be no innocent.  In their gamesome<br><br>but still serious way, one whispers to the other--"Jack, he's robbed<br><br>a widow;" or, "Joe, do you mark him; he's a bigamist;" or, "Harry<br><br>lad, I guess he's the adulterer that broke jail in old Gomorrah, or<br><br>belike, one of the missing murderers from Sodom."  Another runs to<br><br>read the bill that's stuck against the spile upon the wharf to which<br><br>the ship is moored, offering five hundred gold coins for the<br><br>apprehension of a parricide, and containing a description of his<br><br>person.  He reads, and looks from Jonah to the bill; while all his<br><br>sympathetic shipmates now crowd round Jonah, prepared to lay their<br><br>hands upon him.  Frighted Jonah trembles, and summoning all his<br><br>boldness to his face, only looks so much the more a coward.  He will<br><br>not confess himself suspected; but that itself is strong suspicion.<br><br>So he makes the best of it; and when the sailors find him not to be<br><br>the man that is advertised, they let him pass, and he descends into<br><br>the cabin.<br><br><br><br>"'Who's there?' cries the Captain at his busy desk, hurriedly making<br><br>out his papers for the Customs--'Who's there?'  Oh! how that harmless<br><br>question mangles Jonah!  For the instant he almost turns to flee<br><br>again.  But he rallies.  'I seek a passage in this ship to Tarshish;<br><br>how soon sail ye, sir?'  Thus far the busy Captain had not looked up<br><br>to Jonah, though the man now stands before him; but no sooner does he<br><br>hear that hollow voice, than he darts a scrutinizing glance.  'We<br><br>sail with the next coming tide,' at last he slowly answered, still<br><br>intently eyeing him.  'No sooner, sir?'--'Soon enough for any honest<br><br>man that goes a passenger.'  Ha!  Jonah, that's another stab.  But he<br><br>swiftly calls away the Captain from that scent.  'I'll sail with<br><br>ye,'--he says,--'the passage money how much is that?--I'll pay now.'<br><br>For it is particularly written, shipmates, as if it were a thing not<br><br>to be overlooked in this history, 'that he paid the fare thereof' ere<br><br>the craft did sail.  And taken with the context, this is full of<br><br>meaning.<br><br><br><br>"Now Jonah's Captain, shipmates, was one whose discernment detects<br><br>crime in any, but whose cupidity exposes it only in the penniless.<br><br>In this world, shipmates, sin that pays its way can travel freely,<br><br>and without a passport; whereas Virtue, if a pauper, is stopped at<br><br>all frontiers.  So Jonah's Captain prepares to test the length of<br><br>Jonah's purse, ere he judge him openly.  He charges him thrice the<br><br>usual sum; and it's assented to.  Then the Captain knows that Jonah<br><br>is a fugitive; but at the same time resolves to help a flight that<br><br>paves its rear with gold.  Yet when Jonah fairly takes out his purse,<br><br>prudent suspicions still molest the Captain.  He rings every coin to<br><br>find a counterfeit.  Not a forger, any way, he mutters; and Jonah is<br><br>put down for his passage.  'Point out my state-room, Sir,' says Jonah<br><br>now, 'I'm travel-weary; I need sleep.'  'Thou lookest like it,' says<br><br>the Captain, 'there's thy room.'  Jonah enters, and would lock the<br><br>door, but the lock contains no key.  Hearing him foolishly fumbling<br><br>there, the Captain laughs lowly to himself, and mutters something<br><br>about the doors of convicts' cells being never allowed to be locked<br><br>within.  All dressed and dusty as he is, Jonah throws himself into<br><br>his berth, and finds the little state-room ceiling almost resting on<br><br>his forehead.  The air is close, and Jonah gasps.  Then, in that<br><br>contracted hole, sunk, too, beneath the ship's water-line, Jonah<br><br>feels the heralding presentiment of that stifling hour, when the<br><br>whale shall hold him in the smallest of his bowels' wards.<br><br><br><br>"Screwed at its axis against the side, a swinging lamp slightly<br><br>oscillates in Jonah's room; and the ship, heeling over towards the<br><br>wharf with the weight of the last bales received, the lamp, flame and<br><br>all, though in slight motion, still maintains a permanent obliquity<br><br>with reference to the room; though, in truth, infallibly straight<br><br>itself, it but made obvious the false, lying levels among which it<br><br>hung.  The lamp alarms and frightens Jonah; as lying in his berth his<br><br>tormented eyes roll round the place, and this thus far successful<br><br>fugitive finds no refuge for his restless glance.  But that<br><br>contradiction in the lamp more and more appals him.  The floor, the<br><br>ceiling, and the side, are all awry.  'Oh! so my conscience hangs in<br><br>me!' he groans, 'straight upwards, so it burns; but the chambers of<br><br>my soul are all in crookedness!'<br><br><br><br>"Like one who after a night of drunken revelry hies to his bed, still<br><br>reeling, but with conscience yet pricking him, as the plungings of<br><br>the Roman race-horse but so much the more strike his steel tags into<br><br>him; as one who in that miserable plight still turns and turns in<br><br>giddy anguish, praying God for annihilation until the fit be passed;<br><br>and at last amid the whirl of woe he feels, a deep stupor steals over<br><br>him, as over the man who bleeds to death, for conscience is the<br><br>wound, and there's naught to staunch it; so, after sore wrestlings in<br><br>his berth, Jonah's prodigy of ponderous misery drags him drowning<br><br>down to sleep.<br><br><br><br>"And now the time of tide has come; the ship casts off her cables;<br><br>and from the deserted wharf the uncheered ship for Tarshish, all<br><br>careening, glides to sea.  That ship, my friends, was the first of<br><br>recorded smugglers! the contraband was Jonah.  But the sea rebels; he<br><br>will not bear the wicked burden.  A dreadful storm comes on, the<br><br>ship is like to break.  But now when the boatswain calls all hands to<br><br>lighten her; when boxes, bales, and jars are clattering overboard;<br><br>when the wind is shrieking, and the men are yelling, and every plank<br><br>thunders with trampling feet right over Jonah's head; in all this<br><br>raging tumult, Jonah sleeps his hideous sleep.  He sees no black sky<br><br>and raging sea, feels not the reeling timbers, and little hears he or<br><br>heeds he the far rush of the mighty whale, which even now with open<br><br>mouth is cleaving the seas after him.  Aye, shipmates, Jonah was gone<br><br>down into the sides of the ship--a berth in the cabin as I have taken<br><br>it, and was fast asleep.  But the frightened master comes to him, and<br><br>shrieks in his dead ear, 'What meanest thou, O, sleeper! arise!'<br><br>Startled from his lethargy by that direful cry, Jonah staggers to his<br><br>feet, and stumbling to the deck, grasps a shroud, to look out upon<br><br>the sea.  But at that moment he is sprung upon by a panther billow<br><br>leaping over the bulwarks.  Wave after wave thus leaps into the ship,<br><br>and finding no speedy vent runs roaring fore and aft, till the<br><br>mariners come nigh to drowning while yet afloat.  And ever, as the<br><br>white moon shows her affrighted face from the steep gullies in the<br><br>blackness overhead, aghast Jonah sees the rearing bowsprit pointing<br><br>high upward, but soon beat downward again towards the tormented deep.<br><br><br><br>"Terrors upon terrors run shouting through his soul.  In all his<br><br>cringing attitudes, the God-fugitive is now too plainly known.  The<br><br>sailors mark him; more and more certain grow their suspicions of him,<br><br>and at last, fully to test the truth, by referring the whole matter<br><br>to high Heaven, they fall to casting lots, to see for whose<br><br>cause this great tempest was upon them.  The lot is Jonah's; that<br><br>discovered, then how furiously they mob him with their questions.<br><br>'What is thine occupation?  Whence comest thou?  Thy country?  What<br><br>people?  But mark now, my shipmates, the behavior of poor Jonah.  The<br><br>eager mariners but ask him who he is, and where from; whereas, they<br><br>not only receive an answer to those questions, but likewise another<br><br>answer to a question not put by them, but the unsolicited answer is<br><br>forced from Jonah by the hard hand of God that is upon him.<br><br><br><br>"'I am a Hebrew,' he cries--and then--'I fear the Lord the God of<br><br>Heaven who hath made the sea and the dry land!'  Fear him, O Jonah?<br><br>Aye, well mightest thou fear the Lord God THEN!  Straightway, he now<br><br>goes on to make a full confession; whereupon the mariners became more<br><br>and more appalled, but still are pitiful.  For when Jonah, not yet<br><br>supplicating God for mercy, since he but too well knew the darkness<br><br>of his deserts,--when wretched Jonah cries out to them to take him<br><br>and cast him forth into the sea, for he knew that for HIS sake this<br><br>great tempest was upon them; they mercifully turn from him, and seek<br><br>by other means to save the ship.  But all in vain; the indignant gale<br><br>howls louder; then, with one hand raised invokingly to God, with the<br><br>other they not unreluctantly lay hold of Jonah.<br><br><br><br>"And now behold Jonah taken up as an anchor and dropped into the sea;<br><br>when instantly an oily calmness floats out from the east, and the sea<br><br>is still, as Jonah carries down the gale with him, leaving smooth<br><br>water behind.  He goes down in the whirling heart of such a<br><br>masterless commotion that he scarce heeds the moment when he drops<br><br>seething into the yawning jaws awaiting him; and the whale shoots-to<br><br>all his ivory teeth, like so many white bolts, upon his prison.  Then<br><br>Jonah prayed unto the Lord out of the fish's belly.  But observe his<br><br>prayer, and learn a weighty lesson.  For sinful as he is, Jonah does<br><br>not weep and wail for direct deliverance.  He feels that his dreadful<br><br>punishment is just.  He leaves all his deliverance to God, contenting<br><br>himself with this, that spite of all his pains and pangs, he will<br><br>still look towards His holy temple.  And here, shipmates, is true and<br><br>faithful repentance; not clamorous for pardon, but grateful for<br><br>punishment.  And how pleasing to God was this conduct in Jonah, is<br><br>shown in the eventual deliverance of him from the sea and the whale.<br><br>Shipmates, I do not place Jonah before you to be copied for his sin<br><br>but I do place him before you as a model for repentance.  Sin not;<br><br>but if you do, take heed to repent of it like Jonah."<br><br><br><br>While he was speaking these words, the howling of the shrieking,<br><br>slanting storm without seemed to add new power to the preacher, who,<br><br>when describing Jonah's sea-storm, seemed tossed by a storm himself.<br><br>His deep chest heaved as with a ground-swell; his tossed arms seemed<br><br>the warring elements at work; and the thunders that rolled away from<br><br>off his swarthy brow, and the light leaping from his eye, made all<br><br>his simple hearers look on him with a quick fear that was strange to<br><br>them.<br><br><br><br>There now came a lull in his look, as he silently turned over the<br><br>leaves of the Book once more; and, at last, standing motionless, with<br><br>closed eyes, for the moment, seemed communing with God and himself.<br><br><br><br>But again he leaned over towards the people, and bowing his head<br><br>lowly, with an aspect of the deepest yet manliest humility, he spake<br><br>these words:<br><br><br><br>"Shipmates, God has laid but one hand upon you; both his hands press<br><br>upon me.  I have read ye by what murky light may be mine the lesson<br><br>that Jonah teaches to all sinners; and therefore to ye, and still<br><br>more to me, for I am a greater sinner than ye.  And now how gladly<br><br>would I come down from this mast-head and sit on the hatches there<br><br>where you sit, and listen as you listen, while some one of you reads<br><br>ME that other and more awful lesson which Jonah teaches to ME, as a<br><br>pilot of the living God.  How being an anointed pilot-prophet, or<br><br>speaker of true things, and bidden by the Lord to sound those<br><br>unwelcome truths in the ears of a wicked Nineveh, Jonah, appalled at<br><br>the hostility he should raise, fled from his mission, and sought to<br><br>escape his duty and his God by taking ship at Joppa.  But God is<br><br>everywhere; Tarshish he never reached.  As we have seen, God came<br><br>upon him in the whale, and swallowed him down to living gulfs of<br><br>doom, and with swift slantings tore him along 'into the midst of the<br><br>seas,' where the eddying depths sucked him ten thousand fathoms down,<br><br>and 'the weeds were wrapped about his head,' and all the watery world<br><br>of woe bowled over him.  Yet even then beyond the reach of any<br><br>plummet--'out of the belly of hell'--when the whale grounded upon the<br><br>ocean's utmost bones, even then, God heard the engulphed, repenting<br><br>prophet when he cried.  Then God spake unto the fish; and from the<br><br>shuddering cold and blackness of the sea, the whale came breeching up<br><br>towards the warm and pleasant sun, and all the delights of air and<br><br>earth; and 'vomited out Jonah upon the dry land;' when the word of<br><br>the Lord came a second time; and Jonah, bruised and beaten--his ears,<br><br>like two sea-shells, still multitudinously murmuring of the<br><br>ocean--Jonah did the Almighty's bidding.  And what was that,<br><br>shipmates?  To preach the Truth to the face of Falsehood!  That was<br><br>it!<br><br><br><br>"This, shipmates, this is that other lesson; and woe to that pilot of<br><br>the living God who slights it.  Woe to him whom this world charms<br><br>from Gospel duty!  Woe to him who seeks to pour oil upon the waters<br><br>when God has brewed them into a gale!  Woe to him who seeks to please<br><br>rather than to appal!  Woe to him whose good name is more to him than<br><br>goodness!  Woe to him who, in this world, courts not dishonour!  Woe<br><br>to him who would not be true, even though to be false were salvation!<br><br>Yea, woe to him who, as the great Pilot Paul has it, while preaching<br><br>to others is himself a castaway!"<br><br><br><br>He dropped and fell away from himself for a moment; then lifting his<br><br>face to them again, showed a deep joy in his eyes, as he cried out<br><br>with a heavenly enthusiasm,--"But oh! shipmates! on the starboard<br><br>hand of every woe, there is a sure delight; and higher the top of<br><br>that delight, than the bottom of the woe is deep.  Is not the<br><br>main-truck higher than the kelson is low?  Delight is to him--a far,<br><br>far upward, and inward delight--who against the proud gods and<br><br>commodores of this earth, ever stands forth his own inexorable self.<br><br>Delight is to him whose strong arms yet support him, when the ship of<br><br>this base treacherous world has gone down beneath him.  Delight is to<br><br>him, who gives no quarter in the truth, and kills, burns, and<br><br>destroys all sin though he pluck it out from under the robes of<br><br>Senators and Judges.  Delight,--top-gallant delight is to him, who<br><br>acknowledges no law or lord, but the Lord his God, and is only a<br><br>patriot to heaven.  Delight is to him, whom all the waves of the<br><br>billows of the seas of the boisterous mob can never shake from this<br><br>sure Keel of the Ages.  And eternal delight and deliciousness will be<br><br>his, who coming to lay him down, can say with his final breath--O<br><br>Father!--chiefly known to me by Thy rod--mortal or immortal, here I<br><br>die.  I have striven to be Thine, more than to be this world's, or<br><br>mine own.  Yet this is nothing: I leave eternity to Thee; for what<br><br>is man that he should live out the lifetime of his God?"<br><br><br><br>He said no more, but slowly waving a benediction, covered his face<br><br>with his hands, and so remained kneeling, till all the people had<br><br>departed, and he was left alone in the place.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 10<br><br><br><br>A Bosom Friend.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Returning to the Spouter-Inn from the Chapel, I found Queequeg there<br><br>quite alone; he having left the Chapel before the benediction some<br><br>time.  He was sitting on a bench before the fire, with his feet on<br><br>the stove hearth, and in one hand was holding close up to his face<br><br>that little negro idol of his; peering hard into its face, and with a<br><br>jack-knife gently whittling away at its nose, meanwhile humming to<br><br>himself in his heathenish way.<br><br><br><br>But being now interrupted, he put up the image; and pretty soon,<br><br>going to the table, took up a large book there, and placing it on his<br><br>lap began counting the pages with deliberate regularity; at every<br><br>fiftieth page--as I fancied--stopping a moment, looking vacantly<br><br>around him, and giving utterance to a long-drawn gurgling whistle of<br><br>astonishment.  He would then begin again at the next fifty; seeming<br><br>to commence at number one each time, as though he could not count<br><br>more than fifty, and it was only by such a large number of fifties<br><br>being found together, that his astonishment at the multitude of pages<br><br>was excited.<br><br><br><br>With much interest I sat watching him.  Savage though he was, and<br><br>hideously marred about the face--at least to my taste--his<br><br>countenance yet had a something in it which was by no means<br><br>disagreeable.  You cannot hide the soul.  Through all his unearthly<br><br>tattooings, I thought I saw the traces of a simple honest heart; and<br><br>in his large, deep eyes, fiery black and bold, there seemed tokens of<br><br>a spirit that would dare a thousand devils.  And besides all this,<br><br>there was a certain lofty bearing about the Pagan, which even his<br><br>uncouthness could not altogether maim.  He looked like a man who had<br><br>never cringed and never had had a creditor.  Whether it was, too,<br><br>that his head being shaved, his forehead was drawn out in freer and<br><br>brighter relief, and looked more expansive than it otherwise would,<br><br>this I will not venture to decide; but certain it was his head was<br><br>phrenologically an excellent one.  It may seem ridiculous, but it<br><br>reminded me of General Washington's head, as seen in the popular<br><br>busts of him.  It had the same long regularly graded retreating slope<br><br>from above the brows, which were likewise very projecting, like two<br><br>long promontories thickly wooded on top.  Queequeg was George<br><br>Washington cannibalistically developed.<br><br><br><br>Whilst I was thus closely scanning him, half-pretending meanwhile to<br><br>be looking out at the storm from the casement, he never heeded my<br><br>presence, never troubled himself with so much as a single glance; but<br><br>appeared wholly occupied with counting the pages of the marvellous<br><br>book.  Considering how sociably we had been sleeping together the<br><br>night previous, and especially considering the affectionate arm I had<br><br>found thrown over me upon waking in the morning, I thought this<br><br>indifference of his very strange.  But savages are strange beings; at<br><br>times you do not know exactly how to take them.  At first they are<br><br>overawing; their calm self-collectedness of simplicity seems a<br><br>Socratic wisdom.  I had noticed also that Queequeg never consorted at<br><br>all, or but very little, with the other seamen in the inn.  He made<br><br>no advances whatever; appeared to have no desire to enlarge the<br><br>circle of his acquaintances.  All this struck me as mighty singular;<br><br>yet, upon second thoughts, there was something almost sublime in it.<br><br>Here was a man some twenty thousand miles from home, by the way of<br><br>Cape Horn, that is--which was the only way he could get there--thrown<br><br>among people as strange to him as though he were in the planet<br><br>Jupiter; and yet he seemed entirely at his ease; preserving the<br><br>utmost serenity; content with his own companionship; always equal to<br><br>himself.  Surely this was a touch of fine philosophy; though no doubt<br><br>he had never heard there was such a thing as that.  But, perhaps, to<br><br>be true philosophers, we mortals should not be conscious of so living<br><br>or so striving.  So soon as I hear that such or such a man gives<br><br>himself out for a philosopher, I conclude that, like the dyspeptic<br><br>old woman, he must have "broken his digester."<br><br><br><br>As I sat there in that now lonely room; the fire burning low, in that<br><br>mild stage when, after its first intensity has warmed the air, it<br><br>then only glows to be looked at; the evening shades and phantoms<br><br>gathering round the casements, and peering in upon us silent,<br><br>solitary twain; the storm booming without in solemn swells; I began<br><br>to be sensible of strange feelings.  I felt a melting in me.  No more<br><br>my splintered heart and maddened hand were turned against the wolfish<br><br>world.  This soothing savage had redeemed it.  There he sat, his very<br><br>indifference speaking a nature in which there lurked no civilized<br><br>hypocrisies and bland deceits.  Wild he was; a very sight of sights<br><br>to see; yet I began to feel myself mysteriously drawn towards him.<br><br>And those same things that would have repelled most others, they were<br><br>the very magnets that thus drew me.  I'll try a pagan friend, thought<br><br>I, since Christian kindness has proved but hollow courtesy.  I drew<br><br>my bench near him, and made some friendly signs and hints, doing my<br><br>best to talk with him meanwhile.  At first he little noticed these<br><br>advances; but presently, upon my referring to his last night's<br><br>hospitalities, he made out to ask me whether we were again to be<br><br>bedfellows.  I told him yes; whereat I thought he looked pleased,<br><br>perhaps a little complimented.<br><br><br><br>We then turned over the book together, and I endeavored to explain to<br><br>him the purpose of the printing, and the meaning of the few pictures<br><br>that were in it.  Thus I soon engaged his interest; and from that we<br><br>went to jabbering the best we could about the various outer sights to<br><br>be seen in this famous town.  Soon I proposed a social smoke; and,<br><br>producing his pouch and tomahawk, he quietly offered me a puff.  And<br><br>then we sat exchanging puffs from that wild pipe of his, and keeping<br><br>it regularly passing between us.<br><br><br><br>If there yet lurked any ice of indifference towards me in the Pagan's<br><br>breast, this pleasant, genial smoke we had, soon thawed it out, and<br><br>left us cronies.  He seemed to take to me quite as naturally and<br><br>unbiddenly as I to him; and when our smoke was over, he pressed his<br><br>forehead against mine, clasped me round the waist, and said that<br><br>henceforth we were married; meaning, in his country's phrase, that we<br><br>were bosom friends; he would gladly die for me, if need should be.<br><br>In a countryman, this sudden flame of friendship would have seemed<br><br>far too premature, a thing to be much distrusted; but in this simple<br><br>savage those old rules would not apply.<br><br><br><br>After supper, and another social chat and smoke, we went to our room<br><br>together.  He made me a present of his embalmed head; took out his<br><br>enormous tobacco wallet, and groping under the tobacco, drew out some<br><br>thirty dollars in silver; then spreading them on the table, and<br><br>mechanically dividing them into two equal portions, pushed one of<br><br>them towards me, and said it was mine.  I was going to remonstrate;<br><br>but he silenced me by pouring them into my trowsers' pockets.  I let<br><br>them stay.  He then went about his evening prayers, took out his<br><br>idol, and removed the paper fireboard.  By certain signs and<br><br>symptoms, I thought he seemed anxious for me to join him; but well<br><br>knowing what was to follow, I deliberated a moment whether, in case<br><br>he invited me, I would comply or otherwise.<br><br><br><br>I was a good Christian; born and bred in the bosom of the infallible<br><br>Presbyterian Church.  How then could I unite with this wild idolator<br><br>in worshipping his piece of wood?  But what is worship? thought I.<br><br>Do you suppose now, Ishmael, that the magnanimous God of heaven and<br><br>earth--pagans and all included--can possibly be jealous of an<br><br>insignificant bit of black wood?  Impossible!  But what is<br><br>worship?--to do the will of God--THAT is worship.  And what is the<br><br>will of God?--to do to my fellow man what I would have my fellow man<br><br>to do to me--THAT is the will of God.  Now, Queequeg is my fellow<br><br>man.  And what do I wish that this Queequeg would do to me?  Why,<br><br>unite with me in my particular Presbyterian form of worship.<br><br>Consequently, I must then unite with him in his; ergo, I must turn<br><br>idolator.  So I kindled the shavings; helped prop up the innocent<br><br>little idol; offered him burnt biscuit with Queequeg; salamed before<br><br>him twice or thrice; kissed his nose; and that done, we undressed and<br><br>went to bed, at peace with our own consciences and all the world.<br><br>But we did not go to sleep without some little chat.<br><br><br><br>How it is I know not; but there is no place like a bed for<br><br>confidential disclosures between friends.  Man and wife, they say,<br><br>there open the very bottom of their souls to each other; and some old<br><br>couples often lie and chat over old times till nearly morning.  Thus,<br><br>then, in our hearts' honeymoon, lay I and Queequeg--a cosy, loving<br><br>pair.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 11<br><br><br><br>Nightgown.<br><br><br><br><br><br>We had lain thus in bed, chatting and napping at short intervals, and<br><br>Queequeg now and then affectionately throwing his brown tattooed legs<br><br>over mine, and then drawing them back; so entirely sociable and free<br><br>and easy were we; when, at last, by reason of our confabulations,<br><br>what little nappishness remained in us altogether departed, and we<br><br>felt like getting up again, though day-break was yet some way down<br><br>the future.<br><br><br><br>Yes, we became very wakeful; so much so that our recumbent position<br><br>began to grow wearisome, and by little and little we found ourselves<br><br>sitting up; the clothes well tucked around us, leaning against the<br><br>head-board with our four knees drawn up close together, and our two<br><br>noses bending over them, as if our kneepans were warming-pans.  We<br><br>felt very nice and snug, the more so since it was so chilly out of<br><br>doors; indeed out of bed-clothes too, seeing that there was no fire<br><br>in the room.  The more so, I say, because truly to enjoy bodily<br><br>warmth, some small part of you must be cold, for there is no quality<br><br>in this world that is not what it is merely by contrast.  Nothing<br><br>exists in itself.  If you flatter yourself that you are all over<br><br>comfortable, and have been so a long time, then you cannot be said to<br><br>be comfortable any more.  But if, like Queequeg and me in the bed,<br><br>the tip of your nose or the crown of your head be slightly chilled,<br><br>why then, indeed, in the general consciousness you feel most<br><br>delightfully and unmistakably warm.  For this reason a sleeping<br><br>apartment should never be furnished with a fire, which is one of the<br><br>luxurious discomforts of the rich.  For the height of this sort of<br><br>deliciousness is to have nothing but the blanket between you and<br><br>your snugness and the cold of the outer air.  Then there you lie like<br><br>the one warm spark in the heart of an arctic crystal.<br><br><br><br>We had been sitting in this crouching manner for some time, when all<br><br>at once I thought I would open my eyes; for when between sheets,<br><br>whether by day or by night, and whether asleep or awake, I have a way<br><br>of always keeping my eyes shut, in order the more to concentrate the<br><br>snugness of being in bed.  Because no man can ever feel his own<br><br>identity aright except his eyes be closed; as if darkness were<br><br>indeed the proper element of our essences, though light be more<br><br>congenial to our clayey part.  Upon opening my eyes then, and coming<br><br>out of my own pleasant and self-created darkness into the imposed and<br><br>coarse outer gloom of the unilluminated twelve-o'clock-at-night, I<br><br>experienced a disagreeable revulsion.  Nor did I at all object to the<br><br>hint from Queequeg that perhaps it were best to strike a light,<br><br>seeing that we were so wide awake; and besides he felt a strong<br><br>desire to have a few quiet puffs from his Tomahawk.  Be it said, that<br><br>though I had felt such a strong repugnance to his smoking in the bed<br><br>the night before, yet see how elastic our stiff prejudices grow when<br><br>love once comes to bend them.  For now I liked nothing better than<br><br>to have Queequeg smoking by me, even in bed, because he seemed to be<br><br>full of such serene household joy then.  I no more felt unduly<br><br>concerned for the landlord's policy of insurance.  I was only alive<br><br>to the condensed confidential comfortableness of sharing a pipe and a<br><br>blanket with a real friend.  With our shaggy jackets drawn about our<br><br>shoulders, we now passed the Tomahawk from one to the other, till<br><br>slowly there grew over us a blue hanging tester of smoke, illuminated<br><br>by the flame of the new-lit lamp.<br><br><br><br>Whether it was that this undulating tester rolled the savage away to<br><br>far distant scenes, I know not, but he now spoke of his native<br><br>island; and, eager to hear his history, I begged him to go on and<br><br>tell it.  He gladly complied.  Though at the time I but ill<br><br>comprehended not a few of his words, yet subsequent disclosures, when<br><br>I had become more familiar with his broken phraseology, now enable me<br><br>to present the whole story such as it may prove in the mere skeleton<br><br>I give.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 12<br><br><br><br>Biographical.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Queequeg was a native of Rokovoko, an island far away to the West<br><br>and South.  It is not down in any map; true places never are.<br><br><br><br>When a new-hatched savage running wild about his native woodlands in<br><br>a grass clout, followed by the nibbling goats, as if he were a green<br><br>sapling; even then, in Queequeg's ambitious soul, lurked a strong<br><br>desire to see something more of Christendom than a specimen whaler or<br><br>two.  His father was a High Chief, a King; his uncle a High Priest;<br><br>and on the maternal side he boasted aunts who were the wives of<br><br>unconquerable warriors.  There was excellent blood in his<br><br>veins--royal stuff; though sadly vitiated, I fear, by the cannibal<br><br>propensity he nourished in his untutored youth.<br><br><br><br>A Sag Harbor ship visited his father's bay, and Queequeg sought a<br><br>passage to Christian lands.  But the ship, having her full complement<br><br>of seamen, spurned his suit; and not all the King his father's<br><br>influence could prevail.  But Queequeg vowed a vow.  Alone in his<br><br>canoe, he paddled off to a distant strait, which he knew the ship<br><br>must pass through when she quitted the island.  On one side was a<br><br>coral reef; on the other a low tongue of land, covered with mangrove<br><br>thickets that grew out into the water.  Hiding his canoe, still<br><br>afloat, among these thickets, with its prow seaward, he sat down in<br><br>the stern, paddle low in hand; and when the ship was gliding by, like<br><br>a flash he darted out; gained her side; with one backward dash of his<br><br>foot capsized and sank his canoe; climbed up the chains; and throwing<br><br>himself at full length upon the deck, grappled a ring-bolt there, and<br><br>swore not to let it go, though hacked in pieces.<br><br><br><br>In vain the captain threatened to throw him overboard; suspended a<br><br>cutlass over his naked wrists; Queequeg was the son of a King, and<br><br>Queequeg budged not.  Struck by his desperate dauntlessness, and his<br><br>wild desire to visit Christendom, the captain at last relented, and<br><br>told him he might make himself at home.  But this fine young<br><br>savage--this sea Prince of Wales, never saw the Captain's cabin.<br><br>They put him down among the sailors, and made a whaleman of him.  But<br><br>like Czar Peter content to toil in the shipyards of foreign cities,<br><br>Queequeg disdained no seeming ignominy, if thereby he might happily<br><br>gain the power of enlightening his untutored countrymen.  For at<br><br>bottom--so he told me--he was actuated by a profound desire to learn<br><br>among the Christians, the arts whereby to make his people still<br><br>happier than they were; and more than that, still better than they<br><br>were.  But, alas! the practices of whalemen soon convinced him that<br><br>even Christians could be both miserable and wicked; infinitely more<br><br>so, than all his father's heathens.  Arrived at last in old Sag<br><br>Harbor; and seeing what the sailors did there; and then going on to<br><br>Nantucket, and seeing how they spent their wages in that place also,<br><br>poor Queequeg gave it up for lost.  Thought he, it's a wicked world<br><br>in all meridians; I'll die a pagan.<br><br><br><br>And thus an old idolator at heart, he yet lived among these<br><br>Christians, wore their clothes, and tried to talk their gibberish.<br><br>Hence the queer ways about him, though now some time from home.<br><br><br><br>By hints, I asked him whether he did not propose going back, and<br><br>having a coronation; since he might now consider his father dead and<br><br>gone, he being very old and feeble at the last accounts.  He answered<br><br>no, not yet; and added that he was fearful Christianity, or rather<br><br>Christians, had unfitted him for ascending the pure and undefiled<br><br>throne of thirty pagan Kings before him.  But by and by, he said, he<br><br>would return,--as soon as he felt himself baptized again.  For the<br><br>nonce, however, he proposed to sail about, and sow his wild oats in<br><br>all four oceans.  They had made a harpooneer of him, and that barbed<br><br>iron was in lieu of a sceptre now.<br><br><br><br>I asked him what might be his immediate purpose, touching his future<br><br>movements.  He answered, to go to sea again, in his old vocation.<br><br>Upon this, I told him that whaling was my own design, and informed<br><br>him of my intention to sail out of Nantucket, as being the most<br><br>promising port for an adventurous whaleman to embark from.  He at<br><br>once resolved to accompany me to that island, ship aboard the same<br><br>vessel, get into the same watch, the same boat, the same mess with<br><br>me, in short to share my every hap; with both my hands in his, boldly<br><br>dip into the Potluck of both worlds.  To all this I joyously<br><br>assented; for besides the affection I now felt for Queequeg, he was<br><br>an experienced harpooneer, and as such, could not fail to be of great<br><br>usefulness to one, who, like me, was wholly ignorant of the mysteries<br><br>of whaling, though well acquainted with the sea, as known to merchant<br><br>seamen.<br><br><br><br>His story being ended with his pipe's last dying puff, Queequeg<br><br>embraced me, pressed his forehead against mine, and blowing out the<br><br>light, we rolled over from each other, this way and that, and very<br><br>soon were sleeping.<br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 13<br><br><br><br>Wheelbarrow.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Next morning, Monday, after disposing of the embalmed head to a<br><br>barber, for a block, I settled my own and comrade's bill; using,<br><br>however, my comrade's money.  The grinning landlord, as well as the<br><br>boarders, seemed amazingly tickled at the sudden friendship which had<br><br>sprung up between me and Queequeg--especially as Peter Coffin's cock<br><br>and bull stories about him had previously so much alarmed me<br><br>concerning the very person whom I now companied with.<br><br><br><br>We borrowed a wheelbarrow, and embarking our things, including my own<br><br>poor carpet-bag, and Queequeg's canvas sack and hammock, away we went<br><br>down to "the Moss," the little Nantucket packet schooner moored at<br><br>the wharf.  As we were going along the people stared; not at Queequeg<br><br>so much--for they were used to seeing cannibals like him in their<br><br>streets,--but at seeing him and me upon such confidential terms.  But<br><br>we heeded them not, going along wheeling the barrow by turns, and<br><br>Queequeg now and then stopping to adjust the sheath on his harpoon<br><br>barbs.  I asked him why he carried such a troublesome thing with him<br><br>ashore, and whether all whaling ships did not find their own<br><br>harpoons.  To this, in substance, he replied, that though what I<br><br>hinted was true enough, yet he had a particular affection for his own<br><br>harpoon, because it was of assured stuff, well tried in many a mortal<br><br>combat, and deeply intimate with the hearts of whales.  In short,<br><br>like many inland reapers and mowers, who go into the farmers' meadows<br><br>armed with their own scythes--though in no wise obliged to furnish<br><br>them--even so, Queequeg, for his own private reasons, preferred his<br><br>own harpoon.<br><br><br><br>Shifting the barrow from my hand to his, he told me a funny story<br><br>about the first wheelbarrow he had ever seen.  It was in Sag Harbor.<br><br>The owners of his ship, it seems, had lent him one, in which to carry<br><br>his heavy chest to his boarding house.  Not to seem ignorant about<br><br>the thing--though in truth he was entirely so, concerning the precise<br><br>way in which to manage the barrow--Queequeg puts his chest upon it;<br><br>lashes it fast; and then shoulders the barrow and marches up the<br><br>wharf.  "Why," said I, "Queequeg, you might have known better than<br><br>that, one would think.  Didn't the people laugh?"<br><br><br><br>Upon this, he told me another story.  The people of his island of<br><br>Rokovoko, it seems, at their wedding feasts express the fragrant<br><br>water of young cocoanuts into a large stained calabash like a<br><br>punchbowl; and this punchbowl always forms the great central ornament<br><br>on the braided mat where the feast is held.  Now a certain grand<br><br>merchant ship once touched at Rokovoko, and its commander--from all<br><br>accounts, a very stately punctilious gentleman, at least for a sea<br><br>captain--this commander was invited to the wedding feast of<br><br>Queequeg's sister, a pretty young princess just turned of ten.  Well;<br><br>when all the wedding guests were assembled at the bride's bamboo<br><br>cottage, this Captain marches in, and being assigned the post of<br><br>honour, placed himself over against the punchbowl, and between the<br><br>High Priest and his majesty the King, Queequeg's father.  Grace being<br><br>said,--for those people have their grace as well as we--though<br><br>Queequeg told me that unlike us, who at such times look downwards to<br><br>our platters, they, on the contrary, copying the ducks, glance<br><br>upwards to the great Giver of all feasts--Grace, I say, being said,<br><br>the High Priest opens the banquet by the immemorial ceremony of the<br><br>island; that is, dipping his consecrated and consecrating fingers<br><br>into the bowl before the blessed beverage circulates.  Seeing himself<br><br>placed next the Priest, and noting the ceremony, and thinking<br><br>himself--being Captain of a ship--as having plain precedence over a<br><br>mere island King, especially in the King's own house--the Captain<br><br>coolly proceeds to wash his hands in the punchbowl;--taking it I<br><br>suppose for a huge finger-glass.  "Now," said Queequeg, "what you<br><br>tink now?--Didn't our people laugh?"<br><br><br><br>At last, passage paid, and luggage safe, we stood on board the<br><br>schooner.  Hoisting sail, it glided down the Acushnet river.  On one<br><br>side, New Bedford rose in terraces of streets, their ice-covered<br><br>trees all glittering in the clear, cold air.  Huge hills and<br><br>mountains of casks on casks were piled upon her wharves, and side by<br><br>side the world-wandering whale ships lay silent and safely moored at<br><br>last; while from others came a sound of carpenters and coopers, with<br><br>blended noises of fires and forges to melt the pitch, all betokening<br><br>that new cruises were on the start; that one most perilous and long<br><br>voyage ended, only begins a second; and a second ended, only begins a<br><br>third, and so on, for ever and for aye.  Such is the endlessness,<br><br>yea, the intolerableness of all earthly effort.<br><br><br><br>Gaining the more open water, the bracing breeze waxed fresh; the<br><br>little Moss tossed the quick foam from her bows, as a young colt his<br><br>snortings.  How I snuffed that Tartar air!--how I spurned that<br><br>turnpike earth!--that common highway all over dented with the marks<br><br>of slavish heels and hoofs; and turned me to admire the magnanimity<br><br>of the sea which will permit no records.<br><br><br><br>At the same foam-fountain, Queequeg seemed to drink and reel with me.<br><br>His dusky nostrils swelled apart; he showed his filed and pointed<br><br>teeth.  On, on we flew; and our offing gained, the Moss did homage to<br><br>the blast; ducked and dived her bows as a slave before the Sultan.<br><br>Sideways leaning, we sideways darted; every ropeyarn tingling like a<br><br>wire; the two tall masts buckling like Indian canes in land<br><br>tornadoes.  So full of this reeling scene were we, as we stood by the<br><br>plunging bowsprit, that for some time we did not notice the jeering<br><br>glances of the passengers, a lubber-like assembly, who marvelled that<br><br>two fellow beings should be so companionable; as though a white man<br><br>were anything more dignified than a whitewashed negro.  But there<br><br>were some boobies and bumpkins there, who, by their intense<br><br>greenness, must have come from the heart and centre of all verdure.<br><br>Queequeg caught one of these young saplings mimicking him behind his<br><br>back.  I thought the bumpkin's hour of doom was come.  Dropping his<br><br>harpoon, the brawny savage caught him in his arms, and by an almost<br><br>miraculous dexterity and strength, sent him high up bodily into the<br><br>air; then slightly tapping his stern in mid-somerset, the fellow<br><br>landed with bursting lungs upon his feet, while Queequeg, turning his<br><br>back upon him, lighted his tomahawk pipe and passed it to me for a<br><br>puff.<br><br><br><br>"Capting!  Capting! yelled the bumpkin, running towards that officer;<br><br>"Capting, Capting, here's the devil."<br><br><br><br>"Hallo, YOU sir," cried the Captain, a gaunt rib of the sea, stalking<br><br>up to Queequeg, "what in thunder do you mean by that?  Don't you know<br><br>you might have killed that chap?"<br><br><br><br>"What him say?" said Queequeg, as he mildly turned to me.<br><br><br><br>"He say," said I, "that you came near kill-e that man there,"<br><br>pointing to the still shivering greenhorn.<br><br><br><br>"Kill-e," cried Queequeg, twisting his tattooed face into an<br><br>unearthly expression of disdain, "ah! him bevy small-e fish-e;<br><br>Queequeg no kill-e so small-e fish-e; Queequeg kill-e big whale!"<br><br><br><br>"Look you," roared the Captain, "I'll kill-e YOU, you cannibal, if<br><br>you try any more of your tricks aboard here; so mind your eye."<br><br><br><br>But it so happened just then, that it was high time for the Captain<br><br>to mind his own eye.  The prodigious strain upon the main-sail had<br><br>parted the weather-sheet, and the tremendous boom was now flying from<br><br>side to side, completely sweeping the entire after part of the deck.<br><br>The poor fellow whom Queequeg had handled so roughly, was swept<br><br>overboard; all hands were in a panic; and to attempt snatching at the<br><br>boom to stay it, seemed madness.  It flew from right to left, and<br><br>back again, almost in one ticking of a watch, and every instant<br><br>seemed on the point of snapping into splinters.  Nothing was done,<br><br>and nothing seemed capable of being done; those on deck rushed<br><br>towards the bows, and stood eyeing the boom as if it were the lower<br><br>jaw of an exasperated whale.  In the midst of this consternation,<br><br>Queequeg dropped deftly to his knees, and crawling under the path of<br><br>the boom, whipped hold of a rope, secured one end to the bulwarks,<br><br>and then flinging the other like a lasso, caught it round the boom as<br><br>it swept over his head, and at the next jerk, the spar was that way<br><br>trapped, and all was safe.  The schooner was run into the wind, and<br><br>while the hands were clearing away the stern boat, Queequeg, stripped<br><br>to the waist, darted from the side with a long living arc of a leap.<br><br>For three minutes or more he was seen swimming like a dog, throwing<br><br>his long arms straight out before him, and by turns revealing his<br><br>brawny shoulders through the freezing foam.  I looked at the grand<br><br>and glorious fellow, but saw no one to be saved.  The greenhorn had<br><br>gone down.  Shooting himself perpendicularly from the water,<br><br>Queequeg, now took an instant's glance around him, and seeming to see<br><br>just how matters were, dived down and disappeared.  A few minutes<br><br>more, and he rose again, one arm still striking out, and with the<br><br>other dragging a lifeless form.  The boat soon picked them up.  The<br><br>poor bumpkin was restored.  All hands voted Queequeg a noble trump;<br><br>the captain begged his pardon.  From that hour I clove to Queequeg<br><br>like a barnacle; yea, till poor Queequeg took his last long dive.<br><br><br><br>Was there ever such unconsciousness?  He did not seem to think that<br><br>he at all deserved a medal from the Humane and Magnanimous Societies.<br><br>He only asked for water--fresh water--something to wipe the brine<br><br>off; that done, he put on dry clothes, lighted his pipe, and leaning<br><br>against the bulwarks, and mildly eyeing those around him, seemed to<br><br>be saying to himself--"It's a mutual, joint-stock world, in all<br><br>meridians.  We cannibals must help these Christians."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 14<br><br><br><br>Nantucket.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Nothing more happened on the passage worthy the mentioning; so, after<br><br>a fine run, we safely arrived in Nantucket.<br><br><br><br>Nantucket!  Take out your map and look at it.  See what a real corner<br><br>of the world it occupies; how it stands there, away off shore, more<br><br>lonely than the Eddystone lighthouse.  Look at it--a mere hillock,<br><br>and elbow of sand; all beach, without a background.  There is more<br><br>sand there than you would use in twenty years as a substitute for<br><br>blotting paper.  Some gamesome wights will tell you that they have to<br><br>plant weeds there, they don't grow naturally; that they import Canada<br><br>thistles; that they have to send beyond seas for a spile to stop a<br><br>leak in an oil cask; that pieces of wood in Nantucket are carried<br><br>about like bits of the true cross in Rome; that people there plant<br><br>toadstools before their houses, to get under the shade in summer<br><br>time; that one blade of grass makes an oasis, three blades in a day's<br><br>walk a prairie; that they wear quicksand shoes, something like<br><br>Laplander snow-shoes; that they are so shut up, belted about, every<br><br>way inclosed, surrounded, and made an utter island of by the ocean,<br><br>that to their very chairs and tables small clams will sometimes be<br><br>found adhering, as to the backs of sea turtles.  But these<br><br>extravaganzas only show that Nantucket is no Illinois.<br><br><br><br>Look now at the wondrous traditional story of how this island was<br><br>settled by the red-men.  Thus goes the legend.  In olden times an<br><br>eagle swooped down upon the New England coast, and carried off an<br><br>infant Indian in his talons.  With loud lament the parents saw their<br><br>child borne out of sight over the wide waters.  They resolved to<br><br>follow in the same direction.  Setting out in their canoes, after a<br><br>perilous passage they discovered the island, and there they found an<br><br>empty ivory casket,--the poor little Indian's skeleton.<br><br><br><br>What wonder, then, that these Nantucketers, born on a beach, should<br><br>take to the sea for a livelihood!  They first caught crabs and<br><br>quohogs in the sand; grown bolder, they waded out with nets for<br><br>mackerel; more experienced, they pushed off in boats and captured<br><br>cod; and at last, launching a navy of great ships on the sea,<br><br>explored this watery world; put an incessant belt of<br><br>circumnavigations round it; peeped in at Behring's Straits; and in<br><br>all seasons and all oceans declared everlasting war with the<br><br>mightiest animated mass that has survived the flood; most monstrous<br><br>and most mountainous!  That Himmalehan, salt-sea Mastodon, clothed<br><br>with such portentousness of unconscious power, that his very panics<br><br>are more to be dreaded than his most fearless and malicious assaults!<br><br><br><br>And thus have these naked Nantucketers, these sea hermits, issuing<br><br>from their ant-hill in the sea, overrun and conquered the watery<br><br>world like so many Alexanders; parcelling out among them the<br><br>Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian oceans, as the three pirate powers did<br><br>Poland.  Let America add Mexico to Texas, and pile Cuba upon Canada;<br><br>let the English overswarm all India, and hang out their blazing<br><br>banner from the sun; two thirds of this terraqueous globe are the<br><br>Nantucketer's.  For the sea is his; he owns it, as Emperors own<br><br>empires; other seamen having but a right of way through it.  Merchant<br><br>ships are but extension bridges; armed ones but floating forts; even<br><br>pirates and privateers, though following the sea as highwaymen the<br><br>road, they but plunder other ships, other fragments of the land like<br><br>themselves, without seeking to draw their living from the bottomless<br><br>deep itself.  The Nantucketer, he alone resides and riots on the sea;<br><br>he alone, in Bible language, goes down to it in ships; to and fro<br><br>ploughing it as his own special plantation.  THERE is his home; THERE<br><br>lies his business, which a Noah's flood would not interrupt, though<br><br>it overwhelmed all the millions in China.  He lives on the sea, as<br><br>prairie cocks in the prairie; he hides among the waves, he climbs<br><br>them as chamois hunters climb the Alps.  For years he knows not the<br><br>land; so that when he comes to it at last, it smells like another<br><br>world, more strangely than the moon would to an Earthsman.  With the<br><br>landless gull, that at sunset folds her wings and is rocked to sleep<br><br>between billows; so at nightfall, the Nantucketer, out of sight of<br><br>land, furls his sails, and lays him to his rest, while under his very<br><br>pillow rush herds of walruses and whales.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 15<br><br><br><br>Chowder.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It was quite late in the evening when the little Moss came snugly to<br><br>anchor, and Queequeg and I went ashore; so we could attend to no<br><br>business that day, at least none but a supper and a bed.  The<br><br>landlord of the Spouter-Inn had recommended us to his cousin Hosea<br><br>Hussey of the Try Pots, whom he asserted to be the proprietor of one<br><br>of the best kept hotels in all Nantucket, and moreover he had assured<br><br>us that Cousin Hosea, as he called him, was famous for his chowders.<br><br>In short, he plainly hinted that we could not possibly do better than<br><br>try pot-luck at the Try Pots.  But the directions he had given us<br><br>about keeping a yellow warehouse on our starboard hand till we opened<br><br>a white church to the larboard, and then keeping that on the larboard<br><br>hand till we made a corner three points to the starboard, and that<br><br>done, then ask the first man we met where the place was: these<br><br>crooked directions of his very much puzzled us at first, especially<br><br>as, at the outset, Queequeg insisted that the yellow warehouse--our<br><br>first point of departure--must be left on the larboard hand, whereas<br><br>I had understood Peter Coffin to say it was on the starboard.<br><br>However, by dint of beating about a little in the dark, and now and<br><br>then knocking up a peaceable inhabitant to inquire the way, we at<br><br>last came to something which there was no mistaking.<br><br><br><br>Two enormous wooden pots painted black, and suspended by asses' ears,<br><br>swung from the cross-trees of an old top-mast, planted in front of an<br><br>old doorway.  The horns of the cross-trees were sawed off on the<br><br>other side, so that this old top-mast looked not a little like a<br><br>gallows.  Perhaps I was over sensitive to such impressions at the<br><br>time, but I could not help staring at this gallows with a vague<br><br>misgiving.  A sort of crick was in my neck as I gazed up to the two<br><br>remaining horns; yes, TWO of them, one for Queequeg, and one for me.<br><br>It's ominous, thinks I.  A Coffin my Innkeeper upon landing in my<br><br>first whaling port; tombstones staring at me in the whalemen's<br><br>chapel; and here a gallows! and a pair of prodigious black pots too!<br><br>Are these last throwing out oblique hints touching Tophet?<br><br><br><br>I was called from these reflections by the sight of a freckled woman<br><br>with yellow hair and a yellow gown, standing in the porch of the inn,<br><br>under a dull red lamp swinging there, that looked much like an<br><br>injured eye, and carrying on a brisk scolding with a man in a purple<br><br>woollen shirt.<br><br><br><br>"Get along with ye," said she to the man, "or I'll be combing ye!"<br><br><br><br>"Come on, Queequeg," said I, "all right.  There's Mrs. Hussey."<br><br><br><br>And so it turned out; Mr. Hosea Hussey being from home, but leaving<br><br>Mrs. Hussey entirely competent to attend to all his affairs.  Upon<br><br>making known our desires for a supper and a bed, Mrs. Hussey,<br><br>postponing further scolding for the present, ushered us into a little<br><br>room, and seating us at a table spread with the relics of a recently<br><br>concluded repast, turned round to us and said--"Clam or Cod?"<br><br><br><br>"What's that about Cods, ma'am?" said I, with much politeness.<br><br><br><br>"Clam or Cod?" she repeated.<br><br><br><br>"A clam for supper? a cold clam; is THAT what you mean, Mrs. Hussey?"<br><br>says I, "but that's a rather cold and clammy reception in the winter<br><br>time, ain't it, Mrs. Hussey?"<br><br><br><br>But being in a great hurry to resume scolding the man in the purple<br><br>Shirt, who was waiting for it in the entry, and seeming to hear<br><br>nothing but the word "clam," Mrs. Hussey hurried towards an open door<br><br>leading to the kitchen, and bawling out "clam for two," disappeared.<br><br><br><br>"Queequeg," said I, "do you think that we can make out a supper for<br><br>us both on one clam?"<br><br><br><br>However, a warm savory steam from the kitchen served to belie the<br><br>apparently cheerless prospect before us.  But when that smoking<br><br>chowder came in, the mystery was delightfully explained.  Oh, sweet<br><br>friends! hearken to me.  It was made of small juicy clams, scarcely<br><br>bigger than hazel nuts, mixed with pounded ship biscuit, and salted<br><br>pork cut up into little flakes; the whole enriched with butter, and<br><br>plentifully seasoned with pepper and salt.  Our appetites being<br><br>sharpened by the frosty voyage, and in particular, Queequeg seeing<br><br>his favourite fishing food before him, and the chowder being<br><br>surpassingly excellent, we despatched it with great expedition: when<br><br>leaning back a moment and bethinking me of Mrs. Hussey's clam and cod<br><br>announcement, I thought I would try a little experiment.  Stepping to<br><br>the kitchen door, I uttered the word "cod" with great emphasis, and<br><br>resumed my seat.  In a few moments the savoury steam came forth<br><br>again, but with a different flavor, and in good time a fine<br><br>cod-chowder was placed before us.<br><br><br><br>We resumed business; and while plying our spoons in the bowl, thinks<br><br>I to myself, I wonder now if this here has any effect on the head?<br><br>What's that stultifying saying about chowder-headed people?  "But<br><br>look, Queequeg, ain't that a live eel in your bowl?  Where's your<br><br>harpoon?"<br><br><br><br>Fishiest of all fishy places was the Try Pots, which well deserved<br><br>its name; for the pots there were always boiling chowders.  Chowder<br><br>for breakfast, and chowder for dinner, and chowder for supper, till<br><br>you began to look for fish-bones coming through your clothes.  The<br><br>area before the house was paved with clam-shells.  Mrs. Hussey wore a<br><br>polished necklace of codfish vertebra; and Hosea Hussey had his<br><br>account books bound in superior old shark-skin.  There was a fishy<br><br>flavor to the milk, too, which I could not at all account for, till<br><br>one morning happening to take a stroll along the beach among some<br><br>fishermen's boats, I saw Hosea's brindled cow feeding on fish<br><br>remnants, and marching along the sand with each foot in a cod's<br><br>decapitated head, looking very slip-shod, I assure ye.<br><br><br><br>Supper concluded, we received a lamp, and directions from Mrs. Hussey<br><br>concerning the nearest way to bed; but, as Queequeg was about to<br><br>precede me up the stairs, the lady reached forth her arm, and<br><br>demanded his harpoon; she allowed no harpoon in her chambers.  "Why<br><br>not? said I; "every true whaleman sleeps with his harpoon--but why<br><br>not?"  "Because it's dangerous," says she.  "Ever since young Stiggs<br><br>coming from that unfort'nt v'y'ge of his, when he was gone four years<br><br>and a half, with only three barrels of ILE, was found dead in my<br><br>first floor back, with his harpoon in his side; ever since then I<br><br>allow no boarders to take sich dangerous weepons in their rooms at<br><br>night.  So, Mr. Queequeg" (for she had learned his name), "I will<br><br>just take this here iron, and keep it for you till morning.  But the<br><br>chowder; clam or cod to-morrow for breakfast, men?"<br><br><br><br>"Both," says I; "and let's have a couple of smoked herring by way of<br><br>variety."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 16<br><br><br><br>The Ship.<br><br><br><br><br><br>In bed we concocted our plans for the morrow.  But to my surprise and<br><br>no small concern, Queequeg now gave me to understand, that he had<br><br>been diligently consulting Yojo--the name of his black little<br><br>god--and Yojo had told him two or three times over, and strongly<br><br>insisted upon it everyway, that instead of our going together among<br><br>the whaling-fleet in harbor, and in concert selecting our craft;<br><br>instead of this, I say, Yojo earnestly enjoined that the selection of<br><br>the ship should rest wholly with me, inasmuch as Yojo purposed<br><br>befriending us; and, in order to do so, had already pitched upon a<br><br>vessel, which, if left to myself, I, Ishmael, should infallibly light<br><br>upon, for all the world as though it had turned out by chance; and in<br><br>that vessel I must immediately ship myself, for the present<br><br>irrespective of Queequeg.<br><br><br><br>I have forgotten to mention that, in many things, Queequeg placed<br><br>great confidence in the excellence of Yojo's judgment and surprising<br><br>forecast of things; and cherished Yojo with considerable esteem, as a<br><br>rather good sort of god, who perhaps meant well enough upon the<br><br>whole, but in all cases did not succeed in his benevolent designs.<br><br><br><br>Now, this plan of Queequeg's, or rather Yojo's, touching the<br><br>selection of our craft; I did not like that plan at all.  I had not a<br><br>little relied upon Queequeg's sagacity to point out the whaler best<br><br>fitted to carry us and our fortunes securely.  But as all my<br><br>remonstrances produced no effect upon Queequeg, I was obliged to<br><br>acquiesce; and accordingly prepared to set about this business with a<br><br>determined rushing sort of energy and vigor, that should quickly<br><br>settle that trifling little affair.
