Next morning early, leaving<br><br>Queequeg shut up with Yojo in our little bedroom--for it seemed that<br><br>it was some sort of Lent or Ramadan, or day of fasting, humiliation,<br><br>and prayer with Queequeg and Yojo that day; HOW it was I never could<br><br>find out, for, though I applied myself to it several times, I never<br><br>could master his liturgies and XXXIX Articles--leaving Queequeg,<br><br>then, fasting on his tomahawk pipe, and Yojo warming himself at his<br><br>sacrificial fire of shavings, I sallied out among the shipping.<br><br>After much prolonged sauntering and many random inquiries, I learnt<br><br>that there were three ships up for three-years' voyages--The<br><br>Devil-dam, the Tit-bit, and the Pequod.  DEVIL-DAM, I do not know<br><br>the origin of; TIT-BIT is obvious; PEQUOD, you will no doubt<br><br>remember, was the name of a celebrated tribe of Massachusetts<br><br>Indians; now extinct as the ancient Medes.  I peered and pryed about<br><br>the Devil-dam; from her, hopped over to the Tit-bit; and finally,<br><br>going on board the Pequod, looked around her for a moment, and then<br><br>decided that this was the very ship for us.<br><br><br><br>You may have seen many a quaint craft in your day, for aught I<br><br>know;--square-toed luggers; mountainous Japanese junks; butter-box<br><br>galliots, and what not; but take my word for it, you never saw such a<br><br>rare old craft as this same rare old Pequod.  She was a ship of the<br><br>old school, rather small if anything; with an old-fashioned<br><br>claw-footed look about her.  Long seasoned and weather-stained in the<br><br>typhoons and calms of all four oceans, her old hull's complexion was<br><br>darkened like a French grenadier's, who has alike fought in Egypt and<br><br>Siberia.  Her venerable bows looked bearded.  Her masts--cut<br><br>somewhere on the coast of Japan, where her original ones were lost<br><br>overboard in a gale--her masts stood stiffly up like the spines of<br><br>the three old kings of Cologne.  Her ancient decks were worn and<br><br>wrinkled, like the pilgrim-worshipped flag-stone in Canterbury<br><br>Cathedral where Becket bled.  But to all these her old antiquities,<br><br>were added new and marvellous features, pertaining to the wild<br><br>business that for more than half a century she had followed.  Old<br><br>Captain Peleg, many years her chief-mate, before he commanded another<br><br>vessel of his own, and now a retired seaman, and one of the principal<br><br>owners of the Pequod,--this old Peleg, during the term of his<br><br>chief-mateship, had built upon her original grotesqueness, and inlaid<br><br>it, all over, with a quaintness both of material and device,<br><br>unmatched by anything except it be Thorkill-Hake's carved buckler or<br><br>bedstead.  She was apparelled like any barbaric Ethiopian emperor,<br><br>his neck heavy with pendants of polished ivory.  She was a thing of<br><br>trophies.  A cannibal of a craft, tricking herself forth in the<br><br>chased bones of her enemies.  All round, her unpanelled, open<br><br>bulwarks were garnished like one continuous jaw, with the long sharp<br><br>teeth of the sperm whale, inserted there for pins, to fasten her old<br><br>hempen thews and tendons to.  Those thews ran not through base blocks<br><br>of land wood, but deftly travelled over sheaves of sea-ivory.<br><br>Scorning a turnstile wheel at her reverend helm, she sported there a<br><br>tiller; and that tiller was in one mass, curiously carved from the<br><br>long narrow lower jaw of her hereditary foe.  The helmsman who<br><br>steered by that tiller in a tempest, felt like the Tartar, when he<br><br>holds back his fiery steed by clutching its jaw.  A noble craft, but<br><br>somehow a most melancholy!  All noble things are touched with that.<br><br><br><br>Now when I looked about the quarter-deck, for some one having<br><br>authority, in order to propose myself as a candidate for the voyage,<br><br>at first I saw nobody; but I could not well overlook a strange sort<br><br>of tent, or rather wigwam, pitched a little behind the main-mast.  It<br><br>seemed only a temporary erection used in port.  It was of a conical<br><br>shape, some ten feet high; consisting of the long, huge slabs of<br><br>limber black bone taken from the middle and highest part of the jaws<br><br>of the right-whale.  Planted with their broad ends on the deck, a<br><br>circle of these slabs laced together, mutually sloped towards each<br><br>other, and at the apex united in a tufted point, where the loose<br><br>hairy fibres waved to and fro like the top-knot on some old<br><br>Pottowottamie Sachem's head.  A triangular opening faced towards the<br><br>bows of the ship, so that the insider commanded a complete view<br><br>forward.<br><br><br><br>And half concealed in this queer tenement, I at length found one who<br><br>by his aspect seemed to have authority; and who, it being noon, and<br><br>the ship's work suspended, was now enjoying respite from the burden<br><br>of command.  He was seated on an old-fashioned oaken chair, wriggling<br><br>all over with curious carving; and the bottom of which was formed of<br><br>a stout interlacing of the same elastic stuff of which the wigwam was<br><br>constructed.<br><br><br><br>There was nothing so very particular, perhaps, about the appearance<br><br>of the elderly man I saw; he was brown and brawny, like most old<br><br>seamen, and heavily rolled up in blue pilot-cloth, cut in the Quaker<br><br>style; only there was a fine and almost microscopic net-work of the<br><br>minutest wrinkles interlacing round his eyes, which must have arisen<br><br>from his continual sailings in many hard gales, and always looking to<br><br>windward;--for this causes the muscles about the eyes to become<br><br>pursed together.  Such eye-wrinkles are very effectual in a scowl.<br><br><br><br>"Is this the Captain of the Pequod?" said I, advancing to the door of<br><br>the tent.<br><br><br><br>"Supposing it be the captain of the Pequod, what dost thou want of<br><br>him?" he demanded.<br><br><br><br>"I was thinking of shipping."<br><br><br><br>"Thou wast, wast thou?  I see thou art no Nantucketer--ever been in<br><br>a stove boat?"<br><br><br><br>"No, Sir, I never have."<br><br><br><br>"Dost know nothing at all about whaling, I dare say--eh?<br><br><br><br>"Nothing, Sir; but I have no doubt I shall soon learn.  I've been<br><br>several voyages in the merchant service, and I think that--"<br><br><br><br>"Merchant service be damned.  Talk not that lingo to me.  Dost see<br><br>that leg?--I'll take that leg away from thy stern, if ever thou<br><br>talkest of the marchant service to me again.  Marchant service<br><br>indeed!  I suppose now ye feel considerable proud of having served in<br><br>those marchant ships.  But flukes! man, what makes thee want to go a<br><br>whaling, eh?--it looks a little suspicious, don't it, eh?--Hast not<br><br>been a pirate, hast thou?--Didst not rob thy last Captain, didst<br><br>thou?--Dost not think of murdering the officers when thou gettest to<br><br>sea?"<br><br><br><br>I protested my innocence of these things.  I saw that under the mask<br><br>of these half humorous innuendoes, this old seaman, as an insulated<br><br>Quakerish Nantucketer, was full of his insular prejudices, and rather<br><br>distrustful of all aliens, unless they hailed from Cape Cod or the<br><br>Vineyard.<br><br><br><br>"But what takes thee a-whaling?  I want to know that before I think<br><br>of shipping ye."<br><br><br><br>"Well, sir, I want to see what whaling is.  I want to see the world."<br><br><br><br>"Want to see what whaling is, eh?  Have ye clapped eye on Captain<br><br>Ahab?"<br><br><br><br>"Who is Captain Ahab, sir?"<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye, I thought so.  Captain Ahab is the Captain of this ship."<br><br><br><br>"I am mistaken then.  I thought I was speaking to the Captain<br><br>himself."<br><br><br><br>"Thou art speaking to Captain Peleg--that's who ye are speaking to,<br><br>young man.  It belongs to me and Captain Bildad to see the Pequod<br><br>fitted out for the voyage, and supplied with all her needs, including<br><br>crew.  We are part owners and agents.  But as I was going to say, if<br><br>thou wantest to know what whaling is, as thou tellest ye do, I can<br><br>put ye in a way of finding it out before ye bind yourself to it, past<br><br>backing out.  Clap eye on Captain Ahab, young man, and thou wilt find<br><br>that he has only one leg."<br><br><br><br>"What do you mean, sir?  Was the other one lost by a whale?"<br><br><br><br>"Lost by a whale!  Young man, come nearer to me: it was devoured,<br><br>chewed up, crunched by the monstrousest parmacetty that ever chipped<br><br>a boat!--ah, ah!"<br><br><br><br>I was a little alarmed by his energy, perhaps also a little touched<br><br>at the hearty grief in his concluding exclamation, but said as calmly<br><br>as I could, "What you say is no doubt true enough, sir; but how could<br><br>I know there was any peculiar ferocity in that particular whale,<br><br>though indeed I might have inferred as much from the simple fact of<br><br>the accident."<br><br><br><br>"Look ye now, young man, thy lungs are a sort of soft, d'ye see; thou<br><br>dost not talk shark a bit.  SURE, ye've been to sea before now; sure<br><br>of that?"<br><br><br><br>"Sir," said I, "I thought I told you that I had been four voyages in<br><br>the merchant--"<br><br><br><br>"Hard down out of that!  Mind what I said about the marchant<br><br>service--don't aggravate me--I won't have it.  But let us understand<br><br>each other.  I have given thee a hint about what whaling is; do ye<br><br>yet feel inclined for it?"<br><br><br><br>"I do, sir."<br><br><br><br>"Very good.  Now, art thou the man to pitch a harpoon down a live<br><br>whale's throat, and then jump after it?  Answer, quick!"<br><br><br><br>"I am, sir, if it should be positively indispensable to do so; not to<br><br>be got rid of, that is; which I don't take to be the fact."<br><br><br><br>"Good again.  Now then, thou not only wantest to go a-whaling, to<br><br>find out by experience what whaling is, but ye also want to go in<br><br>order to see the world?  Was not that what ye said?  I thought so.<br><br>Well then, just step forward there, and take a peep over the<br><br>weather-bow, and then back to me and tell me what ye see there."<br><br><br><br>For a moment I stood a little puzzled by this curious request, not<br><br>knowing exactly how to take it, whether humorously or in earnest.<br><br>But concentrating all his crow's feet into one scowl, Captain Peleg<br><br>started me on the errand.<br><br><br><br>Going forward and glancing over the weather bow, I perceived that the<br><br>ship swinging to her anchor with the flood-tide, was now obliquely<br><br>pointing towards the open ocean.  The prospect was unlimited, but<br><br>exceedingly monotonous and forbidding; not the slightest variety that<br><br>I could see.<br><br><br><br>"Well, what's the report?" said Peleg when I came back; "what did ye<br><br>see?"<br><br><br><br>"Not much," I replied--"nothing but water; considerable horizon<br><br>though, and there's a squall coming up, I think."<br><br><br><br>"Well, what does thou think then of seeing the world?  Do ye wish to<br><br>go round Cape Horn to see any more of it, eh?  Can't ye see the world<br><br>where you stand?"<br><br><br><br>I was a little staggered, but go a-whaling I must, and I would; and<br><br>the Pequod was as good a ship as any--I thought the best--and all<br><br>this I now repeated to Peleg.  Seeing me so determined, he expressed<br><br>his willingness to ship me.<br><br><br><br>"And thou mayest as well sign the papers right off," he added--"come<br><br>along with ye."  And so saying, he led the way below deck into the<br><br>cabin.<br><br><br><br>Seated on the transom was what seemed to me a most uncommon and<br><br>surprising figure.  It turned out to be Captain Bildad, who along<br><br>with Captain Peleg was one of the largest owners of the vessel; the<br><br>other shares, as is sometimes the case in these ports, being held by<br><br>a crowd of old annuitants; widows, fatherless children, and chancery<br><br>wards; each owning about the value of a timber head, or a foot of<br><br>plank, or a nail or two in the ship.  People in Nantucket invest<br><br>their money in whaling vessels, the same way that you do yours in<br><br>approved state stocks bringing in good interest.<br><br><br><br>Now, Bildad, like Peleg, and indeed many other Nantucketers, was a<br><br>Quaker, the island having been originally settled by that sect; and<br><br>to this day its inhabitants in general retain in an uncommon measure<br><br>the peculiarities of the Quaker, only variously and anomalously<br><br>modified by things altogether alien and heterogeneous.  For some of<br><br>these same Quakers are the most sanguinary of all sailors and<br><br>whale-hunters.  They are fighting Quakers; they are Quakers with a<br><br>vengeance.<br><br><br><br>So that there are instances among them of men, who, named with<br><br>Scripture names--a singularly common fashion on the island--and in<br><br>childhood naturally imbibing the stately dramatic thee and thou of<br><br>the Quaker idiom; still, from the audacious, daring, and boundless<br><br>adventure of their subsequent lives, strangely blend with these<br><br>unoutgrown peculiarities, a thousand bold dashes of character, not<br><br>unworthy a Scandinavian sea-king, or a poetical Pagan Roman.  And<br><br>when these things unite in a man of greatly superior natural force,<br><br>with a globular brain and a ponderous heart; who has also by the<br><br>stillness and seclusion of many long night-watches in the remotest<br><br>waters, and beneath constellations never seen here at the north, been<br><br>led to think untraditionally and independently; receiving all<br><br>nature's sweet or savage impressions fresh from her own virgin<br><br>voluntary and confiding breast, and thereby chiefly, but with some<br><br>help from accidental advantages, to learn a bold and nervous lofty<br><br>language--that man makes one in a whole nation's census--a mighty<br><br>pageant creature, formed for noble tragedies.  Nor will it at all<br><br>detract from him, dramatically regarded, if either by birth or other<br><br>circumstances, he have what seems a half wilful overruling morbidness<br><br>at the bottom of his nature.  For all men tragically great are made<br><br>so through a certain morbidness.  Be sure of this, O young ambition,<br><br>all mortal greatness is but disease.  But, as yet we have not to do<br><br>with such an one, but with quite another; and still a man, who, if<br><br>indeed peculiar, it only results again from another phase of the<br><br>Quaker, modified by individual circumstances.<br><br><br><br>Like Captain Peleg, Captain Bildad was a well-to-do, retired<br><br>whaleman.  But unlike Captain Peleg--who cared not a rush for what<br><br>are called serious things, and indeed deemed those self-same serious<br><br>things the veriest of all trifles--Captain Bildad had not only been<br><br>originally educated according to the strictest sect of Nantucket<br><br>Quakerism, but all his subsequent ocean life, and the sight of many<br><br>unclad, lovely island creatures, round the Horn--all that had not<br><br>moved this native born Quaker one single jot, had not so much as<br><br>altered one angle of his vest.  Still, for all this immutableness,<br><br>was there some lack of common consistency about worthy Captain<br><br>Peleg.  Though refusing, from conscientious scruples, to bear arms<br><br>against land invaders, yet himself had illimitably invaded the<br><br>Atlantic and Pacific; and though a sworn foe to human bloodshed, yet<br><br>had he in his straight-bodied coat, spilled tuns upon tuns of<br><br>leviathan gore.  How now in the contemplative evening of his days,<br><br>the pious Bildad reconciled these things in the reminiscence, I do<br><br>not know; but it did not seem to concern him much, and very probably<br><br>he had long since come to the sage and sensible conclusion that a<br><br>man's religion is one thing, and this practical world quite another.<br><br>This world pays dividends.  Rising from a little cabin-boy in short<br><br>clothes of the drabbest drab, to a harpooneer in a broad shad-bellied<br><br>waistcoat; from that becoming boat-header, chief-mate, and captain,<br><br>and finally a ship owner; Bildad, as I hinted before, had concluded<br><br>his adventurous career by wholly retiring from active life at the<br><br>goodly age of sixty, and dedicating his remaining days to the quiet<br><br>receiving of his well-earned income.<br><br><br><br>Now, Bildad, I am sorry to say, had the reputation of being an<br><br>incorrigible old hunks, and in his sea-going days, a bitter, hard<br><br>task-master.  They told me in Nantucket, though it certainly seems a<br><br>curious story, that when he sailed the old Categut whaleman, his<br><br>crew, upon arriving home, were mostly all carried ashore to the<br><br>hospital, sore exhausted and worn out.  For a pious man, especially<br><br>for a Quaker, he was certainly rather hard-hearted, to say the<br><br>least.  He never used to swear, though, at his men, they said; but<br><br>somehow he got an inordinate quantity of cruel, unmitigated hard work<br><br>out of them.  When Bildad was a chief-mate, to have his drab-coloured<br><br>eye intently looking at you, made you feel completely nervous, till<br><br>you could clutch something--a hammer or a marling-spike, and go to<br><br>work like mad, at something or other, never mind what.  Indolence and<br><br>idleness perished before him.  His own person was the exact<br><br>embodiment of his utilitarian character.  On his long, gaunt body, he<br><br>carried no spare flesh, no superfluous beard, his chin having a soft,<br><br>economical nap to it, like the worn nap of his broad-brimmed hat.<br><br><br><br>Such, then, was the person that I saw seated on the transom when I<br><br>followed Captain Peleg down into the cabin.  The space between the<br><br>decks was small; and there, bolt-upright, sat old Bildad, who always<br><br>sat so, and never leaned, and this to save his coat tails.  His<br><br>broad-brim was placed beside him; his legs were stiffly crossed; his<br><br>drab vesture was buttoned up to his chin; and spectacles on nose, he<br><br>seemed absorbed in reading from a ponderous volume.<br><br><br><br>"Bildad," cried Captain Peleg, "at it again, Bildad, eh?  Ye have<br><br>been studying those Scriptures, now, for the last thirty years, to my<br><br>certain knowledge.  How far ye got, Bildad?"<br><br><br><br>As if long habituated to such profane talk from his old shipmate,<br><br>Bildad, without noticing his present irreverence, quietly looked up,<br><br>and seeing me, glanced again inquiringly towards Peleg.<br><br><br><br>"He says he's our man, Bildad," said Peleg, "he wants to ship."<br><br><br><br>"Dost thee?" said Bildad, in a hollow tone, and turning round to me.<br><br><br><br>"I dost," said I unconsciously, he was so intense a Quaker.<br><br><br><br>"What do ye think of him, Bildad?" said Peleg.<br><br><br><br>"He'll do," said Bildad, eyeing me, and then went on spelling away at<br><br>his book in a mumbling tone quite audible.<br><br><br><br>I thought him the queerest old Quaker I ever saw, especially as<br><br>Peleg, his friend and old shipmate, seemed such a blusterer.  But I<br><br>said nothing, only looking round me sharply.  Peleg now threw open a<br><br>chest, and drawing forth the ship's articles, placed pen and ink<br><br>before him, and seated himself at a little table.  I began to think<br><br>it was high time to settle with myself at what terms I would be<br><br>willing to engage for the voyage.  I was already aware that in the<br><br>whaling business they paid no wages; but all hands, including the<br><br>captain, received certain shares of the profits called lays, and that<br><br>these lays were proportioned to the degree of importance pertaining<br><br>to the respective duties of the ship's company.  I was also aware<br><br>that being a green hand at whaling, my own lay would not be very<br><br>large; but considering that I was used to the sea, could steer a<br><br>ship, splice a rope, and all that, I made no doubt that from all I<br><br>had heard I should be offered at least the 275th lay--that is, the<br><br>275th part of the clear net proceeds of the voyage, whatever that<br><br>might eventually amount to.  And though the 275th lay was what they<br><br>call a rather LONG LAY, yet it was better than nothing; and if we had<br><br>a lucky voyage, might pretty nearly pay for the clothing I would wear<br><br>out on it, not to speak of my three years' beef and board, for which<br><br>I would not have to pay one stiver.<br><br><br><br>It might be thought that this was a poor way to accumulate a princely<br><br>fortune--and so it was, a very poor way indeed.  But I am one of<br><br>those that never take on about princely fortunes, and am quite<br><br>content if the world is ready to board and lodge me, while I am<br><br>putting up at this grim sign of the Thunder Cloud.  Upon the whole, I<br><br>thought that the 275th lay would be about the fair thing, but would not<br><br>have been surprised had I been offered the 200th, considering I was<br><br>of a broad-shouldered make.<br><br><br><br>But one thing, nevertheless, that made me a little distrustful about<br><br>receiving a generous share of the profits was this: Ashore, I had<br><br>heard something of both Captain Peleg and his unaccountable old crony<br><br>Bildad; how that they being the principal proprietors of the Pequod,<br><br>therefore the other and more inconsiderable and scattered owners,<br><br>left nearly the whole management of the ship's affairs to these two.<br><br>And I did not know but what the stingy old Bildad might have a mighty<br><br>deal to say about shipping hands, especially as I now found him on<br><br>board the Pequod, quite at home there in the cabin, and reading his<br><br>Bible as if at his own fireside.  Now while Peleg was vainly trying<br><br>to mend a pen with his jack-knife, old Bildad, to my no small<br><br>surprise, considering that he was such an interested party in these<br><br>proceedings; Bildad never heeded us, but went on mumbling to himself<br><br>out of his book, "LAY not up for yourselves treasures upon earth,<br><br>where moth--"<br><br><br><br>"Well, Captain Bildad," interrupted Peleg, "what d'ye say, what lay<br><br>shall we give this young man?"<br><br><br><br>"Thou knowest best," was the sepulchral reply, "the seven hundred and<br><br>seventy-seventh wouldn't be too much, would it?--'where moth and rust<br><br>do corrupt, but LAY--'"<br><br><br><br>LAY, indeed, thought I, and such a lay! the seven hundred and<br><br>seventy-seventh!  Well, old Bildad, you are determined that I, for<br><br>one, shall not LAY up many LAYS here below, where moth and rust do<br><br>corrupt.  It was an exceedingly LONG LAY that, indeed; and though<br><br>from the magnitude of the figure it might at first deceive a<br><br>landsman, yet the slightest consideration will show that though seven<br><br>hundred and seventy-seven is a pretty large number, yet, when you<br><br>come to make a TEENTH of it, you will then see, I say, that the seven<br><br>hundred and seventy-seventh part of a farthing is a good deal less<br><br>than seven hundred and seventy-seven gold doubloons; and so I thought<br><br>at the time.<br><br><br><br>"Why, blast your eyes, Bildad," cried Peleg, "thou dost not want to<br><br>swindle this young man! he must have more than that."<br><br><br><br>"Seven hundred and seventy-seventh," again said Bildad, without<br><br>lifting his eyes; and then went on mumbling--"for where your treasure<br><br>is, there will your heart be also."<br><br><br><br>"I am going to put him down for the three hundredth," said Peleg, "do<br><br>ye hear that, Bildad!  The three hundredth lay, I say."<br><br><br><br>Bildad laid down his book, and turning solemnly towards him said,<br><br>"Captain Peleg, thou hast a generous heart; but thou must consider<br><br>the duty thou owest to the other owners of this ship--widows and<br><br>orphans, many of them--and that if we too abundantly reward the<br><br>labors of this young man, we may be taking the bread from those<br><br>widows and those orphans.  The seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay,<br><br>Captain Peleg."<br><br><br><br>"Thou Bildad!" roared Peleg, starting up and clattering about the<br><br>cabin.  "Blast ye, Captain Bildad, if I had followed thy advice in<br><br>these matters, I would afore now had a conscience to lug about that<br><br>would be heavy enough to founder the largest ship that ever sailed<br><br>round Cape Horn."<br><br><br><br>"Captain Peleg," said Bildad steadily, "thy conscience may be drawing<br><br>ten inches of water, or ten fathoms, I can't tell; but as thou art<br><br>still an impenitent man, Captain Peleg, I greatly fear lest thy<br><br>conscience be but a leaky one; and will in the end sink thee<br><br>foundering down to the fiery pit, Captain Peleg."<br><br><br><br>"Fiery pit! fiery pit! ye insult me, man; past all natural bearing,<br><br>ye insult me.  It's an all-fired outrage to tell any human creature<br><br>that he's bound to hell.  Flukes and flames!  Bildad, say that again<br><br>to me, and start my soul-bolts, but I'll--I'll--yes, I'll swallow a<br><br>live goat with all his hair and horns on.  Out of the cabin, ye<br><br>canting, drab-coloured son of a wooden gun--a straight wake with ye!"<br><br><br><br>As he thundered out this he made a rush at Bildad, but with a<br><br>marvellous oblique, sliding celerity, Bildad for that time eluded<br><br>him.<br><br><br><br>Alarmed at this terrible outburst between the two principal and<br><br>responsible owners of the ship, and feeling half a mind to give up<br><br>all idea of sailing in a vessel so questionably owned and temporarily<br><br>commanded, I stepped aside from the door to give egress to Bildad,<br><br>who, I made no doubt, was all eagerness to vanish from before the<br><br>awakened wrath of Peleg.  But to my astonishment, he sat down again<br><br>on the transom very quietly, and seemed to have not the slightest<br><br>intention of withdrawing.  He seemed quite used to impenitent Peleg<br><br>and his ways.  As for Peleg, after letting off his rage as he had,<br><br>there seemed no more left in him, and he, too, sat down like a lamb,<br><br>though he twitched a little as if still nervously agitated.  "Whew!"<br><br>he whistled at last--"the squall's gone off to leeward, I think.<br><br>Bildad, thou used to be good at sharpening a lance, mend that pen,<br><br>will ye.  My jack-knife here needs the grindstone.  That's he; thank<br><br>ye, Bildad.  Now then, my young man, Ishmael's thy name, didn't ye<br><br>say?  Well then, down ye go here, Ishmael, for the three hundredth<br><br>lay."<br><br><br><br>"Captain Peleg," said I, "I have a friend with me who wants to ship<br><br>too--shall I bring him down to-morrow?"<br><br><br><br>"To be sure," said Peleg.  "Fetch him along, and we'll look at him."<br><br><br><br>"What lay does he want?" groaned Bildad, glancing up from the book<br><br>in which he had again been burying himself.<br><br><br><br>"Oh! never thee mind about that, Bildad," said Peleg.  "Has he ever<br><br>whaled it any?" turning to me.<br><br><br><br>"Killed more whales than I can count, Captain Peleg."<br><br><br><br>"Well, bring him along then."<br><br><br><br>And, after signing the papers, off I went; nothing doubting but that<br><br>I had done a good morning's work, and that the Pequod was the<br><br>identical ship that Yojo had provided to carry Queequeg and me round<br><br>the Cape.<br><br><br><br>But I had not proceeded far, when I began to bethink me that the<br><br>Captain with whom I was to sail yet remained unseen by me; though,<br><br>indeed, in many cases, a whale-ship will be completely fitted out,<br><br>and receive all her crew on board, ere the captain makes himself<br><br>visible by arriving to take command; for sometimes these voyages are<br><br>so prolonged, and the shore intervals at home so exceedingly brief,<br><br>that if the captain have a family, or any absorbing concernment of<br><br>that sort, he does not trouble himself much about his ship in port,<br><br>but leaves her to the owners till all is ready for sea.  However, it<br><br>is always as well to have a look at him before irrevocably committing<br><br>yourself into his hands.  Turning back I accosted Captain Peleg,<br><br>inquiring where Captain Ahab was to be found.<br><br><br><br>"And what dost thou want of Captain Ahab?  It's all right enough;<br><br>thou art shipped."<br><br><br><br>"Yes, but I should like to see him."<br><br><br><br>"But I don't think thou wilt be able to at present.  I don't know<br><br>exactly what's the matter with him; but he keeps close inside the<br><br>house; a sort of sick, and yet he don't look so.  In fact, he ain't<br><br>sick; but no, he isn't well either.  Any how, young man, he won't<br><br>always see me, so I don't suppose he will thee.  He's a queer man,<br><br>Captain Ahab--so some think--but a good one.  Oh, thou'lt like him<br><br>well enough; no fear, no fear.  He's a grand, ungodly, god-like man,<br><br>Captain Ahab; doesn't speak much; but, when he does speak, then you<br><br>may well listen.  Mark ye, be forewarned; Ahab's above the common;<br><br>Ahab's been in colleges, as well as 'mong the cannibals; been used to<br><br>deeper wonders than the waves; fixed his fiery lance in mightier,<br><br>stranger foes than whales.  His lance! aye, the keenest and the surest<br><br>that out of all our isle!  Oh! he ain't Captain Bildad; no, and he<br><br>ain't Captain Peleg; HE'S AHAB, boy; and Ahab of old, thou knowest,<br><br>was a crowned king!"<br><br><br><br>"And a very vile one.  When that wicked king was slain, the dogs, did<br><br>they not lick his blood?"<br><br><br><br>"Come hither to me--hither, hither," said Peleg, with a significance<br><br>in his eye that almost startled me.  "Look ye, lad; never say that on<br><br>board the Pequod.  Never say it anywhere.  Captain Ahab did not name<br><br>himself.  'Twas a foolish, ignorant whim of his crazy, widowed<br><br>mother, who died when he was only a twelvemonth old.  And yet the old<br><br>squaw Tistig, at Gayhead, said that the name would somehow prove<br><br>prophetic.  And, perhaps, other fools like her may tell thee the<br><br>same.  I wish to warn thee.  It's a lie.  I know Captain Ahab well;<br><br>I've sailed with him as mate years ago; I know what he is--a good<br><br>man--not a pious, good man, like Bildad, but a swearing good<br><br>man--something like me--only there's a good deal more of him.  Aye,<br><br>aye, I know that he was never very jolly; and I know that on the<br><br>passage home, he was a little out of his mind for a spell; but it was<br><br>the sharp shooting pains in his bleeding stump that brought that<br><br>about, as any one might see.  I know, too, that ever since he lost<br><br>his leg last voyage by that accursed whale, he's been a kind of<br><br>moody--desperate moody, and savage sometimes; but that will all pass<br><br>off.  And once for all, let me tell thee and assure thee, young man,<br><br>it's better to sail with a moody good captain than a laughing bad<br><br>one.  So good-bye to thee--and wrong not Captain Ahab, because he<br><br>happens to have a wicked name.  Besides, my boy, he has a wife--not<br><br>three voyages wedded--a sweet, resigned girl.  Think of that; by that<br><br>sweet girl that old man has a child: hold ye then there can be any<br><br>utter, hopeless harm in Ahab?  No, no, my lad; stricken, blasted, if<br><br>he be, Ahab has his humanities!"<br><br><br><br>As I walked away, I was full of thoughtfulness; what had been<br><br>incidentally revealed to me of Captain Ahab, filled me with a certain<br><br>wild vagueness of painfulness concerning him.  And somehow, at the<br><br>time, I felt a sympathy and a sorrow for him, but for I don't know<br><br>what, unless it was the cruel loss of his leg.  And yet I also felt a<br><br>strange awe of him; but that sort of awe, which I cannot at all<br><br>describe, was not exactly awe; I do not know what it was.  But I felt<br><br>it; and it did not disincline me towards him; though I felt<br><br>impatience at what seemed like mystery in him, so imperfectly as he<br><br>was known to me then.  However, my thoughts were at length carried in<br><br>other directions, so that for the present dark Ahab slipped my mind.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 17<br><br><br><br>The Ramadan.<br><br><br><br><br><br>As Queequeg's Ramadan, or Fasting and Humiliation, was to continue<br><br>all day, I did not choose to disturb him till towards night-fall; for<br><br>I cherish the greatest respect towards everybody's religious<br><br>obligations, never mind how comical, and could not find it in my<br><br>heart to undervalue even a congregation of ants worshipping a<br><br>toad-stool; or those other creatures in certain parts of our earth,<br><br>who with a degree of footmanism quite unprecedented in other planets,<br><br>bow down before the torso of a deceased landed proprietor merely on<br><br>account of the inordinate possessions yet owned and rented in his<br><br>name.<br><br><br><br>I say, we good Presbyterian Christians should be charitable in these<br><br>things, and not fancy ourselves so vastly superior to other mortals,<br><br>pagans and what not, because of their half-crazy conceits on these<br><br>subjects.  There was Queequeg, now, certainly entertaining the most<br><br>absurd notions about Yojo and his Ramadan;--but what of that?<br><br>Queequeg thought he knew what he was about, I suppose; he seemed to<br><br>be content; and there let him rest.  All our arguing with him would<br><br>not avail; let him be, I say: and Heaven have mercy on us<br><br>all--Presbyterians and Pagans alike--for we are all somehow<br><br>dreadfully cracked about the head, and sadly need mending.<br><br><br><br>Towards evening, when I felt assured that all his performances and<br><br>rituals must be over, I went up to his room and knocked at the door;<br><br>but no answer.  I tried to open it, but it was fastened inside.<br><br>"Queequeg," said I softly through the key-hole:--all silent.  "I say,<br><br>Queequeg! why don't you speak?  It's I--Ishmael."  But all remained<br><br>still as before.  I began to grow alarmed.  I had allowed him such<br><br>abundant time; I thought he might have had an apoplectic fit.  I<br><br>looked through the key-hole; but the door opening into an odd corner<br><br>of the room, the key-hole prospect was but a crooked and sinister<br><br>one.  I could only see part of the foot-board of the bed and a line<br><br>of the wall, but nothing more.  I was surprised to behold resting<br><br>against the wall the wooden shaft of Queequeg's harpoon, which the<br><br>landlady the evening previous had taken from him, before our mounting<br><br>to the chamber.  That's strange, thought I; but at any rate, since<br><br>the harpoon stands yonder, and he seldom or never goes abroad without<br><br>it, therefore he must be inside here, and no possible mistake.<br><br><br><br>"Queequeg!--Queequeg!"--all still.  Something must have happened.<br><br>Apoplexy!  I tried to burst open the door; but it stubbornly<br><br>resisted.  Running down stairs, I quickly stated my suspicions to the<br><br>first person I met--the chamber-maid.  "La! la!" she cried, "I<br><br>thought something must be the matter.  I went to make the bed after<br><br>breakfast, and the door was locked; and not a mouse to be heard; and<br><br>it's been just so silent ever since.  But I thought, may be, you had<br><br>both gone off and locked your baggage in for safe keeping.  La! la,<br><br>ma'am!--Mistress! murder!  Mrs. Hussey! apoplexy!"--and with these<br><br>cries, she ran towards the kitchen, I following.<br><br><br><br>Mrs. Hussey soon appeared, with a mustard-pot in one hand and a<br><br>vinegar-cruet in the other, having just broken away from the<br><br>occupation of attending to the castors, and scolding her little black<br><br>boy meantime.<br><br><br><br>"Wood-house!" cried I, "which way to it?  Run for God's sake, and<br><br>fetch something to pry open the door--the axe!--the axe! he's had a<br><br>stroke; depend upon it!"--and so saying I was unmethodically rushing<br><br>up stairs again empty-handed, when Mrs. Hussey interposed the<br><br>mustard-pot and vinegar-cruet, and the entire castor of her<br><br>countenance.<br><br><br><br>"What's the matter with you, young man?"<br><br><br><br>"Get the axe!  For God's sake, run for the doctor, some one, while I<br><br>pry it open!"<br><br><br><br>"Look here," said the landlady, quickly putting down the<br><br>vinegar-cruet, so as to have one hand free; "look here; are you<br><br>talking about prying open any of my doors?"--and with that she seized<br><br>my arm.  "What's the matter with you?  What's the matter with you,<br><br>shipmate?"<br><br><br><br>In as calm, but rapid a manner as possible, I gave her to understand<br><br>the whole case.  Unconsciously clapping the vinegar-cruet to one side<br><br>of her nose, she ruminated for an instant; then exclaimed--"No!  I<br><br>haven't seen it since I put it there."  Running to a little closet<br><br>under the landing of the stairs, she glanced in, and returning, told<br><br>me that Queequeg's harpoon was missing.  "He's killed himself," she<br><br>cried.  "It's unfort'nate Stiggs done over again there goes another<br><br>counterpane--God pity his poor mother!--it will be the ruin of my<br><br>house.  Has the poor lad a sister?  Where's that girl?--there, Betty,<br><br>go to Snarles the Painter, and tell him to paint me a sign, with--"no<br><br>suicides permitted here, and no smoking in the parlor;"--might as<br><br>well kill both birds at once.  Kill?  The Lord be merciful to his<br><br>ghost!  What's that noise there?  You, young man, avast there!"<br><br><br><br>And running up after me, she caught me as I was again trying to force<br><br>open the door.<br><br><br><br>"I don't allow it; I won't have my premises spoiled.  Go for the<br><br>locksmith, there's one about a mile from here.  But avast!" putting<br><br>her hand in her side-pocket, "here's a key that'll fit, I guess;<br><br>let's see."  And with that, she turned it in the lock; but, alas!<br><br>Queequeg's supplemental bolt remained unwithdrawn within.<br><br><br><br>"Have to burst it open," said I, and was running down the entry a<br><br>little, for a good start, when the landlady caught at me, again<br><br>vowing I should not break down her premises; but I tore from her, and<br><br>with a sudden bodily rush dashed myself full against the mark.<br><br><br><br>With a prodigious noise the door flew open, and the knob slamming<br><br>against the wall, sent the plaster to the ceiling; and there, good<br><br>heavens! there sat Queequeg, altogether cool and self-collected;<br><br>right in the middle of the room; squatting on his hams, and holding<br><br>Yojo on top of his head.  He looked neither one way nor the other<br><br>way, but sat like a carved image with scarce a sign of active life.<br><br><br><br>"Queequeg," said I, going up to him, "Queequeg, what's the matter<br><br>with you?"<br><br><br><br>"He hain't been a sittin' so all day, has he?" said the landlady.<br><br><br><br>But all we said, not a word could we drag out of him; I almost felt<br><br>like pushing him over, so as to change his position, for it was<br><br>almost intolerable, it seemed so painfully and unnaturally<br><br>constrained; especially, as in all probability he had been sitting so<br><br>for upwards of eight or ten hours, going too without his regular<br><br>meals.<br><br><br><br>"Mrs. Hussey," said I, "he's ALIVE at all events; so leave us, if you<br><br>please, and I will see to this strange affair myself."<br><br><br><br>Closing the door upon the landlady, I endeavored to prevail upon<br><br>Queequeg to take a chair; but in vain.  There he sat; and all he<br><br>could do--for all my polite arts and blandishments--he would not move<br><br>a peg, nor say a single word, nor even look at me, nor notice my<br><br>presence in the slightest way.<br><br><br><br>I wonder, thought I, if this can possibly be a part of his Ramadan;<br><br>do they fast on their hams that way in his native island.  It must be<br><br>so; yes, it's part of his creed, I suppose; well, then, let him<br><br>rest; he'll get up sooner or later, no doubt.  It can't last for<br><br>ever, thank God, and his Ramadan only comes once a year; and I don't<br><br>believe it's very punctual then.<br><br><br><br>I went down to supper.  After sitting a long time listening to the<br><br>long stories of some sailors who had just come from a plum-pudding<br><br>voyage, as they called it (that is, a short whaling-voyage in a<br><br>schooner or brig, confined to the north of the line, in the Atlantic<br><br>Ocean only); after listening to these plum-puddingers till nearly<br><br>eleven o'clock, I went up stairs to go to bed, feeling quite sure by<br><br>this time Queequeg must certainly have brought his Ramadan to a<br><br>termination.  But no; there he was just where I had left him; he had<br><br>not stirred an inch.  I began to grow vexed with him; it seemed so<br><br>downright senseless and insane to be sitting there all day and half<br><br>the night on his hams in a cold room, holding a piece of wood on his<br><br>head.<br><br><br><br>"For heaven's sake, Queequeg, get up and shake yourself; get up and<br><br>have some supper.  You'll starve; you'll kill yourself, Queequeg."<br><br>But not a word did he reply.<br><br><br><br>Despairing of him, therefore, I determined to go to bed and to sleep;<br><br>and no doubt, before a great while, he would follow me.  But previous<br><br>to turning in, I took my heavy bearskin jacket, and threw it over<br><br>him, as it promised to be a very cold night; and he had nothing but<br><br>his ordinary round jacket on.  For some time, do all I would, I could<br><br>not get into the faintest doze.  I had blown out the candle; and the<br><br>mere thought of Queequeg--not four feet off--sitting there in that<br><br>uneasy position, stark alone in the cold and dark; this made me<br><br>really wretched.  Think of it; sleeping all night in the same room<br><br>with a wide awake pagan on his hams in this dreary, unaccountable<br><br>Ramadan!<br><br><br><br>But somehow I dropped off at last, and knew nothing more till break<br><br>of day; when, looking over the bedside, there squatted Queequeg, as<br><br>if he had been screwed down to the floor.  But as soon as the first<br><br>glimpse of sun entered the window, up he got, with stiff and grating<br><br>joints, but with a cheerful look; limped towards me where I lay;<br><br>pressed his forehead again against mine; and said his Ramadan was<br><br>over.<br><br><br><br>Now, as I before hinted, I have no objection to any person's<br><br>religion, be it what it may, so long as that person does not kill or<br><br>insult any other person, because that other person don't believe it<br><br>also.  But when a man's religion becomes really frantic; when it is a<br><br>positive torment to him; and, in fine, makes this earth of ours an<br><br>uncomfortable inn to lodge in; then I think it high time to take that<br><br>individual aside and argue the point with him.<br><br><br><br>And just so I now did with Queequeg.  "Queequeg," said I, "get into<br><br>bed now, and lie and listen to me."  I then went on, beginning with<br><br>the rise and progress of the primitive religions, and coming down to<br><br>the various religions of the present time, during which time I<br><br>labored to show Queequeg that all these Lents, Ramadans, and<br><br>prolonged ham-squattings in cold, cheerless rooms were stark<br><br>nonsense; bad for the health; useless for the soul; opposed, in<br><br>short, to the obvious laws of Hygiene and common sense.  I told him,<br><br>too, that he being in other things such an extremely sensible and<br><br>sagacious savage, it pained me, very badly pained me, to see him now<br><br>so deplorably foolish about this ridiculous Ramadan of his.  Besides,<br><br>argued I, fasting makes the body cave in; hence the spirit caves in;<br><br>and all thoughts born of a fast must necessarily be half-starved.<br><br>This is the reason why most dyspeptic religionists cherish such<br><br>melancholy notions about their hereafters.  In one word, Queequeg,<br><br>said I, rather digressively; hell is an idea first born on an<br><br>undigested apple-dumpling; and since then perpetuated through the<br><br>hereditary dyspepsias nurtured by Ramadans.<br><br><br><br>I then asked Queequeg whether he himself was ever troubled with<br><br>dyspepsia; expressing the idea very plainly, so that he could take it<br><br>in.  He said no; only upon one memorable occasion.  It was after a<br><br>great feast given by his father the king, on the gaining of a great<br><br>battle wherein fifty of the enemy had been killed by about two<br><br>o'clock in the afternoon, and all cooked and eaten that very evening.<br><br><br><br>"No more, Queequeg," said I, shuddering; "that will do;" for I knew<br><br>the inferences without his further hinting them.  I had seen a sailor<br><br>who had visited that very island, and he told me that it was the<br><br>custom, when a great battle had been gained there, to barbecue all<br><br>the slain in the yard or garden of the victor; and then, one by one,<br><br>they were placed in great wooden trenchers, and garnished round like<br><br>a pilau, with breadfruit and cocoanuts; and with some parsley in<br><br>their mouths, were sent round with the victor's compliments to all<br><br>his friends, just as though these presents were so many Christmas<br><br>turkeys.<br><br><br><br>After all, I do not think that my remarks about religion made much<br><br>impression upon Queequeg.  Because, in the first place, he somehow<br><br>seemed dull of hearing on that important subject, unless considered<br><br>from his own point of view; and, in the second place, he did not more<br><br>than one third understand me, couch my ideas simply as I would; and,<br><br>finally, he no doubt thought he knew a good deal more about the true<br><br>religion than I did.  He looked at me with a sort of condescending<br><br>concern and compassion, as though he thought it a great pity that<br><br>such a sensible young man should be so hopelessly lost to evangelical<br><br>pagan piety.<br><br><br><br>At last we rose and dressed; and Queequeg, taking a prodigiously<br><br>hearty breakfast of chowders of all sorts, so that the landlady<br><br>should not make much profit by reason of his Ramadan, we sallied out<br><br>to board the Pequod, sauntering along, and picking our teeth with<br><br>halibut bones.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 18<br><br><br><br>His Mark.<br><br><br><br><br><br>As we were walking down the end of the wharf towards the ship,<br><br>Queequeg carrying his harpoon, Captain Peleg in his gruff voice<br><br>loudly hailed us from his wigwam, saying he had not suspected my<br><br>friend was a cannibal, and furthermore announcing that he let no<br><br>cannibals on board that craft, unless they previously produced their<br><br>papers.<br><br><br><br>"What do you mean by that, Captain Peleg?" said I, now jumping on the<br><br>bulwarks, and leaving my comrade standing on the wharf.<br><br><br><br>"I mean," he replied, "he must show his papers."<br><br><br><br>"Yes," said Captain Bildad in his hollow voice, sticking his head<br><br>from behind Peleg's, out of the wigwam.  "He must show that he's<br><br>converted.  Son of darkness," he added, turning to Queequeg, "art<br><br>thou at present in communion with any Christian church?"<br><br><br><br>"Why," said I, "he's a member of the first Congregational Church."<br><br>Here be it said, that many tattooed savages sailing in Nantucket<br><br>ships at last come to be converted into the churches.<br><br><br><br>"First Congregational Church," cried Bildad, "what! that worships in<br><br>Deacon Deuteronomy Coleman's meeting-house?" and so saying, taking<br><br>out his spectacles, he rubbed them with his great yellow bandana<br><br>handkerchief, and putting them on very carefully, came out of the<br><br>wigwam, and leaning stiffly over the bulwarks, took a good long look<br><br>at Queequeg.<br><br><br><br>"How long hath he been a member?" he then said, turning to me; "not<br><br>very long, I rather guess, young man."<br><br><br><br>"No," said Peleg, "and he hasn't been baptized right either, or it<br><br>would have washed some of that devil's blue off his face."<br><br><br><br>"Do tell, now," cried Bildad, "is this Philistine a regular member of<br><br>Deacon Deuteronomy's meeting?  I never saw him going there, and I<br><br>pass it every Lord's day."<br><br><br><br>"I don't know anything about Deacon Deuteronomy or his meeting," said<br><br>I; "all I know is, that Queequeg here is a born member of the First<br><br>Congregational Church.  He is a deacon himself, Queequeg is."<br><br><br><br>"Young man," said Bildad sternly, "thou art skylarking with<br><br>me--explain thyself, thou young Hittite.  What church dost thee mean?<br><br>answer me."<br><br><br><br>Finding myself thus hard pushed, I replied.  "I mean, sir, the same<br><br>ancient Catholic Church to which you and I, and Captain Peleg there,<br><br>and Queequeg here, and all of us, and every mother's son and soul of<br><br>us belong; the great and everlasting First Congregation of this whole<br><br>worshipping world; we all belong to that; only some of us cherish<br><br>some queer crotchets no ways touching the grand belief; in THAT we<br><br>all join hands."<br><br><br><br>"Splice, thou mean'st SPLICE hands," cried Peleg, drawing nearer.<br><br>"Young man, you'd better ship for a missionary, instead of a<br><br>fore-mast hand; I never heard a better sermon.  Deacon<br><br>Deuteronomy--why Father Mapple himself couldn't beat it, and he's<br><br>reckoned something.  Come aboard, come aboard; never mind about the<br><br>papers.  I say, tell Quohog there--what's that you call him? tell<br><br>Quohog to step along.  By the great anchor, what a harpoon he's got<br><br>there! looks like good stuff that; and he handles it about right.  I<br><br>say, Quohog, or whatever your name is, did you ever stand in the head<br><br>of a whale-boat? did you ever strike a fish?"<br><br><br><br>Without saying a word, Queequeg, in his wild sort of way, jumped upon<br><br>the bulwarks, from thence into the bows of one of the whale-boats<br><br>hanging to the side; and then bracing his left knee, and poising his<br><br>harpoon, cried out in some such way as this:--<br><br><br><br>"Cap'ain, you see him small drop tar on water dere?  You see him?<br><br>well, spose him one whale eye, well, den!" and taking sharp aim at<br><br>it, he darted the iron right over old Bildad's broad brim, clean<br><br>across the ship's decks, and struck the glistening tar spot out of<br><br>sight.<br><br><br><br>"Now," said Queequeg, quietly hauling in the line, "spos-ee him<br><br>whale-e eye; why, dad whale dead."<br><br><br><br>"Quick, Bildad," said Peleg, his partner, who, aghast at the close<br><br>vicinity of the flying harpoon, had retreated towards the cabin<br><br>gangway.  "Quick, I say, you Bildad, and get the ship's papers.  We<br><br>must have Hedgehog there, I mean Quohog, in one of our boats.  Look<br><br>ye, Quohog, we'll give ye the ninetieth lay, and that's more than<br><br>ever was given a harpooneer yet out of Nantucket."<br><br><br><br>So down we went into the cabin, and to my great joy Queequeg was soon<br><br>enrolled among the same ship's company to which I myself belonged.<br><br><br><br>When all preliminaries were over and Peleg had got everything ready<br><br>for signing, he turned to me and said, "I guess, Quohog there don't<br><br>know how to write, does he?  I say, Quohog, blast ye! dost thou sign<br><br>thy name or make thy mark?<br><br><br><br>But at this question, Queequeg, who had twice or thrice before taken<br><br>part in similar ceremonies, looked no ways abashed; but taking the<br><br>offered pen, copied upon the paper, in the proper place, an exact<br><br>counterpart of a queer round figure which was tattooed upon his arm;<br><br>so that through Captain Peleg's obstinate mistake touching his<br><br>appellative, it stood something like this:--<br><br><br><br>Quohog.<br><br>his X mark.<br><br><br><br>Meanwhile Captain Bildad sat earnestly and steadfastly eyeing<br><br>Queequeg, and at last rising solemnly and fumbling in the huge<br><br>pockets of his broad-skirted drab coat, took out a bundle of tracts,<br><br>and selecting one entitled "The Latter Day Coming; or No Time to<br><br>Lose," placed it in Queequeg's hands, and then grasping them and the<br><br>book with both his, looked earnestly into his eyes, and said, "Son of<br><br>darkness, I must do my duty by thee; I am part owner of this ship,<br><br>and feel concerned for the souls of all its crew; if thou still<br><br>clingest to thy Pagan ways, which I sadly fear, I beseech thee,<br><br>remain not for aye a Belial bondsman.  Spurn the idol Bell, and the<br><br>hideous dragon; turn from the wrath to come; mind thine eye, I say;<br><br>oh! goodness gracious! steer clear of the fiery pit!"<br><br><br><br>Something of the salt sea yet lingered in old Bildad's language,<br><br>heterogeneously mixed with Scriptural and domestic phrases.<br><br><br><br>"Avast there, avast there, Bildad, avast now spoiling our<br><br>harpooneer," Peleg.  "Pious harpooneers never make good voyagers--it<br><br>takes the shark out of 'em; no harpooneer is worth a straw who aint<br><br>pretty sharkish.  There was young Nat Swaine, once the bravest<br><br>boat-header out of all Nantucket and the Vineyard; he joined the<br><br>meeting, and never came to good.  He got so frightened about his<br><br>plaguy soul, that he shrinked and sheered away from whales, for fear<br><br>of after-claps, in case he got stove and went to Davy Jones."<br><br><br><br>"Peleg!  Peleg!" said Bildad, lifting his eyes and hands, "thou<br><br>thyself, as I myself, hast seen many a perilous time; thou knowest,<br><br>Peleg, what it is to have the fear of death; how, then, can'st thou<br><br>prate in this ungodly guise.  Thou beliest thine own heart, Peleg.<br><br>Tell me, when this same Pequod here had her three masts overboard in<br><br>that typhoon on Japan, that same voyage when thou went mate with<br><br>Captain Ahab, did'st thou not think of Death and the Judgment then?"<br><br><br><br>"Hear him, hear him now," cried Peleg, marching across the cabin, and<br><br>thrusting his hands far down into his pockets,--"hear him, all of ye.<br><br>Think of that!  When every moment we thought the ship would sink!<br><br>Death and the Judgment then?  What?  With all three masts making such<br><br>an everlasting thundering against the side; and every sea breaking<br><br>over us, fore and aft.  Think of Death and the Judgment then?  No!<br><br>no time to think about Death then.  Life was what Captain Ahab and I<br><br>was thinking of; and how to save all hands--how to rig<br><br>jury-masts--how to get into the nearest port; that was what I was<br><br>thinking of."<br><br><br><br>Bildad said no more, but buttoning up his coat, stalked on deck,<br><br>where we followed him.  There he stood, very quietly overlooking some<br><br>sailmakers who were mending a top-sail in the waist.  Now and then he<br><br>stooped to pick up a patch, or save an end of tarred twine, which<br><br>otherwise might have been wasted.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 19<br><br><br><br>The Prophet.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"Shipmates, have ye shipped in that ship?"<br><br><br><br>Queequeg and I had just left the Pequod, and were sauntering away from<br><br>the water, for the moment each occupied with his own thoughts, when<br><br>the above words were put to us by a stranger, who, pausing before us,<br><br>levelled his massive forefinger at the vessel in question.  He was<br><br>but shabbily apparelled in faded jacket and patched trowsers; a rag<br><br>of a black handkerchief investing his neck.  A confluent small-pox<br><br>had in all directions flowed over his face, and left it like the<br><br>complicated ribbed bed of a torrent, when the rushing waters have<br><br>been dried up.<br><br><br><br>"Have ye shipped in her?" he repeated.<br><br><br><br>"You mean the ship Pequod, I suppose," said I, trying to gain a<br><br>little more time for an uninterrupted look at him.<br><br><br><br>"Aye, the Pequod--that ship there," he said, drawing back his whole<br><br>arm, and then rapidly shoving it straight out from him, with the<br><br>fixed bayonet of his pointed finger darted full at the object.<br><br><br><br>"Yes," said I, "we have just signed the articles."<br><br><br><br>"Anything down there about your souls?"<br><br><br><br>"About what?"<br><br><br><br>"Oh, perhaps you hav'n't got any," he said quickly.  "No matter<br><br>though, I know many chaps that hav'n't got any,--good luck to 'em;<br><br>and they are all the better off for it.  A soul's a sort of a fifth<br><br>wheel to a wagon."<br><br><br><br>"What are you jabbering about, shipmate?" said I.<br><br><br><br>"HE'S got enough, though, to make up for all deficiencies of that<br><br>sort in other chaps," abruptly said the stranger, placing a nervous<br><br>emphasis upon the word HE.<br><br><br><br>"Queequeg," said I, "let's go; this fellow has broken loose from<br><br>somewhere; he's talking about something and somebody we don't know."<br><br><br><br>"Stop!" cried the stranger. Ye<br><br>hav'n't seen him yet, have ye?"<br><br><br><br>"No, we hav'n't.  He's sick they say, but is getting better, and will<br><br>be all right again before long."<br><br><br><br>"All right again before long!" laughed the stranger, with a solemnly<br><br>derisive sort of laugh.  "Look ye; when Captain Ahab is all right,<br><br>then this left arm of mine will be all right; not before."<br><br><br><br>"What do you know about him?"<br><br><br><br>"What did they TELL you about him?  Say that!"<br><br><br><br>"They didn't tell much of anything about him; only I've heard that<br><br>he's a good whale-hunter, and a good captain to his crew."<br><br><br><br>"That's true, that's true--yes, both true enough.  But you must jump<br><br>when he gives an order.  Step and growl; growl and go--that's the<br><br>word with Captain Ahab.  But nothing about that thing that happened<br><br>to him off Cape Horn, long ago, when he lay like dead for three days<br><br>and nights; nothing about that deadly skrimmage with the Spaniard<br><br>afore the altar in Santa?--heard nothing about that, eh?  Nothing<br><br>about the silver calabash he spat into?  And nothing about his losing<br><br>his leg last voyage, according to the prophecy.  Didn't ye hear a<br><br>word about them matters and something more, eh?  No, I don't think ye<br><br>did; how could ye?  Who knows it?  Not all Nantucket, I guess.  But<br><br>hows'ever, mayhap, ye've heard tell about the leg, and how he lost<br><br>it; aye, ye have heard of that, I dare say.  Oh yes, THAT every one<br><br>knows a'most--I mean they know he's only one leg; and that a<br><br>parmacetti took the other off."<br><br><br><br>"My friend," said I, "what all this gibberish of yours is about, I<br><br>don't know, and I don't much care; for it seems to me that you must<br><br>be a little damaged in the head.  But if you are speaking of Captain<br><br>Ahab, of that ship there, the Pequod, then let me tell you, that I<br><br>know all about the loss of his leg."<br><br><br><br>"ALL about it, eh--sure you do?--all?"<br><br><br><br>"Pretty sure."<br><br><br><br>With finger pointed and eye levelled at the Pequod, the beggar-like<br><br>stranger stood a moment, as if in a troubled reverie; then starting a<br><br>little, turned and said:--"Ye've shipped, have ye?  Names down on the<br><br>papers?  Well, well, what's signed, is signed; and what's to be, will<br><br>be; and then again, perhaps it won't be, after all.  Anyhow, it's<br><br>all fixed and arranged a'ready; and some sailors or other must go<br><br>with him, I suppose; as well these as any other men, God pity 'em!<br><br>Morning to ye, shipmates, morning; the ineffable heavens bless ye;<br><br>I'm sorry I stopped ye."<br><br><br><br>"Look here, friend," said I, "if you have anything important to tell<br><br>us, out with it; but if you are only trying to bamboozle us, you are<br><br>mistaken in your game; that's all I have to say."<br><br><br><br>"And it's said very well, and I like to hear a chap talk up that way;<br><br>you are just the man for him--the likes of ye.  Morning to ye,<br><br>shipmates, morning!  Oh! when ye get there, tell 'em I've concluded<br><br>not to make one of 'em."<br><br><br><br>"Ah, my dear fellow, you can't fool us that way--you can't fool us.<br><br>It is the easiest thing in the world for a man to look as if he had a<br><br>great secret in him."<br><br><br><br>"Morning to ye, shipmates, morning."<br><br><br><br>"Morning it is," said I.  "Come along, Queequeg, let's leave this<br><br>crazy man.  But stop, tell me your name, will you?"<br><br><br><br>"Elijah."<br><br><br><br>Elijah! thought I, and we walked away, both commenting, after each<br><br>other's fashion, upon this ragged old sailor; and agreed that he was<br><br>nothing but a humbug, trying to be a bugbear.  But we had not gone<br><br>perhaps above a hundred yards, when chancing to turn a corner, and<br><br>looking back as I did so, who should be seen but Elijah following us,<br><br>though at a distance.  Somehow, the sight of him struck me so, that I<br><br>said nothing to Queequeg of his being behind, but passed on with my<br><br>comrade, anxious to see whether the stranger would turn the same<br><br>corner that we did.  He did; and then it seemed to me that he was<br><br>dogging us, but with what intent I could not for the life of me<br><br>imagine. But Elijah<br><br>passed on, without seeming to notice us.  This relieved me; and once<br><br>more, and finally as it seemed to me, I pronounced him in my heart, a<br><br>humbug.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 20<br><br><br><br>All Astir.<br><br><br><br><br><br>A day or two passed, and there was great activity aboard the Pequod.<br><br>Not only were the old sails being mended, but new sails were coming<br><br>on board, and bolts of canvas, and coils of rigging; in short,<br><br>everything betokened that the ship's preparations were hurrying to a<br><br>close.  Captain Peleg seldom or never went ashore, but sat in his<br><br>wigwam keeping a sharp look-out upon the hands: Bildad did all the<br><br>purchasing and providing at the stores; and the men employed in the<br><br>hold and on the rigging were working till long after night-fall.<br><br><br><br>On the day following Queequeg's signing the articles, word was given<br><br>at all the inns where the ship's company were stopping, that their<br><br>chests must be on board before night, for there was no telling how<br><br>soon the vessel might be sailing.  So Queequeg and I got down our<br><br>traps, resolving, however, to sleep ashore till the last.  But it<br><br>seems they always give very long notice in these cases, and the ship<br><br>did not sail for several days.  But no wonder; there was a good deal<br><br>to be done, and there is no telling how many things to be thought of,<br><br>before the Pequod was fully equipped.<br><br><br><br>Every one knows what a multitude of things--beds, sauce-pans, knives<br><br>and forks, shovels and tongs, napkins, nut-crackers, and what not,<br><br>are indispensable to the business of housekeeping.  Just so with<br><br>whaling, which necessitates a three-years' housekeeping upon the wide<br><br>ocean, far from all grocers, costermongers, doctors, bakers, and<br><br>bankers.  And though this also holds true of merchant vessels, yet<br><br>not by any means to the same extent as with whalemen.  For besides<br><br>the great length of the whaling voyage, the numerous articles<br><br>peculiar to the prosecution of the fishery, and the impossibility of<br><br>replacing them at the remote harbors usually frequented, it must be<br><br>remembered, that of all ships, whaling vessels are the most exposed<br><br>to accidents of all kinds, and especially to the destruction and loss<br><br>of the very things upon which the success of the voyage most depends.<br><br>Hence, the spare boats, spare spars, and spare lines and harpoons,<br><br>and spare everythings, almost, but a spare Captain and duplicate<br><br>ship.<br><br><br><br>At the period of our arrival at the Island, the heaviest storage of<br><br>the Pequod had been almost completed; comprising her beef, bread,<br><br>water, fuel, and iron hoops and staves.  But, as before hinted, for<br><br>some time there was a continual fetching and carrying on board of<br><br>divers odds and ends of things, both large and small.<br><br><br><br>Chief among those who did this fetching and carrying was Captain<br><br>Bildad's sister, a lean old lady of a most determined and<br><br>indefatigable spirit, but withal very kindhearted, who seemed<br><br>resolved that, if SHE could help it, nothing should be found wanting<br><br>in the Pequod, after once fairly getting to sea.  At one time she<br><br>would come on board with a jar of pickles for the steward's pantry;<br><br>another time with a bunch of quills for the chief mate's desk, where<br><br>he kept his log; a third time with a roll of flannel for the small of<br><br>some one's rheumatic back.  Never did any woman better deserve her<br><br>name, which was Charity--Aunt Charity, as everybody called her.  And<br><br>like a sister of charity did this charitable Aunt Charity bustle<br><br>about hither and thither, ready to turn her hand and heart to<br><br>anything that promised to yield safety, comfort, and consolation to<br><br>all on board a ship in which her beloved brother Bildad was<br><br>concerned, and in which she herself owned a score or two of<br><br>well-saved dollars.<br><br><br><br>But it was startling to see this excellent hearted Quakeress coming<br><br>on board, as she did the last day, with a long oil-ladle in one hand,<br><br>and a still longer whaling lance in the other. I wonder he don't<br><br>wake."<br><br><br><br>Queequeg removed himself to just beyond the head of the sleeper, and<br><br>lighted his tomahawk pipe.  I sat at the feet. Meanwhile Captain Ahab remained<br><br>invisibly enshrined within his cabin.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 22<br><br><br><br>Merry Christmas.<br><br><br><br><br><br>At length, towards noon, upon the final dismissal of the ship's<br><br>riggers, and after the Pequod had been hauled out from the wharf, and<br><br>after the ever-thoughtful Charity had come off in a whale-boat, with<br><br>her last gift--a night-cap for Stubb, the second mate, her<br><br>brother-in-law, and a spare Bible for the steward--after all this,<br><br>the two Captains, Peleg and Bildad, issued from the cabin, and<br><br>turning to the chief mate, Peleg said:<br><br><br><br>"Now, Mr. Starbuck, are you sure everything is right?  Captain Ahab<br><br>is all ready--just spoke to him--nothing more to be got from shore,<br><br>eh?  Well, call all hands, then.  Muster 'em aft here--blast 'em!"<br><br><br><br>"No need of profane words, however great the hurry, Peleg," said<br><br>Bildad, "but away with thee, friend Starbuck, and do our bidding."<br><br><br><br>How now!  Here upon the very point of starting for the voyage,<br><br>Captain Peleg and Captain Bildad were going it with a high hand on<br><br>the quarter-deck, just as if they were to be joint-commanders at sea,<br><br>as well as to all appearances in port.  And, as for Captain Ahab, no<br><br>sign of him was yet to be seen; only, they said he was in the cabin.<br><br>But then, the idea was, that his presence was by no means necessary<br><br>in getting the ship under weigh, and steering her well out to sea.<br><br>Indeed, as that was not at all his proper business, but the pilot's;<br><br>and as he was not yet completely recovered--so they said--therefore,<br><br>Captain Ahab stayed below.  And all this seemed natural enough;<br><br>especially as in the merchant service many captains never show<br><br>themselves on deck for a considerable time after heaving up the<br><br>anchor, but remain over the cabin table, having a farewell<br><br>merry-making with their shore friends, before they quit the ship for<br><br>good with the pilot.<br><br><br><br>But there was not much chance to think over the matter, for Captain<br><br>Peleg was now all alive.  He seemed to do most of the talking and<br><br>commanding, and not Bildad.<br><br><br><br>"Aft here, ye sons of bachelors," he cried, as the sailors lingered<br><br>at the main-mast.  "Mr. Starbuck, drive'em aft."<br><br><br><br>"Strike the tent there!"--was the next order.  As I hinted before,<br><br>this whalebone marquee was never pitched except in port; and on board<br><br>the Pequod, for thirty years, the order to strike the tent was well<br><br>known to be the next thing to heaving up the anchor.<br><br><br><br>"Man the capstan!  Blood and thunder!--jump!"--was the next command,<br><br>and the crew sprang for the handspikes.<br><br><br><br>Now in getting under weigh, the station generally occupied by the<br><br>pilot is the forward part of the ship.  And here Bildad, who, with<br><br>Peleg, be it known, in addition to his other officers, was one of the<br><br>licensed pilots of the port--he being suspected to have got himself<br><br>made a pilot in order to save the Nantucket pilot-fee to all the<br><br>ships he was concerned in, for he never piloted any other<br><br>craft--Bildad, I say, might now be seen actively engaged in looking<br><br>over the bows for the approaching anchor, and at intervals singing<br><br>what seemed a dismal stave of psalmody, to cheer the hands at the<br><br>windlass, who roared forth some sort of a chorus about the girls in<br><br>Booble Alley, with hearty good will.  Nevertheless, not three days<br><br>previous, Bildad had told them that no profane songs would be allowed<br><br>on board the Pequod, particularly in getting under weigh; and<br><br>Charity, his sister, had placed a small choice copy of Watts in each<br><br>seaman's berth.<br><br><br><br>Meantime, overseeing the other part of the ship, Captain Peleg ripped<br><br>and swore astern in the most frightful manner.  I almost thought he<br><br>would sink the ship before the anchor could be got up; involuntarily<br><br>I paused on my handspike, and told Queequeg to do the same, thinking<br><br>of the perils we both ran, in starting on the voyage with such a<br><br>devil for a pilot.  I was comforting myself, however, with the<br><br>thought that in pious Bildad might be found some salvation, spite of<br><br>his seven hundred and seventy-seventh lay; when I felt a sudden sharp<br><br>poke in my rear, and turning round, was horrified at the apparition<br><br>of Captain Peleg in the act of withdrawing his leg from my immediate<br><br>vicinity.  That was my first kick.<br><br><br><br>"Is that the way they heave in the marchant service?" he roared.<br><br>"Spring, thou sheep-head; spring, and break thy backbone!  Why don't<br><br>ye spring, I say, all of ye--spring!  Quohog! spring, thou chap with<br><br>the red whiskers; spring there, Scotch-cap; spring, thou green<br><br>pants.  Spring, I say, all of ye, and spring your eyes out!"  And so<br><br>saying, he moved along the windlass, here and there using his leg<br><br>very freely, while imperturbable Bildad kept leading off with his<br><br>psalmody.  Thinks I, Captain Peleg must have been drinking something<br><br>to-day.<br><br><br><br>At last the anchor was up, the sails were set, and off we glided.  It<br><br>was a short, cold Christmas; and as the short northern day merged<br><br>into night, we found ourselves almost broad upon the wintry ocean,<br><br>whose freezing spray cased us in ice, as in polished armor.  The long<br><br>rows of teeth on the bulwarks glistened in the moonlight; and like<br><br>the white ivory tusks of some huge elephant, vast curving icicles<br><br>depended from the bows.<br><br><br><br>Lank Bildad, as pilot, headed the first watch, and ever and anon, as<br><br>the old craft deep dived into the green seas, and sent the shivering<br><br>frost all over her, and the winds howled, and the cordage rang, his<br><br>steady notes were heard,--<br><br><br><br>"Sweet fields beyond the swelling flood,<br><br>Stand dressed in living green.<br><br>So to the Jews old Canaan stood,<br><br>While Jordan rolled between."<br><br><br><br><br><br>Never did those sweet words sound more sweetly to me than then.  They<br><br>were full of hope and fruition.  Spite of this frigid winter night in<br><br>the boisterous Atlantic, spite of my wet feet and wetter jacket,<br><br>there was yet, it then seemed to me, many a pleasant haven in store;<br><br>and meads and glades so eternally vernal, that the grass shot up by<br><br>the spring, untrodden, unwilted, remains at midsummer.<br><br><br><br>At last we gained such an offing, that the two pilots were needed no<br><br>longer.  The stout sail-boat that had accompanied us began ranging<br><br>alongside.<br><br><br><br>It was curious and not unpleasing, how Peleg and Bildad were affected<br><br>at this juncture, especially Captain Bildad.  For loath to depart,<br><br>yet; very loath to leave, for good, a ship bound on so long and<br><br>perilous a voyage--beyond both stormy Capes; a ship in which some<br><br>thousands of his hard earned dollars were invested; a ship, in which<br><br>an old shipmate sailed as captain; a man almost as old as he, once<br><br>more starting to encounter all the terrors of the pitiless jaw; loath<br><br>to say good-bye to a thing so every way brimful of every interest to<br><br>him,--poor old Bildad lingered long; paced the deck with anxious<br><br>strides; ran down into the cabin to speak another farewell word<br><br>there; again came on deck, and looked to windward; looked towards the<br><br>wide and endless waters, only bounded by the far-off unseen Eastern<br><br>Continents; looked towards the land; looked aloft; looked right and<br><br>left; looked everywhere and nowhere; and at last, mechanically<br><br>coiling a rope upon its pin, convulsively grasped stout Peleg by the<br><br>hand, and holding up a lantern, for a moment stood gazing heroically<br><br>in his face, as much as to say, "Nevertheless, friend Peleg, I can<br><br>stand it; yes, I can."<br><br><br><br>As for Peleg himself, he took it more like a philosopher; but for all<br><br>his philosophy, there was a tear twinkling in his eye, when the<br><br>lantern came too near.  And he, too, did not a little run from cabin<br><br>to deck--now a word below, and now a word with Starbuck, the chief<br><br>mate.<br><br><br><br>But, at last, he turned to his comrade, with a final sort of look<br><br>about him,--"Captain Bildad--come, old shipmate, we must go.  Back<br><br>the main-yard there!  Boat ahoy!  Stand by to come close alongside,<br><br>now!  Careful, careful!--come, Bildad, boy--say your last.  Luck to<br><br>ye, Starbuck--luck to ye, Mr. Stubb--luck to ye, Mr. Flask--good-bye<br><br>and good luck to ye all--and this day three years I'll have a hot<br><br>supper smoking for ye in old Nantucket.  Hurrah and away!"<br><br><br><br>"God bless ye, and have ye in His holy keeping, men," murmured old<br><br>Bildad, almost incoherently.  "I hope ye'll have fine weather now, so<br><br>that Captain Ahab may soon be moving among ye--a pleasant sun is all<br><br>he needs, and ye'll have plenty of them in the tropic voyage ye go.<br><br>Be careful in the hunt, ye mates.  Don't stave the boats needlessly,<br><br>ye harpooneers; good white cedar plank is raised full three per cent.<br><br>within the year.  Don't forget your prayers, either.  Mr. Starbuck,<br><br>mind that cooper don't waste the spare staves.  Oh! the sail-needles<br><br>are in the green locker!  Don't whale it too much a' Lord's days,<br><br>men; but don't miss a fair chance either, that's rejecting Heaven's<br><br>good gifts.  Have an eye to the molasses tierce, Mr. Stubb; it was a<br><br>little leaky, I thought.  If ye touch at the islands, Mr. Flask,<br><br>beware of fornication.  Good-bye, good-bye!  Don't keep that cheese<br><br>too long down in the hold, Mr. Starbuck; it'll spoil.  Be careful<br><br>with the butter--twenty cents the pound it was, and mind ye, if--"<br><br><br><br>"Come, come, Captain Bildad; stop palavering,--away!" and with that,<br><br>Peleg hurried him over the side, and both dropt into the boat.<br><br><br><br>Ship and boat diverged; the cold, damp night breeze blew between; a<br><br>screaming gull flew overhead; the two hulls wildly rolled; we gave<br><br>three heavy-hearted cheers, and blindly plunged like fate into the<br><br>lone Atlantic.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 23<br><br><br><br>The Lee Shore.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Some chapters back, one Bulkington was spoken of, a tall, newlanded<br><br>mariner, encountered in New Bedford at the inn.<br><br><br><br>When on that shivering winter's night, the Pequod thrust her<br><br>vindictive bows into the cold malicious waves, who should I see<br><br>standing at her helm but Bulkington!  I looked with sympathetic awe<br><br>and fearfulness upon the man, who in mid-winter just landed from a<br><br>four years' dangerous voyage, could so unrestingly push off again for<br><br>still another tempestuous term.  The land seemed scorching to his<br><br>feet.  Wonderfullest things are ever the unmentionable; deep memories<br><br>yield no epitaphs; this six-inch chapter is the stoneless grave of<br><br>Bulkington.  Let me only say that it fared with him as with the<br><br>storm-tossed ship, that miserably drives along the leeward land.  The<br><br>port would fain give succor; the port is pitiful; in the port is<br><br>safety, comfort, hearthstone, supper, warm blankets, friends, all<br><br>that's kind to our mortalities.  But in that gale, the port, the<br><br>land, is that ship's direst jeopardy; she must fly all hospitality;<br><br>one touch of land, though it but graze the keel, would make her<br><br>shudder through and through.  With all her might she crowds all sail<br><br>off shore; in so doing, fights 'gainst the very winds that fain would<br><br>blow her homeward; seeks all the lashed sea's landlessness again; for<br><br>refuge's sake forlornly rushing into peril; her only friend her<br><br>bitterest foe!<br><br><br><br>Know ye now, Bulkington?  Glimpses do ye seem to see of that mortally<br><br>intolerable truth; that all deep, earnest thinking is but the<br><br>intrepid effort of the soul to keep the open independence of her sea;<br><br>while the wildest winds of heaven and earth conspire to cast her on<br><br>the treacherous, slavish shore?<br><br><br><br>But as in landlessness alone resides highest truth, shoreless,<br><br>indefinite as God--so, better is it to perish in that howling<br><br>infinite, than be ingloriously dashed upon the lee, even if that were<br><br>safety!
