For worm-like, then, oh! who would craven crawl to land!<br><br>Terrors of the terrible! is all this agony so vain?  Take heart, take<br><br>heart, O Bulkington!  Bear thee grimly, demigod!  Up from the spray<br><br>of thy ocean-perishing--straight up, leaps thy apotheosis!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 24<br><br><br><br>The Advocate.<br><br><br><br><br><br>As Queequeg and I are now fairly embarked in this business of<br><br>whaling; and as this business of whaling has somehow come to be<br><br>regarded among landsmen as a rather unpoetical and disreputable<br><br>pursuit; therefore, I am all anxiety to convince ye, ye landsmen, of<br><br>the injustice hereby done to us hunters of whales.<br><br><br><br>In the first place, it may be deemed almost superfluous to establish<br><br>the fact, that among people at large, the business of whaling is not<br><br>accounted on a level with what are called the liberal professions.<br><br>If a stranger were introduced into any miscellaneous metropolitan<br><br>society, it would but slightly advance the general opinion of his<br><br>merits, were he presented to the company as a harpooneer, say; and if<br><br>in emulation of the naval officers he should append the initials<br><br>S.W.F. (Sperm Whale Fishery) to his visiting card, such a procedure<br><br>would be deemed pre-eminently presuming and ridiculous.<br><br><br><br>Doubtless one leading reason why the world declines honouring us<br><br>whalemen, is this: they think that, at best, our vocation amounts to<br><br>a butchering sort of business; and that when actively engaged<br><br>therein, we are surrounded by all manner of defilements.  Butchers we<br><br>are, that is true.  But butchers, also, and butchers of the bloodiest<br><br>badge have been all Martial Commanders whom the world invariably<br><br>delights to honour.  And as for the matter of the alleged<br><br>uncleanliness of our business, ye shall soon be initiated into<br><br>certain facts hitherto pretty generally unknown, and which, upon the<br><br>whole, will triumphantly plant the sperm whale-ship at least among<br><br>the cleanliest things of this tidy earth.  But even granting the<br><br>charge in question to be true; what disordered slippery decks of a<br><br>whale-ship are comparable to the unspeakable carrion of those<br><br>battle-fields from which so many soldiers return to drink in all<br><br>ladies' plaudits?  And if the idea of peril so much enhances the<br><br>popular conceit of the soldier's profession; let me assure ye that<br><br>many a veteran who has freely marched up to a battery, would quickly<br><br>recoil at the apparition of the sperm whale's vast tail, fanning into<br><br>eddies the air over his head.  For what are the comprehensible<br><br>terrors of man compared with the interlinked terrors and wonders of<br><br>God!<br><br><br><br>But, though the world scouts at us whale hunters, yet does it<br><br>unwittingly pay us the profoundest homage; yea, an all-abounding<br><br>adoration! for almost all the tapers, lamps, and candles that burn<br><br>round the globe, burn, as before so many shrines, to our glory!<br><br><br><br>But look at this matter in other lights; weigh it in all sorts of<br><br>scales; see what we whalemen are, and have been.<br><br><br><br>Why did the Dutch in De Witt's time have admirals of their whaling<br><br>fleets?  Why did Louis XVI. of France, at his own personal expense,<br><br>fit out whaling ships from Dunkirk, and politely invite to that town<br><br>some score or two of families from our own island of Nantucket?  Why<br><br>did Britain between the years 1750 and 1788 pay to her whalemen in<br><br>bounties upwards of L1,000,000?  And lastly, how comes it that we<br><br>whalemen of America now outnumber all the rest of the banded whalemen<br><br>in the world; sail a navy of upwards of seven hundred vessels; manned<br><br>by eighteen thousand men; yearly consuming 4,000,000 of dollars; the<br><br>ships worth, at the time of sailing, $20,000,000! and every year<br><br>importing into our harbors a well reaped harvest of $7,000,000.  How<br><br>comes all this, if there be not something puissant in whaling?<br><br><br><br>But this is not the half; look again.<br><br><br><br>I freely assert, that the cosmopolite philosopher cannot, for his<br><br>life, point out one single peaceful influence, which within the last<br><br>sixty years has operated more potentially upon the whole broad world,<br><br>taken in one aggregate, than the high and mighty business of whaling.<br><br>One way and another, it has begotten events so remarkable in<br><br>themselves, and so continuously momentous in their sequential issues,<br><br>that whaling may well be regarded as that Egyptian mother, who bore<br><br>offspring themselves pregnant from her womb.  It would be a hopeless,<br><br>endless task to catalogue all these things.  Let a handful suffice.<br><br>For many years past the whale-ship has been the pioneer in ferreting<br><br>out the remotest and least known parts of the earth.  She has<br><br>explored seas and archipelagoes which had no chart, where no Cook or<br><br>Vancouver had ever sailed.  If American and European men-of-war<br><br>now peacefully ride in once savage harbors, let them fire salutes to<br><br>the honour and glory of the whale-ship, which originally showed them<br><br>the way, and first interpreted between them and the savages.  They<br><br>may celebrate as they will the heroes of Exploring Expeditions, your<br><br>Cooks, your Krusensterns; but I say that scores of anonymous<br><br>Captains have sailed out of Nantucket, that were as great, and<br><br>greater than your Cook and your Krusenstern.  For in their<br><br>succourless empty-handedness, they, in the heathenish sharked waters,<br><br>and by the beaches of unrecorded, javelin islands, battled with<br><br>virgin wonders and terrors that Cook with all his marines and<br><br>muskets would not willingly have dared.  All that is made such a<br><br>flourish of in the old South Sea Voyages, those things were but the<br><br>life-time commonplaces of our heroic Nantucketers.  Often,<br><br>adventures which Vancouver dedicates three chapters to, these men<br><br>accounted unworthy of being set down in the ship's common log.  Ah,<br><br>the world!  Oh, the world!<br><br><br><br>Until the whale fishery rounded Cape Horn, no commerce but colonial,<br><br>scarcely any intercourse but colonial, was carried on between Europe<br><br>and the long line of the opulent Spanish provinces on the Pacific<br><br>coast.  It was the whaleman who first broke through the jealous<br><br>policy of the Spanish crown, touching those colonies; and, if space<br><br>permitted, it might be distinctly shown how from those whalemen at<br><br>last eventuated the liberation of Peru, Chili, and Bolivia from the<br><br>yoke of Old Spain, and the establishment of the eternal democracy in<br><br>those parts.<br><br><br><br>That great America on the other side of the sphere, Australia, was<br><br>given to the enlightened world by the whaleman.  After its first<br><br>blunder-born discovery by a Dutchman, all other ships long shunned<br><br>those shores as pestiferously barbarous; but the whale-ship touched<br><br>there.  The whale-ship is the true mother of that now mighty colony.<br><br>Moreover, in the infancy of the first Australian settlement, the<br><br>emigrants were several times saved from starvation by the benevolent<br><br>biscuit of the whale-ship luckily dropping an anchor in their waters.<br><br>The uncounted isles of all Polynesia confess the same truth, and do<br><br>commercial homage to the whale-ship, that cleared the way for the<br><br>missionary and the merchant, and in many cases carried the primitive<br><br>missionaries to their first destinations.  If that double-bolted<br><br>land, Japan, is ever to become hospitable, it is the whale-ship alone<br><br>to whom the credit will be due; for already she is on the threshold.<br><br><br><br>But if, in the face of all this, you still declare that whaling has<br><br>no aesthetically noble associations connected with it, then am I<br><br>ready to shiver fifty lances with you there, and unhorse you with a<br><br>split helmet every time.<br><br><br><br>The whale has no famous author, and whaling no famous chronicler, you<br><br>will say.<br><br><br><br>THE WHALE NO FAMOUS AUTHOR, AND WHALING NO FAMOUS CHRONICLER?  Who<br><br>wrote the first account of our Leviathan?  Who but mighty Job!  And<br><br>who composed the first narrative of a whaling-voyage?  Who, but no<br><br>less a prince than Alfred the Great, who, with his own royal pen,<br><br>took down the words from Other, the Norwegian whale-hunter of those<br><br>times!  And who pronounced our glowing eulogy in Parliament?  Who,<br><br>but Edmund Burke!<br><br><br><br>True enough, but then whalemen themselves are poor devils; they have<br><br>no good blood in their veins.<br><br><br><br>NO GOOD BLOOD IN THEIR VEINS?  They have something better than royal<br><br>blood there.  The grandmother of Benjamin Franklin was Mary Morrel;<br><br>afterwards, by marriage, Mary Folger, one of the old settlers of<br><br>Nantucket, and the ancestress to a long line of Folgers and<br><br>harpooneers--all kith and kin to noble Benjamin--this day darting the<br><br>barbed iron from one side of the world to the other.<br><br><br><br>Good again; but then all confess that somehow whaling is not<br><br>respectable.<br><br><br><br>WHALING NOT RESPECTABLE?  Whaling is imperial!  By old English<br><br>statutory law, the whale is declared "a royal fish."*<br><br><br><br>Oh, that's only nominal!  The whale himself has never figured in any<br><br>grand imposing way.<br><br><br><br>THE WHALE NEVER FIGURED IN ANY GRAND IMPOSING WAY?  In one of the<br><br>mighty triumphs given to a Roman general upon his entering the<br><br>world's capital, the bones of a whale, brought all the way from the<br><br>Syrian coast, were the most conspicuous object in the cymballed<br><br>procession.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*See subsequent chapters for something more on this head.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Grant it, since you cite it; but, say what you will, there is no real<br><br>dignity in whaling.<br><br><br><br>NO DIGNITY IN WHALING?  The dignity of our calling the very heavens<br><br>attest.  Cetus is a constellation in the South!  No more!  Drive<br><br>down your hat in presence of the Czar, and take it off to Queequeg!<br><br>No more!  I know a man that, in his lifetime, has taken three hundred<br><br>and fifty whales.  I account that man more honourable than that great<br><br>captain of antiquity who boasted of taking as many walled towns.<br><br><br><br>And, as for me, if, by any possibility, there be any as yet<br><br>undiscovered prime thing in me; if I shall ever deserve any real<br><br>repute in that small but high hushed world which I might not be<br><br>unreasonably ambitious of; if hereafter I shall do anything that, upon<br><br>the whole, a man might rather have done than to have left undone; if,<br><br>at my death, my executors, or more properly my creditors, find any<br><br>precious MSS. in my desk, then here I prospectively ascribe all the<br><br>honour and the glory to whaling; for a whale-ship was my Yale College<br><br>and my Harvard.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 25<br><br><br><br>Postscript.<br><br><br><br><br><br>In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance naught but<br><br>substantiated facts.  But after embattling his facts, an advocate who<br><br>should wholly suppress a not unreasonable surmise, which might tell<br><br>eloquently upon his cause--such an advocate, would he not be<br><br>blameworthy?<br><br><br><br>It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, even<br><br>modern ones, a certain curious process of seasoning them for their<br><br>functions is gone through.  There is a saltcellar of state, so<br><br>called, and there may be a castor of state.  How they use the salt,<br><br>precisely--who knows?  Certain I am, however, that a king's head is<br><br>solemnly oiled at his coronation, even as a head of salad.  Can it<br><br>be, though, that they anoint it with a view of making its interior<br><br>run well, as they anoint machinery?  Much might be ruminated here,<br><br>concerning the essential dignity of this regal process, because in<br><br>common life we esteem but meanly and contemptibly a fellow who<br><br>anoints his hair, and palpably smells of that anointing.  In truth, a<br><br>mature man who uses hair-oil, unless medicinally, that man has<br><br>probably got a quoggy spot in him somewhere.  As a general rule, he<br><br>can't amount to much in his totality.<br><br><br><br>But the only thing to be considered here, is this--what kind of oil<br><br>is used at coronations?  Certainly it cannot be olive oil, nor<br><br>macassar oil, nor castor oil, nor bear's oil, nor train oil, nor<br><br>cod-liver oil.  What then can it possibly be, but sperm oil in<br><br>its unmanufactured, unpolluted state, the sweetest of all oils?<br><br><br><br>Think of that, ye loyal Britons! we whalemen supply your kings and<br><br>queens with coronation stuff!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 26<br><br><br><br>Knights and Squires.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The chief mate of the Pequod was Starbuck, a native of Nantucket, and<br><br>a Quaker by descent.  He was a long, earnest man, and though born on<br><br>an icy coast, seemed well adapted to endure hot latitudes, his flesh<br><br>being hard as twice-baked biscuit.  Transported to the Indies, his<br><br>live blood would not spoil like bottled ale.  He must have been born<br><br>in some time of general drought and famine, or upon one of those fast<br><br>days for which his state is famous.  Only some thirty arid summers<br><br>had he seen; those summers had dried up all his physical<br><br>superfluousness.  But this, his thinness, so to speak, seemed no more<br><br>the token of wasting anxieties and cares, than it seemed the<br><br>indication of any bodily blight.  It was merely the condensation of<br><br>the man.  He was by no means ill-looking; quite the contrary.  His<br><br>pure tight skin was an excellent fit; and closely wrapped up in it,<br><br>and embalmed with inner health and strength, like a revivified<br><br>Egyptian, this Starbuck seemed prepared to endure for long ages to<br><br>come, and to endure always, as now; for be it Polar snow or torrid<br><br>sun, like a patent chronometer, his interior vitality was warranted<br><br>to do well in all climates.  Looking into his eyes, you seemed to<br><br>see there the yet lingering images of those thousand-fold perils he<br><br>had calmly confronted through life.  A staid, steadfast man, whose<br><br>life for the most part was a telling pantomime of action, and not a<br><br>tame chapter of sounds.  Yet, for all his hardy sobriety and<br><br>fortitude, there were certain qualities in him which at times<br><br>affected, and in some cases seemed well nigh to overbalance all the<br><br>rest.  Uncommonly conscientious for a seaman, and endued with a deep<br><br>natural reverence, the wild watery loneliness of his life did<br><br>therefore strongly incline him to superstition; but to that sort of<br><br>superstition, which in some organizations seems rather to spring,<br><br>somehow, from intelligence than from ignorance.  Outward portents and<br><br>inward presentiments were his.  And if at times these things bent the<br><br>welded iron of his soul, much more did his far-away domestic memories<br><br>of his young Cape wife and child, tend to bend him still more from<br><br>the original ruggedness of his nature, and open him still further to<br><br>those latent influences which, in some honest-hearted men, restrain<br><br>the gush of dare-devil daring, so often evinced by others in the more<br><br>perilous vicissitudes of the fishery.  "I will have no man in my<br><br>boat," said Starbuck, "who is not afraid of a whale."  By this, he<br><br>seemed to mean, not only that the most reliable and useful courage<br><br>was that which arises from the fair estimation of the encountered<br><br>peril, but that an utterly fearless man is a far more dangerous<br><br>comrade than a coward.<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye," said Stubb, the second mate, "Starbuck, there, is as<br><br>careful a man as you'll find anywhere in this fishery."  But we shall<br><br>ere long see what that word "careful" precisely means when used by a<br><br>man like Stubb, or almost any other whale hunter.<br><br><br><br>Starbuck was no crusader after perils; in him courage was not a<br><br>sentiment; but a thing simply useful to him, and always at hand upon<br><br>all mortally practical occasions.  Besides, he thought, perhaps, that<br><br>in this business of whaling, courage was one of the great staple<br><br>outfits of the ship, like her beef and her bread, and not to be<br><br>foolishly wasted.  Wherefore he had no fancy for lowering for whales<br><br>after sun-down; nor for persisting in fighting a fish that too much<br><br>persisted in fighting him.  For, thought Starbuck, I am here in this<br><br>critical ocean to kill whales for my living, and not to be killed by<br><br>them for theirs; and that hundreds of men had been so killed Starbuck<br><br>well knew.  What doom was his own father's?  Where, in the bottomless<br><br>deeps, could he find the torn limbs of his brother?<br><br><br><br>With memories like these in him, and, moreover, given to a certain<br><br>superstitiousness, as has been said; the courage of this Starbuck<br><br>which could, nevertheless, still flourish, must indeed have been<br><br>extreme.  But it was not in reasonable nature that a man so<br><br>organized, and with such terrible experiences and remembrances as he<br><br>had; it was not in nature that these things should fail in latently<br><br>engendering an element in him, which, under suitable circumstances,<br><br>would break out from its confinement, and burn all his courage up.<br><br>And brave as he might be, it was that sort of bravery chiefly,<br><br>visible in some intrepid men, which, while generally abiding firm in<br><br>the conflict with seas, or winds, or whales, or any of the ordinary<br><br>irrational horrors of the world, yet cannot withstand those more<br><br>terrific, because more spiritual terrors, which sometimes menace you<br><br>from the concentrating brow of an enraged and mighty man.<br><br><br><br>But were the coming narrative to reveal in any instance, the complete<br><br>abasement of poor Starbuck's fortitude, scarce might I have the heart<br><br>to write it; for it is a thing most sorrowful, nay shocking, to<br><br>expose the fall of valour in the soul.  Men may seem detestable as<br><br>joint stock-companies and nations; knaves, fools, and murderers there<br><br>may be; men may have mean and meagre faces; but man, in the ideal,<br><br>is so noble and so sparkling, such a grand and glowing creature, that<br><br>over any ignominious blemish in him all his fellows should run to<br><br>throw their costliest robes.  That immaculate manliness we feel<br><br>within ourselves, so far within us, that it remains intact though all<br><br>the outer character seem gone; bleeds with keenest anguish at the<br><br>undraped spectacle of a valor-ruined man.  Nor can piety itself, at<br><br>such a shameful sight, completely stifle her upbraidings against the<br><br>permitting stars.  But this august dignity I treat of, is not the<br><br>dignity of kings and robes, but that abounding dignity which has no<br><br>robed investiture.  Thou shalt see it shining in the arm that wields<br><br>a pick or drives a spike; that democratic dignity which, on all<br><br>hands, radiates without end from God; Himself!  The great God<br><br>absolute!  The centre and circumference of all democracy!  His<br><br>omnipresence, our divine equality!<br><br><br><br>If, then, to meanest mariners, and renegades and castaways, I shall<br><br>hereafter ascribe high qualities, though dark; weave round them<br><br>tragic graces; if even the most mournful, perchance the most abased,<br><br>among them all, shall at times lift himself to the exalted mounts; if<br><br>I shall touch that workman's arm with some ethereal light; if I shall<br><br>spread a rainbow over his disastrous set of sun; then against all<br><br>mortal critics bear me out in it, thou Just Spirit of Equality,<br><br>which hast spread one royal mantle of humanity over all my kind!<br><br>Bear me out in it, thou great democratic God! who didst not refuse to<br><br>the swart convict, Bunyan, the pale, poetic pearl; Thou who didst<br><br>clothe with doubly hammered leaves of finest gold, the stumped and<br><br>paupered arm of old Cervantes; Thou who didst pick up Andrew Jackson<br><br>from the pebbles; who didst hurl him upon a war-horse; who didst<br><br>thunder him higher than a throne!  Thou who, in all Thy mighty,<br><br>earthly marchings, ever cullest Thy selectest champions from the<br><br>kingly commons; bear me out in it, O God!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 27<br><br><br><br>Knights and Squires.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Stubb was the second mate.  He was a native of Cape Cod; and hence,<br><br>according to local usage, was called a Cape-Cod-man.  A<br><br>happy-go-lucky; neither craven nor valiant; taking perils as they<br><br>came with an indifferent air; and while engaged in the most imminent<br><br>crisis of the chase, toiling away, calm and collected as a journeyman<br><br>joiner engaged for the year.  Good-humored, easy, and careless, he<br><br>presided over his whale-boat as if the most deadly encounter were but<br><br>a dinner, and his crew all invited guests.  He was as particular<br><br>about the comfortable arrangement of his part of the boat, as an<br><br>old stage-driver is about the snugness of his box.  When close to the<br><br>whale, in the very death-lock of the fight, he handled his unpitying<br><br>lance coolly and off-handedly, as a whistling tinker his hammer.  He<br><br>would hum over his old rigadig tunes while flank and flank with the<br><br>most exasperated monster.  Long usage had, for this Stubb, converted<br><br>the jaws of death into an easy chair.  What he thought of death<br><br>itself, there is no telling.  Whether he ever thought of it at all,<br><br>might be a question; but, if he ever did chance to cast his mind that<br><br>way after a comfortable dinner, no doubt, like a good sailor, he took<br><br>it to be a sort of call of the watch to tumble aloft, and bestir<br><br>themselves there, about something which he would find out when he<br><br>obeyed the order, and not sooner.<br><br><br><br>What, perhaps, with other things, made Stubb such an easy-going,<br><br>unfearing man, so cheerily trudging off with the burden of life in a<br><br>world full of grave pedlars, all bowed to the ground with their<br><br>packs; what helped to bring about that almost impious good-humor of<br><br>his; that thing must have been his pipe.  For, like his nose, his<br><br>short, black little pipe was one of the regular features of his face.<br><br>You would almost as soon have expected him to turn out of his bunk<br><br>without his nose as without his pipe.  He kept a whole row of pipes<br><br>there ready loaded, stuck in a rack, within easy reach of his hand;<br><br>and, whenever he turned in, he smoked them all out in succession,<br><br>lighting one from the other to the end of the chapter; then loading<br><br>them again to be in readiness anew.  For, when Stubb dressed, instead<br><br>of first putting his legs into his trowsers, he put his pipe into his<br><br>mouth.<br><br><br><br>I say this continual smoking must have been one cause, at least, of<br><br>his peculiar disposition; for every one knows that this earthly air,<br><br>whether ashore or afloat, is terribly infected with the nameless<br><br>miseries of the numberless mortals who have died exhaling it; and as<br><br>in time of the cholera, some people go about with a camphorated<br><br>handkerchief to their mouths; so, likewise, against all mortal<br><br>tribulations, Stubb's tobacco smoke might have operated as a sort of<br><br>disinfecting agent.<br><br><br><br>The third mate was Flask, a native of Tisbury, in Martha's Vineyard.<br><br>A short, stout, ruddy young fellow, very pugnacious concerning<br><br>whales, who somehow seemed to think that the great leviathans had<br><br>personally and hereditarily affronted him; and therefore it was a<br><br>sort of point of honour with him, to destroy them whenever<br><br>encountered.  So utterly lost was he to all sense of reverence for<br><br>the many marvels of their majestic bulk and mystic ways; and so dead<br><br>to anything like an apprehension of any possible danger from<br><br>encountering them; that in his poor opinion, the wondrous whale was<br><br>but a species of magnified mouse, or at least water-rat, requiring<br><br>only a little circumvention and some small application of time and<br><br>trouble in order to kill and boil.  This ignorant, unconscious<br><br>fearlessness of his made him a little waggish in the matter of<br><br>whales; he followed these fish for the fun of it; and a three years'<br><br>voyage round Cape Horn was only a jolly joke that lasted that length<br><br>of time.  As a carpenter's nails are divided into wrought nails and<br><br>cut nails; so mankind may be similarly divided.  Little Flask was one<br><br>of the wrought ones; made to clinch tight and last long.  They called<br><br>him King-Post on board of the Pequod; because, in form, he could be<br><br>well likened to the short, square timber known by that name in Arctic<br><br>whalers; and which by the means of many radiating side timbers<br><br>inserted into it, serves to brace the ship against the icy<br><br>concussions of those battering seas.<br><br><br><br>Now these three mates--Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask, were momentous<br><br>men.  They it was who by universal prescription commanded three of the<br><br>Pequod's boats as headsmen.  In that grand order of battle in which<br><br>Captain Ahab would probably marshal his forces to descend on the<br><br>whales, these three headsmen were as captains of companies.  Or,<br><br>being armed with their long keen whaling spears, they were as a<br><br>picked trio of lancers; even as the harpooneers were flingers of<br><br>javelins.<br><br><br><br>And since in this famous fishery, each mate or headsman, like a<br><br>Gothic Knight of old, is always accompanied by his boat-steerer or<br><br>harpooneer, who in certain conjunctures provides him with a fresh<br><br>lance, when the former one has been badly twisted, or elbowed in the<br><br>assault; and moreover, as there generally subsists between the two, a<br><br>close intimacy and friendliness; it is therefore but meet, that in<br><br>this place we set down who the Pequod's harpooneers were, and to what<br><br>headsman each of them belonged.<br><br><br><br>First of all was Queequeg, whom Starbuck, the chief mate, had<br><br>selected for his squire.  But Queequeg is already known.<br><br><br><br>Next was Tashtego, an unmixed Indian from Gay Head, the most westerly<br><br>promontory of Martha's Vineyard, where there still exists the last<br><br>remnant of a village of red men, which has long supplied the<br><br>neighboring island of Nantucket with many of her most daring<br><br>harpooneers.  In the fishery, they usually go by the generic name of<br><br>Gay-Headers.  Tashtego's long, lean, sable hair, his high cheek<br><br>bones, and black rounding eyes--for an Indian, Oriental in their<br><br>largeness, but Antarctic in their glittering expression--all this<br><br>sufficiently proclaimed him an inheritor of the unvitiated blood of<br><br>those proud warrior hunters, who, in quest of the great New England<br><br>moose, had scoured, bow in hand, the aboriginal forests of the main.<br><br>But no longer snuffing in the trail of the wild beasts of the<br><br>woodland, Tashtego now hunted in the wake of the great whales of the<br><br>sea; the unerring harpoon of the son fitly replacing the infallible<br><br>arrow of the sires.  To look at the tawny brawn of his lithe snaky<br><br>limbs, you would almost have credited the superstitions of some of<br><br>the earlier Puritans, and half-believed this wild Indian to be a son<br><br>of the Prince of the Powers of the Air.  Tashtego was Stubb the<br><br>second mate's squire.<br><br><br><br>Third among the harpooneers was Daggoo, a gigantic, coal-black<br><br>negro-savage, with a lion-like tread--an Ahasuerus to behold.<br><br>Suspended from his ears were two golden hoops, so large that the<br><br>sailors called them ring-bolts, and would talk of securing the<br><br>top-sail halyards to them.  In his youth Daggoo had voluntarily<br><br>shipped on board of a whaler, lying in a lonely bay on his native<br><br>coast.  And never having been anywhere in the world but in Africa,<br><br>Nantucket, and the pagan harbors most frequented by whalemen; and<br><br>having now led for many years the bold life of the fishery in the<br><br>ships of owners uncommonly heedful of what manner of men they<br><br>shipped; Daggoo retained all his barbaric virtues, and erect as a<br><br>giraffe, moved about the decks in all the pomp of six feet five in<br><br>his socks.  There was a corporeal humility in looking up at him; and<br><br>a white man standing before him seemed a white flag come to beg truce<br><br>of a fortress.  Curious to tell, this imperial negro, Ahasuerus<br><br>Daggoo, was the Squire of little Flask, who looked like a chess-man<br><br>beside him.  As for the residue of the Pequod's company, be it said,<br><br>that at the present day not one in two of the many thousand men<br><br>before the mast employed in the American whale fishery, are Americans<br><br>born, though pretty nearly all the officers are.  Herein it is the<br><br>same with the American whale fishery as with the American army and<br><br>military and merchant navies, and the engineering forces employed in<br><br>the construction of the American Canals and Railroads.  The same, I<br><br>say, because in all these cases the native American liberally<br><br>provides the brains, the rest of the world as generously supplying<br><br>the muscles.  No small number of these whaling seamen belong to the<br><br>Azores, where the outward bound Nantucket whalers frequently touch to<br><br>augment their crews from the hardy peasants of those rocky shores.<br><br>In like manner, the Greenland whalers sailing out of Hull or London,<br><br>put in at the Shetland Islands, to receive the full complement of<br><br>their crew.  Upon the passage homewards, they drop them there again.<br><br>How it is, there is no telling, but Islanders seem to make the best<br><br>whalemen.  They were nearly all Islanders in the Pequod, ISOLATOES<br><br>too, I call such, not acknowledging the common continent of men, but<br><br>each ISOLATO living on a separate continent of his own.  Yet now,<br><br>federated along one keel, what a set these Isolatoes were!  An<br><br>Anacharsis Clootz deputation from all the isles of the sea, and all<br><br>the ends of the earth, accompanying Old Ahab in the Pequod to lay the<br><br>world's grievances before that bar from which not very many of them<br><br>ever come back.  Black Little Pip--he never did--oh, no! he went<br><br>before.  Poor Alabama boy!  On the grim Pequod's forecastle, ye shall<br><br>ere long see him, beating his tambourine; prelusive of the eternal<br><br>time, when sent for, to the great quarter-deck on high, he was bid<br><br>strike in with angels, and beat his tambourine in glory; called a<br><br>coward here, hailed a hero there!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 28<br><br><br><br>Ahab.<br><br><br><br><br><br>For several days after leaving Nantucket, nothing above hatches was<br><br>seen of Captain Ahab.  The mates regularly relieved each other at the<br><br>watches, and for aught that could be seen to the contrary, they<br><br>seemed to be the only commanders of the ship; only they sometimes<br><br>issued from the cabin with orders so sudden and peremptory, that<br><br>after all it was plain they but commanded vicariously.  Yes, their<br><br>supreme lord and dictator was there, though hitherto unseen by any<br><br>eyes not permitted to penetrate into the now sacred retreat of the<br><br>cabin.<br><br><br><br>Every time I ascended to the deck from my watches below, I instantly<br><br>gazed aft to mark if any strange face were visible; for my first<br><br>vague disquietude touching the unknown captain, now in the seclusion<br><br>of the sea, became almost a perturbation.  This was strangely<br><br>heightened at times by the ragged Elijah's diabolical incoherences<br><br>uninvitedly recurring to me, with a subtle energy I could not have<br><br>before conceived of.  But poorly could I withstand them, much as in<br><br>other moods I was almost ready to smile at the solemn whimsicalities<br><br>of that outlandish prophet of the wharves.  But whatever it was of<br><br>apprehensiveness or uneasiness--to call it so--which I felt, yet<br><br>whenever I came to look about me in the ship, it seemed against all<br><br>warrantry to cherish such emotions.  For though the harpooneers, with<br><br>the great body of the crew, were a far more barbaric, heathenish, and<br><br>motley set than any of the tame merchant-ship companies which my<br><br>previous experiences had made me acquainted with, still I ascribed<br><br>this--and rightly ascribed it--to the fierce uniqueness of the very<br><br>nature of that wild Scandinavian vocation in which I had so<br><br>abandonedly embarked.  But it was especially the aspect of the three<br><br>chief officers of the ship, the mates, which was most forcibly<br><br>calculated to allay these colourless misgivings, and induce confidence<br><br>and cheerfulness in every presentment of the voyage.  Three better,<br><br>more likely sea-officers and men, each in his own different way,<br><br>could not readily be found, and they were every one of them<br><br>Americans; a Nantucketer, a Vineyarder, a Cape man.  Now, it being<br><br>Christmas when the ship shot from out her harbor, for a space we had<br><br>biting Polar weather, though all the time running away from it to the<br><br>southward; and by every degree and minute of latitude which we<br><br>sailed, gradually leaving that merciless winter, and all its<br><br>intolerable weather behind us.  It was one of those less lowering,<br><br>but still grey and gloomy enough mornings of the transition, when<br><br>with a fair wind the ship was rushing through the water with a<br><br>vindictive sort of leaping and melancholy rapidity, that as I mounted<br><br>to the deck at the call of the forenoon watch, so soon as I levelled<br><br>my glance towards the taffrail, foreboding shivers ran over me.<br><br>Reality outran apprehension; Captain Ahab stood upon his<br><br>quarter-deck.<br><br><br><br>There seemed no sign of common bodily illness about him, nor of the<br><br>recovery from any.  He looked like a man cut away from the stake,<br><br>when the fire has overrunningly wasted all the limbs without<br><br>consuming them, or taking away one particle from their compacted aged<br><br>robustness.  His whole high, broad form, seemed made of solid bronze,<br><br>and shaped in an unalterable mould, like Cellini's cast Perseus.<br><br>Threading its way out from among his grey hairs, and continuing right<br><br>down one side of his tawny scorched face and neck, till it<br><br>disappeared in his clothing, you saw a slender rod-like mark, lividly<br><br>whitish.  It resembled that perpendicular seam sometimes made in the<br><br>straight, lofty trunk of a great tree, when the upper lightning<br><br>tearingly darts down it, and without wrenching a single twig, peels<br><br>and grooves out the bark from top to bottom, ere running off into the<br><br>soil, leaving the tree still greenly alive, but branded.  Whether<br><br>that mark was born with him, or whether it was the scar left by some<br><br>desperate wound, no one could certainly say.  By some tacit consent,<br><br>throughout the voyage little or no allusion was made to it,<br><br>especially by the mates.  But once Tashtego's senior, an old Gay-Head<br><br>Indian among the crew, superstitiously asserted that not till he was<br><br>full forty years old did Ahab become that way branded, and then it<br><br>came upon him, not in the fury of any mortal fray, but in an<br><br>elemental strife at sea.  Yet, this wild hint seemed inferentially<br><br>negatived, by what a grey Manxman insinuated, an old sepulchral man,<br><br>who, having never before sailed out of Nantucket, had never ere this<br><br>laid eye upon wild Ahab.  Nevertheless, the old sea-traditions, the<br><br>immemorial credulities, popularly invested this old Manxman with<br><br>preternatural powers of discernment.  So that no white sailor<br><br>seriously contradicted him when he said that if ever Captain Ahab<br><br>should be tranquilly laid out--which might hardly come to pass, so he<br><br>muttered--then, whoever should do that last office for the dead,<br><br>would find a birth-mark on him from crown to sole.<br><br><br><br>So powerfully did the whole grim aspect of Ahab affect me, and the<br><br>livid brand which streaked it, that for the first few moments I<br><br>hardly noted that not a little of this overbearing grimness was owing<br><br>to the barbaric white leg upon which he partly stood.  It had<br><br>previously come to me that this ivory leg had at sea been fashioned<br><br>from the polished bone of the sperm whale's jaw.  "Aye, he was<br><br>dismasted off Japan," said the old Gay-Head Indian once; "but like<br><br>his dismasted craft, he shipped another mast without coming home for<br><br>it.  He has a quiver of 'em."<br><br><br><br>I was struck with the singular posture he maintained.  Upon each side<br><br>of the Pequod's quarter deck, and pretty close to the mizzen shrouds,<br><br>there was an auger hole, bored about half an inch or so, into the<br><br>plank.  His bone leg steadied in that hole; one arm elevated, and<br><br>holding by a shroud; Captain Ahab stood erect, looking straight out<br><br>beyond the ship's ever-pitching prow.  There was an infinity of<br><br>firmest fortitude, a determinate, unsurrenderable wilfulness, in the<br><br>fixed and fearless, forward dedication of that glance.  Not a word he<br><br>spoke; nor did his officers say aught to him; though by all their<br><br>minutest gestures and expressions, they plainly showed the uneasy, if<br><br>not painful, consciousness of being under a troubled master-eye.  And<br><br>not only that, but moody stricken Ahab stood before them with a<br><br>crucifixion in his face; in all the nameless regal overbearing<br><br>dignity of some mighty woe.<br><br><br><br>Ere long, from his first visit in the air, he withdrew into his<br><br>cabin.  But after that morning, he was every day visible to the crew;<br><br>either standing in his pivot-hole, or seated upon an ivory stool he<br><br>had; or heavily walking the deck.  As the sky grew less gloomy;<br><br>indeed, began to grow a little genial, he became still less and less<br><br>a recluse; as if, when the ship had sailed from home, nothing but the<br><br>dead wintry bleakness of the sea had then kept him so secluded.  And,<br><br>by and by, it came to pass, that he was almost continually in the<br><br>air; but, as yet, for all that he said, or perceptibly did, on the at<br><br>last sunny deck, he seemed as unnecessary there as another mast.  But<br><br>the Pequod was only making a passage now; not regularly cruising;<br><br>nearly all whaling preparatives needing supervision the mates were<br><br>fully competent to, so that there was little or nothing, out of<br><br>himself, to employ or excite Ahab, now; and thus chase away, for that<br><br>one interval, the clouds that layer upon layer were piled upon his<br><br>brow, as ever all clouds choose the loftiest peaks to pile themselves<br><br>upon.<br><br><br><br>Nevertheless, ere long, the warm, warbling persuasiveness of the<br><br>pleasant, holiday weather we came to, seemed gradually to charm him<br><br>from his mood.  For, as when the red-cheeked, dancing girls, April<br><br>and May, trip home to the wintry, misanthropic woods; even the<br><br>barest, ruggedest, most thunder-cloven old oak will at least send<br><br>forth some few green sprouts, to welcome such glad-hearted visitants;<br><br>so Ahab did, in the end, a little respond to the playful allurings of<br><br>that girlish air.  More than once did he put forth the faint blossom<br><br>of a look, which, in any other man, would have soon flowered out in a<br><br>smile.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 29<br><br><br><br>Enter Ahab; to Him, Stubb.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Some days elapsed, and ice and icebergs all astern, the Pequod now<br><br>went rolling through the bright Quito spring, which, at sea, almost<br><br>perpetually reigns on the threshold of the eternal August of the<br><br>Tropic.  The warmly cool, clear, ringing, perfumed, overflowing,<br><br>redundant days, were as crystal goblets of Persian sherbet, heaped<br><br>up--flaked up, with rose-water snow.  The starred and stately nights<br><br>seemed haughty dames in jewelled velvets, nursing at home in lonely<br><br>pride, the memory of their absent conquering Earls, the golden<br><br>helmeted suns!  For sleeping man, 'twas hard to choose between such<br><br>winsome days and such seducing nights.  But all the witcheries of<br><br>that unwaning weather did not merely lend new spells and potencies to<br><br>the outward world.  Inward they turned upon the soul, especially when<br><br>the still mild hours of eve came on; then, memory shot her crystals<br><br>as the clear ice most forms of noiseless twilights.  And all these<br><br>subtle agencies, more and more they wrought on Ahab's texture.<br><br><br><br>Old age is always wakeful; as if, the longer linked with life, the<br><br>less man has to do with aught that looks like death.  Among<br><br>sea-commanders, the old greybeards will oftenest leave their berths<br><br>to visit the night-cloaked deck.  It was so with Ahab; only that now,<br><br>of late, he seemed so much to live in the open air, that truly<br><br>speaking, his visits were more to the cabin, than from the cabin to<br><br>the planks.  "It feels like going down into one's tomb,"--he would<br><br>mutter to himself--"for an old captain like me to be descending this<br><br>narrow scuttle, to go to my grave-dug berth."<br><br><br><br>So, almost every twenty-four hours, when the watches of the night<br><br>were set, and the band on deck sentinelled the slumbers of the band<br><br>below; and when if a rope was to be hauled upon the forecastle, the<br><br>sailors flung it not rudely down, as by day, but with some<br><br>cautiousness dropt it to its place for fear of disturbing their<br><br>slumbering shipmates; when this sort of steady quietude would begin<br><br>to prevail, habitually, the silent steersman would watch the<br><br>cabin-scuttle; and ere long the old man would emerge, gripping at the<br><br>iron banister, to help his crippled way.  Some considering touch of<br><br>humanity was in him; for at times like these, he usually abstained<br><br>from patrolling the quarter-deck; because to his wearied mates,<br><br>seeking repose within six inches of his ivory heel, such would have<br><br>been the reverberating crack and din of that bony step, that their<br><br>dreams would have been on the crunching teeth of sharks.  But once,<br><br>the mood was on him too deep for common regardings; and as with<br><br>heavy, lumber-like pace he was measuring the ship from taffrail to<br><br>mainmast, Stubb, the old second mate, came up from below, with a<br><br>certain unassured, deprecating humorousness, hinted that if Captain<br><br>Ahab was pleased to walk the planks, then, no one could say nay; but<br><br>there might be some way of muffling the noise; hinting something<br><br>indistinctly and hesitatingly about a globe of tow, and the insertion<br><br>into it, of the ivory heel.  Ah!  Stubb, thou didst not know Ahab<br><br>then.<br><br><br><br>"Am I a cannon-ball, Stubb," said Ahab, "that thou wouldst wad me<br><br>that fashion?  But go thy ways; I had forgot.  Below to thy nightly<br><br>grave; where such as ye sleep between shrouds, to use ye to the<br><br>filling one at last.--Down, dog, and kennel!"<br><br><br><br>Starting at the unforseen concluding exclamation of the so suddenly<br><br>scornful old man, Stubb was speechless a moment; then said excitedly,<br><br>"I am not used to be spoken to that way, sir; I do but less than half<br><br>like it, sir."<br><br><br><br>"Avast! gritted Ahab between his set teeth, and violently moving<br><br>away, as if to avoid some passionate temptation.<br><br><br><br>"No, sir; not yet," said Stubb, emboldened, "I will not tamely be<br><br>called a dog, sir."<br><br><br><br>"Then be called ten times a donkey, and a mule, and an ass, and<br><br>begone, or I'll clear the world of thee!"<br><br><br><br>As he said this, Ahab advanced upon him with such overbearing terrors<br><br>in his aspect, that Stubb involuntarily retreated.<br><br><br><br>"I was never served so before without giving a hard blow for it,"<br><br>muttered Stubb, as he found himself descending the cabin-scuttle.<br><br>"It's very queer.  Stop, Stubb; somehow, now, I don't well know<br><br>whether to go back and strike him, or--what's that?--down here on my<br><br>knees and pray for him?  Yes, that was the thought coming up in me;<br><br>but it would be the first time I ever DID pray.  It's queer; very<br><br>queer; and he's queer too; aye, take him fore and aft, he's about the<br><br>queerest old man Stubb ever sailed with.  How he flashed at me!--his<br><br>eyes like powder-pans! is he mad?  Anyway there's something on his<br><br>mind, as sure as there must be something on a deck when it cracks.<br><br>He aint in his bed now, either, more than three hours out of the<br><br>twenty-four; and he don't sleep then.  Didn't that Dough-Boy, the<br><br>steward, tell me that of a morning he always finds the old man's<br><br>hammock clothes all rumpled and tumbled, and the sheets down at the<br><br>foot, and the coverlid almost tied into knots, and the pillow a sort<br><br>of frightful hot, as though a baked brick had been on it?  A hot old<br><br>man!  I guess he's got what some folks ashore call a conscience; it's<br><br>a kind of Tic-Dolly-row they say--worse nor a toothache.  Well, well;<br><br>I don't know what it is, but the Lord keep me from catching it.  He's<br><br>full of riddles; I wonder what he goes into the after hold for, every<br><br>night, as Dough-Boy tells me he suspects; what's that for, I should<br><br>like to know?  Who's made appointments with him in the hold?  Ain't<br><br>that queer, now?  But there's no telling, it's the old game--Here<br><br>goes for a snooze.  Damn me, it's worth a fellow's while to be born<br><br>into the world, if only to fall right asleep.  And now that I think<br><br>of it, that's about the first thing babies do, and that's a sort of<br><br>queer, too.  Damn me, but all things are queer, come to think of 'em.<br><br>But that's against my principles.  Think not, is my eleventh<br><br>commandment; and sleep when you can, is my twelfth--So here goes<br><br>again.  But how's that? didn't he call me a dog? blazes! he called me<br><br>ten times a donkey, and piled a lot of jackasses on top of THAT!  He<br><br>might as well have kicked me, and done with it.  Maybe he DID kick<br><br>me, and I didn't observe it, I was so taken all aback with his brow,<br><br>somehow.  It flashed like a bleached bone.  What the devil's the<br><br>matter with me?  I don't stand right on my legs.  Coming afoul of<br><br>that old man has a sort of turned me wrong side out.  By the Lord, I<br><br>must have been dreaming, though--How? how? how?--but the only way's<br><br>to stash it; so here goes to hammock again; and in the morning, I'll<br><br>see how this plaguey juggling thinks over by daylight."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 30<br><br><br><br>The Pipe.<br><br><br><br><br><br>When Stubb had departed, Ahab stood for a while leaning over the<br><br>bulwarks; and then, as had been usual with him of late, calling a<br><br>sailor of the watch, he sent him below for his ivory stool, and also<br><br>his pipe.  Lighting the pipe at the binnacle lamp and planting the<br><br>stool on the weather side of the deck, he sat and smoked.<br><br><br><br>In old Norse times, the thrones of the sea-loving Danish kings were<br><br>fabricated, saith tradition, of the tusks of the narwhale.  How could<br><br>one look at Ahab then, seated on that tripod of bones, without<br><br>bethinking him of the royalty it symbolized?  For a Khan of the<br><br>plank, and a king of the sea, and a great lord of Leviathans was<br><br>Ahab.<br><br><br><br>Some moments passed, during which the thick vapour came from his mouth<br><br>in quick and constant puffs, which blew back again into his face.<br><br>"How now," he soliloquized at last, withdrawing the tube, "this<br><br>smoking no longer soothes.  Oh, my pipe! hard must it go with me if<br><br>thy charm be gone!  Here have I been unconsciously toiling, not<br><br>pleasuring--aye, and ignorantly smoking to windward all the while; to<br><br>windward, and with such nervous whiffs, as if, like the dying whale,<br><br>my final jets were the strongest and fullest of trouble.  What<br><br>business have I with this pipe?  This thing that is meant for<br><br>sereneness, to send up mild white vapours among mild white hairs, not<br><br>among torn iron-grey locks like mine.  I'll smoke no more--"<br><br><br><br>He tossed the still lighted pipe into the sea.  The fire hissed in<br><br>the waves; the same instant the ship shot by the bubble the sinking<br><br>pipe made.  With slouched hat, Ahab lurchingly paced the planks.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 31<br><br><br><br>Queen Mab.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Next morning Stubb accosted Flask.<br><br><br><br>"Such a queer dream, King-Post, I never had.  You know the old man's<br><br>ivory leg, well I dreamed he kicked me with it; and when I tried to<br><br>kick back, upon my soul, my little man, I kicked my leg right off!<br><br>And then, presto!  Ahab seemed a pyramid, and I, like a blazing fool,<br><br>kept kicking at it.  But what was still more curious, Flask--you know<br><br>how curious all dreams are--through all this rage that I was in, I<br><br>somehow seemed to be thinking to myself, that after all, it was not<br><br>much of an insult, that kick from Ahab.  'Why,' thinks I, 'what's the<br><br>row?  It's not a real leg, only a false leg.'  And there's a mighty<br><br>difference between a living thump and a dead thump.  That's what<br><br>makes a blow from the hand, Flask, fifty times more savage to bear<br><br>than a blow from a cane.  The living member--that makes the living<br><br>insult, my little man.  And thinks I to myself all the while, mind,<br><br>while I was stubbing my silly toes against that cursed pyramid--so<br><br>confoundedly contradictory was it all, all the while, I say, I was<br><br>thinking to myself, 'what's his leg now, but a cane--a whalebone<br><br>cane.  Yes,' thinks I, 'it was only a playful cudgelling--in fact,<br><br>only a whaleboning that he gave me--not a base kick.  Besides,'<br><br>thinks I, 'look at it once; why, the end of it--the foot part--what a<br><br>small sort of end it is; whereas, if a broad footed farmer kicked me,<br><br>THERE'S a devilish broad insult.  But this insult is whittled down to<br><br>a point only.'  But now comes the greatest joke of the dream, Flask.<br><br>While I was battering away at the pyramid, a sort of badger-haired<br><br>old merman, with a hump on his back, takes me by the shoulders, and<br><br>slews me round.  'What are you 'bout?' says he.  Slid! man, but I was<br><br>frightened.  Such a phiz!  But, somehow, next moment I was over the<br><br>fright.  'What am I about?' says I at last.  'And what business is<br><br>that of yours, I should like to know, Mr. Humpback?  Do YOU want a<br><br>kick?'  By the lord, Flask, I had no sooner said that, than he turned<br><br>round his stern to me, bent over, and dragging up a lot of seaweed he<br><br>had for a clout--what do you think, I saw?--why thunder alive, man,<br><br>his stern was stuck full of marlinspikes, with the points out.  Says<br><br>I, on second thoughts, 'I guess I won't kick you, old fellow.'  'Wise<br><br>Stubb,' said he, 'wise Stubb;' and kept muttering it all the time, a<br><br>sort of eating of his own gums like a chimney hag.  Seeing he wasn't<br><br>going to stop saying over his 'wise Stubb, wise Stubb,' I thought I<br><br>might as well fall to kicking the pyramid again.  But I had only just<br><br>lifted my foot for it, when he roared out, 'Stop that kicking!'<br><br>'Halloa,' says I, 'what's the matter now, old fellow?'  'Look ye<br><br>here,' says he; 'let's argue the insult.  Captain Ahab kicked ye,<br><br>didn't he?'  'Yes, he did,' says I--'right HERE it was.'  'Very<br><br>good,' says he--'he used his ivory leg, didn't he?'  'Yes, he did,'<br><br>says I.  'Well then,' says he, 'wise Stubb, what have you to complain<br><br>of?  Didn't he kick with right good will? it wasn't a common pitch<br><br>pine leg he kicked with, was it?  No, you were kicked by a great man,<br><br>and with a beautiful ivory leg, Stubb.  It's an honour; I consider it<br><br>an honour.  Listen, wise Stubb.  In old England the greatest lords<br><br>think it great glory to be slapped by a queen, and made<br><br>garter-knights of; but, be YOUR boast, Stubb, that ye were kicked by<br><br>old Ahab, and made a wise man of.  Remember what I say; BE kicked by<br><br>him; account his kicks honours; and on no account kick back; for you<br><br>can't help yourself, wise Stubb.  Don't you see that pyramid?'  With<br><br>that, he all of a sudden seemed somehow, in some queer fashion, to<br><br>swim off into the air.  I snored; rolled over; and there I was in my<br><br>hammock!  Now, what do you think of that dream, Flask?"<br><br><br><br>"I don't know; it seems a sort of foolish to me, tho.'"<br><br><br><br>"May be; may be.  But it's made a wise man of me, Flask.  D'ye see<br><br>Ahab standing there, sideways looking over the stern?  Well, the best<br><br>thing you can do, Flask, is to let the old man alone; never speak to<br><br>him, whatever he says.  Halloa!  What's that he shouts?  Hark!"<br><br><br><br>"Mast-head, there!  Look sharp, all of ye!  There are whales<br><br>hereabouts!<br><br><br><br>If ye see a white one, split your lungs for him!<br><br><br><br>"What do you think of that now, Flask? ain't there a small drop of<br><br>something queer about that, eh?  A white whale--did ye mark that,<br><br>man?  Look ye--there's something special in the wind.  Stand by for<br><br>it, Flask.  Ahab has that that's bloody on his mind.  But, mum; he<br><br>comes this way."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 32<br><br><br><br>Cetology.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Already we are boldly launched upon the deep; but soon we shall be<br><br>lost in its unshored, harbourless immensities.  Ere that come to pass;<br><br>ere the Pequod's weedy hull rolls side by side with the barnacled<br><br>hulls of the leviathan; at the outset it is but well to attend to a<br><br>matter almost indispensable to a thorough appreciative understanding<br><br>of the more special leviathanic revelations and allusions of all<br><br>sorts which are to follow.<br><br><br><br>It is some systematized exhibition of the whale in his broad genera,<br><br>that I would now fain put before you.  Yet is it no easy task.  The<br><br>classification of the constituents of a chaos, nothing less is here<br><br>essayed.  Listen to what the best and latest authorities have laid<br><br>down.<br><br><br><br>"No branch of Zoology is so much involved as that which is entitled<br><br>Cetology," says Captain Scoresby, A.D. 1820.<br><br><br><br>"It is not my intention, were it in my power, to enter into the<br><br>inquiry as to the true method of dividing the cetacea into groups and<br><br>families....  Utter confusion exists among the historians of this<br><br>animal" (sperm whale), says Surgeon Beale, A.D. 1839.<br><br><br><br>"Unfitness to pursue our research in the unfathomable waters."<br><br>"Impenetrable veil covering our knowledge of the cetacea."  "A field<br><br>strewn with thorns."  "All these incomplete indications but serve to<br><br>torture us naturalists."<br><br><br><br>Thus speak of the whale, the great Cuvier, and John Hunter, and<br><br>Lesson, those lights of zoology and anatomy.  Nevertheless, though of<br><br>real knowledge there be little, yet of books there are a plenty; and<br><br>so in some small degree, with cetology, or the science of whales.<br><br>Many are the men, small and great, old and new, landsmen and seamen,<br><br>who have at large or in little, written of the whale.  Run over a<br><br>few:--The Authors of the Bible; Aristotle; Pliny; Aldrovandi; Sir<br><br>Thomas Browne; Gesner; Ray; Linnaeus; Rondeletius; Willoughby; Green;<br><br>Artedi; Sibbald; Brisson; Marten; Lacepede; Bonneterre; Desmarest;<br><br>Baron Cuvier; Frederick Cuvier; John Hunter; Owen; Scoresby; Beale;<br><br>Bennett; J.  Ross Browne; the Author of Miriam Coffin; Olmstead; and<br><br>the Rev.  T.  Cheever.  But to what ultimate generalizing purpose all<br><br>these have written, the above cited extracts will show.<br><br><br><br>Of the names in this list of whale authors, only those following Owen<br><br>ever saw living whales; and but one of them was a real professional<br><br>harpooneer and whaleman.  I mean Captain Scoresby.  On the separate<br><br>subject of the Greenland or right-whale, he is the best existing<br><br>authority.  But Scoresby knew nothing and says nothing of the great<br><br>sperm whale, compared with which the Greenland whale is almost<br><br>unworthy mentioning.  And here be it said, that the Greenland whale<br><br>is an usurper upon the throne of the seas.  He is not even by any<br><br>means the largest of the whales.  Yet, owing to the long priority of<br><br>his claims, and the profound ignorance which, till some seventy years<br><br>back, invested the then fabulous or utterly unknown sperm-whale, and<br><br>which ignorance to this present day still reigns in all but some few<br><br>scientific retreats and whale-ports; this usurpation has been every<br><br>way complete.  Reference to nearly all the leviathanic allusions in<br><br>the great poets of past days, will satisfy you that the Greenland<br><br>whale, without one rival, was to them the monarch of the seas.  But<br><br>the time has at last come for a new proclamation.  This is Charing<br><br>Cross; hear ye! good people all,--the Greenland whale is<br><br>deposed,--the great sperm whale now reigneth!<br><br><br><br>There are only two books in being which at all pretend to put the<br><br>living sperm whale before you, and at the same time, in the remotest<br><br>degree succeed in the attempt.  Those books are Beale's and<br><br>Bennett's; both in their time surgeons to English South-Sea<br><br>whale-ships, and both exact and reliable men.  The original matter<br><br>touching the sperm whale to be found in their volumes is necessarily<br><br>small; but so far as it goes, it is of excellent quality, though<br><br>mostly confined to scientific description.  As yet, however, the<br><br>sperm whale, scientific or poetic, lives not complete in any<br><br>literature.  Far above all other hunted whales, his is an unwritten<br><br>life.<br><br><br><br>Now the various species of whales need some sort of popular<br><br>comprehensive classification, if only an easy outline one for the<br><br>present, hereafter to be filled in all its departments by subsequent<br><br>laborers.  As no better man advances to take this matter in hand, I<br><br>hereupon offer my own poor endeavors.  I promise nothing complete;<br><br>because any human thing supposed to be complete, must for that very<br><br>reason infallibly be faulty.  I shall not pretend to a minute<br><br>anatomical description of the various species, or--in this place at<br><br>least--to much of any description.  My object here is simply to<br><br>project the draught of a systematization of cetology.  I am the<br><br>architect, not the builder.<br><br><br><br>But it is a ponderous task; no ordinary letter-sorter in the<br><br>Post-Office is equal to it.  To grope down into the bottom of the sea<br><br>after them; to have one's hands among the unspeakable foundations,<br><br>ribs, and very pelvis of the world; this is a fearful thing.  What am<br><br>I that I should essay to hook the nose of this leviathan!  The awful<br><br>tauntings in Job might well appal me.  "Will he the (leviathan) make<br><br>a covenant with thee?  Behold the hope of him is vain!  But I have<br><br>swam through libraries and sailed through oceans; I have had to do<br><br>with whales with these visible hands; I am in earnest; and I will<br><br>try.  There are some preliminaries to settle.<br><br><br><br>First: The uncertain, unsettled condition of this science of Cetology<br><br>is in the very vestibule attested by the fact, that in some quarters<br><br>it still remains a moot point whether a whale be a fish.  In his<br><br>System of Nature, A.D. 1776, Linnaeus declares, "I hereby separate<br><br>the whales from the fish."  But of my own knowledge, I know that down<br><br>to the year 1850, sharks and shad, alewives and herring, against<br><br>Linnaeus's express edict, were still found dividing the possession of<br><br>the same seas with the Leviathan.<br><br><br><br>The grounds upon which Linnaeus would fain have banished the whales<br><br>from the waters, he states as follows: "On account of their warm<br><br>bilocular heart, their lungs, their movable eyelids, their hollow<br><br>ears, penem intrantem feminam mammis lactantem," and finally, "ex<br><br>lege naturae jure meritoque."  I submitted all this to my friends<br><br>Simeon Macey and Charley Coffin, of Nantucket, both messmates of mine<br><br>in a certain voyage, and they united in the opinion that the reasons<br><br>set forth were altogether insufficient.  Charley profanely hinted<br><br>they were humbug.<br><br><br><br>Be it known that, waiving all argument, I take the good old fashioned<br><br>ground that the whale is a fish, and call upon holy Jonah to back me.<br><br>This fundamental thing settled, the next point is, in what internal<br><br>respect does the whale differ from other fish.  Above, Linnaeus has<br><br>given you those items.  But in brief, they are these: lungs and warm<br><br>blood; whereas, all other fish are lungless and cold blooded.<br><br><br><br>Next: how shall we define the whale, by his obvious externals, so as<br><br>conspicuously to label him for all time to come?  To be short, then,<br><br>a whale is A SPOUTING FISH WITH A HORIZONTAL TAIL.  There you have<br><br>him.  However contracted, that definition is the result of expanded<br><br>meditation.  A walrus spouts much like a whale, but the walrus is not<br><br>a fish, because he is amphibious.  But the last term of the<br><br>definition is still more cogent, as coupled with the first.  Almost<br><br>any one must have noticed that all the fish familiar to landsmen have<br><br>not a flat, but a vertical, or up-and-down tail.  Whereas, among<br><br>spouting fish the tail, though it may be similarly shaped, invariably<br><br>assumes a horizontal position.<br><br><br><br>By the above definition of what a whale is, I do by no means exclude<br><br>from the leviathanic brotherhood any sea creature hitherto identified<br><br>with the whale by the best informed Nantucketers; nor, on the other<br><br>hand, link with it any fish hitherto authoritatively regarded as<br><br>alien.*  Hence, all the smaller, spouting, and horizontal tailed fish<br><br>must be included in this ground-plan of Cetology.  Now, then, come<br><br>the grand divisions of the entire whale host.<br><br><br><br><br><br>*I am aware that down to the present time, the fish styled Lamatins<br><br>and Dugongs (Pig-fish and Sow-fish of the Coffins of Nantucket) are<br><br>included by many naturalists among the whales.  But as these pig-fish<br><br>are a noisy, contemptible set, mostly lurking in the mouths of<br><br>rivers, and feeding on wet hay, and especially as they do not spout,<br><br>I deny their credentials as whales; and have presented them with<br><br>their passports to quit the Kingdom of Cetology.<br><br><br><br><br><br>First: According to magnitude I divide the whales into three primary<br><br>BOOKS (subdivisible into CHAPTERS), and these shall comprehend them<br><br>all, both small and large.<br><br><br><br>I. THE FOLIO WHALE; II. the OCTAVO WHALE; III. the DUODECIMO WHALE.<br><br><br><br>As the type of the FOLIO I present the SPERM WHALE; of the OCTAVO,<br><br>the GRAMPUS; of the DUODECIMO, the PORPOISE.<br><br><br><br>FOLIOS.  Among these I here include the following chapters:--I. The<br><br>SPERM WHALE; II. the RIGHT WHALE; III. the FIN-BACK WHALE; IV. the<br><br>HUMP-BACKED WHALE; V. the RAZOR-BACK WHALE; VI. the SULPHUR-BOTTOM<br><br>WHALE.<br><br><br><br>BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER I. (SPERM WHALE).--This whale, among the<br><br>English of old vaguely known as the Trumpa whale, and the Physeter<br><br>whale, and the Anvil Headed whale, is the present Cachalot of the<br><br>French, and the Pottsfich of the Germans, and the Macrocephalus of<br><br>the Long Words.  He is, without doubt, the largest inhabitant of the<br><br>globe; the most formidable of all whales to encounter; the most<br><br>majestic in aspect; and lastly, by far the most valuable in commerce;<br><br>he being the only creature from which that valuable substance,<br><br>spermaceti, is obtained.  All his peculiarities will, in many other<br><br>places, be enlarged upon.  It is chiefly with his name that I now<br><br>have to do.  Philologically considered, it is absurd.  Some centuries<br><br>ago, when the Sperm whale was almost wholly unknown in his own<br><br>proper individuality, and when his oil was only accidentally obtained<br><br>from the stranded fish; in those days spermaceti, it would seem, was<br><br>popularly supposed to be derived from a creature identical with the<br><br>one then known in England as the Greenland or Right Whale.  It was<br><br>the idea also, that this same spermaceti was that quickening humor of<br><br>the Greenland Whale which the first syllable of the word literally<br><br>expresses.  In those times, also, spermaceti was exceedingly scarce,<br><br>not being used for light, but only as an ointment and medicament.  It<br><br>was only to be had from the druggists as you nowadays buy an ounce of<br><br>rhubarb.  When, as I opine, in the course of time, the true nature of<br><br>spermaceti became known, its original name was still retained by the<br><br>dealers; no doubt to enhance its value by a notion so strangely<br><br>significant of its scarcity.  And so the appellation must at last<br><br>have come to be bestowed upon the whale from which this spermaceti<br><br>was really derived.<br><br><br><br>BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER II. (RIGHT WHALE).--In one respect this is<br><br>the most venerable of the leviathans, being the one first regularly<br><br>hunted by man.  It yields the article commonly known as whalebone or<br><br>baleen; and the oil specially known as "whale oil," an inferior<br><br>article in commerce.  Among the fishermen, he is indiscriminately<br><br>designated by all the following titles: The Whale; the Greenland<br><br>Whale; the Black Whale; the Great Whale; the True Whale; the Right<br><br>Whale.  There is a deal of obscurity concerning the identity of the<br><br>species thus multitudinously baptised.  What then is the whale, which<br><br>I include in the second species of my Folios?  It is the Great<br><br>Mysticetus of the English naturalists; the Greenland Whale of the<br><br>English whalemen; the Baliene Ordinaire of the French whalemen; the<br><br>Growlands Walfish of the Swedes.  It is the whale which for more than<br><br>two centuries past has been hunted by the Dutch and English in the<br><br>Arctic seas; it is the whale which the American fishermen have long<br><br>pursued in the Indian ocean, on the Brazil Banks, on the Nor' West<br><br>Coast, and various other parts of the world, designated by them Right<br><br>Whale Cruising Grounds.<br><br><br><br>Some pretend to see a difference between the Greenland whale of the<br><br>English and the right whale of the Americans.  But they precisely<br><br>agree in all their grand features; nor has there yet been presented a<br><br>single determinate fact upon which to ground a radical distinction.<br><br>It is by endless subdivisions based upon the most inconclusive<br><br>differences, that some departments of natural history become so<br><br>repellingly intricate.  The right whale will be elsewhere treated of<br><br>at some length, with reference to elucidating the sperm whale.<br><br><br><br>BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER III. (FIN-BACK).--Under this head I reckon a<br><br>monster which, by the various names of Fin-Back, Tall-Spout, and<br><br>Long-John, has been seen almost in every sea and is commonly the<br><br>whale whose distant jet is so often descried by passengers crossing<br><br>the Atlantic, in the New York packet-tracks.  In the length he<br><br>attains, and in his baleen, the Fin-back resembles the right whale,<br><br>but is of a less portly girth, and a lighter colour, approaching to<br><br>olive.  His great lips present a cable-like aspect, formed by the<br><br>intertwisting, slanting folds of large wrinkles.  His grand<br><br>distinguishing feature, the fin, from which he derives his name, is<br><br>often a conspicuous object.  This fin is some three or four feet<br><br>long, growing vertically from the hinder part of the back, of an<br><br>angular shape, and with a very sharp pointed end.  Even if not the<br><br>slightest other part of the creature be visible, this isolated fin<br><br>will, at times, be seen plainly projecting from the surface.  When<br><br>the sea is moderately calm, and slightly marked with spherical<br><br>ripples, and this gnomon-like fin stands up and casts shadows upon<br><br>the wrinkled surface, it may well be supposed that the watery circle<br><br>surrounding it somewhat resembles a dial, with its style and wavy<br><br>hour-lines graved on it.  On that Ahaz-dial the shadow often goes<br><br>back.  The Fin-Back is not gregarious.  He seems a whale-hater, as<br><br>some men are man-haters.  Very shy; always going solitary;<br><br>unexpectedly rising to the surface in the remotest and most sullen<br><br>waters; his straight and single lofty jet rising like a tall<br><br>misanthropic spear upon a barren plain; gifted with such wondrous<br><br>power and velocity in swimming, as to defy all present pursuit from<br><br>man; this leviathan seems the banished and unconquerable Cain of his<br><br>race, bearing for his mark that style upon his back.  From having the<br><br>baleen in his mouth, the Fin-Back is sometimes included with the<br><br>right whale, among a theoretic species denominated WHALEBONE WHALES,<br><br>that is, whales with baleen.  Of these so called Whalebone whales,<br><br>there would seem to be several varieties, most of which, however, are<br><br>little known.  Broad-nosed whales and beaked whales; pike-headed<br><br>whales; bunched whales; under-jawed whales and rostrated whales, are<br><br>the fishermen's names for a few sorts.<br><br><br><br>In connection with this appellative of "Whalebone whales," it is of<br><br>great importance to mention, that however such a nomenclature may be<br><br>convenient in facilitating allusions to some kind of whales, yet it<br><br>is in vain to attempt a clear classification of the Leviathan,<br><br>founded upon either his baleen, or hump, or fin, or teeth;<br><br>notwithstanding that those marked parts or features very obviously<br><br>seem better adapted to afford the basis for a regular system of<br><br>Cetology than any other detached bodily distinctions, which the<br><br>whale, in his kinds, presents.  How then?  The baleen, hump,<br><br>back-fin, and teeth; these are things whose peculiarities are<br><br>indiscriminately dispersed among all sorts of whales, without any<br><br>regard to what may be the nature of their structure in other and<br><br>more essential particulars.  Thus, the sperm whale and the humpbacked<br><br>whale, each has a hump; but there the similitude ceases.  Then, this<br><br>same humpbacked whale and the Greenland whale, each of these has<br><br>baleen; but there again the similitude ceases.  And it is just the<br><br>same with the other parts above mentioned.  In various sorts of<br><br>whales, they form such irregular combinations; or, in the case of any<br><br>one of them detached, such an irregular isolation; as utterly to defy<br><br>all general methodization formed upon such a basis.  On this rock<br><br>every one of the whale-naturalists has split.<br><br><br><br>But it may possibly be conceived that, in the internal parts of the<br><br>whale, in his anatomy--there, at least, we shall be able to hit the<br><br>right classification.  Nay; what thing, for example, is there in the<br><br>Greenland whale's anatomy more striking than his baleen?  Yet we have<br><br>seen that by his baleen it is impossible correctly to classify the<br><br>Greenland whale.  And if you descend into the bowels of the various<br><br>leviathans, why there you will not find distinctions a fiftieth part<br><br>as available to the systematizer as those external ones already<br><br>enumerated.  What then remains? nothing but to take hold of the<br><br>whales bodily, in their entire liberal volume, and boldly sort them<br><br>that way.  And this is the Bibliographical system here adopted; and<br><br>it is the only one that can possibly succeed, for it alone is<br><br>practicable.  To proceed.<br><br><br><br>BOOK I. (FOLIO) CHAPTER IV. (HUMP-BACK).--This whale is often seen on<br><br>the northern American coast.  He has been frequently captured there,<br><br>and towed into harbor.  He has a great pack on him like a peddler; or<br><br>you might call him the Elephant and Castle whale.  At any rate, the<br><br>popular name for him does not sufficiently distinguish him, since the<br><br>sperm whale also has a hump though a smaller one.  His oil is not<br><br>very valuable.  He has baleen.  He is the most gamesome and<br><br>light-hearted of all the whales, making more gay foam and white water<br><br>generally than any other of them.<br><br><br><br>BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER V. (RAZOR-BACK).--Of this whale little is<br><br>known but his name.  I have seen him at a distance off Cape Horn.  Of<br><br>a retiring nature, he eludes both hunters and philosophers.  Though<br><br>no coward, he has never yet shown any part of him but his back, which<br><br>rises in a long sharp ridge.  Let him go.  I know little more of him,<br><br>nor does anybody else.<br><br><br><br>BOOK I. (FOLIO), CHAPTER VI. (SULPHUR-BOTTOM).--Another retiring<br><br>gentleman, with a brimstone belly, doubtless got by scraping along<br><br>the Tartarian tiles in some of his profounder divings.  He is seldom<br><br>seen; at least I have never seen him except in the remoter southern<br><br>seas, and then always at too great a distance to study his<br><br>countenance.  He is never chased; he would run away with rope-walks<br><br>of line.  Prodigies are told of him.  Adieu, Sulphur Bottom!  I can<br><br>say nothing more that is true of ye, nor can the oldest Nantucketer.<br><br><br><br>Thus ends BOOK I. (FOLIO), and now begins BOOK II. (OCTAVO).<br><br><br><br>OCTAVOES.*--These embrace the whales of middling magnitude, among<br><br>which present may be numbered:--I., the GRAMPUS; II., the BLACK FISH;<br><br>III., the NARWHALE; IV., the THRASHER; V., the KILLER.<br><br><br><br><br><br>*Why this book of whales is not denominated the Quarto is very plain.<br><br>Because, while the whales of this order, though smaller than those<br><br>of the former order, nevertheless retain a proportionate likeness to<br><br>them in figure, yet the bookbinder's Quarto volume in its dimensioned<br><br>form does not preserve the shape of the Folio volume, but the Octavo<br><br>volume does.<br><br><br><br><br><br>BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER I. (GRAMPUS).--Though this fish, whose<br><br>loud sonorous breathing, or rather blowing, has furnished a proverb<br><br>to landsmen, is so well known a denizen of the deep, yet is he not<br><br>popularly classed among whales.  But possessing all the grand<br><br>distinctive features of the leviathan, most naturalists have<br><br>recognised him for one.  He is of moderate octavo size, varying from<br><br>fifteen to twenty-five feet in length, and of corresponding<br><br>dimensions round the waist.  He swims in herds; he is never regularly<br><br>hunted, though his oil is considerable in quantity, and pretty good<br><br>for light.  By some fishermen his approach is regarded as premonitory<br><br>of the advance of the great sperm whale.<br><br><br><br>BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER II. (BLACK FISH).--I give the popular<br><br>fishermen's names for all these fish, for generally they are the<br><br>best.  Where any name happens to be vague or inexpressive, I shall<br><br>say so, and suggest another.  I do so now, touching the Black Fish,<br><br>so-called, because blackness is the rule among almost all whales.<br><br>So, call him the Hyena Whale, if you please.  His voracity is well<br><br>known, and from the circumstance that the inner angles of his lips<br><br>are curved upwards, he carries an everlasting Mephistophelean grin on<br><br>his face.  This whale averages some sixteen or eighteen feet in<br><br>length.  He is found in almost all latitudes.  He has a peculiar way<br><br>of showing his dorsal hooked fin in swimming, which looks something<br><br>like a Roman nose.  When not more profitably employed, the sperm<br><br>whale hunters sometimes capture the Hyena whale, to keep up the<br><br>supply of cheap oil for domestic employment--as some frugal<br><br>housekeepers, in the absence of company, and quite alone by<br><br>themselves, burn unsavory tallow instead of odorous wax.  Though<br><br>their blubber is very thin, some of these whales will yield you<br><br>upwards of thirty gallons of oil.<br><br><br><br>BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER III. (NARWHALE), that is, NOSTRIL<br><br>WHALE.--Another instance of a curiously named whale, so named I<br><br>suppose from his peculiar horn being originally mistaken for a peaked<br><br>nose.  The creature is some sixteen feet in length, while its horn<br><br>averages five feet, though some exceed ten, and even attain to<br><br>fifteen feet.  Strictly speaking, this horn is but a lengthened tusk,<br><br>growing out from the jaw in a line a little depressed from the<br><br>horizontal.  But it is only found on the sinister side, which has an<br><br>ill effect, giving its owner something analogous to the aspect of a<br><br>clumsy left-handed man.  What precise purpose this ivory horn or<br><br>lance answers, it would be hard to say.
