It does not seem to be used<br><br>like the blade of the sword-fish and bill-fish; though some sailors<br><br>tell me that the Narwhale employs it for a rake in turning over the<br><br>bottom of the sea for food.  Charley Coffin said it was used for an<br><br>ice-piercer; for the Narwhale, rising to the surface of the Polar<br><br>Sea, and finding it sheeted with ice, thrusts his horn up, and so<br><br>breaks through.  But you cannot prove either of these surmises to be<br><br>correct.  My own opinion is, that however this one-sided horn may<br><br>really be used by the Narwhale--however that may be--it would<br><br>certainly be very convenient to him for a folder in reading<br><br>pamphlets.  The Narwhale I have heard called the Tusked whale, the<br><br>Horned whale, and the Unicorn whale.  He is certainly a curious<br><br>example of the Unicornism to be found in almost every kingdom of<br><br>animated nature.  From certain cloistered old authors I have gathered<br><br>that this same sea-unicorn's horn was in ancient days regarded as the<br><br>great antidote against poison, and as such, preparations of it<br><br>brought immense prices.  It was also distilled to a volatile salts<br><br>for fainting ladies, the same way that the horns of the male deer are<br><br>manufactured into hartshorn.  Originally it was in itself accounted<br><br>an object of great curiosity.  Black Letter tells me that Sir Martin<br><br>Frobisher on his return from that voyage, when Queen Bess did<br><br>gallantly wave her jewelled hand to him from a window of Greenwich<br><br>Palace, as his bold ship sailed down the Thames; "when Sir Martin<br><br>returned from that voyage," saith Black Letter, "on bended knees he<br><br>presented to her highness a prodigious long horn of the Narwhale,<br><br>which for a long period after hung in the castle at Windsor."  An<br><br>Irish author avers that the Earl of Leicester, on bended knees, did<br><br>likewise present to her highness another horn, pertaining to a land<br><br>beast of the unicorn nature.<br><br><br><br>The Narwhale has a very picturesque, leopard-like look, being of a<br><br>milk-white ground colour, dotted with round and oblong spots of black.<br><br>His oil is very superior, clear and fine; but there is little of it,<br><br>and he is seldom hunted.  He is mostly found in the circumpolar seas.<br><br><br><br>BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER IV. (KILLER).--Of this whale little is<br><br>precisely known to the Nantucketer, and nothing at all to the<br><br>professed naturalist.  From what I have seen of him at a distance,<br><br>I should say that he was about the bigness of a grampus.  He is very<br><br>savage--a sort of Feegee fish.  He sometimes takes the great Folio<br><br>whales by the lip, and hangs there like a leech, till the mighty<br><br>brute is worried to death.  The Killer is never hunted.  I never<br><br>heard what sort of oil he has.  Exception might be taken to the name<br><br>bestowed upon this whale, on the ground of its indistinctness.  For<br><br>we are all killers, on land and on sea; Bonapartes and Sharks<br><br>included.<br><br><br><br>BOOK II. (OCTAVO), CHAPTER V. (THRASHER).--This gentleman is famous<br><br>for his tail, which he uses for a ferule in thrashing his foes.  He<br><br>mounts the Folio whale's back, and as he swims, he works his passage<br><br>by flogging him; as some schoolmasters get along in the world by a<br><br>similar process.  Still less is known of the Thrasher than of the<br><br>Killer.  Both are outlaws, even in the lawless seas.<br><br><br><br>Thus ends BOOK II. (OCTAVO), and begins BOOK III. (DUODECIMO).<br><br><br><br>DUODECIMOES.--These include the smaller whales.  I. The Huzza<br><br>Porpoise.  II. The Algerine Porpoise.  III. The Mealy-mouthed<br><br>Porpoise.<br><br><br><br>To those who have not chanced specially to study the subject, it may<br><br>possibly seem strange, that fishes not commonly exceeding four or<br><br>five feet should be marshalled among WHALES--a word, which, in the<br><br>popular sense, always conveys an idea of hugeness.  But the creatures<br><br>set down above as Duodecimoes are infallibly whales, by the terms of<br><br>my definition of what a whale is--i.e. a spouting fish, with a<br><br>horizontal tail.<br><br><br><br>BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER 1. (HUZZA PORPOISE).--This is the<br><br>common porpoise found almost all over the globe.  The name is of my<br><br>own bestowal; for there are more than one sort of porpoises, and<br><br>something must be done to distinguish them.  I call him thus, because<br><br>he always swims in hilarious shoals, which upon the broad sea keep<br><br>tossing themselves to heaven like caps in a Fourth-of-July crowd.<br><br>Their appearance is generally hailed with delight by the mariner.<br><br>Full of fine spirits, they invariably come from the breezy billows to<br><br>windward.  They are the lads that always live before the wind.  They<br><br>are accounted a lucky omen.  If you yourself can withstand three<br><br>cheers at beholding these vivacious fish, then heaven help ye; the<br><br>spirit of godly gamesomeness is not in ye.  A well-fed, plump Huzza<br><br>Porpoise will yield you one good gallon of good oil.  But the fine<br><br>and delicate fluid extracted from his jaws is exceedingly valuable.<br><br>It is in request among jewellers and watchmakers.  Sailors put it on<br><br>their hones.  Porpoise meat is good eating, you know.  It may never<br><br>have occurred to you that a porpoise spouts.  Indeed, his spout is so<br><br>small that it is not very readily discernible.  But the next time you<br><br>have a chance, watch him; and you will then see the great Sperm whale<br><br>himself in miniature.<br><br><br><br>BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER II. (ALGERINE PORPOISE).--A pirate.<br><br>Very savage.  He is only found, I think, in the Pacific.  He is<br><br>somewhat larger than the Huzza Porpoise, but much of the same general<br><br>make.  Provoke him, and he will buckle to a shark.  I have lowered<br><br>for him many times, but never yet saw him captured.<br><br><br><br>BOOK III. (DUODECIMO), CHAPTER III. (MEALY-MOUTHED PORPOISE).--The<br><br>largest kind of Porpoise; and only found in the Pacific, so far as it<br><br>is known.  The only English name, by which he has hitherto been<br><br>designated, is that of the fishers--Right-Whale Porpoise, from the<br><br>circumstance that he is chiefly found in the vicinity of that Folio.<br><br>In shape, he differs in some degree from the Huzza Porpoise, being of<br><br>a less rotund and jolly girth; indeed, he is of quite a neat and<br><br>gentleman-like figure.  He has no fins on his back (most other<br><br>porpoises have), he has a lovely tail, and sentimental Indian eyes of<br><br>a hazel hue.  But his mealy-mouth spoils all.  Though his entire<br><br>back down to his side fins is of a deep sable, yet a boundary line,<br><br>distinct as the mark in a ship's hull, called the "bright waist,"<br><br>that line streaks him from stem to stern, with two separate colours,<br><br>black above and white below.  The white comprises part of his head,<br><br>and the whole of his mouth, which makes him look as if he had just<br><br>escaped from a felonious visit to a meal-bag.  A most mean and mealy<br><br>aspect!  His oil is much like that of the common porpoise.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Beyond the DUODECIMO, this system does not proceed, inasmuch as the<br><br>Porpoise is the smallest of the whales.  Above, you have all the<br><br>Leviathans of note.  But there are a rabble of uncertain, fugitive,<br><br>half-fabulous whales, which, as an American whaleman, I know by<br><br>reputation, but not personally.  I shall enumerate them by their<br><br>fore-castle appellations; for possibly such a list may be valuable to<br><br>future investigators, who may complete what I have here but begun.<br><br>If any of the following whales, shall hereafter be caught and marked,<br><br>then he can readily be incorporated into this System, according to<br><br>his Folio, Octavo, or Duodecimo magnitude:--The Bottle-Nose Whale;<br><br>the Junk Whale; the Pudding-Headed Whale; the Cape Whale; the Leading<br><br>Whale; the Cannon Whale; the Scragg Whale; the Coppered Whale; the<br><br>Elephant Whale; the Iceberg Whale; the Quog Whale; the Blue Whale; etc.<br><br>From Icelandic, Dutch, and old English authorities, there might<br><br>be quoted other lists of uncertain whales, blessed with all manner of<br><br>uncouth names.  But I omit them as altogether obsolete; and can<br><br>hardly help suspecting them for mere sounds, full of Leviathanism,<br><br>but signifying nothing.<br><br><br><br>Finally: It was stated at the outset, that this system would not be<br><br>here, and at once, perfected.  You cannot but plainly see that I have<br><br>kept my word.  But I now leave my cetological System standing thus<br><br>unfinished, even as the great Cathedral of Cologne was left, with the<br><br>crane still standing upon the top of the uncompleted tower.  For<br><br>small erections may be finished by their first architects; grand<br><br>ones, true ones, ever leave the copestone to posterity.  God keep me<br><br>from ever completing anything.  This whole book is but a<br><br>draught--nay, but the draught of a draught.  Oh, Time, Strength,<br><br>Cash, and Patience!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 33<br><br><br><br>The Specksynder.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Concerning the officers of the whale-craft, this seems as good a<br><br>place as any to set down a little domestic peculiarity on ship-board,<br><br>arising from the existence of the harpooneer class of officers, a<br><br>class unknown of course in any other marine than the whale-fleet.<br><br><br><br>The large importance attached to the harpooneer's vocation is evinced<br><br>by the fact, that originally in the old Dutch Fishery, two centuries<br><br>and more ago, the command of a whale ship was not wholly lodged in<br><br>the person now called the captain, but was divided between him and an<br><br>officer called the Specksynder.  Literally this word means<br><br>Fat-Cutter; usage, however, in time made it equivalent to Chief<br><br>Harpooneer.  In those days, the captain's authority was restricted to<br><br>the navigation and general management of the vessel; while over the<br><br>whale-hunting department and all its concerns, the Specksynder or<br><br>Chief Harpooneer reigned supreme.  In the British Greenland Fishery,<br><br>under the corrupted title of Specksioneer, this old Dutch official is<br><br>still retained, but his former dignity is sadly abridged.  At present<br><br>he ranks simply as senior Harpooneer; and as such, is but one of the<br><br>captain's more inferior subalterns.  Nevertheless, as upon the good<br><br>conduct of the harpooneers the success of a whaling voyage largely<br><br>depends, and since in the American Fishery he is not only an<br><br>important officer in the boat, but under certain circumstances (night<br><br>watches on a whaling ground) the command of the ship's deck is also<br><br>his; therefore the grand political maxim of the sea demands, that he<br><br>should nominally live apart from the men before the mast, and be in<br><br>some way distinguished as their professional superior; though always,<br><br>by them, familiarly regarded as their social equal.<br><br><br><br>Now, the grand distinction drawn between officer and man at sea, is<br><br>this--the first lives aft, the last forward.  Hence, in whale-ships<br><br>and merchantmen alike, the mates have their quarters with the<br><br>captain; and so, too, in most of the American whalers the harpooneers<br><br>are lodged in the after part of the ship.  That is to say, they take<br><br>their meals in the captain's cabin, and sleep in a place indirectly<br><br>communicating with it.<br><br><br><br>Though the long period of a Southern whaling voyage (by far the<br><br>longest of all voyages now or ever made by man), the peculiar perils<br><br>of it, and the community of interest prevailing among a company, all<br><br>of whom, high or low, depend for their profits, not upon fixed wages,<br><br>but upon their common luck, together with their common vigilance,<br><br>intrepidity, and hard work; though all these things do in some cases<br><br>tend to beget a less rigorous discipline than in merchantmen<br><br>generally; yet, never mind how much like an old Mesopotamian family<br><br>these whalemen may, in some primitive instances, live together; for<br><br>all that, the punctilious externals, at least, of the quarter-deck<br><br>are seldom materially relaxed, and in no instance done away.  Indeed,<br><br>many are the Nantucket ships in which you will see the skipper<br><br>parading his quarter-deck with an elated grandeur not surpassed in<br><br>any military navy; nay, extorting almost as much outward homage as if<br><br>he wore the imperial purple, and not the shabbiest of pilot-cloth.<br><br><br><br>And though of all men the moody captain of the Pequod was the least<br><br>given to that sort of shallowest assumption; and though the only<br><br>homage he ever exacted, was implicit, instantaneous obedience; though<br><br>he required no man to remove the shoes from his feet ere stepping<br><br>upon the quarter-deck; and though there were times when, owing to<br><br>peculiar circumstances connected with events hereafter to be<br><br>detailed, he addressed them in unusual terms, whether of<br><br>condescension or IN TERROREM, or otherwise; yet even Captain Ahab was<br><br>by no means unobservant of the paramount forms and usages of the sea.<br><br><br><br>Nor, perhaps, will it fail to be eventually perceived, that behind<br><br>those forms and usages, as it were, he sometimes masked himself;<br><br>incidentally making use of them for other and more private ends than<br><br>they were legitimately intended to subserve.  That certain sultanism<br><br>of his brain, which had otherwise in a good degree remained<br><br>unmanifested; through those forms that same sultanism became<br><br>incarnate in an irresistible dictatorship.  For be a man's<br><br>intellectual superiority what it will, it can never assume the<br><br>practical, available supremacy over other men, without the aid of<br><br>some sort of external arts and entrenchments, always, in themselves,<br><br>more or less paltry and base.  This it is, that for ever keeps God's<br><br>true princes of the Empire from the world's hustings; and leaves the<br><br>highest honours that this air can give, to those men who become famous<br><br>more through their infinite inferiority to the choice hidden handful<br><br>of the Divine Inert, than through their undoubted superiority over<br><br>the dead level of the mass.  Such large virtue lurks in these small<br><br>things when extreme political superstitions invest them, that in some<br><br>royal instances even to idiot imbecility they have imparted potency.<br><br>But when, as in the case of Nicholas the Czar, the ringed crown of<br><br>geographical empire encircles an imperial brain; then, the plebeian<br><br>herds crouch abased before the tremendous centralization.  Nor, will<br><br>the tragic dramatist who would depict mortal indomitableness in its<br><br>fullest sweep and direct swing, ever forget a hint, incidentally so<br><br>important in his art, as the one now alluded to.<br><br><br><br>But Ahab, my Captain, still moves before me in all his Nantucket<br><br>grimness and shagginess; and in this episode touching Emperors and<br><br>Kings, I must not conceal that I have only to do with a poor old<br><br>whale-hunter like him; and, therefore, all outward majestical<br><br>trappings and housings are denied me.  Oh, Ahab! what shall be grand<br><br>in thee, it must needs be plucked at from the skies, and dived for in<br><br>the deep, and featured in the unbodied air!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 34<br><br><br><br>The Cabin-Table.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It is noon; and Dough-Boy, the steward, thrusting his pale<br><br>loaf-of-bread face from the cabin-scuttle, announces dinner to his<br><br>lord and master; who, sitting in the lee quarter-boat, has just been<br><br>taking an observation of the sun; and is now mutely reckoning the<br><br>latitude on the smooth, medallion-shaped tablet, reserved for that<br><br>daily purpose on the upper part of his ivory leg.  From his complete<br><br>inattention to the tidings, you would think that moody Ahab had not<br><br>heard his menial.  But presently, catching hold of the mizen shrouds,<br><br>he swings himself to the deck, and in an even, unexhilarated voice,<br><br>saying, "Dinner, Mr. Starbuck," disappears into the cabin.<br><br><br><br>When the last echo of his sultan's step has died away, and Starbuck,<br><br>the first Emir, has every reason to suppose that he is seated, then<br><br>Starbuck rouses from his quietude, takes a few turns along the<br><br>planks, and, after a grave peep into the binnacle, says, with some<br><br>touch of pleasantness, "Dinner, Mr. Stubb," and descends the scuttle.<br><br>The second Emir lounges about the rigging awhile, and then slightly<br><br>shaking the main brace, to see whether it will be all right with<br><br>that important rope, he likewise takes up the old burden, and with a<br><br>rapid "Dinner, Mr. Flask," follows after his predecessors.<br><br><br><br>But the third Emir, now seeing himself all alone on the quarter-deck,<br><br>seems to feel relieved from some curious restraint; for, tipping all<br><br>sorts of knowing winks in all sorts of directions, and kicking off<br><br>his shoes, he strikes into a sharp but noiseless squall of a hornpipe<br><br>right over the Grand Turk's head; and then, by a dexterous sleight,<br><br>pitching his cap up into the mizentop for a shelf, he goes down<br><br>rollicking so far at least as he remains visible from the deck,<br><br>reversing all other processions, by bringing up the rear with music.<br><br>But ere stepping into the cabin doorway below, he pauses, ships a new<br><br>face altogether, and, then, independent, hilarious little Flask<br><br>enters King Ahab's presence, in the character of Abjectus, or the<br><br>Slave.<br><br><br><br>It is not the least among the strange things bred by the intense<br><br>artificialness of sea-usages, that while in the open air of the deck<br><br>some officers will, upon provocation, bear themselves boldly and<br><br>defyingly enough towards their commander; yet, ten to one, let those<br><br>very officers the next moment go down to their customary dinner in<br><br>that same commander's cabin, and straightway their inoffensive, not<br><br>to say deprecatory and humble air towards him, as he sits at the head<br><br>of the table; this is marvellous, sometimes most comical.  Wherefore<br><br>this difference?  A problem?  Perhaps not.  To have been Belshazzar,<br><br>King of Babylon; and to have been Belshazzar, not haughtily but<br><br>courteously, therein certainly must have been some touch of mundane<br><br>grandeur.  But he who in the rightly regal and intelligent spirit<br><br>presides over his own private dinner-table of invited guests, that<br><br>man's unchallenged power and dominion of individual influence for the<br><br>time; that man's royalty of state transcends Belshazzar's, for<br><br>Belshazzar was not the greatest.  Who has but once dined his friends,<br><br>has tasted what it is to be Caesar.  It is a witchery of social<br><br>czarship which there is no withstanding.  Now, if to this<br><br>consideration you superadd the official supremacy of a ship-master,<br><br>then, by inference, you will derive the cause of that peculiarity of<br><br>sea-life just mentioned.<br><br><br><br>Over his ivory-inlaid table, Ahab presided like a mute, maned<br><br>sea-lion on the white coral beach, surrounded by his warlike but<br><br>still deferential cubs.  In his own proper turn, each officer waited<br><br>to be served.  They were as little children before Ahab; and yet, in<br><br>Ahab, there seemed not to lurk the smallest social arrogance.  With<br><br>one mind, their intent eyes all fastened upon the old man's knife, as<br><br>he carved the chief dish before him.  I do not suppose that for the<br><br>world they would have profaned that moment with the slightest<br><br>observation, even upon so neutral a topic as the weather.  No!  And<br><br>when reaching out his knife and fork, between which the slice of beef<br><br>was locked, Ahab thereby motioned Starbuck's plate towards him, the<br><br>mate received his meat as though receiving alms; and cut it tenderly;<br><br>and a little started if, perchance, the knife grazed against the<br><br>plate; and chewed it noiselessly; and swallowed it, not without<br><br>circumspection.  For, like the Coronation banquet at Frankfort, where<br><br>the German Emperor profoundly dines with the seven Imperial<br><br>Electors, so these cabin meals were somehow solemn meals, eaten in<br><br>awful silence; and yet at table old Ahab forbade not conversation;<br><br>only he himself was dumb.  What a relief it was to choking Stubb,<br><br>when a rat made a sudden racket in the hold below.  And poor little<br><br>Flask, he was the youngest son, and little boy of this weary family<br><br>party.  His were the shinbones of the saline beef; his would have<br><br>been the drumsticks.  For Flask to have presumed to help himself,<br><br>this must have seemed to him tantamount to larceny in the first<br><br>degree.  Had he helped himself at that table, doubtless, never more<br><br>would he have been able to hold his head up in this honest world;<br><br>nevertheless, strange to say, Ahab never forbade him.  And had Flask<br><br>helped himself, the chances were Ahab had never so much as noticed<br><br>it.  Least of all, did Flask presume to help himself to butter.<br><br>Whether he thought the owners of the ship denied it to him, on<br><br>account of its clotting his clear, sunny complexion; or whether he<br><br>deemed that, on so long a voyage in such marketless waters, butter<br><br>was at a premium, and therefore was not for him, a subaltern; however<br><br>it was, Flask, alas! was a butterless man!<br><br><br><br>Another thing.  Flask was the last person down at the dinner, and<br><br>Flask is the first man up.  Consider!  For hereby Flask's dinner was<br><br>badly jammed in point of time.  Starbuck and Stubb both had the start<br><br>of him; and yet they also have the privilege of lounging in the rear.<br><br>If Stubb even, who is but a peg higher than Flask, happens to have<br><br>but a small appetite, and soon shows symptoms of concluding his<br><br>repast, then Flask must bestir himself, he will not get more than<br><br>three mouthfuls that day; for it is against holy usage for Stubb to<br><br>precede Flask to the deck.  Therefore it was that Flask once admitted<br><br>in private, that ever since he had arisen to the dignity of an<br><br>officer, from that moment he had never known what it was to be<br><br>otherwise than hungry, more or less.  For what he ate did not so much<br><br>relieve his hunger, as keep it immortal in him.  Peace and<br><br>satisfaction, thought Flask, have for ever departed from my stomach.<br><br>I am an officer; but, how I wish I could fish a bit of old-fashioned<br><br>beef in the forecastle, as I used to when I was before the mast.<br><br>There's the fruits of promotion now; there's the vanity of glory:<br><br>there's the insanity of life!  Besides, if it were so that any mere<br><br>sailor of the Pequod had a grudge against Flask in Flask's official<br><br>capacity, all that sailor had to do, in order to obtain ample<br><br>vengeance, was to go aft at dinner-time, and get a peep at Flask<br><br>through the cabin sky-light, sitting silly and dumfoundered before<br><br>awful Ahab.<br><br><br><br>Now, Ahab and his three mates formed what may be called the first<br><br>table in the Pequod's cabin.  After their departure, taking place in<br><br>inverted order to their arrival, the canvas cloth was cleared, or<br><br>rather was restored to some hurried order by the pallid steward.  And<br><br>then the three harpooneers were bidden to the feast, they being its<br><br>residuary legatees.  They made a sort of temporary servants' hall of<br><br>the high and mighty cabin.<br><br><br><br>In strange contrast to the hardly tolerable constraint and nameless<br><br>invisible domineerings of the captain's table, was the entire<br><br>care-free license and ease, the almost frantic democracy of those<br><br>inferior fellows the harpooneers.  While their masters, the mates,<br><br>seemed afraid of the sound of the hinges of their own jaws, the<br><br>harpooneers chewed their food with such a relish that there was a<br><br>report to it.  They dined like lords; they filled their bellies like<br><br>Indian ships all day loading with spices.  Such portentous appetites<br><br>had Queequeg and Tashtego, that to fill out the vacancies made by the<br><br>previous repast, often the pale Dough-Boy was fain to bring on a<br><br>great baron of salt-junk, seemingly quarried out of the solid ox.<br><br>And if he were not lively about it, if he did not go with a nimble<br><br>hop-skip-and-jump, then Tashtego had an ungentlemanly way of<br><br>accelerating him by darting a fork at his back, harpoon-wise.  And<br><br>once Daggoo, seized with a sudden humor, assisted Dough-Boy's memory<br><br>by snatching him up bodily, and thrusting his head into a great empty<br><br>wooden trencher, while Tashtego, knife in hand, began laying out the<br><br>circle preliminary to scalping him.  He was naturally a very nervous,<br><br>shuddering sort of little fellow, this bread-faced steward; the<br><br>progeny of a bankrupt baker and a hospital nurse.  And what with the<br><br>standing spectacle of the black terrific Ahab, and the periodical<br><br>tumultuous visitations of these three savages, Dough-Boy's whole life<br><br>was one continual lip-quiver.  Commonly, after seeing the harpooneers<br><br>furnished with all things they demanded, he would escape from their<br><br>clutches into his little pantry adjoining, and fearfully peep out at<br><br>them through the blinds of its door, till all was over.<br><br><br><br>It was a sight to see Queequeg seated over against Tashtego, opposing<br><br>his filed teeth to the Indian's: crosswise to them, Daggoo seated on<br><br>the floor, for a bench would have brought his hearse-plumed head to<br><br>the low carlines; at every motion of his colossal limbs, making the<br><br>low cabin framework to shake, as when an African elephant goes<br><br>passenger in a ship.  But for all this, the great negro was<br><br>wonderfully abstemious, not to say dainty.  It seemed hardly possible<br><br>that by such comparatively small mouthfuls he could keep up the<br><br>vitality diffused through so broad, baronial, and superb a person.<br><br>But, doubtless, this noble savage fed strong and drank deep of the<br><br>abounding element of air; and through his dilated nostrils snuffed in<br><br>the sublime life of the worlds.  Not by beef or by bread, are giants<br><br>made or nourished.  But Queequeg, he had a mortal, barbaric smack of<br><br>the lip in eating--an ugly sound enough--so much so, that the<br><br>trembling Dough-Boy almost looked to see whether any marks of teeth<br><br>lurked in his own lean arms.  And when he would hear Tashtego singing<br><br>out for him to produce himself, that his bones might be picked, the<br><br>simple-witted steward all but shattered the crockery hanging round<br><br>him in the pantry, by his sudden fits of the palsy.  Nor did the<br><br>whetstone which the harpooneers carried in their pockets, for their<br><br>lances and other weapons; and with which whetstones, at dinner, they<br><br>would ostentatiously sharpen their knives; that grating sound did not<br><br>at all tend to tranquillize poor Dough-Boy.  How could he forget that<br><br>in his Island days, Queequeg, for one, must certainly have been<br><br>guilty of some murderous, convivial indiscretions.  Alas!  Dough-Boy!<br><br>hard fares the white waiter who waits upon cannibals.  Not a napkin<br><br>should he carry on his arm, but a buckler.  In good time, though, to<br><br>his great delight, the three salt-sea warriors would rise and depart;<br><br>to his credulous, fable-mongering ears, all their martial bones<br><br>jingling in them at every step, like Moorish scimetars in scabbards.<br><br><br><br>But, though these barbarians dined in the cabin, and nominally lived<br><br>there; still, being anything but sedentary in their habits, they were<br><br>scarcely ever in it except at mealtimes, and just before<br><br>sleeping-time, when they passed through it to their own peculiar<br><br>quarters.<br><br><br><br>In this one matter, Ahab seemed no exception to most American whale<br><br>captains, who, as a set, rather incline to the opinion that by rights<br><br>the ship's cabin belongs to them; and that it is by courtesy alone<br><br>that anybody else is, at any time, permitted there.  So that, in real<br><br>truth, the mates and harpooneers of the Pequod might more properly be<br><br>said to have lived out of the cabin than in it.  For when they did<br><br>enter it, it was something as a street-door enters a house; turning<br><br>inwards for a moment, only to be turned out the next; and, as a<br><br>permanent thing, residing in the open air.  Nor did they lose much<br><br>hereby; in the cabin was no companionship; socially, Ahab was<br><br>inaccessible.  Though nominally included in the census of<br><br>Christendom, he was still an alien to it.  He lived in the world, as<br><br>the last of the Grisly Bears lived in settled Missouri.  And as when<br><br>Spring and Summer had departed, that wild Logan of the woods, burying<br><br>himself in the hollow of a tree, lived out the winter there, sucking<br><br>his own paws; so, in his inclement, howling old age, Ahab's soul,<br><br>shut up in the caved trunk of his body, there fed upon the sullen<br><br>paws of its gloom!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 35<br><br><br><br>The Mast-Head.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It was during the more pleasant weather, that in due rotation with<br><br>the other seamen my first mast-head came round.<br><br><br><br>In most American whalemen the mast-heads are manned almost<br><br>simultaneously with the vessel's leaving her port; even though she<br><br>may have fifteen thousand miles, and more, to sail ere reaching her<br><br>proper cruising ground.  And if, after a three, four, or five years'<br><br>voyage she is drawing nigh home with anything empty in her--say, an<br><br>empty vial even--then, her mast-heads are kept manned to the last;<br><br>and not till her skysail-poles sail in among the spires of the port,<br><br>does she altogether relinquish the hope of capturing one whale more.<br><br><br><br>Now, as the business of standing mast-heads, ashore or afloat, is a<br><br>very ancient and interesting one, let us in some measure expatiate<br><br>here.  I take it, that the earliest standers of mast-heads were the<br><br>old Egyptians; because, in all my researches, I find none prior to<br><br>them.  For though their progenitors, the builders of Babel, must<br><br>doubtless, by their tower, have intended to rear the loftiest<br><br>mast-head in all Asia, or Africa either; yet (ere the final truck was<br><br>put to it) as that great stone mast of theirs may be said to have<br><br>gone by the board, in the dread gale of God's wrath; therefore, we<br><br>cannot give these Babel builders priority over the Egyptians.  And<br><br>that the Egyptians were a nation of mast-head standers, is an<br><br>assertion based upon the general belief among archaeologists, that<br><br>the first pyramids were founded for astronomical purposes: a theory<br><br>singularly supported by the peculiar stair-like formation of all four<br><br>sides of those edifices; whereby, with prodigious long upliftings of<br><br>their legs, those old astronomers were wont to mount to the apex, and<br><br>sing out for new stars; even as the look-outs of a modern ship sing<br><br>out for a sail, or a whale just bearing in sight.  In Saint Stylites,<br><br>the famous Christian hermit of old times, who built him a lofty stone<br><br>pillar in the desert and spent the whole latter portion of his life<br><br>on its summit, hoisting his food from the ground with a tackle; in<br><br>him we have a remarkable instance of a dauntless<br><br>stander-of-mast-heads; who was not to be driven from his place by<br><br>fogs or frosts, rain, hail, or sleet; but valiantly facing everything<br><br>out to the last, literally died at his post.  Of modern<br><br>standers-of-mast-heads we have but a lifeless set; mere stone, iron,<br><br>and bronze men; who, though well capable of facing out a stiff gale,<br><br>are still entirely incompetent to the business of singing out upon<br><br>discovering any strange sight.  There is Napoleon; who, upon the top<br><br>of the column of Vendome, stands with arms folded, some one hundred<br><br>and fifty feet in the air; careless, now, who rules the decks below;<br><br>whether Louis Philippe, Louis Blanc, or Louis the Devil.  Great<br><br>Washington, too, stands high aloft on his towering main-mast in<br><br>Baltimore, and like one of Hercules' pillars, his column marks that<br><br>point of human grandeur beyond which few mortals will go.  Admiral<br><br>Nelson, also, on a capstan of gun-metal, stands his mast-head in<br><br>Trafalgar Square; and ever when most obscured by that London smoke,<br><br>token is yet given that a hidden hero is there; for where there is<br><br>smoke, must be fire.  But neither great Washington, nor Napoleon, nor<br><br>Nelson, will answer a single hail from below, however madly invoked<br><br>to befriend by their counsels the distracted decks upon which they<br><br>gaze; however it may be surmised, that their spirits penetrate<br><br>through the thick haze of the future, and descry what shoals and what<br><br>rocks must be shunned.<br><br><br><br>It may seem unwarrantable to couple in any respect the mast-head<br><br>standers of the land with those of the sea; but that in truth it is<br><br>not so, is plainly evinced by an item for which Obed Macy, the sole<br><br>historian of Nantucket, stands accountable.  The worthy Obed tells<br><br>us, that in the early times of the whale fishery, ere ships were<br><br>regularly launched in pursuit of the game, the people of that island<br><br>erected lofty spars along the sea-coast, to which the look-outs<br><br>ascended by means of nailed cleats, something as fowls go upstairs in<br><br>a hen-house.  A few years ago this same plan was adopted by the Bay<br><br>whalemen of New Zealand, who, upon descrying the game, gave notice to<br><br>the ready-manned boats nigh the beach.  But this custom has now<br><br>become obsolete; turn we then to the one proper mast-head, that of a<br><br>whale-ship at sea.  The three mast-heads are kept manned from<br><br>sun-rise to sun-set; the seamen taking their regular turns (as at the<br><br>helm), and relieving each other every two hours.  In the serene<br><br>weather of the tropics it is exceedingly pleasant the mast-head; nay,<br><br>to a dreamy meditative man it is delightful.  There you stand, a<br><br>hundred feet above the silent decks, striding along the deep, as if<br><br>the masts were gigantic stilts, while beneath you and between your<br><br>legs, as it were, swim the hugest monsters of the sea, even as ships<br><br>once sailed between the boots of the famous Colossus at old Rhodes.<br><br>There you stand, lost in the infinite series of the sea, with nothing<br><br>ruffled but the waves.  The tranced ship indolently rolls; the drowsy<br><br>trade winds blow; everything resolves you into languor.  For the most<br><br>part, in this tropic whaling life, a sublime uneventfulness invests<br><br>you; you hear no news; read no gazettes; extras with startling<br><br>accounts of commonplaces never delude you into unnecessary<br><br>excitements; you hear of no domestic afflictions; bankrupt<br><br>securities; fall of stocks; are never troubled with the thought of<br><br>what you shall have for dinner--for all your meals for three years<br><br>and more are snugly stowed in casks, and your bill of fare is<br><br>immutable.<br><br><br><br>In one of those southern whalesmen, on a long three or four years'<br><br>voyage, as often happens, the sum of the various hours you spend at<br><br>the mast-head would amount to several entire months.  And it is much<br><br>to be deplored that the place to which you devote so considerable a<br><br>portion of the whole term of your natural life, should be so sadly<br><br>destitute of anything approaching to a cosy inhabitiveness, or<br><br>adapted to breed a comfortable localness of feeling, such as pertains<br><br>to a bed, a hammock, a hearse, a sentry box, a pulpit, a coach, or<br><br>any other of those small and snug contrivances in which men<br><br>temporarily isolate themselves.  Your most usual point of perch is<br><br>the head of the t' gallant-mast, where you stand upon two thin<br><br>parallel sticks (almost peculiar to whalemen) called the t' gallant<br><br>cross-trees.  Here, tossed about by the sea, the beginner feels about<br><br>as cosy as he would standing on a bull's horns.  To be sure, in cold<br><br>weather you may carry your house aloft with you, in the shape of a<br><br>watch-coat; but properly speaking the thickest watch-coat is no more<br><br>of a house than the unclad body; for as the soul is glued inside of<br><br>its fleshy tabernacle, and cannot freely move about in it, nor even<br><br>move out of it, without running great risk of perishing (like an<br><br>ignorant pilgrim crossing the snowy Alps in winter); so a watch-coat<br><br>is not so much of a house as it is a mere envelope, or additional<br><br>skin encasing you.  You cannot put a shelf or chest of drawers in<br><br>your body, and no more can you make a convenient closet of your<br><br>watch-coat.<br><br><br><br>Concerning all this, it is much to be deplored that the mast-heads of<br><br>a southern whale ship are unprovided with those enviable little tents<br><br>or pulpits, called CROW'S-NESTS, in which the look-outs of a<br><br>Greenland whaler are protected from the inclement weather of the<br><br>frozen seas.  In the fireside narrative of Captain Sleet, entitled<br><br>"A Voyage among the Icebergs, in quest of the Greenland Whale, and<br><br>incidentally for the re-discovery of the Lost Icelandic Colonies of<br><br>Old Greenland;" in this admirable volume, all standers of mast-heads<br><br>are furnished with a charmingly circumstantial account of the then<br><br>recently invented CROW'S-NEST of the Glacier, which was the name of<br><br>Captain Sleet's good craft.  He called it the SLEET'S CROW'S-NEST, in<br><br>honour of himself; he being the original inventor and patentee, and<br><br>free from all ridiculous false delicacy, and holding that if we call<br><br>our own children after our own names (we fathers being the original<br><br>inventors and patentees), so likewise should we denominate after<br><br>ourselves any other apparatus we may beget.  In shape, the Sleet's<br><br>crow's-nest is something like a large tierce or pipe; it is open<br><br>above, however, where it is furnished with a movable side-screen to<br><br>keep to windward of your head in a hard gale.  Being fixed on the<br><br>summit of the mast, you ascend into it through a little trap-hatch in<br><br>the bottom.  On the after side, or side next the stern of the ship,<br><br>is a comfortable seat, with a locker underneath for umbrellas,<br><br>comforters, and coats.  In front is a leather rack, in which to keep<br><br>your speaking trumpet, pipe, telescope, and other nautical<br><br>conveniences.  When Captain Sleet in person stood his mast-head in<br><br>this crow's-nest of his, he tells us that he always had a rifle with<br><br>him (also fixed in the rack), together with a powder flask and shot,<br><br>for the purpose of popping off the stray narwhales, or vagrant sea<br><br>unicorns infesting those waters; for you cannot successfully shoot at<br><br>them from the deck owing to the resistance of the water, but to shoot<br><br>down upon them is a very different thing.  Now, it was plainly a<br><br>labor of love for Captain Sleet to describe, as he does, all the<br><br>little detailed conveniences of his crow's-nest; but though he so<br><br>enlarges upon many of these, and though he treats us to a very<br><br>scientific account of his experiments in this crow's-nest, with a<br><br>small compass he kept there for the purpose of counteracting the<br><br>errors resulting from what is called the "local attraction" of all<br><br>binnacle magnets; an error ascribable to the horizontal vicinity of<br><br>the iron in the ship's planks, and in the Glacier's case, perhaps, to<br><br>there having been so many broken-down blacksmiths among her crew; I<br><br>say, that though the Captain is very discreet and scientific here,<br><br>yet, for all his learned "binnacle deviations," "azimuth compass<br><br>observations," and "approximate errors," he knows very well, Captain<br><br>Sleet, that he was not so much immersed in those profound magnetic<br><br>meditations, as to fail being attracted occasionally towards that<br><br>well replenished little case-bottle, so nicely tucked in on one side<br><br>of his crow's nest, within easy reach of his hand.  Though, upon the<br><br>whole, I greatly admire and even love the brave, the honest, and<br><br>learned Captain; yet I take it very ill of him that he should so<br><br>utterly ignore that case-bottle, seeing what a faithful friend and<br><br>comforter it must have been, while with mittened fingers and hooded<br><br>head he was studying the mathematics aloft there in that bird's nest<br><br>within three or four perches of the pole.<br><br><br><br>But if we Southern whale-fishers are not so snugly housed aloft as<br><br>Captain Sleet and his Greenlandmen were; yet that disadvantage is<br><br>greatly counter-balanced by the widely contrasting serenity of those<br><br>seductive seas in which we South fishers mostly float.  For one, I<br><br>used to lounge up the rigging very leisurely, resting in the top to<br><br>have a chat with Queequeg, or any one else off duty whom I might find<br><br>there; then ascending a little way further, and throwing a lazy leg<br><br>over the top-sail yard, take a preliminary view of the watery<br><br>pastures, and so at last mount to my ultimate destination.<br><br><br><br>Let me make a clean breast of it here, and frankly admit that I kept<br><br>but sorry guard.  With the problem of the universe revolving in me,<br><br>how could I--being left completely to myself at such a<br><br>thought-engendering altitude--how could I but lightly hold my<br><br>obligations to observe all whale-ships' standing orders, "Keep your<br><br>weather eye open, and sing out every time."<br><br><br><br>And let me in this place movingly admonish you, ye ship-owners of<br><br>Nantucket!  Beware of enlisting in your vigilant fisheries any lad<br><br>with lean brow and hollow eye; given to unseasonable meditativeness;<br><br>and who offers to ship with the Phaedon instead of Bowditch in his<br><br>head.  Beware of such an one, I say; your whales must be seen before<br><br>they can be killed; and this sunken-eyed young Platonist will tow you<br><br>ten wakes round the world, and never make you one pint of sperm the<br><br>richer.  Nor are these monitions at all unneeded.  For nowadays, the<br><br>whale-fishery furnishes an asylum for many romantic, melancholy, and<br><br>absent-minded young men, disgusted with the carking cares of earth,<br><br>and seeking sentiment in tar and blubber.  Childe Harold not<br><br>unfrequently perches himself upon the mast-head of some luckless<br><br>disappointed whale-ship, and in moody phrase ejaculates:--<br><br><br><br>"Roll on, thou deep and dark blue ocean, roll!  Ten thousand<br><br>blubber-hunters sweep over thee in vain."<br><br><br><br>Very often do the captains of such ships take those absent-minded<br><br>young philosophers to task, upbraiding them with not feeling<br><br>sufficient "interest" in the voyage; half-hinting that they are so<br><br>hopelessly lost to all honourable ambition, as that in their secret<br><br>souls they would rather not see whales than otherwise.  But all in<br><br>vain; those young Platonists have a notion that their vision is<br><br>imperfect; they are short-sighted; what use, then, to strain the<br><br>visual nerve?  They have left their opera-glasses at home.<br><br><br><br>"Why, thou monkey," said a harpooneer to one of these lads, "we've<br><br>been cruising now hard upon three years, and thou hast not raised a<br><br>whale yet.  Whales are scarce as hen's teeth whenever thou art up<br><br>here."  Perhaps they were; or perhaps there might have been shoals of<br><br>them in the far horizon; but lulled into such an opium-like<br><br>listlessness of vacant, unconscious reverie is this absent-minded<br><br>youth by the blending cadence of waves with thoughts, that at last he<br><br>loses his identity; takes the mystic ocean at his feet for the<br><br>visible image of that deep, blue, bottomless soul, pervading mankind<br><br>and nature; and every strange, half-seen, gliding, beautiful thing<br><br>that eludes him; every dimly-discovered, uprising fin of some<br><br>undiscernible form, seems to him the embodiment of those elusive<br><br>thoughts that only people the soul by continually flitting through<br><br>it.  In this enchanted mood, thy spirit ebbs away to whence it came;<br><br>becomes diffused through time and space; like Crammer's sprinkled<br><br>Pantheistic ashes, forming at last a part of every shore the round<br><br>globe over.<br><br><br><br>There is no life in thee, now, except that rocking life imparted by a<br><br>gently rolling ship; by her, borrowed from the sea; by the sea, from<br><br>the inscrutable tides of God.  But while this sleep, this dream is on<br><br>ye, move your foot or hand an inch; slip your hold at all; and your<br><br>identity comes back in horror.  Over Descartian vortices you hover.<br><br>And perhaps, at mid-day, in the fairest weather, with one<br><br>half-throttled shriek you drop through that transparent air into the<br><br>summer sea, no more to rise for ever.  Heed it well, ye Pantheists!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 36<br><br><br><br>The Quarter-Deck.<br><br><br><br><br><br>(ENTER AHAB: THEN, ALL)<br><br><br><br><br><br>It was not a great while after the affair of the pipe, that one<br><br>morning shortly after breakfast, Ahab, as was his wont, ascended the<br><br>cabin-gangway to the deck.  There most sea-captains usually walk at<br><br>that hour, as country gentlemen, after the same meal, take a few<br><br>turns in the garden.<br><br><br><br>Soon his steady, ivory stride was heard, as to and fro he paced his<br><br>old rounds, upon planks so familiar to his tread, that they were all<br><br>over dented, like geological stones, with the peculiar mark of his<br><br>walk.  Did you fixedly gaze, too, upon that ribbed and dented brow;<br><br>there also, you would see still stranger foot-prints--the foot-prints<br><br>of his one unsleeping, ever-pacing thought.<br><br><br><br>But on the occasion in question, those dents looked deeper, even as<br><br>his nervous step that morning left a deeper mark.  And, so full of<br><br>his thought was Ahab, that at every uniform turn that he made, now at<br><br>the main-mast and now at the binnacle, you could almost see that<br><br>thought turn in him as he turned, and pace in him as he paced; so<br><br>completely possessing him, indeed, that it all but seemed the inward<br><br>mould of every outer movement.<br><br><br><br>"D'ye mark him, Flask?" whispered Stubb; "the chick that's in him<br><br>pecks the shell.  'Twill soon be out."<br><br><br><br>The hours wore on;--Ahab now shut up within his cabin; anon, pacing<br><br>the deck, with the same intense bigotry of purpose in his aspect.<br><br><br><br>It drew near the close of day.  Suddenly he came to a halt by the<br><br>bulwarks, and inserting his bone leg into the auger-hole there, and<br><br>with one hand grasping a shroud, he ordered Starbuck to send<br><br>everybody aft.<br><br><br><br>"Sir!" said the mate, astonished at an order seldom or never given on<br><br>ship-board except in some extraordinary case.<br><br><br><br>"Send everybody aft," repeated Ahab.  "Mast-heads, there! come down!"<br><br><br><br>When the entire ship's company were assembled, and with curious and<br><br>not wholly unapprehensive faces, were eyeing him, for he looked not<br><br>unlike the weather horizon when a storm is coming up, Ahab, after<br><br>rapidly glancing over the bulwarks, and then darting his eyes among<br><br>the crew, started from his standpoint; and as though not a soul were<br><br>nigh him resumed his heavy turns upon the deck.  With bent head and<br><br>half-slouched hat he continued to pace, unmindful of the wondering<br><br>whispering among the men; till Stubb cautiously whispered to Flask,<br><br>that Ahab must have summoned them there for the purpose of witnessing<br><br>a pedestrian feat.  But this did not last long.  Vehemently pausing,<br><br>he cried:--<br><br><br><br>"What do ye do when ye see a whale, men?"<br><br><br><br>"Sing out for him!" was the impulsive rejoinder from a score of<br><br>clubbed voices.<br><br><br><br>"Good!" cried Ahab, with a wild approval in his tones; observing the<br><br>hearty animation into which his unexpected question had so<br><br>magnetically thrown them.<br><br><br><br>"And what do ye next, men?"<br><br><br><br>"Lower away, and after him!"<br><br><br><br>"And what tune is it ye pull to, men?"<br><br><br><br>"A dead whale or a stove boat!"<br><br><br><br>More and more strangely and fiercely glad and approving, grew the<br><br>countenance of the old man at every shout; while the mariners began<br><br>to gaze curiously at each other, as if marvelling how it was that<br><br>they themselves became so excited at such seemingly purposeless<br><br>questions.<br><br><br><br>But, they were all eagerness again, as Ahab, now half-revolving in<br><br>his pivot-hole, with one hand reaching high up a shroud, and tightly,<br><br>almost convulsively grasping it, addressed them thus:--<br><br><br><br>"All ye mast-headers have before now heard me give orders about a<br><br>white whale.  Look ye! d'ye see this Spanish ounce of gold?"--holding<br><br>up a broad bright coin to the sun--"it is a sixteen dollar piece,<br><br>men.  D'ye see it?  Mr. Starbuck, hand me yon top-maul."<br><br><br><br>While the mate was getting the hammer, Ahab, without speaking, was<br><br>slowly rubbing the gold piece against the skirts of his jacket, as if<br><br>to heighten its lustre, and without using any words was meanwhile<br><br>lowly humming to himself, producing a sound so strangely muffled and<br><br>inarticulate that it seemed the mechanical humming of the wheels of<br><br>his vitality in him.<br><br><br><br>Receiving the top-maul from Starbuck, he advanced towards the<br><br>main-mast with the hammer uplifted in one hand, exhibiting the gold<br><br>with the other, and with a high raised voice exclaiming: "Whosoever<br><br>of ye raises me a white-headed whale with a wrinkled brow and a<br><br>crooked jaw; whosoever of ye raises me that white-headed whale, with<br><br>three holes punctured in his starboard fluke--look ye, whosoever of<br><br>ye raises me that same white whale, he shall have this gold ounce, my<br><br>boys!"<br><br><br><br>"Huzza! huzza!" cried the seamen, as with swinging tarpaulins they<br><br>hailed the act of nailing the gold to the mast.<br><br><br><br>"It's a white whale, I say," resumed Ahab, as he threw down the<br><br>topmaul: "a white whale.  Skin your eyes for him, men; look sharp for<br><br>white water; if ye see but a bubble, sing out."<br><br><br><br>All this while Tashtego, Daggoo, and Queequeg had looked on with even<br><br>more intense interest and surprise than the rest, and at the mention<br><br>of the wrinkled brow and crooked jaw they had started as if each was<br><br>separately touched by some specific recollection.<br><br><br><br>"Captain Ahab," said Tashtego, "that white whale must be the same<br><br>that some call Moby Dick."<br><br><br><br>"Moby Dick?" shouted Ahab.  "Do ye know the white whale then, Tash?"<br><br><br><br>"Does he fan-tail a little curious, sir, before he goes down?" said<br><br>the Gay-Header deliberately.<br><br><br><br>"And has he a curious spout, too," said Daggoo, "very bushy, even for<br><br>a parmacetty, and mighty quick, Captain Ahab?"<br><br><br><br>"And he have one, two, three--oh! good many iron in him hide, too,<br><br>Captain," cried Queequeg disjointedly, "all twiske-tee be-twisk, like<br><br>him--him--" faltering hard for a word, and screwing his hand round<br><br>and round as though uncorking a bottle--"like him--him--"<br><br><br><br>"Corkscrew!" cried Ahab, "aye, Queequeg, the harpoons lie all twisted<br><br>and wrenched in him; aye, Daggoo, his spout is a big one, like a<br><br>whole shock of wheat, and white as a pile of our Nantucket wool after<br><br>the great annual sheep-shearing; aye, Tashtego, and he fan-tails like<br><br>a split jib in a squall.  Death and devils! men, it is Moby Dick ye<br><br>have seen--Moby Dick--Moby Dick!"<br><br><br><br>"Captain Ahab," said Starbuck, who, with Stubb and Flask, had thus<br><br>far been eyeing his superior with increasing surprise, but at last<br><br>seemed struck with a thought which somewhat explained all the wonder.<br><br>"Captain Ahab, I have heard of Moby Dick--but it was not Moby Dick<br><br>that took off thy leg?"<br><br><br><br>"Who told thee that?" cried Ahab; then pausing, "Aye, Starbuck; aye,<br><br>my hearties all round; it was Moby Dick that dismasted me; Moby Dick<br><br>that brought me to this dead stump I stand on now.  Aye, aye," he<br><br>shouted with a terrific, loud, animal sob, like that of a<br><br>heart-stricken moose; "Aye, aye! it was that accursed white whale<br><br>that razeed me; made a poor pegging lubber of me for ever and a day!"<br><br>Then tossing both arms, with measureless imprecations he shouted<br><br>out: "Aye, aye! and I'll chase him round Good Hope, and round the<br><br>Horn, and round the Norway Maelstrom, and round perdition's flames<br><br>before I give him up. What say ye,<br><br>men, will ye splice hands on it, now?  I think ye do look brave."<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye!" shouted the harpooneers and seamen, running closer to the<br><br>excited old man: "A sharp eye for the white whale; a sharp lance for<br><br>Moby Dick!"<br><br><br><br>"God bless ye," he seemed to half sob and half shout.  "God bless ye,<br><br>men.  Steward! go draw the great measure of grog.  But what's this<br><br>long face about, Mr. Starbuck; wilt thou not chase the white whale?<br><br>art not game for Moby Dick?"<br><br><br><br>"I am game for his crooked jaw, and for the jaws of Death too,<br><br>Captain Ahab, if it fairly comes in the way of the business we<br><br>follow; but I came here to hunt whales, not my commander's vengeance.<br><br>How many barrels will thy vengeance yield thee even if thou gettest<br><br>it, Captain Ahab? it will not fetch thee much in our Nantucket<br><br>market."<br><br><br><br>"Nantucket market!  Hoot!  But come closer, Starbuck; thou requirest<br><br>a little lower layer.  If money's to be the measurer, man, and the<br><br>accountants have computed their great counting-house the globe, by<br><br>girdling it with guineas, one to every three parts of an inch; then,<br><br>let me tell thee, that my vengeance will fetch a great premium HERE!"<br><br><br><br>"He smites his chest," whispered Stubb, "what's that for? methinks it<br><br>rings most vast, but hollow."<br><br><br><br>"Vengeance on a dumb brute!" cried Starbuck, "that simply smote thee<br><br>from blindest instinct!  Madness!  To be enraged with a dumb thing,<br><br>Captain Ahab, seems blasphemous."<br><br><br><br>"Hark ye yet again--the little lower layer.  All visible objects,<br><br>man, are but as pasteboard masks.  But in each event--in the living<br><br>act, the undoubted deed--there, some unknown but still reasoning<br><br>thing puts forth the mouldings of its features from behind the<br><br>unreasoning mask.  If man will strike, strike through the mask!  How<br><br>can the prisoner reach outside except by thrusting through the wall?<br><br>To me, the white whale is that wall, shoved near to me.  Sometimes I<br><br>think there's naught beyond.  But 'tis enough.  He tasks me; he heaps<br><br>me; I see in him outrageous strength, with an inscrutable malice<br><br>sinewing it.  That inscrutable thing is chiefly what I hate; and be<br><br>the white whale agent, or be the white whale principal, I will wreak<br><br>that hate upon him.  Talk not to me of blasphemy, man; I'd strike the<br><br>sun if it insulted me.  For could the sun do that, then could I do<br><br>the other; since there is ever a sort of fair play herein, jealousy<br><br>presiding over all creations.  But not my master, man, is even that<br><br>fair play.  Who's over me?  Truth hath no confines.  Take off thine<br><br>eye! more intolerable than fiends' glarings is a doltish stare!  So,<br><br>so; thou reddenest and palest; my heat has melted thee to anger-glow.<br><br>But look ye, Starbuck, what is said in heat, that thing unsays<br><br>itself. The Pagan leopards--the unrecking and unworshipping things,<br><br>that live; and seek, and give no reasons for the torrid life they<br><br>feel!  The crew, man, the crew!  Are they not one and all with Ahab,<br><br>in this matter of the whale?  See Stubb! he laughs!  See yonder<br><br>Chilian! he snorts to think of it.  Stand up amid the general<br><br>hurricane, thy one tost sapling cannot, Starbuck!  And what is it?<br><br>Reckon it.  'Tis but to help strike a fin; no wondrous feat for<br><br>Starbuck.  What is it more?  From this one poor hunt, then, the best<br><br>lance out of all Nantucket, surely he will not hang back, when every<br><br>foremast-hand has clutched a whetstone?  Ah! constrainings seize<br><br>thee; I see! the billow lifts thee!  Speak, but speak!--Aye, aye! thy<br><br>silence, then, THAT voices thee.  (ASIDE) Something shot from my<br><br>dilated nostrils, he has inhaled it in his lungs.  Starbuck now is<br><br>mine; cannot oppose me now, without rebellion."<br><br><br><br>"God keep me!--keep us all!" murmured Starbuck, lowly.<br><br><br><br>But in his joy at the enchanted, tacit acquiescence of the mate, Ahab<br><br>did not hear his foreboding invocation; nor yet the low laugh from<br><br>the hold; nor yet the presaging vibrations of the winds in the<br><br>cordage; nor yet the hollow flap of the sails against the masts, as<br><br>for a moment their hearts sank in. Yet not so much predictions from without, as verifications<br><br>of the foregoing things within.  For with little external to<br><br>constrain us, the innermost necessities in our being, these still<br><br>drive us on.<br><br><br><br>"The measure! the measure!" cried Ahab.<br><br><br><br>Receiving the brimming pewter, and turning to the harpooneers, he<br><br>ordered them to produce their weapons. Perchance ye need it not.  Down lances!  And now,<br><br>ye mates, I do appoint ye three cupbearers to my three pagan kinsmen<br><br>there--yon three most honourable gentlemen and noblemen, my valiant<br><br>harpooneers.  Disdain the task?  What, when the great Pope washes the<br><br>feet of beggars, using his tiara for ewer?  Oh, my sweet cardinals!<br><br>your own condescension, THAT shall bend ye to it. Commend the murderous chalices!<br><br>Bestow them, ye who are now made parties to this indissoluble league.<br><br>Ha!  Starbuck! but the deed is done!  Yon ratifying sun now waits to<br><br>sit upon it.  Drink, ye harpooneers! drink and swear, ye men that man<br><br>the deathful whaleboat's bow--Death to Moby Dick! The long, barbed steel<br><br>goblets were lifted; and to cries and maledictions against the white<br><br>whale, the spirits were simultaneously quaffed down with a hiss.<br><br>Starbuck paled, and turned, and shivered.  Once more, and finally,<br><br>the replenished pewter went the rounds among the frantic crew; when,<br><br>waving his free hand to them, they all dispersed; and Ahab retired<br><br>within his cabin.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 37<br><br><br><br>Sunset.<br><br><br><br><br><br>THE CABIN; BY THE STERN WINDOWS; AHAB SITTING ALONE, AND GAZING OUT.<br><br><br><br><br><br>I leave a white and turbid wake; pale waters, paler cheeks, where'er<br><br>I sail.  The envious billows sidelong swell to whelm my track; let<br><br>them; but first I pass.<br><br><br><br>Yonder, by ever-brimming goblet's rim, the warm waves blush like<br><br>wine.  The gold brow plumbs the blue.  The diver sun--slow dived from<br><br>noon--goes down; my soul mounts up! she wearies with her endless<br><br>hill.  Is, then, the crown too heavy that I wear? this Iron Crown of<br><br>Lombardy.  Yet is it bright with many a gem; I the wearer, see not<br><br>its far flashings; but darkly feel that I wear that, that dazzlingly<br><br>confounds.  'Tis iron--that I know--not gold.  'Tis split, too--that<br><br>I feel; the jagged edge galls me so, my brain seems to beat against<br><br>the solid metal; aye, steel skull, mine; the sort that needs no<br><br>helmet in the most brain-battering fight!<br><br><br><br>Dry heat upon my brow?  Oh! time was, when as the sunrise nobly<br><br>spurred me, so the sunset soothed.  No more.  This lovely light, it<br><br>lights not me; all loveliness is anguish to me, since I can ne'er<br><br>enjoy.  Gifted with the high perception, I lack the low, enjoying<br><br>power; damned, most subtly and most malignantly! damned in the midst<br><br>of Paradise!  Good night--good night! (WAVING HIS HAND, HE MOVES FROM<br><br>THE WINDOW.)<br><br><br><br>'Twas not so hard a task.  I thought to find one stubborn, at the<br><br>least; but my one cogged circle fits into all their various wheels,<br><br>and they revolve.  Or, if you will, like so many ant-hills of powder,<br><br>they all stand before me; and I their match.  Oh, hard! that to fire<br><br>others, the match itself must needs be wasting!  What I've dared,<br><br>I've willed; and what I've willed, I'll do!  They think me<br><br>mad--Starbuck does; but I'm demoniac, I am madness maddened!  That<br><br>wild madness that's only calm to comprehend itself!  The prophecy was<br><br>that I should be dismembered; and--Aye!  I lost this leg.  I now<br><br>prophesy that I will dismember my dismemberer.  Now, then, be the<br><br>prophet and the fulfiller one.  That's more than ye, ye great gods,<br><br>ever were.  I laugh and hoot at ye, ye cricket-players, ye pugilists,<br><br>ye deaf Burkes and blinded Bendigoes!  I will not say as schoolboys<br><br>do to bullies--Take some one of your own size; don't pommel ME!  No,<br><br>ye've knocked me down, and I am up again; but YE have run and hidden.<br><br>Come forth from behind your cotton bags!  I have no long gun to<br><br>reach ye.  Come, Ahab's compliments to ye; come and see if ye can<br><br>swerve me.  Swerve me? ye cannot swerve me, else ye swerve<br><br>yourselves! man has ye there.  Swerve me?  The path to my fixed<br><br>purpose is laid with iron rails, whereon my soul is grooved to run.<br><br>Over unsounded gorges, through the rifled hearts of mountains, under<br><br>torrents' beds, unerringly I rush!  Naught's an obstacle, naught's an<br><br>angle to the iron way!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 38<br><br><br><br>Dusk.<br><br><br><br><br><br>BY THE MAINMAST; STARBUCK LEANING AGAINST IT.<br><br><br><br><br><br>My soul is more than matched; she's overmanned; and by a madman!<br><br>Insufferable sting, that sanity should ground arms on such a field!<br><br>But he drilled deep down, and blasted all my reason out of me!  I<br><br>think I see his impious end; but feel that I must help him to it.<br><br>Will I, nill I, the ineffable thing has tied me to him; tows me with<br><br>a cable I have no knife to cut.  Horrible old man!  Who's over him,<br><br>he cries;--aye, he would be a democrat to all above; look, how he<br><br>lords it over all below!  Oh!  I plainly see my miserable office,--to<br><br>obey, rebelling; and worse yet, to hate with touch of pity!  For in<br><br>his eyes I read some lurid woe would shrivel me up, had I it.  Yet is<br><br>there hope.  Time and tide flow wide.  The hated whale has the round<br><br>watery world to swim in, as the small gold-fish has its glassy globe.<br><br>His heaven-insulting purpose, God may wedge aside.  I would up<br><br>heart, were it not like lead.  But my whole clock's run down; my<br><br>heart the all-controlling weight, I have no key to lift again.<br><br><br><br><br><br>[A BURST OF REVELRY FROM THE FORECASTLE.]<br><br><br><br><br><br>Oh, God! to sail with such a heathen crew that have small touch of<br><br>human mothers in them!  Whelped somewhere by the sharkish sea.  The<br><br>white whale is their demigorgon.  Hark! the infernal orgies! that<br><br>revelry is forward! mark the unfaltering silence aft!  Methinks it<br><br>pictures life.  Foremost through the sparkling sea shoots on the gay,<br><br>embattled, bantering bow, but only to drag dark Ahab after it, where<br><br>he broods within his sternward cabin, builded over the dead water of<br><br>the wake, and further on, hunted by its wolfish gurglings.  The long<br><br>howl thrills me through!  Peace! ye revellers, and set the watch!<br><br>Oh, life!  'tis in an hour like this, with soul beat down and held to<br><br>knowledge,--as wild, untutored things are forced to feed--Oh, life!<br><br>'tis now that I do feel the latent horror in thee! but 'tis not me!<br><br>that horror's out of me! and with the soft feeling of the human in<br><br>me, yet will I try to fight ye, ye grim, phantom futures!  Stand by<br><br>me, hold me, bind me, O ye blessed influences!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 39<br><br><br><br>First Night Watch.<br><br><br><br>Fore-Top.<br><br><br><br>(STUBB SOLUS, AND MENDING A BRACE.)<br><br><br><br><br><br>Ha! ha! ha! ha! hem! clear my throat!--I've been thinking over it<br><br>ever since, and that ha, ha's the final consequence.  Why so?<br><br>Because a laugh's the wisest, easiest answer to all that's queer; and<br><br>come what will, one comfort's always left--that unfailing comfort is,<br><br>it's all predestinated.  I heard not all his talk with Starbuck; but<br><br>to my poor eye Starbuck then looked something as I the other evening<br><br>felt.  Be sure the old Mogul has fixed him, too.  I twigged it, knew<br><br>it; had had the gift, might readily have prophesied it--for when I<br><br>clapped my eye upon his skull I saw it.  Well, Stubb, WISE<br><br>Stubb--that's my title--well, Stubb, what of it, Stubb?  Here's a<br><br>carcase.  I know not all that may be coming, but be it what it will,<br><br>I'll go to it laughing.  Such a waggish leering as lurks in all your<br><br>horribles!  I feel funny.  Fa, la! lirra, skirra!  What's my juicy<br><br>little pear at home doing now?  Crying its eyes out?--Giving a party<br><br>to the last arrived harpooneers, I dare say, gay as a frigate's<br><br>pennant, and so am I--fa, la! lirra, skirra!  Oh--<br><br><br><br>We'll drink to-night with hearts as light,<br><br>To love, as gay and fleeting<br><br>As bubbles that swim, on the beaker's brim,<br><br>And break on the lips while meeting.<br><br><br><br><br><br>A brave stave that--who calls? Fine prospects to 'em; they're on<br><br>the road to heaven.  Hold on hard!  Jimmini, what a squall!  But<br><br>those chaps there are worse yet--they are your white squalls, they.<br><br>White squalls? white whale, shirr! shirr! A wild, mystical, sympathetical feeling was in me; Ahab's<br><br>quenchless feud seemed mine.  With greedy ears I learned the history<br><br>of that murderous monster against whom I and all the others had taken<br><br>our oaths of violence and revenge.<br><br><br><br>For some time past, though at intervals only, the unaccompanied,<br><br>secluded White Whale had haunted those uncivilized seas mostly<br><br>frequented by the Sperm Whale fishermen.  But not all of them knew of<br><br>his existence; only a few of them, comparatively, had knowingly seen<br><br>him; while the number who as yet had actually and knowingly given<br><br>battle to him, was small indeed.  For, owing to the large number of<br><br>whale-cruisers; the disorderly way they were sprinkled over the<br><br>entire watery circumference, many of them adventurously pushing their<br><br>quest along solitary latitudes, so as seldom or never for a whole<br><br>twelvemonth or more on a stretch, to encounter a single news-telling<br><br>sail of any sort; the inordinate length of each separate voyage; the<br><br>irregularity of the times of sailing from home; all these, with other<br><br>circumstances, direct and indirect, long obstructed the spread<br><br>through the whole world-wide whaling-fleet of the special<br><br>individualizing tidings concerning Moby Dick.  It was hardly to be<br><br>doubted, that several vessels reported to have encountered, at such<br><br>or such a time, or on such or such a meridian, a Sperm Whale of<br><br>uncommon magnitude and malignity, which whale, after doing great<br><br>mischief to his assailants, had completely escaped them; to some<br><br>minds it was not an unfair presumption, I say, that the whale in<br><br>question must have been no other than Moby Dick.  Yet as of late the<br><br>Sperm Whale fishery had been marked by various and not unfrequent<br><br>instances of great ferocity, cunning, and malice in the monster<br><br>attacked; therefore it was, that those who by accident ignorantly<br><br>gave battle to Moby Dick; such hunters, perhaps, for the most part,<br><br>were content to ascribe the peculiar terror he bred, more, as it<br><br>were, to the perils of the Sperm Whale fishery at large, than to the<br><br>individual cause.  In that way, mostly, the disastrous encounter<br><br>between Ahab and the whale had hitherto been popularly regarded.<br><br><br><br>And as for those who, previously hearing of the White Whale, by<br><br>chance caught sight of him; in the beginning of the thing they had<br><br>every one of them, almost, as boldly and fearlessly lowered for him,<br><br>as for any other whale of that species.  But at length, such<br><br>calamities did ensue in these assaults--not restricted to sprained<br><br>wrists and ankles, broken limbs, or devouring amputations--but fatal<br><br>to the last degree of fatality; those repeated disastrous repulses,<br><br>all accumulating and piling their terrors upon Moby Dick; those<br><br>things had gone far to shake the fortitude of many brave hunters, to<br><br>whom the story of the White Whale had eventually come.<br><br><br><br>Nor did wild rumors of all sorts fail to exaggerate, and still the<br><br>more horrify the true histories of these deadly encounters.  For not<br><br>only do fabulous rumors naturally grow out of the very body of all<br><br>surprising terrible events,--as the smitten tree gives birth to its<br><br>fungi; but, in maritime life, far more than in that of terra firma,<br><br>wild rumors abound, wherever there is any adequate reality for them<br><br>to cling to.  And as the sea surpasses the land in this matter, so<br><br>the whale fishery surpasses every other sort of maritime life, in the<br><br>wonderfulness and fearfulness of the rumors which sometimes circulate<br><br>there.  For not only are whalemen as a body unexempt from that<br><br>ignorance and superstitiousness hereditary to all sailors; but of all<br><br>sailors, they are by all odds the most directly brought into contact<br><br>with whatever is appallingly astonishing in the sea; face to face<br><br>they not only eye its greatest marvels, but, hand to jaw, give battle<br><br>to them.  Alone, in such remotest waters, that though you sailed a<br><br>thousand miles, and passed a thousand shores, you would not come to<br><br>any chiseled hearth-stone, or aught hospitable beneath that part of<br><br>the sun; in such latitudes and longitudes, pursuing too such a<br><br>calling as he does, the whaleman is wrapped by influences all tending<br><br>to make his fancy pregnant with many a mighty birth.<br><br><br><br>No wonder, then, that ever gathering volume from the mere transit<br><br>over the widest watery spaces, the outblown rumors of the White Whale<br><br>did in the end incorporate with themselves all manner of morbid<br><br>hints, and half-formed foetal suggestions of supernatural agencies,<br><br>which eventually invested Moby Dick with new terrors unborrowed from<br><br>anything that visibly appears.  So that in many cases such a panic<br><br>did he finally strike, that few who by those rumors, at least, had<br><br>heard of the White Whale, few of those hunters were willing to<br><br>encounter the perils of his jaw.<br><br><br><br>But there were still other and more vital practical influences at<br><br>work.  Not even at the present day has the original prestige of the<br><br>Sperm Whale, as fearfully distinguished from all other species of the<br><br>leviathan, died out of the minds of the whalemen as a body.  There<br><br>are those this day among them, who, though intelligent and courageous<br><br>enough in offering battle to the Greenland or Right whale, would<br><br>perhaps--either from professional inexperience, or incompetency, or<br><br>timidity, decline a contest with the Sperm Whale; at any rate, there<br><br>are plenty of whalemen, especially among those whaling nations not<br><br>sailing under the American flag, who have never hostilely encountered<br><br>the Sperm Whale, but whose sole knowledge of the leviathan is<br><br>restricted to the ignoble monster primitively pursued in the North;<br><br>seated on their hatches, these men will hearken with a childish<br><br>fireside interest and awe, to the wild, strange tales of Southern<br><br>whaling.  Nor is the pre-eminent tremendousness of the great Sperm<br><br>Whale anywhere more feelingly comprehended, than on board of those<br><br>prows which stem him.<br><br><br><br>And as if the now tested reality of his might had in former legendary<br><br>times thrown its shadow before it; we find some book<br><br>naturalists--Olassen and Povelson--declaring the Sperm Whale not only<br><br>to be a consternation to every other creature in the sea, but also to<br><br>be so incredibly ferocious as continually to be athirst for human<br><br>blood.  Nor even down to so late a time as Cuvier's, were these or<br><br>almost similar impressions effaced.  For in his Natural History, the<br><br>Baron himself affirms that at sight of the Sperm Whale, all fish<br><br>(sharks included) are "struck with the most lively terrors," and<br><br>"often in the precipitancy of their flight dash themselves against<br><br>the rocks with such violence as to cause instantaneous death."  And<br><br>however the general experiences in the fishery may amend such reports<br><br>as these; yet in their full terribleness, even to the bloodthirsty<br><br>item of Povelson, the superstitious belief in them is, in some<br><br>vicissitudes of their vocation, revived in the minds of the hunters.<br><br><br><br>So that overawed by the rumors and portents concerning him, not a few<br><br>of the fishermen recalled, in reference to Moby Dick, the earlier<br><br>days of the Sperm Whale fishery, when it was oftentimes hard to<br><br>induce long practised Right whalemen to embark in the perils of this<br><br>new and daring warfare; such men protesting that although other<br><br>leviathans might be hopefully pursued, yet to chase and point lance<br><br>at such an apparition as the Sperm Whale was not for mortal man.<br><br>That to attempt it, would be inevitably to be torn into a quick<br><br>eternity.  On this head, there are some remarkable documents that may<br><br>be consulted.<br><br><br><br>Nevertheless, some there were, who even in the face of these things<br><br>were ready to give chase to Moby Dick; and a still greater number<br><br>who, chancing only to hear of him distantly and vaguely, without the<br><br>specific details of any certain calamity, and without superstitious<br><br>accompaniments, were sufficiently hardy not to flee from the battle<br><br>if offered.<br><br><br><br>One of the wild suggestions referred to, as at last coming to be<br><br>linked with the White Whale in the minds of the superstitiously<br><br>inclined, was the unearthly conceit that Moby Dick was ubiquitous;<br><br>that he had actually been encountered in opposite latitudes at one<br><br>and the same instant of time.<br><br><br><br>Nor, credulous as such minds must have been, was this conceit<br><br>altogether without some faint show of superstitious probability.  For<br><br>as the secrets of the currents in the seas have never yet been<br><br>divulged, even to the most erudite research; so the hidden ways of<br><br>the Sperm Whale when beneath the surface remain, in great part,<br><br>unaccountable to his pursuers; and from time to time have originated<br><br>the most curious and contradictory speculations regarding them,<br><br>especially concerning the mystic modes whereby, after sounding to a<br><br>great depth, he transports himself with such vast swiftness to the<br><br>most widely distant points.<br><br><br><br>It is a thing well known to both American and English whale-ships,<br><br>and as well a thing placed upon authoritative record years ago by<br><br>Scoresby, that some whales have been captured far north in the<br><br>Pacific, in whose bodies have been found the barbs of harpoons darted<br><br>in the Greenland seas.  Nor is it to be gainsaid, that in some of<br><br>these instances it has been declared that the interval of time<br><br>between the two assaults could not have exceeded very many days.<br><br>Hence, by inference, it has been believed by some whalemen, that the<br><br>Nor' West Passage, so long a problem to man, was never a problem to<br><br>the whale.
