So that here, in the real living experience of living<br><br>men, the prodigies related in old times of the inland Strello<br><br>mountain in Portugal (near whose top there was said to be a lake in<br><br>which the wrecks of ships floated up to the surface); and that still<br><br>more wonderful story of the Arethusa fountain near Syracuse (whose<br><br>waters were believed to have come from the Holy Land by an<br><br>underground passage); these fabulous narrations are almost fully<br><br>equalled by the realities of the whalemen.<br><br><br><br>Forced into familiarity, then, with such prodigies as these; and<br><br>knowing that after repeated, intrepid assaults, the White Whale had<br><br>escaped alive; it cannot be much matter of surprise that some<br><br>whalemen should go still further in their superstitions; declaring<br><br>Moby Dick not only ubiquitous, but immortal (for immortality is but<br><br>ubiquity in time); that though groves of spears should be planted in<br><br>his flanks, he would still swim away unharmed; or if indeed he should<br><br>ever be made to spout thick blood, such a sight would be but a<br><br>ghastly deception; for again in unensanguined billows hundreds of<br><br>leagues away, his unsullied jet would once more be seen.<br><br><br><br>But even stripped of these supernatural surmisings, there was enough<br><br>in the earthly make and incontestable character of the monster to<br><br>strike the imagination with unwonted power.  For, it was not so much<br><br>his uncommon bulk that so much distinguished him from other sperm<br><br>whales, but, as was elsewhere thrown out--a peculiar snow-white<br><br>wrinkled forehead, and a high, pyramidical white hump.  These were<br><br>his prominent features; the tokens whereby, even in the limitless,<br><br>uncharted seas, he revealed his identity, at a long distance, to<br><br>those who knew him.<br><br><br><br>The rest of his body was so streaked, and spotted, and marbled with<br><br>the same shrouded hue, that, in the end, he had gained his<br><br>distinctive appellation of the White Whale; a name, indeed, literally<br><br>justified by his vivid aspect, when seen gliding at high noon through<br><br>a dark blue sea, leaving a milky-way wake of creamy foam, all<br><br>spangled with golden gleamings.<br><br><br><br>Nor was it his unwonted magnitude, nor his remarkable hue, nor yet<br><br>his deformed lower jaw, that so much invested the whale with natural<br><br>terror, as that unexampled, intelligent malignity which, according to<br><br>specific accounts, he had over and over again evinced in his<br><br>assaults.  More than all, his treacherous retreats struck more of<br><br>dismay than perhaps aught else.  For, when swimming before his<br><br>exulting pursuers, with every apparent symptom of alarm, he had<br><br>several times been known to turn round suddenly, and, bearing down<br><br>upon them, either stave their boats to splinters, or drive them back<br><br>in consternation to their ship.<br><br><br><br>Already several fatalities had attended his chase.  But though<br><br>similar disasters, however little bruited ashore, were by no means<br><br>unusual in the fishery; yet, in most instances, such seemed the White<br><br>Whale's infernal aforethought of ferocity, that every dismembering or<br><br>death that he caused, was not wholly regarded as having been<br><br>inflicted by an unintelligent agent.<br><br><br><br>Judge, then, to what pitches of inflamed, distracted fury the minds<br><br>of his more desperate hunters were impelled, when amid the chips of<br><br>chewed boats, and the sinking limbs of torn comrades, they swam out<br><br>of the white curds of the whale's direful wrath into the serene,<br><br>exasperating sunlight, that smiled on, as if at a birth or a bridal.<br><br><br><br>His three boats stove around him, and oars and men both whirling in<br><br>the eddies; one captain, seizing the line-knife from his broken prow,<br><br>had dashed at the whale, as an Arkansas duellist at his foe, blindly<br><br>seeking with a six inch blade to reach the fathom-deep life of the<br><br>whale.  That captain was Ahab.  And then it was, that suddenly<br><br>sweeping his sickle-shaped lower jaw beneath him, Moby Dick had<br><br>reaped away Ahab's leg, as a mower a blade of grass in the field.  No<br><br>turbaned Turk, no hired Venetian or Malay, could have smote him with<br><br>more seeming malice.  Small reason was there to doubt, then, that<br><br>ever since that almost fatal encounter, Ahab had cherished a wild<br><br>vindictiveness against the whale, all the more fell for that in his<br><br>frantic morbidness he at last came to identify with him, not only all<br><br>his bodily woes, but all his intellectual and spiritual<br><br>exasperations.  The White Whale swam before him as the monomaniac<br><br>incarnation of all those malicious agencies which some deep men feel<br><br>eating in them, till they are left living on with half a heart and<br><br>half a lung.  That intangible malignity which has been from the<br><br>beginning; to whose dominion even the modern Christians ascribe<br><br>one-half of the worlds; which the ancient Ophites of the east<br><br>reverenced in their statue devil;--Ahab did not fall down and worship<br><br>it like them; but deliriously transferring its idea to the abhorred<br><br>white whale, he pitted himself, all mutilated, against it.  All that<br><br>most maddens and torments; all that stirs up the lees of things; all<br><br>truth with malice in it; all that cracks the sinews and cakes the<br><br>brain; all the subtle demonisms of life and thought; all evil, to<br><br>crazy Ahab, were visibly personified, and made practically assailable<br><br>in Moby Dick.  He piled upon the whale's white hump the sum of all<br><br>the general rage and hate felt by his whole race from Adam down; and<br><br>then, as if his chest had been a mortar, he burst his hot heart's<br><br>shell upon it.<br><br><br><br>It is not probable that this monomania in him took its instant rise<br><br>at the precise time of his bodily dismemberment.  Then, in darting at<br><br>the monster, knife in hand, he had but given loose to a sudden,<br><br>passionate, corporal animosity; and when he received the stroke that<br><br>tore him, he probably but felt the agonizing bodily laceration, but<br><br>nothing more.  Yet, when by this collision forced to turn towards<br><br>home, and for long months of days and weeks, Ahab and anguish lay<br><br>stretched together in one hammock, rounding in mid winter that<br><br>dreary, howling Patagonian Cape; then it was, that his torn body and<br><br>gashed soul bled into one another; and so interfusing, made him mad.<br><br>That it was only then, on the homeward voyage, after the encounter,<br><br>that the final monomania seized him, seems all but certain from the<br><br>fact that, at intervals during the passage, he was a raving lunatic;<br><br>and, though unlimbed of a leg, yet such vital strength yet lurked in<br><br>his Egyptian chest, and was moreover intensified by his delirium,<br><br>that his mates were forced to lace him fast, even there, as he<br><br>sailed, raving in his hammock.  In a strait-jacket, he swung to the<br><br>mad rockings of the gales.  And, when running into more sufferable<br><br>latitudes, the ship, with mild stun'sails spread, floated across the<br><br>tranquil tropics, and, to all appearances, the old man's delirium<br><br>seemed left behind him with the Cape Horn swells, and he came forth<br><br>from his dark den into the blessed light and air; even then, when he<br><br>bore that firm, collected front, however pale, and issued his calm<br><br>orders once again; and his mates thanked God the direful madness was<br><br>now gone; even then, Ahab, in his hidden self, raved on.  Human<br><br>madness is oftentimes a cunning and most feline thing.  When you<br><br>think it fled, it may have but become transfigured into some still<br><br>subtler form.  Ahab's full lunacy subsided not, but deepeningly<br><br>contracted; like the unabated Hudson, when that noble Northman flows<br><br>narrowly, but unfathomably through the Highland gorge.  But, as in<br><br>his narrow-flowing monomania, not one jot of Ahab's broad madness had<br><br>been left behind; so in that broad madness, not one jot of his great<br><br>natural intellect had perished.  That before living agent, now became<br><br>the living instrument.  If such a furious trope may stand, his<br><br>special lunacy stormed his general sanity, and carried it, and turned<br><br>all its concentred cannon upon its own mad mark; so that far from<br><br>having lost his strength, Ahab, to that one end, did now possess a<br><br>thousand fold more potency than ever he had sanely brought to bear<br><br>upon any one reasonable object.<br><br><br><br>This is much; yet Ahab's larger, darker, deeper part remains<br><br>unhinted.  But vain to popularize profundities, and all truth is<br><br>profound.  Winding far down from within the very heart of this spiked<br><br>Hotel de Cluny where we here stand--however grand and wonderful, now<br><br>quit it;--and take your way, ye nobler, sadder souls, to those vast<br><br>Roman halls of Thermes; where far beneath the fantastic towers of<br><br>man's upper earth, his root of grandeur, his whole awful essence sits<br><br>in bearded state; an antique buried beneath antiquities, and throned<br><br>on torsoes!  So with a broken throne, the great gods mock that<br><br>captive king; so like a Caryatid, he patient sits, upholding on his<br><br>frozen brow the piled entablatures of ages.  Wind ye down there, ye<br><br>prouder, sadder souls! question that proud, sad king!  A family<br><br>likeness! aye, he did beget ye, ye young exiled royalties; and from<br><br>your grim sire only will the old State-secret come.<br><br><br><br>Now, in his heart, Ahab had some glimpse of this, namely: all my<br><br>means are sane, my motive and my object mad.  Yet without power to<br><br>kill, or change, or shun the fact; he likewise knew that to mankind<br><br>he did long dissemble; in some sort, did still.  But that thing of<br><br>his dissembling was only subject to his perceptibility, not to his<br><br>will determinate.  Nevertheless, so well did he succeed in that<br><br>dissembling, that when with ivory leg he stepped ashore at last, no<br><br>Nantucketer thought him otherwise than but naturally grieved, and<br><br>that to the quick, with the terrible casualty which had overtaken<br><br>him.<br><br><br><br>The report of his undeniable delirium at sea was likewise popularly<br><br>ascribed to a kindred cause.  And so too, all the added moodiness<br><br>which always afterwards, to the very day of sailing in the Pequod on<br><br>the present voyage, sat brooding on his brow.  Nor is it so very<br><br>unlikely, that far from distrusting his fitness for another whaling<br><br>voyage, on account of such dark symptoms, the calculating people of<br><br>that prudent isle were inclined to harbor the conceit, that for those<br><br>very reasons he was all the better qualified and set on edge, for a<br><br>pursuit so full of rage and wildness as the bloody hunt of whales.<br><br>Gnawed within and scorched without, with the infixed, unrelenting<br><br>fangs of some incurable idea; such an one, could he be found, would<br><br>seem the very man to dart his iron and lift his lance against the<br><br>most appalling of all brutes.  Or, if for any reason thought to be<br><br>corporeally incapacitated for that, yet such an one would seem<br><br>superlatively competent to cheer and howl on his underlings to the<br><br>attack.  But be all this as it may, certain it is, that with the mad<br><br>secret of his unabated rage bolted up and keyed in him, Ahab had<br><br>purposely sailed upon the present voyage with the one only and<br><br>all-engrossing object of hunting the White Whale.  Had any one of his<br><br>old acquaintances on shore but half dreamed of what was lurking in<br><br>him then, how soon would their aghast and righteous souls have<br><br>wrenched the ship from such a fiendish man!  They were bent on<br><br>profitable cruises, the profit to be counted down in dollars from the<br><br>mint.  He was intent on an audacious, immitigable, and supernatural<br><br>revenge.<br><br><br><br>Here, then, was this grey-headed, ungodly old man, chasing with<br><br>curses a Job's whale round the world, at the head of a crew, too,<br><br>chiefly made up of mongrel renegades, and castaways, and<br><br>cannibals--morally enfeebled also, by the incompetence of mere<br><br>unaided virtue or right-mindedness in Starbuck, the invunerable<br><br>jollity of indifference and recklessness in Stubb, and the pervading<br><br>mediocrity in Flask.  Such a crew, so officered, seemed specially<br><br>picked and packed by some infernal fatality to help him to his<br><br>monomaniac revenge.  How it was that they so aboundingly responded to<br><br>the old man's ire--by what evil magic their souls were possessed,<br><br>that at times his hate seemed almost theirs; the White Whale as much<br><br>their insufferable foe as his; how all this came to be--what the<br><br>White Whale was to them, or how to their unconscious understandings,<br><br>also, in some dim, unsuspected way, he might have seemed the gliding<br><br>great demon of the seas of life,--all this to explain, would be to<br><br>dive deeper than Ishmael can go.  The subterranean miner that works<br><br>in us all, how can one tell whither leads his shaft by the ever<br><br>shifting, muffled sound of his pick?  Who does not feel the<br><br>irresistible arm drag?  What skiff in tow of a seventy-four can stand<br><br>still?  For one, I gave myself up to the abandonment of the time and<br><br>the place; but while yet all a-rush to encounter the whale, could see<br><br>naught in that brute but the deadliest ill.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 42<br><br><br><br>The Whiteness of The Whale.<br><br><br><br><br><br>What the white whale was to Ahab, has been hinted; what, at times, he<br><br>was to me, as yet remains unsaid.<br><br><br><br>Aside from those more obvious considerations touching Moby Dick,<br><br>which could not but occasionally awaken in any man's soul some alarm,<br><br>there was another thought, or rather vague, nameless horror<br><br>concerning him, which at times by its intensity completely<br><br>overpowered all the rest; and yet so mystical and well nigh ineffable<br><br>was it, that I almost despair of putting it in a comprehensible form.<br><br>It was the whiteness of the whale that above all things appalled me.<br><br>But how can I hope to explain myself here; and yet, in some dim,<br><br>random way, explain myself I must, else all these chapters might be<br><br>naught.<br><br><br><br>Though in many natural objects, whiteness refiningly enhances beauty,<br><br>as if imparting some special virtue of its own, as in marbles,<br><br>japonicas, and pearls; and though various nations have in some way<br><br>recognised a certain royal preeminence in this hue; even the<br><br>barbaric, grand old kings of Pegu placing the title "Lord of the<br><br>White Elephants" above all their other magniloquent ascriptions of<br><br>dominion; and the modern kings of Siam unfurling the same snow-white<br><br>quadruped in the royal standard; and the Hanoverian flag bearing the<br><br>one figure of a snow-white charger; and the great Austrian Empire,<br><br>Caesarian, heir to overlording Rome, having for the imperial colour<br><br>the same imperial hue; and though this pre-eminence in it applies to<br><br>the human race itself, giving the white man ideal mastership over<br><br>every dusky tribe; and though, besides, all this, whiteness has been<br><br>even made significant of gladness, for among the Romans a white stone<br><br>marked a joyful day; and though in other mortal sympathies and<br><br>symbolizings, this same hue is made the emblem of many touching,<br><br>noble things--the innocence of brides, the benignity of age; though<br><br>among the Red Men of America the giving of the white belt of wampum<br><br>was the deepest pledge of honour; though in many climes, whiteness<br><br>typifies the majesty of Justice in the ermine of the Judge, and<br><br>contributes to the daily state of kings and queens drawn by<br><br>milk-white steeds; though even in the higher mysteries of the most<br><br>august religions it has been made the symbol of the divine<br><br>spotlessness and power; by the Persian fire worshippers, the white<br><br>forked flame being held the holiest on the altar; and in the Greek<br><br>mythologies, Great Jove himself being made incarnate in a snow-white<br><br>bull; and though to the noble Iroquois, the midwinter sacrifice of<br><br>the sacred White Dog was by far the holiest festival of their<br><br>theology, that spotless, faithful creature being held the purest<br><br>envoy they could send to the Great Spirit with the annual tidings of<br><br>their own fidelity; and though directly from the Latin word for<br><br>white, all Christian priests derive the name of one part of their<br><br>sacred vesture, the alb or tunic, worn beneath the cassock; and<br><br>though among the holy pomps of the Romish faith, white is specially<br><br>employed in the celebration of the Passion of our Lord; though in the<br><br>Vision of St. John, white robes are given to the redeemed, and the<br><br>four-and-twenty elders stand clothed in white before the great-white<br><br>throne, and the Holy One that sitteth there white like wool; yet for<br><br>all these accumulated associations, with whatever is sweet, and<br><br>honourable, and sublime, there yet lurks an elusive something in the<br><br>innermost idea of this hue, which strikes more of panic to the soul<br><br>than that redness which affrights in blood.<br><br><br><br>This elusive quality it is, which causes the thought of whiteness,<br><br>when divorced from more kindly associations, and coupled with any<br><br>object terrible in itself, to heighten that terror to the furthest<br><br>bounds.  Witness the white bear of the poles, and the white shark of<br><br>the tropics; what but their smooth, flaky whiteness makes them the<br><br>transcendent horrors they are?  That ghastly whiteness it is which<br><br>imparts such an abhorrent mildness, even more loathsome than<br><br>terrific, to the dumb gloating of their aspect.  So that not the<br><br>fierce-fanged tiger in his heraldic coat can so stagger courage as<br><br>the white-shrouded bear or shark.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*With reference to the Polar bear, it may possibly be urged by him<br><br>who would fain go still deeper into this matter, that it is not the<br><br>whiteness, separately regarded, which heightens the intolerable<br><br>hideousness of that brute; for, analysed, that heightened<br><br>hideousness, it might be said, only rises from the circumstance, that<br><br>the irresponsible ferociousness of the creature stands invested in<br><br>the fleece of celestial innocence and love; and hence, by bringing<br><br>together two such opposite emotions in our minds, the Polar bear<br><br>frightens us with so unnatural a contrast.  But even assuming all<br><br>this to be true; yet, were it not for the whiteness, you would not<br><br>have that intensified terror.<br><br><br><br>As for the white shark, the white gliding ghostliness of repose in<br><br>that creature, when beheld in his ordinary moods, strangely tallies<br><br>with the same quality in the Polar quadruped.  This peculiarity is<br><br>most vividly hit by the French in the name they bestow upon that<br><br>fish.  The Romish mass for the dead begins with "Requiem eternam"<br><br>(eternal rest), whence REQUIEM denominating the mass itself, and any<br><br>other funeral music.  Now, in allusion to the white, silent stillness<br><br>of death in this shark, and the mild deadliness of his habits, the<br><br>French call him REQUIN.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Bethink thee of the albatross, whence come those clouds of spiritual<br><br>wonderment and pale dread, in which that white phantom sails in all<br><br>imaginations?  Not Coleridge first threw that spell; but God's great,<br><br>unflattering laureate, Nature.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*I remember the first albatross I ever saw.  It was during a<br><br>prolonged gale, in waters hard upon the Antarctic seas.  From my<br><br>forenoon watch below, I ascended to the overclouded deck; and there,<br><br>dashed upon the main hatches, I saw a regal, feathery thing of<br><br>unspotted whiteness, and with a hooked, Roman bill sublime.  At<br><br>intervals, it arched forth its vast archangel wings, as if to embrace<br><br>some holy ark.  Wondrous flutterings and throbbings shook it.  Though<br><br>bodily unharmed, it uttered cries, as some king's ghost in<br><br>supernatural distress.  Through its inexpressible, strange eyes,<br><br>methought I peeped to secrets which took hold of God.  As Abraham<br><br>before the angels, I bowed myself; the white thing was so white, its<br><br>wings so wide, and in those for ever exiled waters, I had lost the<br><br>miserable warping memories of traditions and of towns.  Long I gazed<br><br>at that prodigy of plumage.  I cannot tell, can only hint, the things<br><br>that darted through me then.  But at last I awoke; and turning, asked<br><br>a sailor what bird was this.  A goney, he replied.  Goney! never had<br><br>heard that name before; is it conceivable that this glorious thing is<br><br>utterly unknown to men ashore! never!  But some time after, I learned<br><br>that goney was some seaman's name for albatross.  So that by no<br><br>possibility could Coleridge's wild Rhyme have had aught to do with<br><br>those mystical impressions which were mine, when I saw that bird upon<br><br>our deck.  For neither had I then read the Rhyme, nor knew the bird<br><br>to be an albatross.  Yet, in saying this, I do but indirectly burnish<br><br>a little brighter the noble merit of the poem and the poet.<br><br><br><br>I assert, then, that in the wondrous bodily whiteness of the bird<br><br>chiefly lurks the secret of the spell; a truth the more evinced in<br><br>this, that by a solecism of terms there are birds called grey<br><br>albatrosses; and these I have frequently seen, but never with such<br><br>emotions as when I beheld the Antarctic fowl.<br><br><br><br>But how had the mystic thing been caught?  Whisper it not, and I will<br><br>tell; with a treacherous hook and line, as the fowl floated on the<br><br>sea.  At last the Captain made a postman of it; tying a lettered,<br><br>leathern tally round its neck, with the ship's time and place; and<br><br>then letting it escape.  But I doubt not, that leathern tally, meant<br><br>for man, was taken off in Heaven, when the white fowl flew to join<br><br>the wing-folding, the invoking, and adoring cherubim!<br><br><br><br><br><br>Most famous in our Western annals and Indian traditions is that of<br><br>the White Steed of the Prairies; a magnificent milk-white charger,<br><br>large-eyed, small-headed, bluff-chested, and with the dignity of a<br><br>thousand monarchs in his lofty, overscorning carriage.  He was the<br><br>elected Xerxes of vast herds of wild horses, whose pastures in those<br><br>days were only fenced by the Rocky Mountains and the Alleghanies.  At<br><br>their flaming head he westward trooped it like that chosen star which<br><br>every evening leads on the hosts of light.  The flashing cascade of<br><br>his mane, the curving comet of his tail, invested him with housings<br><br>more resplendent than gold and silver-beaters could have furnished<br><br>him.  A most imperial and archangelical apparition of that unfallen,<br><br>western world, which to the eyes of the old trappers and hunters<br><br>revived the glories of those primeval times when Adam walked majestic<br><br>as a god, bluff-browed and fearless as this mighty steed.  Whether<br><br>marching amid his aides and marshals in the van of countless cohorts<br><br>that endlessly streamed it over the plains, like an Ohio; or whether<br><br>with his circumambient subjects browsing all around at the horizon,<br><br>the White Steed gallopingly reviewed them with warm nostrils<br><br>reddening through his cool milkiness; in whatever aspect he presented<br><br>himself, always to the bravest Indians he was the object of trembling<br><br>reverence and awe.  Nor can it be questioned from what stands on<br><br>legendary record of this noble horse, that it was his spiritual<br><br>whiteness chiefly, which so clothed him with divineness; and that<br><br>this divineness had that in it which, though commanding worship, at<br><br>the same time enforced a certain nameless terror.<br><br><br><br>But there are other instances where this whiteness loses all that<br><br>accessory and strange glory which invests it in the White Steed and<br><br>Albatross.<br><br><br><br>What is it that in the Albino man so peculiarly repels and often<br><br>shocks the eye, as that sometimes he is loathed by his own kith and<br><br>kin!  It is that whiteness which invests him, a thing expressed by<br><br>the name he bears.  The Albino is as well made as other men--has no<br><br>substantive deformity--and yet this mere aspect of all-pervading<br><br>whiteness makes him more strangely hideous than the ugliest abortion.<br><br>Why should this be so?<br><br><br><br>Nor, in quite other aspects, does Nature in her least palpable but<br><br>not the less malicious agencies, fail to enlist among her forces this<br><br>crowning attribute of the terrible.  From its snowy aspect, the<br><br>gauntleted ghost of the Southern Seas has been denominated the White<br><br>Squall.  Nor, in some historic instances, has the art of human malice<br><br>omitted so potent an auxiliary.  How wildly it heightens the effect<br><br>of that passage in Froissart, when, masked in the snowy symbol of<br><br>their faction, the desperate White Hoods of Ghent murder their<br><br>bailiff in the market-place!<br><br><br><br>Nor, in some things, does the common, hereditary experience of all<br><br>mankind fail to bear witness to the supernaturalism of this hue.  It<br><br>cannot well be doubted, that the one visible quality in the aspect of<br><br>the dead which most appals the gazer, is the marble pallor lingering<br><br>there; as if indeed that pallor were as much like the badge of<br><br>consternation in the other world, as of mortal trepidation here.  And<br><br>from that pallor of the dead, we borrow the expressive hue of the<br><br>shroud in which we wrap them.  Nor even in our superstitions do we<br><br>fail to throw the same snowy mantle round our phantoms; all ghosts<br><br>rising in a milk-white fog--Yea, while these terrors seize us, let us<br><br>add, that even the king of terrors, when personified by the<br><br>evangelist, rides on his pallid horse.<br><br><br><br>Therefore, in his other moods, symbolize whatever grand or gracious<br><br>thing he will by whiteness, no man can deny that in its profoundest<br><br>idealized significance it calls up a peculiar apparition to the soul.<br><br><br><br>But though without dissent this point be fixed, how is mortal man to<br><br>account for it?  To analyse it, would seem impossible.  Can we,<br><br>then, by the citation of some of those instances wherein this thing<br><br>of whiteness--though for the time either wholly or in great part<br><br>stripped of all direct associations calculated to impart to it aught<br><br>fearful, but nevertheless, is found to exert over us the same<br><br>sorcery, however modified;--can we thus hope to light upon some<br><br>chance clue to conduct us to the hidden cause we seek?<br><br><br><br>Let us try.  But in a matter like this, subtlety appeals to subtlety,<br><br>and without imagination no man can follow another into these halls.<br><br>And though, doubtless, some at least of the imaginative impressions<br><br>about to be presented may have been shared by most men, yet few<br><br>perhaps were entirely conscious of them at the time, and therefore<br><br>may not be able to recall them now.<br><br><br><br>Why to the man of untutored ideality, who happens to be but loosely<br><br>acquainted with the peculiar character of the day, does the bare<br><br>mention of Whitsuntide marshal in the fancy such long, dreary,<br><br>speechless processions of slow-pacing pilgrims, down-cast and hooded<br><br>with new-fallen snow?  Or, to the unread, unsophisticated Protestant<br><br>of the Middle American States, why does the passing mention of a<br><br>White Friar or a White Nun, evoke such an eyeless statue in the soul?<br><br><br><br>Or what is there apart from the traditions of dungeoned warriors and<br><br>kings (which will not wholly account for it) that makes the White<br><br>Tower of London tell so much more strongly on the imagination of an<br><br>untravelled American, than those other storied structures, its<br><br>neighbors--the Byward Tower, or even the Bloody?  And those sublimer<br><br>towers, the White Mountains of New Hampshire, whence, in peculiar<br><br>moods, comes that gigantic ghostliness over the soul at the bare<br><br>mention of that name, while the thought of Virginia's Blue Ridge is<br><br>full of a soft, dewy, distant dreaminess?  Or why, irrespective of<br><br>all latitudes and longitudes, does the name of the White Sea exert<br><br>such a spectralness over the fancy, while that of the Yellow Sea<br><br>lulls us with mortal thoughts of long lacquered mild afternoons on<br><br>the waves, followed by the gaudiest and yet sleepiest of sunsets?<br><br>Or, to choose a wholly unsubstantial instance, purely addressed to<br><br>the fancy, why, in reading the old fairy tales of Central Europe,<br><br>does "the tall pale man" of the Hartz forests, whose changeless<br><br>pallor unrustlingly glides through the green of the groves--why is<br><br>this phantom more terrible than all the whooping imps of the<br><br>Blocksburg?<br><br><br><br>Nor is it, altogether, the remembrance of her cathedral-toppling<br><br>earthquakes; nor the stampedoes of her frantic seas; nor the<br><br>tearlessness of arid skies that never rain; nor the sight of her<br><br>wide field of leaning spires, wrenched cope-stones, and crosses all<br><br>adroop (like canted yards of anchored fleets); and her suburban<br><br>avenues of house-walls lying over upon each other, as a tossed pack<br><br>of cards;--it is not these things alone which make tearless Lima, the<br><br>strangest, saddest city thou can'st see.  For Lima has taken the<br><br>white veil; and there is a higher horror in this whiteness of her<br><br>woe.  Old as Pizarro, this whiteness keeps her ruins for ever new;<br><br>admits not the cheerful greenness of complete decay; spreads over her<br><br>broken ramparts the rigid pallor of an apoplexy that fixes its own<br><br>distortions.<br><br><br><br>I know that, to the common apprehension, this phenomenon of whiteness<br><br>is not confessed to be the prime agent in exaggerating the terror of<br><br>objects otherwise terrible; nor to the unimaginative mind is there<br><br>aught of terror in those appearances whose awfulness to another mind<br><br>almost solely consists in this one phenomenon, especially when<br><br>exhibited under any form at all approaching to muteness or<br><br>universality.  What I mean by these two statements may perhaps be<br><br>respectively elucidated by the following examples.<br><br><br><br>First: The mariner, when drawing nigh the coasts of foreign lands, if<br><br>by night he hear the roar of breakers, starts to vigilance, and feels<br><br>just enough of trepidation to sharpen all his faculties; but under<br><br>precisely similar circumstances, let him be called from his hammock<br><br>to view his ship sailing through a midnight sea of milky<br><br>whiteness--as if from encircling headlands shoals of combed white<br><br>bears were swimming round him, then he feels a silent, superstitious<br><br>dread; the shrouded phantom of the whitened waters is horrible to him<br><br>as a real ghost; in vain the lead assures him he is still off<br><br>soundings; heart and helm they both go down; he never rests till blue<br><br>water is under him again.  Yet where is the mariner who will tell<br><br>thee, "Sir, it was not so much the fear of striking hidden rocks, as<br><br>the fear of that hideous whiteness that so stirred me?"<br><br><br><br>Second: To the native Indian of Peru, the continual sight of the<br><br>snowhowdahed Andes conveys naught of dread, except, perhaps, in the<br><br>mere fancying of the eternal frosted desolateness reigning at such<br><br>vast altitudes, and the natural conceit of what a fearfulness it<br><br>would be to lose oneself in such inhuman solitudes.  Much the same is<br><br>it with the backwoodsman of the West, who with comparative<br><br>indifference views an unbounded prairie sheeted with driven snow, no<br><br>shadow of tree or twig to break the fixed trance of whiteness.  Not<br><br>so the sailor, beholding the scenery of the Antarctic seas; where at<br><br>times, by some infernal trick of legerdemain in the powers of frost<br><br>and air, he, shivering and half shipwrecked, instead of rainbows<br><br>speaking hope and solace to his misery, views what seems a boundless<br><br>churchyard grinning upon him with its lean ice monuments and<br><br>splintered crosses.<br><br><br><br>But thou sayest, methinks that white-lead chapter about whiteness is<br><br>but a white flag hung out from a craven soul; thou surrenderest to a<br><br>hypo, Ishmael.<br><br><br><br>Tell me, why this strong young colt, foaled in some peaceful valley<br><br>of Vermont, far removed from all beasts of prey--why is it that upon<br><br>the sunniest day, if you but shake a fresh buffalo robe behind him,<br><br>so that he cannot even see it, but only smells its wild animal<br><br>muskiness--why will he start, snort, and with bursting eyes paw the<br><br>ground in phrensies of affright?  There is no remembrance in him of<br><br>any gorings of wild creatures in his green northern home, so that the<br><br>strange muskiness he smells cannot recall to him anything associated<br><br>with the experience of former perils; for what knows he, this New<br><br>England colt, of the black bisons of distant Oregon?<br><br><br><br>No; but here thou beholdest even in a dumb brute, the instinct of the<br><br>knowledge of the demonism in the world.  Though thousands of miles<br><br>from Oregon, still when he smells that savage musk, the rending,<br><br>goring bison herds are as present as to the deserted wild foal of the<br><br>prairies, which this instant they may be trampling into dust.<br><br><br><br>Thus, then, the muffled rollings of a milky sea; the bleak rustlings<br><br>of the festooned frosts of mountains; the desolate shiftings of the<br><br>windrowed snows of prairies; all these, to Ishmael, are as the<br><br>shaking of that buffalo robe to the frightened colt!<br><br><br><br>Though neither knows where lie the nameless things of which the<br><br>mystic sign gives forth such hints; yet with me, as with the colt,<br><br>somewhere those things must exist.  Though in many of its aspects<br><br>this visible world seems formed in love, the invisible spheres were<br><br>formed in fright.<br><br><br><br>But not yet have we solved the incantation of this whiteness, and<br><br>learned why it appeals with such power to the soul; and more strange<br><br>and far more portentous--why, as we have seen, it is at once the most<br><br>meaning symbol of spiritual things, nay, the very veil of the<br><br>Christian's Deity; and yet should be as it is, the intensifying agent<br><br>in things the most appalling to mankind.<br><br><br><br>Is it that by its indefiniteness it shadows forth the heartless voids<br><br>and immensities of the universe, and thus stabs us from behind with<br><br>the thought of annihilation, when beholding the white depths of the<br><br>milky way?  Or is it, that as in essence whiteness is not so much a<br><br>colour as the visible absence of colour; and at the same time the<br><br>concrete of all colours; is it for these reasons that there is such a<br><br>dumb blankness, full of meaning, in a wide landscape of snows--a<br><br>colourless, all-colour of atheism from which we shrink?  And when we<br><br>consider that other theory of the natural philosophers, that all<br><br>other earthly hues--every stately or lovely emblazoning--the sweet<br><br>tinges of sunset skies and woods; yea, and the gilded velvets of<br><br>butterflies, and the butterfly cheeks of young girls; all these are<br><br>but subtile deceits, not actually inherent in substances, but only<br><br>laid on from without; so that all deified Nature absolutely paints<br><br>like the harlot, whose allurements cover nothing but the<br><br>charnel-house within; and when we proceed further, and consider that<br><br>the mystical cosmetic which produces every one of her hues, the great<br><br>principle of light, for ever remains white or colourless in itself,<br><br>and if operating without medium upon matter, would touch all objects,<br><br>even tulips and roses, with its own blank tinge--pondering all this,<br><br>the palsied universe lies before us a leper; and like wilful<br><br>travellers in Lapland, who refuse to wear coloured and colouring<br><br>glasses upon their eyes, so the wretched infidel gazes himself blind<br><br>at the monumental white shroud that wraps all the prospect around<br><br>him.  And of all these things the Albino whale was the symbol.<br><br>Wonder ye then at the fiery hunt?<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 43<br><br><br><br>Hark!<br><br><br><br><br><br>"HIST!  Did you hear that noise, Cabaco?<br><br><br><br>It was the middle-watch; a fair moonlight; the seamen were standing<br><br>in a cordon, extending from one of the fresh-water butts in the<br><br>waist, to the scuttle-butt near the taffrail.  In this manner, they<br><br>passed the buckets to fill the scuttle-butt.  Standing, for the most<br><br>part, on the hallowed precincts of the quarter-deck, they were<br><br>careful not to speak or rustle their feet.  From hand to hand, the<br><br>buckets went in the deepest silence, only broken by the occasional<br><br>flap of a sail, and the steady hum of the unceasingly advancing keel.<br><br><br><br>It was in the midst of this repose, that Archy, one of the cordon,<br><br>whose post was near the after-hatches, whispered to his neighbor, a<br><br>Cholo, the words above.<br><br><br><br>"Hist! did you hear that noise, Cabaco?"<br><br><br><br>"Take the bucket, will ye, Archy? what noise d'ye mean?"<br><br><br><br>"There it is again--under the hatches--don't you hear it--a cough--it<br><br>sounded like a cough."<br><br><br><br>"Cough be damned!  Pass along that return bucket."<br><br><br><br>"There again--there it is!--it sounds like two or three sleepers<br><br>turning over, now!"<br><br><br><br>"Caramba! have done, shipmate, will ye?  It's the three soaked<br><br>biscuits ye eat for supper turning over inside of ye--nothing else.<br><br>Look to the bucket!"<br><br><br><br>"Say what ye will, shipmate; I've sharp ears."<br><br><br><br>"Aye, you are the chap, ain't ye, that heard the hum of the old<br><br>Quakeress's knitting-needles fifty miles at sea from Nantucket;<br><br>you're the chap."<br><br><br><br>"Grin away; we'll see what turns up.  Hark ye, Cabaco, there is<br><br>somebody down in the after-hold that has not yet been seen on deck;<br><br>and I suspect our old Mogul knows something of it too.  I heard Stubb<br><br>tell Flask, one morning watch, that there was something of that sort<br><br>in the wind."<br><br><br><br>"Tish! the bucket!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 44<br><br><br><br>The Chart.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Had you followed Captain Ahab down into his cabin after the squall<br><br>that took place on the night succeeding that wild ratification of his<br><br>purpose with his crew, you would have seen him go to a locker in the<br><br>transom, and bringing out a large wrinkled roll of yellowish sea<br><br>charts, spread them before him on his screwed-down table.  Then<br><br>seating himself before it, you would have seen him intently study the<br><br>various lines and shadings which there met his eye; and with slow but<br><br>steady pencil trace additional courses over spaces that before were<br><br>blank.  At intervals, he would refer to piles of old log-books beside<br><br>him, wherein were set down the seasons and places in which, on<br><br>various former voyages of various ships, sperm whales had been<br><br>captured or seen.<br><br><br><br>While thus employed, the heavy pewter lamp suspended in chains over<br><br>his head, continually rocked with the motion of the ship, and for<br><br>ever threw shifting gleams and shadows of lines upon his wrinkled<br><br>brow, till it almost seemed that while he himself was marking out<br><br>lines and courses on the wrinkled charts, some invisible pencil was<br><br>also tracing lines and courses upon the deeply marked chart of his<br><br>forehead.<br><br><br><br>But it was not this night in particular that, in the solitude of his<br><br>cabin, Ahab thus pondered over his charts.  Almost every night they<br><br>were brought out; almost every night some pencil marks were effaced,<br><br>and others were substituted.  For with the charts of all four oceans<br><br>before him, Ahab was threading a maze of currents and eddies, with a<br><br>view to the more certain accomplishment of that monomaniac thought of<br><br>his soul.<br><br><br><br>Now, to any one not fully acquainted with the ways of the leviathans,<br><br>it might seem an absurdly hopeless task thus to seek out one solitary<br><br>creature in the unhooped oceans of this planet.  But not so did it<br><br>seem to Ahab, who knew the sets of all tides and currents; and<br><br>thereby calculating the driftings of the sperm whale's food; and,<br><br>also, calling to mind the regular, ascertained seasons for hunting<br><br>him in particular latitudes; could arrive at reasonable surmises,<br><br>almost approaching to certainties, concerning the timeliest day to be<br><br>upon this or that ground in search of his prey.<br><br><br><br>So assured, indeed, is the fact concerning the periodicalness of the<br><br>sperm whale's resorting to given waters, that many hunters believe<br><br>that, could he be closely observed and studied throughout the world;<br><br>were the logs for one voyage of the entire whale fleet carefully<br><br>collated, then the migrations of the sperm whale would be found to<br><br>correspond in invariability to those of the herring-shoals or the<br><br>flights of swallows.  On this hint, attempts have been made to<br><br>construct elaborate migratory charts of the sperm whale.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*Since the above was written, the statement is happily borne out by<br><br>an official circular, issued by Lieutenant Maury, of the National<br><br>Observatory, Washington, April 16th, 1851.  By that circular, it<br><br>appears that precisely such a chart is in course of completion; and<br><br>portions of it are presented in the circular.  "This chart divides<br><br>the ocean into districts of five degrees of latitude by five degrees<br><br>of longitude; perpendicularly through each of which districts are<br><br>twelve columns for the twelve months; and horizontally through each<br><br>of which districts are three lines; one to show the number of days<br><br>that have been spent in each month in every district, and the two<br><br>others to show the number of days in which whales, sperm or right,<br><br>have been seen."<br><br><br><br><br><br>Besides, when making a passage from one feeding-ground to another,<br><br>the sperm whales, guided by some infallible instinct--say, rather,<br><br>secret intelligence from the Deity--mostly swim in VEINS, as they are<br><br>called; continuing their way along a given ocean-line with such<br><br>undeviating exactitude, that no ship ever sailed her course, by any<br><br>chart, with one tithe of such marvellous precision.  Though, in these<br><br>cases, the direction taken by any one whale be straight as a<br><br>surveyor's parallel, and though the line of advance be strictly<br><br>confined to its own unavoidable, straight wake, yet the arbitrary<br><br>VEIN in which at these times he is said to swim, generally embraces<br><br>some few miles in width (more or less, as the vein is presumed to<br><br>expand or contract); but never exceeds the visual sweep from the<br><br>whale-ship's mast-heads, when circumspectly gliding along this magic<br><br>zone.  The sum is, that at particular seasons within that breadth and<br><br>along that path, migrating whales may with great confidence be looked<br><br>for.<br><br><br><br>And hence not only at substantiated times, upon well known separate<br><br>feeding-grounds, could Ahab hope to encounter his prey; but in<br><br>crossing the widest expanses of water between those grounds he could,<br><br>by his art, so place and time himself on his way, as even then not to<br><br>be wholly without prospect of a meeting.<br><br><br><br>There was a circumstance which at first sight seemed to entangle his<br><br>delirious but still methodical scheme.  But not so in the reality,<br><br>perhaps.  Though the gregarious sperm whales have their regular<br><br>seasons for particular grounds, yet in general you cannot conclude<br><br>that the herds which haunted such and such a latitude or longitude<br><br>this year, say, will turn out to be identically the same with those<br><br>that were found there the preceding season; though there are peculiar<br><br>and unquestionable instances where the contrary of this has proved<br><br>true.  In general, the same remark, only within a less wide limit,<br><br>applies to the solitaries and hermits among the matured, aged sperm<br><br>whales.  So that though Moby Dick had in a former year been seen, for<br><br>example, on what is called the Seychelle ground in the Indian ocean,<br><br>or Volcano Bay on the Japanese Coast; yet it did not follow, that<br><br>were the Pequod to visit either of those spots at any subsequent<br><br>corresponding season, she would infallibly encounter him there.  So,<br><br>too, with some other feeding grounds, where he had at times revealed<br><br>himself.  But all these seemed only his casual stopping-places and<br><br>ocean-inns, so to speak, not his places of prolonged abode.  And<br><br>where Ahab's chances of accomplishing his object have hitherto been<br><br>spoken of, allusion has only been made to whatever way-side,<br><br>antecedent, extra prospects were his, ere a particular set time or<br><br>place were attained, when all possibilities would become<br><br>probabilities, and, as Ahab fondly thought, every possibility the<br><br>next thing to a certainty.  That particular set time and place were<br><br>conjoined in the one technical phrase--the Season-on-the-Line.  For<br><br>there and then, for several consecutive years, Moby Dick had been<br><br>periodically descried, lingering in those waters for awhile, as the<br><br>sun, in its annual round, loiters for a predicted interval in any one<br><br>sign of the Zodiac.  There it was, too, that most of the deadly<br><br>encounters with the white whale had taken place; there the waves were<br><br>storied with his deeds; there also was that tragic spot where the<br><br>monomaniac old man had found the awful motive to his vengeance.  But<br><br>in the cautious comprehensiveness and unloitering vigilance with<br><br>which Ahab threw his brooding soul into this unfaltering hunt, he<br><br>would not permit himself to rest all his hopes upon the one crowning<br><br>fact above mentioned, however flattering it might be to those hopes;<br><br>nor in the sleeplessness of his vow could he so tranquillize his<br><br>unquiet heart as to postpone all intervening quest.<br><br><br><br>Now, the Pequod had sailed from Nantucket at the very beginning of<br><br>the Season-on-the-Line.  No possible endeavor then could enable her<br><br>commander to make the great passage southwards, double Cape Horn, and<br><br>then running down sixty degrees of latitude arrive in the equatorial<br><br>Pacific in time to cruise there.  Therefore, he must wait for the<br><br>next ensuing season.  Yet the premature hour of the Pequod's sailing<br><br>had, perhaps, been correctly selected by Ahab, with a view to this<br><br>very complexion of things.  Because, an interval of three hundred and<br><br>sixty-five days and nights was before him; an interval which, instead<br><br>of impatiently enduring ashore, he would spend in a miscellaneous<br><br>hunt; if by chance the White Whale, spending his vacation in seas far<br><br>remote from his periodical feeding-grounds, should turn up his<br><br>wrinkled brow off the Persian Gulf, or in the Bengal Bay, or China<br><br>Seas, or in any other waters haunted by his race.  So that Monsoons,<br><br>Pampas, Nor'-Westers, Harmattans, Trades; any wind but the Levanter<br><br>and Simoon, might blow Moby Dick into the devious zig-zag<br><br>world-circle of the Pequod's circumnavigating wake.<br><br><br><br>But granting all this; yet, regarded discreetly and coolly, seems it<br><br>not but a mad idea, this; that in the broad boundless ocean, one<br><br>solitary whale, even if encountered, should be thought capable of<br><br>individual recognition from his hunter, even as a white-bearded Mufti<br><br>in the thronged thoroughfares of Constantinople?  Yes.  For the<br><br>peculiar snow-white brow of Moby Dick, and his snow-white hump, could<br><br>not but be unmistakable.  And have I not tallied the whale, Ahab<br><br>would mutter to himself, as after poring over his charts till long<br><br>after midnight he would throw himself back in reveries--tallied him,<br><br>and shall he escape?  His broad fins are bored, and scalloped out<br><br>like a lost sheep's ear!  And here, his mad mind would run on in a<br><br>breathless race; till a weariness and faintness of pondering came<br><br>over him; and in the open air of the deck he would seek to recover<br><br>his strength.  Ah, God! what trances of torments does that man endure<br><br>who is consumed with one unachieved revengeful desire.  He sleeps<br><br>with clenched hands; and wakes with his own bloody nails in his<br><br>palms.<br><br><br><br>Often, when forced from his hammock by exhausting and intolerably<br><br>vivid dreams of the night, which, resuming his own intense thoughts<br><br>through the day, carried them on amid a clashing of phrensies, and<br><br>whirled them round and round and round in his blazing brain, till<br><br>the very throbbing of his life-spot became insufferable anguish; and<br><br>when, as was sometimes the case, these spiritual throes in him heaved<br><br>his being up from its base, and a chasm seemed opening in him, from<br><br>which forked flames and lightnings shot up, and accursed fiends<br><br>beckoned him to leap down among them; when this hell in himself<br><br>yawned beneath him, a wild cry would be heard through the ship; and<br><br>with glaring eyes Ahab would burst from his state room, as though<br><br>escaping from a bed that was on fire.  Yet these, perhaps, instead of<br><br>being the unsuppressable symptoms of some latent weakness, or fright<br><br>at his own resolve, were but the plainest tokens of its intensity.<br><br>For, at such times, crazy Ahab, the scheming, unappeasedly steadfast<br><br>hunter of the white whale; this Ahab that had gone to his hammock,<br><br>was not the agent that so caused him to burst from it in horror<br><br>again.  The latter was the eternal, living principle or soul in him;<br><br>and in sleep, being for the time dissociated from the characterizing<br><br>mind, which at other times employed it for its outer vehicle or<br><br>agent, it spontaneously sought escape from the scorching contiguity<br><br>of the frantic thing, of which, for the time, it was no longer an<br><br>integral.  But as the mind does not exist unless leagued with the<br><br>soul, therefore it must have been that, in Ahab's case, yielding up<br><br>all his thoughts and fancies to his one supreme purpose; that<br><br>purpose, by its own sheer inveteracy of will, forced itself against<br><br>gods and devils into a kind of self-assumed, independent being of its<br><br>own.  Nay, could grimly live and burn, while the common vitality to<br><br>which it was conjoined, fled horror-stricken from the unbidden and<br><br>unfathered birth.  Therefore, the tormented spirit that glared out of<br><br>bodily eyes, when what seemed Ahab rushed from his room, was for the<br><br>time but a vacated thing, a formless somnambulistic being, a ray of<br><br>living light, to be sure, but without an object to colour, and<br><br>therefore a blankness in itself.  God help thee, old man, thy<br><br>thoughts have created a creature in thee; and he whose intense<br><br>thinking thus makes him a Prometheus; a vulture feeds upon that heart<br><br>for ever; that vulture the very creature he creates.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 45<br><br><br><br>The Affidavit.<br><br><br><br><br><br>So far as what there may be of a narrative in this book; and, indeed,<br><br>as indirectly touching one or two very interesting and curious<br><br>particulars in the habits of sperm whales, the foregoing chapter, in<br><br>its earlier part, is as important a one as will be found in this<br><br>volume; but the leading matter of it requires to be still further and<br><br>more familiarly enlarged upon, in order to be adequately understood,<br><br>and moreover to take away any incredulity which a profound ignorance<br><br>of the entire subject may induce in some minds, as to the natural<br><br>verity of the main points of this affair.<br><br><br><br>I care not to perform this part of my task methodically; but shall be<br><br>content to produce the desired impression by separate citations of<br><br>items, practically or reliably known to me as a whaleman; and from<br><br>these citations, I take it--the conclusion aimed at will naturally<br><br>follow of itself.<br><br><br><br>First: I have personally known three instances where a whale, after<br><br>receiving a harpoon, has effected a complete escape; and, after an<br><br>interval (in one instance of three years), has been again struck by<br><br>the same hand, and slain; when the two irons, both marked by the same<br><br>private cypher, have been taken from the body.  In the instance where<br><br>three years intervened between the flinging of the two harpoons; and<br><br>I think it may have been something more than that; the man who darted<br><br>them happening, in the interval, to go in a trading ship on a voyage<br><br>to Africa, went ashore there, joined a discovery party, and<br><br>penetrated far into the interior, where he travelled for a period of<br><br>nearly two years, often endangered by serpents, savages, tigers,<br><br>poisonous miasmas, with all the other common perils incident to<br><br>wandering in the heart of unknown regions.  Meanwhile, the whale he<br><br>had struck must also have been on its travels; no doubt it had thrice<br><br>circumnavigated the globe, brushing with its flanks all the coasts of<br><br>Africa; but to no purpose.  This man and this whale again came<br><br>together, and the one vanquished the other.  I say I, myself, have<br><br>known three instances similar to this; that is in two of them I saw<br><br>the whales struck; and, upon the second attack, saw the two irons<br><br>with the respective marks cut in them, afterwards taken from the dead<br><br>fish.  In the three-year instance, it so fell out that I was in the<br><br>boat both times, first and last, and the last time distinctly<br><br>recognised a peculiar sort of huge mole under the whale's eye, which<br><br>I had observed there three years previous.  I say three years, but I<br><br>am pretty sure it was more than that.  Here are three instances,<br><br>then, which I personally know the truth of; but I have heard of many<br><br>other instances from persons whose veracity in the matter there is no<br><br>good ground to impeach.<br><br><br><br>Secondly: It is well known in the Sperm Whale Fishery, however<br><br>ignorant the world ashore may be of it, that there have been several<br><br>memorable historical instances where a particular whale in the ocean<br><br>has been at distant times and places popularly cognisable.  Why such<br><br>a whale became thus marked was not altogether and originally owing to<br><br>his bodily peculiarities as distinguished from other whales; for<br><br>however peculiar in that respect any chance whale may be, they soon<br><br>put an end to his peculiarities by killing him, and boiling him down<br><br>into a peculiarly valuable oil.  No: the reason was this: that from<br><br>the fatal experiences of the fishery there hung a terrible prestige<br><br>of perilousness about such a whale as there did about Rinaldo<br><br>Rinaldini, insomuch that most fishermen were content to recognise him<br><br>by merely touching their tarpaulins when he would be discovered<br><br>lounging by them on the sea, without seeking to cultivate a more<br><br>intimate acquaintance.  Like some poor devils ashore that happen to<br><br>know an irascible great man, they make distant unobtrusive<br><br>salutations to him in the street, lest if they pursued the<br><br>acquaintance further, they might receive a summary thump for their<br><br>presumption.<br><br><br><br>But not only did each of these famous whales enjoy great individual<br><br>celebrity--Nay, you may call it an ocean-wide renown; not only was he<br><br>famous in life and now is immortal in forecastle stories after death,<br><br>but he was admitted into all the rights, privileges, and distinctions<br><br>of a name; had as much a name indeed as Cambyses or Caesar.  Was it<br><br>not so, O Timor Tom! thou famed leviathan, scarred like an iceberg,<br><br>who so long did'st lurk in the Oriental straits of that name, whose<br><br>spout was oft seen from the palmy beach of Ombay?  Was it not so, O<br><br>New Zealand Jack! thou terror of all cruisers that crossed their<br><br>wakes in the vicinity of the Tattoo Land?  Was it not so, O Morquan!<br><br>King of Japan, whose lofty jet they say at times assumed the<br><br>semblance of a snow-white cross against the sky?  Was it not so, O<br><br>Don Miguel! thou Chilian whale, marked like an old tortoise with<br><br>mystic hieroglyphics upon the back!  In plain prose, here are four<br><br>whales as well known to the students of Cetacean History as Marius or<br><br>Sylla to the classic scholar.<br><br><br><br>But this is not all.  New Zealand Tom and Don Miguel, after at<br><br>various times creating great havoc among the boats of different<br><br>vessels, were finally gone in quest of, systematically hunted out,<br><br>chased and killed by valiant whaling captains, who heaved up their<br><br>anchors with that express object as much in view, as in setting out<br><br>through the Narragansett Woods, Captain Butler of old had it in his<br><br>mind to capture that notorious murderous savage Annawon, the headmost<br><br>warrior of the Indian King Philip.<br><br><br><br>I do not know where I can find a better place than just here, to make<br><br>mention of one or two other things, which to me seem important, as in<br><br>printed form establishing in all respects the reasonableness of the<br><br>whole story of the White Whale, more especially the catastrophe.  For<br><br>this is one of those disheartening instances where truth requires<br><br>full as much bolstering as error.  So ignorant are most landsmen of<br><br>some of the plainest and most palpable wonders of the world, that<br><br>without some hints touching the plain facts, historical and<br><br>otherwise, of the fishery, they might scout at Moby Dick as a<br><br>monstrous fable, or still worse and more detestable, a hideous and<br><br>intolerable allegory.<br><br><br><br>First: Though most men have some vague flitting ideas of the general<br><br>perils of the grand fishery, yet they have nothing like a fixed,<br><br>vivid conception of those perils, and the frequency with which they<br><br>recur.  One reason perhaps is, that not one in fifty of the actual<br><br>disasters and deaths by casualties in the fishery, ever finds a<br><br>public record at home, however transient and immediately forgotten<br><br>that record.  Do you suppose that that poor fellow there, who this<br><br>moment perhaps caught by the whale-line off the coast of New Guinea,<br><br>is being carried down to the bottom of the sea by the sounding<br><br>leviathan--do you suppose that that poor fellow's name will appear in<br><br>the newspaper obituary you will read to-morrow at your breakfast?<br><br>No: because the mails are very irregular between here and New Guinea.<br><br>In fact, did you ever hear what might be called regular news direct<br><br>or indirect from New Guinea?  Yet I tell you that upon one particular<br><br>voyage which I made to the Pacific, among many others we spoke thirty<br><br>different ships, every one of which had had a death by a whale, some<br><br>of them more than one, and three that had each lost a boat's crew.<br><br>For God's sake, be economical with your lamps and candles! not a<br><br>gallon you burn, but at least one drop of man's blood was spilled for<br><br>it.<br><br><br><br>Secondly: People ashore have indeed some indefinite idea that a whale<br><br>is an enormous creature of enormous power; but I have ever found that<br><br>when narrating to them some specific example of this two-fold<br><br>enormousness, they have significantly complimented me upon my<br><br>facetiousness; when, I declare upon my soul, I had no more idea of<br><br>being facetious than Moses, when he wrote the history of the plagues<br><br>of Egypt.<br><br><br><br>But fortunately the special point I here seek can be established upon<br><br>testimony entirely independent of my own.  That point is this: The<br><br>Sperm Whale is in some cases sufficiently powerful, knowing, and<br><br>judiciously malicious, as with direct aforethought to stave in,<br><br>utterly destroy, and sink a large ship; and what is more, the Sperm<br><br>Whale HAS done it.<br><br><br><br>First: In the year 1820 the ship Essex, Captain Pollard, of<br><br>Nantucket, was cruising in the Pacific Ocean.  One day she saw<br><br>spouts, lowered her boats, and gave chase to a shoal of sperm whales.<br><br>Ere long, several of the whales were wounded; when, suddenly, a very<br><br>large whale escaping from the boats, issued from the shoal, and bore<br><br>directly down upon the ship.  Dashing his forehead against her hull,<br><br>he so stove her in, that in less than "ten minutes" she settled down<br><br>and fell over.  Not a surviving plank of her has been seen since.<br><br>After the severest exposure, part of the crew reached the land in<br><br>their boats.  Being returned home at last, Captain Pollard once more<br><br>sailed for the Pacific in command of another ship, but the gods<br><br>shipwrecked him again upon unknown rocks and breakers; for the second<br><br>time his ship was utterly lost, and forthwith forswearing the sea, he<br><br>has never tempted it since.  At this day Captain Pollard is a<br><br>resident of Nantucket.  I have seen Owen Chace, who was chief mate of<br><br>the Essex at the time of the tragedy; I have read his plain and<br><br>faithful narrative; I have conversed with his son; and all this<br><br>within a few miles of the scene of the catastrophe.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*The following are extracts from Chace's narrative: "Every fact<br><br>seemed to warrant me in concluding that it was anything but chance<br><br>which directed his operations; he made two several attacks upon the<br><br>ship, at a short interval between them, both of which, according to<br><br>their direction, were calculated to do us the most injury, by being<br><br>made ahead, and thereby combining the speed of the two objects for<br><br>the shock; to effect which, the exact manoeuvres which he made were<br><br>necessary.  His aspect was most horrible, and such as indicated<br><br>resentment and fury.  He came directly from the shoal which we had<br><br>just before entered, and in which we had struck three of his<br><br>companions, as if fired with revenge for their sufferings."  Again:<br><br>"At all events, the whole circumstances taken together, all happening<br><br>before my own eyes, and producing, at the time, impressions in my<br><br>mind of decided, calculating mischief, on the part of the whale (many<br><br>of which impressions I cannot now recall), induce me to be satisfied<br><br>that I am correct in my opinion."<br><br><br><br>Here are his reflections some time after quitting the ship, during a<br><br>black night an open boat, when almost despairing of reaching any<br><br>hospitable shore.  "The dark ocean and swelling waters were nothing;<br><br>the fears of being swallowed up by some dreadful tempest, or dashed<br><br>upon hidden rocks, with all the other ordinary subjects of fearful<br><br>contemplation, seemed scarcely entitled to a moment's thought; the<br><br>dismal looking wreck, and THE HORRID ASPECT AND REVENGE OF THE WHALE,<br><br>wholly engrossed my reflections, until day again made its<br><br>appearance."<br><br><br><br>In another place--p. 45,--he speaks of "THE MYSTERIOUS AND MORTAL<br><br>ATTACK OF THE ANIMAL."<br><br><br><br><br><br>Secondly: The ship Union, also of Nantucket, was in the year 1807<br><br>totally lost off the Azores by a similar onset, but the authentic<br><br>particulars of this catastrophe I have never chanced to encounter,<br><br>though from the whale hunters I have now and then heard casual<br><br>allusions to it.<br><br><br><br>Thirdly: Some eighteen or twenty years ago Commodore J---, then<br><br>commanding an American sloop-of-war of the first class, happened to<br><br>be dining with a party of whaling captains, on board a Nantucket ship<br><br>in the harbor of Oahu, Sandwich Islands.  Conversation turning upon<br><br>whales, the Commodore was pleased to be sceptical touching the<br><br>amazing strength ascribed to them by the professional gentlemen<br><br>present.  He peremptorily denied for example, that any whale could so<br><br>smite his stout sloop-of-war as to cause her to leak so much as a<br><br>thimbleful.  Very good; but there is more coming.  Some weeks after,<br><br>the Commodore set sail in this impregnable craft for Valparaiso.  But<br><br>he was stopped on the way by a portly sperm whale, that begged a few<br><br>moments' confidential business with him.  That business consisted in<br><br>fetching the Commodore's craft such a thwack, that with all his pumps<br><br>going he made straight for the nearest port to heave down and repair.<br><br>I am not superstitious, but I consider the Commodore's interview<br><br>with that whale as providential.  Was not Saul of Tarsus converted<br><br>from unbelief by a similar fright?  I tell you, the sperm whale will<br><br>stand no nonsense.<br><br><br><br>I will now refer you to Langsdorff's Voyages for a little<br><br>circumstance in point, peculiarly interesting to the writer hereof.<br><br>Langsdorff, you must know by the way, was attached to the Russian<br><br>Admiral Krusenstern's famous Discovery Expedition in the beginning of<br><br>the present century.  Captain Langsdorff thus begins his seventeenth<br><br>chapter:<br><br><br><br>"By the thirteenth of May our ship was ready to sail, and the next<br><br>day we were out in the open sea, on our way to Ochotsh.  The weather<br><br>was very clear and fine, but so intolerably cold that we were obliged<br><br>to keep on our fur clothing.  For some days we had very little wind;<br><br>it was not till the nineteenth that a brisk gale from the northwest<br><br>sprang up.  An uncommon large whale, the body of which was larger<br><br>than the ship itself, lay almost at the surface of the water, but was<br><br>not perceived by any one on board till the moment when the ship,<br><br>which was in full sail, was almost upon him, so that it was<br><br>impossible to prevent its striking against him.  We were thus placed<br><br>in the most imminent danger, as this gigantic creature, setting up<br><br>its back, raised the ship three feet at least out of the water.  The<br><br>masts reeled, and the sails fell altogether, while we who were below<br><br>all sprang instantly upon the deck, concluding that we had struck<br><br>upon some rock; instead of this we saw the monster sailing off with<br><br>the utmost gravity and solemnity.  Captain D'Wolf applied immediately<br><br>to the pumps to examine whether or not the vessel had received any<br><br>damage from the shock, but we found that very happily it had escaped<br><br>entirely uninjured."<br><br><br><br>Now, the Captain D'Wolf here alluded to as commanding the ship in<br><br>question, is a New Englander, who, after a long life of unusual<br><br>adventures as a sea-captain, this day resides in the village of<br><br>Dorchester near Boston.  I have the honour of being a nephew of his.<br><br>I have particularly questioned him concerning this passage in<br><br>Langsdorff.  He substantiates every word.  The ship, however, was by<br><br>no means a large one: a Russian craft built on the Siberian coast,<br><br>and purchased by my uncle after bartering away the vessel in which he<br><br>sailed from home.<br><br><br><br>In that up and down manly book of old-fashioned adventure, so full,<br><br>too, of honest wonders--the voyage of Lionel Wafer, one of ancient<br><br>Dampier's old chums--I found a little matter set down so like that<br><br>just quoted from Langsdorff, that I cannot forbear inserting it here<br><br>for a corroborative example, if such be needed.<br><br><br><br>Lionel, it seems, was on his way to "John Ferdinando," as he calls<br><br>the modern Juan Fernandes.  "In our way thither," he says, "about<br><br>four o'clock in the morning, when we were about one hundred and fifty<br><br>leagues from the Main of America, our ship felt a terrible shock,<br><br>which put our men in such consternation that they could hardly tell<br><br>where they were or what to think; but every one began to prepare for<br><br>death.  And, indeed, the shock was so sudden and violent, that we<br><br>took it for granted the ship had struck against a rock; but when the<br><br>amazement was a little over, we cast the lead, and sounded, but found<br><br>no ground.  ....  The suddenness of the shock made the guns leap in<br><br>their carriages, and several of the men were shaken out of their<br><br>hammocks.  Captain Davis, who lay with his head on a gun, was thrown<br><br>out of his cabin!"  Lionel then goes on to impute the shock to an<br><br>earthquake, and seems to substantiate the imputation by stating that<br><br>a great earthquake, somewhere about that time, did actually do great<br><br>mischief along the Spanish land.  But I should not much wonder if, in<br><br>the darkness of that early hour of the morning, the shock was after<br><br>all caused by an unseen whale vertically bumping the hull from<br><br>beneath.<br><br><br><br>I might proceed with several more examples, one way or another known<br><br>to me, of the great power and malice at times of the sperm whale.  In<br><br>more than one instance, he has been known, not only to chase the<br><br>assailing boats back to their ships, but to pursue the ship itself,<br><br>and long withstand all the lances hurled at him from its decks.  The<br><br>English ship Pusie Hall can tell a story on that head; and, as for<br><br>his strength, let me say, that there have been examples where the<br><br>lines attached to a running sperm whale have, in a calm, been<br><br>transferred to the ship, and secured there; the whale towing her<br><br>great hull through the water, as a horse walks off with a cart.<br><br>Again, it is very often observed that, if the sperm whale, once<br><br>struck, is allowed time to rally, he then acts, not so often with<br><br>blind rage, as with wilful, deliberate designs of destruction to his<br><br>pursuers; nor is it without conveying some eloquent indication of his<br><br>character, that upon being attacked he will frequently open his<br><br>mouth, and retain it in that dread expansion for several consecutive<br><br>minutes.  But I must be content with only one more and a concluding<br><br>illustration; a remarkable and most significant one, by which you<br><br>will not fail to see, that not only is the most marvellous event in<br><br>this book corroborated by plain facts of the present day, but that<br><br>these marvels (like all marvels) are mere repetitions of the ages; so<br><br>that for the millionth time we say amen with Solomon--Verily there is<br><br>nothing new under the sun.<br><br><br><br>In the sixth Christian century lived Procopius, a Christian<br><br>magistrate of Constantinople, in the days when Justinian was Emperor<br><br>and Belisarius general.  As many know, he wrote the history of his<br><br>own times, a work every way of uncommon value.  By the best<br><br>authorities, he has always been considered a most trustworthy and<br><br>unexaggerating historian, except in some one or two particulars, not<br><br>at all affecting the matter presently to be mentioned.<br><br><br><br>Now, in this history of his, Procopius mentions that, during the term<br><br>of his prefecture at Constantinople, a great sea-monster was captured<br><br>in the neighboring Propontis, or Sea of Marmora, after having<br><br>destroyed vessels at intervals in those waters for a period of more<br><br>than fifty years.  A fact thus set down in substantial history cannot<br><br>easily be gainsaid.  Nor is there any reason it should be.  Of what<br><br>precise species this sea-monster was, is not mentioned.  But as he<br><br>destroyed ships, as well as for other reasons, he must have been a<br><br>whale; and I am strongly inclined to think a sperm whale.  And I will<br><br>tell you why.  For a long time I fancied that the sperm whale had<br><br>been always unknown in the Mediterranean and the deep waters<br><br>connecting with it.  Even now I am certain that those seas are not,<br><br>and perhaps never can be, in the present constitution of things, a<br><br>place for his habitual gregarious resort.  But further investigations<br><br>have recently proved to me, that in modern times there have been<br><br>isolated instances of the presence of the sperm whale in the<br><br>Mediterranean.  I am told, on good authority, that on the Barbary<br><br>coast, a Commodore Davis of the British navy found the skeleton of a<br><br>sperm whale.  Now, as a vessel of war readily passes through the<br><br>Dardanelles, hence a sperm whale could, by the same route, pass out<br><br>of the Mediterranean into the Propontis.<br><br><br><br>In the Propontis, as far as I can learn, none of that peculiar<br><br>substance called BRIT is to be found, the aliment of the right whale.<br><br>But I have every reason to believe that the food of the sperm<br><br>whale--squid or cuttle-fish--lurks at the bottom of that sea, because<br><br>large creatures, but by no means the largest of that sort, have been<br><br>found at its surface.  If, then, you properly put these statements<br><br>together, and reason upon them a bit, you will clearly perceive that,<br><br>according to all human reasoning, Procopius's sea-monster, that for<br><br>half a century stove the ships of a Roman Emperor, must in all<br><br>probability have been a sperm whale.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 46<br><br><br><br>Surmises.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Though, consumed with the hot fire of his purpose, Ahab in all his<br><br>thoughts and actions ever had in view the ultimate capture of Moby<br><br>Dick; though he seemed ready to sacrifice all mortal interests to<br><br>that one passion; nevertheless it may have been that he was by nature<br><br>and long habituation far too wedded to a fiery whaleman's ways,<br><br>altogether to abandon the collateral prosecution of the voyage.  Or<br><br>at least if this were otherwise, there were not wanting other motives<br><br>much more influential with him.  It would be refining too much,<br><br>perhaps, even considering his monomania, to hint that his<br><br>vindictiveness towards the White Whale might have possibly extended<br><br>itself in some degree to all sperm whales, and that the more monsters<br><br>he slew by so much the more he multiplied the chances that each<br><br>subsequently encountered whale would prove to be the hated one he<br><br>hunted.  But if such an hypothesis be indeed exceptionable, there<br><br>were still additional considerations which, though not so strictly<br><br>according with the wildness of his ruling passion, yet were by no<br><br>means incapable of swaying him.<br><br><br><br>To accomplish his object Ahab must use tools; and of all tools used<br><br>in the shadow of the moon, men are most apt to get out of order.  He<br><br>knew, for example, that however magnetic his ascendency in some<br><br>respects was over Starbuck, yet that ascendency did not cover the<br><br>complete spiritual man any more than mere corporeal superiority<br><br>involves intellectual mastership; for to the purely spiritual, the<br><br>intellectual but stand in a sort of corporeal relation.  Starbuck's<br><br>body and Starbuck's coerced will were Ahab's, so long as Ahab kept<br><br>his magnet at Starbuck's brain; still he knew that for all this the<br><br>chief mate, in his soul, abhorred his captain's quest, and could he,<br><br>would joyfully disintegrate himself from it, or even frustrate it.<br><br>It might be that a long interval would elapse ere the White Whale was<br><br>seen.  During that long interval Starbuck would ever be apt to fall<br><br>into open relapses of rebellion against his captain's leadership,<br><br>unless some ordinary, prudential, circumstantial influences were<br><br>brought to bear upon him.  Not only that, but the subtle insanity of<br><br>Ahab respecting Moby Dick was noways more significantly manifested<br><br>than in his superlative sense and shrewdness in foreseeing that, for<br><br>the present, the hunt should in some way be stripped of that strange<br><br>imaginative impiousness which naturally invested it; that the full<br><br>terror of the voyage must be kept withdrawn into the obscure<br><br>background (for few men's courage is proof against protracted<br><br>meditation unrelieved by action); that when they stood their long<br><br>night watches, his officers and men must have some nearer things to<br><br>think of than Moby Dick.  For however eagerly and impetuously the<br><br>savage crew had hailed the announcement of his quest; yet all sailors<br><br>of all sorts are more or less capricious and unreliable--they live in<br><br>the varying outer weather, and they inhale its fickleness--and when<br><br>retained for any object remote and blank in the pursuit, however<br><br>promissory of life and passion in the end, it is above all things<br><br>requisite that temporary interests and employments should intervene<br><br>and hold them healthily suspended for the final dash.<br><br><br><br>Nor was Ahab unmindful of another thing.  In times of strong emotion<br><br>mankind disdain all base considerations; but such times are<br><br>evanescent.  The permanent constitutional condition of the<br><br>manufactured man, thought Ahab, is sordidness.
