Granting that the<br><br>White Whale fully incites the hearts of this my savage crew, and<br><br>playing round their savageness even breeds a certain generous<br><br>knight-errantism in them, still, while for the love of it they give<br><br>chase to Moby Dick, they must also have food for their more common,<br><br>daily appetites.  For even the high lifted and chivalric Crusaders of<br><br>old times were not content to traverse two thousand miles of land to<br><br>fight for their holy sepulchre, without committing burglaries,<br><br>picking pockets, and gaining other pious perquisites by the way.  Had<br><br>they been strictly held to their one final and romantic object--that<br><br>final and romantic object, too many would have turned from in<br><br>disgust.  I will not strip these men, thought Ahab, of all hopes of<br><br>cash--aye, cash.  They may scorn cash now; but let some months go by,<br><br>and no perspective promise of it to them, and then this same<br><br>quiescent cash all at once mutinying in them, this same cash would<br><br>soon cashier Ahab.<br><br><br><br>Nor was there wanting still another precautionary motive more related<br><br>to Ahab personally.  Having impulsively, it is probable, and perhaps<br><br>somewhat prematurely revealed the prime but private purpose of the<br><br>Pequod's voyage, Ahab was now entirely conscious that, in so doing,<br><br>he had indirectly laid himself open to the unanswerable charge of<br><br>usurpation; and with perfect impunity, both moral and legal, his crew<br><br>if so disposed, and to that end competent, could refuse all further<br><br>obedience to him, and even violently wrest from him the command.<br><br>From even the barely hinted imputation of usurpation, and the<br><br>possible consequences of such a suppressed impression gaining ground,<br><br>Ahab must of course have been most anxious to protect himself.  That<br><br>protection could only consist in his own predominating brain and<br><br>heart and hand, backed by a heedful, closely calculating attention to<br><br>every minute atmospheric influence which it was possible for his crew<br><br>to be subjected to.<br><br><br><br>For all these reasons then, and others perhaps too analytic to be<br><br>verbally developed here, Ahab plainly saw that he must still in a<br><br>good degree continue true to the natural, nominal purpose of the<br><br>Pequod's voyage; observe all customary usages; and not only that, but<br><br>force himself to evince all his well known passionate interest in the<br><br>general pursuit of his profession.<br><br><br><br>Be all this as it may, his voice was now often heard hailing the<br><br>three mast-heads and admonishing them to keep a bright look-out, and<br><br>not omit reporting even a porpoise.  This vigilance was not long<br><br>without reward.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 47<br><br><br><br>The Mat-Maker.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It was a cloudy, sultry afternoon; the seamen were lazily lounging<br><br>about the decks, or vacantly gazing over into the lead-coloured<br><br>waters.  Queequeg and I were mildly employed weaving what is called a<br><br>sword-mat, for an additional lashing to our boat.  So still and<br><br>subdued and yet somehow preluding was all the scene, and such an<br><br>incantation of reverie lurked in the air, that each silent sailor<br><br>seemed resolved into his own invisible self.<br><br><br><br>I was the attendant or page of Queequeg, while busy at the mat.  As I<br><br>kept passing and repassing the filling or woof of marline between the<br><br>long yarns of the warp, using my own hand for the shuttle, and as<br><br>Queequeg, standing sideways, ever and anon slid his heavy oaken sword<br><br>between the threads, and idly looking off upon the water, carelessly<br><br>and unthinkingly drove home every yarn: I say so strange a<br><br>dreaminess did there then reign all over the ship and all over the<br><br>sea, only broken by the intermitting dull sound of the sword, that it<br><br>seemed as if this were the Loom of Time, and I myself were a shuttle<br><br>mechanically weaving and weaving away at the Fates.  There lay the<br><br>fixed threads of the warp subject to but one single, ever returning,<br><br>unchanging vibration, and that vibration merely enough to admit of<br><br>the crosswise interblending of other threads with its own.  This warp<br><br>seemed necessity; and here, thought I, with my own hand I ply my own<br><br>shuttle and weave my own destiny into these unalterable threads.<br><br>Meantime, Queequeg's impulsive, indifferent sword, sometimes hitting<br><br>the woof slantingly, or crookedly, or strongly, or weakly, as the<br><br>case might be; and by this difference in the concluding blow<br><br>producing a corresponding contrast in the final aspect of the<br><br>completed fabric; this savage's sword, thought I, which thus finally<br><br>shapes and fashions both warp and woof; this easy, indifferent sword<br><br>must be chance--aye, chance, free will, and necessity--nowise<br><br>incompatible--all interweavingly working together.  The straight warp<br><br>of necessity, not to be swerved from its ultimate course--its every<br><br>alternating vibration, indeed, only tending to that; free will still<br><br>free to ply her shuttle between given threads; and chance, though<br><br>restrained in its play within the right lines of necessity, and<br><br>sideways in its motions directed by free will, though thus prescribed<br><br>to by both, chance by turns rules either, and has the last featuring<br><br>blow at events.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Thus we were weaving and weaving away when I started at a sound so<br><br>strange, long drawn, and musically wild and unearthly, that the ball<br><br>of free will dropped from my hand, and I stood gazing up at the<br><br>clouds whence that voice dropped like a wing.  High aloft in the<br><br>cross-trees was that mad Gay-Header, Tashtego.  His body was reaching<br><br>eagerly forward, his hand stretched out like a wand, and at brief<br><br>sudden intervals he continued his cries.  To be sure the same sound<br><br>was that very moment perhaps being heard all over the seas, from<br><br>hundreds of whalemen's look-outs perched as high in the air; but from<br><br>few of those lungs could that accustomed old cry have derived such a<br><br>marvellous cadence as from Tashtego the Indian's.<br><br><br><br>As he stood hovering over you half suspended in air, so wildly and<br><br>eagerly peering towards the horizon, you would have thought him some<br><br>prophet or seer beholding the shadows of Fate, and by those wild<br><br>cries announcing their coming.<br><br><br><br>"There she blows! there! there! there! she blows! she blows!"<br><br><br><br>"Where-away?"<br><br><br><br>"On the lee-beam, about two miles off! a school of them!"<br><br><br><br>Instantly all was commotion.<br><br><br><br>The Sperm Whale blows as a clock ticks, with the same undeviating and<br><br>reliable uniformity.  And thereby whalemen distinguish this fish from<br><br>other tribes of his genus.<br><br><br><br>"There go flukes!" was now the cry from Tashtego; and the whales<br><br>disappeared.<br><br><br><br>"Quick, steward!" cried Ahab.  "Time! time!"<br><br><br><br>Dough-Boy hurried below, glanced at the watch, and reported the exact<br><br>minute to Ahab.<br><br><br><br>The ship was now kept away from the wind, and she went gently rolling<br><br>before it.  Tashtego reporting that the whales had gone down heading<br><br>to leeward, we confidently looked to see them again directly in<br><br>advance of our bows.  For that singular craft at times evinced by the<br><br>Sperm Whale when, sounding with his head in one direction, he<br><br>nevertheless, while concealed beneath the surface, mills round, and<br><br>swiftly swims off in the opposite quarter--this deceitfulness of his<br><br>could not now be in action; for there was no reason to suppose that<br><br>the fish seen by Tashtego had been in any way alarmed, or indeed knew<br><br>at all of our vicinity.  One of the men selected for<br><br>shipkeepers--that is, those not appointed to the boats, by this time<br><br>relieved the Indian at the main-mast head.  The sailors at the fore<br><br>and mizzen had come down; the line tubs were fixed in their places;<br><br>the cranes were thrust out; the mainyard was backed, and the three<br><br>boats swung over the sea like three samphire baskets over high<br><br>cliffs.  Outside of the bulwarks their eager crews with one hand<br><br>clung to the rail, while one foot was expectantly poised on the<br><br>gunwale.  So look the long line of man-of-war's men about to throw<br><br>themselves on board an enemy's ship.<br><br><br><br>But at this critical instant a sudden exclamation was heard that took<br><br>every eye from the whale.  With a start all glared at dark Ahab, who<br><br>was surrounded by five dusky phantoms that seemed fresh formed out of<br><br>air.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 48<br><br><br><br>The First Lowering.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The phantoms, for so they then seemed, were flitting on the other<br><br>side of the deck, and, with a noiseless celerity, were casting loose<br><br>the tackles and bands of the boat which swung there.  This boat had<br><br>always been deemed one of the spare boats, though technically called<br><br>the captain's, on account of its hanging from the starboard quarter.<br><br>The figure that now stood by its bows was tall and swart, with one<br><br>white tooth evilly protruding from its steel-like lips.  A rumpled<br><br>Chinese jacket of black cotton funereally invested him, with wide<br><br>black trowsers of the same dark stuff.  But strangely crowning this<br><br>ebonness was a glistening white plaited turban, the living hair<br><br>braided and coiled round and round upon his head.  Less swart in<br><br>aspect, the companions of this figure were of that vivid,<br><br>tiger-yellow complexion peculiar to some of the aboriginal natives of<br><br>the Manillas;--a race notorious for a certain diabolism of subtilty,<br><br>and by some honest white mariners supposed to be the paid spies and<br><br>secret confidential agents on the water of the devil, their lord,<br><br>whose counting-room they suppose to be elsewhere.<br><br><br><br>While yet the wondering ship's company were gazing upon these<br><br>strangers, Ahab cried out to the white-turbaned old man at their<br><br>head, "All ready there, Fedallah?"<br><br><br><br>"Ready," was the half-hissed reply.<br><br><br><br>"Lower away then; d'ye hear?" shouting across the deck.  "Lower away<br><br>there, I say."<br><br><br><br>Such was the thunder of his voice, that spite of their amazement the<br><br>men sprang over the rail; the sheaves whirled round in the blocks;<br><br>with a wallow, the three boats dropped into the sea; while, with a<br><br>dexterous, off-handed daring, unknown in any other vocation, the<br><br>sailors, goat-like, leaped down the rolling ship's side into the<br><br>tossed boats below.<br><br><br><br>Hardly had they pulled out from under the ship's lee, when a fourth<br><br>keel, coming from the windward side, pulled round under the stern,<br><br>and showed the five strangers rowing Ahab, who, standing erect in the<br><br>stern, loudly hailed Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask, to spread themselves<br><br>widely, so as to cover a large expanse of water.  But with all their<br><br>eyes again riveted upon the swart Fedallah and his crew, the inmates<br><br>of the other boats obeyed not the command.<br><br><br><br>"Captain Ahab?--" said Starbuck.<br><br><br><br>"Spread yourselves," cried Ahab; "give way, all four boats.  Thou,<br><br>Flask, pull out more to leeward!"<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye, sir," cheerily cried little King-Post, sweeping round his<br><br>great steering oar.  "Lay back!" addressing his crew.<br><br>"There!--there!--there again!  There she blows right ahead,<br><br>boys!--lay back!"<br><br><br><br>"Never heed yonder yellow boys, Archy."<br><br><br><br>"Oh, I don't mind'em, sir," said Archy; "I knew it all before now.<br><br>Didn't I hear 'em in the hold?  And didn't I tell Cabaco here of it?<br><br>What say ye, Cabaco?  They are stowaways, Mr. Flask."<br><br><br><br>"Pull, pull, my fine hearts-alive; pull, my children; pull, my little<br><br>ones," drawlingly and soothingly sighed Stubb to his crew, some of<br><br>whom still showed signs of uneasiness.  "Why don't you break your<br><br>backbones, my boys?  What is it you stare at?  Those chaps in yonder<br><br>boat?  Tut!  They are only five more hands come to help us--never<br><br>mind from where--the more the merrier.  Pull, then, do pull; never<br><br>mind the brimstone--devils are good fellows enough.  So, so; there<br><br>you are now; that's the stroke for a thousand pounds; that's the<br><br>stroke to sweep the stakes!  Hurrah for the gold cup of sperm oil, my<br><br>heroes!  Three cheers, men--all hearts alive!  Easy, easy; don't be<br><br>in a hurry--don't be in a hurry.  Why don't you snap your oars, you<br><br>rascals?  Bite something, you dogs!  So, so, so, then:--softly,<br><br>softly!  That's it--that's it! long and strong.  Give way there, give<br><br>way!  The devil fetch ye, ye ragamuffin rapscallions; ye are all<br><br>asleep.  Stop snoring, ye sleepers, and pull.  Pull, will ye? pull,<br><br>can't ye? pull, won't ye?  Why in the name of gudgeons and<br><br>ginger-cakes don't ye pull?--pull and break something! pull, and<br><br>start your eyes out!  Here!" whipping out the sharp knife from his<br><br>girdle; "every mother's son of ye draw his knife, and pull with the<br><br>blade between his teeth.  That's it--that's it.  Now ye do something;<br><br>that looks like it, my steel-bits.  Start her--start her, my<br><br>silver-spoons!  Start her, marling-spikes!"<br><br><br><br>Stubb's exordium to his crew is given here at large, because he had<br><br>rather a peculiar way of talking to them in general, and especially<br><br>in inculcating the religion of rowing.  But you must not suppose from<br><br>this specimen of his sermonizings that he ever flew into downright<br><br>passions with his congregation.  Not at all; and therein consisted<br><br>his chief peculiarity.  He would say the most terrific things to his<br><br>crew, in a tone so strangely compounded of fun and fury, and the fury<br><br>seemed so calculated merely as a spice to the fun, that no oarsman<br><br>could hear such queer invocations without pulling for dear life, and<br><br>yet pulling for the mere joke of the thing. Give way!"<br><br><br><br>Now the advent of these outlandish strangers at such a critical<br><br>instant as the lowering of the boats from the deck, this had not<br><br>unreasonably awakened a sort of superstitious amazement in some of<br><br>the ship's company; but Archy's fancied discovery having some time<br><br>previous got abroad among them, though indeed not credited then, this<br><br>had in some small measure prepared them for the event. "Thou,<br><br>Queequeg, stand up!"<br><br><br><br>Nimbly springing up on the triangular raised box in the bow, the<br><br>savage stood erect there, and with intensely eager eyes gazed off<br><br>towards the spot where the chase had last been descried. It is used for catching turns with<br><br>the whale line. The whales might have made one of their regular<br><br>soundings, not a temporary dive from mere fright; and if that were<br><br>the case, Stubb, as his wont in such cases, it seems, was resolved to<br><br>solace the languishing interval with his pipe. "Sing out and say<br><br>something, my hearties.  Roar and pull, my thunderbolts!  Beach me,<br><br>beach me on their black backs, boys; only do that for me, and I'll<br><br>sign over to you my Martha's Vineyard plantation, boys; including<br><br>wife and children, boys.  Lay me on--lay me on!  O Lord, Lord! but I<br><br>shall go stark, staring mad!  See! see that white water!"  And so<br><br>shouting, he pulled his hat from his head, and stamped up and down on<br><br>it; then picking it up, flirted it far off upon the sea; and finally<br><br>fell to rearing and plunging in the boat's stern like a crazed colt<br><br>from the prairie.<br><br><br><br>"Look at that chap now," philosophically drawled Stubb, who, with his<br><br>unlighted short pipe, mechanically retained between his teeth, at a<br><br>short distance, followed after--"He's got fits, that Flask has.<br><br>Fits? yes, give him fits--that's the very word--pitch fits into 'em.<br><br>Merrily, merrily, hearts-alive.  Pudding for supper, you<br><br>know;--merry's the word.  Pull, babes--pull, sucklings--pull, all.<br><br>But what the devil are you hurrying about?  Softly, softly, and<br><br>steadily, my men.  Only pull, and keep pulling; nothing more.  Crack<br><br>all your backbones, and bite your knives in two--that's all.  Take it<br><br>easy--why don't ye take it easy, I say, and burst all your livers and<br><br>lungs!"<br><br><br><br>But what it was that inscrutable Ahab said to that tiger-yellow crew<br><br>of his--these were words best omitted here; for you live under the<br><br>blessed light of the evangelical land.  Only the infidel sharks in<br><br>the audacious seas may give ear to such words, when, with tornado<br><br>brow, and eyes of red murder, and foam-glued lips, Ahab leaped after<br><br>his prey.<br><br><br><br>Meanwhile, all the boats tore on.  The repeated specific allusions of<br><br>Flask to "that whale," as he called the fictitious monster which he<br><br>declared to be incessantly tantalizing his boat's bow with its<br><br>tail--these allusions of his were at times so vivid and life-like,<br><br>that they would cause some one or two of his men to snatch a fearful<br><br>look over the shoulder.  But this was against all rule; for the<br><br>oarsmen must put out their eyes, and ram a skewer through their<br><br>necks; usage pronouncing that they must have no organs but ears, and<br><br>no limbs but arms, in these critical moments.<br><br><br><br>It was a sight full of quick wonder and awe!  The vast swells of the<br><br>omnipotent sea; the surging, hollow roar they made, as they rolled<br><br>along the eight gunwales, like gigantic bowls in a boundless<br><br>bowling-green; the brief suspended agony of the boat, as it would tip<br><br>for an instant on the knife-like edge of the sharper waves, that<br><br>almost seemed threatening to cut it in two; the sudden profound dip<br><br>into the watery glens and hollows; the keen spurrings and goadings to<br><br>gain the top of the opposite hill; the headlong, sled-like slide down<br><br>its other side;--all these, with the cries of the headsmen and<br><br>harpooneers, and the shuddering gasps of the oarsmen, with the<br><br>wondrous sight of the ivory Pequod bearing down upon her boats with<br><br>outstretched sails, like a wild hen after her screaming brood;--all<br><br>this was thrilling.<br><br><br><br>Not the raw recruit, marching from the bosom of his wife into the<br><br>fever heat of his first battle; not the dead man's ghost encountering<br><br>the first unknown phantom in the other world;--neither of these can<br><br>feel stranger and stronger emotions than that man does, who for the<br><br>first time finds himself pulling into the charmed, churned circle of<br><br>the hunted sperm whale.<br><br><br><br>The dancing white water made by the chase was now becoming more and<br><br>more visible, owing to the increasing darkness of the dun<br><br>cloud-shadows flung upon the sea.  The jets of vapour no longer<br><br>blended, but tilted everywhere to right and left; the whales seemed<br><br>separating their wakes.  The boats were pulled more apart; Starbuck<br><br>giving chase to three whales running dead to leeward.  Our sail was<br><br>now set, and, with the still rising wind, we rushed along; the boat<br><br>going with such madness through the water, that the lee oars could<br><br>scarcely be worked rapidly enough to escape being torn from the<br><br>row-locks.<br><br><br><br>Soon we were running through a suffusing wide veil of mist; neither<br><br>ship nor boat to be seen.<br><br><br><br>"Give way, men," whispered Starbuck, drawing still further aft the<br><br>sheet of his sail; "there is time to kill a fish yet before the<br><br>squall comes.  There's white water again!--close to!  Spring!"<br><br><br><br>Soon after, two cries in quick succession on each side of us denoted<br><br>that the other boats had got fast; but hardly were they overheard,<br><br>when with a lightning-like hurtling whisper Starbuck said: "Stand<br><br>up!" and Queequeg, harpoon in hand, sprang to his feet.<br><br><br><br>Though not one of the oarsmen was then facing the life and death<br><br>peril so close to them ahead, yet with their eyes on the intense<br><br>countenance of the mate in the stern of the boat, they knew that the<br><br>imminent instant had come; they heard, too, an enormous wallowing<br><br>sound as of fifty elephants stirring in their litter.  Meanwhile the<br><br>boat was still booming through the mist, the waves curling and<br><br>hissing around us like the erected crests of enraged serpents.<br><br><br><br>"That's his hump.  THERE, THERE, give it to him!" whispered Starbuck.<br><br><br><br>A short rushing sound leaped out of the boat; it was the darted iron<br><br>of Queequeg.  Then all in one welded commotion came an invisible push<br><br>from astern, while forward the boat seemed striking on a ledge; the<br><br>sail collapsed and exploded; a gush of scalding vapour shot up near<br><br>by; something rolled and tumbled like an earthquake beneath us.  The<br><br>whole crew were half suffocated as they were tossed helter-skelter<br><br>into the white curdling cream of the squall.  Squall, whale, and<br><br>harpoon had all blended together; and the whale, merely grazed by the<br><br>iron, escaped.<br><br><br><br>Though completely swamped, the boat was nearly unharmed.  Swimming<br><br>round it we picked up the floating oars, and lashing them across the<br><br>gunwale, tumbled back to our places.  There we sat up to our knees in<br><br>the sea, the water covering every rib and plank, so that to our<br><br>downward gazing eyes the suspended craft seemed a coral boat grown up<br><br>to us from the bottom of the ocean.<br><br><br><br>The wind increased to a howl; the waves dashed their bucklers<br><br>together; the whole squall roared, forked, and crackled around us<br><br>like a white fire upon the prairie, in which, unconsumed, we were<br><br>burning; immortal in these jaws of death!  In vain we hailed the<br><br>other boats; as well roar to the live coals down the chimney of a<br><br>flaming furnace as hail those boats in that storm.  Meanwhile the<br><br>driving scud, rack, and mist, grew darker with the shadows of night;<br><br>no sign of the ship could be seen.  The rising sea forbade all<br><br>attempts to bale out the boat.  The oars were useless as propellers,<br><br>performing now the office of life-preservers.  So, cutting the<br><br>lashing of the waterproof match keg, after many failures Starbuck<br><br>contrived to ignite the lamp in the lantern; then stretching it on a<br><br>waif pole, handed it to Queequeg as the standard-bearer of this<br><br>forlorn hope.  There, then, he sat, holding up that imbecile candle<br><br>in the heart of that almighty forlornness.  There, then, he sat, the<br><br>sign and symbol of a man without faith, hopelessly holding up hope in<br><br>the midst of despair.<br><br><br><br>Wet, drenched through, and shivering cold, despairing of ship or<br><br>boat, we lifted up our eyes as the dawn came on.  The mist still<br><br>spread over the sea, the empty lantern lay crushed in the bottom of<br><br>the boat.  Suddenly Queequeg started to his feet, hollowing his hand<br><br>to his ear.  We all heard a faint creaking, as of ropes and yards<br><br>hitherto muffled by the storm.  The sound came nearer and nearer; the<br><br>thick mists were dimly parted by a huge, vague form.  Affrighted, we<br><br>all sprang into the sea as the ship at last loomed into view, bearing<br><br>right down upon us within a distance of not much more than its<br><br>length.<br><br><br><br>Floating on the waves we saw the abandoned boat, as for one instant<br><br>it tossed and gaped beneath the ship's bows like a chip at the base<br><br>of a cataract; and then the vast hull rolled over it, and it was seen<br><br>no more till it came up weltering astern.  Again we swam for it, were<br><br>dashed against it by the seas, and were at last taken up and safely<br><br>landed on board.  Ere the squall came close to, the other boats had<br><br>cut loose from their fish and returned to the ship in good time.  The<br><br>ship had given us up, but was still cruising, if haply it might light<br><br>upon some token of our perishing,--an oar or a lance pole.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 49<br><br><br><br>The Hyena.<br><br><br><br><br><br>There are certain queer times and occasions in this strange mixed<br><br>affair we call life when a man takes this whole universe for a vast<br><br>practical joke, though the wit thereof he but dimly discerns, and<br><br>more than suspects that the joke is at nobody's expense but his own.<br><br>However, nothing dispirits, and nothing seems worth while disputing.<br><br>He bolts down all events, all creeds, and beliefs, and persuasions,<br><br>all hard things visible and invisible, never mind how knobby; as an<br><br>ostrich of potent digestion gobbles down bullets and gun flints.  And<br><br>as for small difficulties and worryings, prospects of sudden<br><br>disaster, peril of life and limb; all these, and death itself, seem<br><br>to him only sly, good-natured hits, and jolly punches in the side<br><br>bestowed by the unseen and unaccountable old joker.  That odd sort of<br><br>wayward mood I am speaking of, comes over a man only in some time of<br><br>extreme tribulation; it comes in the very midst of his earnestness,<br><br>so that what just before might have seemed to him a thing most<br><br>momentous, now seems but a part of the general joke.  There is<br><br>nothing like the perils of whaling to breed this free and easy sort<br><br>of genial, desperado philosophy; and with it I now regarded this<br><br>whole voyage of the Pequod, and the great White Whale its object.<br><br><br><br>"Queequeg," said I, when they had dragged me, the last man, to the<br><br>deck, and I was still shaking myself in my jacket to fling off the<br><br>water; "Queequeg, my fine friend, does this sort of thing often<br><br>happen?"  Without much emotion, though soaked through just like me,<br><br>he gave me to understand that such things did often happen.<br><br><br><br>"Mr. Stubb," said I, turning to that worthy, who, buttoned up in his<br><br>oil-jacket, was now calmly smoking his pipe in the rain; "Mr. Stubb,<br><br>I think I have heard you say that of all whalemen you ever met, our<br><br>chief mate, Mr. Starbuck, is by far the most careful and prudent.  I<br><br>suppose then, that going plump on a flying whale with your sail set<br><br>in a foggy squall is the height of a whaleman's discretion?"<br><br><br><br>"Certain.  I've lowered for whales from a leaking ship in a gale off<br><br>Cape Horn."<br><br><br><br>"Mr. Flask," said I, turning to little King-Post, who was standing<br><br>close by; "you are experienced in these things, and I am not.  Will<br><br>you tell me whether it is an unalterable law in this fishery, Mr.<br><br>Flask, for an oarsman to break his own back pulling himself<br><br>back-foremost into death's jaws?"<br><br><br><br>"Can't you twist that smaller?" said Flask.  "Yes, that's the law.  I<br><br>should like to see a boat's crew backing water up to a whale face<br><br>foremost.  Ha, ha! the whale would give them squint for squint, mind<br><br>that!"<br><br><br><br>Here then, from three impartial witnesses, I had a deliberate<br><br>statement of the entire case.  Considering, therefore, that squalls<br><br>and capsizings in the water and consequent bivouacks on the deep,<br><br>were matters of common occurrence in this kind of life; considering<br><br>that at the superlatively critical instant of going on to the whale I<br><br>must resign my life into the hands of him who steered the<br><br>boat--oftentimes a fellow who at that very moment is in his<br><br>impetuousness upon the point of scuttling the craft with his own<br><br>frantic stampings; considering that the particular disaster to our<br><br>own particular boat was chiefly to be imputed to Starbuck's driving<br><br>on to his whale almost in the teeth of a squall, and considering that<br><br>Starbuck, notwithstanding, was famous for his great heedfulness in<br><br>the fishery; considering that I belonged to this uncommonly prudent<br><br>Starbuck's boat; and finally considering in what a devil's chase I<br><br>was implicated, touching the White Whale: taking all things together,<br><br>I say, I thought I might as well go below and make a rough draft of<br><br>my will.  "Queequeg," said I, "come along, you shall be my lawyer,<br><br>executor, and legatee."<br><br><br><br>It may seem strange that of all men sailors should be tinkering at<br><br>their last wills and testaments, but there are no people in the world<br><br>more fond of that diversion.  This was the fourth time in my nautical<br><br>life that I had done the same thing.  After the ceremony was<br><br>concluded upon the present occasion, I felt all the easier; a stone<br><br>was rolled away from my heart.  Besides, all the days I should now<br><br>live would be as good as the days that Lazarus lived after his<br><br>resurrection; a supplementary clean gain of so many months or weeks<br><br>as the case might be.  I survived myself; my death and burial were<br><br>locked up in my chest.  I looked round me tranquilly and contentedly,<br><br>like a quiet ghost with a clean conscience sitting inside the bars of<br><br>a snug family vault.<br><br><br><br>Now then, thought I, unconsciously rolling up the sleeves of my<br><br>frock, here goes for a cool, collected dive at death and destruction,<br><br>and the devil fetch the hindmost.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 50<br><br><br><br>Ahab's Boat and Crew.  Fedallah.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"Who would have thought it, Flask!" cried Stubb; "if I had but one<br><br>leg you would not catch me in a boat, unless maybe to stop the<br><br>plug-hole with my timber toe.  Oh! he's a wonderful old man!"<br><br><br><br>"I don't think it so strange, after all, on that account," said<br><br>Flask.  "If his leg were off at the hip, now, it would be a different<br><br>thing.  That would disable him; but he has one knee, and good part of<br><br>the other left, you know."<br><br><br><br>"I don't know that, my little man; I never yet saw him kneel."<br><br><br><br><br><br>Among whale-wise people it has often been argued whether, considering<br><br>the paramount importance of his life to the success of the voyage, it<br><br>is right for a whaling captain to jeopardize that life in the active<br><br>perils of the chase.  So Tamerlane's soldiers often argued with tears<br><br>in their eyes, whether that invaluable life of his ought to be<br><br>carried into the thickest of the fight.<br><br><br><br>But with Ahab the question assumed a modified aspect.  Considering<br><br>that with two legs man is but a hobbling wight in all times of<br><br>danger; considering that the pursuit of whales is always under great<br><br>and extraordinary difficulties; that every individual moment, indeed,<br><br>then comprises a peril; under these circumstances is it wise for any<br><br>maimed man to enter a whale-boat in the hunt?  As a general thing,<br><br>the joint-owners of the Pequod must have plainly thought not.<br><br><br><br>Ahab well knew that although his friends at home would think little<br><br>of his entering a boat in certain comparatively harmless vicissitudes<br><br>of the chase, for the sake of being near the scene of action and<br><br>giving his orders in person, yet for Captain Ahab to have a boat<br><br>actually apportioned to him as a regular headsman in the hunt--above<br><br>all for Captain Ahab to be supplied with five extra men, as that same<br><br>boat's crew, he well knew that such generous conceits never entered the<br><br>heads of the owners of the Pequod.  Therefore he had not solicited a<br><br>boat's crew from them, nor had he in any way hinted his desires on<br><br>that head.  Nevertheless he had taken private measures of his own<br><br>touching all that matter.  Until Cabaco's published discovery, the<br><br>sailors had little foreseen it, though to be sure when, after being a<br><br>little while out of port, all hands had concluded the customary<br><br>business of fitting the whaleboats for service; when some time after<br><br>this Ahab was now and then found bestirring himself in the matter of<br><br>making thole-pins with his own hands for what was thought to be one<br><br>of the spare boats, and even solicitously cutting the small wooden<br><br>skewers, which when the line is running out are pinned over the<br><br>groove in the bow: when all this was observed in him, and<br><br>particularly his solicitude in having an extra coat of sheathing in<br><br>the bottom of the boat, as if to make it better withstand the pointed<br><br>pressure of his ivory limb; and also the anxiety he evinced in<br><br>exactly shaping the thigh board, or clumsy cleat, as it is sometimes<br><br>called, the horizontal piece in the boat's bow for bracing the knee<br><br>against in darting or stabbing at the whale; when it was observed how<br><br>often he stood up in that boat with his solitary knee fixed in the<br><br>semi-circular depression in the cleat, and with the carpenter's<br><br>chisel gouged out a little here and straightened it a little there;<br><br>all these things, I say, had awakened much interest and curiosity at<br><br>the time.  But almost everybody supposed that this particular<br><br>preparative heedfulness in Ahab must only be with a view to the<br><br>ultimate chase of Moby Dick; for he had already revealed his<br><br>intention to hunt that mortal monster in person.  But such a<br><br>supposition did by no means involve the remotest suspicion as to any<br><br>boat's crew being assigned to that boat.<br><br><br><br>Now, with the subordinate phantoms, what wonder remained soon waned<br><br>away; for in a whaler wonders soon wane.  Besides, now and then such<br><br>unaccountable odds and ends of strange nations come up from the<br><br>unknown nooks and ash-holes of the earth to man these floating<br><br>outlaws of whalers; and the ships themselves often pick up such queer<br><br>castaway creatures found tossing about the open sea on planks, bits<br><br>of wreck, oars, whaleboats, canoes, blown-off Japanese junks, and<br><br>what not; that Beelzebub himself might climb up the side and step<br><br>down into the cabin to chat with the captain, and it would not create<br><br>any unsubduable excitement in the forecastle.<br><br><br><br>But be all this as it may, certain it is that while the subordinate<br><br>phantoms soon found their place among the crew, though still as it<br><br>were somehow distinct from them, yet that hair-turbaned Fedallah<br><br>remained a muffled mystery to the last.  Whence he came in a mannerly<br><br>world like this, by what sort of unaccountable tie he soon evinced<br><br>himself to be linked with Ahab's peculiar fortunes; nay, so far as to<br><br>have some sort of a half-hinted influence; Heaven knows, but it might<br><br>have been even authority over him; all this none knew.  But one<br><br>cannot sustain an indifferent air concerning Fedallah.  He was such a<br><br>creature as civilized, domestic people in the temperate zone only see<br><br>in their dreams, and that but dimly; but the like of whom now and<br><br>then glide among the unchanging Asiatic communities, especially the<br><br>Oriental isles to the east of the continent--those insulated,<br><br>immemorial, unalterable countries, which even in these modern days<br><br>still preserve much of the ghostly aboriginalness of earth's primal<br><br>generations, when the memory of the first man was a distinct<br><br>recollection, and all men his descendants, unknowing whence he came,<br><br>eyed each other as real phantoms, and asked of the sun and the moon<br><br>why they were created and to what end; when though, according to<br><br>Genesis, the angels indeed consorted with the daughters of men, the<br><br>devils also, add the uncanonical Rabbins, indulged in mundane amours.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 51<br><br><br><br>The Spirit-Spout.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Days, weeks passed, and under easy sail, the ivory Pequod had slowly<br><br>swept across four several cruising-grounds; that off the Azores; off<br><br>the Cape de Verdes; on the Plate (so called), being off the mouth of<br><br>the Rio de la Plata; and the Carrol Ground, an unstaked, watery<br><br>locality, southerly from St. Helena.<br><br><br><br>It was while gliding through these latter waters that one serene and<br><br>moonlight night, when all the waves rolled by like scrolls of silver;<br><br>and, by their soft, suffusing seethings, made what seemed a silvery<br><br>silence, not a solitude; on such a silent night a silvery jet was<br><br>seen far in advance of the white bubbles at the bow.  Lit up by the<br><br>moon, it looked celestial; seemed some plumed and glittering god<br><br>uprising from the sea.  Fedallah first descried this jet.  For of<br><br>these moonlight nights, it was his wont to mount to the main-mast<br><br>head, and stand a look-out there, with the same precision as if it<br><br>had been day.  And yet, though herds of whales were seen by night,<br><br>not one whaleman in a hundred would venture a lowering for them.  You<br><br>may think with what emotions, then, the seamen beheld this old<br><br>Oriental perched aloft at such unusual hours; his turban and the<br><br>moon, companions in one sky.  But when, after spending his uniform<br><br>interval there for several successive nights without uttering a<br><br>single sound; when, after all this silence, his unearthly voice was<br><br>heard announcing that silvery, moon-lit jet, every reclining mariner<br><br>started to his feet as if some winged spirit had lighted in the<br><br>rigging, and hailed the mortal crew.  "There she blows!"  Had the<br><br>trump of judgment blown, they could not have quivered more; yet still<br><br>they felt no terror; rather pleasure.  For though it was a most<br><br>unwonted hour, yet so impressive was the cry, and so deliriously<br><br>exciting, that almost every soul on board instinctively desired a<br><br>lowering.<br><br><br><br>Walking the deck with quick, side-lunging strides, Ahab commanded the<br><br>t'gallant sails and royals to be set, and every stunsail spread.  The<br><br>best man in the ship must take the helm.  Then, with every mast-head<br><br>manned, the piled-up craft rolled down before the wind.  The strange,<br><br>upheaving, lifting tendency of the taffrail breeze filling the<br><br>hollows of so many sails, made the buoyant, hovering deck to feel<br><br>like air beneath the feet; while still she rushed along, as if two<br><br>antagonistic influences were struggling in her--one to mount direct<br><br>to heaven, the other to drive yawingly to some horizontal goal. While his one live<br><br>leg made lively echoes along the deck, every stroke of his dead limb<br><br>sounded like a coffin-tap.  On life and death this old man walked.<br><br>But though the ship so swiftly sped, and though from every eye, like<br><br>arrows, the eager glances shot, yet the silvery jet was no more seen<br><br>that night.  Every sailor swore he saw it once, but not a second<br><br>time.<br><br><br><br>This midnight-spout had almost grown a forgotten thing, when, some<br><br>days after, lo! at the same silent hour, it was again announced:<br><br>again it was descried by all; but upon making sail to overtake it,<br><br>once more it disappeared as if it had never been.  And so it served<br><br>us night after night, till no one heeded it but to wonder at it.<br><br>Mysteriously jetted into the clear moonlight, or starlight, as the<br><br>case might be; disappearing again for one whole day, or two days, or<br><br>three; and somehow seeming at every distinct repetition to be<br><br>advancing still further and further in our van, this solitary jet<br><br>seemed for ever alluring us on.<br><br><br><br>Nor with the immemorial superstition of their race, and in accordance<br><br>with the preternaturalness, as it seemed, which in many things<br><br>invested the Pequod, were there wanting some of the seamen who swore<br><br>that whenever and wherever descried; at however remote times, or in<br><br>however far apart latitudes and longitudes, that unnearable spout was<br><br>cast by one self-same whale; and that whale, Moby Dick.  For a time,<br><br>there reigned, too, a sense of peculiar dread at this flitting<br><br>apparition, as if it were treacherously beckoning us on and on, in<br><br>order that the monster might turn round upon us, and rend us at last<br><br>in the remotest and most savage seas.<br><br><br><br>These temporary apprehensions, so vague but so awful, derived a<br><br>wondrous potency from the contrasting serenity of the weather, in<br><br>which, beneath all its blue blandness, some thought there lurked a<br><br>devilish charm, as for days and days we voyaged along, through seas<br><br>so wearily, lonesomely mild, that all space, in repugnance to our<br><br>vengeful errand, seemed vacating itself of life before our urn-like<br><br>prow.<br><br><br><br>But, at last, when turning to the eastward, the Cape winds began<br><br>howling around us, and we rose and fell upon the long, troubled seas<br><br>that are there; when the ivory-tusked Pequod sharply bowed to the<br><br>blast, and gored the dark waves in her madness, till, like showers of<br><br>silver chips, the foam-flakes flew over her bulwarks; then all this<br><br>desolate vacuity of life went away, but gave place to sights more<br><br>dismal than before.<br><br><br><br>Close to our bows, strange forms in the water darted hither and<br><br>thither before us; while thick in our rear flew the inscrutable<br><br>sea-ravens.  And every morning, perched on our stays, rows of these<br><br>birds were seen; and spite of our hootings, for a long time<br><br>obstinately clung to the hemp, as though they deemed our ship some<br><br>drifting, uninhabited craft; a thing appointed to desolation, and<br><br>therefore fit roosting-place for their homeless selves.  And heaved<br><br>and heaved, still unrestingly heaved the black sea, as if its vast<br><br>tides were a conscience; and the great mundane soul were in anguish<br><br>and remorse for the long sin and suffering it had bred.<br><br><br><br>Cape of Good Hope, do they call ye?  Rather Cape Tormentoto, as<br><br>called of yore; for long allured by the perfidious silences that<br><br>before had attended us, we found ourselves launched into this<br><br>tormented sea, where guilty beings transformed into those fowls and<br><br>these fish, seemed condemned to swim on everlastingly without any<br><br>haven in store, or beat that black air without any horizon.  But<br><br>calm, snow-white, and unvarying; still directing its fountain of<br><br>feathers to the sky; still beckoning us on from before, the solitary<br><br>jet would at times be descried.<br><br><br><br>During all this blackness of the elements, Ahab, though assuming for<br><br>the time the almost continual command of the drenched and dangerous<br><br>deck, manifested the gloomiest reserve; and more seldom than ever<br><br>addressed his mates.  In tempestuous times like these, after<br><br>everything above and aloft has been secured, nothing more can be done<br><br>but passively to await the issue of the gale.  Then Captain and crew<br><br>become practical fatalists.  So, with his ivory leg inserted into its<br><br>accustomed hole, and with one hand firmly grasping a shroud, Ahab for<br><br>hours and hours would stand gazing dead to windward, while an<br><br>occasional squall of sleet or snow would all but congeal his very<br><br>eyelashes together.  Meantime, the crew driven from the forward part<br><br>of the ship by the perilous seas that burstingly broke over its bows,<br><br>stood in a line along the bulwarks in the waist; and the better to<br><br>guard against the leaping waves, each man had slipped himself into a<br><br>sort of bowline secured to the rail, in which he swung as in a<br><br>loosened belt.  Few or no words were spoken; and the silent ship, as<br><br>if manned by painted sailors in wax, day after day tore on through<br><br>all the swift madness and gladness of the demoniac waves.  By night<br><br>the same muteness of humanity before the shrieks of the ocean<br><br>prevailed; still in silence the men swung in the bowlines; still<br><br>wordless Ahab stood up to the blast.  Even when wearied nature seemed<br><br>demanding repose he would not seek that repose in his hammock.<br><br>Never could Starbuck forget the old man's aspect, when one night<br><br>going down into the cabin to mark how the barometer stood, he saw him<br><br>with closed eyes sitting straight in his floor-screwed chair; the<br><br>rain and half-melted sleet of the storm from which he had some time<br><br>before emerged, still slowly dripping from the unremoved hat and<br><br>coat.  On the table beside him lay unrolled one of those charts of<br><br>tides and currents which have previously been spoken of.  His lantern<br><br>swung from his tightly clenched hand.  Though the body was erect, the<br><br>head was thrown back so that the closed eyes were pointed towards the<br><br>needle of the tell-tale that swung from a beam in the ceiling.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*The cabin-compass is called the tell-tale, because without going to<br><br>the compass at the helm, the Captain, while below, can inform himself<br><br>of the course of the ship.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Terrible old man! thought Starbuck with a shudder, sleeping in this<br><br>gale, still thou steadfastly eyest thy purpose.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 52<br><br><br><br>The Albatross.<br><br><br><br><br><br>South-eastward from the Cape, off the distant Crozetts, a good<br><br>cruising ground for Right Whalemen, a sail loomed ahead, the Goney<br><br>(Albatross) by name.  As she slowly drew nigh, from my lofty perch at<br><br>the fore-mast-head, I had a good view of that sight so remarkable to<br><br>a tyro in the far ocean fisheries--a whaler at sea, and long absent<br><br>from home.<br><br><br><br>As if the waves had been fullers, this craft was bleached like the<br><br>skeleton of a stranded walrus.  All down her sides, this spectral<br><br>appearance was traced with long channels of reddened rust, while all<br><br>her spars and her rigging were like the thick branches of trees<br><br>furred over with hoar-frost.  Only her lower sails were set.  A wild<br><br>sight it was to see her long-bearded look-outs at those three<br><br>mast-heads.  They seemed clad in the skins of beasts, so torn and<br><br>bepatched the raiment that had survived nearly four years of<br><br>cruising.  Standing in iron hoops nailed to the mast, they swayed and<br><br>swung over a fathomless sea; and though, when the ship slowly glided<br><br>close under our stern, we six men in the air came so nigh to each<br><br>other that we might almost have leaped from the mast-heads of one<br><br>ship to those of the other; yet, those forlorn-looking fishermen,<br><br>mildly eyeing us as they passed, said not one word to our own<br><br>look-outs, while the quarter-deck hail was being heard from below.<br><br><br><br>"Ship ahoy!  Have ye seen the White Whale?"<br><br><br><br>But as the strange captain, leaning over the pallid bulwarks, was in<br><br>the act of putting his trumpet to his mouth, it somehow fell from his<br><br>hand into the sea; and the wind now rising amain, he in vain strove<br><br>to make himself heard without it.  Meantime his ship was still<br><br>increasing the distance between.  While in various silent ways<br><br>the seamen of the Pequod were evincing their observance of this<br><br>ominous incident at the first mere mention of the White Whale's name<br><br>to another ship, Ahab for a moment paused; it almost seemed as though<br><br>he would have lowered a boat to board the stranger, had not the<br><br>threatening wind forbade.  But taking advantage of his windward<br><br>position, he again seized his trumpet, and knowing by her aspect that<br><br>the stranger vessel was a Nantucketer and shortly bound home, he<br><br>loudly hailed--"Ahoy there!  This is the Pequod, bound round the<br><br>world!  Tell them to address all future letters to the Pacific ocean!<br><br>and this time three years, if I am not at home, tell them to address<br><br>them to--"<br><br><br><br>At that moment the two wakes were fairly crossed, and instantly,<br><br>then, in accordance with their singular ways, shoals of small<br><br>harmless fish, that for some days before had been placidly swimming<br><br>by our side, darted away with what seemed shuddering fins, and ranged<br><br>themselves fore and aft with the stranger's flanks.  Though in the<br><br>course of his continual voyagings Ahab must often before have noticed<br><br>a similar sight, yet, to any monomaniac man, the veriest trifles<br><br>capriciously carry meanings.<br><br><br><br>"Swim away from me, do ye?" murmured Ahab, gazing over into the<br><br>water.  There seemed but little in the words, but the tone conveyed<br><br>more of deep helpless sadness than the insane old man had ever before<br><br>evinced.  But turning to the steersman, who thus far had been holding<br><br>the ship in the wind to diminish her headway, he cried out in his old<br><br>lion voice,--"Up helm!  Keep her off round the world!"<br><br><br><br>Round the world!  There is much in that sound to inspire proud<br><br>feelings; but whereto does all that circumnavigation conduct?  Only<br><br>through numberless perils to the very point whence we started, where<br><br>those that we left behind secure, were all the time before us.<br><br><br><br>Were this world an endless plain, and by sailing eastward we could<br><br>for ever reach new distances, and discover sights more sweet and<br><br>strange than any Cyclades or Islands of King Solomon, then there were<br><br>promise in the voyage.  But in pursuit of those far mysteries we<br><br>dream of, or in tormented chase of that demon phantom that, some time<br><br>or other, swims before all human hearts; while chasing such over this<br><br>round globe, they either lead us on in barren mazes or midway leave<br><br>us whelmed.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 53<br><br><br><br>The Gam.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The ostensible reason why Ahab did not go on board of the whaler we<br><br>had spoken was this: the wind and sea betokened storms.  But even had<br><br>this not been the case, he would not after all, perhaps, have boarded<br><br>her--judging by his subsequent conduct on similar occasions--if so it<br><br>had been that, by the process of hailing, he had obtained a negative<br><br>answer to the question he put.  For, as it eventually turned out, he<br><br>cared not to consort, even for five minutes, with any stranger<br><br>captain, except he could contribute some of that information he so<br><br>absorbingly sought.  But all this might remain inadequately<br><br>estimated, were not something said here of the peculiar usages of<br><br>whaling-vessels when meeting each other in foreign seas, and<br><br>especially on a common cruising-ground.<br><br><br><br>If two strangers crossing the Pine Barrens in New York State, or the<br><br>equally desolate Salisbury Plain in England; if casually encountering<br><br>each other in such inhospitable wilds, these twain, for the life of<br><br>them, cannot well avoid a mutual salutation; and stopping for a<br><br>moment to interchange the news; and, perhaps, sitting down for a<br><br>while and resting in concert: then, how much more natural that upon<br><br>the illimitable Pine Barrens and Salisbury Plains of the sea, two<br><br>whaling vessels descrying each other at the ends of the earth--off<br><br>lone Fanning's Island, or the far away King's Mills; how much more<br><br>natural, I say, that under such circumstances these ships should not<br><br>only interchange hails, but come into still closer, more friendly and<br><br>sociable contact.  And especially would this seem to be a matter of<br><br>course, in the case of vessels owned in one seaport, and whose<br><br>captains, officers, and not a few of the men are personally known to<br><br>each other; and consequently, have all sorts of dear domestic things<br><br>to talk about.<br><br><br><br>For the long absent ship, the outward-bounder, perhaps, has letters<br><br>on board; at any rate, she will be sure to let her have some papers<br><br>of a date a year or two later than the last one on her blurred and<br><br>thumb-worn files.  And in return for that courtesy, the outward-bound<br><br>ship would receive the latest whaling intelligence from the<br><br>cruising-ground to which she may be destined, a thing of the utmost<br><br>importance to her.  And in degree, all this will hold true concerning<br><br>whaling vessels crossing each other's track on the cruising-ground<br><br>itself, even though they are equally long absent from home.  For one<br><br>of them may have received a transfer of letters from some third, and<br><br>now far remote vessel; and some of those letters may be for the<br><br>people of the ship she now meets.  Besides, they would exchange the<br><br>whaling news, and have an agreeable chat.  For not only would they<br><br>meet with all the sympathies of sailors, but likewise with all the<br><br>peculiar congenialities arising from a common pursuit and mutually<br><br>shared privations and perils.<br><br><br><br>Nor would difference of country make any very essential difference;<br><br>that is, so long as both parties speak one language, as is the case<br><br>with Americans and English.  Though, to be sure, from the small<br><br>number of English whalers, such meetings do not very often occur, and<br><br>when they do occur there is too apt to be a sort of shyness between<br><br>them; for your Englishman is rather reserved, and your Yankee, he<br><br>does not fancy that sort of thing in anybody but himself.  Besides,<br><br>the English whalers sometimes affect a kind of metropolitan<br><br>superiority over the American whalers; regarding the long, lean<br><br>Nantucketer, with his nondescript provincialisms, as a sort of<br><br>sea-peasant.  But where this superiority in the English whalemen<br><br>does really consist, it would be hard to say, seeing that the Yankees<br><br>in one day, collectively, kill more whales than all the English,<br><br>collectively, in ten years.  But this is a harmless little foible in<br><br>the English whale-hunters, which the Nantucketer does not take much<br><br>to heart; probably, because he knows that he has a few foibles<br><br>himself.<br><br><br><br>So, then, we see that of all ships separately sailing the sea, the<br><br>whalers have most reason to be sociable--and they are so.  Whereas,<br><br>some merchant ships crossing each other's wake in the mid-Atlantic,<br><br>will oftentimes pass on without so much as a single word of<br><br>recognition, mutually cutting each other on the high seas, like a<br><br>brace of dandies in Broadway; and all the time indulging, perhaps, in<br><br>finical criticism upon each other's rig.  As for Men-of-War, when<br><br>they chance to meet at sea, they first go through such a string of<br><br>silly bowings and scrapings, such a ducking of ensigns, that there<br><br>does not seem to be much right-down hearty good-will and brotherly<br><br>love about it at all.  As touching Slave-ships meeting, why, they are<br><br>in such a prodigious hurry, they run away from each other as soon as<br><br>possible.  And as for Pirates, when they chance to cross each other's<br><br>cross-bones, the first hail is--"How many skulls?"--the same way that<br><br>whalers hail--"How many barrels?"  And that question once answered,<br><br>pirates straightway steer apart, for they are infernal villains on<br><br>both sides, and don't like to see overmuch of each other's villanous<br><br>likenesses.<br><br><br><br>But look at the godly, honest, unostentatious, hospitable, sociable,<br><br>free-and-easy whaler!  What does the whaler do when she meets another<br><br>whaler in any sort of decent weather?  She has a "GAM," a thing so<br><br>utterly unknown to all other ships that they never heard of the name<br><br>even; and if by chance they should hear of it, they only grin at it,<br><br>and repeat gamesome stuff about "spouters" and "blubber-boilers," and<br><br>such like pretty exclamations.  Why it is that all Merchant-seamen,<br><br>and also all Pirates and Man-of-War's men, and Slave-ship sailors,<br><br>cherish such a scornful feeling towards Whale-ships; this is a<br><br>question it would be hard to answer.  Because, in the case of<br><br>pirates, say, I should like to know whether that profession of theirs<br><br>has any peculiar glory about it.  It sometimes ends in uncommon<br><br>elevation, indeed; but only at the gallows.  And besides, when a man<br><br>is elevated in that odd fashion, he has no proper foundation for his<br><br>superior altitude.  Hence, I conclude, that in boasting himself to be<br><br>high lifted above a whaleman, in that assertion the pirate has no<br><br>solid basis to stand on.<br><br><br><br>But what is a GAM?  You might wear out your index-finger running up<br><br>and down the columns of dictionaries, and never find the word.  Dr.<br><br>Johnson never attained to that erudition; Noah Webster's ark does not<br><br>hold it.  Nevertheless, this same expressive word has now for many<br><br>years been in constant use among some fifteen thousand true born<br><br>Yankees.  Certainly, it needs a definition, and should be<br><br>incorporated into the Lexicon.  With that view, let me learnedly<br><br>define it.<br><br><br><br>GAM.  NOUN--A SOCIAL MEETING OF TWO (OR MORE) WHALESHIPS, GENERALLY<br><br>ON A CRUISING-GROUND; WHEN, AFTER EXCHANGING HAILS, THEY EXCHANGE<br><br>VISITS BY BOATS' CREWS; THE TWO CAPTAINS REMAINING, FOR THE TIME, ON<br><br>BOARD OF ONE SHIP, AND THE TWO CHIEF MATES ON THE OTHER.<br><br><br><br>There is another little item about Gamming which must not be<br><br>forgotten here.  All professions have their own little peculiarities<br><br>of detail; so has the whale fishery.  In a pirate, man-of-war, or<br><br>slave ship, when the captain is rowed anywhere in his boat, he always<br><br>sits in the stern sheets on a comfortable, sometimes cushioned seat<br><br>there, and often steers himself with a pretty little milliner's<br><br>tiller decorated with gay cords and ribbons.  But the whale-boat has<br><br>no seat astern, no sofa of that sort whatever, and no tiller at all.<br><br>High times indeed, if whaling captains were wheeled about the water<br><br>on castors like gouty old aldermen in patent chairs.  And as for a<br><br>tiller, the whale-boat never admits of any such effeminacy; and<br><br>therefore as in gamming a complete boat's crew must leave the ship,<br><br>and hence as the boat steerer or harpooneer is of the number, that<br><br>subordinate is the steersman upon the occasion, and the captain,<br><br>having no place to sit in, is pulled off to his visit all standing<br><br>like a pine tree.  And often you will notice that being conscious of<br><br>the eyes of the whole visible world resting on him from the sides of<br><br>the two ships, this standing captain is all alive to the importance<br><br>of sustaining his dignity by maintaining his legs.  Nor is this any<br><br>very easy matter; for in his rear is the immense projecting steering<br><br>oar hitting him now and then in the small of his back, the after-oar<br><br>reciprocating by rapping his knees in front.  He is thus completely<br><br>wedged before and behind, and can only expand himself sideways by<br><br>settling down on his stretched legs; but a sudden, violent pitch of<br><br>the boat will often go far to topple him, because length of<br><br>foundation is nothing without corresponding breadth.  Merely make a<br><br>spread angle of two poles, and you cannot stand them up.  Then,<br><br>again, it would never do in plain sight of the world's riveted eyes,<br><br>it would never do, I say, for this straddling captain to be seen<br><br>steadying himself the slightest particle by catching hold of anything<br><br>with his hands; indeed, as token of his entire, buoyant self-command,<br><br>he generally carries his hands in his trowsers' pockets; but perhaps<br><br>being generally very large, heavy hands, he carries them there for<br><br>ballast.  Nevertheless there have occurred instances, well<br><br>authenticated ones too, where the captain has been known for an<br><br>uncommonly critical moment or two, in a sudden squall say--to seize<br><br>hold of the nearest oarsman's hair, and hold on there like grim<br><br>death.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 54<br><br><br><br>The Town-Ho's Story.<br><br><br><br><br><br>(AS TOLD AT THE GOLDEN INN)<br><br><br><br><br><br>The Cape of Good Hope, and all the watery region round about there,<br><br>is much like some noted four corners of a great highway, where you<br><br>meet more travellers than in any other part.<br><br><br><br>It was not very long after speaking the Goney that another<br><br>homeward-bound whaleman, the Town-Ho,* was encountered.  She was<br><br>manned almost wholly by Polynesians.  In the short gam that ensued<br><br>she gave us strong news of Moby Dick.  To some the general interest<br><br>in the White Whale was now wildly heightened by a circumstance of the<br><br>Town-Ho's story, which seemed obscurely to involve with the whale a<br><br>certain wondrous, inverted visitation of one of those so called<br><br>judgments of God which at times are said to overtake some men.  This<br><br>latter circumstance, with its own particular accompaniments, forming<br><br>what may be called the secret part of the tragedy about to be<br><br>narrated, never reached the ears of Captain Ahab or his mates.  For<br><br>that secret part of the story was unknown to the captain of the<br><br>Town-Ho himself.  It was the private property of three confederate<br><br>white seamen of that ship, one of whom, it seems, communicated it to<br><br>Tashtego with Romish injunctions of secrecy, but the following night<br><br>Tashtego rambled in his sleep, and revealed so much of it in that<br><br>way, that when he was wakened he could not well withhold the rest.<br><br>Nevertheless, so potent an influence did this thing have on those<br><br>seamen in the Pequod who came to the full knowledge of it, and by<br><br>such a strange delicacy, to call it so, were they governed in this<br><br>matter, that they kept the secret among themselves so that it never<br><br>transpired abaft the Pequod's main-mast.  Interweaving in its proper<br><br>place this darker thread with the story as publicly narrated on the<br><br>ship, the whole of this strange affair I now proceed to put on<br><br>lasting record.<br><br><br><br><br><br>*The ancient whale-cry upon first sighting a whale from the<br><br>mast-head, still used by whalemen in hunting the famous Gallipagos<br><br>terrapin.<br><br><br><br><br><br>For my humor's sake, I shall preserve the style in which I once<br><br>narrated it at Lima, to a lounging circle of my Spanish friends, one<br><br>saint's eve, smoking upon the thick-gilt tiled piazza of the Golden<br><br>Inn.  Of those fine cavaliers, the young Dons, Pedro and Sebastian,<br><br>were on the closer terms with me; and hence the interluding questions<br><br>they occasionally put, and which are duly answered at the time.<br><br><br><br>"Some two years prior to my first learning the events which I am<br><br>about rehearsing to you, gentlemen, the Town-Ho, Sperm Whaler of<br><br>Nantucket, was cruising in your Pacific here, not very many days'<br><br>sail eastward from the eaves of this good Golden Inn.  She was<br><br>somewhere to the northward of the Line.  One morning upon handling<br><br>the pumps, according to daily usage, it was observed that she made<br><br>more water in her hold than common.  They supposed a sword-fish had<br><br>stabbed her, gentlemen.  But the captain, having some unusual reason<br><br>for believing that rare good luck awaited him in those latitudes; and<br><br>therefore being very averse to quit them, and the leak not being then<br><br>considered at all dangerous, though, indeed, they could not find it<br><br>after searching the hold as low down as was possible in rather heavy<br><br>weather, the ship still continued her cruisings, the mariners working<br><br>at the pumps at wide and easy intervals; but no good luck came; more<br><br>days went by, and not only was the leak yet undiscovered, but it<br><br>sensibly increased.  So much so, that now taking some alarm, the<br><br>captain, making all sail, stood away for the nearest harbor among the<br><br>islands, there to have his hull hove out and repaired.<br><br><br><br>"Though no small passage was before her, yet, if the commonest chance<br><br>favoured, he did not at all fear that his ship would founder by the<br><br>way, because his pumps were of the best, and being periodically<br><br>relieved at them, those six-and-thirty men of his could easily keep<br><br>the ship free; never mind if the leak should double on her.  In<br><br>truth, well nigh the whole of this passage being attended by very<br><br>prosperous breezes, the Town-Ho had all but certainly arrived in<br><br>perfect safety at her port without the occurrence of the least<br><br>fatality, had it not been for the brutal overbearing of Radney, the<br><br>mate, a Vineyarder, and the bitterly provoked vengeance of Steelkilt,<br><br>a Lakeman and desperado from Buffalo.<br><br><br><br>"'Lakeman!--Buffalo!  Pray, what is a Lakeman, and where is Buffalo?'<br><br>said Don Sebastian, rising in his swinging mat of grass.<br><br><br><br>"On the eastern shore of our Lake Erie, Don; but--I crave your<br><br>courtesy--may be, you shall soon hear further of all that.  Now,<br><br>gentlemen, in square-sail brigs and three-masted ships, well-nigh as<br><br>large and stout as any that ever sailed out of your old Callao to far<br><br>Manilla; this Lakeman, in the land-locked heart of our America, had<br><br>yet been nurtured by all those agrarian freebooting impressions<br><br>popularly connected with the open ocean.  For in their interflowing<br><br>aggregate, those grand fresh-water seas of ours,--Erie, and Ontario,<br><br>and Huron, and Superior, and Michigan,--possess an ocean-like<br><br>expansiveness, with many of the ocean's noblest traits; with many of<br><br>its rimmed varieties of races and of climes.  They contain round<br><br>archipelagoes of romantic isles, even as the Polynesian waters do; in<br><br>large part, are shored by two great contrasting nations, as the<br><br>Atlantic is; they furnish long maritime approaches to our numerous<br><br>territorial colonies from the East, dotted all round their banks;<br><br>here and there are frowned upon by batteries, and by the goat-like<br><br>craggy guns of lofty Mackinaw; they have heard the fleet thunderings<br><br>of naval victories; at intervals, they yield their beaches to wild<br><br>barbarians, whose red painted faces flash from out their peltry<br><br>wigwams; for leagues and leagues are flanked by ancient and unentered<br><br>forests, where the gaunt pines stand like serried lines of kings in<br><br>Gothic genealogies; those same woods harboring wild Afric beasts of<br><br>prey, and silken creatures whose exported furs give robes to Tartar<br><br>Emperors; they mirror the paved capitals of Buffalo and Cleveland, as<br><br>well as Winnebago villages; they float alike the full-rigged merchant<br><br>ship, the armed cruiser of the State, the steamer, and the beech<br><br>canoe; they are swept by Borean and dismasting blasts as direful as<br><br>any that lash the salted wave; they know what shipwrecks are, for out<br><br>of sight of land, however inland, they have drowned full many a<br><br>midnight ship with all its shrieking crew.  Thus, gentlemen, though<br><br>an inlander, Steelkilt was wild-ocean born, and wild-ocean nurtured;<br><br>as much of an audacious mariner as any.  And for Radney, though in<br><br>his infancy he may have laid him down on the lone Nantucket beach, to<br><br>nurse at his maternal sea; though in after life he had long followed<br><br>our austere Atlantic and your contemplative Pacific; yet was he quite<br><br>as vengeful and full of social quarrel as the backwoods seaman, fresh<br><br>from the latitudes of buck-horn handled bowie-knives.  Yet was this<br><br>Nantucketer a man with some good-hearted traits; and this Lakeman, a<br><br>mariner, who though a sort of devil indeed, might yet by inflexible<br><br>firmness, only tempered by that common decency of human recognition<br><br>which is the meanest slave's right; thus treated, this Steelkilt had<br><br>long been retained harmless and docile.  At all events, he had proved<br><br>so thus far; but Radney was doomed and made mad, and Steelkilt--but,<br><br>gentlemen, you shall hear.<br><br><br><br>"It was not more than a day or two at the furthest after pointing her<br><br>prow for her island haven, that the Town-Ho's leak seemed again<br><br>increasing, but only so as to require an hour or more at the pumps<br><br>every day.  You must know that in a settled and civilized ocean like<br><br>our Atlantic, for example, some skippers think little of pumping<br><br>their whole way across it; though of a still, sleepy night, should<br><br>the officer of the deck happen to forget his duty in that respect,<br><br>the probability would be that he and his shipmates would never again<br><br>remember it, on account of all hands gently subsiding to the bottom.<br><br>Nor in the solitary and savage seas far from you to the westward,<br><br>gentlemen, is it altogether unusual for ships to keep clanging at<br><br>their pump-handles in full chorus even for a voyage of considerable<br><br>length; that is, if it lie along a tolerably accessible coast, or if<br><br>any other reasonable retreat is afforded them.  It is only when a<br><br>leaky vessel is in some very out of the way part of those waters,<br><br>some really landless latitude, that her captain begins to feel a<br><br>little anxious.<br><br><br><br>"Much this way had it been with the Town-Ho; so when her leak was<br><br>found gaining once more, there was in truth some small concern<br><br>manifested by several of her company; especially by Radney the mate.<br><br>He commanded the upper sails to be well hoisted, sheeted home anew,<br><br>and every way expanded to the breeze.  Now this Radney, I suppose,<br><br>was as little of a coward, and as little inclined to any sort of<br><br>nervous apprehensiveness touching his own person as any fearless,<br><br>unthinking creature on land or on sea that you can conveniently<br><br>imagine, gentlemen.  Therefore when he betrayed this solicitude about<br><br>the safety of the ship, some of the seamen declared that it was only<br><br>on account of his being a part owner in her.  So when they were<br><br>working that evening at the pumps, there was on this head no small<br><br>gamesomeness slily going on among them, as they stood with their feet<br><br>continually overflowed by the rippling clear water; clear as any<br><br>mountain spring, gentlemen--that bubbling from the pumps ran across<br><br>the deck, and poured itself out in steady spouts at the lee<br><br>scupper-holes.<br><br><br><br>"Now, as you well know, it is not seldom the case in this<br><br>conventional world of ours--watery or otherwise; that when a person<br><br>placed in command over his fellow-men finds one of them to be very<br><br>significantly his superior in general pride of manhood, straightway<br><br>against that man he conceives an unconquerable dislike and<br><br>bitterness; and if he have a chance he will pull down and pulverize<br><br>that subaltern's tower, and make a little heap of dust of it.  Be<br><br>this conceit of mine as it may, gentlemen, at all events Steelkilt<br><br>was a tall and noble animal with a head like a Roman, and a flowing<br><br>golden beard like the tasseled housings of your last viceroy's<br><br>snorting charger; and a brain, and a heart, and a soul in him,<br><br>gentlemen, which had made Steelkilt Charlemagne, had he been born son<br><br>to Charlemagne's father.  But Radney, the mate, was ugly as a mule;<br><br>yet as hardy, as stubborn, as malicious.  He did not love Steelkilt,<br><br>and Steelkilt knew it.<br><br><br><br>"Espying the mate drawing near as he was toiling at the pump with the<br><br>rest, the Lakeman affected not to notice him, but unawed, went on<br><br>with his gay banterings.<br><br><br><br>"'Aye, aye, my merry lads, it's a lively leak this; hold a cannikin,<br><br>one of ye, and let's have a taste.  By the Lord, it's worth bottling!<br><br>I tell ye what, men, old Rad's investment must go for it! he had<br><br>best cut away his part of the hull and tow it home.  The fact is,<br><br>boys, that sword-fish only began the job; he's come back again with a<br><br>gang of ship-carpenters, saw-fish, and file-fish, and what not; and<br><br>the whole posse of 'em are now hard at work cutting and slashing at<br><br>the bottom; making improvements, I suppose.  If old Rad were here<br><br>now, I'd tell him to jump overboard and scatter 'em.  They're playing<br><br>the devil with his estate, I can tell him.  But he's a simple old<br><br>soul,--Rad, and a beauty too.  Boys, they say the rest of his<br><br>property is invested in looking-glasses.  I wonder if he'd give a<br><br>poor devil like me the model of his nose.'<br><br><br><br>"'Damn your eyes! what's that pump stopping for?' roared Radney,<br><br>pretending not to have heard the sailors' talk.  'Thunder away at<br><br>it!'<br><br><br><br>'Aye, aye, sir,' said Steelkilt, merry as a cricket.  'Lively, boys,<br><br>lively, now!'  And with that the pump clanged like fifty<br><br>fire-engines; the men tossed their hats off to it, and ere long that<br><br>peculiar gasping of the lungs was heard which denotes the fullest<br><br>tension of life's utmost energies.<br><br><br><br>"Quitting the pump at last, with the rest of his band, the Lakeman<br><br>went forward all panting, and sat himself down on the windlass; his<br><br>face fiery red, his eyes bloodshot, and wiping the profuse sweat from<br><br>his brow.  Now what cozening fiend it was, gentlemen, that possessed<br><br>Radney to meddle with such a man in that corporeally exasperated<br><br>state, I know not; but so it happened.  Intolerably striding along<br><br>the deck, the mate commanded him to get a broom and sweep down the<br><br>planks, and also a shovel, and remove some offensive matters<br><br>consequent upon allowing a pig to run at large.<br><br><br><br>"Now, gentlemen, sweeping a ship's deck at sea is a piece of<br><br>household work which in all times but raging gales is regularly<br><br>attended to every evening; it has been known to be done in the case<br><br>of ships actually foundering at the time.  Such, gentlemen, is the<br><br>inflexibility of sea-usages and the instinctive love of neatness in<br><br>seamen; some of whom would not willingly drown without first washing<br><br>their faces.  But in all vessels this broom business is the<br><br>prescriptive province of the boys, if boys there be aboard.  Besides,<br><br>it was the stronger men in the Town-Ho that had been divided into<br><br>gangs, taking turns at the pumps; and being the most athletic seaman<br><br>of them all, Steelkilt had been regularly assigned captain of one of<br><br>the gangs; consequently he should have been freed from any trivial<br><br>business not connected with truly nautical duties, such being the<br><br>case with his comrades.  I mention all these particulars so that you<br><br>may understand exactly how this affair stood between the two men.<br><br><br><br>"But there was more than this: the order about the shovel was almost<br><br>as plainly meant to sting and insult Steelkilt, as though Radney had<br><br>spat in his face.  Any man who has gone sailor in a whale-ship will<br><br>understand this; and all this and doubtless much more, the Lakeman<br><br>fully comprehended when the mate uttered his command.  But as he sat<br><br>still for a moment, and as he steadfastly looked into the mate's<br><br>malignant eye and perceived the stacks of powder-casks heaped up in<br><br>him and the slow-match silently burning along towards them; as he<br><br>instinctively saw all this, that strange forbearance and<br><br>unwillingness to stir up the deeper passionateness in any already<br><br>ireful being--a repugnance most felt, when felt at all, by really<br><br>valiant men even when aggrieved--this nameless phantom feeling,<br><br>gentlemen, stole over Steelkilt.<br><br><br><br>"Therefore, in his ordinary tone, only a little broken by the bodily<br><br>exhaustion he was temporarily in, he answered him saying that<br><br>sweeping the deck was not his business, and he would not do it.  And<br><br>then, without at all alluding to the shovel, he pointed to three<br><br>lads as the customary sweepers; who, not being billeted at the<br><br>pumps, had done little or nothing all day.  To this, Radney replied<br><br>with an oath, in a most domineering and outrageous manner<br><br>unconditionally reiterating his command; meanwhile advancing upon the<br><br>still seated Lakeman, with an uplifted cooper's club hammer which he<br><br>had snatched from a cask near by.<br><br><br><br>"Heated and irritated as he was by his spasmodic toil at the pumps,<br><br>for all his first nameless feeling of forbearance the sweating<br><br>Steelkilt could but ill brook this bearing in the mate; but somehow<br><br>still smothering the conflagration within him, without speaking he<br><br>remained doggedly rooted to his seat, till at last the incensed<br><br>Radney shook the hammer within a few inches of his face, furiously<br><br>commanding him to do his bidding.<br><br><br><br>"Steelkilt rose, and slowly retreating round the windlass, steadily<br><br>followed by the mate with his menacing hammer, deliberately repeated<br><br>his intention not to obey.  Seeing, however, that his forbearance had<br><br>not the slightest effect, by an awful and unspeakable intimation with<br><br>his twisted hand he warned off the foolish and infatuated man; but it<br><br>was to no purpose.  And in this way the two went once slowly round<br><br>the windlass; when, resolved at last no longer to retreat, bethinking<br><br>him that he had now forborne as much as comported with his humor, the<br><br>Lakeman paused on the hatches and thus spoke to the officer:<br><br><br><br>"'Mr. Radney, I will not obey you.  Take that hammer away, or look to<br><br>yourself.'  But the predestinated mate coming still closer to him,<br><br>where the Lakeman stood fixed, now shook the heavy hammer within an<br><br>inch of his teeth; meanwhile repeating a string of insufferable<br><br>maledictions.
