Retreating not the thousandth part of an inch;<br><br>stabbing him in the eye with the unflinching poniard of his glance,<br><br>Steelkilt, clenching his right hand behind him and creepingly drawing<br><br>it back, told his persecutor that if the hammer but grazed his cheek<br><br>he (Steelkilt) would murder him.  But, gentlemen, the fool had been<br><br>branded for the slaughter by the gods.  Immediately the hammer<br><br>touched the cheek; the next instant the lower jaw of the mate was<br><br>stove in his head; he fell on the hatch spouting blood like a whale.<br><br><br><br>"Ere the cry could go aft Steelkilt was shaking one of the backstays<br><br>leading far aloft to where two of his comrades were standing their<br><br>mastheads.  They were both Canallers.<br><br><br><br>"'Canallers!' cried Don Pedro.  'We have seen many whale-ships in our<br><br>harbours, but never heard of your Canallers.  Pardon: who and what are<br><br>they?'<br><br><br><br>"'Canallers, Don, are the boatmen belonging to our grand Erie Canal.<br><br>You must have heard of it.'<br><br><br><br>"'Nay, Senor; hereabouts in this dull, warm, most lazy, and<br><br>hereditary land, we know but little of your vigorous North.'<br><br><br><br>"'Aye?  Well then, Don, refill my cup.  Your chicha's very fine; and<br><br>ere proceeding further I will tell ye what our Canallers are; for<br><br>such information may throw side-light upon my story.'<br><br><br><br>"For three hundred and sixty miles, gentlemen, through the entire<br><br>breadth of the state of New York; through numerous populous cities<br><br>and most thriving villages; through long, dismal, uninhabited swamps,<br><br>and affluent, cultivated fields, unrivalled for fertility; by<br><br>billiard-room and bar-room; through the holy-of-holies of great<br><br>forests; on Roman arches over Indian rivers; through sun and shade;<br><br>by happy hearts or broken; through all the wide contrasting scenery<br><br>of those noble Mohawk counties; and especially, by rows of snow-white<br><br>chapels, whose spires stand almost like milestones, flows one<br><br>continual stream of Venetianly corrupt and often lawless life.<br><br>There's your true Ashantee, gentlemen; there howl your pagans; where<br><br>you ever find them, next door to you; under the long-flung shadow,<br><br>and the snug patronising lee of churches.  For by some curious<br><br>fatality, as it is often noted of your metropolitan freebooters that<br><br>they ever encamp around the halls of justice, so sinners, gentlemen,<br><br>most abound in holiest vicinities.<br><br><br><br>"'Is that a friar passing?' said Don Pedro, looking downwards into<br><br>the crowded plazza, with humorous concern.<br><br><br><br>"'Well for our northern friend, Dame Isabella's Inquisition wanes in<br><br>Lima,' laughed Don Sebastian.  'Proceed, Senor.'<br><br><br><br>"'A moment!  Pardon!' cried another of the company.  'In the name of<br><br>all us Limeese, I but desire to express to you, sir sailor, that we<br><br>have by no means overlooked your delicacy in not substituting present<br><br>Lima for distant Venice in your corrupt comparison.  Oh! do not bow<br><br>and look surprised; you know the proverb all along this<br><br>coast--"Corrupt as Lima."  It but bears out your saying, too;<br><br>churches more plentiful than billiard-tables, and for ever open--and<br><br>"Corrupt as Lima."  So, too, Venice; I have been there; the holy city<br><br>of the blessed evangelist, St. Mark!--St. Dominic, purge it!  Your<br><br>cup!  Thanks: here I refill; now, you pour out again.'<br><br><br><br>"Freely depicted in his own vocation, gentlemen, the Canaller would<br><br>make a fine dramatic hero, so abundantly and picturesquely wicked is<br><br>he.  Like Mark Antony, for days and days along his green-turfed,<br><br>flowery Nile, he indolently floats, openly toying with his<br><br>red-cheeked Cleopatra, ripening his apricot thigh upon the sunny<br><br>deck.  But ashore, all this effeminacy is dashed.  The brigandish<br><br>guise which the Canaller so proudly sports; his slouched and<br><br>gaily-ribboned hat betoken his grand features.  A terror to the<br><br>smiling innocence of the villages through which he floats; his swart<br><br>visage and bold swagger are not unshunned in cities.  Once a vagabond<br><br>on his own canal, I have received good turns from one of these<br><br>Canallers; I thank him heartily; would fain be not ungrateful; but it<br><br>is often one of the prime redeeming qualities of your man of<br><br>violence, that at times he has as stiff an arm to back a poor<br><br>stranger in a strait, as to plunder a wealthy one.  In sum,<br><br>gentlemen, what the wildness of this canal life is, is emphatically<br><br>evinced by this; that our wild whale-fishery contains so many of its<br><br>most finished graduates, and that scarce any race of mankind, except<br><br>Sydney men, are so much distrusted by our whaling captains.  Nor does<br><br>it at all diminish the curiousness of this matter, that to many<br><br>thousands of our rural boys and young men born along its line, the<br><br>probationary life of the Grand Canal furnishes the sole transition<br><br>between quietly reaping in a Christian corn-field, and recklessly<br><br>ploughing the waters of the most barbaric seas.<br><br><br><br>"'I see!  I see!' impetuously exclaimed Don Pedro, spilling his<br><br>chicha upon his silvery ruffles.  'No need to travel!  The world's<br><br>one Lima.  I had thought, now, that at your temperate North the<br><br>generations were cold and holy as the hills.--But the story.'<br><br><br><br>"I left off, gentlemen, where the Lakeman shook the backstay.<br><br>Hardly had he done so, when he was surrounded by the three junior<br><br>mates and the four harpooneers, who all crowded him to the deck.  But<br><br>sliding down the ropes like baleful comets, the two Canallers rushed<br><br>into the uproar, and sought to drag their man out of it towards the<br><br>forecastle.  Others of the sailors joined with them in this attempt,<br><br>and a twisted turmoil ensued; while standing out of harm's way, the<br><br>valiant captain danced up and down with a whale-pike, calling upon<br><br>his officers to manhandle that atrocious scoundrel, and smoke him<br><br>along to the quarter-deck.  At intervals, he ran close up to the<br><br>revolving border of the confusion, and prying into the heart of it<br><br>with his pike, sought to prick out the object of his resentment.  But<br><br>Steelkilt and his desperadoes were too much for them all; they<br><br>succeeded in gaining the forecastle deck, where, hastily slewing<br><br>about three or four large casks in a line with the windlass, these<br><br>sea-Parisians entrenched themselves behind the barricade.<br><br><br><br>"'Come out of that, ye pirates!' roared the captain, now menacing<br><br>them with a pistol in each hand, just brought to him by the steward.<br><br>'Come out of that, ye cut-throats!'<br><br><br><br>"Steelkilt leaped on the barricade, and striding up and down there,<br><br>defied the worst the pistols could do; but gave the captain to<br><br>understand distinctly, that his (Steelkilt's) death would be the<br><br>signal for a murderous mutiny on the part of all hands.  Fearing in<br><br>his heart lest this might prove but too true, the captain a little<br><br>desisted, but still commanded the insurgents instantly to return to<br><br>their duty.<br><br><br><br>"'Will you promise not to touch us, if we do?' demanded their<br><br>ringleader.<br><br><br><br>"'Turn to! turn to!--I make no promise;--to your duty!  Do you want<br><br>to sink the ship, by knocking off at a time like this?  Turn to!' and<br><br>he once more raised a pistol.<br><br><br><br>"'Sink the ship?' cried Steelkilt.  'Aye, let her sink.  Not a man of<br><br>us turns to, unless you swear not to raise a rope-yarn against us.<br><br>What say ye, men?' turning to his comrades.  A fierce cheer was their<br><br>response.<br><br><br><br>"The Lakeman now patrolled the barricade, all the while keeping his<br><br>eye on the Captain, and jerking out such sentences as these:--'It's<br><br>not our fault; we didn't want it; I told him to take his hammer away;<br><br>it was boy's business; he might have known me before this; I told him<br><br>not to prick the buffalo; I believe I have broken a finger here<br><br>against his cursed jaw; ain't those mincing knives down in the<br><br>forecastle there, men? look to those handspikes, my hearties.<br><br>Captain, by God, look to yourself; say the word; don't be a fool;<br><br>forget it all; we are ready to turn to; treat us decently, and we're<br><br>your men; but we won't be flogged.'<br><br><br><br>"'Turn to!  I make no promises, turn to, I say!'<br><br><br><br>"'Look ye, now,' cried the Lakeman, flinging out his arm towards him,<br><br>'there are a few of us here (and I am one of them) who have shipped<br><br>for the cruise, d'ye see; now as you well know, sir, we can claim our<br><br>discharge as soon as the anchor is down; so we don't want a row; it's<br><br>not our interest; we want to be peaceable; we are ready to work, but<br><br>we won't be flogged.'<br><br><br><br>"'Turn to!' roared the Captain.<br><br><br><br>"Steelkilt glanced round him a moment, and then said:--'I tell you<br><br>what it is now, Captain, rather than kill ye, and be hung for such a<br><br>shabby rascal, we won't lift a hand against ye unless ye attack us;<br><br>but till you say the word about not flogging us, we don't do a hand's<br><br>turn.'<br><br><br><br>"'Down into the forecastle then, down with ye, I'll keep ye there<br><br>till ye're sick of it.  Down ye go.'<br><br><br><br>"'Shall we?' cried the ringleader to his men.  Most of them were<br><br>against it; but at length, in obedience to Steelkilt, they preceded<br><br>him down into their dark den, growlingly disappearing, like bears<br><br>into a cave.<br><br><br><br>"As the Lakeman's bare head was just level with the planks, the<br><br>Captain and his posse leaped the barricade, and rapidly drawing over<br><br>the slide of the scuttle, planted their group of hands upon it, and<br><br>loudly called for the steward to bring the heavy brass padlock<br><br>belonging to the companionway.<br><br><br><br>Then opening the slide a little, the Captain whispered something down<br><br>the crack, closed it, and turned the key upon them--ten in<br><br>number--leaving on deck some twenty or more, who thus far had<br><br>remained neutral.<br><br><br><br>"All night a wide-awake watch was kept by all the officers, forward<br><br>and aft, especially about the forecastle scuttle and fore hatchway;<br><br>at which last place it was feared the insurgents might emerge, after<br><br>breaking through the bulkhead below.  But the hours of darkness<br><br>passed in peace; the men who still remained at their duty toiling<br><br>hard at the pumps, whose clinking and clanking at intervals through<br><br>the dreary night dismally resounded through the ship.<br><br><br><br>"At sunrise the Captain went forward, and knocking on the deck,<br><br>summoned the prisoners to work; but with a yell they refused.  Water<br><br>was then lowered down to them, and a couple of handfuls of biscuit<br><br>were tossed after it; when again turning the key upon them and<br><br>pocketing it, the Captain returned to the quarter-deck.  Twice every<br><br>day for three days this was repeated; but on the fourth morning a<br><br>confused wrangling, and then a scuffling was heard, as the customary<br><br>summons was delivered; and suddenly four men burst up from the<br><br>forecastle, saying they were ready to turn to.  The fetid closeness<br><br>of the air, and a famishing diet, united perhaps to some fears of<br><br>ultimate retribution, had constrained them to surrender at<br><br>discretion.  Emboldened by this, the Captain reiterated his demand to<br><br>the rest, but Steelkilt shouted up to him a terrific hint to stop his<br><br>babbling and betake himself where he belonged.  On the fifth morning<br><br>three others of the mutineers bolted up into the air from the<br><br>desperate arms below that sought to restrain them.  Only three were<br><br>left.<br><br><br><br>"'Better turn to, now?' said the Captain with a heartless jeer.<br><br><br><br>"'Shut us up again, will ye!' cried Steelkilt.<br><br><br><br>"'Oh certainly,' the Captain, and the key clicked.<br><br><br><br>"It was at this point, gentlemen, that enraged by the defection of<br><br>seven of his former associates, and stung by the mocking voice that<br><br>had last hailed him, and maddened by his long entombment in a place<br><br>as black as the bowels of despair; it was then that Steelkilt<br><br>proposed to the two Canallers, thus far apparently of one mind with<br><br>him, to burst out of their hole at the next summoning of the<br><br>garrison; and armed with their keen mincing knives (long, crescentic,<br><br>heavy implements with a handle at each end) run amuck from the<br><br>bowsprit to the taffrail; and if by any devilishness of desperation<br><br>possible, seize the ship.  For himself, he would do this, he said,<br><br>whether they joined him or not.  That was the last night he should<br><br>spend in that den.  But the scheme met with no opposition on the part<br><br>of the other two; they swore they were ready for that, or for any<br><br>other mad thing, for anything in short but a surrender.  And what was<br><br>more, they each insisted upon being the first man on deck, when the<br><br>time to make the rush should come.  But to this their leader as<br><br>fiercely objected, reserving that priority for himself; particularly<br><br>as his two comrades would not yield, the one to the other, in the<br><br>matter; and both of them could not be first, for the ladder would but<br><br>admit one man at a time.  And here, gentlemen, the foul play of these<br><br>miscreants must come out.<br><br><br><br>"Upon hearing the frantic project of their leader, each in his own<br><br>separate soul had suddenly lighted, it would seem, upon the same<br><br>piece of treachery, namely: to be foremost in breaking out, in<br><br>order to be the first of the three, though the last of the ten, to<br><br>surrender; and thereby secure whatever small chance of pardon such<br><br>conduct might merit.  But when Steelkilt made known his determination<br><br>still to lead them to the last, they in some way, by some subtle<br><br>chemistry of villany, mixed their before secret treacheries together;<br><br>and when their leader fell into a doze, verbally opened their souls<br><br>to each other in three sentences; and bound the sleeper with cords,<br><br>and gagged him with cords; and shrieked out for the Captain at<br><br>midnight.<br><br><br><br>"Thinking murder at hand, and smelling in the dark for the blood, he<br><br>and all his armed mates and harpooneers rushed for the forecastle.<br><br>In a few minutes the scuttle was opened, and, bound hand and foot,<br><br>the still struggling ringleader was shoved up into the air by his<br><br>perfidious allies, who at once claimed the honour of securing a man<br><br>who had been fully ripe for murder.  But all these were collared, and<br><br>dragged along the deck like dead cattle; and, side by side, were<br><br>seized up into the mizzen rigging, like three quarters of meat, and<br><br>there they hung till morning.  'Damn ye,' cried the Captain, pacing<br><br>to and fro before them, 'the vultures would not touch ye, ye<br><br>villains!'<br><br><br><br>"At sunrise he summoned all hands; and separating those who had<br><br>rebelled from those who had taken no part in the mutiny, he told the<br><br>former that he had a good mind to flog them all round--thought, upon<br><br>the whole, he would do so--he ought to--justice demanded it; but for<br><br>the present, considering their timely surrender, he would let them go<br><br>with a reprimand, which he accordingly administered in the vernacular.<br><br><br><br>"'But as for you, ye carrion rogues,' turning to the three men in the<br><br>rigging--'for you, I mean to mince ye up for the try-pots;' and,<br><br>seizing a rope, he applied it with all his might to the backs of the<br><br>two traitors, till they yelled no more, but lifelessly hung their<br><br>heads sideways, as the two crucified thieves are drawn.<br><br><br><br>"'My wrist is sprained with ye!' he cried, at last; 'but there is<br><br>still rope enough left for you, my fine bantam, that wouldn't give<br><br>up.  Take that gag from his mouth, and let us hear what he can say<br><br>for himself.'<br><br><br><br>"For a moment the exhausted mutineer made a tremulous motion of his<br><br>cramped jaws, and then painfully twisting round his head, said in a<br><br>sort of hiss, 'What I say is this--and mind it well--if you flog me,<br><br>I murder you!'<br><br><br><br>"'Say ye so? then see how ye frighten me'--and the Captain drew off<br><br>with the rope to strike.<br><br><br><br>"'Best not,' hissed the Lakeman.<br><br><br><br>"'But I must,'--and the rope was once more drawn back for the stroke.<br><br><br><br>"Steelkilt here hissed out something, inaudible to all but the<br><br>Captain; who, to the amazement of all hands, started back, paced the<br><br>deck rapidly two or three times, and then suddenly throwing down his<br><br>rope, said, 'I won't do it--let him go--cut him down: d'ye hear?'<br><br><br><br>But as the junior mates were hurrying to execute the order, a pale<br><br>man, with a bandaged head, arrested them--Radney the chief mate.<br><br>Ever since the blow, he had lain in his berth; but that morning,<br><br>hearing the tumult on the deck, he had crept out, and thus far had<br><br>watched the whole scene.  Such was the state of his mouth, that he<br><br>could hardly speak; but mumbling something about his being willing<br><br>and able to do what the captain dared not attempt, he snatched the<br><br>rope and advanced to his pinioned foe.<br><br><br><br>"'You are a coward!' hissed the Lakeman.<br><br><br><br>"'So I am, but take that.'  The mate was in the very act of striking,<br><br>when another hiss stayed his uplifted arm.  He paused: and then<br><br>pausing no more, made good his word, spite of Steelkilt's threat,<br><br>whatever that might have been.  The three men were then cut down, all<br><br>hands were turned to, and, sullenly worked by the moody seamen, the<br><br>iron pumps clanged as before.<br><br><br><br>"Just after dark that day, when one watch had retired below, a clamor<br><br>was heard in the forecastle; and the two trembling traitors running<br><br>up, besieged the cabin door, saying they durst not consort with the<br><br>crew.  Entreaties, cuffs, and kicks could not drive them back, so at<br><br>their own instance they were put down in the ship's run for<br><br>salvation.  Still, no sign of mutiny reappeared among the rest.  On<br><br>the contrary, it seemed, that mainly at Steelkilt's instigation, they<br><br>had resolved to maintain the strictest peacefulness, obey all orders<br><br>to the last, and, when the ship reached port, desert her in a body.<br><br>But in order to insure the speediest end to the voyage, they all<br><br>agreed to another thing--namely, not to sing out for whales, in case<br><br>any should be discovered.  For, spite of her leak, and spite of all her<br><br>other perils, the Town-Ho still maintained her mast-heads, and her<br><br>captain was just as willing to lower for a fish that moment, as on<br><br>the day his craft first struck the cruising ground; and Radney the mate<br><br>was quite as ready to change his berth for a boat, and with his<br><br>bandaged mouth seek to gag in death the vital jaw of the whale.<br><br><br><br>"But though the Lakeman had induced the seamen to adopt this sort of<br><br>passiveness in their conduct, he kept his own counsel (at least till<br><br>all was over) concerning his own proper and private revenge upon the<br><br>man who had stung him in the ventricles of his heart.  He was in<br><br>Radney the chief mate's watch; and as if the infatuated man sought to<br><br>run more than half way to meet his doom, after the scene at the<br><br>rigging, he insisted, against the express counsel of the captain,<br><br>upon resuming the head of his watch at night.  Upon this, and one or<br><br>two other circumstances, Steelkilt systematically built the plan of<br><br>his revenge.<br><br><br><br>"During the night, Radney had an unseamanlike way of sitting on the<br><br>bulwarks of the quarter-deck, and leaning his arm upon the gunwale of<br><br>the boat which was hoisted up there, a little above the ship's side.<br><br>In this attitude, it was well known, he sometimes dozed.  There was a<br><br>considerable vacancy between the boat and the ship, and down between<br><br>this was the sea.  Steelkilt calculated his time, and found that his<br><br>next trick at the helm would come round at two o'clock, in the<br><br>morning of the third day from that in which he had been betrayed.  At<br><br>his leisure, he employed the interval in braiding something very<br><br>carefully in his watches below.<br><br><br><br>"'What are you making there?' said a shipmate.<br><br><br><br>"'What do you think? what does it look like?'<br><br><br><br>"'Like a lanyard for your bag; but it's an odd one, seems to me.'<br><br><br><br>'Yes, rather oddish,' said the Lakeman, holding it at arm's length<br><br>before him; 'but I think it will answer.  Shipmate, I haven't enough<br><br>twine,--have you any?'<br><br><br><br>"But there was none in the forecastle.<br><br><br><br>"'Then I must get some from old Rad;' and he rose to go aft.<br><br><br><br>"'You don't mean to go a begging to HIM!' said a sailor.<br><br><br><br>"'Why not?  Do you think he won't do me a turn, when it's to help<br><br>himself in the end, shipmate?' and going to the mate, he looked at<br><br>him quietly, and asked him for some twine to mend his hammock.  It<br><br>was given him--neither twine nor lanyard were seen again; but the<br><br>next night an iron ball, closely netted, partly rolled from the<br><br>pocket of the Lakeman's monkey jacket, as he was tucking the coat<br><br>into his hammock for a pillow.  Twenty-four hours after, his trick at<br><br>the silent helm--nigh to the man who was apt to doze over the grave<br><br>always ready dug to the seaman's hand--that fatal hour was then to<br><br>come; and in the fore-ordaining soul of Steelkilt, the mate was<br><br>already stark and stretched as a corpse, with his forehead crushed<br><br>in.<br><br><br><br>"But, gentlemen, a fool saved the would-be murderer from the bloody<br><br>deed he had planned.  Yet complete revenge he had, and without being<br><br>the avenger.  For by a mysterious fatality, Heaven itself seemed to<br><br>step in to take out of his hands into its own the damning thing he<br><br>would have done.<br><br><br><br>"It was just between daybreak and sunrise of the morning of the<br><br>second day, when they were washing down the decks, that a stupid<br><br>Teneriffe man, drawing water in the main-chains, all at once shouted<br><br>out, 'There she rolls! there she rolls!'  Jesu, what a whale!  It was<br><br>Moby Dick.<br><br><br><br>"'Moby Dick!' cried Don Sebastian; 'St. Dominic!  Sir sailor, but do<br><br>whales have christenings?  Whom call you Moby Dick?'<br><br><br><br>"'A very white, and famous, and most deadly immortal monster,<br><br>Don;--but that would be too long a story.'<br><br><br><br>"'How? how?' cried all the young Spaniards, crowding.<br><br><br><br>"'Nay, Dons, Dons--nay, nay!  I cannot rehearse that now.  Let me get<br><br>more into the air, Sirs.'<br><br><br><br>"'The chicha! the chicha!' cried Don Pedro; 'our vigorous friend looks<br><br>faint;--fill up his empty glass!'<br><br><br><br>"No need, gentlemen; one moment, and I proceed.--Now, gentlemen, so<br><br>suddenly perceiving the snowy whale within fifty yards of the<br><br>ship--forgetful of the compact among the crew--in the excitement of<br><br>the moment, the Teneriffe man had instinctively and involuntarily<br><br>lifted his voice for the monster, though for some little time past it<br><br>had been plainly beheld from the three sullen mast-heads.  All was<br><br>now a phrensy.  'The White Whale--the White Whale!' was the cry from<br><br>captain, mates, and harpooneers, who, undeterred by fearful rumours,<br><br>were all anxious to capture so famous and precious a fish; while the<br><br>dogged crew eyed askance, and with curses, the appalling beauty of<br><br>the vast milky mass, that lit up by a horizontal spangling sun,<br><br>shifted and glistened like a living opal in the blue morning sea.<br><br>Gentlemen, a strange fatality pervades the whole career of these<br><br>events, as if verily mapped out before the world itself was charted.<br><br>The mutineer was the bowsman of the mate, and when fast to a fish, it<br><br>was his duty to sit next him, while Radney stood up with his lance in<br><br>the prow, and haul in or slacken the line, at the word of command.<br><br>Moreover, when the four boats were lowered, the mate's got the start;<br><br>and none howled more fiercely with delight than did Steelkilt, as he<br><br>strained at his oar.  After a stiff pull, their harpooneer got fast,<br><br>and, spear in hand, Radney sprang to the bow.  He was always a<br><br>furious man, it seems, in a boat.  And now his bandaged cry was, to<br><br>beach him on the whale's topmost back.  Nothing loath, his bowsman<br><br>hauled him up and up, through a blinding foam that blent two<br><br>whitenesses together; till of a sudden the boat struck as against a<br><br>sunken ledge, and keeling over, spilled out the standing mate.  That<br><br>instant, as he fell on the whale's slippery back, the boat righted,<br><br>and was dashed aside by the swell, while Radney was tossed over into<br><br>the sea, on the other flank of the whale.  He struck out through the<br><br>spray, and, for an instant, was dimly seen through that veil, wildly<br><br>seeking to remove himself from the eye of Moby Dick.  But the whale<br><br>rushed round in a sudden maelstrom; seized the swimmer between his<br><br>jaws; and rearing high up with him, plunged headlong again, and went<br><br>down.<br><br><br><br>"Meantime, at the first tap of the boat's bottom, the Lakeman had<br><br>slackened the line, so as to drop astern from the whirlpool; calmly<br><br>looking on, he thought his own thoughts.  But a sudden, terrific,<br><br>downward jerking of the boat, quickly brought his knife to the line.<br><br>He cut it; and the whale was free.  But, at some distance, Moby Dick<br><br>rose again, with some tatters of Radney's red woollen shirt, caught<br><br>in the teeth that had destroyed him.  All four boats gave chase<br><br>again; but the whale eluded them, and finally wholly disappeared.<br><br><br><br>"In good time, the Town-Ho reached her port--a savage, solitary<br><br>place--where no civilized creature resided.  There, headed by the<br><br>Lakeman, all but five or six of the foremastmen deliberately<br><br>deserted among the palms; eventually, as it turned out, seizing a<br><br>large double war-canoe of the savages, and setting sail for some<br><br>other harbor.<br><br><br><br>"The ship's company being reduced to but a handful, the captain<br><br>called upon the Islanders to assist him in the laborious business of<br><br>heaving down the ship to stop the leak.  But to such unresting<br><br>vigilance over their dangerous allies was this small band of whites<br><br>necessitated, both by night and by day, and so extreme was the hard<br><br>work they underwent, that upon the vessel being ready again for sea,<br><br>they were in such a weakened condition that the captain durst not put<br><br>off with them in so heavy a vessel.  After taking counsel with his<br><br>officers, he anchored the ship as far off shore as possible; loaded<br><br>and ran out his two cannon from the bows; stacked his muskets on the<br><br>poop; and warning the Islanders not to approach the ship at their<br><br>peril, took one man with him, and setting the sail of his best<br><br>whale-boat, steered straight before the wind for Tahiti, five hundred<br><br>miles distant, to procure a reinforcement to his crew.<br><br><br><br>"On the fourth day of the sail, a large canoe was descried, which<br><br>seemed to have touched at a low isle of corals.  He steered away from<br><br>it; but the savage craft bore down on him; and soon the voice of<br><br>Steelkilt hailed him to heave to, or he would run him under water.<br><br>The captain presented a pistol.  With one foot on each prow of the<br><br>yoked war-canoes, the Lakeman laughed him to scorn; assuring him that<br><br>if the pistol so much as clicked in the lock, he would bury him in<br><br>bubbles and foam.<br><br><br><br>"'What do you want of me?' cried the captain.<br><br><br><br>"'Where are you bound? and for what are you bound?' demanded<br><br>Steelkilt; 'no lies.'<br><br><br><br>"'I am bound to Tahiti for more men.'<br><br><br><br>"'Very good.  Let me board you a moment--I come in peace.'  With that<br><br>he leaped from the canoe, swam to the boat; and climbing the gunwale,<br><br>stood face to face with the captain.<br><br><br><br>"'Cross your arms, sir; throw back your head.  Now, repeat after me.<br><br>As soon as Steelkilt leaves me, I swear to beach this boat on yonder<br><br>island, and remain there six days.  If I do not, may lightning strike<br><br>me!'<br><br><br><br>"'A pretty scholar,' laughed the Lakeman.  'Adios, Senor!' and<br><br>leaping into the sea, he swam back to his comrades.<br><br><br><br>"Watching the boat till it was fairly beached, and drawn up to the<br><br>roots of the cocoa-nut trees, Steelkilt made sail again, and in due<br><br>time arrived at Tahiti, his own place of destination.  There, luck<br><br>befriended him; two ships were about to sail for France, and were<br><br>providentially in want of precisely that number of men which the<br><br>sailor headed.  They embarked; and so for ever got the start of<br><br>their former captain, had he been at all minded to work them legal<br><br>retribution.<br><br><br><br>"Some ten days after the French ships sailed, the whale-boat arrived,<br><br>and the captain was forced to enlist some of the more civilized<br><br>Tahitians, who had been somewhat used to the sea.  Chartering a small<br><br>native schooner, he returned with them to his vessel; and finding all<br><br>right there, again resumed his cruisings.<br><br><br><br>"Where Steelkilt now is, gentlemen, none know; but upon the island of<br><br>Nantucket, the widow of Radney still turns to the sea which refuses<br><br>to give up its dead; still in dreams sees the awful white whale that<br><br>destroyed him.<br><br><br><br>"'Are you through?' said Don Sebastian, quietly.<br><br><br><br>"'I am, Don.'<br><br><br><br>"'Then I entreat you, tell me if to the best of your own convictions,<br><br>this your story is in substance really true?  It is so passing<br><br>wonderful!  Did you get it from an unquestionable source?  Bear with<br><br>me if I seem to press.'<br><br><br><br>"'Also bear with all of us, sir sailor; for we all join in Don<br><br>Sebastian's suit,' cried the company, with exceeding interest.<br><br><br><br>"'Is there a copy of the Holy Evangelists in the Golden Inn,<br><br>gentlemen?'<br><br><br><br>"'Nay,' said Don Sebastian; 'but I know a worthy priest near by, who<br><br>will quickly procure one for me.  I go for it; but are you well<br><br>advised? this may grow too serious.'<br><br><br><br>"'Will you be so good as to bring the priest also, Don?'<br><br><br><br>"'Though there are no Auto-da-Fe's in Lima now,' said one of the<br><br>company to another; 'I fear our sailor friend runs risk of the<br><br>archiepiscopacy.  Let us withdraw more out of the moonlight.  I see<br><br>no need of this.'<br><br><br><br>"'Excuse me for running after you, Don Sebastian; but may I also beg<br><br>that you will be particular in procuring the largest sized<br><br>Evangelists you can.'<br><br><br><br><br><br>'This is the priest, he brings you the Evangelists,' said Don<br><br>Sebastian, gravely, returning with a tall and solemn figure.<br><br><br><br>"'Let me remove my hat.  Now, venerable priest, further into the<br><br>light, and hold the Holy Book before me that I may touch it.<br><br><br><br>"'So help me Heaven, and on my honour the story I have told ye,<br><br>gentlemen, is in substance and its great items, true.  I know it to<br><br>be true; it happened on this ball; I trod the ship; I knew the crew;<br><br>I have seen and talked with Steelkilt since the death of Radney.'"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 55<br><br><br><br>Of the Monstrous Pictures of Whales.<br><br><br><br><br><br>I shall ere long paint to you as well as one can without canvas,<br><br>something like the true form of the whale as he actually appears to<br><br>the eye of the whaleman when in his own absolute body the whale is<br><br>moored alongside the whale-ship so that he can be fairly stepped upon<br><br>there.  It may be worth while, therefore, previously to advert to<br><br>those curious imaginary portraits of him which even down to the<br><br>present day confidently challenge the faith of the landsman.  It is<br><br>time to set the world right in this matter, by proving such pictures<br><br>of the whale all wrong.<br><br><br><br>It may be that the primal source of all those pictorial delusions<br><br>will be found among the oldest Hindoo, Egyptian, and Grecian<br><br>sculptures.  For ever since those inventive but unscrupulous times<br><br>when on the marble panellings of temples, the pedestals of statues,<br><br>and on shields, medallions, cups, and coins, the dolphin was drawn in<br><br>scales of chain-armor like Saladin's, and a helmeted head like St.<br><br>George's; ever since then has something of the same sort of license<br><br>prevailed, not only in most popular pictures of the whale, but in<br><br>many scientific presentations of him.<br><br><br><br>Now, by all odds, the most ancient extant portrait anyways purporting<br><br>to be the whale's, is to be found in the famous cavern-pagoda of<br><br>Elephanta, in India.  The Brahmins maintain that in the almost<br><br>endless sculptures of that immemorial pagoda, all the trades and<br><br>pursuits, every conceivable avocation of man, were prefigured ages<br><br>before any of them actually came into being.  No wonder then, that in<br><br>some sort our noble profession of whaling should have been there<br><br>shadowed forth.  The Hindoo whale referred to, occurs in a separate<br><br>department of the wall, depicting the incarnation of Vishnu in the<br><br>form of leviathan, learnedly known as the Matse Avatar.  But though<br><br>this sculpture is half man and half whale, so as only to give the<br><br>tail of the latter, yet that small section of him is all wrong.  It<br><br>looks more like the tapering tail of an anaconda, than the broad palms<br><br>of the true whale's majestic flukes.<br><br><br><br>But go to the old Galleries, and look now at a great Christian<br><br>painter's portrait of this fish; for he succeeds no better than the<br><br>antediluvian Hindoo.  It is Guido's picture of Perseus rescuing<br><br>Andromeda from the sea-monster or whale.  Where did Guido get the<br><br>model of such a strange creature as that?  Nor does Hogarth, in<br><br>painting the same scene in his own "Perseus Descending," make out one<br><br>whit better.  The huge corpulence of that Hogarthian monster<br><br>undulates on the surface, scarcely drawing one inch of water.  It has<br><br>a sort of howdah on its back, and its distended tusked mouth into<br><br>which the billows are rolling, might be taken for the Traitors' Gate<br><br>leading from the Thames by water into the Tower.  Then, there are the<br><br>Prodromus whales of old Scotch Sibbald, and Jonah's whale, as<br><br>depicted in the prints of old Bibles and the cuts of old primers.<br><br>What shall be said of these?  As for the book-binder's whale winding<br><br>like a vine-stalk round the stock of a descending anchor--as stamped<br><br>and gilded on the backs and title-pages of many books both old and<br><br>new--that is a very picturesque but purely fabulous creature,<br><br>imitated, I take it, from the like figures on antique vases.  Though<br><br>universally denominated a dolphin, I nevertheless call this<br><br>book-binder's fish an attempt at a whale; because it was so intended<br><br>when the device was first introduced.  It was introduced by an old<br><br>Italian publisher somewhere about the 15th century, during the<br><br>Revival of Learning; and in those days, and even down to a<br><br>comparatively late period, dolphins were popularly supposed to be a<br><br>species of the Leviathan.<br><br><br><br>In the vignettes and other embellishments of some ancient books you<br><br>will at times meet with very curious touches at the whale, where all<br><br>manner of spouts, jets d'eau, hot springs and cold, Saratoga and<br><br>Baden-Baden, come bubbling up from his unexhausted brain.  In the<br><br>title-page of the original edition of the "Advancement of Learning"<br><br>you will find some curious whales.<br><br><br><br>But quitting all these unprofessional attempts, let us glance at<br><br>those pictures of leviathan purporting to be sober, scientific<br><br>delineations, by those who know.  In old Harris's collection of<br><br>voyages there are some plates of whales extracted from a Dutch book<br><br>of voyages, A.D. 1671, entitled "A Whaling Voyage to Spitzbergen in<br><br>the ship Jonas in the Whale, Peter Peterson of Friesland, master."<br><br>In one of those plates the whales, like great rafts of logs, are<br><br>represented lying among ice-isles, with white bears running over<br><br>their living backs.  In another plate, the prodigious blunder is made<br><br>of representing the whale with perpendicular flukes.<br><br><br><br>Then again, there is an imposing quarto, written by one Captain<br><br>Colnett, a Post Captain in the English navy, entitled "A Voyage round<br><br>Cape Horn into the South Seas, for the purpose of extending the<br><br>Spermaceti Whale Fisheries."  In this book is an outline purporting<br><br>to be a "Picture of a Physeter or Spermaceti whale, drawn by scale<br><br>from one killed on the coast of Mexico, August, 1793, and hoisted on<br><br>deck."  I doubt not the captain had this veracious picture taken for<br><br>the benefit of his marines.  To mention but one thing about it, let<br><br>me say that it has an eye which applied, according to the<br><br>accompanying scale, to a full grown sperm whale, would make the eye<br><br>of that whale a bow-window some five feet long.  Ah, my gallant<br><br>captain, why did ye not give us Jonah looking out of that eye!<br><br><br><br>Nor are the most conscientious compilations of Natural History for<br><br>the benefit of the young and tender, free from the same heinousness<br><br>of mistake.  Look at that popular work "Goldsmith's Animated Nature."<br><br>In the abridged London edition of 1807, there are plates of an<br><br>alleged "whale" and a "narwhale."  I do not wish to seem inelegant,<br><br>but this unsightly whale looks much like an amputated sow; and, as<br><br>for the narwhale, one glimpse at it is enough to amaze one, that in<br><br>this nineteenth century such a hippogriff could be palmed for genuine<br><br>upon any intelligent public of schoolboys.<br><br><br><br>Then, again, in 1825, Bernard Germain, Count de Lacepede, a great<br><br>naturalist, published a scientific systemized whale book, wherein are<br><br>several pictures of the different species of the Leviathan.  All<br><br>these are not only incorrect, but the picture of the Mysticetus or<br><br>Greenland whale (that is to say, the Right whale), even Scoresby, a<br><br>long experienced man as touching that species, declares not to have<br><br>its counterpart in nature.<br><br><br><br>But the placing of the cap-sheaf to all this blundering business was<br><br>reserved for the scientific Frederick Cuvier, brother to the famous<br><br>Baron.  In 1836, he published a Natural History of Whales, in which<br><br>he gives what he calls a picture of the Sperm Whale.  Before showing<br><br>that picture to any Nantucketer, you had best provide for your<br><br>summary retreat from Nantucket.  In a word, Frederick Cuvier's Sperm<br><br>Whale is not a Sperm Whale, but a squash.  Of course, he never had<br><br>the benefit of a whaling voyage (such men seldom have), but whence he<br><br>derived that picture, who can tell?  Perhaps he got it as his<br><br>scientific predecessor in the same field, Desmarest, got one of his<br><br>authentic abortions; that is, from a Chinese drawing.  And what sort<br><br>of lively lads with the pencil those Chinese are, many queer cups and<br><br>saucers inform us.<br><br><br><br>As for the sign-painters' whales seen in the streets hanging over the<br><br>shops of oil-dealers, what shall be said of them?  They are generally<br><br>Richard III. whales, with dromedary humps, and very savage;<br><br>breakfasting on three or four sailor tarts, that is whaleboats full<br><br>of mariners: their deformities floundering in seas of blood and blue<br><br>paint.<br><br><br><br>But these manifold mistakes in depicting the whale are not so very<br><br>surprising after all.  Consider!  Most of the scientific drawings<br><br>have been taken from the stranded fish; and these are about as<br><br>correct as a drawing of a wrecked ship, with broken back, would<br><br>correctly represent the noble animal itself in all its undashed pride<br><br>of hull and spars.  Though elephants have stood for their<br><br>full-lengths, the living Leviathan has never yet fairly floated<br><br>himself for his portrait.  The living whale, in his full majesty and<br><br>significance, is only to be seen at sea in unfathomable waters; and<br><br>afloat the vast bulk of him is out of sight, like a launched<br><br>line-of-battle ship; and out of that element it is a thing eternally<br><br>impossible for mortal man to hoist him bodily into the air, so as to<br><br>preserve all his mighty swells and undulations.  And, not to speak of<br><br>the highly presumable difference of contour between a young sucking<br><br>whale and a full-grown Platonian Leviathan; yet, even in the case of<br><br>one of those young sucking whales hoisted to a ship's deck, such is<br><br>then the outlandish, eel-like, limbered, varying shape of him, that<br><br>his precise expression the devil himself could not catch.<br><br><br><br>But it may be fancied, that from the naked skeleton of the stranded<br><br>whale, accurate hints may be derived touching his true form.  Not at<br><br>all.  For it is one of the more curious things about this Leviathan,<br><br>that his skeleton gives very little idea of his general shape.<br><br>Though Jeremy Bentham's skeleton, which hangs for candelabra in the<br><br>library of one of his executors, correctly conveys the idea of a<br><br>burly-browed utilitarian old gentleman, with all Jeremy's other<br><br>leading personal characteristics; yet nothing of this kind could be<br><br>inferred from any leviathan's articulated bones.  In fact, as the<br><br>great Hunter says, the mere skeleton of the whale bears the same<br><br>relation to the fully invested and padded animal as the insect does<br><br>to the chrysalis that so roundingly envelopes it.  This peculiarity<br><br>is strikingly evinced in the head, as in some part of this book will<br><br>be incidentally shown.  It is also very curiously displayed in the<br><br>side fin, the bones of which almost exactly answer to the bones of the<br><br>human hand, minus only the thumb.  This fin has four regular<br><br>bone-fingers, the index, middle, ring, and little finger.  But all<br><br>these are permanently lodged in their fleshy covering, as the human<br><br>fingers in an artificial covering.  "However recklessly the whale may<br><br>sometimes serve us," said humorous Stubb one day, "he can never be<br><br>truly said to handle us without mittens."<br><br><br><br>For all these reasons, then, any way you may look at it, you must<br><br>needs conclude that the great Leviathan is that one creature in the<br><br>world which must remain unpainted to the last.  True, one portrait<br><br>may hit the mark much nearer than another, but none can hit it with<br><br>any very considerable degree of exactness.  So there is no earthly<br><br>way of finding out precisely what the whale really looks like.  And<br><br>the only mode in which you can derive even a tolerable idea of his<br><br>living contour, is by going a whaling yourself; but by so doing, you<br><br>run no small risk of being eternally stove and sunk by him.<br><br>Wherefore, it seems to me you had best not be too fastidious in your<br><br>curiosity touching this Leviathan.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 56<br><br><br><br>Of the Less Erroneous Pictures of Whales, and the True Pictures of<br><br>Whaling Scenes.<br><br><br><br><br><br>In connexion with the monstrous pictures of whales, I am strongly<br><br>tempted here to enter upon those still more monstrous stories of them<br><br>which are to be found in certain books, both ancient and modern,<br><br>especially in Pliny, Purchas, Hackluyt, Harris, Cuvier, etc.  But I<br><br>pass that matter by.<br><br><br><br>I know of only four published outlines of the great Sperm Whale;<br><br>Colnett's, Huggins's, Frederick Cuvier's, and Beale's.  In the<br><br>previous chapter Colnett and Cuvier have been referred to.  Huggins's<br><br>is far better than theirs; but, by great odds, Beale's is the best.<br><br>All Beale's drawings of this whale are good, excepting the middle<br><br>figure in the picture of three whales in various attitudes, capping<br><br>his second chapter.  His frontispiece, boats attacking Sperm Whales,<br><br>though no doubt calculated to excite the civil scepticism of some<br><br>parlor men, is admirably correct and life-like in its general effect.<br><br>Some of the Sperm Whale drawings in J.  Ross Browne are pretty<br><br>correct in contour; but they are wretchedly engraved.  That is not<br><br>his fault though.<br><br><br><br>Of the Right Whale, the best outline pictures are in Scoresby; but<br><br>they are drawn on too small a scale to convey a desirable impression.<br><br>He has but one picture of whaling scenes, and this is a sad<br><br>deficiency, because it is by such pictures only, when at all well<br><br>done, that you can derive anything like a truthful idea of the living<br><br>whale as seen by his living hunters.<br><br><br><br>But, taken for all in all, by far the finest, though in some details<br><br>not the most correct, presentations of whales and whaling scenes to<br><br>be anywhere found, are two large French engravings, well executed,<br><br>and taken from paintings by one Garnery.  Respectively, they<br><br>represent attacks on the Sperm and Right Whale.  In the first<br><br>engraving a noble Sperm Whale is depicted in full majesty of might,<br><br>just risen beneath the boat from the profundities of the ocean, and<br><br>bearing high in the air upon his back the terrific wreck of the<br><br>stoven planks.  The prow of the boat is partially unbroken, and is<br><br>drawn just balancing upon the monster's spine; and standing in that<br><br>prow, for that one single incomputable flash of time, you behold an<br><br>oarsman, half shrouded by the incensed boiling spout of the whale,<br><br>and in the act of leaping, as if from a precipice.  The action of the<br><br>whole thing is wonderfully good and true.  The half-emptied line-tub<br><br>floats on the whitened sea; the wooden poles of the spilled harpoons<br><br>obliquely bob in it; the heads of the swimming crew are scattered<br><br>about the whale in contrasting expressions of affright; while in the<br><br>black stormy distance the ship is bearing down upon the scene.<br><br>Serious fault might be found with the anatomical details of this<br><br>whale, but let that pass; since, for the life of me, I could not draw<br><br>so good a one.<br><br><br><br>In the second engraving, the boat is in the act of drawing alongside<br><br>the barnacled flank of a large running Right Whale, that rolls his<br><br>black weedy bulk in the sea like some mossy rock-slide from the<br><br>Patagonian cliffs.  His jets are erect, full, and black like soot; so<br><br>that from so abounding a smoke in the chimney, you would think there<br><br>must be a brave supper cooking in the great bowels below.  Sea fowls<br><br>are pecking at the small crabs, shell-fish, and other sea candies and<br><br>maccaroni, which the Right Whale sometimes carries on his pestilent<br><br>back.  And all the while the thick-lipped leviathan is rushing<br><br>through the deep, leaving tons of tumultuous white curds in his wake,<br><br>and causing the slight boat to rock in the swells like a skiff caught<br><br>nigh the paddle-wheels of an ocean steamer.  Thus, the foreground is<br><br>all raging commotion; but behind, in admirable artistic contrast, is<br><br>the glassy level of a sea becalmed, the drooping unstarched sails of<br><br>the powerless ship, and the inert mass of a dead whale, a conquered<br><br>fortress, with the flag of capture lazily hanging from the whale-pole<br><br>inserted into his spout-hole.<br><br><br><br>Who Garnery the painter is, or was, I know not.  But my life for it<br><br>he was either practically conversant with his subject, or else<br><br>marvellously tutored by some experienced whaleman.  The French are<br><br>the lads for painting action.  Go and gaze upon all the paintings of<br><br>Europe, and where will you find such a gallery of living and<br><br>breathing commotion on canvas, as in that triumphal hall at<br><br>Versailles; where the beholder fights his way, pell-mell, through the<br><br>consecutive great battles of France; where every sword seems a flash<br><br>of the Northern Lights, and the successive armed kings and Emperors<br><br>dash by, like a charge of crowned centaurs?  Not wholly unworthy of a<br><br>place in that gallery, are these sea battle-pieces of Garnery.<br><br><br><br>The natural aptitude of the French for seizing the picturesqueness of<br><br>things seems to be peculiarly evinced in what paintings and<br><br>engravings they have of their whaling scenes.  With not one tenth of<br><br>England's experience in the fishery, and not the thousandth part of<br><br>that of the Americans, they have nevertheless furnished both nations<br><br>with the only finished sketches at all capable of conveying the real<br><br>spirit of the whale hunt.  For the most part, the English and<br><br>American whale draughtsmen seem entirely content with presenting the<br><br>mechanical outline of things, such as the vacant profile of the<br><br>whale; which, so far as picturesqueness of effect is concerned, is<br><br>about tantamount to sketching the profile of a pyramid.  Even<br><br>Scoresby, the justly renowned Right whaleman, after giving us a stiff<br><br>full length of the Greenland whale, and three or four delicate<br><br>miniatures of narwhales and porpoises, treats us to a series of<br><br>classical engravings of boat hooks, chopping knives, and grapnels;<br><br>and with the microscopic diligence of a Leuwenhoeck submits to the<br><br>inspection of a shivering world ninety-six fac-similes of magnified<br><br>Arctic snow crystals.  I mean no disparagement to the excellent<br><br>voyager (I honour him for a veteran), but in so important a matter it<br><br>was certainly an oversight not to have procured for every crystal a<br><br>sworn affidavit taken before a Greenland Justice of the Peace.<br><br><br><br>In addition to those fine engravings from Garnery, there are two<br><br>other French engravings worthy of note, by some one who subscribes<br><br>himself "H.  Durand."  One of them, though not precisely adapted to<br><br>our present purpose, nevertheless deserves mention on other accounts.<br><br>It is a quiet noon-scene among the isles of the Pacific; a French<br><br>whaler anchored, inshore, in a calm, and lazily taking water on<br><br>board; the loosened sails of the ship, and the long leaves of the<br><br>palms in the background, both drooping together in the breezeless<br><br>air.  The effect is very fine, when considered with reference to its<br><br>presenting the hardy fishermen under one of their few aspects of<br><br>oriental repose.  The other engraving is quite a different affair:<br><br>the ship hove-to upon the open sea, and in the very heart of the<br><br>Leviathanic life, with a Right Whale alongside; the vessel (in the<br><br>act of cutting-in) hove over to the monster as if to a quay; and a<br><br>boat, hurriedly pushing off from this scene of activity, is about<br><br>giving chase to whales in the distance.  The harpoons and lances lie<br><br>levelled for use; three oarsmen are just setting the mast in its<br><br>hole; while from a sudden roll of the sea, the little craft stands<br><br>half-erect out of the water, like a rearing horse.  From the ship,<br><br>the smoke of the torments of the boiling whale is going up like the<br><br>smoke over a village of smithies; and to windward, a black cloud,<br><br>rising up with earnest of squalls and rains, seems to quicken the<br><br>activity of the excited seamen.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 57<br><br><br><br>Of Whales in Paint; in Teeth; in Wood; in Sheet-Iron; in Stone; in<br><br>Mountains; in Stars.<br><br><br><br><br><br>On Tower-hill, as you go down to the London docks, you may have seen<br><br>a crippled beggar (or KEDGER, as the sailors say) holding a painted<br><br>board before him, representing the tragic scene in which he lost his<br><br>leg.  There are three whales and three boats; and one of the boats<br><br>(presumed to contain the missing leg in all its original integrity)<br><br>is being crunched by the jaws of the foremost whale.  Any time these<br><br>ten years, they tell me, has that man held up that picture, and<br><br>exhibited that stump to an incredulous world.  But the time of his<br><br>justification has now come.  His three whales are as good whales as<br><br>were ever published in Wapping, at any rate; and his stump as<br><br>unquestionable a stump as any you will find in the western clearings.<br><br>But, though for ever mounted on that stump, never a stump-speech<br><br>does the poor whaleman make; but, with downcast eyes, stands ruefully<br><br>contemplating his own amputation.<br><br><br><br>Throughout the Pacific, and also in Nantucket, and New Bedford, and<br><br>Sag Harbor, you will come across lively sketches of whales and<br><br>whaling-scenes, graven by the fishermen themselves on Sperm<br><br>Whale-teeth, or ladies' busks wrought out of the Right Whale-bone,<br><br>and other like skrimshander articles, as the whalemen call the<br><br>numerous little ingenious contrivances they elaborately carve out of<br><br>the rough material, in their hours of ocean leisure.  Some of them<br><br>have little boxes of dentistical-looking implements, specially<br><br>intended for the skrimshandering business.  But, in general, they<br><br>toil with their jack-knives alone; and, with that almost omnipotent<br><br>tool of the sailor, they will turn you out anything you please, in<br><br>the way of a mariner's fancy.<br><br><br><br>Long exile from Christendom and civilization inevitably restores a<br><br>man to that condition in which God placed him, i.e. what is called<br><br>savagery.  Your true whale-hunter is as much a savage as an Iroquois.<br><br>I myself am a savage, owning no allegiance but to the King of the<br><br>Cannibals; and ready at any moment to rebel against him.<br><br><br><br>Now, one of the peculiar characteristics of the savage in his<br><br>domestic hours, is his wonderful patience of industry.  An ancient<br><br>Hawaiian war-club or spear-paddle, in its full multiplicity and<br><br>elaboration of carving, is as great a trophy of human perseverance as<br><br>a Latin lexicon.  For, with but a bit of broken sea-shell or a<br><br>shark's tooth, that miraculous intricacy of wooden net-work has been<br><br>achieved; and it has cost steady years of steady application.<br><br><br><br>As with the Hawaiian savage, so with the white sailor-savage.  With<br><br>the same marvellous patience, and with the same single shark's tooth,<br><br>of his one poor jack-knife, he will carve you a bit of bone<br><br>sculpture, not quite as workmanlike, but as close packed in its<br><br>maziness of design, as the Greek savage, Achilles's shield; and full<br><br>of barbaric spirit and suggestiveness, as the prints of that fine old<br><br>Dutch savage, Albert Durer.<br><br><br><br>Wooden whales, or whales cut in profile out of the small dark slabs<br><br>of the noble South Sea war-wood, are frequently met with in the<br><br>forecastles of American whalers.  Some of them are done with much<br><br>accuracy.<br><br><br><br>At some old gable-roofed country houses you will see brass whales<br><br>hung by the tail for knockers to the road-side door.  When the porter<br><br>is sleepy, the anvil-headed whale would be best.  But these knocking<br><br>whales are seldom remarkable as faithful essays.  On the spires of<br><br>some old-fashioned churches you will see sheet-iron whales placed<br><br>there for weather-cocks; but they are so elevated, and besides that<br><br>are to all intents and purposes so labelled with "HANDS OFF!" you<br><br>cannot examine them closely enough to decide upon their merit.<br><br><br><br>In bony, ribby regions of the earth, where at the base of high broken<br><br>cliffs masses of rock lie strewn in fantastic groupings upon the<br><br>plain, you will often discover images as of the petrified forms of<br><br>the Leviathan partly merged in grass, which of a windy day breaks<br><br>against them in a surf of green surges.<br><br><br><br>Then, again, in mountainous countries where the traveller is<br><br>continually girdled by amphitheatrical heights; here and there from<br><br>some lucky point of view you will catch passing glimpses of the<br><br>profiles of whales defined along the undulating ridges.  But you must<br><br>be a thorough whaleman, to see these sights; and not only that, but<br><br>if you wish to return to such a sight again, you must be sure and<br><br>take the exact intersecting latitude and longitude of your first<br><br>stand-point, else so chance-like are such observations of the hills,<br><br>that your precise, previous stand-point would require a laborious<br><br>re-discovery; like the Soloma Islands, which still remain incognita,<br><br>though once high-ruffed Mendanna trod them and old Figuera<br><br>chronicled them.<br><br><br><br>Nor when expandingly lifted by your subject, can you fail to trace<br><br>out great whales in the starry heavens, and boats in pursuit of them;<br><br>as when long filled with thoughts of war the Eastern nations saw<br><br>armies locked in battle among the clouds.  Thus at the North have I<br><br>chased Leviathan round and round the Pole with the revolutions of the<br><br>bright points that first defined him to me.  And beneath the<br><br>effulgent Antarctic skies I have boarded the Argo-Navis, and joined<br><br>the chase against the starry Cetus far beyond the utmost stretch of<br><br>Hydrus and the Flying Fish.<br><br><br><br>With a frigate's anchors for my bridle-bitts and fasces of harpoons<br><br>for spurs, would I could mount that whale and leap the topmost skies,<br><br>to see whether the fabled heavens with all their countless tents<br><br>really lie encamped beyond my mortal sight!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 58<br><br><br><br>Brit.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Steering north-eastward from the Crozetts, we fell in with vast<br><br>meadows of brit, the minute, yellow substance, upon which the Right<br><br>Whale largely feeds.  For leagues and leagues it undulated round us,<br><br>so that we seemed to be sailing through boundless fields of ripe and<br><br>golden wheat.<br><br><br><br>On the second day, numbers of Right Whales were seen, who, secure<br><br>from the attack of a Sperm Whaler like the Pequod, with open jaws<br><br>sluggishly swam through the brit, which, adhering to the fringing<br><br>fibres of that wondrous Venetian blind in their mouths, was in that<br><br>manner separated from the water that escaped at the lip.<br><br><br><br>As morning mowers, who side by side slowly and seethingly advance<br><br>their scythes through the long wet grass of marshy meads; even so<br><br>these monsters swam, making a strange, grassy, cutting sound; and<br><br>leaving behind them endless swaths of blue upon the yellow sea.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*That part of the sea known among whalemen as the "Brazil Banks" does<br><br>not bear that name as the Banks of Newfoundland do, because of there<br><br>being shallows and soundings there, but because of this remarkable<br><br>meadow-like appearance, caused by the vast drifts of brit continually<br><br>floating in those latitudes, where the Right Whale is often chased.<br><br><br><br><br><br>But it was only the sound they made as they parted the brit which at<br><br>all reminded one of mowers.  Seen from the mast-heads, especially<br><br>when they paused and were stationary for a while, their vast black<br><br>forms looked more like lifeless masses of rock than anything else.<br><br>And as in the great hunting countries of India, the stranger at a<br><br>distance will sometimes pass on the plains recumbent elephants<br><br>without knowing them to be such, taking them for bare, blackened<br><br>elevations of the soil; even so, often, with him, who for the first<br><br>time beholds this species of the leviathans of the sea.  And even<br><br>when recognised at last, their immense magnitude renders it very<br><br>hard really to believe that such bulky masses of overgrowth can<br><br>possibly be instinct, in all parts, with the same sort of life that<br><br>lives in a dog or a horse.<br><br><br><br>Indeed, in other respects, you can hardly regard any creatures of the<br><br>deep with the same feelings that you do those of the shore.  For<br><br>though some old naturalists have maintained that all creatures of the<br><br>land are of their kind in the sea; and though taking a broad general<br><br>view of the thing, this may very well be; yet coming to specialties,<br><br>where, for example, does the ocean furnish any fish that in<br><br>disposition answers to the sagacious kindness of the dog?  The<br><br>accursed shark alone can in any generic respect be said to bear<br><br>comparative analogy to him.<br><br><br><br>But though, to landsmen in general, the native inhabitants of the<br><br>seas have ever been regarded with emotions unspeakably unsocial and<br><br>repelling; though we know the sea to be an everlasting terra<br><br>incognita, so that Columbus sailed over numberless unknown worlds to<br><br>discover his one superficial western one; though, by vast odds, the<br><br>most terrific of all mortal disasters have immemorially and<br><br>indiscriminately befallen tens and hundreds of thousands of those who<br><br>have gone upon the waters; though but a moment's consideration will<br><br>teach, that however baby man may brag of his science and skill, and<br><br>however much, in a flattering future, that science and skill may<br><br>augment; yet for ever and for ever, to the crack of doom, the sea<br><br>will insult and murder him, and pulverize the stateliest, stiffest<br><br>frigate he can make; nevertheless, by the continual repetition of<br><br>these very impressions, man has lost that sense of the full awfulness<br><br>of the sea which aboriginally belongs to it.<br><br><br><br>The first boat we read of, floated on an ocean, that with Portuguese<br><br>vengeance had whelmed a whole world without leaving so much as a<br><br>widow.  That same ocean rolls now; that same ocean destroyed the<br><br>wrecked ships of last year.  Yea, foolish mortals, Noah's flood is<br><br>not yet subsided; two thirds of the fair world it yet covers.<br><br><br><br>Wherein differ the sea and the land, that a miracle upon one is not a<br><br>miracle upon the other?  Preternatural terrors rested upon the<br><br>Hebrews, when under the feet of Korah and his company the live ground<br><br>opened and swallowed them up for ever; yet not a modern sun ever<br><br>sets, but in precisely the same manner the live sea swallows up ships<br><br>and crews.<br><br><br><br>But not only is the sea such a foe to man who is an alien to it, but<br><br>it is also a fiend to its own off-spring; worse than the Persian host<br><br>who murdered his own guests; sparing not the creatures which itself<br><br>hath spawned.  Like a savage tigress that tossing in the jungle<br><br>overlays her own cubs, so the sea dashes even the mightiest whales<br><br>against the rocks, and leaves them there side by side with the split<br><br>wrecks of ships.  No mercy, no power but its own controls it.<br><br>Panting and snorting like a mad battle steed that has lost its rider,<br><br>the masterless ocean overruns the globe.<br><br><br><br>Consider the subtleness of the sea; how its most dreaded creatures<br><br>glide under water, unapparent for the most part, and treacherously<br><br>hidden beneath the loveliest tints of azure.  Consider also the<br><br>devilish brilliance and beauty of many of its most remorseless<br><br>tribes, as the dainty embellished shape of many species of sharks.<br><br>Consider, once more, the universal cannibalism of the sea; all whose<br><br>creatures prey upon each other, carrying on eternal war since the<br><br>world began.<br><br><br><br>Consider all this; and then turn to this green, gentle, and most<br><br>docile earth; consider them both, the sea and the land; and do you<br><br>not find a strange analogy to something in yourself?  For as this<br><br>appalling ocean surrounds the verdant land, so in the soul of man<br><br>there lies one insular Tahiti, full of peace and joy, but encompassed<br><br>by all the horrors of the half known life.  God keep thee!  Push not<br><br>off from that isle, thou canst never return!<br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 59<br><br><br><br>Squid.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Slowly wading through the meadows of brit, the Pequod still held on<br><br>her way north-eastward towards the island of Java; a gentle air<br><br>impelling her keel, so that in the surrounding serenity her three<br><br>tall tapering masts mildly waved to that languid breeze, as three<br><br>mild palms on a plain.  And still, at wide intervals in the silvery<br><br>night, the lonely, alluring jet would be seen.<br><br><br><br>But one transparent blue morning, when a stillness almost<br><br>preternatural spread over the sea, however unattended with any<br><br>stagnant calm; when the long burnished sun-glade on the waters seemed<br><br>a golden finger laid across them, enjoining some secrecy; when the<br><br>slippered waves whispered together as they softly ran on; in this<br><br>profound hush of the visible sphere a strange spectre was seen by<br><br>Daggoo from the main-mast-head.<br><br><br><br>In the distance, a great white mass lazily rose, and rising higher<br><br>and higher, and disentangling itself from the azure, at last gleamed<br><br>before our prow like a snow-slide, new slid from the hills.  Thus<br><br>glistening for a moment, as slowly it subsided, and sank.  Then once<br><br>more arose, and silently gleamed.  It seemed not a whale; and yet is<br><br>this Moby Dick? thought Daggoo.  Again the phantom went down, but on<br><br>re-appearing once more, with a stiletto-like cry that startled every<br><br>man from his nod, the negro yelled out--"There! there again! there<br><br>she breaches! right ahead!  The White Whale, the White Whale!"<br><br><br><br>Upon this, the seamen rushed to the yard-arms, as in swarming-time<br><br>the bees rush to the boughs.  Bare-headed in the sultry sun, Ahab<br><br>stood on the bowsprit, and with one hand pushed far behind in<br><br>readiness to wave his orders to the helmsman, cast his eager glance<br><br>in the direction indicated aloft by the outstretched motionless arm<br><br>of Daggoo.<br><br><br><br>Whether the flitting attendance of the one still and solitary jet had<br><br>gradually worked upon Ahab, so that he was now prepared to connect<br><br>the ideas of mildness and repose with the first sight of the<br><br>particular whale he pursued; however this was, or whether his<br><br>eagerness betrayed him; whichever way it might have been, no sooner<br><br>did he distinctly perceive the white mass, than with a quick<br><br>intensity he instantly gave orders for lowering.<br><br><br><br>The four boats were soon on the water; Ahab's in advance, and all<br><br>swiftly pulling towards their prey.  Soon it went down, and while,<br><br>with oars suspended, we were awaiting its reappearance, lo! in the<br><br>same spot where it sank, once more it slowly rose.  Almost forgetting<br><br>for the moment all thoughts of Moby Dick, we now gazed at the most<br><br>wondrous phenomenon which the secret seas have hitherto revealed to<br><br>mankind.  A vast pulpy mass, furlongs in length and breadth, of a<br><br>glancing cream-colour, lay floating on the water, innumerable long<br><br>arms radiating from its centre, and curling and twisting like a nest<br><br>of anacondas, as if blindly to clutch at any hapless object within<br><br>reach.  No perceptible face or front did it have; no conceivable<br><br>token of either sensation or instinct; but undulated there on the<br><br>billows, an unearthly, formless, chance-like apparition of life.<br><br><br><br>As with a low sucking sound it slowly disappeared again, Starbuck<br><br>still gazing at the agitated waters where it had sunk, with a wild<br><br>voice exclaimed--"Almost rather had I seen Moby Dick and fought him,<br><br>than to have seen thee, thou white ghost!"<br><br><br><br>"What was it, Sir?" said Flask.<br><br><br><br>"The great live squid, which, they say, few whale-ships ever beheld,<br><br>and returned to their ports to tell of it."<br><br><br><br>But Ahab said nothing; turning his boat, he sailed back to the<br><br>vessel; the rest as silently following.<br><br><br><br>Whatever superstitions the sperm whalemen in general have connected<br><br>with the sight of this object, certain it is, that a glimpse of it<br><br>being so very unusual, that circumstance has gone far to invest it<br><br>with portentousness.  So rarely is it beheld, that though one and all<br><br>of them declare it to be the largest animated thing in the ocean, yet<br><br>very few of them have any but the most vague ideas concerning its<br><br>true nature and form; notwithstanding, they believe it to furnish to<br><br>the sperm whale his only food.  For though other species of whales<br><br>find their food above water, and may be seen by man in the act of<br><br>feeding, the spermaceti whale obtains his whole food in unknown zones<br><br>below the surface; and only by inference is it that any one can tell<br><br>of what, precisely, that food consists.  At times, when closely<br><br>pursued, he will disgorge what are supposed to be the detached arms<br><br>of the squid; some of them thus exhibited exceeding twenty and thirty<br><br>feet in length.  They fancy that the monster to which these arms<br><br>belonged ordinarily clings by them to the bed of the ocean; and that<br><br>the sperm whale, unlike other species, is supplied with teeth in<br><br>order to attack and tear it.<br><br><br><br>There seems some ground to imagine that the great Kraken of Bishop<br><br>Pontoppodan may ultimately resolve itself into Squid.  The manner in<br><br>which the Bishop describes it, as alternately rising and sinking,<br><br>with some other particulars he narrates, in all this the two<br><br>correspond.  But much abatement is necessary with respect to the<br><br>incredible bulk he assigns it.<br><br><br><br>By some naturalists who have vaguely heard rumors of the mysterious<br><br>creature, here spoken of, it is included among the class of<br><br>cuttle-fish, to which, indeed, in certain external respects it would<br><br>seem to belong, but only as the Anak of the tribe.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 60<br><br><br><br>The Line.<br><br><br><br><br><br>With reference to the whaling scene shortly to be described, as well<br><br>as for the better understanding of all similar scenes elsewhere<br><br>presented, I have here to speak of the magical, sometimes horrible<br><br>whale-line.<br><br><br><br>The line originally used in the fishery was of the best hemp,<br><br>slightly vapoured with tar, not impregnated with it, as in the case of<br><br>ordinary ropes; for while tar, as ordinarily used, makes the hemp<br><br>more pliable to the rope-maker, and also renders the rope itself more<br><br>convenient to the sailor for common ship use; yet, not only would the<br><br>ordinary quantity too much stiffen the whale-line for the close<br><br>coiling to which it must be subjected; but as most seamen are<br><br>beginning to learn, tar in general by no means adds to the rope's<br><br>durability or strength, however much it may give it compactness and<br><br>gloss.<br><br><br><br>Of late years the Manilla rope has in the American fishery almost<br><br>entirely superseded hemp as a material for whale-lines; for, though<br><br>not so durable as hemp, it is stronger, and far more soft and<br><br>elastic; and I will add (since there is an aesthetics in all things),<br><br>is much more handsome and becoming to the boat, than hemp.  Hemp is a<br><br>dusky, dark fellow, a sort of Indian; but Manilla is as a<br><br>golden-haired Circassian to behold.<br><br><br><br>The whale-line is only two-thirds of an inch in thickness.  At first<br><br>sight, you would not think it so strong as it really is.  By<br><br>experiment its one and fifty yarns will each suspend a weight of one<br><br>hundred and twenty pounds; so that the whole rope will bear a strain<br><br>nearly equal to three tons.  In length, the common sperm whale-line<br><br>measures something over two hundred fathoms.  Towards the stern of<br><br>the boat it is spirally coiled away in the tub, not like the<br><br>worm-pipe of a still though, but so as to form one round,<br><br>cheese-shaped mass of densely bedded "sheaves," or layers of<br><br>concentric spiralizations, without any hollow but the "heart," or<br><br>minute vertical tube formed at the axis of the cheese.  As the least<br><br>tangle or kink in the coiling would, in running out, infallibly take<br><br>somebody's arm, leg, or entire body off, the utmost precaution is<br><br>used in stowing the line in its tub.  Some harpooneers will consume<br><br>almost an entire morning in this business, carrying the line high<br><br>aloft and then reeving it downwards through a block towards the tub,<br><br>so as in the act of coiling to free it from all possible wrinkles and<br><br>twists.<br><br><br><br>In the English boats two tubs are used instead of one; the same line<br><br>being continuously coiled in both tubs.  There is some advantage in<br><br>this; because these twin-tubs being so small they fit more readily<br><br>into the boat, and do not strain it so much; whereas, the American<br><br>tub, nearly three feet in diameter and of proportionate depth, makes<br><br>a rather bulky freight for a craft whose planks are but one half-inch<br><br>in thickness; for the bottom of the whale-boat is like critical ice,<br><br>which will bear up a considerable distributed weight, but not very<br><br>much of a concentrated one.  When the painted canvas cover is clapped<br><br>on the American line-tub, the boat looks as if it were pulling off<br><br>with a prodigious great wedding-cake to present to the whales.<br><br><br><br>Both ends of the line are exposed; the lower end terminating in an<br><br>eye-splice or loop coming up from the bottom against the side of the<br><br>tub, and hanging over its edge completely disengaged from everything.<br><br>This arrangement of the lower end is necessary on two accounts.<br><br>First: In order to facilitate the fastening to it of an additional<br><br>line from a neighboring boat, in case the stricken whale should sound<br><br>so deep as to threaten to carry off the entire line originally<br><br>attached to the harpoon.  In these instances, the whale of course is<br><br>shifted like a mug of ale, as it were, from the one boat to the<br><br>other; though the first boat always hovers at hand to assist its<br><br>consort.  Second: This arrangement is indispensable for common<br><br>safety's sake; for were the lower end of the line in any way attached<br><br>to the boat, and were the whale then to run the line out to the end<br><br>almost in a single, smoking minute as he sometimes does, he would not<br><br>stop there, for the doomed boat would infallibly be dragged down<br><br>after him into the profundity of the sea; and in that case no<br><br>town-crier would ever find her again.<br><br><br><br>Before lowering the boat for the chase, the upper end of the line is<br><br>taken aft from the tub, and passing round the loggerhead there, is<br><br>again carried forward the entire length of the boat, resting<br><br>crosswise upon the loom or handle of every man's oar, so that it jogs<br><br>against his wrist in rowing; and also passing between the men, as<br><br>they alternately sit at the opposite gunwales, to the leaded chocks<br><br>or grooves in the extreme pointed prow of the boat, where a wooden<br><br>pin or skewer the size of a common quill, prevents it from slipping<br><br>out.  From the chocks it hangs in a slight festoon over the bows, and<br><br>is then passed inside the boat again; and some ten or twenty fathoms<br><br>(called box-line) being coiled upon the box in the bows, it continues<br><br>its way to the gunwale still a little further aft, and is then<br><br>attached to the short-warp--the rope which is immediately connected<br><br>with the harpoon; but previous to that connexion, the short-warp goes<br><br>through sundry mystifications too tedious to detail.<br><br><br><br>Thus the whale-line folds the whole boat in its complicated coils,<br><br>twisting and writhing around it in almost every direction.  All the<br><br>oarsmen are involved in its perilous contortions; so that to the<br><br>timid eye of the landsman, they seem as Indian jugglers, with the<br><br>deadliest snakes sportively festooning their limbs.  Nor can any son<br><br>of mortal woman, for the first time, seat himself amid those hempen<br><br>intricacies, and while straining his utmost at the oar, bethink him<br><br>that at any unknown instant the harpoon may be darted, and all these<br><br>horrible contortions be put in play like ringed lightnings; he cannot<br><br>be thus circumstanced without a shudder that makes the very marrow in<br><br>his bones to quiver in him like a shaken jelly.
