Yet habit--strange<br><br>thing! what cannot habit accomplish?--Gayer sallies, more merry<br><br>mirth, better jokes, and brighter repartees, you never heard over<br><br>your mahogany, than you will hear over the half-inch white cedar of<br><br>the whale-boat, when thus hung in hangman's nooses; and, like the six<br><br>burghers of Calais before King Edward, the six men composing the crew<br><br>pull into the jaws of death, with a halter around every neck, as you<br><br>may say.<br><br><br><br>Perhaps a very little thought will now enable you to account for<br><br>those repeated whaling disasters--some few of which are casually<br><br>chronicled--of this man or that man being taken out of the boat by<br><br>the line, and lost.  For, when the line is darting out, to be seated<br><br>then in the boat, is like being seated in the midst of the manifold<br><br>whizzings of a steam-engine in full play, when every flying beam, and<br><br>shaft, and wheel, is grazing you.  It is worse; for you cannot sit<br><br>motionless in the heart of these perils, because the boat is rocking<br><br>like a cradle, and you are pitched one way and the other, without the<br><br>slightest warning; and only by a certain self-adjusting buoyancy and<br><br>simultaneousness of volition and action, can you escape being made a<br><br>Mazeppa of, and run away with where the all-seeing sun himself could<br><br>never pierce you out.<br><br><br><br>Again: as the profound calm which only apparently precedes and<br><br>prophesies of the storm, is perhaps more awful than the storm itself;<br><br>for, indeed, the calm is but the wrapper and envelope of the storm;<br><br>and contains it in itself, as the seemingly harmless rifle holds the<br><br>fatal powder, and the ball, and the explosion; so the graceful repose<br><br>of the line, as it silently serpentines about the oarsmen before<br><br>being brought into actual play--this is a thing which carries more of<br><br>true terror than any other aspect of this dangerous affair.  But why<br><br>say more?  All men live enveloped in whale-lines.  All are born with<br><br>halters round their necks; but it is only when caught in the swift,<br><br>sudden turn of death, that mortals realize the silent, subtle,<br><br>ever-present perils of life.  And if you be a philosopher, though<br><br>seated in the whale-boat, you would not at heart feel one whit more<br><br>of terror, than though seated before your evening fire with a poker,<br><br>and not a harpoon, by your side.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 61<br><br><br><br>Stubb Kills a Whale.<br><br><br><br><br><br>If to Starbuck the apparition of the Squid was a thing of portents,<br><br>to Queequeg it was quite a different object.<br><br><br><br>"When you see him 'quid," said the savage, honing his harpoon in the<br><br>bow of his hoisted boat, "then you quick see him 'parm whale."<br><br><br><br>The next day was exceedingly still and sultry, and with nothing<br><br>special to engage them, the Pequod's crew could hardly resist the<br><br>spell of sleep induced by such a vacant sea.  For this part of the<br><br>Indian Ocean through which we then were voyaging is not what whalemen<br><br>call a lively ground; that is, it affords fewer glimpses of<br><br>porpoises, dolphins, flying-fish, and other vivacious denizens of<br><br>more stirring waters, than those off the Rio de la Plata, or the<br><br>in-shore ground off Peru.<br><br><br><br>It was my turn to stand at the foremast-head; and with my shoulders<br><br>leaning against the slackened royal shrouds, to and fro I idly swayed<br><br>in what seemed an enchanted air.  No resolution could withstand it;<br><br>in that dreamy mood losing all consciousness, at last my soul went<br><br>out of my body; though my body still continued to sway as a pendulum<br><br>will, long after the power which first moved it is withdrawn.<br><br><br><br>Ere forgetfulness altogether came over me, I had noticed that the<br><br>seamen at the main and mizzen-mast-heads were already drowsy.  So<br><br>that at last all three of us lifelessly swung from the spars, and for<br><br>every swing that we made there was a nod from below from the<br><br>slumbering helmsman.  The waves, too, nodded their indolent crests;<br><br>and across the wide trance of the sea, east nodded to west, and the<br><br>sun over all.<br><br><br><br>Suddenly bubbles seemed bursting beneath my closed eyes; like vices<br><br>my hands grasped the shrouds; some invisible, gracious agency<br><br>preserved me; with a shock I came back to life.  And lo! close under<br><br>our lee, not forty fathoms off, a gigantic Sperm Whale lay rolling in<br><br>the water like the capsized hull of a frigate, his broad, glossy<br><br>back, of an Ethiopian hue, glistening in the sun's rays like a<br><br>mirror.  But lazily undulating in the trough of the sea, and ever and<br><br>anon tranquilly spouting his vapoury jet, the whale looked like a<br><br>portly burgher smoking his pipe of a warm afternoon.  But that pipe,<br><br>poor whale, was thy last.  As if struck by some enchanter's wand, the<br><br>sleepy ship and every sleeper in it all at once started into<br><br>wakefulness; and more than a score of voices from all parts of the<br><br>vessel, simultaneously with the three notes from aloft, shouted forth<br><br>the accustomed cry, as the great fish slowly and regularly spouted<br><br>the sparkling brine into the air.<br><br><br><br>"Clear away the boats!  Luff!" cried Ahab.  And obeying his own<br><br>order, he dashed the helm down before the helmsman could handle the<br><br>spokes.<br><br><br><br>The sudden exclamations of the crew must have alarmed the whale; and<br><br>ere the boats were down, majestically turning, he swam away to the<br><br>leeward, but with such a steady tranquillity, and making so few<br><br>ripples as he swam, that thinking after all he might not as yet be<br><br>alarmed, Ahab gave orders that not an oar should be used, and no man<br><br>must speak but in whispers.  So seated like Ontario Indians on the<br><br>gunwales of the boats, we swiftly but silently paddled along; the<br><br>calm not admitting of the noiseless sails being set.  Presently, as<br><br>we thus glided in chase, the monster perpendicularly flitted his tail<br><br>forty feet into the air, and then sank out of sight like a tower<br><br>swallowed up.<br><br><br><br>"There go flukes!" was the cry, an announcement immediately followed<br><br>by Stubb's producing his match and igniting his pipe, for now a<br><br>respite was granted.  After the full interval of his sounding had<br><br>elapsed, the whale rose again, and being now in advance of the<br><br>smoker's boat, and much nearer to it than to any of the others, Stubb<br><br>counted upon the honour of the capture.  It was obvious, now, that the<br><br>whale had at length become aware of his pursuers.  All silence of<br><br>cautiousness was therefore no longer of use.  Paddles were dropped,<br><br>and oars came loudly into play.  And still puffing at his pipe, Stubb<br><br>cheered on his crew to the assault.<br><br><br><br>Yes, a mighty change had come over the fish.  All alive to his<br><br>jeopardy, he was going "head out"; that part obliquely projecting<br><br>from the mad yeast which he brewed.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*It will be seen in some other place of what a very light substance<br><br>the entire interior of the sperm whale's enormous head consists.<br><br>Though apparently the most massive, it is by far the most buoyant<br><br>part about him.  So that with ease he elevates it in the air, and<br><br>invariably does so when going at his utmost speed.  Besides, such is<br><br>the breadth of the upper part of the front of his head, and such the<br><br>tapering cut-water formation of the lower part, that by obliquely<br><br>elevating his head, he thereby may be said to transform himself from<br><br>a bluff-bowed sluggish galliot into a sharppointed New York<br><br>pilot-boat.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"Start her, start her, my men!  Don't hurry yourselves; take plenty<br><br>of time--but start her; start her like thunder-claps, that's all,"<br><br>cried Stubb, spluttering out the smoke as he spoke.  "Start her, now;<br><br>give 'em the long and strong stroke, Tashtego.  Start her, Tash, my<br><br>boy--start her, all; but keep cool, keep cool--cucumbers is the<br><br>word--easy, easy--only start her like grim death and grinning devils,<br><br>and raise the buried dead perpendicular out of their graves,<br><br>boys--that's all.  Start her!"<br><br><br><br>"Woo-hoo!  Wa-hee!" screamed the Gay-Header in reply, raising some<br><br>old war-whoop to the skies; as every oarsman in the strained boat<br><br>involuntarily bounced forward with the one tremendous leading stroke<br><br>which the eager Indian gave.<br><br><br><br>But his wild screams were answered by others quite as wild.<br><br>"Kee-hee!  Kee-hee!" yelled Daggoo, straining forwards and backwards<br><br>on his seat, like a pacing tiger in his cage.<br><br><br><br>"Ka-la!  Koo-loo!" howled Queequeg, as if smacking his lips over a<br><br>mouthful of Grenadier's steak.  And thus with oars and yells the<br><br>keels cut the sea.  Meanwhile, Stubb retaining his place in the<br><br>van, still encouraged his men to the onset, all the while puffing the<br><br>smoke from his mouth.  Like desperadoes they tugged and they<br><br>strained, till the welcome cry was heard--"Stand up, Tashtego!--give<br><br>it to him!"  The harpoon was hurled.  "Stern all!"  The oarsmen<br><br>backed water; the same moment something went hot and hissing along<br><br>every one of their wrists.  It was the magical line.  An instant<br><br>before, Stubb had swiftly caught two additional turns with it round<br><br>the loggerhead, whence, by reason of its increased rapid circlings, a<br><br>hempen blue smoke now jetted up and mingled with the steady fumes<br><br>from his pipe.  As the line passed round and round the loggerhead; so<br><br>also, just before reaching that point, it blisteringly passed through<br><br>and through both of Stubb's hands, from which the hand-cloths, or<br><br>squares of quilted canvas sometimes worn at these times, had<br><br>accidentally dropped.  It was like holding an enemy's sharp two-edged<br><br>sword by the blade, and that enemy all the time striving to wrest it<br><br>out of your clutch.<br><br><br><br>"Wet the line! wet the line!" cried Stubb to the tub oarsman (him<br><br>seated by the tub) who, snatching off his hat, dashed sea-water into<br><br>it.*  More turns were taken, so that the line began holding its place.<br><br>The boat now flew through the boiling water like a shark all fins.<br><br>Stubb and Tashtego here changed places--stem for stern--a staggering<br><br>business truly in that rocking commotion.<br><br><br><br><br><br>*Partly to show the indispensableness of this act, it may here be<br><br>stated, that, in the old Dutch fishery, a mop was used to dash the<br><br>running line with water; in many other ships, a wooden piggin, or<br><br>bailer, is set apart for that purpose.  Your hat, however, is the<br><br>most convenient.<br><br><br><br><br><br>From the vibrating line extending the entire length of the upper part<br><br>of the boat, and from its now being more tight than a harpstring, you<br><br>would have thought the craft had two keels--one cleaving the water,<br><br>the other the air--as the boat churned on through both opposing<br><br>elements at once.  A continual cascade played at the bows; a<br><br>ceaseless whirling eddy in her wake; and, at the slightest motion<br><br>from within, even but of a little finger, the vibrating, cracking<br><br>craft canted over her spasmodic gunwale into the sea.  Thus they<br><br>rushed; each man with might and main clinging to his seat, to prevent<br><br>being tossed to the foam; and the tall form of Tashtego at the<br><br>steering oar crouching almost double, in order to bring down his<br><br>centre of gravity.  Whole Atlantics and Pacifics seemed passed as<br><br>they shot on their way, till at length the whale somewhat slackened<br><br>his flight.<br><br><br><br>"Haul in--haul in!" cried Stubb to the bowsman! and, facing round<br><br>towards the whale, all hands began pulling the boat up to him, while<br><br>yet the boat was being towed on.  Soon ranging up by his flank,<br><br>Stubb, firmly planting his knee in the clumsy cleat, darted dart<br><br>after dart into the flying fish; at the word of command, the boat<br><br>alternately sterning out of the way of the whale's horrible wallow,<br><br>and then ranging up for another fling.<br><br><br><br>The red tide now poured from all sides of the monster like brooks<br><br>down a hill.  His tormented body rolled not in brine but in blood,<br><br>which bubbled and seethed for furlongs behind in their wake.  The<br><br>slanting sun playing upon this crimson pond in the sea, sent back<br><br>its reflection into every face, so that they all glowed to each other<br><br>like red men.  And all the while, jet after jet of white smoke was<br><br>agonizingly shot from the spiracle of the whale, and vehement puff<br><br>after puff from the mouth of the excited headsman; as at every dart,<br><br>hauling in upon his crooked lance (by the line attached to it), Stubb<br><br>straightened it again and again, by a few rapid blows against the<br><br>gunwale, then again and again sent it into the whale.<br><br><br><br>"Pull up--pull up!" he now cried to the bowsman, as the waning whale<br><br>relaxed in his wrath.  "Pull up!--close to!" and the boat ranged<br><br>along the fish's flank.  When reaching far over the bow, Stubb slowly<br><br>churned his long sharp lance into the fish, and kept it there,<br><br>carefully churning and churning, as if cautiously seeking to feel<br><br>after some gold watch that the whale might have swallowed, and which<br><br>he was fearful of breaking ere he could hook it out.  But that gold<br><br>watch he sought was the innermost life of the fish.  And now it is<br><br>struck; for, starting from his trance into that unspeakable thing<br><br>called his "flurry," the monster horribly wallowed in his blood,<br><br>overwrapped himself in impenetrable, mad, boiling spray, so that the<br><br>imperilled craft, instantly dropping astern, had much ado blindly to<br><br>struggle out from that phrensied twilight into the clear air of the<br><br>day.<br><br><br><br>And now abating in his flurry, the whale once more rolled out into<br><br>view; surging from side to side; spasmodically dilating and<br><br>contracting his spout-hole, with sharp, cracking, agonized<br><br>respirations.  At last, gush after gush of clotted red gore, as if it<br><br>had been the purple lees of red wine, shot into the frighted air; and<br><br>falling back again, ran dripping down his motionless flanks into<br><br>the sea.  His heart had burst!<br><br><br><br>"He's dead, Mr. Stubb," said Daggoo.<br><br><br><br>"Yes; both pipes smoked out!" and withdrawing his own from his mouth,<br><br>Stubb scattered the dead ashes over the water; and, for a moment,<br><br>stood thoughtfully eyeing the vast corpse he had made.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 62<br><br><br><br>The Dart.<br><br><br><br><br><br>A word concerning an incident in the last chapter.<br><br><br><br>According to the invariable usage of the fishery, the whale-boat<br><br>pushes off from the ship, with the headsman or whale-killer as<br><br>temporary steersman, and the harpooneer or whale-fastener pulling the<br><br>foremost oar, the one known as the harpooneer-oar.  Now it needs a<br><br>strong, nervous arm to strike the first iron into the fish; for<br><br>often, in what is called a long dart, the heavy implement has to be<br><br>flung to the distance of twenty or thirty feet.  But however<br><br>prolonged and exhausting the chase, the harpooneer is expected to<br><br>pull his oar meanwhile to the uttermost; indeed, he is expected to<br><br>set an example of superhuman activity to the rest, not only by<br><br>incredible rowing, but by repeated loud and intrepid exclamations;<br><br>and what it is to keep shouting at the top of one's compass, while<br><br>all the other muscles are strained and half started--what that is<br><br>none know but those who have tried it.  For one, I cannot bawl very<br><br>heartily and work very recklessly at one and the same time.  In this<br><br>straining, bawling state, then, with his back to the fish, all at<br><br>once the exhausted harpooneer hears the exciting cry--"Stand up, and<br><br>give it to him!"  He now has to drop and secure his oar, turn round<br><br>on his centre half way, seize his harpoon from the crotch, and with<br><br>what little strength may remain, he essays to pitch it somehow into<br><br>the whale.  No wonder, taking the whole fleet of whalemen in a body,<br><br>that out of fifty fair chances for a dart, not five are successful;<br><br>no wonder that so many hapless harpooneers are madly cursed and<br><br>disrated; no wonder that some of them actually burst their<br><br>blood-vessels in the boat; no wonder that some sperm whalemen are<br><br>absent four years with four barrels; no wonder that to many ship<br><br>owners, whaling is but a losing concern; for it is the harpooneer<br><br>that makes the voyage, and if you take the breath out of his body how<br><br>can you expect to find it there when most wanted!<br><br><br><br>Again, if the dart be successful, then at the second critical<br><br>instant, that is, when the whale starts to run, the boatheader and<br><br>harpooneer likewise start to running fore and aft, to the imminent<br><br>jeopardy of themselves and every one else.  It is then they change<br><br>places; and the headsman, the chief officer of the little craft,<br><br>takes his proper station in the bows of the boat.<br><br><br><br>Now, I care not who maintains the contrary, but all this is both<br><br>foolish and unnecessary.  The headsman should stay in the bows from<br><br>first to last; he should both dart the harpoon and the lance, and no<br><br>rowing whatever should be expected of him, except under circumstances<br><br>obvious to any fisherman.  I know that this would sometimes involve a<br><br>slight loss of speed in the chase; but long experience in various<br><br>whalemen of more than one nation has convinced me that in the vast<br><br>majority of failures in the fishery, it has not by any means been so<br><br>much the speed of the whale as the before described exhaustion of the<br><br>harpooneer that has caused them.<br><br><br><br>To insure the greatest efficiency in the dart, the harpooneers of<br><br>this world must start to their feet from out of idleness, and not<br><br>from out of toil.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 63<br><br><br><br>The Crotch.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Out of the trunk, the branches grow; out of them, the twigs.  So, in<br><br>productive subjects, grow the chapters.<br><br><br><br>The crotch alluded to on a previous page deserves independent<br><br>mention.  It is a notched stick of a peculiar form, some two feet in<br><br>length, which is perpendicularly inserted into the starboard gunwale<br><br>near the bow, for the purpose of furnishing a rest for the wooden<br><br>extremity of the harpoon, whose other naked, barbed end slopingly<br><br>projects from the prow.  Thereby the weapon is instantly at hand to<br><br>its hurler, who snatches it up as readily from its rest as a<br><br>backwoodsman swings his rifle from the wall.  It is customary to have<br><br>two harpoons reposing in the crotch, respectively called the first<br><br>and second irons.<br><br><br><br>But these two harpoons, each by its own cord, are both connected with<br><br>the line; the object being this: to dart them both, if possible, one<br><br>instantly after the other into the same whale; so that if, in the<br><br>coming drag, one should draw out, the other may still retain a hold.<br><br>It is a doubling of the chances.  But it very often happens that<br><br>owing to the instantaneous, violent, convulsive running of the whale<br><br>upon receiving the first iron, it becomes impossible for the<br><br>harpooneer, however lightning-like in his movements, to pitch the<br><br>second iron into him.  Nevertheless, as the second iron is already<br><br>connected with the line, and the line is running, hence that weapon<br><br>must, at all events, be anticipatingly tossed out of the boat,<br><br>somehow and somewhere; else the most terrible jeopardy would involve<br><br>all hands.  Tumbled into the water, it accordingly is in such cases;<br><br>the spare coils of box line (mentioned in a preceding chapter) making<br><br>this feat, in most instances, prudently practicable.  But this<br><br>critical act is not always unattended with the saddest and most fatal<br><br>casualties.<br><br><br><br>Furthermore: you must know that when the second iron is thrown<br><br>overboard, it thenceforth becomes a dangling, sharp-edged terror,<br><br>skittishly curvetting about both boat and whale, entangling the<br><br>lines, or cutting them, and making a prodigious sensation in all<br><br>directions.  Nor, in general, is it possible to secure it again until<br><br>the whale is fairly captured and a corpse.<br><br><br><br>Consider, now, how it must be in the case of four boats all engaging<br><br>one unusually strong, active, and knowing whale; when owing to these<br><br>qualities in him, as well as to the thousand concurring accidents of<br><br>such an audacious enterprise, eight or ten loose second irons may be<br><br>simultaneously dangling about him.  For, of course, each boat is<br><br>supplied with several harpoons to bend on to the line should the<br><br>first one be ineffectually darted without recovery.  All these<br><br>particulars are faithfully narrated here, as they will not fail to<br><br>elucidate several most important, however intricate passages, in<br><br>scenes hereafter to be painted.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 64<br><br><br><br>Stubb's Supper.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Stubb's whale had been killed some distance from the ship.  It was a<br><br>calm; so, forming a tandem of three boats, we commenced the slow<br><br>business of towing the trophy to the Pequod.  And now, as we eighteen<br><br>men with our thirty-six arms, and one hundred and eighty thumbs and<br><br>fingers, slowly toiled hour after hour upon that inert, sluggish<br><br>corpse in the sea; and it seemed hardly to budge at all, except at<br><br>long intervals; good evidence was hereby furnished of the<br><br>enormousness of the mass we moved.  For, upon the great canal of<br><br>Hang-Ho, or whatever they call it, in China, four or five laborers on<br><br>the foot-path will draw a bulky freighted junk at the rate of a mile<br><br>an hour; but this grand argosy we towed heavily forged along, as if<br><br>laden with pig-lead in bulk.<br><br><br><br>Darkness came on; but three lights up and down in the Pequod's<br><br>main-rigging dimly guided our way; till drawing nearer we saw Ahab<br><br>dropping one of several more lanterns over the bulwarks.  Vacantly<br><br>eyeing the heaving whale for a moment, he issued the usual orders for<br><br>securing it for the night, and then handing his lantern to a seaman,<br><br>went his way into the cabin, and did not come forward again until<br><br>morning.<br><br><br><br>Though, in overseeing the pursuit of this whale, Captain Ahab had<br><br>evinced his customary activity, to call it so; yet now that the<br><br>creature was dead, some vague dissatisfaction, or impatience, or<br><br>despair, seemed working in him; as if the sight of that dead body<br><br>reminded him that Moby Dick was yet to be slain; and though a<br><br>thousand other whales were brought to his ship, all that would not<br><br>one jot advance his grand, monomaniac object.  Very soon you would<br><br>have thought from the sound on the Pequod's decks, that all hands<br><br>were preparing to cast anchor in the deep; for heavy chains are being<br><br>dragged along the deck, and thrust rattling out of the port-holes.<br><br>But by those clanking links, the vast corpse itself, not the ship, is<br><br>to be moored.  Tied by the head to the stern, and by the tail to the<br><br>bows, the whale now lies with its black hull close to the vessel's<br><br>and seen through the darkness of the night, which obscured the spars<br><br>and rigging aloft, the two--ship and whale, seemed yoked together<br><br>like colossal bullocks, whereof one reclines while the other remains<br><br>standing.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*A little item may as well be related here.  The strongest and most<br><br>reliable hold which the ship has upon the whale when moored<br><br>alongside, is by the flukes or tail; and as from its greater density<br><br>that part is relatively heavier than any other (excepting the<br><br>side-fins), its flexibility even in death, causes it to sink low<br><br>beneath the surface; so that with the hand you cannot get at it from<br><br>the boat, in order to put the chain round it.  But this difficulty is<br><br>ingeniously overcome: a small, strong line is prepared with a wooden<br><br>float at its outer end, and a weight in its middle, while the other<br><br>end is secured to the ship.  By adroit management the wooden float is<br><br>made to rise on the other side of the mass, so that now having<br><br>girdled the whale, the chain is readily made to follow suit; and<br><br>being slipped along the body, is at last locked fast round the<br><br>smallest part of the tail, at the point of junction with its broad<br><br>flukes or lobes.<br><br><br><br><br><br>If moody Ahab was now all quiescence, at least so far as could be<br><br>known on deck, Stubb, his second mate, flushed with conquest,<br><br>betrayed an unusual but still good-natured excitement.  Such an<br><br>unwonted bustle was he in that the staid Starbuck, his official<br><br>superior, quietly resigned to him for the time the sole management of<br><br>affairs.  One small, helping cause of all this liveliness in Stubb,<br><br>was soon made strangely manifest.  Stubb was a high liver; he was<br><br>somewhat intemperately fond of the whale as a flavorish thing to his<br><br>palate.<br><br><br><br>"A steak, a steak, ere I sleep!  You, Daggoo! overboard you go, and<br><br>cut me one from his small!"<br><br><br><br>Here be it known, that though these wild fishermen do not, as a<br><br>general thing, and according to the great military maxim, make the<br><br>enemy defray the current expenses of the war (at least before<br><br>realizing the proceeds of the voyage), yet now and then you find some<br><br>of these Nantucketers who have a genuine relish for that particular<br><br>part of the Sperm Whale designated by Stubb; comprising the tapering<br><br>extremity of the body.<br><br><br><br>About midnight that steak was cut and cooked; and lighted by two<br><br>lanterns of sperm oil, Stubb stoutly stood up to his spermaceti<br><br>supper at the capstan-head, as if that capstan were a sideboard.  Nor<br><br>was Stubb the only banqueter on whale's flesh that night.  Mingling<br><br>their mumblings with his own mastications, thousands on thousands of<br><br>sharks, swarming round the dead leviathan, smackingly feasted on its<br><br>fatness.  The few sleepers below in their bunks were often startled<br><br>by the sharp slapping of their tails against the hull, within a few<br><br>inches of the sleepers' hearts.  Peering over the side you could just<br><br>see them (as before you heard them) wallowing in the sullen, black<br><br>waters, and turning over on their backs as they scooped out huge<br><br>globular pieces of the whale of the bigness of a human head.  This<br><br>particular feat of the shark seems all but miraculous.  How at such<br><br>an apparently unassailable surface, they contrive to gouge out such<br><br>symmetrical mouthfuls, remains a part of the universal problem of all<br><br>things.  The mark they thus leave on the whale, may best be likened<br><br>to the hollow made by a carpenter in countersinking for a screw.<br><br><br><br>Though amid all the smoking horror and diabolism of a sea-fight,<br><br>sharks will be seen longingly gazing up to the ship's decks, like<br><br>hungry dogs round a table where red meat is being carved, ready to<br><br>bolt down every killed man that is tossed to them; and though, while<br><br>the valiant butchers over the deck-table are thus cannibally carving<br><br>each other's live meat with carving-knives all gilded and tasselled,<br><br>the sharks, also, with their jewel-hilted mouths, are quarrelsomely<br><br>carving away under the table at the dead meat; and though, were you<br><br>to turn the whole affair upside down, it would still be pretty much<br><br>the same thing, that is to say, a shocking sharkish business enough<br><br>for all parties; and though sharks also are the invariable outriders<br><br>of all slave ships crossing the Atlantic, systematically trotting<br><br>alongside, to be handy in case a parcel is to be carried anywhere, or<br><br>a dead slave to be decently buried; and though one or two other like<br><br>instances might be set down, touching the set terms, places, and<br><br>occasions, when sharks do most socially congregate, and most<br><br>hilariously feast; yet is there no conceivable time or occasion when<br><br>you will find them in such countless numbers, and in gayer or more<br><br>jovial spirits, than around a dead sperm whale, moored by night to a<br><br>whaleship at sea.  If you have never seen that sight, then suspend<br><br>your decision about the propriety of devil-worship, and the<br><br>expediency of conciliating the devil.<br><br><br><br>But, as yet, Stubb heeded not the mumblings of the banquet that was<br><br>going on so nigh him, no more than the sharks heeded the smacking of<br><br>his own epicurean lips.<br><br><br><br>"Cook, cook!--where's that old Fleece?" he cried at length, widening<br><br>his legs still further, as if to form a more secure base for his<br><br>supper; and, at the same time darting his fork into the dish, as if<br><br>stabbing with his lance; "cook, you cook!--sail this way, cook!"<br><br><br><br>The old black, not in any very high glee at having been previously<br><br>roused from his warm hammock at a most unseasonable hour, came<br><br>shambling along from his galley, for, like many old blacks, there was<br><br>something the matter with his knee-pans, which he did not keep well<br><br>scoured like his other pans; this old Fleece, as they called him,<br><br>came shuffling and limping along, assisting his step with his tongs,<br><br>which, after a clumsy fashion, were made of straightened iron hoops;<br><br>this old Ebony floundered along, and in obedience to the word of<br><br>command, came to a dead stop on the opposite side of Stubb's<br><br>sideboard; when, with both hands folded before him, and resting on<br><br>his two-legged cane, he bowed his arched back still further over, at<br><br>the same time sideways inclining his head, so as to bring his best<br><br>ear into play.<br><br><br><br>"Cook," said Stubb, rapidly lifting a rather reddish morsel to his<br><br>mouth, "don't you think this steak is rather overdone?  You've been<br><br>beating this steak too much, cook; it's too tender.  Don't I always<br><br>say that to be good, a whale-steak must be tough?  There are those<br><br>sharks now over the side, don't you see they prefer it tough and<br><br>rare?  What a shindy they are kicking up!  Cook, go and talk to 'em;<br><br>tell 'em they are welcome to help themselves civilly, and in<br><br>moderation, but they must keep quiet.  Blast me, if I can hear my own<br><br>voice.  Away, cook, and deliver my message.  Here, take this<br><br>lantern," snatching one from his sideboard; "now then, go and preach<br><br>to 'em!"<br><br><br><br>Sullenly taking the offered lantern, old Fleece limped across the<br><br>deck to the bulwarks; and then, with one hand dropping his light low<br><br>over the sea, so as to get a good view of his congregation, with the<br><br>other hand he solemnly flourished his tongs, and leaning far over the<br><br>side in a mumbling voice began addressing the sharks, while Stubb,<br><br>softly crawling behind, overheard all that was said.<br><br><br><br>"Fellow-critters: I'se ordered here to say dat you must stop dat dam<br><br>noise dare.  You hear?  Stop dat dam smackin' ob de lips!  Massa<br><br>Stubb say dat you can fill your dam bellies up to de hatchings, but<br><br>by Gor! you must stop dat dam racket!"<br><br><br><br>"Cook," here interposed Stubb, accompanying the word with a sudden<br><br>slap on the shoulder,--"Cook! why, damn your eyes, you mustn't swear<br><br>that way when you're preaching.  That's no way to convert sinners,<br><br>cook!"<br><br><br><br>"Who dat?  Den preach to him yourself," sullenly turning to go.<br><br><br><br>"No, cook; go on, go on."<br><br><br><br>"Well, den, Belubed fellow-critters:"-<br><br><br><br>"Right!" exclaimed Stubb, approvingly, "coax 'em to it; try that,"<br><br>and Fleece continued.<br><br><br><br>"Do you is all sharks, and by natur wery woracious, yet I zay to you,<br><br>fellow-critters, dat dat woraciousness--'top dat dam slappin' ob de<br><br>tail!  How you tink to hear, spose you keep up such a dam slappin'<br><br>and bitin' dare?"<br><br><br><br>"Cook," cried Stubb, collaring him, "I won't have that swearing.<br><br>Talk to 'em gentlemanly."<br><br><br><br>Once more the sermon proceeded.<br><br><br><br>"Your woraciousness, fellow-critters, I don't blame ye so much for;<br><br>dat is natur, and can't be helped; but to gobern dat wicked natur,<br><br>dat is de pint.  You is sharks, sartin; but if you gobern de shark in<br><br>you, why den you be angel; for all angel is not'ing more dan de shark<br><br>well goberned.  Now, look here, bred'ren, just try wonst to be cibil,<br><br>a helping yourselbs from dat whale.  Don't be tearin' de blubber out<br><br>your neighbour's mout, I say.  Is not one shark dood right as toder<br><br>to dat whale?  And, by Gor, none on you has de right to dat whale;<br><br>dat whale belong to some one else.  I know some o' you has berry brig<br><br>mout, brigger dan oders; but den de brig mouts sometimes has de<br><br>small bellies; so dat de brigness of de mout is not to swaller wid,<br><br>but to bit off de blubber for de small fry ob sharks, dat can't get<br><br>into de scrouge to help demselves."<br><br><br><br>"Well done, old Fleece!" cried Stubb, "that's Christianity; go on."<br><br><br><br>"No use goin' on; de dam willains will keep a scougin' and slappin'<br><br>each oder, Massa Stubb; dey don't hear one word; no use a-preaching<br><br>to such dam g'uttons as you call 'em, till dare bellies is full, and<br><br>dare bellies is bottomless; and when dey do get 'em full, dey wont<br><br>hear you den; for den dey sink in the sea, go fast to sleep on de<br><br>coral, and can't hear noting at all, no more, for eber and eber."<br><br><br><br>"Upon my soul, I am about of the same opinion; so give the<br><br>benediction, Fleece, and I'll away to my supper."<br><br><br><br>Upon this, Fleece, holding both hands over the fishy mob, raised his<br><br>shrill voice, and cried--<br><br><br><br>"Cussed fellow-critters!  Kick up de damndest row as ever you can;<br><br>fill your dam bellies 'till dey bust--and den die."<br><br><br><br>"Now, cook," said Stubb, resuming his supper at the capstan; "stand<br><br>just where you stood before, there, over against me, and pay<br><br>particular attention."<br><br><br><br>"All 'dention," said Fleece, again stooping over upon his tongs in<br><br>the desired position.<br><br><br><br>"Well," said Stubb, helping himself freely meanwhile; "I shall now go<br><br>back to the subject of this steak.  In the first place, how old are<br><br>you, cook?"<br><br><br><br>"What dat do wid de 'teak," said the old black, testily.<br><br><br><br>"Silence!  How old are you, cook?"<br><br><br><br>"'Bout ninety, dey say," he gloomily muttered.<br><br><br><br>"And you have lived in this world hard upon one hundred years, cook,<br><br>and don't know yet how to cook a whale-steak?" rapidly bolting<br><br>another mouthful at the last word, so that morsel seemed a<br><br>continuation of the question.  "Where were you born, cook?"<br><br><br><br>"'Hind de hatchway, in ferry-boat, goin' ober de Roanoke."<br><br><br><br>"Born in a ferry-boat!  That's queer, too.  But I want to know what<br><br>country you were born in, cook!"<br><br><br><br>"Didn't I say de Roanoke country?" he cried sharply.<br><br><br><br>"No, you didn't, cook; but I'll tell you what I'm coming to, cook.<br><br>You must go home and be born over again; you don't know how to cook a<br><br>whale-steak yet."<br><br><br><br>"Bress my soul, if I cook noder one," he growled, angrily, turning<br><br>round to depart.<br><br><br><br>"Come back here, cook;--here, hand me those tongs;--now take that bit<br><br>of steak there, and tell me if you think that steak cooked as it<br><br>should be?  Take it, I say"--holding the tongs towards him--"take it,<br><br>and taste it."<br><br><br><br>Faintly smacking his withered lips over it for a moment, the old<br><br>negro muttered, "Best cooked 'teak I eber taste; joosy, berry joosy."<br><br><br><br>"Cook," said Stubb, squaring himself once more; "do you belong to the<br><br>church?"<br><br><br><br>"Passed one once in Cape-Down," said the old man sullenly.<br><br><br><br>"And you have once in your life passed a holy church in Cape-Town,<br><br>where you doubtless overheard a holy parson addressing his hearers as<br><br>his beloved fellow-creatures, have you, cook!  And yet you come here,<br><br>and tell me such a dreadful lie as you did just now, eh?" said Stubb.<br><br>"Where do you expect to go to, cook?"<br><br><br><br>"Go to bed berry soon," he mumbled, half-turning as he spoke.<br><br><br><br>"Avast! heave to!  I mean when you die, cook.  It's an awful<br><br>question.  Now what's your answer?"<br><br><br><br>"When dis old brack man dies," said the negro slowly, changing his<br><br>whole air and demeanor, "he hisself won't go nowhere; but some<br><br>bressed angel will come and fetch him."<br><br><br><br>"Fetch him?  How?  In a coach and four, as they fetched Elijah?  And<br><br>fetch him where?"<br><br><br><br>"Up dere," said Fleece, holding his tongs straight over his head, and<br><br>keeping it there very solemnly.<br><br><br><br>"So, then, you expect to go up into our main-top, do you, cook, when<br><br>you are dead?  But don't you know the higher you climb, the colder it<br><br>gets?  Main-top, eh?"<br><br><br><br>"Didn't say dat t'all," said Fleece, again in the sulks.<br><br><br><br>"You said up there, didn't you? and now look yourself, and see where<br><br>your tongs are pointing.  But, perhaps you expect to get into heaven<br><br>by crawling through the lubber's hole, cook; but, no, no, cook, you<br><br>don't get there, except you go the regular way, round by the rigging.<br><br>It's a ticklish business, but must be done, or else it's no go.  But<br><br>none of us are in heaven yet.  Drop your tongs, cook, and hear my<br><br>orders.  Do ye hear?  Hold your hat in one hand, and clap t'other<br><br>a'top of your heart, when I'm giving my orders, cook.  What! that<br><br>your heart, there?--that's your gizzard!  Aloft! aloft!--that's<br><br>it--now you have it.  Hold it there now, and pay attention."<br><br><br><br>"All 'dention," said the old black, with both hands placed as<br><br>desired, vainly wriggling his grizzled head, as if to get both ears<br><br>in front at one and the same time.<br><br><br><br>"Well then, cook, you see this whale-steak of yours was so very bad,<br><br>that I have put it out of sight as soon as possible; you see that,<br><br>don't you?  Well, for the future, when you cook another whale-steak<br><br>for my private table here, the capstan, I'll tell you what to do so<br><br>as not to spoil it by overdoing.  Hold the steak in one hand, and<br><br>show a live coal to it with the other; that done, dish it; d'ye hear?<br><br>And now to-morrow, cook, when we are cutting in the fish, be sure<br><br>you stand by to get the tips of his fins; have them put in pickle.<br><br>As for the ends of the flukes, have them soused, cook.  There, now ye<br><br>may go."<br><br><br><br>But Fleece had hardly got three paces off, when he was recalled.<br><br><br><br>"Cook, give me cutlets for supper to-morrow night in the mid-watch.<br><br>D'ye hear? away you sail, then.--Halloa! stop! make a bow before you<br><br>go.--Avast heaving again!  Whale-balls for breakfast--don't forget."<br><br><br><br>"Wish, by gor! whale eat him, 'stead of him eat whale.  I'm bressed<br><br>if he ain't more of shark dan Massa Shark hisself," muttered the old<br><br>man, limping away; with which sage ejaculation he went to his<br><br>hammock.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 65<br><br><br><br>The Whale as a Dish.<br><br><br><br><br><br>That mortal man should feed upon the creature that feeds his lamp,<br><br>and, like Stubb, eat him by his own light, as you may say; this seems<br><br>so outlandish a thing that one must needs go a little into the<br><br>history and philosophy of it.<br><br><br><br>It is upon record, that three centuries ago the tongue of the Right<br><br>Whale was esteemed a great delicacy in France, and commanded large<br><br>prices there.  Also, that in Henry VIIIth's time, a certain cook of<br><br>the court obtained a handsome reward for inventing an admirable sauce<br><br>to be eaten with barbacued porpoises, which, you remember, are a<br><br>species of whale.  Porpoises, indeed, are to this day considered fine<br><br>eating.  The meat is made into balls about the size of billiard<br><br>balls, and being well seasoned and spiced might be taken for<br><br>turtle-balls or veal balls.  The old monks of Dunfermline were very<br><br>fond of them.  They had a great porpoise grant from the crown.<br><br><br><br>The fact is, that among his hunters at least, the whale would by all<br><br>hands be considered a noble dish, were there not so much of him; but<br><br>when you come to sit down before a meat-pie nearly one hundred feet<br><br>long, it takes away your appetite.  Only the most unprejudiced of men<br><br>like Stubb, nowadays partake of cooked whales; but the Esquimaux are<br><br>not so fastidious.  We all know how they live upon whales, and have<br><br>rare old vintages of prime old train oil.  Zogranda, one of their<br><br>most famous doctors, recommends strips of blubber for infants, as<br><br>being exceedingly juicy and nourishing.  And this reminds me that<br><br>certain Englishmen, who long ago were accidentally left in Greenland<br><br>by a whaling vessel--that these men actually lived for several months<br><br>on the mouldy scraps of whales which had been left ashore after<br><br>trying out the blubber.  Among the Dutch whalemen these scraps are<br><br>called "fritters"; which, indeed, they greatly resemble, being brown<br><br>and crisp, and smelling something like old Amsterdam housewives'<br><br>dough-nuts or oly-cooks, when fresh.  They have such an eatable look<br><br>that the most self-denying stranger can hardly keep his hands off.<br><br><br><br>But what further depreciates the whale as a civilized dish, is his<br><br>exceeding richness.  He is the great prize ox of the sea, too fat to<br><br>be delicately good.  Look at his hump, which would be as fine eating<br><br>as the buffalo's (which is esteemed a rare dish), were it not such a<br><br>solid pyramid of fat.  But the spermaceti itself, how bland and<br><br>creamy that is; like the transparent, half-jellied, white meat of a<br><br>cocoanut in the third month of its growth, yet far too rich to supply<br><br>a substitute for butter.  Nevertheless, many whalemen have a method<br><br>of absorbing it into some other substance, and then partaking of it.<br><br>In the long try watches of the night it is a common thing for the<br><br>seamen to dip their ship-biscuit into the huge oil-pots and let them<br><br>fry there awhile.  Many a good supper have I thus made.<br><br><br><br>In the case of a small Sperm Whale the brains are accounted a fine<br><br>dish.  The casket of the skull is broken into with an axe, and the<br><br>two plump, whitish lobes being withdrawn (precisely resembling two<br><br>large puddings), they are then mixed with flour, and cooked into a<br><br>most delectable mess, in flavor somewhat resembling calves' head,<br><br>which is quite a dish among some epicures; and every one knows that<br><br>some young bucks among the epicures, by continually dining upon<br><br>calves' brains, by and by get to have a little brains of their own,<br><br>so as to be able to tell a calf's head from their own heads; which,<br><br>indeed, requires uncommon discrimination.  And that is the reason why<br><br>a young buck with an intelligent looking calf's head before him, is<br><br>somehow one of the saddest sights you can see.  The head looks a sort<br><br>of reproachfully at him, with an "Et tu Brute!" expression.<br><br><br><br>It is not, perhaps, entirely because the whale is so excessively<br><br>unctuous that landsmen seem to regard the eating of him with<br><br>abhorrence; that appears to result, in some way, from the<br><br>consideration before mentioned: i.e. that a man should eat a newly<br><br>murdered thing of the sea, and eat it too by its own light.  But no<br><br>doubt the first man that ever murdered an ox was regarded as a<br><br>murderer; perhaps he was hung; and if he had been put on his trial by<br><br>oxen, he certainly would have been; and he certainly deserved it if<br><br>any murderer does.  Go to the meat-market of a Saturday night and see<br><br>the crowds of live bipeds staring up at the long rows of dead<br><br>quadrupeds.  Does not that sight take a tooth out of the cannibal's<br><br>jaw?  Cannibals? who is not a cannibal?  I tell you it will be more<br><br>tolerable for the Fejee that salted down a lean missionary in his<br><br>cellar against a coming famine; it will be more tolerable for that<br><br>provident Fejee, I say, in the day of judgment, than for thee,<br><br>civilized and enlightened gourmand, who nailest geese to the ground<br><br>and feastest on their bloated livers in thy pate-de-foie-gras.<br><br><br><br>But Stubb, he eats the whale by its own light, does he? and that is<br><br>adding insult to injury, is it?  Look at your knife-handle, there, my<br><br>civilized and enlightened gourmand dining off that roast beef, what<br><br>is that handle made of?--what but the bones of the brother of the<br><br>very ox you are eating?  And what do you pick your teeth with, after<br><br>devouring that fat goose?  With a feather of the same fowl.  And with<br><br>what quill did the Secretary of the Society for the Suppression of<br><br>Cruelty to Ganders formally indite his circulars?  It is only within<br><br>the last month or two that that society passed a resolution to<br><br>patronise nothing but steel pens.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 66<br><br><br><br>The Shark Massacre.<br><br><br><br><br><br>When in the Southern Fishery, a captured Sperm Whale, after long and<br><br>weary toil, is brought alongside late at night, it is not, as a<br><br>general thing at least, customary to proceed at once to the business<br><br>of cutting him in.  For that business is an exceedingly laborious<br><br>one; is not very soon completed; and requires all hands to set about<br><br>it.  Therefore, the common usage is to take in all sail; lash the<br><br>helm a'lee; and then send every one below to his hammock till<br><br>daylight, with the reservation that, until that time, anchor-watches<br><br>shall be kept; that is, two and two for an hour, each couple, the<br><br>crew in rotation shall mount the deck to see that all goes well.<br><br><br><br>But sometimes, especially upon the Line in the Pacific, this plan<br><br>will not answer at all; because such incalculable hosts of sharks<br><br>gather round the moored carcase, that were he left so for six hours,<br><br>say, on a stretch, little more than the skeleton would be visible by<br><br>morning.  In most other parts of the ocean, however, where these fish<br><br>do not so largely abound, their wondrous voracity can be at times<br><br>considerably diminished, by vigorously stirring them up with sharp<br><br>whaling-spades, a procedure notwithstanding, which, in some<br><br>instances, only seems to tickle them into still greater activity.<br><br>But it was not thus in the present case with the Pequod's sharks;<br><br>though, to be sure, any man unaccustomed to such sights, to have<br><br>looked over her side that night, would have almost thought the whole<br><br>round sea was one huge cheese, and those sharks the maggots in it.<br><br><br><br>Nevertheless, upon Stubb setting the anchor-watch after his supper<br><br>was concluded; and when, accordingly, Queequeg and a forecastle<br><br>seaman came on deck, no small excitement was created among the<br><br>sharks; for immediately suspending the cutting stages over the side,<br><br>and lowering three lanterns, so that they cast long gleams of light<br><br>over the turbid sea, these two mariners, darting their long<br><br>whaling-spades, kept up an incessant murdering of the sharks,* by<br><br>striking the keen steel deep into their skulls, seemingly their only<br><br>vital part.  But in the foamy confusion of their mixed and struggling<br><br>hosts, the marksmen could not always hit their mark; and this brought<br><br>about new revelations of the incredible ferocity of the foe.  They<br><br>viciously snapped, not only at each other's disembowelments, but like<br><br>flexible bows, bent round, and bit their own; till those entrails<br><br>seemed swallowed over and over again by the same mouth, to be<br><br>oppositely voided by the gaping wound.  Nor was this all.  It was<br><br>unsafe to meddle with the corpses and ghosts of these creatures.  A<br><br>sort of generic or Pantheistic vitality seemed to lurk in their very<br><br>joints and bones, after what might be called the individual life had<br><br>departed.  Killed and hoisted on deck for the sake of his skin, one<br><br>of these sharks almost took poor Queequeg's hand off, when he tried<br><br>to shut down the dead lid of his murderous jaw.<br><br><br><br><br><br>*The whaling-spade used for cutting-in is made of the very best<br><br>steel; is about the bigness of a man's spread hand; and in general<br><br>shape, corresponds to the garden implement after which it is named;<br><br>only its sides are perfectly flat, and its upper end considerably<br><br>narrower than the lower.  This weapon is always kept as sharp as<br><br>possible; and when being used is occasionally honed, just like a<br><br>razor.  In its socket, a stiff pole, from twenty to thirty feet long,<br><br>is inserted for a handle.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"Queequeg no care what god made him shark," said the savage,<br><br>agonizingly lifting his hand up and down; "wedder Fejee god or<br><br>Nantucket god; but de god wat made shark must be one dam Ingin."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 67<br><br><br><br>Cutting In.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It was a Saturday night, and such a Sabbath as followed!  Ex officio<br><br>professors of Sabbath breaking are all whalemen.  The ivory Pequod<br><br>was turned into what seemed a shamble; every sailor a butcher.  You<br><br>would have thought we were offering up ten thousand red oxen to the<br><br>sea gods.<br><br><br><br>In the first place, the enormous cutting tackles, among other<br><br>ponderous things comprising a cluster of blocks generally painted<br><br>green, and which no single man can possibly lift--this vast bunch of<br><br>grapes was swayed up to the main-top and firmly lashed to the lower<br><br>mast-head, the strongest point anywhere above a ship's deck.  The end<br><br>of the hawser-like rope winding through these intricacies, was then<br><br>conducted to the windlass, and the huge lower block of the tackles<br><br>was swung over the whale; to this block the great blubber hook,<br><br>weighing some one hundred pounds, was attached.  And now suspended in<br><br>stages over the side, Starbuck and Stubb, the mates, armed with their<br><br>long spades, began cutting a hole in the body for the insertion of<br><br>the hook just above the nearest of the two side-fins.  This done, a<br><br>broad, semicircular line is cut round the hole, the hook is inserted,<br><br>and the main body of the crew striking up a wild chorus, now commence<br><br>heaving in one dense crowd at the windlass.  When instantly, the<br><br>entire ship careens over on her side; every bolt in her starts like<br><br>the nail-heads of an old house in frosty weather; she trembles,<br><br>quivers, and nods her frighted mast-heads to the sky.  More and more<br><br>she leans over to the whale, while every gasping heave of the<br><br>windlass is answered by a helping heave from the billows; till at<br><br>last, a swift, startling snap is heard; with a great swash the ship<br><br>rolls upwards and backwards from the whale, and the triumphant tackle<br><br>rises into sight dragging after it the disengaged semicircular end of<br><br>the first strip of blubber.  Now as the blubber envelopes the whale<br><br>precisely as the rind does an orange, so is it stripped off from the<br><br>body precisely as an orange is sometimes stripped by spiralizing it.<br><br>For the strain constantly kept up by the windlass continually keeps<br><br>the whale rolling over and over in the water, and as the blubber in<br><br>one strip uniformly peels off along the line called the "scarf,"<br><br>simultaneously cut by the spades of Starbuck and Stubb, the mates;<br><br>and just as fast as it is thus peeled off, and indeed by that very<br><br>act itself, it is all the time being hoisted higher and higher aloft<br><br>till its upper end grazes the main-top; the men at the windlass then<br><br>cease heaving, and for a moment or two the prodigious blood-dripping<br><br>mass sways to and fro as if let down from the sky, and every one<br><br>present must take good heed to dodge it when it swings, else it may<br><br>box his ears and pitch him headlong overboard.<br><br><br><br>One of the attending harpooneers now advances with a long, keen<br><br>weapon called a boarding-sword, and watching his chance he<br><br>dexterously slices out a considerable hole in the lower part of the<br><br>swaying mass.  Into this hole, the end of the second alternating<br><br>great tackle is then hooked so as to retain a hold upon the blubber,<br><br>in order to prepare for what follows.  Whereupon, this accomplished<br><br>swordsman, warning all hands to stand off, once more makes a<br><br>scientific dash at the mass, and with a few sidelong, desperate,<br><br>lunging slicings, severs it completely in twain; so that while the<br><br>short lower part is still fast, the long upper strip, called a<br><br>blanket-piece, swings clear, and is all ready for lowering.  The<br><br>heavers forward now resume their song, and while the one tackle is<br><br>peeling and hoisting a second strip from the whale, the other is<br><br>slowly slackened away, and down goes the first strip through the main<br><br>hatchway right beneath, into an unfurnished parlor called the<br><br>blubber-room.  Into this twilight apartment sundry nimble hands keep<br><br>coiling away the long blanket-piece as if it were a great live mass<br><br>of plaited serpents.  And thus the work proceeds; the two tackles<br><br>hoisting and lowering simultaneously; both whale and windlass<br><br>heaving, the heavers singing, the blubber-room gentlemen coiling, the<br><br>mates scarfing, the ship straining, and all hands swearing<br><br>occasionally, by way of assuaging the general friction.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 68<br><br><br><br>The Blanket.<br><br><br><br><br><br>I have given no small attention to that not unvexed subject, the skin<br><br>of the whale.  I have had controversies about it with experienced<br><br>whalemen afloat, and learned naturalists ashore.  My original opinion<br><br>remains unchanged; but it is only an opinion.<br><br><br><br>The question is, what and where is the skin of the whale?  Already<br><br>you know what his blubber is.  That blubber is something of the<br><br>consistence of firm, close-grained beef, but tougher, more elastic<br><br>and compact, and ranges from eight or ten to twelve and fifteen<br><br>inches in thickness.<br><br><br><br>Now, however preposterous it may at first seem to talk of any<br><br>creature's skin as being of that sort of consistence and thickness,<br><br>yet in point of fact these are no arguments against such a<br><br>presumption; because you cannot raise any other dense enveloping<br><br>layer from the whale's body but that same blubber; and the outermost<br><br>enveloping layer of any animal, if reasonably dense, what can that be<br><br>but the skin?  True, from the unmarred dead body of the whale, you<br><br>may scrape off with your hand an infinitely thin, transparent<br><br>substance, somewhat resembling the thinnest shreds of isinglass, only<br><br>it is almost as flexible and soft as satin; that is, previous to<br><br>being dried, when it not only contracts and thickens, but becomes<br><br>rather hard and brittle.  I have several such dried bits, which I use<br><br>for marks in my whale-books.  It is transparent, as I said before;<br><br>and being laid upon the printed page, I have sometimes pleased myself<br><br>with fancying it exerted a magnifying influence.  At any rate, it is<br><br>pleasant to read about whales through their own spectacles, as you<br><br>may say.  But what I am driving at here is this.  That same<br><br>infinitely thin, isinglass substance, which, I admit, invests the<br><br>entire body of the whale, is not so much to be regarded as the skin<br><br>of the creature, as the skin of the skin, so to speak; for it were<br><br>simply ridiculous to say, that the proper skin of the tremendous<br><br>whale is thinner and more tender than the skin of a new-born child.<br><br>But no more of this.<br><br><br><br>Assuming the blubber to be the skin of the whale; then, when this<br><br>skin, as in the case of a very large Sperm Whale, will yield the bulk<br><br>of one hundred barrels of oil; and, when it is considered that, in<br><br>quantity, or rather weight, that oil, in its expressed state, is only<br><br>three fourths, and not the entire substance of the coat; some idea<br><br>may hence be had of the enormousness of that animated mass, a mere<br><br>part of whose mere integument yields such a lake of liquid as that.<br><br>Reckoning ten barrels to the ton, you have ten tons for the net<br><br>weight of only three quarters of the stuff of the whale's skin.<br><br><br><br>In life, the visible surface of the Sperm Whale is not the least<br><br>among the many marvels he presents.  Almost invariably it is all over<br><br>obliquely crossed and re-crossed with numberless straight marks in<br><br>thick array, something like those in the finest Italian line<br><br>engravings.  But these marks do not seem to be impressed upon the<br><br>isinglass substance above mentioned, but seem to be seen through it,<br><br>as if they were engraved upon the body itself.  Nor is this all.  In<br><br>some instances, to the quick, observant eye, those linear marks, as<br><br>in a veritable engraving, but afford the ground for far other<br><br>delineations.  These are hieroglyphical; that is, if you call those<br><br>mysterious cyphers on the walls of pyramids hieroglyphics, then that<br><br>is the proper word to use in the present connexion.  By my retentive<br><br>memory of the hieroglyphics upon one Sperm Whale in particular, I was<br><br>much struck with a plate representing the old Indian characters<br><br>chiselled on the famous hieroglyphic palisades on the banks of the<br><br>Upper Mississippi.  Like those mystic rocks, too, the mystic-marked<br><br>whale remains undecipherable.  This allusion to the Indian rocks<br><br>reminds me of another thing.  Besides all the other phenomena which<br><br>the exterior of the Sperm Whale presents, he not seldom displays the<br><br>back, and more especially his flanks, effaced in great part of the<br><br>regular linear appearance, by reason of numerous rude scratches,<br><br>altogether of an irregular, random aspect.  I should say that those<br><br>New England rocks on the sea-coast, which Agassiz imagines to bear<br><br>the marks of violent scraping contact with vast floating icebergs--I<br><br>should say, that those rocks must not a little resemble the Sperm<br><br>Whale in this particular.  It also seems to me that such scratches in<br><br>the whale are probably made by hostile contact with other whales; for<br><br>I have most remarked them in the large, full-grown bulls of the<br><br>species.<br><br><br><br>A word or two more concerning this matter of the skin or blubber of<br><br>the whale.  It has already been said, that it is stript from him in<br><br>long pieces, called blanket-pieces.  Like most sea-terms, this one is<br><br>very happy and significant.  For the whale is indeed wrapt up in his<br><br>blubber as in a real blanket or counterpane; or, still better, an<br><br>Indian poncho slipt over his head, and skirting his extremity.  It is<br><br>by reason of this cosy blanketing of his body, that the whale is<br><br>enabled to keep himself comfortable in all weathers, in all seas,<br><br>times, and tides.  What would become of a Greenland whale, say, in<br><br>those shuddering, icy seas of the North, if unsupplied with his cosy<br><br>surtout?  True, other fish are found exceedingly brisk in those<br><br>Hyperborean waters; but these, be it observed, are your cold-blooded,<br><br>lungless fish, whose very bellies are refrigerators; creatures, that<br><br>warm themselves under the lee of an iceberg, as a traveller in winter<br><br>would bask before an inn fire; whereas, like man, the whale has lungs<br><br>and warm blood.  Freeze his blood, and he dies.  How wonderful is it<br><br>then--except after explanation--that this great monster, to whom<br><br>corporeal warmth is as indispensable as it is to man; how wonderful<br><br>that he should be found at home, immersed to his lips for life in<br><br>those Arctic waters! where, when seamen fall overboard, they are<br><br>sometimes found, months afterwards, perpendicularly frozen into the<br><br>hearts of fields of ice, as a fly is found glued in amber.  But more<br><br>surprising is it to know, as has been proved by experiment, that the<br><br>blood of a Polar whale is warmer than that of a Borneo negro in<br><br>summer.<br><br><br><br>It does seem to me, that herein we see the rare virtue of a strong<br><br>individual vitality, and the rare virtue of thick walls, and the rare<br><br>virtue of interior spaciousness.  Oh, man! admire and model thyself<br><br>after the whale!  Do thou, too, remain warm among ice.  Do thou, too,<br><br>live in this world without being of it.  Be cool at the equator; keep<br><br>thy blood fluid at the Pole.  Like the great dome of St. Peter's, and<br><br>like the great whale, retain, O man! in all seasons a temperature of<br><br>thine own.<br><br><br><br>But how easy and how hopeless to teach these fine things!  Of<br><br>erections, how few are domed like St. Peter's! of creatures, how few<br><br>vast as the whale!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 69<br><br><br><br>The Funeral.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Haul in the chains!  Let the carcase go astern!<br><br><br><br>The vast tackles have now done their duty.  The peeled white body of<br><br>the beheaded whale flashes like a marble sepulchre; though changed in<br><br>hue, it has not perceptibly lost anything in bulk.  It is still<br><br>colossal.  Slowly it floats more and more away, the water round it<br><br>torn and splashed by the insatiate sharks, and the air above vexed<br><br>with rapacious flights of screaming fowls, whose beaks are like so<br><br>many insulting poniards in the whale.  The vast white headless<br><br>phantom floats further and further from the ship, and every rod that<br><br>it so floats, what seem square roods of sharks and cubic roods of<br><br>fowls, augment the murderous din.  For hours and hours from the<br><br>almost stationary ship that hideous sight is seen.  Beneath the<br><br>unclouded and mild azure sky, upon the fair face of the pleasant sea,<br><br>wafted by the joyous breezes, that great mass of death floats on and<br><br>on, till lost in infinite perspectives.<br><br><br><br>There's a most doleful and most mocking funeral!  The sea-vultures<br><br>all in pious mourning, the air-sharks all punctiliously in black or<br><br>speckled.  In life but few of them would have helped the whale, I<br><br>ween, if peradventure he had needed it; but upon the banquet of his<br><br>funeral they most piously do pounce.  Oh, horrible vultureism of<br><br>earth! from which not the mightiest whale is free.<br><br><br><br>Nor is this the end.  Desecrated as the body is, a vengeful ghost<br><br>survives and hovers over it to scare.  Espied by some timid<br><br>man-of-war or blundering discovery-vessel from afar, when the<br><br>distance obscuring the swarming fowls, nevertheless still shows the<br><br>white mass floating in the sun, and the white spray heaving high<br><br>against it; straightway the whale's unharming corpse, with trembling<br><br>fingers is set down in the log--SHOALS, ROCKS, AND BREAKERS<br><br>HEREABOUTS: BEWARE!  And for years afterwards, perhaps, ships shun<br><br>the place; leaping over it as silly sheep leap over a vacuum, because<br><br>their leader originally leaped there when a stick was held.  There's<br><br>your law of precedents; there's your utility of traditions; there's<br><br>the story of your obstinate survival of old beliefs never bottomed on<br><br>the earth, and now not even hovering in the air!  There's orthodoxy!<br><br><br><br>Thus, while in life the great whale's body may have been a real<br><br>terror to his foes, in his death his ghost becomes a powerless panic<br><br>to a world.<br><br><br><br>Are you a believer in ghosts, my friend?  There are other ghosts than<br><br>the Cock-Lane one, and far deeper men than Doctor Johnson who believe<br><br>in them.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 70<br><br><br><br>The Sphynx.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It should not have been omitted that previous to completely stripping<br><br>the body of the leviathan, he was beheaded.  Now, the beheading of<br><br>the Sperm Whale is a scientific anatomical feat, upon which<br><br>experienced whale surgeons very much pride themselves: and not<br><br>without reason.<br><br><br><br>Consider that the whale has nothing that can properly be called a<br><br>neck; on the contrary, where his head and body seem to join, there,<br><br>in that very place, is the thickest part of him.  Remember, also,<br><br>that the surgeon must operate from above, some eight or ten feet<br><br>intervening between him and his subject, and that subject almost<br><br>hidden in a discoloured, rolling, and oftentimes tumultuous and<br><br>bursting sea.  Bear in mind, too, that under these untoward<br><br>circumstances he has to cut many feet deep in the flesh; and in that<br><br>subterraneous manner, without so much as getting one single peep into<br><br>the ever-contracting gash thus made, he must skilfully steer clear<br><br>of all adjacent, interdicted parts, and exactly divide the spine at a<br><br>critical point hard by its insertion into the skull.  Do you not<br><br>marvel, then, at Stubb's boast, that he demanded but ten minutes to<br><br>behead a sperm whale?<br><br><br><br>When first severed, the head is dropped astern and held there by a<br><br>cable till the body is stripped.  That done, if it belong to a small<br><br>whale it is hoisted on deck to be deliberately disposed of.  But,<br><br>with a full grown leviathan this is impossible; for the sperm whale's<br><br>head embraces nearly one third of his entire bulk, and completely to<br><br>suspend such a burden as that, even by the immense tackles of a<br><br>whaler, this were as vain a thing as to attempt weighing a Dutch barn<br><br>in jewellers' scales.<br><br><br><br>The Pequod's whale being decapitated and the body stripped, the head<br><br>was hoisted against the ship's side--about half way out of the sea,<br><br>so that it might yet in great part be buoyed up by its native<br><br>element.  And there with the strained craft steeply leaning over to it,<br><br>by reason of the enormous downward drag from the lower mast-head, and<br><br>every yard-arm on that side projecting like a crane over the waves;<br><br>there, that blood-dripping head hung to the Pequod's waist like the<br><br>giant Holofernes's from the girdle of Judith.<br><br><br><br>When this last task was accomplished it was noon, and the seamen went<br><br>below to their dinner.  Silence reigned over the before tumultuous<br><br>but now deserted deck.  An intense copper calm, like a universal<br><br>yellow lotus, was more and more unfolding its noiseless measureless<br><br>leaves upon the sea.<br><br><br><br>A short space elapsed, and up into this noiselessness came Ahab alone<br><br>from his cabin.  Taking a few turns on the quarter-deck, he paused to<br><br>gaze over the side, then slowly getting into the main-chains he took<br><br>Stubb's long spade--still remaining there after the whale's<br><br>Decapitation--and striking it into the lower part of the<br><br>half-suspended mass, placed its other end crutch-wise under one arm,<br><br>and so stood leaning over with eyes attentively fixed on this head.<br><br><br><br>It was a black and hooded head; and hanging there in the midst of so<br><br>intense a calm, it seemed the Sphynx's in the desert.  "Speak, thou<br><br>vast and venerable head," muttered Ahab, "which, though ungarnished<br><br>with a beard, yet here and there lookest hoary with mosses; speak,<br><br>mighty head, and tell us the secret thing that is in thee.  Of all<br><br>divers, thou hast dived the deepest.  That head upon which the upper<br><br>sun now gleams, has moved amid this world's foundations.  Where<br><br>unrecorded names and navies rust, and untold hopes and anchors rot;<br><br>where in her murderous hold this frigate earth is ballasted with<br><br>bones of millions of the drowned; there, in that awful water-land,<br><br>there was thy most familiar home.  Thou hast been where bell or diver<br><br>never went; hast slept by many a sailor's side, where sleepless<br><br>mothers would give their lives to lay them down.  Thou saw'st the<br><br>locked lovers when leaping from their flaming ship; heart to heart<br><br>they sank beneath the exulting wave; true to each other, when heaven<br><br>seemed false to them.  Thou saw'st the murdered mate when tossed by<br><br>pirates from the midnight deck; for hours he fell into the deeper<br><br>midnight of the insatiate maw; and his murderers still sailed on<br><br>unharmed--while swift lightnings shivered the neighboring ship that<br><br>would have borne a righteous husband to outstretched, longing arms.<br><br>O head! thou hast seen enough to split the planets and make an<br><br>infidel of Abraham, and not one syllable is thine!"<br><br><br><br>"Sail ho!" cried a triumphant voice from the main-mast-head.<br><br><br><br>"Aye?  Well, now, that's cheering," cried Ahab, suddenly erecting<br><br>himself, while whole thunder-clouds swept aside from his brow.  "That<br><br>lively cry upon this deadly calm might almost convert a better<br><br>man.--Where away?"<br><br><br><br>"Three points on the starboard bow, sir, and bringing down her breeze<br><br>to us!<br><br><br><br>"Better and better, man.  Would now St. Paul would come along that<br><br>way, and to my breezelessness bring his breeze!  O Nature, and O soul<br><br>of man! how far beyond all utterance are your linked analogies! not<br><br>the smallest atom stirs or lives on matter, but has its cunning<br><br>duplicate in mind."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 71<br><br><br><br>The Jeroboam's Story.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Hand in hand, ship and breeze blew on; but the breeze came faster<br><br>than the ship, and soon the Pequod began to rock.<br><br><br><br>By and by, through the glass the stranger's boats and manned<br><br>mast-heads proved her a whale-ship.  But as she was so far to<br><br>windward, and shooting by, apparently making a passage to some other<br><br>ground, the Pequod could not hope to reach her.  So the signal was<br><br>set to see what response would be made.<br><br><br><br>Here be it said, that like the vessels of military marines, the ships<br><br>of the American Whale Fleet have each a private signal; all which<br><br>signals being collected in a book with the names of the respective<br><br>vessels attached, every captain is provided with it.  Thereby, the<br><br>whale commanders are enabled to recognise each other upon the ocean,<br><br>even at considerable distances and with no small facility.<br><br><br><br>The Pequod's signal was at last responded to by the stranger's<br><br>setting her own; which proved the ship to be the Jeroboam of<br><br>Nantucket.  Squaring her yards, she bore down, ranged abeam under the<br><br>Pequod's lee, and lowered a boat; it soon drew nigh; but, as the<br><br>side-ladder was being rigged by Starbuck's order to accommodate the<br><br>visiting captain, the stranger in question waved his hand from his<br><br>boat's stern in token of that proceeding being entirely unnecessary.<br><br>It turned out that the Jeroboam had a malignant epidemic on board,<br><br>and that Mayhew, her captain, was fearful of infecting the Pequod's<br><br>company.  For, though himself and boat's crew remained untainted, and<br><br>though his ship was half a rifle-shot off, and an incorruptible sea<br><br>and air rolling and flowing between; yet conscientiously adhering to<br><br>the timid quarantine of the land, he peremptorily refused to come<br><br>into direct contact with the Pequod.<br><br><br><br>But this did by no means prevent all communications.  Preserving an<br><br>interval of some few yards between itself and the ship, the<br><br>Jeroboam's boat by the occasional use of its oars contrived to keep<br><br>parallel to the Pequod, as she heavily forged through the sea (for by<br><br>this time it blew very fresh), with her main-topsail aback; though,<br><br>indeed, at times by the sudden onset of a large rolling wave, the<br><br>boat would be pushed some way ahead; but would be soon skilfully<br><br>brought to her proper bearings again.  Subject to this, and other the<br><br>like interruptions now and then, a conversation was sustained between<br><br>the two parties; but at intervals not without still another<br><br>interruption of a very different sort.<br><br><br><br>Pulling an oar in the Jeroboam's boat, was a man of a singular<br><br>appearance, even in that wild whaling life where individual<br><br>notabilities make up all totalities.  He was a small, short, youngish<br><br>man, sprinkled all over his face with freckles, and wearing redundant<br><br>yellow hair.  A long-skirted, cabalistically-cut coat of a faded<br><br>walnut tinge enveloped him; the overlapping sleeves of which were<br><br>rolled up on his wrists.  A deep, settled, fanatic delirium was in<br><br>his eyes.<br><br><br><br>So soon as this figure had been first descried, Stubb had<br><br>exclaimed--"That's he! that's he!--the long-togged scaramouch the<br><br>Town-Ho's company told us of!"  Stubb here alluded to a strange story<br><br>told of the Jeroboam, and a certain man among her crew, some time<br><br>previous when the Pequod spoke the Town-Ho.  According to this<br><br>account and what was subsequently learned, it seemed that the<br><br>scaramouch in question had gained a wonderful ascendency over almost<br><br>everybody in the Jeroboam.  His story was this:<br><br><br><br>He had been originally nurtured among the crazy society of Neskyeuna<br><br>Shakers, where he had been a great prophet; in their cracked, secret<br><br>meetings having several times descended from heaven by the way of a<br><br>trap-door, announcing the speedy opening of the seventh vial, which<br><br>he carried in his vest-pocket; but, which, instead of containing<br><br>gunpowder, was supposed to be charged with laudanum.  A strange,<br><br>apostolic whim having seized him, he had left Neskyeuna for<br><br>Nantucket, where, with that cunning peculiar to craziness, he assumed<br><br>a steady, common-sense exterior, and offered himself as a green-hand<br><br>candidate for the Jeroboam's whaling voyage.  They engaged him; but<br><br>straightway upon the ship's getting out of sight of land, his<br><br>insanity broke out in a freshet.  He announced himself as the<br><br>archangel Gabriel, and commanded the captain to jump overboard.  He<br><br>published his manifesto, whereby he set himself forth as the<br><br>deliverer of the isles of the sea and vicar-general of all Oceanica.<br><br>The unflinching earnestness with which he declared these things;--the<br><br>dark, daring play of his sleepless, excited imagination, and all the<br><br>preternatural terrors of real delirium, united to invest this Gabriel<br><br>in the minds of the majority of the ignorant crew, with an atmosphere<br><br>of sacredness.  Moreover, they were afraid of him.  As such a man,<br><br>however, was not of much practical use in the ship, especially as he<br><br>refused to work except when he pleased, the incredulous captain would<br><br>fain have been rid of him; but apprised that that individual's<br><br>intention was to land him in the first convenient port, the archangel<br><br>forthwith opened all his seals and vials--devoting the ship and all<br><br>hands to unconditional perdition, in case this intention was carried<br><br>out.  So strongly did he work upon his disciples among the crew, that<br><br>at last in a body they went to the captain and told him if Gabriel<br><br>was sent from the ship, not a man of them would remain.  He was<br><br>therefore forced to relinquish his plan.  Nor would they permit<br><br>Gabriel to be any way maltreated, say or do what he would; so that it<br><br>came to pass that Gabriel had the complete freedom of the ship.  The<br><br>consequence of all this was, that the archangel cared little or<br><br>nothing for the captain and mates; and since the epidemic had broken<br><br>out, he carried a higher hand than ever; declaring that the plague,<br><br>as he called it, was at his sole command; nor should it be stayed but<br><br>according to his good pleasure.  The sailors, mostly poor devils,<br><br>cringed, and some of them fawned before him; in obedience to his<br><br>instructions, sometimes rendering him personal homage, as to a god.<br><br>Such things may seem incredible; but, however wondrous, they are<br><br>true.  Nor is the history of fanatics half so striking in respect to<br><br>the measureless self-deception of the fanatic himself, as his<br><br>measureless power of deceiving and bedevilling so many others.  But<br><br>it is time to return to the Pequod.<br><br><br><br>"I fear not thy epidemic, man," said Ahab from the bulwarks, to<br><br>Captain Mayhew, who stood in the boat's stern; "come on board."<br><br><br><br>But now Gabriel started to his feet.<br><br><br><br>"Think, think of the fevers, yellow and bilious!  Beware of the<br><br>horrible plague!"<br><br><br><br>"Gabriel!
