Gabriel!" cried Captain Mayhew; "thou must either--"  But<br><br>that instant a headlong wave shot the boat far ahead, and its<br><br>seethings drowned all speech.<br><br><br><br>"Hast thou seen the White Whale?" demanded Ahab, when the boat<br><br>drifted back.<br><br><br><br>"Think, think of thy whale-boat, stoven and sunk!  Beware of the<br><br>horrible tail!"<br><br><br><br>"I tell thee again, Gabriel, that--"  But again the boat tore ahead<br><br>as if dragged by fiends.  Nothing was said for some moments, while a<br><br>succession of riotous waves rolled by, which by one of those<br><br>occasional caprices of the seas were tumbling, not heaving it.<br><br>Meantime, the hoisted sperm whale's head jogged about very violently,<br><br>and Gabriel was seen eyeing it with rather more apprehensiveness than<br><br>his archangel nature seemed to warrant.<br><br><br><br>When this interlude was over, Captain Mayhew began a dark story<br><br>concerning Moby Dick; not, however, without frequent interruptions<br><br>from Gabriel, whenever his name was mentioned, and the crazy sea that<br><br>seemed leagued with him.<br><br><br><br>It seemed that the Jeroboam had not long left home, when upon<br><br>speaking a whale-ship, her people were reliably apprised of the<br><br>existence of Moby Dick, and the havoc he had made.  Greedily sucking<br><br>in this intelligence, Gabriel solemnly warned the captain against<br><br>attacking the White Whale, in case the monster should be seen; in his<br><br>gibbering insanity, pronouncing the White Whale to be no less a being<br><br>than the Shaker God incarnated; the Shakers receiving the Bible.  But<br><br>when, some year or two afterwards, Moby Dick was fairly sighted from<br><br>the mast-heads, Macey, the chief mate, burned with ardour to encounter<br><br>him; and the captain himself being not unwilling to let him have the<br><br>opportunity, despite all the archangel's denunciations and<br><br>forewarnings, Macey succeeded in persuading five men to man his boat.<br><br>With them he pushed off; and, after much weary pulling, and many<br><br>perilous, unsuccessful onsets, he at last succeeded in getting one<br><br>iron fast.  Meantime, Gabriel, ascending to the main-royal mast-head,<br><br>was tossing one arm in frantic gestures, and hurling forth prophecies<br><br>of speedy doom to the sacrilegious assailants of his divinity.  Now,<br><br>while Macey, the mate, was standing up in his boat's bow, and with<br><br>all the reckless energy of his tribe was venting his wild<br><br>exclamations upon the whale, and essaying to get a fair chance for<br><br>his poised lance, lo! a broad white shadow rose from the sea; by its<br><br>quick, fanning motion, temporarily taking the breath out of the<br><br>bodies of the oarsmen.  Next instant, the luckless mate, so full of<br><br>furious life, was smitten bodily into the air, and making a long arc<br><br>in his descent, fell into the sea at the distance of about fifty<br><br>yards.  Not a chip of the boat was harmed, nor a hair of any<br><br>oarsman's head; but the mate for ever sank.<br><br><br><br>It is well to parenthesize here, that of the fatal accidents in the<br><br>Sperm-Whale Fishery, this kind is perhaps almost as frequent as any.<br><br>Sometimes, nothing is injured but the man who is thus annihilated;<br><br>oftener the boat's bow is knocked off, or the thigh-board, in which<br><br>the headsman stands, is torn from its place and accompanies the body.<br><br>But strangest of all is the circumstance, that in more instances<br><br>than one, when the body has been recovered, not a single mark of<br><br>violence is discernible; the man being stark dead.<br><br><br><br>The whole calamity, with the falling form of Macey, was plainly<br><br>descried from the ship.  Raising a piercing shriek--"The vial! the<br><br>vial!"  Gabriel called off the terror-stricken crew from the further<br><br>hunting of the whale.  This terrible event clothed the archangel with<br><br>added influence; because his credulous disciples believed that he had<br><br>specifically fore-announced it, instead of only making a general<br><br>prophecy, which any one might have done, and so have chanced to hit<br><br>one of many marks in the wide margin allowed.  He became a nameless<br><br>terror to the ship.<br><br><br><br>Mayhew having concluded his narration, Ahab put such questions to<br><br>him, that the stranger captain could not forbear inquiring whether he<br><br>intended to hunt the White Whale, if opportunity should offer.  To<br><br>which Ahab answered--"Aye."  Straightway, then, Gabriel once more<br><br>started to his feet, glaring upon the old man, and vehemently<br><br>exclaimed, with downward pointed finger--"Think, think of the<br><br>blasphemer--dead, and down there!--beware of the blasphemer's end!"<br><br><br><br>Ahab stolidly turned aside; then said to Mayhew, "Captain, I have<br><br>just bethought me of my letter-bag; there is a letter for one of thy<br><br>officers, if I mistake not.  Starbuck, look over the bag."<br><br><br><br>Every whale-ship takes out a goodly number of letters for various<br><br>ships, whose delivery to the persons to whom they may be addressed,<br><br>depends upon the mere chance of encountering them in the four oceans.<br><br>Thus, most letters never reach their mark; and many are only<br><br>received after attaining an age of two or three years or more.<br><br><br><br>Soon Starbuck returned with a letter in his hand.  It was sorely<br><br>tumbled, damp, and covered with a dull, spotted, green mould, in<br><br>consequence of being kept in a dark locker of the cabin.  Of such a<br><br>letter, Death himself might well have been the post-boy.<br><br><br><br>"Can'st not read it?" cried Ahab.  "Give it me, man.  Aye, aye, it's<br><br>but a dim scrawl;--what's this?"  As he was studying it out, Starbuck<br><br>took a long cutting-spade pole, and with his knife slightly split the<br><br>end, to insert the letter there, and in that way, hand it to the<br><br>boat, without its coming any closer to the ship.<br><br><br><br>Meantime, Ahab holding the letter, muttered, "Mr. Har--yes, Mr.<br><br>Harry--(a woman's pinny hand,--the man's wife, I'll wager)--Aye--Mr.<br><br>Harry Macey, Ship Jeroboam;--why it's Macey, and he's dead!"<br><br><br><br>"Poor fellow! poor fellow! and from his wife," sighed Mayhew; "but<br><br>let me have it."<br><br><br><br>"Nay, keep it thyself," cried Gabriel to Ahab; "thou art soon going<br><br>that way."<br><br><br><br>"Curses throttle thee!" yelled Ahab.  "Captain Mayhew, stand by now<br><br>to receive it"; and taking the fatal missive from Starbuck's hands,<br><br>he caught it in the slit of the pole, and reached it over towards the<br><br>boat.  But as he did so, the oarsmen expectantly desisted from<br><br>rowing; the boat drifted a little towards the ship's stern; so that,<br><br>as if by magic, the letter suddenly ranged along with Gabriel's eager<br><br>hand.  He clutched it in an instant, seized the boat-knife, and<br><br>impaling the letter on it, sent it thus loaded back into the ship.<br><br>It fell at Ahab's feet.  Then Gabriel shrieked out to his comrades to<br><br>give way with their oars, and in that manner the mutinous boat<br><br>rapidly shot away from the Pequod.<br><br><br><br>As, after this interlude, the seamen resumed their work upon the<br><br>jacket of the whale, many strange things were hinted in reference to<br><br>this wild affair.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 72<br><br><br><br>The Monkey-Rope.<br><br><br><br><br><br>In the tumultuous business of cutting-in and attending to a whale,<br><br>there is much running backwards and forwards among the crew.  Now<br><br>hands are wanted here, and then again hands are wanted there.  There<br><br>is no staying in any one place; for at one and the same time<br><br>everything has to be done everywhere.  It is much the same with him<br><br>who endeavors the description of the scene.  We must now retrace our<br><br>way a little.  It was mentioned that upon first breaking ground in<br><br>the whale's back, the blubber-hook was inserted into the original<br><br>hole there cut by the spades of the mates.  But how did so clumsy and<br><br>weighty a mass as that same hook get fixed in that hole?  It was<br><br>inserted there by my particular friend Queequeg, whose duty it was,<br><br>as harpooneer, to descend upon the monster's back for the special<br><br>purpose referred to.  But in very many cases, circumstances require<br><br>that the harpooneer shall remain on the whale till the whole tensing<br><br>or stripping operation is concluded.  The whale, be it observed, lies<br><br>almost entirely submerged, excepting the immediate parts operated<br><br>upon.  So down there, some ten feet below the level of the deck, the<br><br>poor harpooneer flounders about, half on the whale and half in the<br><br>water, as the vast mass revolves like a tread-mill beneath him.  On<br><br>the occasion in question, Queequeg figured in the Highland costume--a<br><br>shirt and socks--in which to my eyes, at least, he appeared to<br><br>uncommon advantage; and no one had a better chance to observe him, as<br><br>will presently be seen.<br><br><br><br>Being the savage's bowsman, that is, the person who pulled the<br><br>bow-oar in his boat (the second one from forward), it was my cheerful<br><br>duty to attend upon him while taking that hard-scrabble scramble upon<br><br>the dead whale's back.  You have seen Italian organ-boys holding a<br><br>dancing-ape by a long cord.  Just so, from the ship's steep side, did<br><br>I hold Queequeg down there in the sea, by what is technically called<br><br>in the fishery a monkey-rope, attached to a strong strip of canvas<br><br>belted round his waist.<br><br><br><br>It was a humorously perilous business for both of us.  For, before we<br><br>proceed further, it must be said that the monkey-rope was fast at<br><br>both ends; fast to Queequeg's broad canvas belt, and fast to my<br><br>narrow leather one.  So that for better or for worse, we two, for the<br><br>time, were wedded; and should poor Queequeg sink to rise no more,<br><br>then both usage and honour demanded, that instead of cutting the cord,<br><br>it should drag me down in his wake.  So, then, an elongated Siamese<br><br>ligature united us.  Queequeg was my own inseparable twin brother;<br><br>nor could I any way get rid of the dangerous liabilities which the<br><br>hempen bond entailed.<br><br><br><br>So strongly and metaphysically did I conceive of my situation then,<br><br>that while earnestly watching his motions, I seemed distinctly to<br><br>perceive that my own individuality was now merged in a joint stock<br><br>company of two; that my free will had received a mortal wound; and<br><br>that another's mistake or misfortune might plunge innocent me into<br><br>unmerited disaster and death.  Therefore, I saw that here was a sort<br><br>of interregnum in Providence; for its even-handed equity never could<br><br>have so gross an injustice.  And yet still further pondering--while I<br><br>jerked him now and then from between the whale and ship, which would<br><br>threaten to jam him--still further pondering, I say, I saw that this<br><br>situation of mine was the precise situation of every mortal that<br><br>breathes; only, in most cases, he, one way or other, has this Siamese<br><br>connexion with a plurality of other mortals.  If your banker breaks,<br><br>you snap; if your apothecary by mistake sends you poison in your<br><br>pills, you die.  True, you may say that, by exceeding caution, you<br><br>may possibly escape these and the multitudinous other evil chances of<br><br>life.  But handle Queequeg's monkey-rope heedfully as I would,<br><br>sometimes he jerked it so, that I came very near sliding overboard.<br><br>Nor could I possibly forget that, do what I would, I only had the<br><br>management of one end of it.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*The monkey-rope is found in all whalers; but it was only in the<br><br>Pequod that the monkey and his holder were ever tied together.  This<br><br>improvement upon the original usage was introduced by no less a man<br><br>than Stubb, in order to afford the imperilled harpooneer the strongest<br><br>possible guarantee for the faithfulness and vigilance of his<br><br>monkey-rope holder.<br><br><br><br><br><br>I have hinted that I would often jerk poor Queequeg from between the<br><br>whale and the ship--where he would occasionally fall, from the<br><br>incessant rolling and swaying of both.  But this was not the only<br><br>jamming jeopardy he was exposed to.  Unappalled by the massacre made<br><br>upon them during the night, the sharks now freshly and more keenly<br><br>allured by the before pent blood which began to flow from the<br><br>carcass--the rabid creatures swarmed round it like bees in a beehive.<br><br><br><br>And right in among those sharks was Queequeg; who often pushed them<br><br>aside with his floundering feet.  A thing altogether incredible were<br><br>it not that attracted by such prey as a dead whale, the otherwise<br><br>miscellaneously carnivorous shark will seldom touch a man.<br><br><br><br>Nevertheless, it may well be believed that since they have such a<br><br>ravenous finger in the pie, it is deemed but wise to look sharp to<br><br>them.  Accordingly, besides the monkey-rope, with which I now and<br><br>then jerked the poor fellow from too close a vicinity to the maw of<br><br>what seemed a peculiarly ferocious shark--he was provided with still<br><br>another protection.  Suspended over the side in one of the stages,<br><br>Tashtego and Daggoo continually flourished over his head a couple of<br><br>keen whale-spades, wherewith they slaughtered as many sharks as they<br><br>could reach.  This procedure of theirs, to be sure, was very<br><br>disinterested and benevolent of them.  They meant Queequeg's best<br><br>happiness, I admit; but in their hasty zeal to befriend him, and from<br><br>the circumstance that both he and the sharks were at times half<br><br>hidden by the blood-muddled water, those indiscreet spades of theirs<br><br>would come nearer amputating a leg than a tall.  But poor Queequeg, I<br><br>suppose, straining and gasping there with that great iron hook--poor<br><br>Queequeg, I suppose, only prayed to his Yojo, and gave up his life<br><br>into the hands of his gods.<br><br><br><br>Well, well, my dear comrade and twin-brother, thought I, as I drew in<br><br>and then slacked off the rope to every swell of the sea--what matters<br><br>it, after all?  Are you not the precious image of each and all of us<br><br>men in this whaling world?  That unsounded ocean you gasp in, is<br><br>Life; those sharks, your foes; those spades, your friends; and what<br><br>between sharks and spades you are in a sad pickle and peril, poor<br><br>lad.<br><br><br><br>But courage! there is good cheer in store for you, Queequeg.  For<br><br>now, as with blue lips and blood-shot eyes the exhausted savage at<br><br>last climbs up the chains and stands all dripping and involuntarily<br><br>trembling over the side; the steward advances, and with a benevolent,<br><br>consolatory glance hands him--what?  Some hot Cognac?  No! hands him,<br><br>ye gods! hands him a cup of tepid ginger and water!<br><br><br><br>"Ginger?  Do I smell ginger?" suspiciously asked Stubb, coming near.<br><br>"Yes, this must be ginger," peering into the as yet untasted cup.<br><br>Then standing as if incredulous for a while, he calmly walked towards<br><br>the astonished steward slowly saying, "Ginger? ginger? and will you<br><br>have the goodness to tell me, Mr. Dough-Boy, where lies the virtue of<br><br>ginger?  Ginger! is ginger the sort of fuel you use, Dough-boy, to<br><br>kindle a fire in this shivering cannibal?  Ginger!--what the devil is<br><br>ginger?--sea-coal? firewood?--lucifer<br><br>matches?--tinder?--gunpowder?--what the devil is ginger, I say, that<br><br>you offer this cup to our poor Queequeg here."<br><br><br><br>"There is some sneaking Temperance Society movement about this<br><br>business," he suddenly added, now approaching Starbuck, who had just<br><br>come from forward.  "Will you look at that kannakin, sir; smell of<br><br>it, if you please."  Then watching the mate's countenance, he added,<br><br>"The steward, Mr. Starbuck, had the face to offer that calomel and<br><br>jalap to Queequeg, there, this instant off the whale.  Is the steward<br><br>an apothecary, sir? and may I ask whether this is the sort of bitters<br><br>by which he blows back the life into a half-drowned man?"<br><br><br><br>"I trust not," said Starbuck, "it is poor stuff enough."<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye, steward," cried Stubb, "we'll teach you to drug it<br><br>harpooneer; none of your apothecary's medicine here; you want to<br><br>poison us, do ye?  You have got out insurances on our lives and want<br><br>to murder us all, and pocket the proceeds, do ye?"<br><br><br><br>"It was not me," cried Dough-Boy, "it was Aunt Charity that brought<br><br>the ginger on board; and bade me never give the harpooneers any<br><br>spirits, but only this ginger-jub--so she called it."<br><br><br><br>"Ginger-jub! you gingerly rascal! take that! and run along with ye to<br><br>the lockers, and get something better.  I hope I do no wrong, Mr.<br><br>Starbuck.  It is the captain's orders--grog for the harpooneer on a<br><br>whale."<br><br><br><br>"Enough," replied Starbuck, "only don't hit him again, but--"<br><br><br><br>"Oh, I never hurt when I hit, except when I hit a whale or something<br><br>of that sort; and this fellow's a weazel.  What were you about<br><br>saying, sir?"<br><br><br><br>"Only this: go down with him, and get what thou wantest thyself."<br><br><br><br>When Stubb reappeared, he came with a dark flask in one hand, and a<br><br>sort of tea-caddy in the other.  The first contained strong spirits,<br><br>and was handed to Queequeg; the second was Aunt Charity's gift, and<br><br>that was freely given to the waves.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 73<br><br><br><br>Stubb and Flask Kill a Right Whale; and Then Have a Talk Over Him.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It must be borne in mind that all this time we have a Sperm Whale's<br><br>prodigious head hanging to the Pequod's side.  But we must let it<br><br>continue hanging there a while till we can get a chance to attend to<br><br>it.  For the present other matters press, and the best we can do now<br><br>for the head, is to pray heaven the tackles may hold.<br><br><br><br>Now, during the past night and forenoon, the Pequod had gradually<br><br>drifted into a sea, which, by its occasional patches of yellow brit,<br><br>gave unusual tokens of the vicinity of Right Whales, a species of the<br><br>Leviathan that but few supposed to be at this particular time lurking<br><br>anywhere near.  And though all hands commonly disdained the capture<br><br>of those inferior creatures; and though the Pequod was not<br><br>commissioned to cruise for them at all, and though she had passed<br><br>numbers of them near the Crozetts without lowering a boat; yet now<br><br>that a Sperm Whale had been brought alongside and beheaded, to the<br><br>surprise of all, the announcement was made that a Right Whale should<br><br>be captured that day, if opportunity offered.<br><br><br><br>Nor was this long wanting.  Tall spouts were seen to leeward; and two<br><br>boats, Stubb's and Flask's, were detached in pursuit.  Pulling<br><br>further and further away, they at last became almost invisible to the<br><br>men at the mast-head.  But suddenly in the distance, they saw a great<br><br>heap of tumultuous white water, and soon after news came from aloft<br><br>that one or both the boats must be fast.  An interval passed and the<br><br>boats were in plain sight, in the act of being dragged right towards<br><br>the ship by the towing whale.  So close did the monster come to the<br><br>hull, that at first it seemed as if he meant it malice; but suddenly<br><br>going down in a maelstrom, within three rods of the planks, he wholly<br><br>disappeared from view, as if diving under the keel.  "Cut, cut!" was<br><br>the cry from the ship to the boats, which, for one instant, seemed on<br><br>the point of being brought with a deadly dash against the vessel's<br><br>side.  But having plenty of line yet in the tubs, and the whale not<br><br>sounding very rapidly, they paid out abundance of rope, and at the<br><br>same time pulled with all their might so as to get ahead of the ship.<br><br>For a few minutes the struggle was intensely critical; for while<br><br>they still slacked out the tightened line in one direction, and still<br><br>plied their oars in another, the contending strain threatened to take<br><br>them under.  But it was only a few feet advance they sought to gain.<br><br>And they stuck to it till they did gain it; when instantly, a swift<br><br>tremor was felt running like lightning along the keel, as the<br><br>strained line, scraping beneath the ship, suddenly rose to view under<br><br>her bows, snapping and quivering; and so flinging off its drippings,<br><br>that the drops fell like bits of broken glass on the water, while the<br><br>whale beyond also rose to sight, and once more the boats were free to<br><br>fly.  But the fagged whale abated his speed, and blindly altering his<br><br>course, went round the stern of the ship towing the two boats after<br><br>him, so that they performed a complete circuit.<br><br><br><br>Meantime, they hauled more and more upon their lines, till close<br><br>flanking him on both sides, Stubb answered Flask with lance for<br><br>lance; and thus round and round the Pequod the battle went, while the<br><br>multitudes of sharks that had before swum round the Sperm Whale's<br><br>body, rushed to the fresh blood that was spilled, thirstily drinking<br><br>at every new gash, as the eager Israelites did at the new bursting<br><br>fountains that poured from the smitten rock.<br><br><br><br>At last his spout grew thick, and with a frightful roll and vomit, he<br><br>turned upon his back a corpse.<br><br><br><br>While the two headsmen were engaged in making fast cords to his<br><br>flukes, and in other ways getting the mass in readiness for towing,<br><br>some conversation ensued between them.<br><br><br><br>"I wonder what the old man wants with this lump of foul lard," said<br><br>Stubb, not without some disgust at the thought of having to do with<br><br>so ignoble a leviathan.<br><br><br><br>"Wants with it?" said Flask, coiling some spare line in the boat's<br><br>bow, "did you never hear that the ship which but once has a Sperm<br><br>Whale's head hoisted on her starboard side, and at the same time a<br><br>Right Whale's on the larboard; did you never hear, Stubb, that that<br><br>ship can never afterwards capsize?"<br><br><br><br>"Why not?<br><br><br><br>"I don't know, but I heard that gamboge ghost of a Fedallah saying<br><br>so, and he seems to know all about ships' charms.  But I sometimes<br><br>think he'll charm the ship to no good at last.  I don't half like<br><br>that chap, Stubb.  Did you ever notice how that tusk of his is a sort<br><br>of carved into a snake's head, Stubb?"<br><br><br><br>"Sink him!  I never look at him at all; but if ever I get a chance of<br><br>a dark night, and he standing hard by the bulwarks, and no one by;<br><br>look down there, Flask"--pointing into the sea with a peculiar motion<br><br>of both hands--"Aye, will I! The<br><br>reason why you don't see his tail, is because he tucks it up out of<br><br>sight; he carries it coiled away in his pocket, I guess.  Blast him!<br><br>now that I think of it, he's always wanting oakum to stuff into the<br><br>toes of his boots."<br><br><br><br>"He sleeps in his boots, don't he?  He hasn't got any hammock; but<br><br>I've seen him lay of nights in a coil of rigging."<br><br><br><br>"No doubt, and it's because of his cursed tail; he coils it down, do<br><br>ye see, in the eye of the rigging."<br><br><br><br>"What's the old man have so much to do with him for?"<br><br><br><br>"Striking up a swap or a bargain, I suppose."<br><br><br><br>"Bargain?--about what?"<br><br><br><br>"Why, do ye see, the old man is hard bent after that White Whale, and<br><br>the devil there is trying to come round him, and get him to swap away<br><br>his silver watch, or his soul, or something of that sort, and then<br><br>he'll surrender Moby Dick."<br><br><br><br>"Pooh!  Stubb, you are skylarking; how can Fedallah do that?"<br><br><br><br>"I don't know, Flask, but the devil is a curious chap, and a wicked<br><br>one, I tell ye.  Why, they say as how he went a sauntering into the<br><br>old flag-ship once, switching his tail about devilish easy and<br><br>gentlemanlike, and inquiring if the old governor was at home.  Well,<br><br>he was at home, and asked the devil what he wanted.  The devil,<br><br>switching his hoofs, up and says, 'I want John.'  'What for?' says<br><br>the old governor.  'What business is that of yours,' says the devil,<br><br>getting mad,--'I want to use him.'  'Take him,' says the<br><br>governor--and by the Lord, Flask, if the devil didn't give John the<br><br>Asiatic cholera before he got through with him, I'll eat this whale<br><br>in one mouthful.  But look sharp--ain't you all ready there?  Well,<br><br>then, pull ahead, and let's get the whale alongside."<br><br><br><br>"I think I remember some such story as you were telling," said Flask,<br><br>when at last the two boats were slowly advancing with their burden<br><br>towards the ship, "but I can't remember where."<br><br><br><br>"Three Spaniards?  Adventures of those three bloody-minded soladoes?<br><br>Did ye read it there, Flask?  I guess ye did?"<br><br><br><br>"No: never saw such a book; heard of it, though.  But now, tell me,<br><br>Stubb, do you suppose that that devil you was speaking of just now,<br><br>was the same you say is now on board the Pequod?"<br><br><br><br>"Am I the same man that helped kill this whale?  Doesn't the devil<br><br>live for ever; who ever heard that the devil was dead?  Did you ever<br><br>see any parson a wearing mourning for the devil? Tell me that, Mr. Flask?"<br><br><br><br>"How old do you suppose Fedallah is, Stubb?"<br><br><br><br>"Do you see that mainmast there?" pointing to the ship; "well, that's<br><br>the figure one; now take all the hoops in the Pequod's hold, and<br><br>string along in a row with that mast, for oughts, do you see; well,<br><br>that wouldn't begin to be Fedallah's age.  Nor all the coopers in<br><br>creation couldn't show hoops enough to make oughts enough."<br><br><br><br>"But see here, Stubb, I thought you a little boasted just now, that<br><br>you meant to give Fedallah a sea-toss, if you got a good chance.<br><br>Now, if he's so old as all those hoops of yours come to, and if he is<br><br>going to live for ever, what good will it do to pitch him<br><br>overboard--tell me that?<br><br><br><br>"Give him a good ducking, anyhow."<br><br><br><br>"But he'd crawl back."<br><br><br><br>"Duck him again; and keep ducking him."<br><br><br><br>"Suppose he should take it into his head to duck you, though--yes,<br><br>and drown you--what then?"<br><br><br><br>"I should like to see him try it; I'd give him such a pair of black<br><br>eyes that he wouldn't dare to show his face in the admiral's cabin<br><br>again for a long while, let alone down in the orlop there, where he<br><br>lives, and hereabouts on the upper decks where he sneaks so much.<br><br>Damn the devil, Flask; so you suppose I'm afraid of the devil?  Who's<br><br>afraid of him, except the old governor who daresn't catch him and put<br><br>him in double-darbies, as he deserves, but lets him go about<br><br>kidnapping people; aye, and signed a bond with him, that all the<br><br>people the devil kidnapped, he'd roast for him?  There's a governor!"<br><br><br><br>"Do you suppose Fedallah wants to kidnap Captain Ahab?"<br><br><br><br>"Do I suppose it?  You'll know it before long, Flask.  But I am going<br><br>now to keep a sharp look-out on him; and if I see anything very<br><br>suspicious going on, I'll just take him by the nape of his neck, and<br><br>say--Look here, Beelzebub, you don't do it; and if he makes any fuss,<br><br>by the Lord I'll make a grab into his pocket for his tail, take it to<br><br>the capstan, and give him such a wrenching and heaving, that his tail<br><br>will come short off at the stump--do you see; and then, I rather<br><br>guess when he finds himself docked in that queer fashion, he'll sneak<br><br>off without the poor satisfaction of feeling his tail between his<br><br>legs."<br><br><br><br>"And what will you do with the tail, Stubb?"<br><br><br><br>"Do with it?  Sell it for an ox whip when we get home;--what else?"<br><br><br><br>"Now, do you mean what you say, and have been saying all along,<br><br>Stubb?"<br><br><br><br>"Mean or not mean, here we are at the ship."<br><br><br><br>The boats were here hailed, to tow the whale on the larboard side,<br><br>where fluke chains and other necessaries were already prepared for<br><br>securing him.<br><br><br><br>"Didn't I tell you so?" said Flask; "yes, you'll soon see this right<br><br>whale's head hoisted up opposite that parmacetti's."<br><br><br><br>In good time, Flask's saying proved true.  As before, the Pequod<br><br>steeply leaned over towards the sperm whale's head, now, by the<br><br>counterpoise of both heads, she regained her even keel; though sorely<br><br>strained, you may well believe.  So, when on one side you hoist in<br><br>Locke's head, you go over that way; but now, on the other side, hoist<br><br>in Kant's and you come back again; but in very poor plight.  Thus,<br><br>some minds for ever keep trimming boat.  Oh, ye foolish! throw all<br><br>these thunder-heads overboard, and then you will float light and<br><br>right.<br><br><br><br>In disposing of the body of a right whale, when brought alongside the<br><br>ship, the same preliminary proceedings commonly take place as in the<br><br>case of a sperm whale; only, in the latter instance, the head is cut<br><br>off whole, but in the former the lips and tongue are separately<br><br>removed and hoisted on deck, with all the well known black bone<br><br>attached to what is called the crown-piece.  But nothing like this,<br><br>in the present case, had been done.  The carcases of both whales had<br><br>dropped astern; and the head-laden ship not a little resembled a mule<br><br>carrying a pair of overburdening panniers.<br><br><br><br>Meantime, Fedallah was calmly eyeing the right whale's head, and ever<br><br>and anon glancing from the deep wrinkles there to the lines in his<br><br>own hand.  And Ahab chanced so to stand, that the Parsee occupied his<br><br>shadow; while, if the Parsee's shadow was there at all it seemed only<br><br>to blend with, and lengthen Ahab's.  As the crew toiled on,<br><br>Laplandish speculations were bandied among them, concerning all these<br><br>passing things.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 74<br><br><br><br>The Sperm Whale's Head--Contrasted View.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Here, now, are two great whales, laying their heads together; let us<br><br>join them, and lay together our own.<br><br><br><br>Of the grand order of folio leviathans, the Sperm Whale and the Right<br><br>Whale are by far the most noteworthy.  They are the only whales<br><br>regularly hunted by man.  To the Nantucketer, they present the two<br><br>extremes of all the known varieties of the whale.  As the external<br><br>difference between them is mainly observable in their heads; and as a<br><br>head of each is this moment hanging from the Pequod's side; and as we<br><br>may freely go from one to the other, by merely stepping across the<br><br>deck:--where, I should like to know, will you obtain a better chance<br><br>to study practical cetology than here?<br><br><br><br>In the first place, you are struck by the general contrast between<br><br>these heads.  Both are massive enough in all conscience; but there<br><br>is a certain mathematical symmetry in the Sperm Whale's which the<br><br>Right Whale's sadly lacks.  There is more character in the Sperm<br><br>Whale's head.  As you behold it, you involuntarily yield the immense<br><br>superiority to him, in point of pervading dignity.  In the present<br><br>instance, too, this dignity is heightened by the pepper and salt<br><br>colour of his head at the summit, giving token of advanced age and<br><br>large experience.  In short, he is what the fishermen technically<br><br>call a "grey-headed whale."<br><br><br><br>Let us now note what is least dissimilar in these heads--namely, the<br><br>two most important organs, the eye and the ear.  Far back on the side<br><br>of the head, and low down, near the angle of either whale's jaw, if<br><br>you narrowly search, you will at last see a lashless eye, which you<br><br>would fancy to be a young colt's eye; so out of all proportion is it<br><br>to the magnitude of the head.<br><br><br><br>Now, from this peculiar sideway position of the whale's eyes, it is<br><br>plain that he can never see an object which is exactly ahead, no more<br><br>than he can one exactly astern.  In a word, the position of the<br><br>whale's eyes corresponds to that of a man's ears; and you may fancy,<br><br>for yourself, how it would fare with you, did you sideways survey<br><br>objects through your ears.  You would find that you could only<br><br>command some thirty degrees of vision in advance of the straight<br><br>side-line of sight; and about thirty more behind it.  If your<br><br>bitterest foe were walking straight towards you, with dagger uplifted<br><br>in broad day, you would not be able to see him, any more than if he<br><br>were stealing upon you from behind.  In a word, you would have two<br><br>backs, so to speak; but, at the same time, also, two fronts (side<br><br>fronts): for what is it that makes the front of a man--what, indeed,<br><br>but his eyes?<br><br><br><br>Moreover, while in most other animals that I can now think of, the<br><br>eyes are so planted as imperceptibly to blend their visual power, so<br><br>as to produce one picture and not two to the brain; the peculiar<br><br>position of the whale's eyes, effectually divided as they are by many<br><br>cubic feet of solid head, which towers between them like a great<br><br>mountain separating two lakes in valleys; this, of course, must<br><br>wholly separate the impressions which each independent organ imparts.<br><br>The whale, therefore, must see one distinct picture on this side,<br><br>and another distinct picture on that side; while all between must be<br><br>profound darkness and nothingness to him.  Man may, in effect, be<br><br>said to look out on the world from a sentry-box with two joined<br><br>sashes for his window.  But with the whale, these two sashes are<br><br>separately inserted, making two distinct windows, but sadly impairing<br><br>the view.  This peculiarity of the whale's eyes is a thing always to<br><br>be borne in mind in the fishery; and to be remembered by the reader<br><br>in some subsequent scenes.<br><br><br><br>A curious and most puzzling question might be started concerning this<br><br>visual matter as touching the Leviathan.  But I must be content with<br><br>a hint.  So long as a man's eyes are open in the light, the act of<br><br>seeing is involuntary; that is, he cannot then help mechanically<br><br>seeing whatever objects are before him.  Nevertheless, any one's<br><br>experience will teach him, that though he can take in an<br><br>undiscriminating sweep of things at one glance, it is quite<br><br>impossible for him, attentively, and completely, to examine any two<br><br>things--however large or however small--at one and the same instant<br><br>of time; never mind if they lie side by side and touch each other.<br><br>But if you now come to separate these two objects, and surround each<br><br>by a circle of profound darkness; then, in order to see one of them,<br><br>in such a manner as to bring your mind to bear on it, the other will<br><br>be utterly excluded from your contemporary consciousness.  How is it,<br><br>then, with the whale?  True, both his eyes, in themselves, must<br><br>simultaneously act; but is his brain so much more comprehensive,<br><br>combining, and subtle than man's, that he can at the same moment of<br><br>time attentively examine two distinct prospects, one on one side of<br><br>him, and the other in an exactly opposite direction?  If he can, then<br><br>is it as marvellous a thing in him, as if a man were able<br><br>simultaneously to go through the demonstrations of two distinct<br><br>problems in Euclid.  Nor, strictly investigated, is there any<br><br>incongruity in this comparison.<br><br><br><br>It may be but an idle whim, but it has always seemed to me, that the<br><br>extraordinary vacillations of movement displayed by some whales when<br><br>beset by three or four boats; the timidity and liability to queer<br><br>frights, so common to such whales; I think that all this indirectly<br><br>proceeds from the helpless perplexity of volition, in which their<br><br>divided and diametrically opposite powers of vision must involve<br><br>them.<br><br><br><br>But the ear of the whale is full as curious as the eye.  If you are<br><br>an entire stranger to their race, you might hunt over these two heads<br><br>for hours, and never discover that organ.  The ear has no external<br><br>leaf whatever; and into the hole itself you can hardly insert a<br><br>quill, so wondrously minute is it.  It is lodged a little behind the<br><br>eye.  With respect to their ears, this important difference is to be<br><br>observed between the sperm whale and the right.  While the ear of<br><br>the former has an external opening, that of the latter is entirely<br><br>and evenly covered over with a membrane, so as to be quite<br><br>imperceptible from without.<br><br><br><br>Is it not curious, that so vast a being as the whale should see the<br><br>world through so small an eye, and hear the thunder through an ear<br><br>which is smaller than a hare's?  But if his eyes were broad as the<br><br>lens of Herschel's great telescope; and his ears capacious as the<br><br>porches of cathedrals; would that make him any longer of sight, or<br><br>sharper of hearing?  Not at all.--Why then do you try to "enlarge"<br><br>your mind?  Subtilize it.<br><br><br><br>Let us now with whatever levers and steam-engines we have at hand,<br><br>cant over the sperm whale's head, that it may lie bottom up;<br><br>then, ascending by a ladder to the summit, have a peep down the<br><br>mouth; and were it not that the body is now completely separated from<br><br>it, with a lantern we might descend into the great Kentucky Mammoth<br><br>Cave of his stomach.  But let us hold on here by this tooth, and look<br><br>about us where we are.  What a really beautiful and chaste-looking<br><br>mouth! from floor to ceiling, lined, or rather papered with a<br><br>glistening white membrane, glossy as bridal satins.<br><br><br><br>But come out now, and look at this portentous lower jaw, which seems<br><br>like the long narrow lid of an immense snuff-box, with the hinge at<br><br>one end, instead of one side.  If you pry it up, so as to get it<br><br>overhead, and expose its rows of teeth, it seems a terrific<br><br>portcullis; and such, alas! it proves to many a poor wight in the<br><br>fishery, upon whom these spikes fall with impaling force.  But far<br><br>more terrible is it to behold, when fathoms down in the sea, you see<br><br>some sulky whale, floating there suspended, with his prodigious jaw,<br><br>some fifteen feet long, hanging straight down at right-angles with<br><br>his body, for all the world like a ship's jib-boom.  This whale is<br><br>not dead; he is only dispirited; out of sorts, perhaps;<br><br>hypochondriac; and so supine, that the hinges of his jaw have<br><br>relaxed, leaving him there in that ungainly sort of plight, a<br><br>reproach to all his tribe, who must, no doubt, imprecate lock-jaws<br><br>upon him.<br><br><br><br>In most cases this lower jaw--being easily unhinged by a practised<br><br>artist--is disengaged and hoisted on deck for the purpose of<br><br>extracting the ivory teeth, and furnishing a supply of that hard<br><br>white whalebone with which the fishermen fashion all sorts of curious<br><br>articles, including canes, umbrella-stocks, and handles to<br><br>riding-whips.<br><br><br><br>With a long, weary hoist the jaw is dragged on board, as if it were<br><br>an anchor; and when the proper time comes--some few days after the<br><br>other work--Queequeg, Daggoo, and Tashtego, being all accomplished<br><br>dentists, are set to drawing teeth.  With a keen cutting-spade,<br><br>Queequeg lances the gums; then the jaw is lashed down to ringbolts,<br><br>and a tackle being rigged from aloft, they drag out these teeth, as<br><br>Michigan oxen drag stumps of old oaks out of wild wood lands.  There<br><br>are generally forty-two teeth in all; in old whales, much worn down,<br><br>but undecayed; nor filled after our artificial fashion.  The jaw is<br><br>afterwards sawn into slabs, and piled away like joists for building<br><br>houses.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 75<br><br><br><br>The Right Whale's Head--Contrasted View.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Crossing the deck, let us now have a good long look at the Right<br><br>Whale's head.<br><br><br><br>As in general shape the noble Sperm Whale's head may be compared to a<br><br>Roman war-chariot (especially in front, where it is so broadly<br><br>rounded); so, at a broad view, the Right Whale's head bears a rather<br><br>inelegant resemblance to a gigantic galliot-toed shoe.  Two hundred<br><br>years ago an old Dutch voyager likened its shape to that of a<br><br>shoemaker's last.  And in this same last or shoe, that old woman of<br><br>the nursery tale, with the swarming brood, might very comfortably be<br><br>lodged, she and all her progeny.<br><br><br><br>But as you come nearer to this great head it begins to assume<br><br>different aspects, according to your point of view.  If you stand on<br><br>its summit and look at these two F-shaped spoutholes, you would take<br><br>the whole head for an enormous bass-viol, and these spiracles, the<br><br>apertures in its sounding-board.  Then, again, if you fix your eye<br><br>upon this strange, crested, comb-like incrustation on the top of the<br><br>mass--this green, barnacled thing, which the Greenlanders call the<br><br>"crown," and the Southern fishers the "bonnet" of the Right Whale;<br><br>fixing your eyes solely on this, you would take the head for the<br><br>trunk of some huge oak, with a bird's nest in its crotch.  At any<br><br>rate, when you watch those live crabs that nestle here on this<br><br>bonnet, such an idea will be almost sure to occur to you; unless,<br><br>indeed, your fancy has been fixed by the technical term "crown" also<br><br>bestowed upon it; in which case you will take great interest in<br><br>thinking how this mighty monster is actually a diademed king of the<br><br>sea, whose green crown has been put together for him in this<br><br>marvellous manner.  But if this whale be a king, he is a very sulky<br><br>looking fellow to grace a diadem.  Look at that hanging lower lip!<br><br>what a huge sulk and pout is there! a sulk and pout, by carpenter's<br><br>measurement, about twenty feet long and five feet deep; a sulk and<br><br>pout that will yield you some 500 gallons of oil and more.<br><br><br><br>A great pity, now, that this unfortunate whale should be hare-lipped.<br><br>The fissure is about a foot across.  Probably the mother during an<br><br>important interval was sailing down the Peruvian coast, when<br><br>earthquakes caused the beach to gape.  Over this lip, as over a<br><br>slippery threshold, we now slide into the mouth.  Upon my word were I<br><br>at Mackinaw, I should take this to be the inside of an Indian wigwam.<br><br>Good Lord! is this the road that Jonah went?  The roof is about<br><br>twelve feet high, and runs to a pretty sharp angle, as if there were<br><br>a regular ridge-pole there; while these ribbed, arched, hairy sides,<br><br>present us with those wondrous, half vertical, scimetar-shaped slats<br><br>of whalebone, say three hundred on a side, which depending from the<br><br>upper part of the head or crown bone, form those Venetian blinds<br><br>which have elsewhere been cursorily mentioned.  The edges of these<br><br>bones are fringed with hairy fibres, through which the Right Whale<br><br>strains the water, and in whose intricacies he retains the small<br><br>fish, when openmouthed he goes through the seas of brit in feeding<br><br>time.  In the central blinds of bone, as they stand in their natural<br><br>order, there are certain curious marks, curves, hollows, and ridges,<br><br>whereby some whalemen calculate the creature's age, as the age of an<br><br>oak by its circular rings.  Though the certainty of this criterion is<br><br>far from demonstrable, yet it has the savor of analogical<br><br>probability.  At any rate, if we yield to it, we must grant a far<br><br>greater age to the Right Whale than at first glance will seem<br><br>reasonable.<br><br><br><br>In old times, there seem to have prevailed the most curious fancies<br><br>concerning these blinds.  One voyager in Purchas calls them the<br><br>wondrous "whiskers" inside of the whale's mouth;* another, "hogs'<br><br>bristles"; a third old gentleman in Hackluyt uses the following<br><br>elegant language: "There are about two hundred and fifty fins growing<br><br>on each side of his upper CHOP, which arch over his tongue on each<br><br>side of his mouth."<br><br><br><br><br><br>*This reminds us that the Right Whale really has a sort of whisker,<br><br>or rather a moustache, consisting of a few scattered white hairs on<br><br>the upper part of the outer end of the lower jaw.  Sometimes these<br><br>tufts impart a rather brigandish expression to his otherwise solemn<br><br>countenance.<br><br><br><br><br><br>As every one knows, these same "hogs' bristles," "fins," "whiskers,"<br><br>"blinds," or whatever you please, furnish to the ladies their busks<br><br>and other stiffening contrivances.  But in this particular, the<br><br>demand has long been on the decline.  It was in Queen Anne's time<br><br>that the bone was in its glory, the farthingale being then all the<br><br>fashion.  And as those ancient dames moved about gaily, though in the<br><br>jaws of the whale, as you may say; even so, in a shower, with the<br><br>like thoughtlessness, do we nowadays fly under the same jaws for<br><br>protection; the umbrella being a tent spread over the same bone.<br><br><br><br>But now forget all about blinds and whiskers for a moment, and,<br><br>standing in the Right Whale's mouth, look around you afresh.  Seeing<br><br>all these colonnades of bone so methodically ranged about, would you<br><br>not think you were inside of the great Haarlem organ, and gazing<br><br>upon its thousand pipes?  For a carpet to the organ we have a rug of<br><br>the softest Turkey--the tongue, which is glued, as it were, to the<br><br>floor of the mouth.  It is very fat and tender, and apt to tear in<br><br>pieces in hoisting it on deck.  This particular tongue now before us;<br><br>at a passing glance I should say it was a six-barreler; that is, it<br><br>will yield you about that amount of oil.<br><br><br><br>Ere this, you must have plainly seen the truth of what I started<br><br>with--that the Sperm Whale and the Right Whale have almost entirely<br><br>different heads.  To sum up, then: in the Right Whale's there is no<br><br>great well of sperm; no ivory teeth at all; no long, slender mandible<br><br>of a lower jaw, like the Sperm Whale's.  Nor in the Sperm Whale are<br><br>there any of those blinds of bone; no huge lower lip; and scarcely<br><br>anything of a tongue.  Again, the Right Whale has two external<br><br>spout-holes, the Sperm Whale only one.<br><br><br><br>Look your last, now, on these venerable hooded heads, while they yet<br><br>lie together; for one will soon sink, unrecorded, in the sea; the<br><br>other will not be very long in following.<br><br><br><br>Can you catch the expression of the Sperm Whale's there?  It is the<br><br>same he died with, only some of the longer wrinkles in the forehead<br><br>seem now faded away.  I think his broad brow to be full of a<br><br>prairie-like placidity, born of a speculative indifference as to<br><br>death.  But mark the other head's expression.  See that amazing lower<br><br>lip, pressed by accident against the vessel's side, so as firmly to<br><br>embrace the jaw.  Does not this whole head seem to speak of an<br><br>enormous practical resolution in facing death?  This Right Whale I<br><br>take to have been a Stoic; the Sperm Whale, a Platonian, who might<br><br>have taken up Spinoza in his latter years.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 76<br><br><br><br>The Battering-Ram.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Ere quitting, for the nonce, the Sperm Whale's head, I would have<br><br>you, as a sensible physiologist, simply--particularly remark its<br><br>front aspect, in all its compacted collectedness.  I would have you<br><br>investigate it now with the sole view of forming to yourself some<br><br>unexaggerated, intelligent estimate of whatever battering-ram power<br><br>may be lodged there.  Here is a vital point; for you must either<br><br>satisfactorily settle this matter with yourself, or for ever remain<br><br>an infidel as to one of the most appalling, but not the less true<br><br>events, perhaps anywhere to be found in all recorded history.<br><br><br><br>You observe that in the ordinary swimming position of the Sperm<br><br>Whale, the front of his head presents an almost wholly vertical plane<br><br>to the water; you observe that the lower part of that front slopes<br><br>considerably backwards, so as to furnish more of a retreat for the<br><br>long socket which receives the boom-like lower jaw; you observe that<br><br>the mouth is entirely under the head, much in the same way, indeed,<br><br>as though your own mouth were entirely under your chin.  Moreover you<br><br>observe that the whale has no external nose; and that what nose he<br><br>has--his spout hole--is on the top of his head; you observe that his<br><br>eyes and ears are at the sides of his head, nearly one third of his<br><br>entire length from the front.  Wherefore, you must now have perceived<br><br>that the front of the Sperm Whale's head is a dead, blind wall,<br><br>without a single organ or tender prominence of any sort whatsoever.<br><br>Furthermore, you are now to consider that only in the extreme, lower,<br><br>backward sloping part of the front of the head, is there the<br><br>slightest vestige of bone; and not till you get near twenty feet from<br><br>the forehead do you come to the full cranial development.  So that<br><br>this whole enormous boneless mass is as one wad.  Finally, though, as<br><br>will soon be revealed, its contents partly comprise the most delicate<br><br>oil; yet, you are now to be apprised of the nature of the substance<br><br>which so impregnably invests all that apparent effeminacy.  In some<br><br>previous place I have described to you how the blubber wraps the body<br><br>of the whale, as the rind wraps an orange.  Just so with the head;<br><br>but with this difference: about the head this envelope, though not so<br><br>thick, is of a boneless toughness, inestimable by any man who has not<br><br>handled it.  The severest pointed harpoon, the sharpest lance darted<br><br>by the strongest human arm, impotently rebounds from it.  It is as<br><br>though the forehead of the Sperm Whale were paved with horses' hoofs.<br><br>I do not think that any sensation lurks in it.<br><br><br><br>Bethink yourself also of another thing.  When two large, loaded<br><br>Indiamen chance to crowd and crush towards each other in the<br><br>docks, what do the sailors do?  They do not suspend between them, at<br><br>the point of coming contact, any merely hard substance, like iron or<br><br>wood.  No, they hold there a large, round wad of tow and cork,<br><br>enveloped in the thickest and toughest of ox-hide.  That bravely and<br><br>uninjured takes the jam which would have snapped all their oaken<br><br>handspikes and iron crow-bars.  By itself this sufficiently<br><br>illustrates the obvious fact I drive at.  But supplementary to this,<br><br>it has hypothetically occurred to me, that as ordinary fish possess<br><br>what is called a swimming bladder in them, capable, at will, of<br><br>distension or contraction; and as the Sperm Whale, as far as I know,<br><br>has no such provision in him; considering, too, the otherwise<br><br>inexplicable manner in which he now depresses his head altogether<br><br>beneath the surface, and anon swims with it high elevated out of the<br><br>water; considering the unobstructed elasticity of its envelope;<br><br>considering the unique interior of his head; it has hypothetically<br><br>occurred to me, I say, that those mystical lung-celled honeycombs<br><br>there may possibly have some hitherto unknown and unsuspected<br><br>connexion with the outer air, so as to be susceptible to atmospheric<br><br>distension and contraction.  If this be so, fancy the<br><br>irresistibleness of that might, to which the most impalpable and<br><br>destructive of all elements contributes.<br><br><br><br>Now, mark.  Unerringly impelling this dead, impregnable, uninjurable<br><br>wall, and this most buoyant thing within; there swims behind it all a<br><br>mass of tremendous life, only to be adequately estimated as piled<br><br>wood is--by the cord; and all obedient to one volition, as the<br><br>smallest insect.  So that when I shall hereafter detail to you all<br><br>the specialities and concentrations of potency everywhere lurking in<br><br>this expansive monster; when I shall show you some of his more<br><br>inconsiderable braining feats; I trust you will have renounced all<br><br>ignorant incredulity, and be ready to abide by this; that though the<br><br>Sperm Whale stove a passage through the Isthmus of Darien, and mixed<br><br>the Atlantic with the Pacific, you would not elevate one hair of your<br><br>eye-brow.  For unless you own the whale, you are but a provincial and<br><br>sentimentalist in Truth.  But clear Truth is a thing for salamander<br><br>giants only to encounter; how small the chances for the provincials<br><br>then?  What befell the weakling youth lifting the dread goddess's<br><br>veil at Lais?<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 77<br><br><br><br>The Great Heidelburgh Tun.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Now comes the Baling of the Case.  But to comprehend it aright, you<br><br>must know something of the curious internal structure of the thing<br><br>operated upon.<br><br><br><br>Regarding the Sperm Whale's head as a solid oblong, you may, on an<br><br>inclined plane, sideways divide it into two quoins,* whereof the<br><br>lower is the bony structure, forming the cranium and jaws, and the<br><br>upper an unctuous mass wholly free from bones; its broad forward end<br><br>forming the expanded vertical apparent forehead of the whale.  At the<br><br>middle of the forehead horizontally subdivide this upper quoin, and<br><br>then you have two almost equal parts, which before were naturally<br><br>divided by an internal wall of a thick tendinous substance.<br><br><br><br><br><br>*Quoin is not a Euclidean term.  It belongs to the pure nautical<br><br>mathematics.  I know not that it has been defined before.  A quoin is<br><br>a solid which differs from a wedge in having its sharp end formed by<br><br>the steep inclination of one side, instead of the mutual tapering of<br><br>both sides.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The lower subdivided part, called the junk, is one immense honeycomb<br><br>of oil, formed by the crossing and recrossing, into ten thousand<br><br>infiltrated cells, of tough elastic white fibres throughout its whole<br><br>extent.  The upper part, known as the Case, may be regarded as the<br><br>great Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale.  And as that famous great<br><br>tierce is mystically carved in front, so the whale's vast plaited<br><br>forehead forms innumerable strange devices for the emblematical<br><br>adornment of his wondrous tun.  Moreover, as that of Heidelburgh was<br><br>always replenished with the most excellent of the wines of the<br><br>Rhenish valleys, so the tun of the whale contains by far the most<br><br>precious of all his oily vintages; namely, the highly-prized<br><br>spermaceti, in its absolutely pure, limpid, and odoriferous state.<br><br>Nor is this precious substance found unalloyed in any other part of<br><br>the creature.  Though in life it remains perfectly fluid, yet, upon<br><br>exposure to the air, after death, it soon begins to concrete; sending<br><br>forth beautiful crystalline shoots, as when the first thin delicate<br><br>ice is just forming in water.  A large whale's case generally yields<br><br>about five hundred gallons of sperm, though from unavoidable<br><br>circumstances, considerable of it is spilled, leaks, and dribbles<br><br>away, or is otherwise irrevocably lost in the ticklish business of<br><br>securing what you can.<br><br><br><br>I know not with what fine and costly material the Heidelburgh Tun was<br><br>coated within, but in superlative richness that coating could not<br><br>possibly have compared with the silken pearl-coloured membrane, like<br><br>the lining of a fine pelisse, forming the inner surface of the Sperm<br><br>Whale's case.<br><br><br><br>It will have been seen that the Heidelburgh Tun of the Sperm Whale<br><br>embraces the entire length of the entire top of the head; and<br><br>since--as has been elsewhere set forth--the head embraces one third<br><br>of the whole length of the creature, then setting that length down at<br><br>eighty feet for a good sized whale, you have more than twenty-six<br><br>feet for the depth of the tun, when it is lengthwise hoisted up and<br><br>down against a ship's side.<br><br><br><br>As in decapitating the whale, the operator's instrument is brought<br><br>close to the spot where an entrance is subsequently forced into the<br><br>spermaceti magazine; he has, therefore, to be uncommonly heedful,<br><br>lest a careless, untimely stroke should invade the sanctuary and<br><br>wastingly let out its invaluable contents.  It is this decapitated<br><br>end of the head, also, which is at last elevated out of the water,<br><br>and retained in that position by the enormous cutting tackles, whose<br><br>hempen combinations, on one side, make quite a wilderness of ropes in<br><br>that quarter.<br><br><br><br>Thus much being said, attend now, I pray you, to that marvellous<br><br>and--in this particular instance--almost fatal operation whereby the<br><br>Sperm Whale's great Heidelburgh Tun is tapped.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 78<br><br><br><br>Cistern and Buckets.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Nimble as a cat, Tashtego mounts aloft; and without altering his<br><br>erect posture, runs straight out upon the overhanging mainyard-arm,<br><br>to the part where it exactly projects over the hoisted Tun.  He has<br><br>carried with him a light tackle called a whip, consisting of only two<br><br>parts, travelling through a single-sheaved block.  Securing this<br><br>block, so that it hangs down from the yard-arm, he swings one end of<br><br>the rope, till it is caught and firmly held by a hand on deck.<br><br>Then, hand-over-hand, down the other part, the Indian drops through<br><br>the air, till dexterously he lands on the summit of the head.<br><br>There--still high elevated above the rest of the company, to whom he<br><br>vivaciously cries--he seems some Turkish Muezzin calling the good<br><br>people to prayers from the top of a tower.  A short-handled sharp<br><br>spade being sent up to him, he diligently searches for the proper<br><br>place to begin breaking into the Tun.  In this business he proceeds<br><br>very heedfully, like a treasure-hunter in some old house, sounding<br><br>the walls to find where the gold is masoned in.  By the time this<br><br>cautious search is over, a stout iron-bound bucket, precisely like a<br><br>well-bucket, has been attached to one end of the whip; while the<br><br>other end, being stretched across the deck, is there held by two or<br><br>three alert hands.  These last now hoist the bucket within grasp of<br><br>the Indian, to whom another person has reached up a very long pole.<br><br>Inserting this pole into the bucket, Tashtego downward guides the<br><br>bucket into the Tun, till it entirely disappears; then giving the<br><br>word to the seamen at the whip, up comes the bucket again, all<br><br>bubbling like a dairy-maid's pail of new milk.  Carefully lowered<br><br>from its height, the full-freighted vessel is caught by an appointed<br><br>hand, and quickly emptied into a large tub.  Then remounting aloft,<br><br>it again goes through the same round until the deep cistern will<br><br>yield no more.  Towards the end, Tashtego has to ram his long pole<br><br>harder and harder, and deeper and deeper into the Tun, until some<br><br>twenty feet of the pole have gone down.<br><br><br><br>Now, the people of the Pequod had been baling some time in this way;<br><br>several tubs had been filled with the fragrant sperm; when all at<br><br>once a queer accident happened.  Whether it was that Tashtego, that<br><br>wild Indian, was so heedless and reckless as to let go for a moment<br><br>his one-handed hold on the great cabled tackles suspending the head;<br><br>or whether the place where he stood was so treacherous and oozy; or<br><br>whether the Evil One himself would have it to fall out so, without<br><br>stating his particular reasons; how it was exactly, there is no<br><br>telling now; but, on a sudden, as the eightieth or ninetieth bucket<br><br>came suckingly up--my God! poor Tashtego--like the twin reciprocating<br><br>bucket in a veritable well, dropped head-foremost down into this<br><br>great Tun of Heidelburgh, and with a horrible oily gurgling, went<br><br>clean out of sight!<br><br><br><br>"Man overboard!" cried Daggoo, who amid the general consternation<br><br>first came to his senses.  "Swing the bucket this way!" and putting<br><br>one foot into it, so as the better to secure his slippery hand-hold<br><br>on the whip itself, the hoisters ran him high up to the top of the<br><br>head, almost before Tashtego could have reached its interior bottom.<br><br>Meantime, there was a terrible tumult.  Looking over the side, they<br><br>saw the before lifeless head throbbing and heaving just below the<br><br>surface of the sea, as if that moment seized with some momentous<br><br>idea; whereas it was only the poor Indian unconsciously revealing by<br><br>those struggles the perilous depth to which he had sunk.<br><br><br><br>At this instant, while Daggoo, on the summit of the head, was<br><br>clearing the whip--which had somehow got foul of the great cutting<br><br>tackles--a sharp cracking noise was heard; and to the unspeakable<br><br>horror of all, one of the two enormous hooks suspending the head tore<br><br>out, and with a vast vibration the enormous mass sideways swung, till<br><br>the drunk ship reeled and shook as if smitten by an iceberg.  The one<br><br>remaining hook, upon which the entire strain now depended, seemed<br><br>every instant to be on the point of giving way; an event still more<br><br>likely from the violent motions of the head.<br><br><br><br>"Come down, come down!" yelled the seamen to Daggoo, but with one<br><br>hand holding on to the heavy tackles, so that if the head should<br><br>drop, he would still remain suspended; the negro having cleared the<br><br>foul line, rammed down the bucket into the now collapsed well,<br><br>meaning that the buried harpooneer should grasp it, and so be hoisted<br><br>out.<br><br><br><br>"In heaven's name, man," cried Stubb, "are you ramming home a<br><br>cartridge there?--Avast!  How will that help him; jamming that<br><br>iron-bound bucket on top of his head?  Avast, will ye!"<br><br><br><br>"Stand clear of the tackle!" cried a voice like the bursting of a<br><br>rocket.<br><br><br><br>Almost in the same instant, with a thunder-boom, the enormous mass<br><br>dropped into the sea, like Niagara's Table-Rock into the whirlpool;<br><br>the suddenly relieved hull rolled away from it, to far down her<br><br>glittering copper; and all caught their breath, as half swinging--now<br><br>over the sailors' heads, and now over the water--Daggoo, through a<br><br>thick mist of spray, was dimly beheld clinging to the pendulous<br><br>tackles, while poor, buried-alive Tashtego was sinking utterly down<br><br>to the bottom of the sea!  But hardly had the blinding vapour cleared<br><br>away, when a naked figure with a boarding-sword in his hand, was for<br><br>one swift moment seen hovering over the bulwarks.  The next, a loud<br><br>splash announced that my brave Queequeg had dived to the rescue.  One<br><br>packed rush was made to the side, and every eye counted every ripple,<br><br>as moment followed moment, and no sign of either the sinker or the<br><br>diver could be seen.  Some hands now jumped into a boat alongside,<br><br>and pushed a little off from the ship.<br><br><br><br>"Ha! ha!" cried Daggoo, all at once, from his now quiet, swinging<br><br>perch overhead; and looking further off from the side, we saw an arm<br><br>thrust upright from the blue waves; a sight strange to see, as an arm<br><br>thrust forth from the grass over a grave.<br><br><br><br>"Both! both!--it is both!"--cried Daggoo again with a joyful shout;<br><br>and soon after, Queequeg was seen boldly striking out with one hand,<br><br>and with the other clutching the long hair of the Indian.  Drawn into<br><br>the waiting boat, they were quickly brought to the deck; but Tashtego<br><br>was long in coming to, and Queequeg did not look very brisk.<br><br><br><br>Now, how had this noble rescue been accomplished?  Why, diving after<br><br>the slowly descending head, Queequeg with his keen sword had made<br><br>side lunges near its bottom, so as to scuttle a large hole there;<br><br>then dropping his sword, had thrust his long arm far inwards and<br><br>upwards, and so hauled out poor Tash by the head.  He averred, that<br><br>upon first thrusting in for him, a leg was presented; but well<br><br>knowing that that was not as it ought to be, and might occasion great<br><br>trouble;--he had thrust back the leg, and by a dexterous heave and<br><br>toss, had wrought a somerset upon the Indian; so that with the next<br><br>trial, he came forth in the good old way--head foremost.  As for the<br><br>great head itself, that was doing as well as could be expected.<br><br><br><br>And thus, through the courage and great skill in obstetrics of<br><br>Queequeg, the deliverance, or rather, delivery of Tashtego, was<br><br>successfully accomplished, in the teeth, too, of the most untoward<br><br>and apparently hopeless impediments; which is a lesson by no means to<br><br>be forgotten.  Midwifery should be taught in the same course with<br><br>fencing and boxing, riding and rowing.<br><br><br><br>I know that this queer adventure of the Gay-Header's will be sure to<br><br>seem incredible to some landsmen, though they themselves may have<br><br>either seen or heard of some one's falling into a cistern ashore; an<br><br>accident which not seldom happens, and with much less reason too than<br><br>the Indian's, considering the exceeding slipperiness of the curb of<br><br>the Sperm Whale's well.<br><br><br><br>But, peradventure, it may be sagaciously urged, how is this?  We<br><br>thought the tissued, infiltrated head of the Sperm Whale, was the<br><br>lightest and most corky part about him; and yet thou makest it sink<br><br>in an element of a far greater specific gravity than itself.  We have<br><br>thee there.  Not at all, but I have ye; for at the time poor Tash<br><br>fell in, the case had been nearly emptied of its lighter contents,<br><br>leaving little but the dense tendinous wall of the well--a double<br><br>welded, hammered substance, as I have before said, much heavier than<br><br>the sea water, and a lump of which sinks in it like lead almost.  But<br><br>the tendency to rapid sinking in this substance was in the present<br><br>instance materially counteracted by the other parts of the head<br><br>remaining undetached from it, so that it sank very slowly and<br><br>deliberately indeed, affording Queequeg a fair chance for performing<br><br>his agile obstetrics on the run, as you may say.  Yes, it was a<br><br>running delivery, so it was.<br><br><br><br>Now, had Tashtego perished in that head, it had been a very precious<br><br>perishing; smothered in the very whitest and daintiest of fragrant<br><br>spermaceti; coffined, hearsed, and tombed in the secret inner chamber<br><br>and sanctum sanctorum of the whale.  Only one sweeter end can readily<br><br>be recalled--the delicious death of an Ohio honey-hunter, who seeking<br><br>honey in the crotch of a hollow tree, found such exceeding store of<br><br>it, that leaning too far over, it sucked him in, so that he died<br><br>embalmed.  How many, think ye, have likewise fallen into Plato's<br><br>honey head, and sweetly perished there?<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 79<br><br><br><br>The Prairie.<br><br><br><br><br><br>To scan the lines of his face, or feel the bumps on the head of this<br><br>Leviathan; this is a thing which no Physiognomist or Phrenologist has<br><br>as yet undertaken.  Such an enterprise would seem almost as hopeful<br><br>as for Lavater to have scrutinized the wrinkles on the Rock of<br><br>Gibraltar, or for Gall to have mounted a ladder and manipulated the<br><br>Dome of the Pantheon.  Still, in that famous work of his, Lavater<br><br>not only treats of the various faces of men, but also attentively<br><br>studies the faces of horses, birds, serpents, and fish; and dwells in<br><br>detail upon the modifications of expression discernible therein.  Nor<br><br>have Gall and his disciple Spurzheim failed to throw out some hints<br><br>touching the phrenological characteristics of other beings than man.<br><br>Therefore, though I am but ill qualified for a pioneer, in the<br><br>application of these two semi-sciences to the whale, I will do my<br><br>endeavor.  I try all things; I achieve what I can.<br><br><br><br>Physiognomically regarded, the Sperm Whale is an anomalous creature.<br><br>He has no proper nose.  And since the nose is the central and most<br><br>conspicuous of the features; and since it perhaps most modifies and<br><br>finally controls their combined expression; hence it would seem that<br><br>its entire absence, as an external appendage, must very largely<br><br>affect the countenance of the whale.  For as in landscape gardening,<br><br>a spire, cupola, monument, or tower of some sort, is deemed almost<br><br>indispensable to the completion of the scene; so no face can be<br><br>physiognomically in keeping without the elevated open-work belfry of<br><br>the nose.  Dash the nose from Phidias's marble Jove, and what a sorry<br><br>remainder!  Nevertheless, Leviathan is of so mighty a magnitude, all<br><br>his proportions are so stately, that the same deficiency which in the<br><br>sculptured Jove were hideous, in him is no blemish at all.  Nay, it<br><br>is an added grandeur.  A nose to the whale would have been<br><br>impertinent.  As on your physiognomical voyage you sail round his<br><br>vast head in your jolly-boat, your noble conceptions of him are never<br><br>insulted by the reflection that he has a nose to be pulled.  A<br><br>pestilent conceit, which so often will insist upon obtruding even<br><br>when beholding the mightiest royal beadle on his throne.<br><br><br><br>In some particulars, perhaps the most imposing physiognomical view<br><br>to be had of the Sperm Whale, is that of the full front of his head.<br><br>This aspect is sublime.<br><br><br><br>In thought, a fine human brow is like the East when troubled with<br><br>the morning.  In the repose of the pasture, the curled brow of the<br><br>bull has a touch of the grand in it.  Pushing heavy cannon up<br><br>mountain defiles, the elephant's brow is majestic.  Human or animal,<br><br>the mystical brow is as that great golden seal affixed by the German<br><br>Emperors to their decrees.  It signifies--"God: done this day by my<br><br>hand."  But in most creatures, nay in man himself, very often the<br><br>brow is but a mere strip of alpine land lying along the snow line.<br><br>Few are the foreheads which like Shakespeare's or Melancthon's rise<br><br>so high, and descend so low, that the eyes themselves seem clear,<br><br>eternal, tideless mountain lakes; and all above them in the forehead's<br><br>wrinkles, you seem to track the antlered thoughts descending there to<br><br>drink, as the Highland hunters track the snow prints of the deer.<br><br>But in the great Sperm Whale, this high and mighty god-like dignity<br><br>inherent in the brow is so immensely amplified, that gazing on it, in<br><br>that full front view, you feel the Deity and the dread powers more<br><br>forcibly than in beholding any other object in living nature.  For<br><br>you see no one point precisely; not one distinct feature is revealed;<br><br>no nose, eyes, ears, or mouth; no face; he has none, proper; nothing<br><br>but that one broad firmament of a forehead, pleated with riddles;<br><br>dumbly lowering with the doom of boats, and ships, and men.  Nor, in<br><br>profile, does this wondrous brow diminish; though that way viewed its<br><br>grandeur does not domineer upon you so.  In profile, you plainly<br><br>perceive that horizontal, semi-crescentic depression in the<br><br>forehead's middle, which, in man, is Lavater's mark of genius.<br><br><br><br>But how?  Genius in the Sperm Whale?  Has the Sperm Whale ever<br><br>written a book, spoken a speech?  No, his great genius is declared in<br><br>his doing nothing particular to prove it.  It is moreover declared in<br><br>his pyramidical silence.  And this reminds me that had the great<br><br>Sperm Whale been known to the young Orient World, he would have been<br><br>deified by their child-magian thoughts.  They deified the crocodile<br><br>of the Nile, because the crocodile is tongueless; and the Sperm Whale<br><br>has no tongue, or at least it is so exceedingly small, as to be<br><br>incapable of protrusion.  If hereafter any highly cultured, poetical<br><br>nation shall lure back to their birth-right, the merry May-day gods<br><br>of old; and livingly enthrone them again in the now egotistical sky;<br><br>in the now unhaunted hill; then be sure, exalted to Jove's high seat,<br><br>the great Sperm Whale shall lord it.<br><br><br><br>Champollion deciphered the wrinkled granite hieroglyphics.  But there<br><br>is no Champollion to decipher the Egypt of every man's and every<br><br>being's face.  Physiognomy, like every other human science, is but a<br><br>passing fable.  If then, Sir William Jones, who read in thirty<br><br>languages, could not read the simplest peasant's face in its<br><br>profounder and more subtle meanings, how may unlettered Ishmael hope<br><br>to read the awful Chaldee of the Sperm Whale's brow?  I but put that<br><br>brow before you.  Read it if you can.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 80<br><br><br><br>The Nut.<br><br><br><br><br><br>If the Sperm Whale be physiognomically a Sphinx, to the phrenologist<br><br>his brain seems that geometrical circle which it is impossible to<br><br>square.<br><br><br><br>In the full-grown creature the skull will measure at least twenty<br><br>feet in length.  Unhinge the lower jaw, and the side view of this<br><br>skull is as the side of a moderately inclined plane resting<br><br>throughout on a level base.  But in life--as we have elsewhere<br><br>seen--this inclined plane is angularly filled up, and almost squared<br><br>by the enormous superincumbent mass of the junk and sperm.  At the<br><br>high end the skull forms a crater to bed that part of the mass; while<br><br>under the long floor of this crater--in another cavity seldom<br><br>exceeding ten inches in length and as many in depth--reposes the<br><br>mere handful of this monster's brain.  The brain is at least twenty<br><br>feet from his apparent forehead in life; it is hidden away behind its<br><br>vast outworks, like the innermost citadel within the amplified<br><br>fortifications of Quebec.  So like a choice casket is it secreted in<br><br>him, that I have known some whalemen who peremptorily deny that the<br><br>Sperm Whale has any other brain than that palpable semblance of one<br><br>formed by the cubic-yards of his sperm magazine.  Lying in strange<br><br>folds, courses, and convolutions, to their apprehensions, it seems<br><br>more in keeping with the idea of his general might to regard that<br><br>mystic part of him as the seat of his intelligence.<br><br><br><br>It is plain, then, that phrenologically the head of this Leviathan,<br><br>in the creature's living intact state, is an entire delusion.  As for<br><br>his true brain, you can then see no indications of it, nor feel any.<br><br>The whale, like all things that are mighty, wears a false brow to the<br><br>common world.<br><br><br><br>If you unload his skull of its spermy heaps and then take a rear view<br><br>of its rear end, which is the high end, you will be struck by its<br><br>resemblance to the human skull, beheld in the same situation, and<br><br>from the same point of view.  Indeed, place this reversed skull<br><br>(scaled down to the human magnitude) among a plate of men's skulls,<br><br>and you would involuntarily confound it with them; and remarking the<br><br>depressions on one part of its summit, in phrenological phrase you<br><br>would say--This man had no self-esteem, and no veneration.  And by<br><br>those negations, considered along with the affirmative fact of his<br><br>prodigious bulk and power, you can best form to yourself the truest,<br><br>though not the most exhilarating conception of what the most exalted<br><br>potency is.<br><br><br><br>But if from the comparative dimensions of the whale's proper brain,<br><br>you deem it incapable of being adequately charted, then I have<br><br>another idea for you.  If you attentively regard almost any<br><br>quadruped's spine, you will be struck with the resemblance of its<br><br>vertebrae to a strung necklace of dwarfed skulls, all bearing<br><br>rudimental resemblance to the skull proper.  It is a German conceit,<br><br>that the vertebrae are absolutely undeveloped skulls.  But the<br><br>curious external resemblance, I take it the Germans were not the<br><br>first men to perceive.  A foreign friend once pointed it out to me,<br><br>in the skeleton of a foe he had slain, and with the vertebrae of<br><br>which he was inlaying, in a sort of basso-relievo, the beaked prow<br><br>of his canoe.  Now, I consider that the phrenologists have omitted an<br><br>important thing in not pushing their investigations from the<br><br>cerebellum through the spinal canal.  For I believe that much of a<br><br>man's character will be found betokened in his backbone.  I would<br><br>rather feel your spine than your skull, whoever you are.  A thin<br><br>joist of a spine never yet upheld a full and noble soul.
