I rejoice<br><br>in my spine, as in the firm audacious staff of that flag which I<br><br>fling half out to the world.<br><br><br><br>Apply this spinal branch of phrenology to the Sperm Whale.  His<br><br>cranial cavity is continuous with the first neck-vertebra; and in<br><br>that vertebra the bottom of the spinal canal will measure ten inches<br><br>across, being eight in height, and of a triangular figure with the<br><br>base downwards.  As it passes through the remaining vertebrae the<br><br>canal tapers in size, but for a considerable distance remains of<br><br>large capacity.  Now, of course, this canal is filled with much the<br><br>same strangely fibrous substance--the spinal cord--as the brain; and<br><br>directly communicates with the brain.  And what is still more, for<br><br>many feet after emerging from the brain's cavity, the spinal cord<br><br>remains of an undecreasing girth, almost equal to that of the brain.<br><br>Under all these circumstances, would it be unreasonable to survey and<br><br>map out the whale's spine phrenologically?  For, viewed in this<br><br>light, the wonderful comparative smallness of his brain proper is<br><br>more than compensated by the wonderful comparative magnitude of his<br><br>spinal cord.<br><br><br><br>But leaving this hint to operate as it may with the phrenologists, I<br><br>would merely assume the spinal theory for a moment, in reference to<br><br>the Sperm Whale's hump.  This august hump, if I mistake not, rises<br><br>over one of the larger vertebrae, and is, therefore, in some sort,<br><br>the outer convex mould of it.  From its relative situation then, I<br><br>should call this high hump the organ of firmness or indomitableness<br><br>in the Sperm Whale.  And that the great monster is indomitable, you<br><br>will yet have reason to know.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 81<br><br><br><br>The Pequod Meets The Virgin.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The predestinated day arrived, and we duly met the ship Jungfrau,<br><br>Derick De Deer, master, of Bremen.<br><br><br><br>At one time the greatest whaling people in the world, the Dutch and<br><br>Germans are now among the least; but here and there at very wide<br><br>intervals of latitude and longitude, you still occasionally meet with<br><br>their flag in the Pacific.<br><br><br><br>For some reason, the Jungfrau seemed quite eager to pay her respects.<br><br>While yet some distance from the Pequod, she rounded to, and<br><br>dropping a boat, her captain was impelled towards us, impatiently<br><br>standing in the bows instead of the stern.<br><br><br><br>"What has he in his hand there?" cried Starbuck, pointing to<br><br>something wavingly held by the German.  "Impossible!--a lamp-feeder!"<br><br><br><br>"Not that," said Stubb, "no, no, it's a coffee-pot, Mr. Starbuck;<br><br>he's coming off to make us our coffee, is the Yarman; don't you see<br><br>that big tin can there alongside of him?--that's his boiling water.<br><br>Oh! he's all right, is the Yarman."<br><br><br><br>"Go along with you," cried Flask, "it's a lamp-feeder and an oil-can.<br><br>He's out of oil, and has come a-begging."<br><br><br><br>However curious it may seem for an oil-ship to be borrowing oil on<br><br>the whale-ground, and however much it may invertedly contradict the<br><br>old proverb about carrying coals to Newcastle, yet sometimes such a<br><br>thing really happens; and in the present case Captain Derick De Deer<br><br>did indubitably conduct a lamp-feeder as Flask did declare.<br><br><br><br>As he mounted the deck, Ahab abruptly accosted him, without at all<br><br>heeding what he had in his hand; but in his broken lingo, the German<br><br>soon evinced his complete ignorance of the White Whale; immediately<br><br>turning the conversation to his lamp-feeder and oil can, with some<br><br>remarks touching his having to turn into his hammock at night in<br><br>profound darkness--his last drop of Bremen oil being gone, and not a<br><br>single flying-fish yet captured to supply the deficiency; concluding<br><br>by hinting that his ship was indeed what in the Fishery is<br><br>technically called a CLEAN one (that is, an empty one), well<br><br>deserving the name of Jungfrau or the Virgin.<br><br><br><br>His necessities supplied, Derick departed; but he had not gained his<br><br>ship's side, when whales were almost simultaneously raised from the<br><br>mast-heads of both vessels; and so eager for the chase was Derick,<br><br>that without pausing to put his oil-can and lamp-feeder aboard, he<br><br>slewed round his boat and made after the leviathan lamp-feeders.<br><br><br><br>Now, the game having risen to leeward, he and the other three German<br><br>boats that soon followed him, had considerably the start of the<br><br>Pequod's keels.  There were eight whales, an average pod.  Aware of<br><br>their danger, they were going all abreast with great speed straight<br><br>before the wind, rubbing their flanks as closely as so many spans of<br><br>horses in harness.  They left a great, wide wake, as though<br><br>continually unrolling a great wide parchment upon the sea.<br><br><br><br>Full in this rapid wake, and many fathoms in the rear, swam a huge,<br><br>humped old bull, which by his comparatively slow progress, as well as<br><br>by the unusual yellowish incrustations overgrowing him, seemed<br><br>afflicted with the jaundice, or some other infirmity.  Whether this<br><br>whale belonged to the pod in advance, seemed questionable; for it is<br><br>not customary for such venerable leviathans to be at all social.<br><br>Nevertheless, he stuck to their wake, though indeed their back water<br><br>must have retarded him, because the white-bone or swell at his broad<br><br>muzzle was a dashed one, like the swell formed when two hostile<br><br>currents meet.  His spout was short, slow, and laborious; coming<br><br>forth with a choking sort of gush, and spending itself in torn<br><br>shreds, followed by strange subterranean commotions in him, which<br><br>seemed to have egress at his other buried extremity, causing the<br><br>waters behind him to upbubble.<br><br><br><br>"Who's got some paregoric?" said Stubb, "he has the stomach-ache, I'm<br><br>afraid.  Lord, think of having half an acre of stomach-ache!  Adverse<br><br>winds are holding mad Christmas in him, boys.  It's the first foul<br><br>wind I ever knew to blow from astern; but look, did ever whale yaw<br><br>so before? it must be, he's lost his tiller."<br><br><br><br>As an overladen Indiaman bearing down the Hindostan coast with a deck<br><br>load of frightened horses, careens, buries, rolls, and wallows on her<br><br>way; so did this old whale heave his aged bulk, and now and then<br><br>partly turning over on his cumbrous rib-ends, expose the cause of his<br><br>devious wake in the unnatural stump of his starboard fin.  Whether he<br><br>had lost that fin in battle, or had been born without it, it were<br><br>hard to say.<br><br><br><br>"Only wait a bit, old chap, and I'll give ye a sling for that wounded<br><br>arm," cried cruel Flask, pointing to the whale-line near him.<br><br><br><br>"Mind he don't sling thee with it," cried Starbuck.  "Give way, or<br><br>the German will have him."<br><br><br><br>With one intent all the combined rival boats were pointed for this<br><br>one fish, because not only was he the largest, and therefore the most<br><br>valuable whale, but he was nearest to them, and the other whales were<br><br>going with such great velocity, moreover, as almost to defy pursuit<br><br>for the time.  At this juncture the Pequod's keels had shot by the<br><br>three German boats last lowered; but from the great start he had had,<br><br>Derick's boat still led the chase, though every moment neared by his<br><br>foreign rivals.  The only thing they feared, was, that from being<br><br>already so nigh to his mark, he would be enabled to dart his iron<br><br>before they could completely overtake and pass him.  As for Derick,<br><br>he seemed quite confident that this would be the case, and<br><br>occasionally with a deriding gesture shook his lamp-feeder at the<br><br>other boats.<br><br><br><br>"The ungracious and ungrateful dog!" cried Starbuck; "he mocks and<br><br>dares me with the very poor-box I filled for him not five minutes<br><br>ago!"--then in his old intense whisper--"Give way, greyhounds!  Dog<br><br>to it!"<br><br><br><br>"I tell ye what it is, men"--cried Stubb to his crew--"it's against<br><br>my religion to get mad; but I'd like to eat that villainous<br><br>Yarman--Pull--won't ye?  Are ye going to let that rascal beat ye?  Do<br><br>ye love brandy?  A hogshead of brandy, then, to the best man.  Come,<br><br>why don't some of ye burst a blood-vessel?  Who's that been dropping<br><br>an anchor overboard--we don't budge an inch--we're becalmed.  Halloo,<br><br>here's grass growing in the boat's bottom--and by the Lord, the mast<br><br>there's budding.  This won't do, boys.  Look at that Yarman!  The<br><br>short and long of it is, men, will ye spit fire or not?"<br><br><br><br>"Oh! see the suds he makes!" cried Flask, dancing up and down--"What<br><br>a hump--Oh, DO pile on the beef--lays like a log!  Oh! my lads, DO<br><br>spring--slap-jacks and quahogs for supper, you know, my lads--baked<br><br>clams and muffins--oh, DO, DO, spring,--he's a hundred barreller--don't<br><br>lose him now--don't oh, DON'T!--see that Yarman--Oh,<br><br>won't ye pull for your duff, my lads--such a sog! such a sogger!<br><br>Don't ye love sperm?  There goes three thousand dollars, men!--a<br><br>bank!--a whole bank!  The bank of England!--Oh, DO, DO, DO!--What's<br><br>that Yarman about now?"<br><br><br><br>At this moment Derick was in the act of pitching his lamp-feeder at<br><br>the advancing boats, and also his oil-can; perhaps with the double<br><br>view of retarding his rivals' way, and at the same time economically<br><br>accelerating his own by the momentary impetus of the backward toss.<br><br><br><br>"The unmannerly Dutch dogger!" cried Stubb.  "Pull now, men, like<br><br>fifty thousand line-of-battle-ship loads of red-haired devils.  What<br><br>d'ye say, Tashtego; are you the man to snap your spine in<br><br>two-and-twenty pieces for the honour of old Gayhead?  What d'ye say?"<br><br><br><br>"I say, pull like god-dam,"--cried the Indian.<br><br><br><br>Fiercely, but evenly incited by the taunts of the German, the<br><br>Pequod's three boats now began ranging almost abreast; and, so<br><br>disposed, momentarily neared him.  In that fine, loose, chivalrous<br><br>attitude of the headsman when drawing near to his prey, the three<br><br>mates stood up proudly, occasionally backing the after oarsman with<br><br>an exhilarating cry of, "There she slides, now!  Hurrah for the<br><br>white-ash breeze!  Down with the Yarman!  Sail over him!"<br><br><br><br>But so decided an original start had Derick had, that spite of all<br><br>their gallantry, he would have proved the victor in this race, had<br><br>not a righteous judgment descended upon him in a crab which caught<br><br>the blade of his midship oarsman.  While this clumsy lubber was<br><br>striving to free his white-ash, and while, in consequence, Derick's<br><br>boat was nigh to capsizing, and he thundering away at his men in a<br><br>mighty rage;--that was a good time for Starbuck, Stubb, and Flask.<br><br>With a shout, they took a mortal start forwards, and slantingly<br><br>ranged up on the German's quarter.  An instant more, and all four<br><br>boats were diagonically in the whale's immediate wake, while<br><br>stretching from them, on both sides, was the foaming swell that he<br><br>made.<br><br><br><br>It was a terrific, most pitiable, and maddening sight.  The whale was<br><br>now going head out, and sending his spout before him in a continual<br><br>tormented jet; while his one poor fin beat his side in an agony of<br><br>fright.  Now to this hand, now to that, he yawed in his faltering<br><br>flight, and still at every billow that he broke, he spasmodically<br><br>sank in the sea, or sideways rolled towards the sky his one beating<br><br>fin.  So have I seen a bird with clipped wing making affrighted<br><br>broken circles in the air, vainly striving to escape the piratical<br><br>hawks.  But the bird has a voice, and with plaintive cries will make<br><br>known her fear; but the fear of this vast dumb brute of the sea, was<br><br>chained up and enchanted in him; he had no voice, save that choking<br><br>respiration through his spiracle, and this made the sight of him<br><br>unspeakably pitiable; while still, in his amazing bulk, portcullis<br><br>jaw, and omnipotent tail, there was enough to appal the stoutest man<br><br>who so pitied.<br><br><br><br>Seeing now that but a very few moments more would give the Pequod's<br><br>boats the advantage, and rather than be thus foiled of his game,<br><br>Derick chose to hazard what to him must have seemed a most unusually<br><br>long dart, ere the last chance would for ever escape.<br><br><br><br>But no sooner did his harpooneer stand up for the stroke, than all<br><br>three tigers--Queequeg, Tashtego, Daggoo--instinctively sprang to<br><br>their feet, and standing in a diagonal row, simultaneously pointed<br><br>their barbs; and darted over the head of the German harpooneer, their<br><br>three Nantucket irons entered the whale.  Blinding vapours of foam and<br><br>white-fire!  The three boats, in the first fury of the whale's<br><br>headlong rush, bumped the German's aside with such force, that both<br><br>Derick and his baffled harpooneer were spilled out, and sailed over<br><br>by the three flying keels.<br><br><br><br>"Don't be afraid, my butter-boxes," cried Stubb, casting a passing<br><br>glance upon them as he shot by; "ye'll be picked up presently--all<br><br>right--I saw some sharks astern--St. Bernard's dogs, you<br><br>know--relieve distressed travellers.  Hurrah! this is the way to sail<br><br>now.  Every keel a sunbeam!  Hurrah!--Here we go like three tin<br><br>kettles at the tail of a mad cougar!  This puts me in mind of<br><br>fastening to an elephant in a tilbury on a plain--makes the<br><br>wheel-spokes fly, boys, when you fasten to him that way; and there's<br><br>danger of being pitched out too, when you strike a hill.  Hurrah!<br><br>this is the way a fellow feels when he's going to Davy Jones--all a<br><br>rush down an endless inclined plane!  Hurrah! this whale carries the<br><br>everlasting mail!"<br><br><br><br>But the monster's run was a brief one.  Giving a sudden gasp, he<br><br>tumultuously sounded.  With a grating rush, the three lines flew<br><br>round the loggerheads with such a force as to gouge deep grooves in<br><br>them; while so fearful were the harpooneers that this rapid sounding<br><br>would soon exhaust the lines, that using all their dexterous might,<br><br>they caught repeated smoking turns with the rope to hold on; till at<br><br>last--owing to the perpendicular strain from the lead-lined chocks of<br><br>the boats, whence the three ropes went straight down into the<br><br>blue--the gunwales of the bows were almost even with the water, while<br><br>the three sterns tilted high in the air.  And the whale soon ceasing<br><br>to sound, for some time they remained in that attitude, fearful of<br><br>expending more line, though the position was a little ticklish.  But<br><br>though boats have been taken down and lost in this way, yet it is<br><br>this "holding on," as it is called; this hooking up by the sharp<br><br>barbs of his live flesh from the back; this it is that often torments<br><br>the Leviathan into soon rising again to meet the sharp lance of his<br><br>foes.  Yet not to speak of the peril of the thing, it is to be<br><br>doubted whether this course is always the best; for it is but<br><br>reasonable to presume, that the longer the stricken whale stays under<br><br>water, the more he is exhausted.  Because, owing to the enormous<br><br>surface of him--in a full grown sperm whale something less than 2000<br><br>square feet--the pressure of the water is immense.  We all know what<br><br>an astonishing atmospheric weight we ourselves stand up under; even<br><br>here, above-ground, in the air; how vast, then, the burden of a<br><br>whale, bearing on his back a column of two hundred fathoms of ocean!<br><br>It must at least equal the weight of fifty atmospheres.  One whaleman<br><br>has estimated it at the weight of twenty line-of-battle ships, with<br><br>all their guns, and stores, and men on board.<br><br><br><br>As the three boats lay there on that gently rolling sea, gazing down<br><br>into its eternal blue noon; and as not a single groan or cry of any<br><br>sort, nay, not so much as a ripple or a bubble came up from its<br><br>depths; what landsman would have thought, that beneath all that<br><br>silence and placidity, the utmost monster of the seas was writhing<br><br>and wrenching in agony!  Not eight inches of perpendicular rope were<br><br>visible at the bows.  Seems it credible that by three such thin<br><br>threads the great Leviathan was suspended like the big weight to an<br><br>eight day clock.  Suspended? and to what?  To three bits of board.<br><br>Is this the creature of whom it was once so triumphantly said--"Canst<br><br>thou fill his skin with barbed irons? or his head with fish-spears?<br><br>The sword of him that layeth at him cannot hold, the spear, the dart,<br><br>nor the habergeon: he esteemeth iron as straw; the arrow cannot make<br><br>him flee; darts are counted as stubble; he laugheth at the shaking of<br><br>a spear!"  This the creature? this he?  Oh! that unfulfilments should<br><br>follow the prophets.  For with the strength of a thousand thighs in<br><br>his tail, Leviathan had run his head under the mountains of the sea,<br><br>to hide him from the Pequod's fish-spears!<br><br><br><br>In that sloping afternoon sunlight, the shadows that the three boats<br><br>sent down beneath the surface, must have been long enough and broad<br><br>enough to shade half Xerxes' army.  Who can tell how appalling to the<br><br>wounded whale must have been such huge phantoms flitting over his<br><br>head!<br><br><br><br>"Stand by, men; he stirs," cried Starbuck, as the three lines<br><br>suddenly vibrated in the water, distinctly conducting upwards to<br><br>them, as by magnetic wires, the life and death throbs of the whale,<br><br>so that every oarsman felt them in his seat.  The next moment,<br><br>relieved in great part from the downward strain at the bows, the<br><br>boats gave a sudden bounce upwards, as a small icefield will, when a<br><br>dense herd of white bears are scared from it into the sea.<br><br><br><br>"Haul in!  Haul in!" cried Starbuck again; "he's rising."<br><br><br><br>The lines, of which, hardly an instant before, not one hand's breadth<br><br>could have been gained, were now in long quick coils flung back all<br><br>dripping into the boats, and soon the whale broke water within two<br><br>ship's lengths of the hunters.<br><br><br><br>His motions plainly denoted his extreme exhaustion.  In most land<br><br>animals there are certain valves or flood-gates in many of their<br><br>veins, whereby when wounded, the blood is in some degree at least<br><br>instantly shut off in certain directions.  Not so with the whale; one<br><br>of whose peculiarities it is to have an entire non-valvular structure<br><br>of the blood-vessels, so that when pierced even by so small a point<br><br>as a harpoon, a deadly drain is at once begun upon his whole<br><br>arterial system; and when this is heightened by the extraordinary<br><br>pressure of water at a great distance below the surface, his life may<br><br>be said to pour from him in incessant streams.  Yet so vast is the<br><br>quantity of blood in him, and so distant and numerous its interior<br><br>fountains, that he will keep thus bleeding and bleeding for a<br><br>considerable period; even as in a drought a river will flow, whose<br><br>source is in the well-springs of far-off and undiscernible hills.<br><br>Even now, when the boats pulled upon this whale, and perilously drew<br><br>over his swaying flukes, and the lances were darted into him, they<br><br>were followed by steady jets from the new made wound, which kept<br><br>continually playing, while the natural spout-hole in his head was<br><br>only at intervals, however rapid, sending its affrighted moisture<br><br>into the air.  From this last vent no blood yet came, because no<br><br>vital part of him had thus far been struck.  His life, as they<br><br>significantly call it, was untouched.<br><br><br><br>As the boats now more closely surrounded him, the whole upper part of<br><br>his form, with much of it that is ordinarily submerged, was plainly<br><br>revealed.  His eyes, or rather the places where his eyes had been,<br><br>were beheld.  As strange misgrown masses gather in the knot-holes of<br><br>the noblest oaks when prostrate, so from the points which the whale's<br><br>eyes had once occupied, now protruded blind bulbs, horribly pitiable<br><br>to see.  But pity there was none.  For all his old age, and his one<br><br>arm, and his blind eyes, he must die the death and be murdered, in<br><br>order to light the gay bridals and other merry-makings of men, and<br><br>also to illuminate the solemn churches that preach unconditional<br><br>inoffensiveness by all to all.  Still rolling in his blood, at last<br><br>he partially disclosed a strangely discoloured bunch or protuberance,<br><br>the size of a bushel, low down on the flank.<br><br><br><br>"A nice spot," cried Flask; "just let me prick him there once."<br><br><br><br>"Avast!" cried Starbuck, "there's no need of that!"<br><br><br><br>But humane Starbuck was too late.  At the instant of the dart an<br><br>ulcerous jet shot from this cruel wound, and goaded by it into more<br><br>than sufferable anguish, the whale now spouting thick blood, with<br><br>swift fury blindly darted at the craft, bespattering them and their<br><br>glorying crews all over with showers of gore, capsizing Flask's boat<br><br>and marring the bows.  It was his death stroke.  For, by this time,<br><br>so spent was he by loss of blood, that he helplessly rolled away from<br><br>the wreck he had made; lay panting on his side, impotently flapped<br><br>with his stumped fin, then over and over slowly revolved like a<br><br>waning world; turned up the white secrets of his belly; lay like a<br><br>log, and died.  It was most piteous, that last expiring spout.  As<br><br>when by unseen hands the water is gradually drawn off from some<br><br>mighty fountain, and with half-stifled melancholy gurglings the<br><br>spray-column lowers and lowers to the ground--so the last long dying<br><br>spout of the whale.<br><br><br><br>Soon, while the crews were awaiting the arrival of the ship, the body<br><br>showed symptoms of sinking with all its treasures unrifled.<br><br>Immediately, by Starbuck's orders, lines were secured to it at<br><br>different points, so that ere long every boat was a buoy; the sunken<br><br>whale being suspended a few inches beneath them by the cords.  By<br><br>very heedful management, when the ship drew nigh, the whale was<br><br>transferred to her side, and was strongly secured there by the<br><br>stiffest fluke-chains, for it was plain that unless artificially<br><br>upheld, the body would at once sink to the bottom.<br><br><br><br>It so chanced that almost upon first cutting into him with the<br><br>spade, the entire length of a corroded harpoon was found imbedded in<br><br>his flesh, on the lower part of the bunch before described.  But as<br><br>the stumps of harpoons are frequently found in the dead bodies of<br><br>captured whales, with the flesh perfectly healed around them, and no<br><br>prominence of any kind to denote their place; therefore, there must<br><br>needs have been some other unknown reason in the present case fully<br><br>to account for the ulceration alluded to.  But still more curious was<br><br>the fact of a lance-head of stone being found in him, not far from<br><br>the buried iron, the flesh perfectly firm about it.  Who had darted<br><br>that stone lance?  And when?  It might have been darted by some Nor'<br><br>West Indian long before America was discovered.<br><br><br><br>What other marvels might have been rummaged out of this monstrous<br><br>cabinet there is no telling.  But a sudden stop was put to further<br><br>discoveries, by the ship's being unprecedentedly dragged over<br><br>sideways to the sea, owing to the body's immensely increasing<br><br>tendency to sink.  However, Starbuck, who had the ordering of<br><br>affairs, hung on to it to the last; hung on to it so resolutely,<br><br>indeed, that when at length the ship would have been capsized, if<br><br>still persisting in locking arms with the body; then, when the<br><br>command was given to break clear from it, such was the immovable<br><br>strain upon the timber-heads to which the fluke-chains and cables<br><br>were fastened, that it was impossible to cast them off.  Meantime<br><br>everything in the Pequod was aslant.  To cross to the other side of<br><br>the deck was like walking up the steep gabled roof of a house.  The<br><br>ship groaned and gasped.  Many of the ivory inlayings of her bulwarks<br><br>and cabins were started from their places, by the unnatural<br><br>dislocation.  In vain handspikes and crows were brought to bear upon<br><br>the immovable fluke-chains, to pry them adrift from the timberheads;<br><br>and so low had the whale now settled that the submerged ends could<br><br>not be at all approached, while every moment whole tons of<br><br>ponderosity seemed added to the sinking bulk, and the ship seemed on<br><br>the point of going over.<br><br><br><br>"Hold on, hold on, won't ye?" cried Stubb to the body, "don't be in<br><br>such a devil of a hurry to sink!  By thunder, men, we must do<br><br>something or go for it.  No use prying there; avast, I say with your<br><br>handspikes, and run one of ye for a prayer book and a pen-knife, and<br><br>cut the big chains."<br><br><br><br>"Knife?  Aye, aye," cried Queequeg, and seizing the carpenter's heavy<br><br>hatchet, he leaned out of a porthole, and steel to iron, began<br><br>slashing at the largest fluke-chains.  But a few strokes, full of<br><br>sparks, were given, when the exceeding strain effected the rest.<br><br>With a terrific snap, every fastening went adrift; the ship righted,<br><br>the carcase sank.<br><br><br><br>Now, this occasional inevitable sinking of the recently killed Sperm<br><br>Whale is a very curious thing; nor has any fisherman yet adequately<br><br>accounted for it.  Usually the dead Sperm Whale floats with great<br><br>buoyancy, with its side or belly considerably elevated above the<br><br>surface.  If the only whales that thus sank were old, meagre, and<br><br>broken-hearted creatures, their pads of lard diminished and all their<br><br>bones heavy and rheumatic; then you might with some reason assert<br><br>that this sinking is caused by an uncommon specific gravity in the<br><br>fish so sinking, consequent upon this absence of buoyant matter in<br><br>him.  But it is not so.  For young whales, in the highest health, and<br><br>swelling with noble aspirations, prematurely cut off in the warm<br><br>flush and May of life, with all their panting lard about them; even<br><br>these brawny, buoyant heroes do sometimes sink.<br><br><br><br>Be it said, however, that the Sperm Whale is far less liable to this<br><br>accident than any other species.  Where one of that sort go down,<br><br>twenty Right Whales do.  This difference in the species is no doubt<br><br>imputable in no small degree to the greater quantity of bone in the<br><br>Right Whale; his Venetian blinds alone sometimes weighing more than a<br><br>ton; from this incumbrance the Sperm Whale is wholly free.  But there<br><br>are instances where, after the lapse of many hours or several days,<br><br>the sunken whale again rises, more buoyant than in life.  But the<br><br>reason of this is obvious.  Gases are generated in him; he swells to<br><br>a prodigious magnitude; becomes a sort of animal balloon.  A<br><br>line-of-battle ship could hardly keep him under then.  In the Shore<br><br>Whaling, on soundings, among the Bays of New Zealand, when a Right<br><br>Whale gives token of sinking, they fasten buoys to him, with plenty<br><br>of rope; so that when the body has gone down, they know where to look<br><br>for it when it shall have ascended again.<br><br><br><br>It was not long after the sinking of the body that a cry was heard<br><br>from the Pequod's mast-heads, announcing that the Jungfrau was again<br><br>lowering her boats; though the only spout in sight was that of a<br><br>Fin-Back, belonging to the species of uncapturable whales, because of<br><br>its incredible power of swimming.  Nevertheless, the Fin-Back's spout<br><br>is so similar to the Sperm Whale's, that by unskilful fishermen it is<br><br>often mistaken for it.  And consequently Derick and all his host were<br><br>now in valiant chase of this unnearable brute.  The Virgin crowding<br><br>all sail, made after her four young keels, and thus they all<br><br>disappeared far to leeward, still in bold, hopeful chase.<br><br><br><br>Oh! many are the Fin-Backs, and many are the Dericks, my friend.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 82<br><br><br><br>The Honour and Glory of Whaling.<br><br><br><br><br><br>There are some enterprises in which a careful disorderliness is the<br><br>true method.<br><br><br><br>The more I dive into this matter of whaling, and push my researches<br><br>up to the very spring-head of it so much the more am I impressed with<br><br>its great honourableness and antiquity; and especially when I find so<br><br>many great demi-gods and heroes, prophets of all sorts, who one way<br><br>or other have shed distinction upon it, I am transported with the<br><br>reflection that I myself belong, though but subordinately, to so<br><br>emblazoned a fraternity.<br><br><br><br>The gallant Perseus, a son of Jupiter, was the first whaleman; and to<br><br>the eternal honour of our calling be it said, that the first whale<br><br>attacked by our brotherhood was not killed with any sordid intent.<br><br>Those were the knightly days of our profession, when we only bore<br><br>arms to succor the distressed, and not to fill men's lamp-feeders.<br><br>Every one knows the fine story of Perseus and Andromeda; how the<br><br>lovely Andromeda, the daughter of a king, was tied to a rock on the<br><br>sea-coast, and as Leviathan was in the very act of carrying her off,<br><br>Perseus, the prince of whalemen, intrepidly advancing, harpooned the<br><br>monster, and delivered and married the maid.  It was an admirable<br><br>artistic exploit, rarely achieved by the best harpooneers of the<br><br>present day; inasmuch as this Leviathan was slain at the very first<br><br>dart.  And let no man doubt this Arkite story; for in the ancient<br><br>Joppa, now Jaffa, on the Syrian coast, in one of the Pagan temples,<br><br>there stood for many ages the vast skeleton of a whale, which the<br><br>city's legends and all the inhabitants asserted to be the identical<br><br>bones of the monster that Perseus slew.  When the Romans took Joppa,<br><br>the same skeleton was carried to Italy in triumph.  What seems most<br><br>singular and suggestively important in this story, is this: it was<br><br>from Joppa that Jonah set sail.<br><br><br><br>Akin to the adventure of Perseus and Andromeda--indeed, by some<br><br>supposed to be indirectly derived from it--is that famous story of<br><br>St. George and the Dragon; which dragon I maintain to have been a<br><br>whale; for in many old chronicles whales and dragons are strangely<br><br>jumbled together, and often stand for each other.  "Thou art as a<br><br>lion of the waters, and as a dragon of the sea," saith Ezekiel;<br><br>hereby, plainly meaning a whale; in truth, some versions of the Bible<br><br>use that word itself.  Besides, it would much subtract from the glory<br><br>of the exploit had St. George but encountered a crawling reptile of<br><br>the land, instead of doing battle with the great monster of the deep.<br><br>Any man may kill a snake, but only a Perseus, a St. George, a<br><br>Coffin, have the heart in them to march boldly up to a whale.<br><br><br><br>Let not the modern paintings of this scene mislead us; for though the<br><br>creature encountered by that valiant whaleman of old is vaguely<br><br>represented of a griffin-like shape, and though the battle is<br><br>depicted on land and the saint on horseback, yet considering the<br><br>great ignorance of those times, when the true form of the whale was<br><br>unknown to artists; and considering that as in Perseus' case, St.<br><br>George's whale might have crawled up out of the sea on the beach; and<br><br>considering that the animal ridden by St. George might have been only<br><br>a large seal, or sea-horse; bearing all this in mind, it will not<br><br>appear altogether incompatible with the sacred legend and the<br><br>ancientest draughts of the scene, to hold this so-called dragon no<br><br>other than the great Leviathan himself.  In fact, placed before the<br><br>strict and piercing truth, this whole story will fare like that fish,<br><br>flesh, and fowl idol of the Philistines, Dagon by name; who being<br><br>planted before the ark of Israel, his horse's head and both the palms<br><br>of his hands fell off from him, and only the stump or fishy part of<br><br>him remained.  Thus, then, one of our own noble stamp, even a<br><br>whaleman, is the tutelary guardian of England; and by good rights, we<br><br>harpooneers of Nantucket should be enrolled in the most noble order<br><br>of St. George.  And therefore, let not the knights of that honourable<br><br>company (none of whom, I venture to say, have ever had to do with a<br><br>whale like their great patron), let them never eye a Nantucketer with<br><br>disdain, since even in our woollen frocks and tarred trowsers we are<br><br>much better entitled to St. George's decoration than they.<br><br><br><br>Whether to admit Hercules among us or not, concerning this I long<br><br>remained dubious: for though according to the Greek mythologies, that<br><br>antique Crockett and Kit Carson--that brawny doer of rejoicing good<br><br>deeds, was swallowed down and thrown up by a whale; still, whether<br><br>that strictly makes a whaleman of him, that might be mooted.  It<br><br>nowhere appears that he ever actually harpooned his fish, unless,<br><br>indeed, from the inside.  Nevertheless, he may be deemed a sort of<br><br>involuntary whaleman; at any rate the whale caught him, if he did not<br><br>the whale.  I claim him for one of our clan.<br><br><br><br>But, by the best contradictory authorities, this Grecian story of<br><br>Hercules and the whale is considered to be derived from the still<br><br>more ancient Hebrew story of Jonah and the whale; and vice versa;<br><br>certainly they are very similar.  If I claim the demigod then, why<br><br>not the prophet?<br><br><br><br>Nor do heroes, saints, demigods, and prophets alone comprise the<br><br>whole roll of our order.  Our grand master is still to be named; for<br><br>like royal kings of old times, we find the head waters of our<br><br>fraternity in nothing short of the great gods themselves.  That<br><br>wondrous oriental story is now to be rehearsed from the Shaster,<br><br>which gives us the dread Vishnoo, one of the three persons in the<br><br>godhead of the Hindoos; gives us this divine Vishnoo himself for our<br><br>Lord;--Vishnoo, who, by the first of his ten earthly incarnations,<br><br>has for ever set apart and sanctified the whale.  When Brahma, or the<br><br>God of Gods, saith the Shaster, resolved to recreate the world after<br><br>one of its periodical dissolutions, he gave birth to Vishnoo, to<br><br>preside over the work; but the Vedas, or mystical books, whose<br><br>perusal would seem to have been indispensable to Vishnoo before<br><br>beginning the creation, and which therefore must have contained<br><br>something in the shape of practical hints to young architects, these<br><br>Vedas were lying at the bottom of the waters; so Vishnoo became<br><br>incarnate in a whale, and sounding down in him to the uttermost<br><br>depths, rescued the sacred volumes.  Was not this Vishnoo a whaleman,<br><br>then? even as a man who rides a horse is called a horseman?<br><br><br><br>Perseus, St. George, Hercules, Jonah, and Vishnoo! there's a<br><br>member-roll for you!  What club but the whaleman's can head off like<br><br>that?<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 83<br><br><br><br>Jonah Historically Regarded.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Reference was made to the historical story of Jonah and the whale in<br><br>the preceding chapter.  Now some Nantucketers rather distrust this<br><br>historical story of Jonah and the whale.  But then there were some<br><br>sceptical Greeks and Romans, who, standing out from the orthodox<br><br>pagans of their times, equally doubted the story of Hercules and the<br><br>whale, and Arion and the dolphin; and yet their doubting those<br><br>traditions did not make those traditions one whit the less facts, for<br><br>all that.<br><br><br><br>One old Sag-Harbor whaleman's chief reason for questioning the Hebrew<br><br>story was this:--He had one of those quaint old-fashioned Bibles,<br><br>embellished with curious, unscientific plates; one of which<br><br>represented Jonah's whale with two spouts in his head--a peculiarity<br><br>only true with respect to a species of the Leviathan (the Right<br><br>Whale, and the varieties of that order), concerning which the<br><br>fishermen have this saying, "A penny roll would choke him"; his<br><br>swallow is so very small.  But, to this, Bishop Jebb's anticipative<br><br>answer is ready.  It is not necessary, hints the Bishop, that we<br><br>consider Jonah as tombed in the whale's belly, but as temporarily<br><br>lodged in some part of his mouth.  And this seems reasonable enough<br><br>in the good Bishop.  For truly, the Right Whale's mouth would<br><br>accommodate a couple of whist-tables, and comfortably seat all the<br><br>players.  Possibly, too, Jonah might have ensconced himself in a<br><br>hollow tooth; but, on second thoughts, the Right Whale is toothless.<br><br><br><br>Another reason which Sag-Harbor (he went by that name) urged for his<br><br>want of faith in this matter of the prophet, was something obscurely<br><br>in reference to his incarcerated body and the whale's gastric juices.<br><br>But this objection likewise falls to the ground, because a German<br><br>exegetist supposes that Jonah must have taken refuge in the floating<br><br>body of a DEAD whale--even as the French soldiers in the Russian<br><br>campaign turned their dead horses into tents, and crawled into them.<br><br>Besides, it has been divined by other continental commentators, that<br><br>when Jonah was thrown overboard from the Joppa ship, he straightway<br><br>effected his escape to another vessel near by, some vessel with a<br><br>whale for a figure-head; and, I would add, possibly called "The<br><br>Whale," as some craft are nowadays christened the "Shark," the<br><br>"Gull," the "Eagle."  Nor have there been wanting learned exegetists<br><br>who have opined that the whale mentioned in the book of Jonah merely<br><br>meant a life-preserver--an inflated bag of wind--which the endangered<br><br>prophet swam to, and so was saved from a watery doom.  Poor<br><br>Sag-Harbor, therefore, seems worsted all round.  But he had still<br><br>another reason for his want of faith.  It was this, if I remember<br><br>right: Jonah was swallowed by the whale in the Mediterranean Sea, and<br><br>after three days he was vomited up somewhere within three days'<br><br>journey of Nineveh, a city on the Tigris, very much more than three<br><br>days' journey across from the nearest point of the Mediterranean<br><br>coast.  How is that?<br><br><br><br>But was there no other way for the whale to land the prophet within<br><br>that short distance of Nineveh?  Yes.  He might have carried him<br><br>round by the way of the Cape of Good Hope.  But not to speak of the<br><br>passage through the whole length of the Mediterranean, and another<br><br>passage up the Persian Gulf and Red Sea, such a supposition would<br><br>involve the complete circumnavigation of all Africa in three days,<br><br>not to speak of the Tigris waters, near the site of Nineveh, being<br><br>too shallow for any whale to swim in.  Besides, this idea of Jonah's<br><br>weathering the Cape of Good Hope at so early a day would wrest the<br><br>honour of the discovery of that great headland from Bartholomew Diaz,<br><br>its reputed discoverer, and so make modern history a liar.<br><br><br><br>But all these foolish arguments of old Sag-Harbor only evinced his<br><br>foolish pride of reason--a thing still more reprehensible in him,<br><br>seeing that he had but little learning except what he had picked up<br><br>from the sun and the sea.  I say it only shows his foolish, impious<br><br>pride, and abominable, devilish rebellion against the reverend<br><br>clergy.  For by a Portuguese Catholic priest, this very idea of<br><br>Jonah's going to Nineveh via the Cape of Good Hope was advanced as a<br><br>signal magnification of the general miracle.  And so it was.<br><br>Besides, to this day, the highly enlightened Turks devoutly believe<br><br>in the historical story of Jonah.  And some three centuries ago, an<br><br>English traveller in old Harris's Voyages, speaks of a Turkish Mosque<br><br>built in honour of Jonah, in which Mosque was a miraculous lamp that<br><br>burnt without any oil.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 84<br><br><br><br>Pitchpoling.<br><br><br><br><br><br>To make them run easily and swiftly, the axles of carriages are<br><br>anointed; and for much the same purpose, some whalers perform an<br><br>analogous operation upon their boat; they grease the bottom.  Nor is<br><br>it to be doubted that as such a procedure can do no harm, it may<br><br>possibly be of no contemptible advantage; considering that oil and<br><br>water are hostile; that oil is a sliding thing, and that the object<br><br>in view is to make the boat slide bravely.  Queequeg believed<br><br>strongly in anointing his boat, and one morning not long after the<br><br>German ship Jungfrau disappeared, took more than customary pains in<br><br>that occupation; crawling under its bottom, where it hung over the<br><br>side, and rubbing in the unctuousness as though diligently seeking to<br><br>insure a crop of hair from the craft's bald keel.  He seemed to be<br><br>working in obedience to some particular presentiment.  Nor did it<br><br>remain unwarranted by the event.<br><br><br><br>Towards noon whales were raised; but so soon as the ship sailed down<br><br>to them, they turned and fled with swift precipitancy; a disordered<br><br>flight, as of Cleopatra's barges from Actium.<br><br><br><br>Nevertheless, the boats pursued, and Stubb's was foremost.  By great<br><br>exertion, Tashtego at last succeeded in planting one iron; but the<br><br>stricken whale, without at all sounding, still continued his<br><br>horizontal flight, with added fleetness.  Such unintermitted<br><br>strainings upon the planted iron must sooner or later inevitably<br><br>extract it.  It became imperative to lance the flying whale, or be<br><br>content to lose him.  But to haul the boat up to his flank was<br><br>impossible, he swam so fast and furious.  What then remained?<br><br><br><br>Of all the wondrous devices and dexterities, the sleights of hand and<br><br>countless subtleties, to which the veteran whaleman is so often<br><br>forced, none exceed that fine manoeuvre with the lance called<br><br>pitchpoling.  Small sword, or broad sword, in all its exercises<br><br>boasts nothing like it.  It is only indispensable with an inveterate<br><br>running whale; its grand fact and feature is the wonderful distance<br><br>to which the long lance is accurately darted from a violently<br><br>rocking, jerking boat, under extreme headway.  Steel and wood<br><br>included, the entire spear is some ten or twelve feet in length; the<br><br>staff is much slighter than that of the harpoon, and also of a<br><br>lighter material--pine.  It is furnished with a small rope called a<br><br>warp, of considerable length, by which it can be hauled back to the<br><br>hand after darting.<br><br><br><br>But before going further, it is important to mention here, that<br><br>though the harpoon may be pitchpoled in the same way with the lance,<br><br>yet it is seldom done; and when done, is still less frequently<br><br>successful, on account of the greater weight and inferior length of<br><br>the harpoon as compared with the lance, which in effect become<br><br>serious drawbacks.  As a general thing, therefore, you must first<br><br>get fast to a whale, before any pitchpoling comes into play.<br><br><br><br>Look now at Stubb; a man who from his humorous, deliberate coolness<br><br>and equanimity in the direst emergencies, was specially qualified to<br><br>excel in pitchpoling.  Look at him; he stands upright in the tossed<br><br>bow of the flying boat; wrapt in fleecy foam, the towing whale is<br><br>forty feet ahead.  Handling the long lance lightly, glancing twice or<br><br>thrice along its length to see if it be exactly straight, Stubb<br><br>whistlingly gathers up the coil of the warp in one hand, so as to<br><br>secure its free end in his grasp, leaving the rest unobstructed.<br><br>Then holding the lance full before his waistband's middle, he levels<br><br>it at the whale; when, covering him with it, he steadily depresses<br><br>the butt-end in his hand, thereby elevating the point till the weapon<br><br>stands fairly balanced upon his palm, fifteen feet in the air.  He<br><br>minds you somewhat of a juggler, balancing a long staff on his chin.<br><br>Next moment with a rapid, nameless impulse, in a superb lofty arch the<br><br>bright steel spans the foaming distance, and quivers in the life spot<br><br>of the whale.  Instead of sparkling water, he now spouts red blood.<br><br><br><br>"That drove the spigot out of him!" cried Stubb.  "'Tis July's<br><br>immortal Fourth; all fountains must run wine today!  Would now, it<br><br>were old Orleans whiskey, or old Ohio, or unspeakable old<br><br>Monongahela!  Then, Tashtego, lad, I'd have ye hold a canakin to the<br><br>jet, and we'd drink round it!  Yea, verily, hearts alive, we'd brew<br><br>choice punch in the spread of his spout-hole there, and from that<br><br>live punch-bowl quaff the living stuff."<br><br><br><br>Again and again to such gamesome talk, the dexterous dart is<br><br>repeated, the spear returning to its master like a greyhound held in<br><br>skilful leash.  The agonized whale goes into his flurry; the tow-line<br><br>is slackened, and the pitchpoler dropping astern, folds his hands,<br><br>and mutely watches the monster die.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 85<br><br><br><br>The Fountain.<br><br><br><br><br><br>That for six thousand years--and no one knows how many millions of<br><br>ages before--the great whales should have been spouting all over the<br><br>sea, and sprinkling and mistifying the gardens of the deep, as with<br><br>so many sprinkling or mistifying pots; and that for some centuries<br><br>back, thousands of hunters should have been close by the fountain of<br><br>the whale, watching these sprinklings and spoutings--that all this<br><br>should be, and yet, that down to this blessed minute (fifteen and a<br><br>quarter minutes past one o'clock P.M. of this sixteenth day of<br><br>December, A.D. 1851), it should still remain a problem, whether these<br><br>spoutings are, after all, really water, or nothing but vapour--this is<br><br>surely a noteworthy thing.<br><br><br><br>Let us, then, look at this matter, along with some interesting items<br><br>contingent.  Every one knows that by the peculiar cunning of their<br><br>gills, the finny tribes in general breathe the air which at all times<br><br>is combined with the element in which they swim; hence, a herring or<br><br>a cod might live a century, and never once raise its head above the<br><br>surface.  But owing to his marked internal structure which gives him<br><br>regular lungs, like a human being's, the whale can only live by<br><br>inhaling the disengaged air in the open atmosphere.  Wherefore the<br><br>necessity for his periodical visits to the upper world.  But he<br><br>cannot in any degree breathe through his mouth, for, in his ordinary<br><br>attitude, the Sperm Whale's mouth is buried at least eight feet<br><br>beneath the surface; and what is still more, his windpipe has no<br><br>connexion with his mouth.  No, he breathes through his spiracle<br><br>alone; and this is on the top of his head.<br><br><br><br>If I say, that in any creature breathing is only a function<br><br>indispensable to vitality, inasmuch as it withdraws from the air a<br><br>certain element, which being subsequently brought into contact with<br><br>the blood imparts to the blood its vivifying principle, I do not<br><br>think I shall err; though I may possibly use some superfluous<br><br>scientific words.  Assume it, and it follows that if all the blood in<br><br>a man could be aerated with one breath, he might then seal up his<br><br>nostrils and not fetch another for a considerable time.  That is to<br><br>say, he would then live without breathing.  Anomalous as it may seem,<br><br>this is precisely the case with the whale, who systematically lives,<br><br>by intervals, his full hour and more (when at the bottom) without<br><br>drawing a single breath, or so much as in any way inhaling a particle<br><br>of air; for, remember, he has no gills.  How is this?  Between his<br><br>ribs and on each side of his spine he is supplied with a remarkable<br><br>involved Cretan labyrinth of vermicelli-like vessels, which vessels,<br><br>when he quits the surface, are completely distended with oxygenated<br><br>blood.  So that for an hour or more, a thousand fathoms in the sea,<br><br>he carries a surplus stock of vitality in him, just as the camel<br><br>crossing the waterless desert carries a surplus supply of drink for<br><br>future use in its four supplementary stomachs.  The anatomical fact<br><br>of this labyrinth is indisputable; and that the supposition founded<br><br>upon it is reasonable and true, seems the more cogent to me, when I<br><br>consider the otherwise inexplicable obstinacy of that leviathan in<br><br>HAVING HIS SPOUTINGS OUT, as the fishermen phrase it.  This is what I<br><br>mean.  If unmolested, upon rising to the surface, the Sperm Whale<br><br>will continue there for a period of time exactly uniform with all his<br><br>other unmolested risings.  Say he stays eleven minutes, and jets<br><br>seventy times, that is, respires seventy breaths; then whenever he<br><br>rises again, he will be sure to have his seventy breaths over again,<br><br>to a minute.  Now, if after he fetches a few breaths you alarm him,<br><br>so that he sounds, he will be always dodging up again to make good<br><br>his regular allowance of air.  And not till those seventy breaths are<br><br>told, will he finally go down to stay out his full term below.<br><br>Remark, however, that in different individuals these rates are<br><br>different; but in any one they are alike.  Now, why should the whale<br><br>thus insist upon having his spoutings out, unless it be to replenish<br><br>his reservoir of air, ere descending for good?  How obvious is it,<br><br>too, that this necessity for the whale's rising exposes him to all<br><br>the fatal hazards of the chase.  For not by hook or by net could<br><br>this vast leviathan be caught, when sailing a thousand fathoms<br><br>beneath the sunlight.  Not so much thy skill, then, O hunter, as the<br><br>great necessities that strike the victory to thee!<br><br><br><br>In man, breathing is incessantly going on--one breath only serving<br><br>for two or three pulsations; so that whatever other business he has<br><br>to attend to, waking or sleeping, breathe he must, or die he will.<br><br>But the Sperm Whale only breathes about one seventh or Sunday of his<br><br>time.<br><br><br><br>It has been said that the whale only breathes through his spout-hole;<br><br>if it could truthfully be added that his spouts are mixed with water,<br><br>then I opine we should be furnished with the reason why his sense of<br><br>smell seems obliterated in him; for the only thing about him that at<br><br>all answers to his nose is that identical spout-hole; and being so<br><br>clogged with two elements, it could not be expected to have the power<br><br>of smelling.  But owing to the mystery of the spout--whether it be<br><br>water or whether it be vapour--no absolute certainty can as yet be<br><br>arrived at on this head.  Sure it is, nevertheless, that the Sperm<br><br>Whale has no proper olfactories.  But what does he want of them?  No<br><br>roses, no violets, no Cologne-water in the sea.<br><br><br><br>Furthermore, as his windpipe solely opens into the tube of his<br><br>spouting canal, and as that long canal--like the grand Erie Canal--is<br><br>furnished with a sort of locks (that open and shut) for the downward<br><br>retention of air or the upward exclusion of water, therefore the<br><br>whale has no voice; unless you insult him by saying, that when he so<br><br>strangely rumbles, he talks through his nose.  But then again, what<br><br>has the whale to say?  Seldom have I known any profound being that<br><br>had anything to say to this world, unless forced to stammer out<br><br>something by way of getting a living.  Oh! happy that the world is<br><br>such an excellent listener!<br><br><br><br>Now, the spouting canal of the Sperm Whale, chiefly intended as it is<br><br>for the conveyance of air, and for several feet laid along,<br><br>horizontally, just beneath the upper surface of his head, and a<br><br>little to one side; this curious canal is very much like a gas-pipe<br><br>laid down in a city on one side of a street.  But the question<br><br>returns whether this gas-pipe is also a water-pipe; in other words,<br><br>whether the spout of the Sperm Whale is the mere vapour of the exhaled<br><br>breath, or whether that exhaled breath is mixed with water taken in<br><br>at the mouth, and discharged through the spiracle.  It is certain<br><br>that the mouth indirectly communicates with the spouting canal; but<br><br>it cannot be proved that this is for the purpose of discharging water<br><br>through the spiracle.  Because the greatest necessity for so doing<br><br>would seem to be, when in feeding he accidentally takes in water.<br><br>But the Sperm Whale's food is far beneath the surface, and there he<br><br>cannot spout even if he would.  Besides, if you regard him very<br><br>closely, and time him with your watch, you will find that when<br><br>unmolested, there is an undeviating rhyme between the periods of his<br><br>jets and the ordinary periods of respiration.<br><br><br><br>But why pester one with all this reasoning on the subject?  Speak<br><br>out!  You have seen him spout; then declare what the spout is; can<br><br>you not tell water from air?  My dear sir, in this world it is not so<br><br>easy to settle these plain things.  I have ever found your plain<br><br>things the knottiest of all.  And as for this whale spout, you might<br><br>almost stand in it, and yet be undecided as to what it is precisely.<br><br><br><br>The central body of it is hidden in the snowy sparkling mist<br><br>enveloping it; and how can you certainly tell whether any water falls<br><br>from it, when, always, when you are close enough to a whale to get a<br><br>close view of his spout, he is in a prodigious commotion, the water<br><br>cascading all around him.  And if at such times you should think that<br><br>you really perceived drops of moisture in the spout, how do you know<br><br>that they are not merely condensed from its vapour; or how do you know<br><br>that they are not those identical drops superficially lodged in the<br><br>spout-hole fissure, which is countersunk into the summit of the<br><br>whale's head?  For even when tranquilly swimming through the mid-day<br><br>sea in a calm, with his elevated hump sun-dried as a dromedary's in<br><br>the desert; even then, the whale always carries a small basin of<br><br>water on his head, as under a blazing sun you will sometimes see a<br><br>cavity in a rock filled up with rain.<br><br><br><br>Nor is it at all prudent for the hunter to be over curious touching<br><br>the precise nature of the whale spout.  It will not do for him to be<br><br>peering into it, and putting his face in it.  You cannot go with your<br><br>pitcher to this fountain and fill it, and bring it away.  For even<br><br>when coming into slight contact with the outer, vapoury shreds of the<br><br>jet, which will often happen, your skin will feverishly smart, from<br><br>the acridness of the thing so touching it.  And I know one, who<br><br>coming into still closer contact with the spout, whether with some<br><br>scientific object in view, or otherwise, I cannot say, the skin<br><br>peeled off from his cheek and arm.  Wherefore, among whalemen, the<br><br>spout is deemed poisonous; they try to evade it.  Another thing; I<br><br>have heard it said, and I do not much doubt it, that if the jet is<br><br>fairly spouted into your eyes, it will blind you.  The wisest thing<br><br>the investigator can do then, it seems to me, is to let this deadly<br><br>spout alone.<br><br><br><br>Still, we can hypothesize, even if we cannot prove and establish.  My<br><br>hypothesis is this: that the spout is nothing but mist.  And besides<br><br>other reasons, to this conclusion I am impelled, by considerations<br><br>touching the great inherent dignity and sublimity of the Sperm Whale;<br><br>I account him no common, shallow being, inasmuch as it is an<br><br>undisputed fact that he is never found on soundings, or near shores;<br><br>all other whales sometimes are.  He is both ponderous and profound.<br><br>And I am convinced that from the heads of all ponderous profound<br><br>beings, such as Plato, Pyrrho, the Devil, Jupiter, Dante, and so on,<br><br>there always goes up a certain semi-visible steam, while in the act<br><br>of thinking deep thoughts.  While composing a little treatise on<br><br>Eternity, I had the curiosity to place a mirror before me; and ere<br><br>long saw reflected there, a curious involved worming and undulation<br><br>in the atmosphere over my head.  The invariable moisture of my hair,<br><br>while plunged in deep thought, after six cups of hot tea in my thin<br><br>shingled attic, of an August noon; this seems an additional argument<br><br>for the above supposition.<br><br><br><br>And how nobly it raises our conceit of the mighty, misty monster, to<br><br>behold him solemnly sailing through a calm tropical sea; his vast,<br><br>mild head overhung by a canopy of vapour, engendered by his<br><br>incommunicable contemplations, and that vapour--as you will sometimes<br><br>see it--glorified by a rainbow, as if Heaven itself had put its seal<br><br>upon his thoughts.  For, d'ye see, rainbows do not visit the clear<br><br>air; they only irradiate vapour.  And so, through all the thick mists<br><br>of the dim doubts in my mind, divine intuitions now and then shoot,<br><br>enkindling my fog with a heavenly ray.  And for this I thank God; for<br><br>all have doubts; many deny; but doubts or denials, few along with<br><br>them, have intuitions.  Doubts of all things earthly, and intuitions<br><br>of some things heavenly; this combination makes neither believer nor<br><br>infidel, but makes a man who regards them both with equal eye.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 86<br><br><br><br>The Tail.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Other poets have warbled the praises of the soft eye of the antelope,<br><br>and the lovely plumage of the bird that never alights; less<br><br>celestial, I celebrate a tail.<br><br><br><br>Reckoning the largest sized Sperm Whale's tail to begin at that point<br><br>of the trunk where it tapers to about the girth of a man, it<br><br>comprises upon its upper surface alone, an area of at least fifty<br><br>square feet.  The compact round body of its root expands into two<br><br>broad, firm, flat palms or flukes, gradually shoaling away to less<br><br>than an inch in thickness.  At the crotch or junction, these flukes<br><br>slightly overlap, then sideways recede from each other like wings,<br><br>leaving a wide vacancy between.  In no living thing are the lines of<br><br>beauty more exquisitely defined than in the crescentic borders of<br><br>these flukes.  At its utmost expansion in the full grown whale, the<br><br>tail will considerably exceed twenty feet across.<br><br><br><br>The entire member seems a dense webbed bed of welded sinews; but cut<br><br>into it, and you find that three distinct strata compose it:--upper,<br><br>middle, and lower.  The fibres in the upper and lower layers, are<br><br>long and horizontal; those of the middle one, very short, and running<br><br>crosswise between the outside layers.  This triune structure, as much<br><br>as anything else, imparts power to the tail.  To the student of old<br><br>Roman walls, the middle layer will furnish a curious parallel to the<br><br>thin course of tiles always alternating with the stone in those<br><br>wonderful relics of the antique, and which undoubtedly contribute so<br><br>much to the great strength of the masonry.<br><br><br><br>But as if this vast local power in the tendinous tail were not<br><br>enough, the whole bulk of the leviathan is knit over with a warp and<br><br>woof of muscular fibres and filaments, which passing on either side<br><br>the loins and running down into the flukes, insensibly blend with<br><br>them, and largely contribute to their might; so that in the tail the<br><br>confluent measureless force of the whole whale seems concentrated to<br><br>a point.  Could annihilation occur to matter, this were the thing to<br><br>do it.<br><br><br><br>Nor does this--its amazing strength, at all tend to cripple the<br><br>graceful flexion of its motions; where infantileness of ease<br><br>undulates through a Titanism of power.  On the contrary, those<br><br>motions derive their most appalling beauty from it.  Real strength<br><br>never impairs beauty or harmony, but it often bestows it; and in<br><br>everything imposingly beautiful, strength has much to do with the<br><br>magic.  Take away the tied tendons that all over seem bursting from<br><br>the marble in the carved Hercules, and its charm would be gone.  As<br><br>devout Eckerman lifted the linen sheet from the naked corpse of<br><br>Goethe, he was overwhelmed with the massive chest of the man, that<br><br>seemed as a Roman triumphal arch.  When Angelo paints even God the<br><br>Father in human form, mark what robustness is there.  And whatever<br><br>they may reveal of the divine love in the Son, the soft, curled,<br><br>hermaphroditical Italian pictures, in which his idea has been most<br><br>successfully embodied; these pictures, so destitute as they are of<br><br>all brawniness, hint nothing of any power, but the mere negative,<br><br>feminine one of submission and endurance, which on all hands it is<br><br>conceded, form the peculiar practical virtues of his teachings.<br><br><br><br>Such is the subtle elasticity of the organ I treat of, that whether<br><br>wielded in sport, or in earnest, or in anger, whatever be the mood it<br><br>be in, its flexions are invariably marked by exceeding grace.<br><br>Therein no fairy's arm can transcend it.<br><br><br><br>Five great motions are peculiar to it.  First, when used as a fin for<br><br>progression; Second, when used as a mace in battle; Third, in<br><br>sweeping; Fourth, in lobtailing; Fifth, in peaking flukes.<br><br><br><br>First: Being horizontal in its position, the Leviathan's tail acts in<br><br>a different manner from the tails of all other sea creatures.  It<br><br>never wriggles.  In man or fish, wriggling is a sign of inferiority.<br><br>To the whale, his tail is the sole means of propulsion.  Scroll-wise<br><br>coiled forwards beneath the body, and then rapidly sprung backwards,<br><br>it is this which gives that singular darting, leaping motion to the<br><br>monster when furiously swimming.  His side-fins only serve to steer<br><br>by.<br><br><br><br>Second: It is a little significant, that while one sperm whale only<br><br>fights another sperm whale with his head and jaw, nevertheless, in<br><br>his conflicts with man, he chiefly and contemptuously uses his tail.<br><br>In striking at a boat, he swiftly curves away his flukes from it, and<br><br>the blow is only inflicted by the recoil.  If it be made in the<br><br>unobstructed air, especially if it descend to its mark, the stroke is<br><br>then simply irresistible.  No ribs of man or boat can withstand it.<br><br>Your only salvation lies in eluding it; but if it comes sideways<br><br>through the opposing water, then partly owing to the light buoyancy<br><br>of the whale boat, and the elasticity of its materials, a cracked<br><br>rib or a dashed plank or two, a sort of stitch in the side, is<br><br>generally the most serious result.  These submerged side blows are so<br><br>often received in the fishery, that they are accounted mere child's<br><br>play.  Some one strips off a frock, and the hole is stopped.<br><br><br><br>Third: I cannot demonstrate it, but it seems to me, that in the whale<br><br>the sense of touch is concentrated in the tail; for in this respect<br><br>there is a delicacy in it only equalled by the daintiness of the<br><br>elephant's trunk.  This delicacy is chiefly evinced in the action of<br><br>sweeping, when in maidenly gentleness the whale with a certain soft<br><br>slowness moves his immense flukes from side to side upon the surface of<br><br>the sea; and if he feel but a sailor's whisker, woe to that sailor,<br><br>whiskers and all.  What tenderness there is in that preliminary<br><br>touch!  Had this tail any prehensile power, I should straightway<br><br>bethink me of Darmonodes' elephant that so frequented the<br><br>flower-market, and with low salutations presented nosegays to<br><br>damsels, and then caressed their zones.  On more accounts than one, a<br><br>pity it is that the whale does not possess this prehensile virtue in<br><br>his tail; for I have heard of yet another elephant, that when wounded<br><br>in the fight, curved round his trunk and extracted the dart.<br><br><br><br>Fourth: Stealing unawares upon the whale in the fancied security of<br><br>the middle of solitary seas, you find him unbent from the vast<br><br>corpulence of his dignity, and kitten-like, he plays on the ocean as<br><br>if it were a hearth.  But still you see his power in his play.  The<br><br>broad palms of his tail are flirted high into the air; then smiting<br><br>the surface, the thunderous concussion resounds for miles.  You would<br><br>almost think a great gun had been discharged; and if you noticed the<br><br>light wreath of vapour from the spiracle at his other extremity, you<br><br>would think that that was the smoke from the touch-hole.<br><br><br><br>Fifth: As in the ordinary floating posture of the leviathan the<br><br>flukes lie considerably below the level of his back, they are then<br><br>completely out of sight beneath the surface; but when he is about to<br><br>plunge into the deeps, his entire flukes with at least thirty feet of<br><br>his body are tossed erect in the air, and so remain vibrating a<br><br>moment, till they downwards shoot out of view.  Excepting the sublime<br><br>BREACH--somewhere else to be described--this peaking of the whale's<br><br>flukes is perhaps the grandest sight to be seen in all animated<br><br>nature.  Out of the bottomless profundities the gigantic tail seems<br><br>spasmodically snatching at the highest heaven.  So in dreams, have I<br><br>seen majestic Satan thrusting forth his tormented colossal claw from<br><br>the flame Baltic of Hell.  But in gazing at such scenes, it is all in<br><br>all what mood you are in; if in the Dantean, the devils will occur to<br><br>you; if in that of Isaiah, the archangels.  Standing at the mast-head<br><br>of my ship during a sunrise that crimsoned sky and sea, I once saw a<br><br>large herd of whales in the east, all heading towards the sun, and<br><br>for a moment vibrating in concert with peaked flukes.  As it seemed<br><br>to me at the time, such a grand embodiment of adoration of the gods<br><br>was never beheld, even in Persia, the home of the fire worshippers.<br><br>As Ptolemy Philopater testified of the African elephant, I then<br><br>testified of the whale, pronouncing him the most devout of all<br><br>beings.  For according to King Juba, the military elephants of<br><br>antiquity often hailed the morning with their trunks uplifted in the<br><br>profoundest silence.<br><br><br><br>The chance comparison in this chapter, between the whale and the<br><br>elephant, so far as some aspects of the tail of the one and the trunk<br><br>of the other are concerned, should not tend to place those two<br><br>opposite organs on an equality, much less the creatures to which they<br><br>respectively belong.  For as the mightiest elephant is but a terrier<br><br>to Leviathan, so, compared with Leviathan's tail, his trunk is but<br><br>the stalk of a lily.  The most direful blow from the elephant's trunk<br><br>were as the playful tap of a fan, compared with the measureless crush<br><br>and crash of the sperm whale's ponderous flukes, which in repeated<br><br>instances have one after the other hurled entire boats with all their<br><br>oars and crews into the air, very much as an Indian juggler tosses<br><br>his balls.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*Though all comparison in the way of general bulk between the whale<br><br>and the elephant is preposterous, inasmuch as in that particular the<br><br>elephant stands in much the same respect to the whale that a dog does<br><br>to the elephant; nevertheless, there are not wanting some points of<br><br>curious similitude; among these is the spout.  It is well known that<br><br>the elephant will often draw up water or dust in his trunk, and then<br><br>elevating it, jet it forth in a stream.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The more I consider this mighty tail, the more do I deplore my<br><br>inability to express it.  At times there are gestures in it, which,<br><br>though they would well grace the hand of man, remain wholly<br><br>inexplicable.  In an extensive herd, so remarkable, occasionally, are<br><br>these mystic gestures, that I have heard hunters who have declared<br><br>them akin to Free-Mason signs and symbols; that the whale, indeed, by<br><br>these methods intelligently conversed with the world.  Nor are there<br><br>wanting other motions of the whale in his general body, full of<br><br>strangeness, and unaccountable to his most experienced assailant.<br><br>Dissect him how I may, then, I but go skin deep; I know him not,<br><br>and never will.  But if I know not even the tail of this whale, how<br><br>understand his head? much more, how comprehend his face, when face he<br><br>has none?  Thou shalt see my back parts, my tail, he seems to say,<br><br>but my face shall not be seen.  But I cannot completely make out his<br><br>back parts; and hint what he will about his face, I say again he has<br><br>no face.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 87<br><br><br><br>The Grand Armada.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The long and narrow peninsula of Malacca, extending south-eastward<br><br>from the territories of Birmah, forms the most southerly point of all<br><br>Asia.  In a continuous line from that peninsula stretch the long<br><br>islands of Sumatra, Java, Bally, and Timor; which, with many others,<br><br>form a vast mole, or rampart, lengthwise connecting Asia with<br><br>Australia, and dividing the long unbroken Indian ocean from the<br><br>thickly studded oriental archipelagoes.  This rampart is pierced by<br><br>several sally-ports for the convenience of ships and whales;<br><br>conspicuous among which are the straits of Sunda and Malacca.  By the<br><br>straits of Sunda, chiefly, vessels bound to China from the west,<br><br>emerge into the China seas.<br><br><br><br>Those narrow straits of Sunda divide Sumatra from Java; and standing<br><br>midway in that vast rampart of islands, buttressed by that bold green<br><br>promontory, known to seamen as Java Head; they not a little<br><br>correspond to the central gateway opening into some vast walled<br><br>empire: and considering the inexhaustible wealth of spices, and<br><br>silks, and jewels, and gold, and ivory, with which the thousand<br><br>islands of that oriental sea are enriched, it seems a significant<br><br>provision of nature, that such treasures, by the very formation of<br><br>the land, should at least bear the appearance, however ineffectual,<br><br>of being guarded from the all-grasping western world.  The shores of<br><br>the Straits of Sunda are unsupplied with those domineering fortresses<br><br>which guard the entrances to the Mediterranean, the Baltic, and the<br><br>Propontis.  Unlike the Danes, these Orientals do not demand the<br><br>obsequious homage of lowered top-sails from the endless procession of<br><br>ships before the wind, which for centuries past, by night and by day,<br><br>have passed between the islands of Sumatra and Java, freighted with<br><br>the costliest cargoes of the east.  But while they freely waive a<br><br>ceremonial like this, they do by no means renounce their claim to<br><br>more solid tribute.<br><br><br><br>Time out of mind the piratical proas of the Malays, lurking among the<br><br>low shaded coves and islets of Sumatra, have sallied out upon the<br><br>vessels sailing through the straits, fiercely demanding tribute at<br><br>the point of their spears.  Though by the repeated bloody<br><br>chastisements they have received at the hands of European cruisers,<br><br>the audacity of these corsairs has of late been somewhat repressed;<br><br>yet, even at the present day, we occasionally hear of English and<br><br>American vessels, which, in those waters, have been remorselessly<br><br>boarded and pillaged.<br><br><br><br>With a fair, fresh wind, the Pequod was now drawing nigh to these<br><br>straits; Ahab purposing to pass through them into the Javan sea, and<br><br>thence, cruising northwards, over waters known to be frequented here<br><br>and there by the Sperm Whale, sweep inshore by the Philippine<br><br>Islands, and gain the far coast of Japan, in time for the great<br><br>whaling season there.  By these means, the circumnavigating Pequod<br><br>would sweep almost all the known Sperm Whale cruising grounds of the<br><br>world, previous to descending upon the Line in the Pacific; where<br><br>Ahab, though everywhere else foiled in his pursuit, firmly counted<br><br>upon giving battle to Moby Dick, in the sea he was most known to<br><br>frequent; and at a season when he might most reasonably be presumed<br><br>to be haunting it.<br><br><br><br>But how now? in this zoned quest, does Ahab touch no land? does his<br><br>crew drink air?  Surely, he will stop for water.  Nay.  For a long<br><br>time, now, the circus-running sun has raced within his fiery ring,<br><br>and needs no sustenance but what's in himself.  So Ahab.  Mark this,<br><br>too, in the whaler.  While other hulls are loaded down with alien<br><br>stuff, to be transferred to foreign wharves; the world-wandering<br><br>whale-ship carries no cargo but herself and crew, their weapons and<br><br>their wants.  She has a whole lake's contents bottled in her ample<br><br>hold.  She is ballasted with utilities; not altogether with unusable<br><br>pig-lead and kentledge.  She carries years' water in her.  Clear old<br><br>prime Nantucket water; which, when three years afloat, the<br><br>Nantucketer, in the Pacific, prefers to drink before the brackish<br><br>fluid, but yesterday rafted off in casks, from the Peruvian or Indian<br><br>streams.  Hence it is, that, while other ships may have gone to China<br><br>from New York, and back again, touching at a score of ports, the<br><br>whale-ship, in all that interval, may not have sighted one grain of<br><br>soil; her crew having seen no man but floating seamen like<br><br>themselves.  So that did you carry them the news that another flood<br><br>had come; they would only answer--"Well, boys, here's the ark!"<br><br><br><br>Now, as many Sperm Whales had been captured off the western coast of<br><br>Java, in the near vicinity of the Straits of Sunda; indeed, as most<br><br>of the ground, roundabout, was generally recognised by the fishermen<br><br>as an excellent spot for cruising; therefore, as the Pequod gained<br><br>more and more upon Java Head, the look-outs were repeatedly hailed,<br><br>and admonished to keep wide awake.  But though the green palmy cliffs<br><br>of the land soon loomed on the starboard bow, and with delighted<br><br>nostrils the fresh cinnamon was snuffed in the air, yet not a single<br><br>jet was descried.  Almost renouncing all thought of falling in with<br><br>any game hereabouts, the ship had well nigh entered the straits, when<br><br>the customary cheering cry was heard from aloft, and ere long a<br><br>spectacle of singular magnificence saluted us.<br><br><br><br>But here be it premised, that owing to the unwearied activity with<br><br>which of late they have been hunted over all four oceans, the Sperm<br><br>Whales, instead of almost invariably sailing in small detached<br><br>companies, as in former times, are now frequently met with in<br><br>extensive herds, sometimes embracing so great a multitude, that it<br><br>would almost seem as if numerous nations of them had sworn solemn<br><br>league and covenant for mutual assistance and protection.  To this<br><br>aggregation of the Sperm Whale into such immense caravans, may be<br><br>imputed the circumstance that even in the best cruising grounds, you<br><br>may now sometimes sail for weeks and months together, without being<br><br>greeted by a single spout; and then be suddenly saluted by what<br><br>sometimes seems thousands on thousands.<br><br><br><br>Broad on both bows, at the distance of some two or three miles, and<br><br>forming a great semicircle, embracing one half of the level horizon,<br><br>a continuous chain of whale-jets were up-playing and sparkling in the<br><br>noon-day air.
