Unlike the straight perpendicular twin-jets of the<br><br>Right Whale, which, dividing at top, fall over in two branches, like<br><br>the cleft drooping boughs of a willow, the single forward-slanting<br><br>spout of the Sperm Whale presents a thick curled bush of white mist,<br><br>continually rising and falling away to leeward.<br><br><br><br>Seen from the Pequod's deck, then, as she would rise on a high hill<br><br>of the sea, this host of vapoury spouts, individually curling up into<br><br>the air, and beheld through a blending atmosphere of bluish haze,<br><br>showed like the thousand cheerful chimneys of some dense metropolis,<br><br>descried of a balmy autumnal morning, by some horseman on a height.<br><br><br><br>As marching armies approaching an unfriendly defile in the mountains,<br><br>accelerate their march, all eagerness to place that perilous passage<br><br>in their rear, and once more expand in comparative security upon the<br><br>plain; even so did this vast fleet of whales now seem hurrying<br><br>forward through the straits; gradually contracting the wings of their<br><br>semicircle, and swimming on, in one solid, but still crescentic<br><br>centre.<br><br><br><br>Crowding all sail the Pequod pressed after them; the harpooneers<br><br>handling their weapons, and loudly cheering from the heads of their<br><br>yet suspended boats.  If the wind only held, little doubt had they,<br><br>that chased through these Straits of Sunda, the vast host would only<br><br>deploy into the Oriental seas to witness the capture of not a few of<br><br>their number.  And who could tell whether, in that congregated<br><br>caravan, Moby Dick himself might not temporarily be swimming, like<br><br>the worshipped white-elephant in the coronation procession of the<br><br>Siamese!  So with stun-sail piled on stun-sail, we sailed along,<br><br>driving these leviathans before us; when, of a sudden, the voice of<br><br>Tashtego was heard, loudly directing attention to something in our<br><br>wake.<br><br><br><br>Corresponding to the crescent in our van, we beheld another in our<br><br>rear.  It seemed formed of detached white vapours, rising and falling<br><br>something like the spouts of the whales; only they did not so<br><br>completely come and go; for they constantly hovered, without finally<br><br>disappearing.  Levelling his glass at this sight, Ahab quickly<br><br>revolved in his pivot-hole, crying, "Aloft there, and rig whips and<br><br>buckets to wet the sails;--Malays, sir, and after us!"<br><br><br><br>As if too long lurking behind the headlands, till the Pequod should<br><br>fairly have entered the straits, these rascally Asiatics were now in<br><br>hot pursuit, to make up for their over-cautious delay.  But when the<br><br>swift Pequod, with a fresh leading wind, was herself in hot chase;<br><br>how very kind of these tawny philanthropists to assist in speeding<br><br>her on to her own chosen pursuit,--mere riding-whips and rowels to<br><br>her, that they were.  As with glass under arm, Ahab to-and-fro paced<br><br>the deck; in his forward turn beholding the monsters he chased, and<br><br>in the after one the bloodthirsty pirates chasing him; some such<br><br>fancy as the above seemed his.  And when he glanced upon the green<br><br>walls of the watery defile in which the ship was then sailing, and<br><br>bethought him that through that gate lay the route to his vengeance,<br><br>and beheld, how that through that same gate he was now both chasing<br><br>and being chased to his deadly end; and not only that, but a herd of<br><br>remorseless wild pirates and inhuman atheistical devils were<br><br>infernally cheering him on with their curses;--when all these<br><br>conceits had passed through his brain, Ahab's brow was left gaunt and<br><br>ribbed, like the black sand beach after some stormy tide has been<br><br>gnawing it, without being able to drag the firm thing from its place.<br><br><br><br>But thoughts like these troubled very few of the reckless crew; and<br><br>when, after steadily dropping and dropping the pirates astern, the<br><br>Pequod at last shot by the vivid green Cockatoo Point on the Sumatra<br><br>side, emerging at last upon the broad waters beyond; then, the<br><br>harpooneers seemed more to grieve that the swift whales had been<br><br>gaining upon the ship, than to rejoice that the ship had so<br><br>victoriously gained upon the Malays.  But still driving on in the<br><br>wake of the whales, at length they seemed abating their speed;<br><br>gradually the ship neared them; and the wind now dying away, word was<br><br>passed to spring to the boats.  But no sooner did the herd, by some<br><br>presumed wonderful instinct of the Sperm Whale, become notified of<br><br>the three keels that were after them,--though as yet a mile in their<br><br>rear,--than they rallied again, and forming in close ranks and<br><br>battalions, so that their spouts all looked like flashing lines of<br><br>stacked bayonets, moved on with redoubled velocity.<br><br><br><br>Stripped to our shirts and drawers, we sprang to the white-ash, and<br><br>after several hours' pulling were almost disposed to renounce the<br><br>chase, when a general pausing commotion among the whales gave<br><br>animating token that they were now at last under the influence of<br><br>that strange perplexity of inert irresolution, which, when the<br><br>fishermen perceive it in the whale, they say he is gallied.  The<br><br>compact martial columns in which they had been hitherto rapidly and<br><br>steadily swimming, were now broken up in one measureless rout; and<br><br>like King Porus' elephants in the Indian battle with Alexander, they<br><br>seemed going mad with consternation.  In all directions expanding in<br><br>vast irregular circles, and aimlessly swimming hither and thither, by<br><br>their short thick spoutings, they plainly betrayed their distraction<br><br>of panic.  This was still more strangely evinced by those of their<br><br>number, who, completely paralysed as it were, helplessly floated like<br><br>water-logged dismantled ships on the sea.  Had these Leviathans been<br><br>but a flock of simple sheep, pursued over the pasture by three fierce<br><br>wolves, they could not possibly have evinced such excessive dismay.<br><br>But this occasional timidity is characteristic of almost all herding<br><br>creatures.  Though banding together in tens of thousands, the<br><br>lion-maned buffaloes of the West have fled before a solitary<br><br>horseman.  Witness, too, all human beings, how when herded together<br><br>in the sheepfold of a theatre's pit, they will, at the slightest<br><br>alarm of fire, rush helter-skelter for the outlets, crowding,<br><br>trampling, jamming, and remorselessly dashing each other to death.<br><br>Best, therefore, withhold any amazement at the strangely gallied<br><br>whales before us, for there is no folly of the beasts of the earth<br><br>which is not infinitely outdone by the madness of men.<br><br><br><br>Though many of the whales, as has been said, were in violent motion,<br><br>yet it is to be observed that as a whole the herd neither advanced<br><br>nor retreated, but collectively remained in one place.  As is<br><br>customary in those cases, the boats at once separated, each making<br><br>for some one lone whale on the outskirts of the shoal.  In about<br><br>three minutes' time, Queequeg's harpoon was flung; the stricken fish<br><br>darted blinding spray in our faces, and then running away with us like<br><br>light, steered straight for the heart of the herd.  Though such a<br><br>movement on the part of the whale struck under such circumstances, is<br><br>in no wise unprecedented; and indeed is almost always more or less<br><br>anticipated; yet does it present one of the more perilous<br><br>vicissitudes of the fishery.  For as the swift monster drags you<br><br>deeper and deeper into the frantic shoal, you bid adieu to<br><br>circumspect life and only exist in a delirious throb.<br><br><br><br>As, blind and deaf, the whale plunged forward, as if by sheer power<br><br>of speed to rid himself of the iron leech that had fastened to him;<br><br>as we thus tore a white gash in the sea, on all sides menaced as we<br><br>flew, by the crazed creatures to and fro rushing about us; our beset<br><br>boat was like a ship mobbed by ice-isles in a tempest, and striving<br><br>to steer through their complicated channels and straits, knowing not at<br><br>what moment it may be locked in and crushed.<br><br><br><br>But not a bit daunted, Queequeg steered us manfully; now sheering off<br><br>from this monster directly across our route in advance; now edging<br><br>away from that, whose colossal flukes were suspended overhead, while<br><br>all the time, Starbuck stood up in the bows, lance in hand, pricking<br><br>out of our way whatever whales he could reach by short darts, for<br><br>there was no time to make long ones.  Nor were the oarsmen quite<br><br>idle, though their wonted duty was now altogether dispensed with.<br><br>They chiefly attended to the shouting part of the business.  "Out of<br><br>the way, Commodore!" cried one, to a great dromedary that of a sudden<br><br>rose bodily to the surface, and for an instant threatened to swamp<br><br>us.  "Hard down with your tail, there!" cried a second to another,<br><br>which, close to our gunwale, seemed calmly cooling himself with his<br><br>own fan-like extremity.<br><br><br><br>All whaleboats carry certain curious contrivances, originally<br><br>invented by the Nantucket Indians, called druggs.  Two thick squares<br><br>of wood of equal size are stoutly clenched together, so that they<br><br>cross each other's grain at right angles; a line of considerable<br><br>length is then attached to the middle of this block, and the other<br><br>end of the line being looped, it can in a moment be fastened to a<br><br>harpoon.  It is chiefly among gallied whales that this drugg is used.<br><br>For then, more whales are close round you than you can possibly<br><br>chase at one time.  But sperm whales are not every day encountered;<br><br>while you may, then, you must kill all you can.  And if you cannot<br><br>kill them all at once, you must wing them, so that they can be<br><br>afterwards killed at your leisure.  Hence it is, that at times like<br><br>these the drugg, comes into requisition.  Our boat was furnished with<br><br>three of them.  The first and second were successfully darted, and we<br><br>saw the whales staggeringly running off, fettered by the enormous<br><br>sidelong resistance of the towing drugg.  They were cramped like<br><br>malefactors with the chain and ball.  But upon flinging the third, in<br><br>the act of tossing overboard the clumsy wooden block, it caught under<br><br>one of the seats of the boat, and in an instant tore it out and<br><br>carried it away, dropping the oarsman in the boat's bottom as the<br><br>seat slid from under him.  On both sides the sea came in at the<br><br>wounded planks, but we stuffed two or three drawers and shirts in,<br><br>and so stopped the leaks for the time.<br><br><br><br>It had been next to impossible to dart these drugged-harpoons, were<br><br>it not that as we advanced into the herd, our whale's way greatly<br><br>diminished; moreover, that as we went still further and further from<br><br>the circumference of commotion, the direful disorders seemed waning.<br><br>So that when at last the jerking harpoon drew out, and the towing<br><br>whale sideways vanished; then, with the tapering force of his parting<br><br>momentum, we glided between two whales into the innermost heart of<br><br>the shoal, as if from some mountain torrent we had slid into a serene<br><br>valley lake.  Here the storms in the roaring glens between the<br><br>outermost whales, were heard but not felt.  In this central expanse<br><br>the sea presented that smooth satin-like surface, called a sleek,<br><br>produced by the subtle moisture thrown off by the whale in his more<br><br>quiet moods.  Yes, we were now in that enchanted calm which they say<br><br>lurks at the heart of every commotion.  And still in the distracted<br><br>distance we beheld the tumults of the outer concentric circles, and<br><br>saw successive pods of whales, eight or ten in each, swiftly going<br><br>round and round, like multiplied spans of horses in a ring; and so<br><br>closely shoulder to shoulder, that a Titanic circus-rider might<br><br>easily have over-arched the middle ones, and so have gone round on<br><br>their backs.  Owing to the density of the crowd of reposing whales,<br><br>more immediately surrounding the embayed axis of the herd, no<br><br>possible chance of escape was at present afforded us.  We must watch<br><br>for a breach in the living wall that hemmed us in; the wall that had<br><br>only admitted us in order to shut us up.  Keeping at the centre of<br><br>the lake, we were occasionally visited by small tame cows and calves;<br><br>the women and children of this routed host.<br><br><br><br>Now, inclusive of the occasional wide intervals between the revolving<br><br>outer circles, and inclusive of the spaces between the various pods<br><br>in any one of those circles, the entire area at this juncture,<br><br>embraced by the whole multitude, must have contained at least two or<br><br>three square miles.  At any rate--though indeed such a test at such a<br><br>time might be deceptive--spoutings might be discovered from our low<br><br>boat that seemed playing up almost from the rim of the horizon.  I<br><br>mention this circumstance, because, as if the cows and calves had<br><br>been purposely locked up in this innermost fold; and as if the wide<br><br>extent of the herd had hitherto prevented them from learning the<br><br>precise cause of its stopping; or, possibly, being so young,<br><br>unsophisticated, and every way innocent and inexperienced; however it<br><br>may have been, these smaller whales--now and then visiting our<br><br>becalmed boat from the margin of the lake--evinced a wondrous<br><br>fearlessness and confidence, or else a still becharmed panic which it<br><br>was impossible not to marvel at.  Like household dogs they came<br><br>snuffling round us, right up to our gunwales, and touching them; till<br><br>it almost seemed that some spell had suddenly domesticated them.<br><br>Queequeg patted their foreheads; Starbuck scratched their backs with<br><br>his lance; but fearful of the consequences, for the time refrained<br><br>from darting it.<br><br><br><br>But far beneath this wondrous world upon the surface, another and<br><br>still stranger world met our eyes as we gazed over the side.  For,<br><br>suspended in those watery vaults, floated the forms of the nursing<br><br>mothers of the whales, and those that by their enormous girth seemed<br><br>shortly to become mothers.  The lake, as I have hinted, was to a<br><br>considerable depth exceedingly transparent; and as human infants<br><br>while suckling will calmly and fixedly gaze away from the breast, as<br><br>if leading two different lives at the time; and while yet drawing<br><br>mortal nourishment, be still spiritually feasting upon some unearthly<br><br>reminiscence;--even so did the young of these whales seem looking up<br><br>towards us, but not at us, as if we were but a bit of Gulfweed in<br><br>their new-born sight.  Floating on their sides, the mothers also<br><br>seemed quietly eyeing us.  One of these little infants, that from<br><br>certain queer tokens seemed hardly a day old, might have measured<br><br>some fourteen feet in length, and some six feet in girth.  He was a<br><br>little frisky; though as yet his body seemed scarce yet recovered<br><br>from that irksome position it had so lately occupied in the maternal<br><br>reticule; where, tail to head, and all ready for the final spring,<br><br>the unborn whale lies bent like a Tartar's bow.  The delicate<br><br>side-fins, and the palms of his flukes, still freshly retained the<br><br>plaited crumpled appearance of a baby's ears newly arrived from<br><br>foreign parts.<br><br><br><br>"Line! line!" cried Queequeg, looking over the gunwale; "him fast!<br><br>him fast!--Who line him!  Who struck?--Two whale; one big, one<br><br>little!"<br><br><br><br>"What ails ye, man?" cried Starbuck.<br><br><br><br>"Look-e here," said Queequeg, pointing down.<br><br><br><br>As when the stricken whale, that from the tub has reeled out hundreds<br><br>of fathoms of rope; as, after deep sounding, he floats up again, and<br><br>shows the slackened curling line buoyantly rising and spiralling<br><br>towards the air; so now, Starbuck saw long coils of the umbilical<br><br>cord of Madame Leviathan, by which the young cub seemed still<br><br>tethered to its dam.  Not seldom in the rapid vicissitudes of the<br><br>chase, this natural line, with the maternal end loose, becomes<br><br>entangled with the hempen one, so that the cub is thereby trapped.<br><br>Some of the subtlest secrets of the seas seemed divulged to us in<br><br>this enchanted pond.  We saw young Leviathan amours in the deep.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*The sperm whale, as with all other species of the Leviathan, but<br><br>unlike most other fish, breeds indifferently at all seasons; after a<br><br>gestation which may probably be set down at nine months, producing<br><br>but one at a time; though in some few known instances giving birth to<br><br>an Esau and Jacob:--a contingency provided for in suckling by two<br><br>teats, curiously situated, one on each side of the anus; but the<br><br>breasts themselves extend upwards from that.  When by chance these<br><br>precious parts in a nursing whale are cut by the hunter's lance, the<br><br>mother's pouring milk and blood rivallingly discolour the sea for<br><br>rods.  The milk is very sweet and rich; it has been tasted by man; it<br><br>might do well with strawberries.  When overflowing with mutual<br><br>esteem, the whales salute MORE HOMINUM.<br><br><br><br><br><br>And thus, though surrounded by circle upon circle of consternations<br><br>and affrights, did these inscrutable creatures at the centre freely<br><br>and fearlessly indulge in all peaceful concernments; yea, serenely<br><br>revelled in dalliance and delight.  But even so, amid the tornadoed<br><br>Atlantic of my being, do I myself still for ever centrally disport in<br><br>mute calm; and while ponderous planets of unwaning woe revolve round<br><br>me, deep down and deep inland there I still bathe me in eternal<br><br>mildness of joy.<br><br><br><br>Meanwhile, as we thus lay entranced, the occasional sudden frantic<br><br>spectacles in the distance evinced the activity of the other boats,<br><br>still engaged in drugging the whales on the frontier of the host; or<br><br>possibly carrying on the war within the first circle, where abundance<br><br>of room and some convenient retreats were afforded them.  But the<br><br>sight of the enraged drugged whales now and then blindly darting to<br><br>and fro across the circles, was nothing to what at last met our eyes.<br><br>It is sometimes the custom when fast to a whale more than commonly<br><br>powerful and alert, to seek to hamstring him, as it were, by<br><br>sundering or maiming his gigantic tail-tendon.  It is done by darting<br><br>a short-handled cutting-spade, to which is attached a rope for<br><br>hauling it back again.  A whale wounded (as we afterwards learned) in<br><br>this part, but not effectually, as it seemed, had broken away from<br><br>the boat, carrying along with him half of the harpoon line; and in<br><br>the extraordinary agony of the wound, he was now dashing among the<br><br>revolving circles like the lone mounted desperado Arnold, at the<br><br>battle of Saratoga, carrying dismay wherever he went.<br><br><br><br>But agonizing as was the wound of this whale, and an appalling<br><br>spectacle enough, any way; yet the peculiar horror with which he<br><br>seemed to inspire the rest of the herd, was owing to a cause which at<br><br>first the intervening distance obscured from us.  But at length we<br><br>perceived that by one of the unimaginable accidents of the fishery,<br><br>this whale had become entangled in the harpoon-line that he towed; he<br><br>had also run away with the cutting-spade in him; and while the free<br><br>end of the rope attached to that weapon, had permanently caught in<br><br>the coils of the harpoon-line round his tail, the cutting-spade<br><br>itself had worked loose from his flesh.  So that tormented to<br><br>madness, he was now churning through the water, violently flailing<br><br>with his flexible tail, and tossing the keen spade about him,<br><br>wounding and murdering his own comrades.<br><br><br><br>This terrific object seemed to recall the whole herd from their<br><br>stationary fright.  First, the whales forming the margin of our lake<br><br>began to crowd a little, and tumble against each other, as if lifted<br><br>by half spent billows from afar; then the lake itself began faintly<br><br>to heave and swell; the submarine bridal-chambers and nurseries<br><br>vanished; in more and more contracting orbits the whales in the more<br><br>central circles began to swim in thickening clusters.  Yes, the long<br><br>calm was departing.  A low advancing hum was soon heard; and then<br><br>like to the tumultuous masses of block-ice when the great river<br><br>Hudson breaks up in Spring, the entire host of whales came tumbling<br><br>upon their inner centre, as if to pile themselves up in one common<br><br>mountain.  Instantly Starbuck and Queequeg changed places; Starbuck<br><br>taking the stern.<br><br><br><br>"Oars!  Oars!" he intensely whispered, seizing the helm--"gripe your<br><br>oars, and clutch your souls, now!  My God, men, stand by!  Shove him<br><br>off, you Queequeg--the whale there!--prick him!--hit him!  Stand<br><br>up--stand up, and stay so!  Spring, men--pull, men; never mind their<br><br>backs--scrape them!--scrape away!"<br><br><br><br>The boat was now all but jammed between two vast black bulks, leaving<br><br>a narrow Dardanelles between their long lengths.  But by desperate<br><br>endeavor we at last shot into a temporary opening; then giving way<br><br>rapidly, and at the same time earnestly watching for another outlet.<br><br>After many similar hair-breadth escapes, we at last swiftly glided<br><br>into what had just been one of the outer circles, but now crossed by<br><br>random whales, all violently making for one centre.  This lucky<br><br>salvation was cheaply purchased by the loss of Queequeg's hat, who,<br><br>while standing in the bows to prick the fugitive whales, had his hat<br><br>taken clean from his head by the air-eddy made by the sudden tossing<br><br>of a pair of broad flukes close by.<br><br><br><br>Riotous and disordered as the universal commotion now was, it soon<br><br>resolved itself into what seemed a systematic movement; for having<br><br>clumped together at last in one dense body, they then renewed their<br><br>onward flight with augmented fleetness.  Further pursuit was useless;<br><br>but the boats still lingered in their wake to pick up what drugged<br><br>whales might be dropped astern, and likewise to secure one which<br><br>Flask had killed and waifed.  The waif is a pennoned pole, two or<br><br>three of which are carried by every boat; and which, when additional<br><br>game is at hand, are inserted upright into the floating body of a<br><br>dead whale, both to mark its place on the sea, and also as token of<br><br>prior possession, should the boats of any other ship draw near.<br><br><br><br>The result of this lowering was somewhat illustrative of that<br><br>sagacious saying in the Fishery,--the more whales the less fish.  Of<br><br>all the drugged whales only one was captured.  The rest contrived to<br><br>escape for the time, but only to be taken, as will hereafter be seen,<br><br>by some other craft than the Pequod.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 88<br><br><br><br>Schools and Schoolmasters.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The previous chapter gave account of an immense body or herd of Sperm<br><br>Whales, and there was also then given the probable cause inducing<br><br>those vast aggregations.<br><br><br><br>Now, though such great bodies are at times encountered, yet, as must<br><br>have been seen, even at the present day, small detached bands are<br><br>occasionally observed, embracing from twenty to fifty individuals<br><br>each.  Such bands are known as schools.  They generally are of two<br><br>sorts; those composed almost entirely of females, and those mustering<br><br>none but young vigorous males, or bulls, as they are familiarly<br><br>designated.<br><br><br><br>In cavalier attendance upon the school of females, you invariably see<br><br>a male of full grown magnitude, but not old; who, upon any alarm,<br><br>evinces his gallantry by falling in the rear and covering the flight<br><br>of his ladies.  In truth, this gentleman is a luxurious Ottoman,<br><br>swimming about over the watery world, surroundingly accompanied by<br><br>all the solaces and endearments of the harem.  The contrast between<br><br>this Ottoman and his concubines is striking; because, while he is<br><br>always of the largest leviathanic proportions, the ladies, even at<br><br>full growth, are not more than one-third of the bulk of an<br><br>average-sized male.  They are comparatively delicate, indeed; I dare<br><br>say, not to exceed half a dozen yards round the waist.  Nevertheless,<br><br>it cannot be denied, that upon the whole they are hereditarily<br><br>entitled to EMBONPOINT.<br><br><br><br>It is very curious to watch this harem and its lord in their indolent<br><br>ramblings.  Like fashionables, they are for ever on the move in<br><br>leisurely search of variety.  You meet them on the Line in time for<br><br>the full flower of the Equatorial feeding season, having just<br><br>returned, perhaps, from spending the summer in the Northern seas, and<br><br>so cheating summer of all unpleasant weariness and warmth.  By the<br><br>time they have lounged up and down the promenade of the Equator<br><br>awhile, they start for the Oriental waters in anticipation of the<br><br>cool season there, and so evade the other excessive temperature of<br><br>the year.<br><br><br><br>When serenely advancing on one of these journeys, if any strange<br><br>suspicious sights are seen, my lord whale keeps a wary eye on his<br><br>interesting family.  Should any unwarrantably pert young Leviathan<br><br>coming that way, presume to draw confidentially close to one of the<br><br>ladies, with what prodigious fury the Bashaw assails him, and chases<br><br>him away!  High times, indeed, if unprincipled young rakes like him<br><br>are to be permitted to invade the sanctity of domestic bliss; though<br><br>do what the Bashaw will, he cannot keep the most notorious Lothario<br><br>out of his bed; for, alas! all fish bed in common.  As ashore, the<br><br>ladies often cause the most terrible duels among their rival<br><br>admirers; just so with the whales, who sometimes come to deadly<br><br>battle, and all for love.  They fence with their long lower jaws,<br><br>sometimes locking them together, and so striving for the supremacy<br><br>like elks that warringly interweave their antlers.  Not a few are<br><br>captured having the deep scars of these encounters,--furrowed heads,<br><br>broken teeth, scolloped fins; and in some instances, wrenched and<br><br>dislocated mouths.<br><br><br><br>But supposing the invader of domestic bliss to betake himself away at<br><br>the first rush of the harem's lord, then is it very diverting to<br><br>watch that lord.  Gently he insinuates his vast bulk among them again<br><br>and revels there awhile, still in tantalizing vicinity to young<br><br>Lothario, like pious Solomon devoutly worshipping among his thousand<br><br>concubines.  Granting other whales to be in sight, the fishermen<br><br>will seldom give chase to one of these Grand Turks; for these Grand<br><br>Turks are too lavish of their strength, and hence their unctuousness<br><br>is small.  As for the sons and the daughters they beget, why, those sons<br><br>and daughters must take care of themselves; at least, with only the<br><br>maternal help.  For like certain other omnivorous roving lovers that<br><br>might be named, my Lord Whale has no taste for the nursery, however<br><br>much for the bower; and so, being a great traveller, he leaves his<br><br>anonymous babies all over the world; every baby an exotic.  In good<br><br>time, nevertheless, as the ardour of youth declines; as years and<br><br>dumps increase; as reflection lends her solemn pauses; in short, as a<br><br>general lassitude overtakes the sated Turk; then a love of ease and<br><br>virtue supplants the love for maidens; our Ottoman enters upon the<br><br>impotent, repentant, admonitory stage of life, forswears, disbands<br><br>the harem, and grown to an exemplary, sulky old soul, goes about all<br><br>alone among the meridians and parallels saying his prayers, and<br><br>warning each young Leviathan from his amorous errors.<br><br><br><br>Now, as the harem of whales is called by the fishermen a school, so<br><br>is the lord and master of that school technically known as the<br><br>schoolmaster.  It is therefore not in strict character, however<br><br>admirably satirical, that after going to school himself, he should<br><br>then go abroad inculcating not what he learned there, but the folly<br><br>of it.  His title, schoolmaster, would very naturally seem derived<br><br>from the name bestowed upon the harem itself, but some have surmised<br><br>that the man who first thus entitled this sort of Ottoman whale, must<br><br>have read the memoirs of Vidocq, and informed himself what sort of a<br><br>country-schoolmaster that famous Frenchman was in his younger days,<br><br>and what was the nature of those occult lessons he inculcated into<br><br>some of his pupils.<br><br><br><br>The same secludedness and isolation to which the schoolmaster whale<br><br>betakes himself in his advancing years, is true of all aged Sperm<br><br>Whales.  Almost universally, a lone whale--as a solitary Leviathan is<br><br>called--proves an ancient one.  Like venerable moss-bearded Daniel<br><br>Boone, he will have no one near him but Nature herself; and her he<br><br>takes to wife in the wilderness of waters, and the best of wives she<br><br>is, though she keeps so many moody secrets.<br><br><br><br>The schools composing none but young and vigorous males, previously<br><br>mentioned, offer a strong contrast to the harem schools.  For while<br><br>those female whales are characteristically timid, the young males, or<br><br>forty-barrel-bulls, as they call them, are by far the most pugnacious<br><br>of all Leviathans, and proverbially the most dangerous to encounter;<br><br>excepting those wondrous grey-headed, grizzled whales, sometimes met,<br><br>and these will fight you like grim fiends exasperated by a penal<br><br>gout.<br><br><br><br>The Forty-barrel-bull schools are larger than the harem schools.<br><br>Like a mob of young collegians, they are full of fight, fun, and<br><br>wickedness, tumbling round the world at such a reckless, rollicking<br><br>rate, that no prudent underwriter would insure them any more than he<br><br>would a riotous lad at Yale or Harvard.  They soon relinquish this<br><br>turbulence though, and when about three-fourths grown, break up, and<br><br>separately go about in quest of settlements, that is, harems.<br><br><br><br>Another point of difference between the male and female schools is<br><br>still more characteristic of the sexes.  Say you strike a<br><br>Forty-barrel-bull--poor devil! all his comrades quit him.  But strike<br><br>a member of the harem school, and her companions swim around her with<br><br>every token of concern, sometimes lingering so near her and so long,<br><br>as themselves to fall a prey.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 89<br><br><br><br>Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The allusion to the waif and waif-poles in the last chapter but one,<br><br>necessitates some account of the laws and regulations of the whale<br><br>fishery, of which the waif may be deemed the grand symbol and badge.<br><br><br><br>It frequently happens that when several ships are cruising in<br><br>company, a whale may be struck by one vessel, then escape, and be<br><br>finally killed and captured by another vessel; and herein are<br><br>indirectly comprised many minor contingencies, all partaking of this<br><br>one grand feature.  For example,--after a weary and perilous chase<br><br>and capture of a whale, the body may get loose from the ship by<br><br>reason of a violent storm; and drifting far away to leeward, be<br><br>retaken by a second whaler, who, in a calm, snugly tows it alongside,<br><br>without risk of life or line.  Thus the most vexatious and violent<br><br>disputes would often arise between the fishermen, were there not some<br><br>written or unwritten, universal, undisputed law applicable to all<br><br>cases.<br><br><br><br>Perhaps the only formal whaling code authorized by legislative<br><br>enactment, was that of Holland.  It was decreed by the States-General<br><br>in A.D. 1695.  But though no other nation has ever had any written<br><br>whaling law, yet the American fishermen have been their own<br><br>legislators and lawyers in this matter.  They have provided a system<br><br>which for terse comprehensiveness surpasses Justinian's Pandects and<br><br>the By-laws of the Chinese Society for the Suppression of Meddling<br><br>with other People's Business.  Yes; these laws might be engraven on a<br><br>Queen Anne's forthing, or the barb of a harpoon, and worn round the<br><br>neck, so small are they.<br><br><br><br>I.  A Fast-Fish belongs to the party fast to it.<br><br><br><br>II.  A Loose-Fish is fair game for anybody who can soonest catch it.<br><br><br><br>But what plays the mischief with this masterly code is the admirable<br><br>brevity of it, which necessitates a vast volume of commentaries to<br><br>expound it.<br><br><br><br>First: What is a Fast-Fish?  Alive or dead a fish is technically<br><br>fast, when it is connected with an occupied ship or boat, by any<br><br>medium at all controllable by the occupant or occupants,--a mast, an<br><br>oar, a nine-inch cable, a telegraph wire, or a strand of cobweb, it<br><br>is all the same.  Likewise a fish is technically fast when it bears a<br><br>waif, or any other recognised symbol of possession; so long as the<br><br>party waifing it plainly evince their ability at any time to take it<br><br>alongside, as well as their intention so to do.<br><br><br><br>These are scientific commentaries; but the commentaries of the<br><br>whalemen themselves sometimes consist in hard words and harder<br><br>knocks--the Coke-upon-Littleton of the fist.  True, among the more<br><br>upright and honourable whalemen allowances are always made for<br><br>peculiar cases, where it would be an outrageous moral injustice for<br><br>one party to claim possession of a whale previously chased or killed<br><br>by another party.  But others are by no means so scrupulous.<br><br><br><br>Some fifty years ago there was a curious case of whale-trover<br><br>litigated in England, wherein the plaintiffs set forth that after a<br><br>hard chase of a whale in the Northern seas; and when indeed they (the<br><br>plaintiffs) had succeeded in harpooning the fish; they were at last,<br><br>through peril of their lives, obliged to forsake not only their<br><br>lines, but their boat itself.  Ultimately the defendants (the crew of<br><br>another ship) came up with the whale, struck, killed, seized, and<br><br>finally appropriated it before the very eyes of the plaintiffs.  And<br><br>when those defendants were remonstrated with, their captain snapped<br><br>his fingers in the plaintiffs' teeth, and assured them that by way of<br><br>doxology to the deed he had done, he would now retain their line,<br><br>harpoons, and boat, which had remained attached to the whale at the<br><br>time of the seizure.  Wherefore the plaintiffs now sued for the<br><br>recovery of the value of their whale, line, harpoons, and boat.<br><br><br><br>Mr. Erskine was counsel for the defendants; Lord Ellenborough was the<br><br>judge.  In the course of the defence, the witty Erskine went on to<br><br>illustrate his position, by alluding to a recent crim. con. case,<br><br>wherein a gentleman, after in vain trying to bridle his wife's<br><br>viciousness, had at last abandoned her upon the seas of life; but in<br><br>the course of years, repenting of that step, he instituted an action<br><br>to recover possession of her.  Erskine was on the other side; and he<br><br>then supported it by saying, that though the gentleman had originally<br><br>harpooned the lady, and had once had her fast, and only by reason of<br><br>the great stress of her plunging viciousness, had at last abandoned<br><br>her; yet abandon her he did, so that she became a loose-fish; and<br><br>therefore when a subsequent gentleman re-harpooned her, the lady then<br><br>became that subsequent gentleman's property, along with whatever<br><br>harpoon might have been found sticking in her.<br><br><br><br>Now in the present case Erskine contended that the examples of the<br><br>whale and the lady were reciprocally illustrative of each other.<br><br><br><br>These pleadings, and the counter pleadings, being duly heard, the<br><br>very learned Judge in set terms decided, to wit,--That as for the<br><br>boat, he awarded it to the plaintiffs, because they had merely<br><br>abandoned it to save their lives; but that with regard to the<br><br>controverted whale, harpoons, and line, they belonged to the<br><br>defendants; the whale, because it was a Loose-Fish at the time of the<br><br>final capture; and the harpoons and line because when the fish made<br><br>off with them, it (the fish) acquired a property in those articles;<br><br>and hence anybody who afterwards took the fish had a right to them.<br><br>Now the defendants afterwards took the fish; ergo, the aforesaid<br><br>articles were theirs.<br><br><br><br>A common man looking at this decision of the very learned Judge,<br><br>might possibly object to it.  But ploughed up to the primary rock of<br><br>the matter, the two great principles laid down in the twin whaling<br><br>laws previously quoted, and applied and elucidated by Lord<br><br>Ellenborough in the above cited case; these two laws touching<br><br>Fast-Fish and Loose-Fish, I say, will, on reflection, be found the<br><br>fundamentals of all human jurisprudence; for notwithstanding its<br><br>complicated tracery of sculpture, the Temple of the Law, like the<br><br>Temple of the Philistines, has but two props to stand on.<br><br><br><br>Is it not a saying in every one's mouth, Possession is half of the<br><br>law: that is, regardless of how the thing came into possession?  But<br><br>often possession is the whole of the law.  What are the sinews and<br><br>souls of Russian serfs and Republican slaves but Fast-Fish, whereof<br><br>possession is the whole of the law?  What to the rapacious landlord<br><br>is the widow's last mite but a Fast-Fish?  What is yonder undetected<br><br>villain's marble mansion with a door-plate for a waif; what is that<br><br>but a Fast-Fish?  What is the ruinous discount which Mordecai, the<br><br>broker, gets from poor Woebegone, the bankrupt, on a loan to<br><br>keep Woebegone's family from starvation; what is that ruinous<br><br>discount but a Fast-Fish?  What is the Archbishop of Savesoul's<br><br>income of L100,000 seized from the scant bread and cheese of<br><br>hundreds of thousands of broken-backed laborers (all sure of heaven<br><br>without any of Savesoul's help) what is that globular L100,000 but a<br><br>Fast-Fish?  What are the Duke of Dunder's hereditary towns and<br><br>hamlets but Fast-Fish?  What to that redoubted harpooneer, John Bull,<br><br>is poor Ireland, but a Fast-Fish?  What to that apostolic lancer,<br><br>Brother Jonathan, is Texas but a Fast-Fish?  And concerning all<br><br>these, is not Possession the whole of the law?<br><br><br><br>But if the doctrine of Fast-Fish be pretty generally applicable, the<br><br>kindred doctrine of Loose-Fish is still more widely so.  That is<br><br>internationally and universally applicable.<br><br><br><br>What was America in 1492 but a Loose-Fish, in which Columbus struck<br><br>the Spanish standard by way of waifing it for his royal master and<br><br>mistress?  What was Poland to the Czar?  What Greece to the Turk?<br><br>What India to England?  What at last will Mexico be to the United<br><br>States?  All Loose-Fish.<br><br><br><br>What are the Rights of Man and the Liberties of the World but<br><br>Loose-Fish?  What all men's minds and opinions but Loose-Fish?  What<br><br>is the principle of religious belief in them but a Loose-Fish?  What<br><br>to the ostentatious smuggling verbalists are the thoughts of thinkers<br><br>but Loose-Fish?  What is the great globe itself but a Loose-Fish?<br><br>And what are you, reader, but a Loose-Fish and a Fast-Fish, too?<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 90<br><br><br><br>Heads or Tails.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"De balena vero sufficit, si rex habeat caput, et regina caudam."<br><br>BRACTON, L. 3, C. 3.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Latin from the books of the Laws of England, which taken along with<br><br>the context, means, that of all whales captured by anybody on the<br><br>coast of that land, the King, as Honourary Grand Harpooneer, must have<br><br>the head, and the Queen be respectfully presented with the tail.  A<br><br>division which, in the whale, is much like halving an apple; there is<br><br>no intermediate remainder.  Now as this law, under a modified form,<br><br>is to this day in force in England; and as it offers in various<br><br>respects a strange anomaly touching the general law of Fast and<br><br>Loose-Fish, it is here treated of in a separate chapter, on the same<br><br>courteous principle that prompts the English railways to be at the<br><br>expense of a separate car, specially reserved for the accommodation<br><br>of royalty.  In the first place, in curious proof of the fact that<br><br>the above-mentioned law is still in force, I proceed to lay before<br><br>you a circumstance that happened within the last two years.<br><br><br><br>It seems that some honest mariners of Dover, or Sandwich, or some one<br><br>of the Cinque Ports, had after a hard chase succeeded in killing and<br><br>beaching a fine whale which they had originally descried afar off<br><br>from the shore.  Now the Cinque Ports are partially or somehow under<br><br>the jurisdiction of a sort of policeman or beadle, called a Lord<br><br>Warden.  Holding the office directly from the crown, I believe, all<br><br>the royal emoluments incident to the Cinque Port territories become<br><br>by assignment his.  By some writers this office is called a sinecure.<br><br>But not so.  Because the Lord Warden is busily employed at times in<br><br>fobbing his perquisites; which are his chiefly by virtue of that same<br><br>fobbing of them.<br><br><br><br>Now when these poor sun-burnt mariners, bare-footed, and with their<br><br>trowsers rolled high up on their eely legs, had wearily hauled their<br><br>fat fish high and dry, promising themselves a good L150 from the<br><br>precious oil and bone; and in fantasy sipping rare tea with their<br><br>wives, and good ale with their cronies, upon the strength of their<br><br>respective shares; up steps a very learned and most Christian and<br><br>charitable gentleman, with a copy of Blackstone under his arm; and<br><br>laying it upon the whale's head, he says--"Hands off! this fish, my<br><br>masters, is a Fast-Fish.  I seize it as the Lord Warden's."  Upon<br><br>this the poor mariners in their respectful consternation--so truly<br><br>English--knowing not what to say, fall to vigorously scratching their<br><br>heads all round; meanwhile ruefully glancing from the whale to the<br><br>stranger.  But that did in nowise mend the matter, or at all soften<br><br>the hard heart of the learned gentleman with the copy of Blackstone.<br><br>At length one of them, after long scratching about for his ideas,<br><br>made bold to speak,<br><br><br><br>"Please, sir, who is the Lord Warden?"<br><br><br><br>"The Duke."<br><br><br><br>"But the duke had nothing to do with taking this fish?"<br><br><br><br>"It is his."<br><br><br><br>"We have been at great trouble, and peril, and some expense, and is<br><br>all that to go to the Duke's benefit; we getting nothing at all for<br><br>our pains but our blisters?"<br><br><br><br>"It is his."<br><br><br><br>"Is the Duke so very poor as to be forced to this desperate mode of<br><br>getting a livelihood?"<br><br><br><br>"It is his."<br><br><br><br>"I thought to relieve my old bed-ridden mother by part of my share of<br><br>this whale."<br><br><br><br>"It is his."<br><br><br><br>"Won't the Duke be content with a quarter or a half?"<br><br><br><br>"It is his."<br><br><br><br>In a word, the whale was seized and sold, and his Grace the Duke of<br><br>Wellington received the money.  Thinking that viewed in some<br><br>particular lights, the case might by a bare possibility in some small<br><br>degree be deemed, under the circumstances, a rather hard one, an<br><br>honest clergyman of the town respectfully addressed a note to his<br><br>Grace, begging him to take the case of those unfortunate mariners<br><br>into full consideration.  To which my Lord Duke in substance replied<br><br>(both letters were published) that he had already done so, and<br><br>received the money, and would be obliged to the reverend gentleman if<br><br>for the future he (the reverend gentleman) would decline meddling<br><br>with other people's business.  Is this the still militant old man,<br><br>standing at the corners of the three kingdoms, on all hands coercing<br><br>alms of beggars?<br><br><br><br>It will readily be seen that in this case the alleged right of the<br><br>Duke to the whale was a delegated one from the Sovereign.  We must<br><br>needs inquire then on what principle the Sovereign is originally<br><br>invested with that right.  The law itself has already been set forth.<br><br>But Plowdon gives us the reason for it.  Says Plowdon, the whale so<br><br>caught belongs to the King and Queen, "because of its superior<br><br>excellence."  And by the soundest commentators this has ever been<br><br>held a cogent argument in such matters.<br><br><br><br>But why should the King have the head, and the Queen the tail?  A<br><br>reason for that, ye lawyers!<br><br><br><br>In his treatise on "Queen-Gold," or Queen-pinmoney, an old King's<br><br>Bench author, one William Prynne, thus discourseth: "Ye tail is ye<br><br>Queen's, that ye Queen's wardrobe may be supplied with ye whalebone."<br><br>Now this was written at a time when the black limber bone of the<br><br>Greenland or Right whale was largely used in ladies' bodices.  But<br><br>this same bone is not in the tail; it is in the head, which is a sad<br><br>mistake for a sagacious lawyer like Prynne.  But is the Queen a<br><br>mermaid, to be presented with a tail?  An allegorical meaning may<br><br>lurk here.<br><br><br><br>There are two royal fish so styled by the English law writers--the<br><br>whale and the sturgeon; both royal property under certain<br><br>limitations, and nominally supplying the tenth branch of the crown's<br><br>ordinary revenue.  I know not that any other author has hinted of the<br><br>matter; but by inference it seems to me that the sturgeon must be<br><br>divided in the same way as the whale, the King receiving the highly<br><br>dense and elastic head peculiar to that fish, which, symbolically<br><br>regarded, may possibly be humorously grounded upon some presumed<br><br>congeniality.  And thus there seems a reason in all things, even in<br><br>law.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 91<br><br><br><br>The Pequod Meets The Rose-Bud.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"In vain it was to rake for Ambergriese in the paunch of this<br><br>Leviathan, insufferable fetor denying not inquiry."<br><br>SIR T. BROWNE, V.E.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It was a week or two after the last whaling scene recounted, and when<br><br>we were slowly sailing over a sleepy, vapoury, mid-day sea, that the<br><br>many noses on the Pequod's deck proved more vigilant discoverers than<br><br>the three pairs of eyes aloft.  A peculiar and not very pleasant<br><br>smell was smelt in the sea.<br><br><br><br>"I will bet something now," said Stubb, "that somewhere hereabouts<br><br>are some of those drugged whales we tickled the other day.  I thought<br><br>they would keel up before long."<br><br><br><br>Presently, the vapours in advance slid aside; and there in the<br><br>distance lay a ship, whose furled sails betokened that some sort of<br><br>whale must be alongside.  As we glided nearer, the stranger showed<br><br>French colours from his peak; and by the eddying cloud of vulture<br><br>sea-fowl that circled, and hovered, and swooped around him, it was<br><br>plain that the whale alongside must be what the fishermen call a<br><br>blasted whale, that is, a whale that has died unmolested on the sea,<br><br>and so floated an unappropriated corpse.  It may well be conceived,<br><br>what an unsavory odor such a mass must exhale; worse than an Assyrian<br><br>city in the plague, when the living are incompetent to bury the<br><br>departed.  So intolerable indeed is it regarded by some, that no<br><br>cupidity could persuade them to moor alongside of it.  Yet are there<br><br>those who will still do it; notwithstanding the fact that the oil<br><br>obtained from such subjects is of a very inferior quality, and by no<br><br>means of the nature of attar-of-rose.<br><br><br><br>Coming still nearer with the expiring breeze, we saw that the<br><br>Frenchman had a second whale alongside; and this second whale seemed<br><br>even more of a nosegay than the first.  In truth, it turned out to be<br><br>one of those problematical whales that seem to dry up and die with a<br><br>sort of prodigious dyspepsia, or indigestion; leaving their defunct<br><br>bodies almost entirely bankrupt of anything like oil.  Nevertheless,<br><br>in the proper place we shall see that no knowing fisherman will ever<br><br>turn up his nose at such a whale as this, however much he may shun<br><br>blasted whales in general.<br><br><br><br>The Pequod had now swept so nigh to the stranger, that Stubb vowed he<br><br>recognised his cutting spade-pole entangled in the lines that were<br><br>knotted round the tail of one of these whales.<br><br><br><br>"There's a pretty fellow, now," he banteringly laughed, standing in<br><br>the ship's bows, "there's a jackal for ye!  I well know that these<br><br>Crappoes of Frenchmen are but poor devils in the fishery; sometimes<br><br>lowering their boats for breakers, mistaking them for Sperm Whale<br><br>spouts; yes, and sometimes sailing from their port with their hold<br><br>full of boxes of tallow candles, and cases of snuffers, foreseeing<br><br>that all the oil they will get won't be enough to dip the Captain's<br><br>wick into; aye, we all know these things; but look ye, here's a<br><br>Crappo that is content with our leavings, the drugged whale there, I<br><br>mean; aye, and is content too with scraping the dry bones of that<br><br>other precious fish he has there.  Poor devil!  I say, pass round a<br><br>hat, some one, and let's make him a present of a little oil for dear<br><br>charity's sake.  For what oil he'll get from that drugged whale<br><br>there, wouldn't be fit to burn in a jail; no, not in a condemned<br><br>cell.  And as for the other whale, why, I'll agree to get more oil by<br><br>chopping up and trying out these three masts of ours, than he'll get<br><br>from that bundle of bones; though, now that I think of it, it may<br><br>contain something worth a good deal more than oil; yes, ambergris.  I<br><br>wonder now if our old man has thought of that.  It's worth trying.<br><br>Yes, I'm for it;" and so saying he started for the quarter-deck.<br><br><br><br>By this time the faint air had become a complete calm; so that<br><br>whether or no, the Pequod was now fairly entrapped in the smell, with<br><br>no hope of escaping except by its breezing up again.  Issuing from<br><br>the cabin, Stubb now called his boat's crew, and pulled off for the<br><br>stranger.  Drawing across her bow, he perceived that in accordance<br><br>with the fanciful French taste, the upper part of her stem-piece was<br><br>carved in the likeness of a huge drooping stalk, was painted green,<br><br>and for thorns had copper spikes projecting from it here and there;<br><br>the whole terminating in a symmetrical folded bulb of a bright red<br><br>colour.  Upon her head boards, in large gilt letters, he read "Bouton<br><br>de Rose,"--Rose-button, or Rose-bud; and this was the romantic name<br><br>of this aromatic ship.<br><br><br><br>Though Stubb did not understand the BOUTON part of the inscription,<br><br>yet the word ROSE, and the bulbous figure-head put together,<br><br>sufficiently explained the whole to him.<br><br><br><br>"A wooden rose-bud, eh?" he cried with his hand to his nose, "that<br><br>will do very well; but how like all creation it smells!"<br><br><br><br>Now in order to hold direct communication with the people on deck, he<br><br>had to pull round the bows to the starboard side, and thus come close<br><br>to the blasted whale; and so talk over it.<br><br><br><br>Arrived then at this spot, with one hand still to his nose, he<br><br>bawled--"Bouton-de-Rose, ahoy! are there any of you Bouton-de-Roses<br><br>that speak English?"<br><br><br><br>"Yes," rejoined a Guernsey-man from the bulwarks, who turned out to<br><br>be the chief-mate.<br><br><br><br>"Well, then, my Bouton-de-Rose-bud, have you seen the White Whale?"<br><br><br><br>"WHAT whale?"<br><br><br><br>"The WHITE Whale--a Sperm Whale--Moby Dick, have ye seen him?<br><br><br><br>"Never heard of such a whale.  Cachalot Blanche!  White Whale--no."<br><br><br><br>"Very good, then; good bye now, and I'll call again in a minute."<br><br><br><br>Then rapidly pulling back towards the Pequod, and seeing Ahab leaning<br><br>over the quarter-deck rail awaiting his report, he moulded his two<br><br>hands into a trumpet and shouted--"No, Sir!  No!"  Upon which Ahab<br><br>retired, and Stubb returned to the Frenchman.<br><br><br><br>He now perceived that the Guernsey-man, who had just got into the<br><br>chains, and was using a cutting-spade, had slung his nose in a sort<br><br>of bag.<br><br><br><br>"What's the matter with your nose, there?" said Stubb.  "Broke it?"<br><br><br><br>"I wish it was broken, or that I didn't have any nose at all!"<br><br>answered the Guernsey-man, who did not seem to relish the job he was<br><br>at very much.  "But what are you holding YOURS for?"<br><br><br><br>"Oh, nothing!  It's a wax nose; I have to hold it on.  Fine day,<br><br>ain't it?  Air rather gardenny, I should say; throw us a bunch of<br><br>posies, will ye, Bouton-de-Rose?"<br><br><br><br>"What in the devil's name do you want here?" roared the Guernseyman,<br><br>flying into a sudden passion.<br><br><br><br>"Oh! keep cool--cool? yes, that's the word! why don't you pack those<br><br>whales in ice while you're working at 'em?  But joking aside, though;<br><br>do you know, Rose-bud, that it's all nonsense trying to get any oil<br><br>out of such whales?  As for that dried up one, there, he hasn't a<br><br>gill in his whole carcase."<br><br><br><br>"I know that well enough; but, d'ye see, the Captain here won't<br><br>believe it; this is his first voyage; he was a Cologne manufacturer<br><br>before.  But come aboard, and mayhap he'll believe you, if he won't<br><br>me; and so I'll get out of this dirty scrape."<br><br><br><br>"Anything to oblige ye, my sweet and pleasant fellow," rejoined<br><br>Stubb, and with that he soon mounted to the deck.  There a queer<br><br>scene presented itself.  The sailors, in tasselled caps of red<br><br>worsted, were getting the heavy tackles in readiness for the whales.<br><br>But they worked rather slow and talked very fast, and seemed in<br><br>anything but a good humor.  All their noses upwardly projected from<br><br>their faces like so many jib-booms.  Now and then pairs of them would<br><br>drop their work, and run up to the mast-head to get some fresh air.<br><br>Some thinking they would catch the plague, dipped oakum in coal-tar,<br><br>and at intervals held it to their nostrils.  Others having broken the<br><br>stems of their pipes almost short off at the bowl, were vigorously<br><br>puffing tobacco-smoke, so that it constantly filled their<br><br>olfactories.<br><br><br><br>Stubb was struck by a shower of outcries and anathemas proceeding<br><br>from the Captain's round-house abaft; and looking in that direction<br><br>saw a fiery face thrust from behind the door, which was held ajar<br><br>from within.  This was the tormented surgeon, who, after in vain<br><br>remonstrating against the proceedings of the day, had betaken himself<br><br>to the Captain's round-house (CABINET he called it) to avoid the<br><br>pest; but still, could not help yelling out his entreaties and<br><br>indignations at times.<br><br><br><br>Marking all this, Stubb argued well for his scheme, and turning to<br><br>the Guernsey-man had a little chat with him, during which the<br><br>stranger mate expressed his detestation of his Captain as a conceited<br><br>ignoramus, who had brought them all into so unsavory and unprofitable<br><br>a pickle.  Sounding him carefully, Stubb further perceived that the<br><br>Guernsey-man had not the slightest suspicion concerning the<br><br>ambergris.  He therefore held his peace on that head, but otherwise<br><br>was quite frank and confidential with him, so that the two quickly<br><br>concocted a little plan for both circumventing and satirizing the<br><br>Captain, without his at all dreaming of distrusting their sincerity.<br><br>According to this little plan of theirs, the Guernsey-man, under<br><br>cover of an interpreter's office, was to tell the Captain what he<br><br>pleased, but as coming from Stubb; and as for Stubb, he was to utter<br><br>any nonsense that should come uppermost in him during the interview.<br><br><br><br>By this time their destined victim appeared from his cabin.  He was a<br><br>small and dark, but rather delicate looking man for a sea-captain,<br><br>with large whiskers and moustache, however; and wore a red cotton<br><br>velvet vest with watch-seals at his side.  To this gentleman, Stubb<br><br>was now politely introduced by the Guernsey-man, who at once<br><br>ostentatiously put on the aspect of interpreting between them.<br><br><br><br>"What shall I say to him first?" said he.<br><br><br><br>"Why," said Stubb, eyeing the velvet vest and the watch and seals,<br><br>"you may as well begin by telling him that he looks a sort of babyish<br><br>to me, though I don't pretend to be a judge."<br><br><br><br>"He says, Monsieur," said the Guernsey-man, in French, turning to his<br><br>captain, "that only yesterday his ship spoke a vessel, whose captain<br><br>and chief-mate, with six sailors, had all died of a fever caught from<br><br>a blasted whale they had brought alongside."<br><br><br><br>Upon this the captain started, and eagerly desired to know more.<br><br><br><br>"What now?" said the Guernsey-man to Stubb.<br><br><br><br>"Why, since he takes it so easy, tell him that now I have eyed him<br><br>carefully, I'm quite certain that he's no more fit to command a<br><br>whale-ship than a St. Jago monkey.  In fact, tell him from me he's a<br><br>baboon."<br><br><br><br>"He vows and declares, Monsieur, that the other whale, the dried one,<br><br>is far more deadly than the blasted one; in fine, Monsieur, he<br><br>conjures us, as we value our lives, to cut loose from these fish."<br><br><br><br>Instantly the captain ran forward, and in a loud voice commanded his<br><br>crew to desist from hoisting the cutting-tackles, and at once cast<br><br>loose the cables and chains confining the whales to the ship.<br><br><br><br>"What now?" said the Guernsey-man, when the Captain had returned to<br><br>them.<br><br><br><br>"Why, let me see; yes, you may as well tell him now that--that--in<br><br>fact, tell him I've diddled him, and (aside to himself) perhaps<br><br>somebody else."<br><br><br><br>"He says, Monsieur, that he's very happy to have been of any service<br><br>to us."<br><br><br><br>Hearing this, the captain vowed that they were the grateful parties<br><br>(meaning himself and mate) and concluded by inviting Stubb down<br><br>into his cabin to drink a bottle of Bordeaux.<br><br><br><br>"He wants you to take a glass of wine with him," said the<br><br>interpreter.<br><br><br><br>"Thank him heartily; but tell him it's against my principles to drink<br><br>with the man I've diddled.  In fact, tell him I must go."<br><br><br><br>"He says, Monsieur, that his principles won't admit of his drinking;<br><br>but that if Monsieur wants to live another day to drink, then<br><br>Monsieur had best drop all four boats, and pull the ship away from<br><br>these whales, for it's so calm they won't drift."<br><br><br><br>By this time Stubb was over the side, and getting into his boat,<br><br>hailed the Guernsey-man to this effect,--that having a long tow-line<br><br>in his boat, he would do what he could to help them, by pulling out<br><br>the lighter whale of the two from the ship's side.  While the<br><br>Frenchman's boats, then, were engaged in towing the ship one way,<br><br>Stubb benevolently towed away at his whale the other way,<br><br>ostentatiously slacking out a most unusually long tow-line.<br><br><br><br>Presently a breeze sprang up; Stubb feigned to cast off from the<br><br>whale; hoisting his boats, the Frenchman soon increased his distance,<br><br>while the Pequod slid in between him and Stubb's whale.  Whereupon<br><br>Stubb quickly pulled to the floating body, and hailing the Pequod to<br><br>give notice of his intentions, at once proceeded to reap the fruit of<br><br>his unrighteous cunning.  Seizing his sharp boat-spade, he commenced<br><br>an excavation in the body, a little behind the side fin.  You would<br><br>almost have thought he was digging a cellar there in the sea; and<br><br>when at length his spade struck against the gaunt ribs, it was like<br><br>turning up old Roman tiles and pottery buried in fat English loam.<br><br>His boat's crew were all in high excitement, eagerly helping their<br><br>chief, and looking as anxious as gold-hunters.<br><br><br><br>And all the time numberless fowls were diving, and ducking, and<br><br>screaming, and yelling, and fighting around them.  Stubb was<br><br>beginning to look disappointed, especially as the horrible nosegay<br><br>increased, when suddenly from out the very heart of this plague,<br><br>there stole a faint stream of perfume, which flowed through the tide<br><br>of bad smells without being absorbed by it, as one river will flow<br><br>into and then along with another, without at all blending with it for<br><br>a time.<br><br><br><br>"I have it, I have it," cried Stubb, with delight, striking something<br><br>in the subterranean regions, "a purse! a purse!"<br><br><br><br>Dropping his spade, he thrust both hands in, and drew out handfuls of<br><br>something that looked like ripe Windsor soap, or rich mottled old<br><br>cheese; very unctuous and savory withal.  You might easily dent it<br><br>with your thumb; it is of a hue between yellow and ash colour.  And<br><br>this, good friends, is ambergris, worth a gold guinea an ounce to any<br><br>druggist.  Some six handfuls were obtained; but more was unavoidably<br><br>lost in the sea, and still more, perhaps, might have been secured<br><br>were it not for impatient Ahab's loud command to Stubb to desist, and<br><br>come on board, else the ship would bid them good bye.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 92<br><br><br><br>Ambergris.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Now this ambergris is a very curious substance, and so important as<br><br>an article of commerce, that in 1791 a certain Nantucket-born Captain<br><br>Coffin was examined at the bar of the English House of Commons on<br><br>that subject.  For at that time, and indeed until a comparatively<br><br>late day, the precise origin of ambergris remained, like amber<br><br>itself, a problem to the learned.  Though the word ambergris is but<br><br>the French compound for grey amber, yet the two substances are quite<br><br>distinct.  For amber, though at times found on the sea-coast, is also<br><br>dug up in some far inland soils, whereas ambergris is never found<br><br>except upon the sea.  Besides, amber is a hard, transparent, brittle,<br><br>odorless substance, used for mouth-pieces to pipes, for beads and<br><br>ornaments; but ambergris is soft, waxy, and so highly fragrant and<br><br>spicy, that it is largely used in perfumery, in pastiles, precious<br><br>candles, hair-powders, and pomatum.  The Turks use it in cooking, and<br><br>also carry it to Mecca, for the same purpose that frankincense is<br><br>carried to St. Peter's in Rome.  Some wine merchants drop a few<br><br>grains into claret, to flavor it.<br><br><br><br>Who would think, then, that such fine ladies and gentlemen should<br><br>regale themselves with an essence found in the inglorious bowels of a<br><br>sick whale!  Yet so it is.  By some, ambergris is supposed to be the<br><br>cause, and by others the effect, of the dyspepsia in the whale.  How<br><br>to cure such a dyspepsia it were hard to say, unless by administering<br><br>three or four boat loads of Brandreth's pills, and then running out<br><br>of harm's way, as laborers do in blasting rocks.<br><br><br><br>I have forgotten to say that there were found in this ambergris,<br><br>certain hard, round, bony plates, which at first Stubb thought might<br><br>be sailors' trowsers buttons; but it afterwards turned out that they<br><br>were nothing more than pieces of small squid bones embalmed in that<br><br>manner.<br><br><br><br>Now that the incorruption of this most fragrant ambergris should be<br><br>found in the heart of such decay; is this nothing?  Bethink thee of<br><br>that saying of St. Paul in Corinthians, about corruption and<br><br>incorruption; how that we are sown in dishonour, but raised in glory.<br><br>And likewise call to mind that saying of Paracelsus about what it is<br><br>that maketh the best musk.  Also forget not the strange fact that of<br><br>all things of ill-savor, Cologne-water, in its rudimental<br><br>manufacturing stages, is the worst.<br><br><br><br>I should like to conclude the chapter with the above appeal, but<br><br>cannot, owing to my anxiety to repel a charge often made against<br><br>whalemen, and which, in the estimation of some already biased minds,<br><br>might be considered as indirectly substantiated by what has been said<br><br>of the Frenchman's two whales.  Elsewhere in this volume the<br><br>slanderous aspersion has been disproved, that the vocation of whaling<br><br>is throughout a slatternly, untidy business.  But there is another<br><br>thing to rebut.  They hint that all whales always smell bad.  Now how<br><br>did this odious stigma originate?<br><br><br><br>I opine, that it is plainly traceable to the first arrival of the<br><br>Greenland whaling ships in London, more than two centuries ago.<br><br>Because those whalemen did not then, and do not now, try out their<br><br>oil at sea as the Southern ships have always done; but cutting up the<br><br>fresh blubber in small bits, thrust it through the bung holes of<br><br>large casks, and carry it home in that manner; the shortness of the<br><br>season in those Icy Seas, and the sudden and violent storms to which<br><br>they are exposed, forbidding any other course.  The consequence is,<br><br>that upon breaking into the hold, and unloading one of these whale<br><br>cemeteries, in the Greenland dock, a savor is given forth somewhat<br><br>similar to that arising from excavating an old city grave-yard, for<br><br>the foundations of a Lying-in-Hospital.<br><br><br><br>I partly surmise also, that this wicked charge against whalers may be<br><br>likewise imputed to the existence on the coast of Greenland, in<br><br>former times, of a Dutch village called Schmerenburgh or Smeerenberg,<br><br>which latter name is the one used by the learned Fogo Von Slack, in<br><br>his great work on Smells, a text-book on that subject.  As its name<br><br>imports (smeer, fat; berg, to put up), this village was founded in<br><br>order to afford a place for the blubber of the Dutch whale fleet to<br><br>be tried out, without being taken home to Holland for that purpose.<br><br>It was a collection of furnaces, fat-kettles, and oil sheds; and when<br><br>the works were in full operation certainly gave forth no very<br><br>pleasant savor.  But all this is quite different with a South Sea<br><br>Sperm Whaler; which in a voyage of four years perhaps, after<br><br>completely filling her hold with oil, does not, perhaps, consume<br><br>fifty days in the business of boiling out; and in the state that it<br><br>is casked, the oil is nearly scentless.  The truth is, that living or<br><br>dead, if but decently treated, whales as a species are by no means<br><br>creatures of ill odor; nor can whalemen be recognised, as the people<br><br>of the middle ages affected to detect a Jew in the company, by the<br><br>nose.  Nor indeed can the whale possibly be otherwise than fragrant,<br><br>when, as a general thing, he enjoys such high health; taking<br><br>abundance of exercise; always out of doors; though, it is true,<br><br>seldom in the open air.  I say, that the motion of a Sperm Whale's<br><br>flukes above water dispenses a perfume, as when a musk-scented lady<br><br>rustles her dress in a warm parlor.  What then shall I liken the<br><br>Sperm Whale to for fragrance, considering his magnitude?  Must it not<br><br>be to that famous elephant, with jewelled tusks, and redolent with<br><br>myrrh, which was led out of an Indian town to do honour to Alexander<br><br>the Great?<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 93<br><br><br><br>The Castaway.<br><br><br><br><br><br>It was but some few days after encountering the Frenchman, that a<br><br>most significant event befell the most insignificant of the Pequod's<br><br>crew; an event most lamentable; and which ended in providing the<br><br>sometimes madly merry and predestinated craft with a living and ever<br><br>accompanying prophecy of whatever shattered sequel might prove her<br><br>own.<br><br><br><br>Now, in the whale ship, it is not every one that goes in the boats.<br><br>Some few hands are reserved called ship-keepers, whose province it is<br><br>to work the vessel while the boats are pursuing the whale.  As a<br><br>general thing, these ship-keepers are as hardy fellows as the men<br><br>comprising the boats' crews.  But if there happen to be an unduly<br><br>slender, clumsy, or timorous wight in the ship, that wight is certain<br><br>to be made a ship-keeper.  It was so in the Pequod with the little<br><br>negro Pippin by nick-name, Pip by abbreviation.  Poor Pip! ye have<br><br>heard of him before; ye must remember his tambourine on that dramatic<br><br>midnight, so gloomy-jolly.<br><br><br><br>In outer aspect, Pip and Dough-Boy made a match, like a black pony<br><br>and a white one, of equal developments, though of dissimilar colour,<br><br>driven in one eccentric span.  But while hapless Dough-Boy was by<br><br>nature dull and torpid in his intellects, Pip, though over<br><br>tender-hearted, was at bottom very bright, with that pleasant,<br><br>genial, jolly brightness peculiar to his tribe; a tribe, which ever<br><br>enjoy all holidays and festivities with finer, freer relish than any<br><br>other race.  For blacks, the year's calendar should show naught but<br><br>three hundred and sixty-five Fourth of Julys and New Year's Days.<br><br>Nor smile so, while I write that this little black was brilliant, for<br><br>even blackness has its brilliancy; behold yon lustrous ebony,<br><br>panelled in king's cabinets.  But Pip loved life, and all life's<br><br>peaceable securities; so that the panic-striking business in which he<br><br>had somehow unaccountably become entrapped, had most sadly blurred<br><br>his brightness; though, as ere long will be seen, what was thus<br><br>temporarily subdued in him, in the end was destined to be luridly<br><br>illumined by strange wild fires, that fictitiously showed him off to<br><br>ten times the natural lustre with which in his native Tolland County<br><br>in Connecticut, he had once enlivened many a fiddler's frolic on the<br><br>green; and at melodious even-tide, with his gay ha-ha! had turned the<br><br>round horizon into one star-belled tambourine.  So, though in the<br><br>clear air of day, suspended against a blue-veined neck, the<br><br>pure-watered diamond drop will healthful glow; yet, when the cunning<br><br>jeweller would show you the diamond in its most impressive lustre, he<br><br>lays it against a gloomy ground, and then lights it up, not by the<br><br>sun, but by some unnatural gases.  Then come out those fiery<br><br>effulgences, infernally superb; then the evil-blazing diamond, once<br><br>the divinest symbol of the crystal skies, looks like some crown-jewel<br><br>stolen from the King of Hell.  But let us to the story.<br><br><br><br>It came to pass, that in the ambergris affair Stubb's after-oarsman<br><br>chanced so to sprain his hand, as for a time to become quite maimed;<br><br>and, temporarily, Pip was put into his place.<br><br><br><br>The first time Stubb lowered with him, Pip evinced much nervousness;<br><br>but happily, for that time, escaped close contact with the whale; and<br><br>therefore came off not altogether discreditably; though Stubb<br><br>observing him, took care, afterwards, to exhort him to cherish his<br><br>courageousness to the utmost, for he might often find it needful.<br><br><br><br>Now upon the second lowering, the boat paddled upon the whale; and as<br><br>the fish received the darted iron, it gave its customary rap, which<br><br>happened, in this instance, to be right under poor Pip's seat.  The<br><br>involuntary consternation of the moment caused him to leap, paddle in<br><br>hand, out of the boat; and in such a way, that part of the slack<br><br>whale line coming against his chest, he breasted it overboard with<br><br>him, so as to become entangled in it, when at last plumping into the<br><br>water.  That instant the stricken whale started on a fierce run, the<br><br>line swiftly straightened; and presto! poor Pip came all foaming up<br><br>to the chocks of the boat, remorselessly dragged there by the line,<br><br>which had taken several turns around his chest and neck.<br><br><br><br>Tashtego stood in the bows.  He was full of the fire of the hunt.  He<br><br>hated Pip for a poltroon.  Snatching the boat-knife from its sheath,<br><br>he suspended its sharp edge over the line, and turning towards Stubb,<br><br>exclaimed interrogatively, "Cut?"  Meantime Pip's blue, choked face<br><br>plainly looked, Do, for God's sake!  All passed in a flash.  In less<br><br>than half a minute, this entire thing happened.<br><br><br><br>"Damn him, cut!" roared Stubb; and so the whale was lost and Pip was<br><br>saved.<br><br><br><br>So soon as he recovered himself, the poor little negro was assailed<br><br>by yells and execrations from the crew.  Tranquilly permitting these<br><br>irregular cursings to evaporate, Stubb then in a plain,<br><br>business-like, but still half humorous manner, cursed Pip officially;<br><br>and that done, unofficially gave him much wholesome advice.  The<br><br>substance was, Never jump from a boat, Pip, except--but all the rest<br><br>was indefinite, as the soundest advice ever is.  Now, in general,<br><br>STICK TO THE BOAT, is your true motto in whaling; but cases will<br><br>sometimes happen when LEAP FROM THE BOAT, is still better.  Moreover,<br><br>as if perceiving at last that if he should give undiluted<br><br>conscientious advice to Pip, he would be leaving him too wide a<br><br>margin to jump in for the future; Stubb suddenly dropped all advice,<br><br>and concluded with a peremptory command, "Stick to the boat, Pip, or<br><br>by the Lord, I won't pick you up if you jump; mind that.  We can't<br><br>afford to lose whales by the likes of you; a whale would sell for<br><br>thirty times what you would, Pip, in Alabama.  Bear that in mind, and<br><br>don't jump any more."  Hereby perhaps Stubb indirectly hinted, that<br><br>though man loved his fellow, yet man is a money-making animal, which<br><br>propensity too often interferes with his benevolence.<br><br><br><br>But we are all in the hands of the Gods; and Pip jumped again.  It<br><br>was under very similar circumstances to the first performance; but<br><br>this time he did not breast out the line; and hence, when the whale<br><br>started to run, Pip was left behind on the sea, like a hurried<br><br>traveller's trunk.  Alas!  Stubb was but too true to his word.  It<br><br>was a beautiful, bounteous, blue day; the spangled sea calm and<br><br>cool, and flatly stretching away, all round, to the horizon, like<br><br>gold-beater's skin hammered out to the extremest.  Bobbing up and<br><br>down in that sea, Pip's ebon head showed like a head of cloves.  No<br><br>boat-knife was lifted when he fell so rapidly astern.  Stubb's<br><br>inexorable back was turned upon him; and the whale was winged.  In<br><br>three minutes, a whole mile of shoreless ocean was between Pip and<br><br>Stubb.  Out from the centre of the sea, poor Pip turned his crisp,<br><br>curling, black head to the sun, another lonely castaway, though the<br><br>loftiest and the brightest.<br><br><br><br>Now, in calm weather, to swim in the open ocean is as easy to the<br><br>practised swimmer as to ride in a spring-carriage ashore.  But the<br><br>awful lonesomeness is intolerable.  The intense concentration of self<br><br>in the middle of such a heartless immensity, my God! who can tell it?<br><br>Mark, how when sailors in a dead calm bathe in the open sea--mark<br><br>how closely they hug their ship and only coast along her sides.<br><br><br><br>But had Stubb really abandoned the poor little negro to his fate?<br><br>No; he did not mean to, at least.  Because there were two boats in<br><br>his wake, and he supposed, no doubt, that they would of course come<br><br>up to Pip very quickly, and pick him up; though, indeed, such<br><br>considerations towards oarsmen jeopardized through their own<br><br>timidity, is not always manifested by the hunters in all similar<br><br>instances; and such instances not unfrequently occur; almost<br><br>invariably in the fishery, a coward, so called, is marked with the<br><br>same ruthless detestation peculiar to military navies and armies.<br><br><br><br>But it so happened, that those boats, without seeing Pip, suddenly<br><br>spying whales close to them on one side, turned, and gave chase; and<br><br>Stubb's boat was now so far away, and he and all his crew so intent<br><br>upon his fish, that Pip's ringed horizon began to expand around him<br><br>miserably.
