By the merest chance the ship itself at last rescued him;<br><br>but from that hour the little negro went about the deck an idiot;<br><br>such, at least, they said he was.  The sea had jeeringly kept his<br><br>finite body up, but drowned the infinite of his soul.  Not drowned<br><br>entirely, though.  Rather carried down alive to wondrous depths,<br><br>where strange shapes of the unwarped primal world glided to and fro<br><br>before his passive eyes; and the miser-merman, Wisdom, revealed his<br><br>hoarded heaps; and among the joyous, heartless, ever-juvenile<br><br>eternities, Pip saw the multitudinous, God-omnipresent, coral<br><br>insects, that out of the firmament of waters heaved the colossal<br><br>orbs.  He saw God's foot upon the treadle of the loom, and spoke it;<br><br>and therefore his shipmates called him mad.  So man's insanity is<br><br>heaven's sense; and wandering from all mortal reason, man comes at<br><br>last to that celestial thought, which, to reason, is absurd and<br><br>frantic; and weal or woe, feels then uncompromised, indifferent as<br><br>his God.<br><br><br><br>For the rest, blame not Stubb too hardly.  The thing is common in<br><br>that fishery; and in the sequel of the narrative, it will then be<br><br>seen what like abandonment befell myself.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 94<br><br><br><br>A Squeeze of the Hand.<br><br><br><br><br><br>That whale of Stubb's, so dearly purchased, was duly brought to the<br><br>Pequod's side, where all those cutting and hoisting operations<br><br>previously detailed, were regularly gone through, even to the baling<br><br>of the Heidelburgh Tun, or Case.<br><br><br><br>While some were occupied with this latter duty, others were employed<br><br>in dragging away the larger tubs, so soon as filled with the sperm;<br><br>and when the proper time arrived, this same sperm was carefully<br><br>manipulated ere going to the try-works, of which anon.<br><br><br><br>It had cooled and crystallized to such a degree, that when, with<br><br>several others, I sat down before a large Constantine's bath of it, I<br><br>found it strangely concreted into lumps, here and there rolling about<br><br>in the liquid part.  It was our business to squeeze these lumps back<br><br>into fluid.  A sweet and unctuous duty!  No wonder that in old times<br><br>this sperm was such a favourite cosmetic.  Such a clearer! such a<br><br>sweetener! such a softener! such a delicious molifier!  After<br><br>having my hands in it for only a few minutes, my fingers felt like<br><br>eels, and began, as it were, to serpentine and spiralise.<br><br><br><br>As I sat there at my ease, cross-legged on the deck; after the bitter<br><br>exertion at the windlass; under a blue tranquil sky; the ship under<br><br>indolent sail, and gliding so serenely along; as I bathed my hands<br><br>among those soft, gentle globules of infiltrated tissues, woven<br><br>almost within the hour; as they richly broke to my fingers, and<br><br>discharged all their opulence, like fully ripe grapes their wine; as<br><br>I snuffed up that uncontaminated aroma,--literally and truly, like<br><br>the smell of spring violets; I declare to you, that for the time I<br><br>lived as in a musky meadow; I forgot all about our horrible oath; in<br><br>that inexpressible sperm, I washed my hands and my heart of it; I<br><br>almost began to credit the old Paracelsan superstition that sperm is<br><br>of rare virtue in allaying the heat of anger; while bathing in that<br><br>bath, I felt divinely free from all ill-will, or petulance, or<br><br>malice, of any sort whatsoever.<br><br><br><br>Squeeze! squeeze! squeeze! all the morning long; I squeezed that<br><br>sperm till I myself almost melted into it; I squeezed that sperm till<br><br>a strange sort of insanity came over me; and I found myself<br><br>unwittingly squeezing my co-laborers' hands in it, mistaking their<br><br>hands for the gentle globules.  Such an abounding, affectionate,<br><br>friendly, loving feeling did this avocation beget; that at last I was<br><br>continually squeezing their hands, and looking up into their eyes<br><br>sentimentally; as much as to say,--Oh! my dear fellow beings, why<br><br>should we longer cherish any social acerbities, or know the slightest<br><br>ill-humor or envy!  Come; let us squeeze hands all round; nay, let us<br><br>all squeeze ourselves into each other; let us squeeze ourselves<br><br>universally into the very milk and sperm of kindness.<br><br><br><br>Would that I could keep squeezing that sperm for ever!  For now,<br><br>since by many prolonged, repeated experiences, I have perceived that<br><br>in all cases man must eventually lower, or at least shift, his<br><br>conceit of attainable felicity; not placing it anywhere in the<br><br>intellect or the fancy; but in the wife, the heart, the bed, the<br><br>table, the saddle, the fireside, the country; now that I have<br><br>perceived all this, I am ready to squeeze case eternally.  In<br><br>thoughts of the visions of the night, I saw long rows of angels in<br><br>paradise, each with his hands in a jar of spermaceti.<br><br><br><br>Now, while discoursing of sperm, it behooves to speak of other things<br><br>akin to it, in the business of preparing the sperm whale for the<br><br>try-works.<br><br><br><br>First comes white-horse, so called, which is obtained from the<br><br>tapering part of the fish, and also from the thicker portions of his<br><br>flukes.  It is tough with congealed tendons--a wad of muscle--but<br><br>still contains some oil.  After being severed from the whale, the<br><br>white-horse is first cut into portable oblongs ere going to the<br><br>mincer.  They look much like blocks of Berkshire marble.<br><br><br><br>Plum-pudding is the term bestowed upon certain fragmentary parts of<br><br>the whale's flesh, here and there adhering to the blanket of blubber,<br><br>and often participating to a considerable degree in its unctuousness.<br><br>It is a most refreshing, convivial, beautiful object to behold.  As<br><br>its name imports, it is of an exceedingly rich, mottled tint, with a<br><br>bestreaked snowy and golden ground, dotted with spots of the deepest<br><br>crimson and purple.  It is plums of rubies, in pictures of citron.<br><br>Spite of reason, it is hard to keep yourself from eating it.  I<br><br>confess, that once I stole behind the foremast to try it.  It tasted<br><br>something as I should conceive a royal cutlet from the thigh of Louis<br><br>le Gros might have tasted, supposing him to have been killed the<br><br>first day after the venison season, and that particular venison<br><br>season contemporary with an unusually fine vintage of the vineyards<br><br>of Champagne.<br><br><br><br>There is another substance, and a very singular one, which turns up<br><br>in the course of this business, but which I feel it to be very<br><br>puzzling adequately to describe.  It is called slobgollion; an<br><br>appellation original with the whalemen, and even so is the nature of<br><br>the substance.  It is an ineffably oozy, stringy affair, most<br><br>frequently found in the tubs of sperm, after a prolonged squeezing,<br><br>and subsequent decanting.  I hold it to be the wondrously thin,<br><br>ruptured membranes of the case, coalescing.<br><br><br><br>Gurry, so called, is a term properly belonging to right whalemen, but<br><br>sometimes incidentally used by the sperm fishermen.  It designates<br><br>the dark, glutinous substance which is scraped off the back of the<br><br>Greenland or right whale, and much of which covers the decks of those<br><br>inferior souls who hunt that ignoble Leviathan.<br><br><br><br>Nippers.  Strictly this word is not indigenous to the whale's<br><br>vocabulary.  But as applied by whalemen, it becomes so.  A whaleman's<br><br>nipper is a short firm strip of tendinous stuff cut from the tapering<br><br>part of Leviathan's tail: it averages an inch in thickness, and for<br><br>the rest, is about the size of the iron part of a hoe.  Edgewise<br><br>moved along the oily deck, it operates like a leathern squilgee; and<br><br>by nameless blandishments, as of magic, allures along with it all<br><br>impurities.<br><br><br><br>But to learn all about these recondite matters, your best way is at<br><br>once to descend into the blubber-room, and have a long talk with its<br><br>inmates.  This place has previously been mentioned as the receptacle<br><br>for the blanket-pieces, when stript and hoisted from the whale.  When<br><br>the proper time arrives for cutting up its contents, this apartment<br><br>is a scene of terror to all tyros, especially by night.  On one side,<br><br>lit by a dull lantern, a space has been left clear for the workmen.<br><br>They generally go in pairs,--a pike-and-gaffman and a spade-man.<br><br>The whaling-pike is similar to a frigate's boarding-weapon of the<br><br>same name.  The gaff is something like a boat-hook.  With his gaff,<br><br>the gaffman hooks on to a sheet of blubber, and strives to hold it<br><br>from slipping, as the ship pitches and lurches about.  Meanwhile, the<br><br>spade-man stands on the sheet itself, perpendicularly chopping it<br><br>into the portable horse-pieces.  This spade is sharp as hone can make<br><br>it; the spademan's feet are shoeless; the thing he stands on will<br><br>sometimes irresistibly slide away from him, like a sledge.  If he<br><br>cuts off one of his own toes, or one of his assistants', would you be<br><br>very much astonished?  Toes are scarce among veteran blubber-room<br><br>men.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 95<br><br><br><br>The Cassock.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Had you stepped on board the Pequod at a certain juncture of this<br><br>post-mortemizing of the whale; and had you strolled forward nigh the<br><br>windlass, pretty sure am I that you would have scanned with no small<br><br>curiosity a very strange, enigmatical object, which you would have<br><br>seen there, lying along lengthwise in the lee scuppers.  Not the<br><br>wondrous cistern in the whale's huge head; not the prodigy of his<br><br>unhinged lower jaw; not the miracle of his symmetrical tail; none of<br><br>these would so surprise you, as half a glimpse of that unaccountable<br><br>cone,--longer than a Kentuckian is tall, nigh a foot in diameter at<br><br>the base, and jet-black as Yojo, the ebony idol of Queequeg.  And an<br><br>idol, indeed, it is; or, rather, in old times, its likeness was.<br><br>Such an idol as that found in the secret groves of Queen Maachah in<br><br>Judea; and for worshipping which, King Asa, her son, did depose her,<br><br>and destroyed the idol, and burnt it for an abomination at the brook<br><br>Kedron, as darkly set forth in the 15th chapter of the First Book of<br><br>Kings.<br><br><br><br>Look at the sailor, called the mincer, who now comes along, and<br><br>assisted by two allies, heavily backs the grandissimus, as the<br><br>mariners call it, and with bowed shoulders, staggers off with it as<br><br>if he were a grenadier carrying a dead comrade from the field.<br><br>Extending it upon the forecastle deck, he now proceeds cylindrically<br><br>to remove its dark pelt, as an African hunter the pelt of a boa.<br><br>This done he turns the pelt inside out, like a pantaloon leg; gives<br><br>it a good stretching, so as almost to double its diameter; and at<br><br>last hangs it, well spread, in the rigging, to dry.  Ere long, it is<br><br>taken down; when removing some three feet of it, towards the pointed<br><br>extremity, and then cutting two slits for arm-holes at the other end,<br><br>he lengthwise slips himself bodily into it.  The mincer now stands<br><br>before you invested in the full canonicals of his calling.<br><br>Immemorial to all his order, this investiture alone will adequately<br><br>protect him, while employed in the peculiar functions of his office.<br><br><br><br>That office consists in mincing the horse-pieces of blubber for the<br><br>pots; an operation which is conducted at a curious wooden horse,<br><br>planted endwise against the bulwarks, and with a capacious tub<br><br>beneath it, into which the minced pieces drop, fast as the sheets<br><br>from a rapt orator's desk.  Arrayed in decent black; occupying a<br><br>conspicuous pulpit; intent on bible leaves; what a candidate for an<br><br>archbishopric, what a lad for a Pope were this mincer!*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*Bible leaves!  Bible leaves!  This is the invariable cry from the<br><br>mates to the mincer.  It enjoins him to be careful, and cut his work<br><br>into as thin slices as possible, inasmuch as by so doing the business<br><br>of boiling out the oil is much accelerated, and its quantity<br><br>considerably increased, besides perhaps improving it in quality.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 96<br><br><br><br>The Try-Works.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Besides her hoisted boats, an American whaler is outwardly<br><br>distinguished by her try-works.  She presents the curious anomaly of<br><br>the most solid masonry joining with oak and hemp in constituting the<br><br>completed ship.  It is as if from the open field a brick-kiln were<br><br>transported to her planks.<br><br><br><br>The try-works are planted between the foremast and mainmast, the<br><br>most roomy part of the deck.  The timbers beneath are of a peculiar<br><br>strength, fitted to sustain the weight of an almost solid mass of<br><br>brick and mortar, some ten feet by eight square, and five in height.<br><br>The foundation does not penetrate the deck, but the masonry is firmly<br><br>secured to the surface by ponderous knees of iron bracing it on all<br><br>sides, and screwing it down to the timbers.  On the flanks it is<br><br>cased with wood, and at top completely covered by a large, sloping,<br><br>battened hatchway.  Removing this hatch we expose the great try-pots,<br><br>two in number, and each of several barrels' capacity.  When not in<br><br>use, they are kept remarkably clean.  Sometimes they are polished<br><br>with soapstone and sand, till they shine within like silver<br><br>punch-bowls.  During the night-watches some cynical old sailors will<br><br>crawl into them and coil themselves away there for a nap.  While<br><br>employed in polishing them--one man in each pot, side by side--many<br><br>confidential communications are carried on, over the iron lips.  It<br><br>is a place also for profound mathematical meditation.  It was in the<br><br>left hand try-pot of the Pequod, with the soapstone diligently<br><br>circling round me, that I was first indirectly struck by the<br><br>remarkable fact, that in geometry all bodies gliding along the<br><br>cycloid, my soapstone for example, will descend from any point in<br><br>precisely the same time.<br><br><br><br>Removing the fire-board from the front of the try-works, the bare<br><br>masonry of that side is exposed, penetrated by the two iron mouths of<br><br>the furnaces, directly underneath the pots.  These mouths are fitted<br><br>with heavy doors of iron.  The intense heat of the fire is prevented<br><br>from communicating itself to the deck, by means of a shallow<br><br>reservoir extending under the entire inclosed surface of the works.<br><br>By a tunnel inserted at the rear, this reservoir is kept replenished<br><br>with water as fast as it evaporates.  There are no external chimneys;<br><br>they open direct from the rear wall.  And here let us go back for a<br><br>moment.<br><br><br><br>It was about nine o'clock at night that the Pequod's try-works were<br><br>first started on this present voyage.  It belonged to Stubb to<br><br>oversee the business.<br><br><br><br>"All ready there?  Off hatch, then, and start her.  You cook, fire<br><br>the works."  This was an easy thing, for the carpenter had been<br><br>thrusting his shavings into the furnace throughout the passage.  Here<br><br>be it said that in a whaling voyage the first fire in the try-works has<br><br>to be fed for a time with wood.  After that no wood is used, except<br><br>as a means of quick ignition to the staple fuel.  In a word, after<br><br>being tried out, the crisp, shrivelled blubber, now called scraps or<br><br>fritters, still contains considerable of its unctuous properties.<br><br>These fritters feed the flames.  Like a plethoric burning martyr, or<br><br>a self-consuming misanthrope, once ignited, the whale supplies his<br><br>own fuel and burns by his own body.  Would that he consumed his own<br><br>smoke! for his smoke is horrible to inhale, and inhale it you must,<br><br>and not only that, but you must live in it for the time.  It has an<br><br>unspeakable, wild, Hindoo odor about it, such as may lurk in the<br><br>vicinity of funereal pyres.  It smells like the left wing of the day<br><br>of judgment; it is an argument for the pit.<br><br><br><br>By midnight the works were in full operation.  We were clear from the<br><br>carcase; sail had been made; the wind was freshening; the wild ocean<br><br>darkness was intense.  But that darkness was licked up by the fierce<br><br>flames, which at intervals forked forth from the sooty flues, and<br><br>illuminated every lofty rope in the rigging, as with the famed Greek<br><br>fire.  The burning ship drove on, as if remorselessly commissioned to<br><br>some vengeful deed.  So the pitch and sulphur-freighted brigs of the<br><br>bold Hydriote, Canaris, issuing from their midnight harbors, with<br><br>broad sheets of flame for sails, bore down upon the Turkish frigates,<br><br>and folded them in conflagrations.<br><br><br><br>The hatch, removed from the top of the works, now afforded a wide<br><br>hearth in front of them.  Standing on this were the Tartarean shapes<br><br>of the pagan harpooneers, always the whale-ship's stokers.  With huge<br><br>pronged poles they pitched hissing masses of blubber into the<br><br>scalding pots, or stirred up the fires beneath, till the snaky flames<br><br>darted, curling, out of the doors to catch them by the feet.  The<br><br>smoke rolled away in sullen heaps.  To every pitch of the ship there<br><br>was a pitch of the boiling oil, which seemed all eagerness to leap<br><br>into their faces.  Opposite the mouth of the works, on the further<br><br>side of the wide wooden hearth, was the windlass.  This served for a<br><br>sea-sofa.  Here lounged the watch, when not otherwise employed,<br><br>looking into the red heat of the fire, till their eyes felt scorched<br><br>in their heads.  Their tawny features, now all begrimed with smoke<br><br>and sweat, their matted beards, and the contrasting barbaric<br><br>brilliancy of their teeth, all these were strangely revealed in the<br><br>capricious emblazonings of the works.  As they narrated to each other<br><br>their unholy adventures, their tales of terror told in words of<br><br>mirth; as their uncivilized laughter forked upwards out of them, like<br><br>the flames from the furnace; as to and fro, in their front, the<br><br>harpooneers wildly gesticulated with their huge pronged forks and<br><br>dippers; as the wind howled on, and the sea leaped, and the ship<br><br>groaned and dived, and yet steadfastly shot her red hell further and<br><br>further into the blackness of the sea and the night, and scornfully<br><br>champed the white bone in her mouth, and viciously spat round her on<br><br>all sides; then the rushing Pequod, freighted with savages, and laden<br><br>with fire, and burning a corpse, and plunging into that blackness of<br><br>darkness, seemed the material counterpart of her monomaniac<br><br>commander's soul.<br><br><br><br>So seemed it to me, as I stood at her helm, and for long hours<br><br>silently guided the way of this fire-ship on the sea.  Wrapped, for<br><br>that interval, in darkness myself, I but the better saw the redness,<br><br>the madness, the ghastliness of others.  The continual sight of the<br><br>fiend shapes before me, capering half in smoke and half in fire,<br><br>these at last begat kindred visions in my soul, so soon as I began to<br><br>yield to that unaccountable drowsiness which ever would come over me<br><br>at a midnight helm.<br><br><br><br>But that night, in particular, a strange (and ever since<br><br>inexplicable) thing occurred to me.  Starting from a brief standing<br><br>sleep, I was horribly conscious of something fatally wrong.  The<br><br>jaw-bone tiller smote my side, which leaned against it; in my ears<br><br>was the low hum of sails, just beginning to shake in the wind; I<br><br>thought my eyes were open; I was half conscious of putting my fingers<br><br>to the lids and mechanically stretching them still further apart.<br><br>But, spite of all this, I could see no compass before me to steer by;<br><br>though it seemed but a minute since I had been watching the card, by<br><br>the steady binnacle lamp illuminating it.  Nothing seemed before me<br><br>but a jet gloom, now and then made ghastly by flashes of redness.<br><br>Uppermost was the impression, that whatever swift, rushing thing I<br><br>stood on was not so much bound to any haven ahead as rushing from all<br><br>havens astern.  A stark, bewildered feeling, as of death, came over<br><br>me.  Convulsively my hands grasped the tiller, but with the crazy<br><br>conceit that the tiller was, somehow, in some enchanted way,<br><br>inverted.  My God! what is the matter with me? thought I.  Lo! in my<br><br>brief sleep I had turned myself about, and was fronting the ship's<br><br>stern, with my back to her prow and the compass.  In an instant I<br><br>faced back, just in time to prevent the vessel from flying up into<br><br>the wind, and very probably capsizing her.  How glad and how grateful<br><br>the relief from this unnatural hallucination of the night, and the<br><br>fatal contingency of being brought by the lee!<br><br><br><br>Look not too long in the face of the fire, O man!  Never dream with<br><br>thy hand on the helm!  Turn not thy back to the compass; accept the<br><br>first hint of the hitching tiller; believe not the artificial fire,<br><br>when its redness makes all things look ghastly.  To-morrow, in the<br><br>natural sun, the skies will be bright; those who glared like devils<br><br>in the forking flames, the morn will show in far other, at least<br><br>gentler, relief; the glorious, golden, glad sun, the only true<br><br>lamp--all others but liars!<br><br><br><br>Nevertheless the sun hides not Virginia's Dismal Swamp, nor Rome's<br><br>accursed Campagna, nor wide Sahara, nor all the millions of miles of<br><br>deserts and of griefs beneath the moon.  The sun hides not the ocean,<br><br>which is the dark side of this earth, and which is two thirds of this<br><br>earth.  So, therefore, that mortal man who hath more of joy than<br><br>sorrow in him, that mortal man cannot be true--not true, or<br><br>undeveloped.  With books the same.  The truest of all men was the Man<br><br>of Sorrows, and the truest of all books is Solomon's, and<br><br>Ecclesiastes is the fine hammered steel of woe.  "All is vanity."<br><br>ALL.  This wilful world hath not got hold of unchristian Solomon's<br><br>wisdom yet.  But he who dodges hospitals and jails, and walks fast<br><br>crossing graveyards, and would rather talk of operas than hell;<br><br>calls Cowper, Young, Pascal, Rousseau, poor devils all of sick men;<br><br>and throughout a care-free lifetime swears by Rabelais as passing<br><br>wise, and therefore jolly;--not that man is fitted to sit down on<br><br>tomb-stones, and break the green damp mould with unfathomably<br><br>wondrous Solomon.<br><br><br><br>But even Solomon, he says, "the man that wandereth out of the way of<br><br>understanding shall remain" (I.E., even while living) "in the<br><br>congregation of the dead."  Give not thyself up, then, to fire, lest<br><br>it invert thee, deaden thee; as for the time it did me.  There is a<br><br>wisdom that is woe; but there is a woe that is madness.  And there is<br><br>a Catskill eagle in some souls that can alike dive down into the<br><br>blackest gorges, and soar out of them again and become invisible in<br><br>the sunny spaces.  And even if he for ever flies within the gorge,<br><br>that gorge is in the mountains; so that even in his lowest swoop the<br><br>mountain eagle is still higher than other birds upon the plain, even<br><br>though they soar.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 97<br><br><br><br>The Lamp.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Had you descended from the Pequod's try-works to the Pequod's<br><br>forecastle, where the off duty watch were sleeping, for one single<br><br>moment you would have almost thought you were standing in some<br><br>illuminated shrine of canonized kings and counsellors.  There they<br><br>lay in their triangular oaken vaults, each mariner a chiselled<br><br>muteness; a score of lamps flashing upon his hooded eyes.<br><br><br><br>In merchantmen, oil for the sailor is more scarce than the milk of<br><br>queens.  To dress in the dark, and eat in the dark, and stumble in<br><br>darkness to his pallet, this is his usual lot.  But the whaleman, as<br><br>he seeks the food of light, so he lives in light.  He makes his berth<br><br>an Aladdin's lamp, and lays him down in it; so that in the pitchiest<br><br>night the ship's black hull still houses an illumination.<br><br><br><br>See with what entire freedom the whaleman takes his handful of<br><br>lamps--often but old bottles and vials, though--to the copper cooler<br><br>at the try-works, and replenishes them there, as mugs of ale at a<br><br>vat.  He burns, too, the purest of oil, in its unmanufactured, and,<br><br>therefore, unvitiated state; a fluid unknown to solar, lunar, or<br><br>astral contrivances ashore.  It is sweet as early grass butter in<br><br>April.  He goes and hunts for his oil, so as to be sure of its<br><br>freshness and genuineness, even as the traveller on the prairie hunts<br><br>up his own supper of game.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 98<br><br><br><br>Stowing Down and Clearing Up.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Already has it been related how the great leviathan is afar off<br><br>descried from the mast-head; how he is chased over the watery moors,<br><br>and slaughtered in the valleys of the deep; how he is then towed<br><br>alongside and beheaded; and how (on the principle which entitled the<br><br>headsman of old to the garments in which the beheaded was killed) his<br><br>great padded surtout becomes the property of his executioner; how, in<br><br>due time, he is condemned to the pots, and, like Shadrach, Meshach,<br><br>and Abednego, his spermaceti, oil, and bone pass unscathed through<br><br>the fire;--but now it remains to conclude the last chapter of this<br><br>part of the description by rehearsing--singing, if I may--the<br><br>romantic proceeding of decanting off his oil into the casks and<br><br>striking them down into the hold, where once again leviathan returns<br><br>to his native profundities, sliding along beneath the surface as<br><br>before; but, alas! never more to rise and blow.<br><br><br><br>While still warm, the oil, like hot punch, is received into the<br><br>six-barrel casks; and while, perhaps, the ship is pitching and<br><br>rolling this way and that in the midnight sea, the enormous casks are<br><br>slewed round and headed over, end for end, and sometimes perilously<br><br>scoot across the slippery deck, like so many land slides, till at<br><br>last man-handled and stayed in their course; and all round the hoops,<br><br>rap, rap, go as many hammers as can play upon them, for now, EX<br><br>OFFICIO, every sailor is a cooper.<br><br><br><br>At length, when the last pint is casked, and all is cool, then the<br><br>great hatchways are unsealed, the bowels of the ship are thrown open,<br><br>and down go the casks to their final rest in the sea.  This done, the<br><br>hatches are replaced, and hermetically closed, like a closet walled<br><br>up.<br><br><br><br>In the sperm fishery, this is perhaps one of the most remarkable<br><br>incidents in all the business of whaling.  One day the planks stream<br><br>with freshets of blood and oil; on the sacred quarter-deck enormous<br><br>masses of the whale's head are profanely piled; great rusty casks lie<br><br>about, as in a brewery yard; the smoke from the try-works has<br><br>besooted all the bulwarks; the mariners go about suffused with<br><br>unctuousness; the entire ship seems great leviathan himself; while on<br><br>all hands the din is deafening.<br><br><br><br>But a day or two after, you look about you, and prick your ears in<br><br>this self-same ship; and were it not for the tell-tale boats and<br><br>try-works, you would all but swear you trod some silent merchant<br><br>vessel, with a most scrupulously neat commander.  The unmanufactured<br><br>sperm oil possesses a singularly cleansing virtue.  This is the<br><br>reason why the decks never look so white as just after what they call<br><br>an affair of oil.  Besides, from the ashes of the burned scraps of<br><br>the whale, a potent lye is readily made; and whenever any<br><br>adhesiveness from the back of the whale remains clinging to the side,<br><br>that lye quickly exterminates it.  Hands go diligently along the<br><br>bulwarks, and with buckets of water and rags restore them to their<br><br>full tidiness.  The soot is brushed from the lower rigging.  All the<br><br>numerous implements which have been in use are likewise faithfully<br><br>cleansed and put away.  The great hatch is scrubbed and placed upon<br><br>the try-works, completely hiding the pots; every cask is out of<br><br>sight; all tackles are coiled in unseen nooks; and when by the<br><br>combined and simultaneous industry of almost the entire ship's<br><br>company, the whole of this conscientious duty is at last concluded,<br><br>then the crew themselves proceed to their own ablutions; shift<br><br>themselves from top to toe; and finally issue to the immaculate deck,<br><br>fresh and all aglow, as bridegrooms new-leaped from out the daintiest<br><br>Holland.<br><br><br><br>Now, with elated step, they pace the planks in twos and threes, and<br><br>humorously discourse of parlors, sofas, carpets, and fine cambrics;<br><br>propose to mat the deck; think of having hanging to the top; object<br><br>not to taking tea by moonlight on the piazza of the forecastle.  To<br><br>hint to such musked mariners of oil, and bone, and blubber, were<br><br>little short of audacity.  They know not the thing you distantly<br><br>allude to.  Away, and bring us napkins!<br><br><br><br>But mark: aloft there, at the three mast heads, stand three men<br><br>intent on spying out more whales, which, if caught, infallibly will<br><br>again soil the old oaken furniture, and drop at least one small<br><br>grease-spot somewhere.  Yes; and many is the time, when, after the<br><br>severest uninterrupted labors, which know no night; continuing<br><br>straight through for ninety-six hours; when from the boat, where they<br><br>have swelled their wrists with all day rowing on the Line,--they only<br><br>step to the deck to carry vast chains, and heave the heavy windlass,<br><br>and cut and slash, yea, and in their very sweatings to be smoked and<br><br>burned anew by the combined fires of the equatorial sun and the<br><br>equatorial try-works; when, on the heel of all this, they have<br><br>finally bestirred themselves to cleanse the ship, and make a spotless<br><br>dairy room of it; many is the time the poor fellows, just buttoning<br><br>the necks of their clean frocks, are startled by the cry of "There<br><br>she blows!" and away they fly to fight another whale, and go through<br><br>the whole weary thing again.  Oh! my friends, but this is<br><br>man-killing!  Yet this is life.  For hardly have we mortals by long<br><br>toilings extracted from this world's vast bulk its small but<br><br>valuable sperm; and then, with weary patience, cleansed ourselves<br><br>from its defilements, and learned to live here in clean tabernacles<br><br>of the soul; hardly is this done, when--THERE SHE BLOWS!--the ghost<br><br>is spouted up, and away we sail to fight some other world, and go<br><br>through young life's old routine again.<br><br><br><br>Oh! the metempsychosis!  Oh!  Pythagoras, that in bright Greece, two<br><br>thousand years ago, did die, so good, so wise, so mild; I sailed with<br><br>thee along the Peruvian coast last voyage--and, foolish as I am,<br><br>taught thee, a green simple boy, how to splice a rope!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 99<br><br><br><br>The Doubloon.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Ere now it has been related how Ahab was wont to pace his<br><br>quarter-deck, taking regular turns at either limit, the binnacle and<br><br>mainmast; but in the multiplicity of other things requiring narration<br><br>it has not been added how that sometimes in these walks, when most<br><br>plunged in his mood, he was wont to pause in turn at each spot, and<br><br>stand there strangely eyeing the particular object before him.  When<br><br>he halted before the binnacle, with his glance fastened on the<br><br>pointed needle in the compass, that glance shot like a javelin with<br><br>the pointed intensity of his purpose; and when resuming his walk he<br><br>again paused before the mainmast, then, as the same riveted glance<br><br>fastened upon the riveted gold coin there, he still wore the same<br><br>aspect of nailed firmness, only dashed with a certain wild longing,<br><br>if not hopefulness.<br><br><br><br>But one morning, turning to pass the doubloon, he seemed to be newly<br><br>attracted by the strange figures and inscriptions stamped on it, as<br><br>though now for the first time beginning to interpret for himself in<br><br>some monomaniac way whatever significance might lurk in them.  And<br><br>some certain significance lurks in all things, else all things are<br><br>little worth, and the round world itself but an empty cipher, except<br><br>to sell by the cartload, as they do hills about Boston, to fill up<br><br>some morass in the Milky Way.<br><br><br><br>Now this doubloon was of purest, virgin gold, raked somewhere out of<br><br>the heart of gorgeous hills, whence, east and west, over golden<br><br>sands, the head-waters of many a Pactolus flows.  And though now<br><br>nailed amidst all the rustiness of iron bolts and the verdigris of<br><br>copper spikes, yet, untouchable and immaculate to any foulness, it<br><br>still preserved its Quito glow.  Nor, though placed amongst a<br><br>ruthless crew and every hour passed by ruthless hands, and through<br><br>the livelong nights shrouded with thick darkness which might cover<br><br>any pilfering approach, nevertheless every sunrise found the doubloon<br><br>where the sunset left it last.  For it was set apart and sanctified<br><br>to one awe-striking end; and however wanton in their sailor ways, one<br><br>and all, the mariners revered it as the white whale's talisman.<br><br>Sometimes they talked it over in the weary watch by night, wondering<br><br>whose it was to be at last, and whether he would ever live to spend<br><br>it.<br><br><br><br>Now those noble golden coins of South America are as medals of the<br><br>sun and tropic token-pieces.  Here palms, alpacas, and volcanoes;<br><br>sun's disks and stars; ecliptics, horns-of-plenty, and rich banners<br><br>waving, are in luxuriant profusion stamped; so that the precious gold<br><br>seems almost to derive an added preciousness and enhancing glories,<br><br>by passing through those fancy mints, so Spanishly poetic.<br><br><br><br>It so chanced that the doubloon of the Pequod was a most wealthy<br><br>example of these things.  On its round border it bore the letters,<br><br>REPUBLICA DEL ECUADOR: QUITO.  So this bright coin came from a<br><br>country planted in the middle of the world, and beneath the great<br><br>equator, and named after it; and it had been cast midway up the<br><br>Andes, in the unwaning clime that knows no autumn.  Zoned by those<br><br>letters you saw the likeness of three Andes' summits; from one a<br><br>flame; a tower on another; on the third a crowing cock; while arching<br><br>over all was a segment of the partitioned zodiac, the signs all<br><br>marked with their usual cabalistics, and the keystone sun entering<br><br>the equinoctial point at Libra.<br><br><br><br>Before this equatorial coin, Ahab, not unobserved by others, was now<br><br>pausing.<br><br><br><br>"There's something ever egotistical in mountain-tops and towers, and<br><br>all other grand and lofty things; look here,--three peaks as proud as<br><br>Lucifer.  The firm tower, that is Ahab; the volcano, that is Ahab;<br><br>the courageous, the undaunted, and victorious fowl, that, too, is<br><br>Ahab; all are Ahab; and this round gold is but the image of the<br><br>rounder globe, which, like a magician's glass, to each and every man<br><br>in turn but mirrors back his own mysterious self.  Great pains, small<br><br>gains for those who ask the world to solve them; it cannot solve<br><br>itself.  Methinks now this coined sun wears a ruddy face; but see!<br><br>aye, he enters the sign of storms, the equinox! and but six months<br><br>before he wheeled out of a former equinox at Aries!  From storm to<br><br>storm!  So be it, then.  Born in throes, 't is fit that man should<br><br>live in pains and die in pangs!  So be it, then!  Here's stout stuff<br><br>for woe to work on.  So be it, then."<br><br><br><br>"No fairy fingers can have pressed the gold, but devil's claws must have<br><br>left their mouldings there since yesterday," murmured Starbuck to<br><br>himself, leaning against the bulwarks.  "The old man seems to read<br><br>Belshazzar's awful writing.  I have never marked the coin<br><br>inspectingly.  He goes below; let me read.  A dark valley between<br><br>three mighty, heaven-abiding peaks, that almost seem the Trinity, in<br><br>some faint earthly symbol.  So in this vale of Death, God girds us<br><br>round; and over all our gloom, the sun of Righteousness still shines<br><br>a beacon and a hope.  If we bend down our eyes, the dark vale shows<br><br>her mouldy soil; but if we lift them, the bright sun meets our glance<br><br>half way, to cheer. I will quit it, lest Truth shake me falsely."<br><br><br><br>"There now's the old Mogul," soliloquized Stubb by the try-works,<br><br>"he's been twigging it; and there goes Starbuck from the same, and<br><br>both with faces which I should say might be somewhere within nine<br><br>fathoms long. Pity if there is nothing wonderful in signs,<br><br>and significant in wonders!  There's a clue somewhere; wait a bit;<br><br>hist--hark!  By Jove, I have it! Caw!<br><br>caw! caw! caw! caw! caw!  Ain't I a crow?  And where's the<br><br>scare-crow?  There he stands; two bones stuck into a pair of old<br><br>trowsers, and two more poked into the sleeves of an old jacket."<br><br><br><br>"Wonder if he means me?--complimentary!--poor lad!--I could go hang<br><br>myself.  Any way, for the present, I'll quit Pip's vicinity.  I can<br><br>stand the rest, for they have plain wits; but he's too crazy-witty<br><br>for my sanity.  So, so, I leave him muttering."<br><br><br><br>"Here's the ship's navel, this doubloon here, and they are all on<br><br>fire to unscrew it.  But, unscrew your navel, and what's the<br><br>consequence?  Then again, if it stays here, that is ugly, too, for<br><br>when aught's nailed to the mast it's a sign that things grow<br><br>desperate.  Ha, ha! old Ahab! the White Whale; he'll nail ye!  This<br><br>is a pine tree.  My father, in old Tolland county, cut down a pine<br><br>tree once, and found a silver ring grown over in it; some old<br><br>darkey's wedding ring.  How did it get there?  And so they'll say in<br><br>the resurrection, when they come to fish up this old mast, and find a<br><br>doubloon lodged in it, with bedded oysters for the shaggy bark.  Oh,<br><br>the gold! the precious, precious, gold! the green miser'll hoard ye<br><br>soon!  Hish! hish!  God goes 'mong the worlds blackberrying.  Cook!<br><br>ho, cook! and cook us!  Jenny! hey, hey, hey, hey, hey, Jenny, Jenny!<br><br>and get your hoe-cake done!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 100<br><br><br><br>Leg and Arm.<br><br><br><br>The Pequod, of Nantucket, Meets the Samuel Enderby, of London.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"Ship, ahoy!  Hast seen the White Whale?"<br><br><br><br>So cried Ahab, once more hailing a ship showing English colours,<br><br>bearing down under the stern.  Trumpet to mouth, the old man was<br><br>standing in his hoisted quarter-boat, his ivory leg plainly revealed<br><br>to the stranger captain, who was carelessly reclining in his own<br><br>boat's bow.  He was a darkly-tanned, burly, good-natured,<br><br>fine-looking man, of sixty or thereabouts, dressed in a spacious<br><br>roundabout, that hung round him in festoons of blue pilot-cloth; and<br><br>one empty arm of this jacket streamed behind him like the broidered<br><br>arm of a hussar's surcoat.<br><br><br><br>"Hast seen the White Whale!"<br><br><br><br>"See you this?" and withdrawing it from the folds that had hidden<br><br>it, he held up a white arm of sperm whale bone, terminating in a<br><br>wooden head like a mallet.<br><br><br><br>"Man my boat!" cried Ahab, impetuously, and tossing about the oars<br><br>near him--"Stand by to lower!"<br><br><br><br>In less than a minute, without quitting his little craft, he and his<br><br>crew were dropped to the water, and were soon alongside of the<br><br>stranger.  But here a curious difficulty presented itself.  In the<br><br>excitement of the moment, Ahab had forgotten that since the loss of<br><br>his leg he had never once stepped on board of any vessel at sea but<br><br>his own, and then it was always by an ingenious and very handy<br><br>mechanical contrivance peculiar to the Pequod, and a thing not to be<br><br>rigged and shipped in any other vessel at a moment's warning.  Now,<br><br>it is no very easy matter for anybody--except those who are almost<br><br>hourly used to it, like whalemen--to clamber up a ship's side from a<br><br>boat on the open sea; for the great swells now lift the boat high up<br><br>towards the bulwarks, and then instantaneously drop it half way down<br><br>to the kelson.  So, deprived of one leg, and the strange ship of<br><br>course being altogether unsupplied with the kindly invention, Ahab<br><br>now found himself abjectly reduced to a clumsy landsman again;<br><br>hopelessly eyeing the uncertain changeful height he could hardly hope<br><br>to attain.<br><br><br><br>It has before been hinted, perhaps, that every little untoward<br><br>circumstance that befell him, and which indirectly sprang from his<br><br>luckless mishap, almost invariably irritated or exasperated Ahab.<br><br>And in the present instance, all this was heightened by the sight of<br><br>the two officers of the strange ship, leaning over the side, by the<br><br>perpendicular ladder of nailed cleets there, and swinging towards him<br><br>a pair of tastefully-ornamented man-ropes; for at first they did not<br><br>seem to bethink them that a one-legged man must be too much of a<br><br>cripple to use their sea bannisters.  But this awkwardness only<br><br>lasted a minute, because the strange captain, observing at a glance<br><br>how affairs stood, cried out, "I see, I see!--avast heaving there!<br><br>Jump, boys, and swing over the cutting-tackle."<br><br><br><br>As good luck would have it, they had had a whale alongside a day or<br><br>two previous, and the great tackles were still aloft, and the massive<br><br>curved blubber-hook, now clean and dry, was still attached to the<br><br>end. He was heading east, I think.--Is your Captain<br><br>crazy?" whispering Fedallah.<br><br><br><br>But Fedallah, putting a finger on his lip, slid over the bulwarks to<br><br>take the boat's steering oar, and Ahab, swinging the cutting-tackle<br><br>towards him, commanded the ship's sailors to stand by to lower.<br><br><br><br>In a moment he was standing in the boat's stern, and the Manilla men<br><br>were springing to their oars.  In vain the English Captain hailed<br><br>him.  With back to the stranger ship, and face set like a flint to<br><br>his own, Ahab stood upright till alongside of the Pequod.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 101<br><br><br><br>The Decanter.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Ere the English ship fades from sight, be it set down here, that she<br><br>hailed from London, and was named after the late Samuel Enderby,<br><br>merchant of that city, the original of the famous whaling house of<br><br>Enderby & Sons; a house which in my poor whaleman's opinion, comes<br><br>not far behind the united royal houses of the Tudors and Bourbons, in<br><br>point of real historical interest.  How long, prior to the year of<br><br>our Lord 1775, this great whaling house was in existence, my numerous<br><br>fish-documents do not make plain; but in that year (1775) it fitted<br><br>out the first English ships that ever regularly hunted the Sperm<br><br>Whale; though for some score of years previous (ever since 1726) our<br><br>valiant Coffins and Maceys of Nantucket and the Vineyard had in large<br><br>fleets pursued that Leviathan, but only in the North and South<br><br>Atlantic: not elsewhere.  Be it distinctly recorded here, that the<br><br>Nantucketers were the first among mankind to harpoon with civilized<br><br>steel the great Sperm Whale; and that for half a century they were<br><br>the only people of the whole globe who so harpooned him.<br><br><br><br>In 1778, a fine ship, the Amelia, fitted out for the express purpose,<br><br>and at the sole charge of the vigorous Enderbys, boldly rounded Cape<br><br>Horn, and was the first among the nations to lower a whale-boat of<br><br>any sort in the great South Sea.  The voyage was a skilful and lucky<br><br>one; and returning to her berth with her hold full of the precious<br><br>sperm, the Amelia's example was soon followed by other ships, English<br><br>and American, and thus the vast Sperm Whale grounds of the Pacific<br><br>were thrown open.  But not content with this good deed, the<br><br>indefatigable house again bestirred itself: Samuel and all his<br><br>Sons--how many, their mother only knows--and under their immediate<br><br>auspices, and partly, I think, at their expense, the British<br><br>government was induced to send the sloop-of-war Rattler on a whaling<br><br>voyage of discovery into the South Sea.  Commanded by a naval<br><br>Post-Captain, the Rattler made a rattling voyage of it, and did some<br><br>service; how much does not appear.  But this is not all.  In 1819,<br><br>the same house fitted out a discovery whale ship of their own, to go<br><br>on a tasting cruise to the remote waters of Japan.  That ship--well<br><br>called the "Syren"--made a noble experimental cruise; and it was thus<br><br>that the great Japanese Whaling Ground first became generally known.<br><br>The Syren in this famous voyage was commanded by a Captain Coffin, a<br><br>Nantucketer.<br><br><br><br>All honour to the Enderbies, therefore, whose house, I think, exists<br><br>to the present day; though doubtless the original Samuel must long<br><br>ago have slipped his cable for the great South Sea of the other<br><br>world.<br><br><br><br>The ship named after him was worthy of the honour, being a very fast<br><br>sailer and a noble craft every way.  I boarded her once at midnight<br><br>somewhere off the Patagonian coast, and drank good flip down in the<br><br>forecastle.  It was a fine gam we had, and they were all<br><br>trumps--every soul on board.  A short life to them, and a jolly<br><br>death.  And that fine gam I had--long, very long after old Ahab<br><br>touched her planks with his ivory heel--it minds me of the noble,<br><br>solid, Saxon hospitality of that ship; and may my parson forget me,<br><br>and the devil remember me, if I ever lose sight of it.  Flip?  Did I<br><br>say we had flip?  Yes, and we flipped it at the rate of ten gallons<br><br>the hour; and when the squall came (for it's squally off there by<br><br>Patagonia), and all hands--visitors and all--were called to reef<br><br>topsails, we were so top-heavy that we had to swing each other aloft<br><br>in bowlines; and we ignorantly furled the skirts of our jackets into<br><br>the sails, so that we hung there, reefed fast in the howling gale, a<br><br>warning example to all drunken tars.  However, the masts did not go<br><br>overboard; and by and by we scrambled down, so sober, that we had to<br><br>pass the flip again, though the savage salt spray bursting down the<br><br>forecastle scuttle, rather too much diluted and pickled it to my<br><br>taste.<br><br><br><br>The beef was fine--tough, but with body in it.  They said it was<br><br>bull-beef; others, that it was dromedary beef; but I do not know, for<br><br>certain, how that was.  They had dumplings too; small, but<br><br>substantial, symmetrically globular, and indestructible dumplings.  I<br><br>fancied that you could feel them, and roll them about in you after<br><br>they were swallowed.  If you stooped over too far forward, you risked<br><br>their pitching out of you like billiard-balls.  The bread--but that<br><br>couldn't be helped; besides, it was an anti-scorbutic; in short, the<br><br>bread contained the only fresh fare they had.  But the forecastle was<br><br>not very light, and it was very easy to step over into a dark corner<br><br>when you ate it.  But all in all, taking her from truck to helm,<br><br>considering the dimensions of the cook's boilers, including his own<br><br>live parchment boilers; fore and aft, I say, the Samuel Enderby was a<br><br>jolly ship; of good fare and plenty; fine flip and strong; crack<br><br>fellows all, and capital from boot heels to hat-band.<br><br><br><br>But why was it, think ye, that the Samuel Enderby, and some other<br><br>English whalers I know of--not all though--were such famous,<br><br>hospitable ships; that passed round the beef, and the bread, and the<br><br>can, and the joke; and were not soon weary of eating, and drinking,<br><br>and laughing?  I will tell you.  The abounding good cheer of these<br><br>English whalers is matter for historical research.  Nor have I been<br><br>at all sparing of historical whale research, when it has seemed<br><br>needed.<br><br><br><br>The English were preceded in the whale fishery by the Hollanders,<br><br>Zealanders, and Danes; from whom they derived many terms still extant<br><br>in the fishery; and what is yet more, their fat old fashions,<br><br>touching plenty to eat and drink.  For, as a general thing, the<br><br>English merchant-ship scrimps her crew; but not so the English<br><br>whaler.  Hence, in the English, this thing of whaling good cheer is<br><br>not normal and natural, but incidental and particular; and,<br><br>therefore, must have some special origin, which is here pointed out,<br><br>and will be still further elucidated.<br><br><br><br>During my researches in the Leviathanic histories, I stumbled upon an<br><br>ancient Dutch volume, which, by the musty whaling smell of it, I knew<br><br>must be about whalers.  The title was, "Dan Coopman," wherefore I<br><br>concluded that this must be the invaluable memoirs of some Amsterdam<br><br>cooper in the fishery, as every whale ship must carry its cooper.  I<br><br>was reinforced in this opinion by seeing that it was the production<br><br>of one "Fitz Swackhammer."  But my friend Dr. Snodhead, a very<br><br>learned man, professor of Low Dutch and High German in the college of<br><br>Santa Claus and St. Pott's, to whom I handed the work for<br><br>translation, giving him a box of sperm candles for his trouble--this<br><br>same Dr. Snodhead, so soon as he spied the book, assured me that "Dan<br><br>Coopman" did not mean "The Cooper," but "The Merchant."  In short,<br><br>this ancient and learned Low Dutch book treated of the commerce of<br><br>Holland; and, among other subjects, contained a very interesting<br><br>account of its whale fishery.  And in this chapter it was, headed,<br><br>"Smeer," or "Fat," that I found a long detailed list of the outfits<br><br>for the larders and cellars of 180 sail of Dutch whalemen; from which<br><br>list, as translated by Dr. Snodhead, I transcribe the following:<br><br><br><br>400,000 lbs. of beef.<br><br>60,000 lbs. Friesland pork.<br><br>150,000 lbs. of stock fish.<br><br>550,000 lbs. of biscuit.<br><br>72,000 lbs. of soft bread.<br><br>2,800 firkins of butter.<br><br>20,000 lbs. Texel & Leyden cheese.<br><br>144,000 lbs. cheese (probably an inferior article).<br><br>550 ankers of Geneva.<br><br>10,800 barrels of beer.<br><br><br><br>Most statistical tables are parchingly dry in the reading; not so in<br><br>the present case, however, where the reader is flooded with whole<br><br>pipes, barrels, quarts, and gills of good gin and good cheer.<br><br><br><br>At the time, I devoted three days to the studious digesting of all<br><br>this beer, beef, and bread, during which many profound thoughts were<br><br>incidentally suggested to me, capable of a transcendental and<br><br>Platonic application; and, furthermore, I compiled supplementary<br><br>tables of my own, touching the probable quantity of stock-fish, etc.,<br><br>consumed by every Low Dutch harpooneer in that ancient Greenland and<br><br>Spitzbergen whale fishery.  In the first place, the amount of butter,<br><br>and Texel and Leyden cheese consumed, seems amazing.  I impute it,<br><br>though, to their naturally unctuous natures, being rendered still<br><br>more unctuous by the nature of their vocation, and especially by<br><br>their pursuing their game in those frigid Polar Seas, on the very<br><br>coasts of that Esquimaux country where the convivial natives pledge<br><br>each other in bumpers of train oil.<br><br><br><br>The quantity of beer, too, is very large, 10,800 barrels.  Now,<br><br>as those polar fisheries could only be prosecuted in the short summer<br><br>of that climate, so that the whole cruise of one of these Dutch<br><br>whalemen, including the short voyage to and from the Spitzbergen sea,<br><br>did not much exceed three months, say, and reckoning 30 men to each<br><br>of their fleet of 180 sail, we have 5,400 Low Dutch seamen in all;<br><br>therefore, I say, we have precisely two barrels of beer per man, for<br><br>a twelve weeks' allowance, exclusive of his fair proportion of that<br><br>550 ankers of gin.  Now, whether these gin and beer harpooneers, so<br><br>fuddled as one might fancy them to have been, were the right sort of<br><br>men to stand up in a boat's head, and take good aim at flying whales;<br><br>this would seem somewhat improbable.  Yet they did aim at them, and<br><br>hit them too.  But this was very far North, be it remembered, where<br><br>beer agrees well with the constitution; upon the Equator, in our<br><br>southern fishery, beer would be apt to make the harpooneer sleepy at<br><br>the mast-head and boozy in his boat; and grievous loss might ensue to<br><br>Nantucket and New Bedford.<br><br><br><br>But no more; enough has been said to show that the old Dutch whalers<br><br>of two or three centuries ago were high livers; and that the English<br><br>whalers have not neglected so excellent an example.  For, say they,<br><br>when cruising in an empty ship, if you can get nothing better out of<br><br>the world, get a good dinner out of it, at least.  And this empties<br><br>the decanter.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 102<br><br><br><br>A Bower in the Arsacides.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Hitherto, in descriptively treating of the Sperm Whale, I have<br><br>chiefly dwelt upon the marvels of his outer aspect; or separately and<br><br>in detail upon some few interior structural features.  But to a large<br><br>and thorough sweeping comprehension of him, it behooves me now to<br><br>unbutton him still further, and untagging the points of his hose,<br><br>unbuckling his garters, and casting loose the hooks and the eyes of<br><br>the joints of his innermost bones, set him before you in his<br><br>ultimatum; that is to say, in his unconditional skeleton.<br><br><br><br>But how now, Ishmael?  How is it, that you, a mere oarsman in the<br><br>fishery, pretend to know aught about the subterranean parts of the<br><br>whale?  Did erudite Stubb, mounted upon your capstan, deliver<br><br>lectures on the anatomy of the Cetacea; and by help of the windlass,<br><br>hold up a specimen rib for exhibition?  Explain thyself, Ishmael.<br><br>Can you land a full-grown whale on your deck for examination, as a<br><br>cook dishes a roast-pig?  Surely not.  A veritable witness have you<br><br>hitherto been, Ishmael; but have a care how you seize the privilege<br><br>of Jonah alone; the privilege of discoursing upon the joists and<br><br>beams; the rafters, ridge-pole, sleepers, and under-pinnings, making<br><br>up the frame-work of leviathan; and belike of the tallow-vats,<br><br>dairy-rooms, butteries, and cheeseries in his bowels.<br><br><br><br>I confess, that since Jonah, few whalemen have penetrated very far<br><br>beneath the skin of the adult whale; nevertheless, I have been<br><br>blessed with an opportunity to dissect him in miniature.  In a ship I<br><br>belonged to, a small cub Sperm Whale was once bodily hoisted to the<br><br>deck for his poke or bag, to make sheaths for the barbs of the<br><br>harpoons, and for the heads of the lances.  Think you I let that<br><br>chance go, without using my boat-hatchet and jack-knife, and breaking<br><br>the seal and reading all the contents of that young cub?<br><br><br><br>And as for my exact knowledge of the bones of the leviathan in their<br><br>gigantic, full grown development, for that rare knowledge I am<br><br>indebted to my late royal friend Tranquo, king of Tranque, one of<br><br>the Arsacides.  For being at Tranque, years ago, when attached to the<br><br>trading-ship Dey of Algiers, I was invited to spend part of the<br><br>Arsacidean holidays with the lord of Tranque, at his retired palm<br><br>villa at Pupella; a sea-side glen not very far distant from what our<br><br>sailors called Bamboo-Town, his capital.<br><br><br><br>Among many other fine qualities, my royal friend Tranquo, being<br><br>gifted with a devout love for all matters of barbaric vertu, had<br><br>brought together in Pupella whatever rare things the more ingenious<br><br>of his people could invent; chiefly carved woods of wonderful<br><br>devices, chiselled shells, inlaid spears, costly paddles, aromatic<br><br>canoes; and all these distributed among whatever natural wonders, the<br><br>wonder-freighted, tribute-rendering waves had cast upon his shores.<br><br><br><br>Chief among these latter was a great Sperm Whale, which, after an<br><br>unusually long raging gale, had been found dead and stranded, with<br><br>his head against a cocoa-nut tree, whose plumage-like, tufted<br><br>droopings seemed his verdant jet.  When the vast body had at last<br><br>been stripped of its fathom-deep enfoldings, and the bones become<br><br>dust dry in the sun, then the skeleton was carefully transported up<br><br>the Pupella glen, where a grand temple of lordly palms now sheltered<br><br>it.<br><br><br><br>The ribs were hung with trophies; the vertebrae were carved with<br><br>Arsacidean annals, in strange hieroglyphics; in the skull, the<br><br>priests kept up an unextinguished aromatic flame, so that the mystic<br><br>head again sent forth its vapoury spout; while, suspended from a<br><br>bough, the terrific lower jaw vibrated over all the devotees, like<br><br>the hair-hung sword that so affrighted Damocles.<br><br><br><br>It was a wondrous sight.  The wood was green as mosses of the Icy<br><br>Glen; the trees stood high and haughty, feeling their living sap; the<br><br>industrious earth beneath was as a weaver's loom, with a gorgeous<br><br>carpet on it, whereof the ground-vine tendrils formed the warp and<br><br>woof, and the living flowers the figures.  All the trees, with all<br><br>their laden branches; all the shrubs, and ferns, and grasses; the<br><br>message-carrying air; all these unceasingly were active.  Through the<br><br>lacings of the leaves, the great sun seemed a flying shuttle weaving<br><br>the unwearied verdure.  Oh, busy weaver! unseen weaver!--pause!--one<br><br>word!--whither flows the fabric? what palace may it deck? wherefore<br><br>all these ceaseless toilings?  Speak, weaver!--stay thy hand!--but<br><br>one single word with thee!  Nay--the shuttle flies--the figures float<br><br>from forth the loom; the freshet-rushing carpet for ever slides<br><br>away.  The weaver-god, he weaves; and by that weaving is he deafened,<br><br>that he hears no mortal voice; and by that humming, we, too, who look<br><br>on the loom are deafened; and only when we escape it shall we hear<br><br>the thousand voices that speak through it.  For even so it is in all<br><br>material factories.  The spoken words that are inaudible among the<br><br>flying spindles; those same words are plainly heard without the<br><br>walls, bursting from the opened casements.  Thereby have villainies<br><br>been detected.  Ah, mortal! then, be heedful; for so, in all this din<br><br>of the great world's loom, thy subtlest thinkings may be overheard<br><br>afar.<br><br><br><br>Now, amid the green, life-restless loom of that Arsacidean wood, the<br><br>great, white, worshipped skeleton lay lounging--a gigantic idler!<br><br>Yet, as the ever-woven verdant warp and woof intermixed and hummed<br><br>around him, the mighty idler seemed the cunning weaver; himself all<br><br>woven over with the vines; every month assuming greener, fresher<br><br>verdure; but himself a skeleton.  Life folded Death; Death trellised<br><br>Life; the grim god wived with youthful Life, and begat him<br><br>curly-headed glories.<br><br><br><br>Now, when with royal Tranquo I visited this wondrous whale, and saw<br><br>the skull an altar, and the artificial smoke ascending from where the<br><br>real jet had issued, I marvelled that the king should regard a chapel<br><br>as an object of vertu.  He laughed.  But more I marvelled that the<br><br>priests should swear that smoky jet of his was genuine.  To and fro I<br><br>paced before this skeleton--brushed the vines aside--broke through<br><br>the ribs--and with a ball of Arsacidean twine, wandered, eddied long<br><br>amid its many winding, shaded colonnades and arbours.  But soon my<br><br>line was out; and following it back, I emerged from the opening where I<br><br>entered.  I saw no living thing within; naught was there but bones.<br><br><br><br>Cutting me a green measuring-rod, I once more dived within the<br><br>skeleton.  From their arrow-slit in the skull, the priests perceived<br><br>me taking the altitude of the final rib, "How now!" they shouted;<br><br>"Dar'st thou measure this our god!  That's for us."  "Aye,<br><br>priests--well, how long do ye make him, then?"  But hereupon a fierce<br><br>contest rose among them, concerning feet and inches; they cracked<br><br>each other's sconces with their yard-sticks--the great skull<br><br>echoed--and seizing that lucky chance, I quickly concluded my own<br><br>admeasurements.<br><br><br><br>These admeasurements I now propose to set before you.  But first, be<br><br>it recorded, that, in this matter, I am not free to utter any fancied<br><br>measurement I please.  Because there are skeleton authorities you<br><br>can refer to, to test my accuracy.  There is a Leviathanic Museum,<br><br>they tell me, in Hull, England, one of the whaling ports of that<br><br>country, where they have some fine specimens of fin-backs and other<br><br>whales.  Likewise, I have heard that in the museum of Manchester, in<br><br>New Hampshire, they have what the proprietors call "the only perfect<br><br>specimen of a Greenland or River Whale in the United States."<br><br>Moreover, at a place in Yorkshire, England, Burton Constable by name,<br><br>a certain Sir Clifford Constable has in his possession the skeleton<br><br>of a Sperm Whale, but of moderate size, by no means of the full-grown<br><br>magnitude of my friend King Tranquo's.<br><br><br><br>In both cases, the stranded whales to which these two skeletons<br><br>belonged, were originally claimed by their proprietors upon similar<br><br>grounds.  King Tranquo seizing his because he wanted it; and Sir<br><br>Clifford, because he was lord of the seignories of those parts.  Sir<br><br>Clifford's whale has been articulated throughout; so that, like a<br><br>great chest of drawers, you can open and shut him, in all his bony<br><br>cavities--spread out his ribs like a gigantic fan--and swing all day<br><br>upon his lower jaw.  Locks are to be put upon some of his trap-doors<br><br>and shutters; and a footman will show round future visitors with a<br><br>bunch of keys at his side.  Sir Clifford thinks of charging twopence<br><br>for a peep at the whispering gallery in the spinal column; threepence<br><br>to hear the echo in the hollow of his cerebellum; and sixpence for<br><br>the unrivalled view from his forehead.<br><br><br><br>The skeleton dimensions I shall now proceed to set down are copied<br><br>verbatim from my right arm, where I had them tattooed; as in my wild<br><br>wanderings at that period, there was no other secure way of<br><br>preserving such valuable statistics.  But as I was crowded for space,<br><br>and wished the other parts of my body to remain a blank page for a<br><br>poem I was then composing--at least, what untattooed parts might<br><br>remain--I did not trouble myself with the odd inches; nor, indeed,<br><br>should inches at all enter into a congenial admeasurement of the<br><br>whale.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 103<br><br><br><br>Measurement of The Whale's Skeleton.<br><br><br><br><br><br>In the first place, I wish to lay before you a particular, plain<br><br>statement, touching the living bulk of this leviathan, whose skeleton<br><br>we are briefly to exhibit.  Such a statement may prove useful here.<br><br><br><br>According to a careful calculation I have made, and which I partly<br><br>base upon Captain Scoresby's estimate, of seventy tons for the<br><br>largest sized Greenland whale of sixty feet in length; according to<br><br>my careful calculation, I say, a Sperm Whale of the largest<br><br>magnitude, between eighty-five and ninety feet in length, and<br><br>something less than forty feet in its fullest circumference, such a<br><br>whale will weigh at least ninety tons; so that, reckoning thirteen<br><br>men to a ton, he would considerably outweigh the combined population<br><br>of a whole village of one thousand one hundred inhabitants.<br><br><br><br>Think you not then that brains, like yoked cattle, should be put to<br><br>this leviathan, to make him at all budge to any landsman's<br><br>imagination?<br><br><br><br>Having already in various ways put before you his skull, spout-hole,<br><br>jaw, teeth, tail, forehead, fins, and divers other parts, I shall now<br><br>simply point out what is most interesting in the general bulk of his<br><br>unobstructed bones.  But as the colossal skull embraces so very large<br><br>a proportion of the entire extent of the skeleton; as it is by far<br><br>the most complicated part; and as nothing is to be repeated<br><br>concerning it in this chapter, you must not fail to carry it in your<br><br>mind, or under your arm, as we proceed, otherwise you will not gain a<br><br>complete notion of the general structure we are about to view.<br><br><br><br>In length, the Sperm Whale's skeleton at Tranque measured seventy-two<br><br>Feet; so that when fully invested and extended in life, he must have<br><br>been ninety feet long; for in the whale, the skeleton loses about one<br><br>fifth in length compared with the living body.  Of this seventy-two<br><br>feet, his skull and jaw comprised some twenty feet, leaving some<br><br>fifty feet of plain back-bone.  Attached to this back-bone, for<br><br>something less than a third of its length, was the mighty circular<br><br>basket of ribs which once enclosed his vitals.<br><br><br><br>To me this vast ivory-ribbed chest, with the long, unrelieved spine,<br><br>extending far away from it in a straight line, not a little resembled<br><br>the hull of a great ship new-laid upon the stocks, when only some<br><br>twenty of her naked bow-ribs are inserted, and the keel is otherwise,<br><br>for the time, but a long, disconnected timber.<br><br><br><br>The ribs were ten on a side.  The first, to begin from the neck, was<br><br>nearly six feet long; the second, third, and fourth were each<br><br>successively longer, till you came to the climax of the fifth, or one<br><br>of the middle ribs, which measured eight feet and some inches.  From<br><br>that part, the remaining ribs diminished, till the tenth and last<br><br>only spanned five feet and some inches.  In general thickness, they<br><br>all bore a seemly correspondence to their length.  The middle ribs<br><br>were the most arched.  In some of the Arsacides they are used for<br><br>beams whereon to lay footpath bridges over small streams.<br><br><br><br>In considering these ribs, I could not but be struck anew with the<br><br>circumstance, so variously repeated in this book, that the skeleton<br><br>of the whale is by no means the mould of his invested form.  The<br><br>largest of the Tranque ribs, one of the middle ones, occupied that<br><br>part of the fish which, in life, is greatest in depth.  Now, the<br><br>greatest depth of the invested body of this particular whale must<br><br>have been at least sixteen feet; whereas, the corresponding rib<br><br>measured but little more than eight feet.  So that this rib only<br><br>conveyed half of the true notion of the living magnitude of that<br><br>part.  Besides, for some way, where I now saw but a naked spine, all<br><br>that had been once wrapped round with tons of added bulk in flesh,<br><br>muscle, blood, and bowels.  Still more, for the ample fins, I here<br><br>saw but a few disordered joints; and in place of the weighty and<br><br>majestic, but boneless flukes, an utter blank!<br><br><br><br>How vain and foolish, then, thought I, for timid untravelled man to<br><br>try to comprehend aright this wondrous whale, by merely poring over<br><br>his dead attenuated skeleton, stretched in this peaceful wood.  No.<br><br>Only in the heart of quickest perils; only when within the eddyings<br><br>of his angry flukes; only on the profound unbounded sea, can the<br><br>fully invested whale be truly and livingly found out.<br><br><br><br>But the spine.  For that, the best way we can consider it is, with a<br><br>crane, to pile its bones high up on end.  No speedy enterprise.  But<br><br>now it's done, it looks much like Pompey's Pillar.<br><br><br><br>There are forty and odd vertebrae in all, which in the skeleton are<br><br>not locked together.  They mostly lie like the great knobbed blocks<br><br>on a Gothic spire, forming solid courses of heavy masonry.  The<br><br>largest, a middle one, is in width something less than three feet,<br><br>and in depth more than four.  The smallest, where the spine tapers<br><br>away into the tail, is only two inches in width, and looks something<br><br>like a white billiard-ball.  I was told that there were still smaller<br><br>ones, but they had been lost by some little cannibal urchins, the<br><br>priest's children, who had stolen them to play marbles with.  Thus we<br><br>see how that the spine of even the hugest of living things tapers off<br><br>at last into simple child's play.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 104<br><br><br><br>The Fossil Whale.<br><br><br><br><br><br>From his mighty bulk the whale affords a most congenial theme whereon<br><br>to enlarge, amplify, and generally expatiate.  Would you, you could<br><br>not compress him.  By good rights he should only be treated of in<br><br>imperial folio.  Not to tell over again his furlongs from spiracle to<br><br>tail, and the yards he measures about the waist; only think of the<br><br>gigantic involutions of his intestines, where they lie in him like<br><br>great cables and hawsers coiled away in the subterranean orlop-deck<br><br>of a line-of-battle-ship.<br><br><br><br>Since I have undertaken to manhandle this Leviathan, it behooves me<br><br>to approve myself omnisciently exhaustive in the enterprise; not<br><br>overlooking the minutest seminal germs of his blood, and spinning him<br><br>out to the uttermost coil of his bowels.  Having already described<br><br>him in most of his present habitatory and anatomical peculiarities,<br><br>it now remains to magnify him in an archaeological, fossiliferous,<br><br>and antediluvian point of view.  Applied to any other creature than<br><br>the Leviathan--to an ant or a flea--such portly terms might justly be<br><br>deemed unwarrantably grandiloquent.  But when Leviathan is the text,<br><br>the case is altered.  Fain am I to stagger to this emprise under<br><br>the weightiest words of the dictionary.  And here be it said, that<br><br>whenever it has been convenient to consult one in the course of these<br><br>dissertations, I have invariably used a huge quarto edition of<br><br>Johnson, expressly purchased for that purpose; because that famous<br><br>lexicographer's uncommon personal bulk more fitted him to compile a<br><br>lexicon to be used by a whale author like me.<br><br><br><br>One often hears of writers that rise and swell with their subject,<br><br>though it may seem but an ordinary one.  How, then, with me, writing<br><br>of this Leviathan?  Unconsciously my chirography expands into placard<br><br>capitals.  Give me a condor's quill!  Give me Vesuvius' crater for an<br><br>inkstand!  Friends, hold my arms!  For in the mere act of penning my<br><br>thoughts of this Leviathan, they weary me, and make me faint with<br><br>their outreaching comprehensiveness of sweep, as if to include the<br><br>whole circle of the sciences, and all the generations of whales, and<br><br>men, and mastodons, past, present, and to come, with all the<br><br>revolving panoramas of empire on earth, and throughout the whole<br><br>universe, not excluding its suburbs.  Such, and so magnifying, is the<br><br>virtue of a large and liberal theme!  We expand to its bulk.  To<br><br>produce a mighty book, you must choose a mighty theme.  No great and<br><br>enduring volume can ever be written on the flea, though many there be<br><br>who have tried it.<br><br><br><br>Ere entering upon the subject of Fossil Whales, I present my<br><br>credentials as a geologist, by stating that in my miscellaneous time<br><br>I have been a stone-mason, and also a great digger of ditches,<br><br>canals and wells, wine-vaults, cellars, and cisterns of all sorts.<br><br>Likewise, by way of preliminary, I desire to remind the reader, that<br><br>while in the earlier geological strata there are found the fossils of<br><br>monsters now almost completely extinct; the subsequent relics<br><br>discovered in what are called the Tertiary formations seem the<br><br>connecting, or at any rate intercepted links, between the<br><br>antichronical creatures, and those whose remote posterity are said to<br><br>have entered the Ark; all the Fossil Whales hitherto discovered<br><br>belong to the Tertiary period, which is the last preceding the<br><br>superficial formations.  And though none of them precisely answer to<br><br>any known species of the present time, they are yet sufficiently akin<br><br>to them in general respects, to justify their taking rank as<br><br>Cetacean fossils.<br><br><br><br>Detached broken fossils of pre-adamite whales, fragments of their<br><br>bones and skeletons, have within thirty years past, at various<br><br>intervals, been found at the base of the Alps, in Lombardy, in<br><br>France, in England, in Scotland, and in the States of Louisiana,<br><br>Mississippi, and Alabama.  Among the more curious of such remains is<br><br>part of a skull, which in the year 1779 was disinterred in the Rue<br><br>Dauphine in Paris, a short street opening almost directly upon the<br><br>palace of the Tuileries; and bones disinterred in excavating the<br><br>great docks of Antwerp, in Napoleon's time.  Cuvier pronounced these<br><br>fragments to have belonged to some utterly unknown Leviathanic<br><br>species.<br><br><br><br>But by far the most wonderful of all Cetacean relics was the almost<br><br>complete vast skeleton of an extinct monster, found in the year 1842,<br><br>on the plantation of Judge Creagh, in Alabama.  The awe-stricken<br><br>credulous slaves in the vicinity took it for the bones of one of the<br><br>fallen angels.  The Alabama doctors declared it a huge reptile, and<br><br>bestowed upon it the name of Basilosaurus.  But some specimen bones<br><br>of it being taken across the sea to Owen, the English Anatomist, it<br><br>turned out that this alleged reptile was a whale, though of a<br><br>departed species.  A significant illustration of the fact, again and<br><br>again repeated in this book, that the skeleton of the whale furnishes<br><br>but little clue to the shape of his fully invested body.  So Owen<br><br>rechristened the monster Zeuglodon; and in his paper read before the<br><br>London Geological Society, pronounced it, in substance, one of the<br><br>most extraordinary creatures which the mutations of the globe have<br><br>blotted out of existence.<br><br><br><br>When I stand among these mighty Leviathan skeletons, skulls, tusks,<br><br>jaws, ribs, and vertebrae, all characterized by partial resemblances<br><br>to the existing breeds of sea-monsters; but at the same time bearing<br><br>on the other hand similar affinities to the annihilated antichronical<br><br>Leviathans, their incalculable seniors; I am, by a flood, borne back<br><br>to that wondrous period, ere time itself can be said to have begun;<br><br>for time began with man.  Here Saturn's grey chaos rolls over me, and<br><br>I obtain dim, shuddering glimpses into those Polar eternities; when<br><br>wedged bastions of ice pressed hard upon what are now the Tropics;<br><br>and in all the 25,000 miles of this world's circumference, not an<br><br>inhabitable hand's breadth of land was visible.  Then the whole world<br><br>was the whale's; and, king of creation, he left his wake along the<br><br>present lines of the Andes and the Himmalehs.  Who can show a<br><br>pedigree like Leviathan?  Ahab's harpoon had shed older blood than<br><br>the Pharaoh's.  Methuselah seems a school-boy.  I look round to shake<br><br>hands with Shem.  I am horror-struck at this antemosaic, unsourced<br><br>existence of the unspeakable terrors of the whale, which, having been<br><br>before all time, must needs exist after all humane ages are over.<br><br><br><br>But not alone has this Leviathan left his pre-adamite traces in the<br><br>stereotype plates of nature, and in limestone and marl bequeathed his<br><br>ancient bust; but upon Egyptian tablets, whose antiquity seems to<br><br>claim for them an almost fossiliferous character, we find the<br><br>unmistakable print of his fin.  In an apartment of the great temple<br><br>of Denderah, some fifty years ago, there was discovered upon the<br><br>granite ceiling a sculptured and painted planisphere, abounding in<br><br>centaurs, griffins, and dolphins, similar to the grotesque figures<br><br>on the celestial globe of the moderns.
