Gliding among them, old<br><br>Leviathan swam as of yore; was there swimming in that planisphere,<br><br>centuries before Solomon was cradled.<br><br><br><br>Nor must there be omitted another strange attestation of the<br><br>antiquity of the whale, in his own osseous post-diluvian reality, as<br><br>set down by the venerable John Leo, the old Barbary traveller.<br><br><br><br>"Not far from the Sea-side, they have a Temple, the Rafters and Beams<br><br>of which are made of Whale-Bones; for Whales of a monstrous size are<br><br>oftentimes cast up dead upon that shore.  The Common People imagine,<br><br>that by a secret Power bestowed by God upon the temple, no Whale can<br><br>pass it without immediate death.  But the truth of the Matter is,<br><br>that on either side of the Temple, there are Rocks that shoot two<br><br>Miles into the Sea, and wound the Whales when they light upon 'em.<br><br>They keep a Whale's Rib of an incredible length for a Miracle, which<br><br>lying upon the Ground with its convex part uppermost, makes an Arch,<br><br>the Head of which cannot be reached by a Man upon a Camel's Back.<br><br>This Rib (says John Leo) is said to have layn there a hundred Years<br><br>before I saw it.  Their Historians affirm, that a Prophet who<br><br>prophesy'd of Mahomet, came from this Temple, and some do not stand<br><br>to assert, that the Prophet Jonas was cast forth by the Whale at the<br><br>Base of the Temple."<br><br><br><br>In this Afric Temple of the Whale I leave you, reader, and if you be<br><br>a Nantucketer, and a whaleman, you will silently worship there.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 105<br><br><br><br>Does the Whale's Magnitude Diminish?--Will He Perish?<br><br><br><br><br><br>Inasmuch, then, as this Leviathan comes floundering down upon us from<br><br>the head-waters of the Eternities, it may be fitly inquired, whether,<br><br>in the long course of his generations, he has not degenerated from<br><br>the original bulk of his sires.<br><br><br><br>But upon investigation we find, that not only are the whales of the<br><br>present day superior in magnitude to those whose fossil remains are<br><br>found in the Tertiary system (embracing a distinct geological period<br><br>prior to man), but of the whales found in that Tertiary system, those<br><br>belonging to its latter formations exceed in size those of its<br><br>earlier ones.<br><br><br><br>Of all the pre-adamite whales yet exhumed, by far the largest is the<br><br>Alabama one mentioned in the last chapter, and that was less than<br><br>seventy feet in length in the skeleton.  Whereas, we have already<br><br>seen, that the tape-measure gives seventy-two feet for the skeleton<br><br>of a large sized modern whale.  And I have heard, on whalemen's<br><br>authority, that Sperm Whales have been captured near a hundred feet<br><br>long at the time of capture.<br><br><br><br>But may it not be, that while the whales of the present hour are an<br><br>advance in magnitude upon those of all previous geological periods;<br><br>may it not be, that since Adam's time they have degenerated?<br><br><br><br>Assuredly, we must conclude so, if we are to credit the accounts of<br><br>such gentlemen as Pliny, and the ancient naturalists generally.  For<br><br>Pliny tells us of Whales that embraced acres of living bulk, and<br><br>Aldrovandus of others which measured eight hundred feet in<br><br>length--Rope Walks and Thames Tunnels of Whales!  And even in the<br><br>days of Banks and Solander, Cooke's naturalists, we find a Danish<br><br>member of the Academy of Sciences setting down certain Iceland Whales<br><br>(reydan-siskur, or Wrinkled Bellies) at one hundred and twenty yards;<br><br>that is, three hundred and sixty feet.  And Lacepede, the French<br><br>naturalist, in his elaborate history of whales, in the very beginning<br><br>of his work (page 3), sets down the Right Whale at one hundred<br><br>metres, three hundred and twenty-eight feet.  And this work was<br><br>published so late as A.D. 1825.<br><br><br><br>But will any whaleman believe these stories?  No.  The whale of<br><br>to-day is as big as his ancestors in Pliny's time.  And if ever I go<br><br>where Pliny is, I, a whaleman (more than he was), will make bold to<br><br>tell him so.  Because I cannot understand how it is, that while the<br><br>Egyptian mummies that were buried thousands of years before even<br><br>Pliny was born, do not measure so much in their coffins as a modern<br><br>Kentuckian in his socks; and while the cattle and other animals<br><br>sculptured on the oldest Egyptian and Nineveh tablets, by the<br><br>relative proportions in which they are drawn, just as plainly prove<br><br>that the high-bred, stall-fed, prize cattle of Smithfield, not only<br><br>equal, but far exceed in magnitude the fattest of Pharaoh's fat kine;<br><br>in the face of all this, I will not admit that of all animals the<br><br>whale alone should have degenerated.<br><br><br><br>But still another inquiry remains; one often agitated by the more<br><br>recondite Nantucketers.  Whether owing to the almost omniscient<br><br>look-outs at the mast-heads of the whaleships, now penetrating even<br><br>through Behring's straits, and into the remotest secret drawers and<br><br>lockers of the world; and the thousand harpoons and lances darted<br><br>along all continental coasts; the moot point is, whether Leviathan<br><br>can long endure so wide a chase, and so remorseless a havoc; whether<br><br>he must not at last be exterminated from the waters, and the last<br><br>whale, like the last man, smoke his last pipe, and then himself<br><br>evaporate in the final puff.<br><br><br><br>Comparing the humped herds of whales with the humped herds of<br><br>buffalo, which, not forty years ago, overspread by tens of thousands<br><br>the prairies of Illinois and Missouri, and shook their iron manes and<br><br>scowled with their thunder-clotted brows upon the sites of populous<br><br>river-capitals, where now the polite broker sells you land at a<br><br>dollar an inch; in such a comparison an irresistible argument would<br><br>seem furnished, to show that the hunted whale cannot now escape<br><br>speedy extinction.<br><br><br><br>But you must look at this matter in every light.  Though so short a<br><br>period ago--not a good lifetime--the census of the buffalo in<br><br>Illinois exceeded the census of men now in London, and though at the<br><br>present day not one horn or hoof of them remains in all that region;<br><br>and though the cause of this wondrous extermination was the spear of<br><br>man; yet the far different nature of the whale-hunt peremptorily<br><br>forbids so inglorious an end to the Leviathan.  Forty men in one ship<br><br>hunting the Sperm Whales for forty-eight months think they have done<br><br>extremely well, and thank God, if at last they carry home the oil of<br><br>forty fish.  Whereas, in the days of the old Canadian and Indian<br><br>hunters and trappers of the West, when the far west (in whose sunset<br><br>suns still rise) was a wilderness and a virgin, the same number of<br><br>moccasined men, for the same number of months, mounted on horse<br><br>instead of sailing in ships, would have slain not forty, but forty<br><br>thousand and more buffaloes; a fact that, if need were, could be<br><br>statistically stated.<br><br><br><br>Nor, considered aright, does it seem any argument in favour of the<br><br>gradual extinction of the Sperm Whale, for example, that in former<br><br>years (the latter part of the last century, say) these Leviathans, in<br><br>small pods, were encountered much oftener than at present, and, in<br><br>consequence, the voyages were not so prolonged, and were also much<br><br>more remunerative.  Because, as has been elsewhere noticed, those<br><br>whales, influenced by some views to safety, now swim the seas in<br><br>immense caravans, so that to a large degree the scattered solitaries,<br><br>yokes, and pods, and schools of other days are now aggregated into<br><br>vast but widely separated, unfrequent armies.  That is all.  And<br><br>equally fallacious seems the conceit, that because the so-called<br><br>whale-bone whales no longer haunt many grounds in former years<br><br>abounding with them, hence that species also is declining.  For they<br><br>are only being driven from promontory to cape; and if one coast is no<br><br>longer enlivened with their jets, then, be sure, some other and<br><br>remoter strand has been very recently startled by the unfamiliar<br><br>spectacle.<br><br><br><br>Furthermore: concerning these last mentioned Leviathans, they have<br><br>two firm fortresses, which, in all human probability, will for ever<br><br>remain impregnable.  And as upon the invasion of their valleys, the<br><br>frosty Swiss have retreated to their mountains; so, hunted from the<br><br>savannas and glades of the middle seas, the whale-bone whales can at<br><br>last resort to their Polar citadels, and diving under the ultimate<br><br>glassy barriers and walls there, come up among icy fields and floes;<br><br>and in a charmed circle of everlasting December, bid defiance to all<br><br>pursuit from man.<br><br><br><br>But as perhaps fifty of these whale-bone whales are harpooned for one<br><br>cachalot, some philosophers of the forecastle have concluded that<br><br>this positive havoc has already very seriously diminished their<br><br>battalions.  But though for some time past a number of these whales,<br><br>not less than 13,000, have been annually slain on the nor'-west<br><br>coast by the Americans alone; yet there are considerations which<br><br>render even this circumstance of little or no account as an opposing<br><br>argument in this matter.<br><br><br><br>Natural as it is to be somewhat incredulous concerning the<br><br>populousness of the more enormous creatures of the globe, yet what<br><br>shall we say to Harto, the historian of Goa, when he tells us that at<br><br>one hunting the King of Siam took 4,000 elephants; that in those<br><br>regions elephants are numerous as droves of cattle in the temperate<br><br>climes.  And there seems no reason to doubt that if these elephants,<br><br>which have now been hunted for thousands of years, by Semiramis, by<br><br>Porus, by Hannibal, and by all the successive monarchs of the<br><br>East--if they still survive there in great numbers, much more may the<br><br>great whale outlast all hunting, since he has a pasture to expatiate<br><br>in, which is precisely twice as large as all Asia, both Americas,<br><br>Europe and Africa, New Holland, and all the Isles of the sea<br><br>combined.<br><br><br><br>Moreover: we are to consider, that from the presumed great longevity<br><br>of whales, their probably attaining the age of a century and more,<br><br>therefore at any one period of time, several distinct adult<br><br>generations must be contemporary.  And what that is, we may soon<br><br>gain some idea of, by imagining all the grave-yards, cemeteries, and<br><br>family vaults of creation yielding up the live bodies of all the men,<br><br>women, and children who were alive seventy-five years ago; and adding<br><br>this countless host to the present human population of the globe.<br><br><br><br>Wherefore, for all these things, we account the whale immortal in his<br><br>species, however perishable in his individuality.  He swam the seas<br><br>before the continents broke water; he once swam over the site of the<br><br>Tuileries, and Windsor Castle, and the Kremlin.  In Noah's flood he<br><br>despised Noah's Ark; and if ever the world is to be again flooded,<br><br>like the Netherlands, to kill off its rats, then the eternal whale<br><br>will still survive, and rearing upon the topmost crest of the<br><br>equatorial flood, spout his frothed defiance to the skies.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 106<br><br><br><br>Ahab's Leg.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The precipitating manner in which Captain Ahab had quitted the Samuel<br><br>Enderby of London, had not been unattended with some small violence<br><br>to his own person.  He had lighted with such energy upon a thwart of<br><br>his boat that his ivory leg had received a half-splintering shock.<br><br>And when after gaining his own deck, and his own pivot-hole there, he<br><br>so vehemently wheeled round with an urgent command to the steersman<br><br>(it was, as ever, something about his not steering inflexibly<br><br>enough); then, the already shaken ivory received such an additional<br><br>twist and wrench, that though it still remained entire, and to all<br><br>appearances lusty, yet Ahab did not deem it entirely trustworthy.<br><br><br><br>And, indeed, it seemed small matter for wonder, that for all his<br><br>pervading, mad recklessness, Ahab did at times give careful heed to<br><br>the condition of that dead bone upon which he partly stood.  For it<br><br>had not been very long prior to the Pequod's sailing from Nantucket,<br><br>that he had been found one night lying prone upon the ground, and<br><br>insensible; by some unknown, and seemingly inexplicable, unimaginable<br><br>casualty, his ivory limb having been so violently displaced, that it<br><br>had stake-wise smitten, and all but pierced his groin; nor was it<br><br>without extreme difficulty that the agonizing wound was entirely<br><br>cured.<br><br><br><br>Nor, at the time, had it failed to enter his monomaniac mind, that<br><br>all the anguish of that then present suffering was but the direct<br><br>issue of a former woe; and he too plainly seemed to see, that as the<br><br>most poisonous reptile of the marsh perpetuates his kind as<br><br>inevitably as the sweetest songster of the grove; so, equally with<br><br>every felicity, all miserable events do naturally beget their like.<br><br>Yea, more than equally, thought Ahab; since both the ancestry and<br><br>posterity of Grief go further than the ancestry and posterity of Joy.<br><br>For, not to hint of this: that it is an inference from certain<br><br>canonic teachings, that while some natural enjoyments here shall have<br><br>no children born to them for the other world, but, on the contrary,<br><br>shall be followed by the joy-childlessness of all hell's despair;<br><br>whereas, some guilty mortal miseries shall still fertilely beget to<br><br>themselves an eternally progressive progeny of griefs beyond the<br><br>grave; not at all to hint of this, there still seems an inequality in<br><br>the deeper analysis of the thing.  For, thought Ahab, while even the<br><br>highest earthly felicities ever have a certain unsignifying pettiness<br><br>lurking in them, but, at bottom, all heartwoes, a mystic<br><br>significance, and, in some men, an archangelic grandeur; so do their<br><br>diligent tracings-out not belie the obvious deduction.  To trail the<br><br>genealogies of these high mortal miseries, carries us at last among<br><br>the sourceless primogenitures of the gods; so that, in the face of<br><br>all the glad, hay-making suns, and soft cymballing, round<br><br>harvest-moons, we must needs give in to this: that the gods<br><br>themselves are not for ever glad.  The ineffaceable, sad birth-mark<br><br>in the brow of man, is but the stamp of sorrow in the signers.<br><br><br><br>Unwittingly here a secret has been divulged, which perhaps might more<br><br>properly, in set way, have been disclosed before.  With many other<br><br>particulars concerning Ahab, always had it remained a mystery to<br><br>some, why it was, that for a certain period, both before and after<br><br>the sailing of the Pequod, he had hidden himself away with such<br><br>Grand-Lama-like exclusiveness; and, for that one interval, sought<br><br>speechless refuge, as it were, among the marble senate of the dead.<br><br>Captain Peleg's bruited reason for this thing appeared by no means<br><br>adequate; though, indeed, as touching all Ahab's deeper part, every<br><br>revelation partook more of significant darkness than of explanatory<br><br>light.  But, in the end, it all came out; this one matter did, at<br><br>least.  That direful mishap was at the bottom of his temporary<br><br>recluseness.  And not only this, but to that ever-contracting,<br><br>dropping circle ashore, who, for any reason, possessed the privilege<br><br>of a less banned approach to him; to that timid circle the above<br><br>hinted casualty--remaining, as it did, moodily unaccounted for by<br><br>Ahab--invested itself with terrors, not entirely underived from the<br><br>land of spirits and of wails.  So that, through their zeal for him,<br><br>they had all conspired, so far as in them lay, to muffle up the<br><br>knowledge of this thing from others; and hence it was, that not till<br><br>a considerable interval had elapsed, did it transpire upon the<br><br>Pequod's decks.<br><br><br><br>But be all this as it may; let the unseen, ambiguous synod in the<br><br>air, or the vindictive princes and potentates of fire, have to do or<br><br>not with earthly Ahab, yet, in this present matter of his leg, he<br><br>took plain practical procedures;--he called the carpenter.<br><br><br><br>And when that functionary appeared before him, he bade him without<br><br>delay set about making a new leg, and directed the mates to see him<br><br>supplied with all the studs and joists of jaw-ivory (Sperm Whale)<br><br>which had thus far been accumulated on the voyage, in order that a<br><br>careful selection of the stoutest, clearest-grained stuff might be<br><br>secured.  This done, the carpenter received orders to have the leg<br><br>completed that night; and to provide all the fittings for it,<br><br>independent of those pertaining to the distrusted one in use.<br><br>Moreover, the ship's forge was ordered to be hoisted out of its<br><br>temporary idleness in the hold; and, to accelerate the affair, the<br><br>blacksmith was commanded to proceed at once to the forging of<br><br>whatever iron contrivances might be needed.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 107<br><br><br><br>The Carpenter.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Seat thyself sultanically among the moons of Saturn, and take high<br><br>abstracted man alone; and he seems a wonder, a grandeur, and a woe.<br><br>But from the same point, take mankind in mass, and for the most part,<br><br>they seem a mob of unnecessary duplicates, both contemporary and<br><br>hereditary.  But most humble though he was, and far from furnishing<br><br>an example of the high, humane abstraction; the Pequod's carpenter<br><br>was no duplicate; hence, he now comes in person on this stage.<br><br><br><br>Like all sea-going ship carpenters, and more especially those<br><br>belonging to whaling vessels, he was, to a certain off-handed,<br><br>practical extent, alike experienced in numerous trades and callings<br><br>collateral to his own; the carpenter's pursuit being the ancient and<br><br>outbranching trunk of all those numerous handicrafts which more or<br><br>less have to do with wood as an auxiliary material.  But, besides the<br><br>application to him of the generic remark above, this carpenter of the<br><br>Pequod was singularly efficient in those thousand nameless mechanical<br><br>emergencies continually recurring in a large ship, upon a three or<br><br>four years' voyage, in uncivilized and far-distant seas.  For not to<br><br>speak of his readiness in ordinary duties:--repairing stove boats,<br><br>sprung spars, reforming the shape of clumsy-bladed oars, inserting<br><br>bull's eyes in the deck, or new tree-nails in the side planks, and<br><br>other miscellaneous matters more directly pertaining to his special<br><br>business; he was moreover unhesitatingly expert in all manner of<br><br>conflicting aptitudes, both useful and capricious.<br><br><br><br>The one grand stage where he enacted all his various parts so<br><br>manifold, was his vice-bench; a long rude ponderous table furnished<br><br>with several vices, of different sizes, and both of iron and of wood.<br><br>At all times except when whales were alongside, this bench was<br><br>securely lashed athwartships against the rear of the Try-works.<br><br><br><br>A belaying pin is found too large to be easily inserted into its<br><br>hole: the carpenter claps it into one of his ever-ready vices, and<br><br>straightway files it smaller.  A lost land-bird of strange plumage<br><br>strays on board, and is made a captive: out of clean shaved rods of<br><br>right-whale bone, and cross-beams of sperm whale ivory, the carpenter<br><br>makes a pagoda-looking cage for it.  An oarsman sprains his wrist:<br><br>the carpenter concocts a soothing lotion.  Stubb longed for<br><br>vermillion stars to be painted upon the blade of his every oar;<br><br>screwing each oar in his big vice of wood, the carpenter<br><br>symmetrically supplies the constellation.  A sailor takes a fancy to<br><br>wear shark-bone ear-rings: the carpenter drills his ears.  Another<br><br>has the toothache: the carpenter out pincers, and clapping one hand<br><br>upon his bench bids him be seated there; but the poor fellow<br><br>unmanageably winces under the unconcluded operation; whirling round<br><br>the handle of his wooden vice, the carpenter signs him to clap his<br><br>jaw in that, if he would have him draw the tooth.<br><br><br><br>Thus, this carpenter was prepared at all points, and alike<br><br>indifferent and without respect in all.  Teeth he accounted bits of<br><br>ivory; heads he deemed but top-blocks; men themselves he lightly held<br><br>for capstans.  But while now upon so wide a field thus variously<br><br>accomplished and with such liveliness of expertness in him, too; all<br><br>this would seem to argue some uncommon vivacity of intelligence.  But<br><br>not precisely so.  For nothing was this man more remarkable, than for<br><br>a certain impersonal stolidity as it were; impersonal, I say; for it<br><br>so shaded off into the surrounding infinite of things, that it seemed<br><br>one with the general stolidity discernible in the whole visible<br><br>world; which while pauselessly active in uncounted modes, still<br><br>eternally holds its peace, and ignores you, though you dig<br><br>foundations for cathedrals.  Yet was this half-horrible stolidity in<br><br>him, involving, too, as it appeared, an all-ramifying<br><br>heartlessness;--yet was it oddly dashed at times, with an old,<br><br>crutch-like, antediluvian, wheezing humorousness, not unstreaked now<br><br>and then with a certain grizzled wittiness; such as might have served<br><br>to pass the time during the midnight watch on the bearded forecastle<br><br>of Noah's ark.  Was it that this old carpenter had been a life-long<br><br>wanderer, whose much rolling, to and fro, not only had gathered no<br><br>moss; but what is more, had rubbed off whatever small outward<br><br>clingings might have originally pertained to him?  He was a stript<br><br>abstract; an unfractioned integral; uncompromised as a new-born babe;<br><br>living without premeditated reference to this world or the next.  You<br><br>might almost say, that this strange uncompromisedness in him involved<br><br>a sort of unintelligence; for in his numerous trades, he did not seem<br><br>to work so much by reason or by instinct, or simply because he had<br><br>been tutored to it, or by any intermixture of all these, even or<br><br>uneven; but merely by a kind of deaf and dumb, spontaneous literal<br><br>process.  He was a pure manipulator; his brain, if he had ever had<br><br>one, must have early oozed along into the muscles of his fingers.  He<br><br>was like one of those unreasoning but still highly useful, MULTUM IN<br><br>PARVO, Sheffield contrivances, assuming the exterior--though a little<br><br>swelled--of a common pocket knife; but containing, not only blades of<br><br>various sizes, but also screw-drivers, cork-screws, tweezers, awls,<br><br>pens, rulers, nail-filers, countersinkers.  So, if his superiors<br><br>wanted to use the carpenter for a screw-driver, all they had to do<br><br>was to open that part of him, and the screw was fast: or if for<br><br>tweezers, take him up by the legs, and there they were.<br><br><br><br>Yet, as previously hinted, this omnitooled, open-and-shut carpenter,<br><br>was, after all, no mere machine of an automaton.  If he did not have<br><br>a common soul in him, he had a subtle something that somehow<br><br>anomalously did its duty.  What that was, whether essence of<br><br>quicksilver, or a few drops of hartshorn, there is no telling.  But<br><br>there it was; and there it had abided for now some sixty years or<br><br>more.  And this it was, this same unaccountable, cunning<br><br>life-principle in him; this it was, that kept him a great part of the<br><br>time soliloquizing; but only like an unreasoning wheel, which also<br><br>hummingly soliloquizes; or rather, his body was a sentry-box and this<br><br>soliloquizer on guard there, and talking all the time to keep himself<br><br>awake.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 108<br><br><br><br>Ahab and the Carpenter.<br><br><br><br>The Deck--First Night Watch.<br><br><br><br><br><br>(CARPENTER STANDING BEFORE HIS VICE-BENCH, AND BY THE LIGHT OF TWO<br><br>LANTERNS BUSILY FILING THE IVORY JOIST FOR THE LEG, WHICH JOIST IS<br><br>FIRMLY FIXED IN THE VICE.  SLABS OF IVORY, LEATHER STRAPS, PADS,<br><br>SCREWS, AND VARIOUS TOOLS OF ALL SORTS LYING ABOUT THE BENCH.<br><br>FORWARD, THE RED FLAME OF THE FORGE IS SEEN, WHERE THE BLACKSMITH IS<br><br>AT WORK.)<br><br><br><br><br><br>Drat the file, and drat the bone!  That is hard which should be soft,<br><br>and that is soft which should be hard.  So we go, who file old jaws<br><br>and shinbones.  Let's try another.  Aye, now, this works better<br><br>(SNEEZES).  Halloa, this bone dust is (SNEEZES)--why it's<br><br>(SNEEZES)--yes it's (SNEEZES)--bless my soul, it won't let me speak!<br><br>This is what an old fellow gets now for working in dead lumber.  Saw<br><br>a live tree, and you don't get this dust; amputate a live bone, and<br><br>you don't get it (SNEEZES).  Come, come, you old Smut, there, bear a<br><br>hand, and let's have that ferule and buckle-screw; I'll be ready<br><br>for them presently.  Lucky now (SNEEZES) there's no knee-joint to<br><br>make; that might puzzle a little; but a mere shinbone--why it's<br><br>easy as making hop-poles; only I should like to put a good finish on.<br><br>Time, time; if I but only had the time, I could turn him out as neat<br><br>a leg now as ever (SNEEZES) scraped to a lady in a parlor.  Those<br><br>buckskin legs and calves of legs I've seen in shop windows wouldn't<br><br>compare at all.  They soak water, they do; and of course get<br><br>rheumatic, and have to be doctored (SNEEZES) with washes and lotions,<br><br>just like live legs.  There; before I saw it off, now, I must call his<br><br>old Mogulship, and see whether the length will be all right; too<br><br>short, if anything, I guess.  Ha! that's the heel; we are in luck;<br><br>here he comes, or it's somebody else, that's certain.<br><br><br><br>AHAB (ADVANCING)<br><br><br><br>(DURING THE ENSUING SCENE, THE CARPENTER CONTINUES SNEEZING AT TIMES)<br><br><br><br><br><br>Well, manmaker!<br><br><br><br>Just in time, sir.  If the captain pleases, I will now mark the<br><br>length.  Let me measure, sir.<br><br><br><br>Measured for a leg! good.  Well, it's not the first time.  About it!<br><br>There; keep thy finger on it.  This is a cogent vice thou hast here,<br><br>carpenter; let me feel its grip once.  So, so; it does pinch some.<br><br><br><br>Oh, sir, it will break bones--beware, beware!<br><br><br><br>No fear; I like a good grip; I like to feel something in this<br><br>slippery world that can hold, man.  What's Prometheus about<br><br>there?--the blacksmith, I mean--what's he about?<br><br><br><br>He must be forging the buckle-screw, sir, now.<br><br><br><br>Right.  It's a partnership; he supplies the muscle part.  He makes a<br><br>fierce red flame there!<br><br><br><br>Aye, sir; he must have the white heat for this kind of fine work.<br><br><br><br>Um-m.  So he must.  I do deem it now a most meaning thing, that that<br><br>old Greek, Prometheus, who made men, they say, should have been a<br><br>blacksmith, and animated them with fire; for what's made in fire must<br><br>properly belong to fire; and so hell's probable.  How the soot flies!<br><br>This must be the remainder the Greek made the Africans of.<br><br>Carpenter, when he's through with that buckle, tell him to forge a<br><br>pair of steel shoulder-blades; there's a pedlar aboard with a<br><br>crushing pack.<br><br><br><br>Sir?<br><br><br><br>Hold; while Prometheus is about it, I'll order a complete man after a<br><br>desirable pattern.  Imprimis, fifty feet high in his socks; then,<br><br>chest modelled after the Thames Tunnel; then, legs with roots to 'em,<br><br>to stay in one place; then, arms three feet through the wrist; no<br><br>heart at all, brass forehead, and about a quarter of an acre of fine<br><br>brains; and let me see--shall I order eyes to see outwards?  No, but<br><br>put a sky-light on top of his head to illuminate inwards.  There,<br><br>take the order, and away.<br><br><br><br>Now, what's he speaking about, and who's he speaking to, I should<br><br>like to know?  Shall I keep standing here? (ASIDE).<br><br><br><br>'Tis but indifferent architecture to make a blind dome; here's one.<br><br>No, no, no; I must have a lantern.<br><br><br><br>Ho, ho!  That's it, hey?  Here are two, sir; one will serve my turn.<br><br><br><br>What art thou thrusting that thief-catcher into my face for, man?<br><br>Thrusted light is worse than presented pistols.<br><br><br><br>I thought, sir, that you spoke to carpenter.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Carpenter? why that's--but no;--a very tidy, and, I may say, an<br><br>extremely gentlemanlike sort of business thou art in here,<br><br>carpenter;--or would'st thou rather work in clay?<br><br><br><br>Sir?--Clay? clay, sir?  That's mud; we leave clay to ditchers, sir.<br><br><br><br>The fellow's impious!  What art thou sneezing about?<br><br><br><br>Bone is rather dusty, sir.<br><br><br><br>Take the hint, then; and when thou art dead, never bury thyself under<br><br>living people's noses.<br><br><br><br>Sir?--oh! ah!--I guess so;--yes--dear!<br><br><br><br>Look ye, carpenter, I dare say thou callest thyself a right good<br><br>workmanlike workman, eh?  Well, then, will it speak thoroughly well<br><br>for thy work, if, when I come to mount this leg thou makest, I shall<br><br>nevertheless feel another leg in the same identical place with it;<br><br>that is, carpenter, my old lost leg; the flesh and blood one, I mean.<br><br>Canst thou not drive that old Adam away?<br><br><br><br>Truly, sir, I begin to understand somewhat now.  Yes, I have heard<br><br>something curious on that score, sir; how that a dismasted man never<br><br>entirely loses the feeling of his old spar, but it will be still<br><br>pricking him at times.  May I humbly ask if it be really so, sir?<br><br><br><br>It is, man.  Look, put thy live leg here in the place where mine once<br><br>was; so, now, here is only one distinct leg to the eye, yet two to<br><br>the soul.  Where thou feelest tingling life; there, exactly there,<br><br>there to a hair, do I.  Is't a riddle?<br><br><br><br>I should humbly call it a poser, sir.<br><br><br><br>Hist, then.  How dost thou know that some entire, living, thinking<br><br>thing may not be invisibly and uninterpenetratingly standing<br><br>precisely where thou now standest; aye, and standing there in thy<br><br>spite?  In thy most solitary hours, then, dost thou not fear<br><br>eavesdroppers?  Hold, don't speak!  And if I still feel the smart of<br><br>my crushed leg, though it be now so long dissolved; then, why mayst<br><br>not thou, carpenter, feel the fiery pains of hell for ever, and<br><br>without a body?  Hah!<br><br><br><br>Good Lord!  Truly, sir, if it comes to that, I must calculate over<br><br>again; I think I didn't carry a small figure, sir.<br><br><br><br>Look ye, pudding-heads should never grant premises.--How long before<br><br>the leg is done?<br><br><br><br>Perhaps an hour, sir.<br><br><br><br>Bungle away at it then, and bring it to me (TURNS TO GO).  Oh, Life!<br><br>Here I am, proud as Greek god, and yet standing debtor to this<br><br>blockhead for a bone to stand on!  Cursed be that mortal<br><br>inter-indebtedness which will not do away with ledgers.  I would be<br><br>free as air; and I'm down in the whole world's books.  I am so rich,<br><br>I could have given bid for bid with the wealthiest Praetorians at the<br><br>auction of the Roman empire (which was the world's); and yet I owe<br><br>for the flesh in the tongue I brag with.  By heavens!  I'll get a<br><br>crucible, and into it, and dissolve myself down to one small,<br><br>compendious vertebra.  So.<br><br><br><br>CARPENTER (RESUMING HIS WORK).<br><br><br><br><br><br>Well, well, well!  Stubb knows him best of all, and Stubb always says<br><br>he's queer; says nothing but that one sufficient little word queer;<br><br>he's queer, says Stubb; he's queer--queer, queer; and keeps dinning<br><br>it into Mr. Starbuck all the time--queer--sir--queer, queer, very<br><br>queer.  And here's his leg!  Yes, now that I think of it, here's his<br><br>bedfellow! has a stick of whale's jaw-bone for a wife!  And this is<br><br>his leg; he'll stand on this.  What was that now about one leg<br><br>standing in three places, and all three places standing in one<br><br>hell--how was that?  Oh!  I don't wonder he looked so scornful at me!<br><br>I'm a sort of strange-thoughted sometimes, they say; but that's only<br><br>haphazard-like.  Then, a short, little old body like me, should never<br><br>undertake to wade out into deep waters with tall, heron-built<br><br>captains; the water chucks you under the chin pretty quick, and<br><br>there's a great cry for life-boats.  And here's the heron's leg! long<br><br>and slim, sure enough!  Now, for most folks one pair of legs lasts a<br><br>lifetime, and that must be because they use them mercifully, as a<br><br>tender-hearted old lady uses her roly-poly old coach-horses.  But<br><br>Ahab; oh he's a hard driver.  Look, driven one leg to death, and<br><br>spavined the other for life, and now wears out bone legs by the cord.<br><br>Halloa, there, you Smut! bear a hand there with those screws, and<br><br>let's finish it before the resurrection fellow comes a-calling with<br><br>his horn for all legs, true or false, as brewery-men go round<br><br>collecting old beer barrels, to fill 'em up again.  What a leg this<br><br>is!  It looks like a real live leg, filed down to nothing but the<br><br>core; he'll be standing on this to-morrow; he'll be taking altitudes<br><br>on it.  Halloa!  I almost forgot the little oval slate, smoothed<br><br>ivory, where he figures up the latitude.  So, so; chisel, file, and<br><br>sand-paper, now!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 109<br><br><br><br>Ahab and Starbuck in the Cabin.<br><br><br><br><br><br>According to usage they were pumping the ship next morning; and lo!<br><br>no inconsiderable oil came up with the water; the casks below must<br><br>have sprung a bad leak.  Much concern was shown; and Starbuck went<br><br>down into the cabin to report this unfavourable affair.*<br><br><br><br><br><br>*In Sperm-whalemen with any considerable quantity of oil on board, it<br><br>is a regular semiweekly duty to conduct a hose into the hold, and<br><br>drench the casks with sea-water; which afterwards, at varying<br><br>intervals, is removed by the ship's pumps.  Hereby the casks are<br><br>sought to be kept damply tight; while by the changed character of the<br><br>withdrawn water, the mariners readily detect any serious leakage in<br><br>the precious cargo.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Now, from the South and West the Pequod was drawing nigh to Formosa<br><br>and the Bashee Isles, between which lies one of the tropical outlets<br><br>from the China waters into the Pacific.  And so Starbuck found Ahab<br><br>with a general chart of the oriental archipelagoes spread before him;<br><br>and another separate one representing the long eastern coasts of the<br><br>Japanese islands--Niphon, Matsmai, and Sikoke.  With his snow-white<br><br>new ivory leg braced against the screwed leg of his table, and with a<br><br>long pruning-hook of a jack-knife in his hand, the wondrous old man,<br><br>with his back to the gangway door, was wrinkling his brow, and<br><br>tracing his old courses again.<br><br><br><br>"Who's there?" hearing the footstep at the door, but not turning<br><br>round to it.  "On deck!  Begone!"<br><br><br><br>"Captain Ahab mistakes; it is I.  The oil in the hold is leaking,<br><br>sir.  We must up Burtons and break out."<br><br><br><br>"Up Burtons and break out?  Now that we are nearing Japan; heave-to<br><br>here for a week to tinker a parcel of old hoops?"<br><br><br><br>"Either do that, sir, or waste in one day more oil than we may make<br><br>good in a year.  What we come twenty thousand miles to get is worth<br><br>saving, sir."<br><br><br><br>"So it is, so it is; if we get it."<br><br><br><br>"I was speaking of the oil in the hold, sir."<br><br><br><br>"And I was not speaking or thinking of that at all.  Begone!  Let it<br><br>leak!  I'm all aleak myself.  Aye! leaks in leaks! not only full of<br><br>leaky casks, but those leaky casks are in a leaky ship; and that's a<br><br>far worse plight than the Pequod's, man.  Yet I don't stop to plug my<br><br>leak; for who can find it in the deep-loaded hull; or how hope to<br><br>plug it, even if found, in this life's howling gale?  Starbuck!<br><br>I'll not have the Burtons hoisted."<br><br><br><br>"What will the owners say, sir?"<br><br><br><br>"Let the owners stand on Nantucket beach and outyell the Typhoons.<br><br>What cares Ahab?  Owners, owners?  Thou art always prating to me,<br><br>Starbuck, about those miserly owners, as if the owners were my<br><br>conscience.  But look ye, the only real owner of anything is its<br><br>commander; and hark ye, my conscience is in this ship's keel.--On<br><br>deck!"<br><br><br><br>"Captain Ahab," said the reddening mate, moving further into the<br><br>cabin, with a daring so strangely respectful and cautious that it<br><br>almost seemed not only every way seeking to avoid the slightest<br><br>outward manifestation of itself, but within also seemed more than<br><br>half distrustful of itself; "A better man than I might well pass over<br><br>in thee what he would quickly enough resent in a younger man; aye,<br><br>and in a happier, Captain Ahab."<br><br><br><br>"Devils!  Dost thou then so much as dare to critically think of<br><br>me?--On deck!"<br><br><br><br>"Nay, sir, not yet; I do entreat.  And I do dare, sir--to be<br><br>forbearing!  Shall we not understand each other better than hitherto,<br><br>Captain Ahab?"<br><br><br><br>Ahab seized a loaded musket from the rack (forming part of most<br><br>South-Sea-men's cabin furniture), and pointing it towards Starbuck,<br><br>exclaimed: "There is one God that is Lord over the earth, and one<br><br>Captain that is lord over the Pequod.--On deck!"<br><br><br><br>For an instant in the flashing eyes of the mate, and his fiery<br><br>cheeks, you would have almost thought that he had really received the<br><br>blaze of the levelled tube.  But, mastering his emotion, he half<br><br>calmly rose, and as he quitted the cabin, paused for an instant and<br><br>said: "Thou hast outraged, not insulted me, sir; but for that I ask<br><br>thee not to beware of Starbuck; thou wouldst but laugh; but let Ahab<br><br>beware of Ahab; beware of thyself, old man."<br><br><br><br>"He waxes brave, but nevertheless obeys; most careful bravery that!"<br><br>murmured Ahab, as Starbuck disappeared.  "What's that he said--Ahab<br><br>beware of Ahab--there's something there!"  Then unconsciously using<br><br>the musket for a staff, with an iron brow he paced to and fro in the<br><br>little cabin; but presently the thick plaits of his forehead relaxed,<br><br>and returning the gun to the rack, he went to the deck.<br><br><br><br>"Thou art but too good a fellow, Starbuck," he said lowly to the<br><br>mate; then raising his voice to the crew: "Furl the t'gallant-sails,<br><br>and close-reef the top-sails, fore and aft; back the main-yard; up<br><br>Burton, and break out in the main-hold."<br><br><br><br>It were perhaps vain to surmise exactly why it was, that as<br><br>respecting Starbuck, Ahab thus acted.  It may have been a flash of<br><br>honesty in him; or mere prudential policy which, under the<br><br>circumstance, imperiously forbade the slightest symptom of open<br><br>disaffection, however transient, in the important chief officer of<br><br>his ship.  However it was, his orders were executed; and the Burtons<br><br>were hoisted.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 110<br><br><br><br>Queequeg in His Coffin.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Upon searching, it was found that the casks last struck into the hold<br><br>were perfectly sound, and that the leak must be further off.  So, it<br><br>being calm weather, they broke out deeper and deeper, disturbing the<br><br>slumbers of the huge ground-tier butts; and from that black midnight<br><br>sending those gigantic moles into the daylight above.  So deep did<br><br>they go; and so ancient, and corroded, and weedy the aspect of the<br><br>lowermost puncheons, that you almost looked next for some mouldy<br><br>corner-stone cask containing coins of Captain Noah, with copies of<br><br>the posted placards, vainly warning the infatuated old world from the<br><br>flood.  Tierce after tierce, too, of water, and bread, and beef, and<br><br>shooks of staves, and iron bundles of hoops, were hoisted out, till<br><br>at last the piled decks were hard to get about; and the hollow hull<br><br>echoed under foot, as if you were treading over empty catacombs, and<br><br>reeled and rolled in the sea like an air-freighted demijohn.<br><br>Top-heavy was the ship as a dinnerless student with all Aristotle in<br><br>his head.  Well was it that the Typhoons did not visit them then.<br><br><br><br>Now, at this time it was that my poor pagan companion, and fast<br><br>bosom-friend, Queequeg, was seized with a fever, which brought him<br><br>nigh to his endless end.<br><br><br><br>Be it said, that in this vocation of whaling, sinecures are unknown;<br><br>dignity and danger go hand in hand; till you get to be Captain, the<br><br>higher you rise the harder you toil.  So with poor Queequeg, who, as<br><br>harpooneer, must not only face all the rage of the living whale,<br><br>but--as we have elsewhere seen--mount his dead back in a rolling sea;<br><br>and finally descend into the gloom of the hold, and bitterly sweating<br><br>all day in that subterraneous confinement, resolutely manhandle the<br><br>clumsiest casks and see to their stowage.  To be short, among<br><br>whalemen, the harpooneers are the holders, so called.<br><br><br><br>Poor Queequeg! when the ship was about half disembowelled, you should<br><br>have stooped over the hatchway, and peered down upon him there;<br><br>where, stripped to his woollen drawers, the tattooed savage was<br><br>crawling about amid that dampness and slime, like a green spotted<br><br>lizard at the bottom of a well.  And a well, or an ice-house, it<br><br>somehow proved to him, poor pagan; where, strange to say, for all the<br><br>heat of his sweatings, he caught a terrible chill which lapsed into a<br><br>fever; and at last, after some days' suffering, laid him in his<br><br>hammock, close to the very sill of the door of death.  How he wasted<br><br>and wasted away in those few long-lingering days, till there seemed<br><br>but little left of him but his frame and tattooing.  But as all else<br><br>in him thinned, and his cheek-bones grew sharper, his eyes,<br><br>nevertheless, seemed growing fuller and fuller; they became of a<br><br>strange softness of lustre; and mildly but deeply looked out at you<br><br>there from his sickness, a wondrous testimony to that immortal health<br><br>in him which could not die, or be weakened.  And like circles on the<br><br>water, which, as they grow fainter, expand; so his eyes seemed<br><br>rounding and rounding, like the rings of Eternity.  An awe that<br><br>cannot be named would steal over you as you sat by the side of this<br><br>waning savage, and saw as strange things in his face, as any beheld<br><br>who were bystanders when Zoroaster died.  For whatever is truly<br><br>wondrous and fearful in man, never yet was put into words or books.<br><br>And the drawing near of Death, which alike levels all, alike<br><br>impresses all with a last revelation, which only an author from the<br><br>dead could adequately tell.  So that--let us say it again--no dying<br><br>Chaldee or Greek had higher and holier thoughts than those, whose<br><br>mysterious shades you saw creeping over the face of poor Queequeg, as<br><br>he quietly lay in his swaying hammock, and the rolling sea seemed<br><br>gently rocking him to his final rest, and the ocean's invisible<br><br>flood-tide lifted him higher and higher towards his destined heaven.<br><br><br><br>Not a man of the crew but gave him up; and, as for Queequeg himself,<br><br>what he thought of his case was forcibly shown by a curious favour he<br><br>asked.  He called one to him in the grey morning watch, when the day<br><br>was just breaking, and taking his hand, said that while in Nantucket<br><br>he had chanced to see certain little canoes of dark wood, like the<br><br>rich war-wood of his native isle; and upon inquiry, he had learned<br><br>that all whalemen who died in Nantucket, were laid in those same dark<br><br>canoes, and that the fancy of being so laid had much pleased him; for<br><br>it was not unlike the custom of his own race, who, after embalming a<br><br>dead warrior, stretched him out in his canoe, and so left him to be<br><br>floated away to the starry archipelagoes; for not only do they<br><br>believe that the stars are isles, but that far beyond all visible<br><br>horizons, their own mild, uncontinented seas, interflow with the blue<br><br>heavens; and so form the white breakers of the milky way.  He added,<br><br>that he shuddered at the thought of being buried in his hammock,<br><br>according to the usual sea-custom, tossed like something vile to the<br><br>death-devouring sharks.  No: he desired a canoe like those of<br><br>Nantucket, all the more congenial to him, being a whaleman, that like<br><br>a whale-boat these coffin-canoes were without a keel; though that<br><br>involved but uncertain steering, and much lee-way adown the dim ages.<br><br><br><br>Now, when this strange circumstance was made known aft, the carpenter<br><br>was at once commanded to do Queequeg's bidding, whatever it might<br><br>include.  There was some heathenish, coffin-coloured old lumber<br><br>aboard, which, upon a long previous voyage, had been cut from the<br><br>aboriginal groves of the Lackaday islands, and from these dark planks<br><br>the coffin was recommended to be made.  No sooner was the carpenter<br><br>apprised of the order, than taking his rule, he forthwith with all<br><br>the indifferent promptitude of his character, proceeded into the<br><br>forecastle and took Queequeg's measure with great accuracy, regularly<br><br>chalking Queequeg's person as he shifted the rule.<br><br><br><br>"Ah! poor fellow! he'll have to die now," ejaculated the Long Island<br><br>sailor.<br><br><br><br>Going to his vice-bench, the carpenter for convenience sake and<br><br>general reference, now transferringly measured on it the exact length<br><br>the coffin was to be, and then made the transfer permanent by cutting<br><br>two notches at its extremities.  This done, he marshalled the planks<br><br>and his tools, and to work.<br><br><br><br>When the last nail was driven, and the lid duly planed and fitted, he<br><br>lightly shouldered the coffin and went forward with it, inquiring<br><br>whether they were ready for it yet in that direction.<br><br><br><br>Overhearing the indignant but half-humorous cries with which the<br><br>people on deck began to drive the coffin away, Queequeg, to every<br><br>one's consternation, commanded that the thing should be instantly<br><br>brought to him, nor was there any denying him; seeing that, of all<br><br>mortals, some dying men are the most tyrannical; and certainly, since<br><br>they will shortly trouble us so little for evermore, the poor fellows<br><br>ought to be indulged.<br><br><br><br>Leaning over in his hammock, Queequeg long regarded the coffin with<br><br>an attentive eye.  He then called for his harpoon, had the wooden<br><br>stock drawn from it, and then had the iron part placed in the coffin<br><br>along with one of the paddles of his boat.  All by his own request,<br><br>also, biscuits were then ranged round the sides within: a flask of<br><br>fresh water was placed at the head, and a small bag of woody earth<br><br>scraped up in the hold at the foot; and a piece of sail-cloth being<br><br>rolled up for a pillow, Queequeg now entreated to be lifted into his<br><br>final bed, that he might make trial of its comforts, if any it had.<br><br>He lay without moving a few minutes, then told one to go to his bag<br><br>and bring out his little god, Yojo.  Then crossing his arms on his<br><br>breast with Yojo between, he called for the coffin lid (hatch he<br><br>called it) to be placed over him.  The head part turned over with a<br><br>leather hinge, and there lay Queequeg in his coffin with little but<br><br>his composed countenance in view.  "Rarmai" (it will do; it is easy),<br><br>he murmured at last, and signed to be replaced in his hammock.<br><br><br><br>But ere this was done, Pip, who had been slily hovering near by all<br><br>this while, drew nigh to him where he lay, and with soft sobbings,<br><br>took him by the hand; in the other, holding his tambourine.<br><br><br><br>"Poor rover! will ye never have done with all this weary roving?<br><br>where go ye now?  But if the currents carry ye to those sweet<br><br>Antilles where the beaches are only beat with water-lilies, will ye<br><br>do one little errand for me?  Seek out one Pip, who's now been<br><br>missing long: I think he's in those far Antilles.  If ye find him,<br><br>then comfort him; for he must be very sad; for look! he's left his<br><br>tambourine behind;--I found it.  Rig-a-dig, dig, dig!  Now, Queequeg,<br><br>die; and I'll beat ye your dying march."<br><br><br><br>"I have heard," murmured Starbuck, gazing down the scuttle, "that in<br><br>violent fevers, men, all ignorance, have talked in ancient tongues;<br><br>and that when the mystery is probed, it turns out always that in<br><br>their wholly forgotten childhood those ancient tongues had been<br><br>really spoken in their hearing by some lofty scholars.  So, to my<br><br>fond faith, poor Pip, in this strange sweetness of his lunacy, brings<br><br>heavenly vouchers of all our heavenly homes.  Where learned he that,<br><br>but there?--Hark! he speaks again: but more wildly now."<br><br><br><br>"Form two and two!  Let's make a General of him!  Ho, where's his<br><br>harpoon?  Lay it across here.--Rig-a-dig, dig, dig! huzza!  Oh for a<br><br>game cock now to sit upon his head and crow!  Queequeg dies<br><br>game!--mind ye that; Queequeg dies game!--take ye good heed of that;<br><br>Queequeg dies game!  I say; game, game, game! but base little Pip, he<br><br>died a coward; died all a'shiver;--out upon Pip!  Hark ye; if ye find<br><br>Pip, tell all the Antilles he's a runaway; a coward, a coward, a<br><br>coward!  Tell them he jumped from a whale-boat!  I'd never beat my<br><br>tambourine over base Pip, and hail him General, if he were once more<br><br>dying here.  No, no! shame upon all cowards--shame upon them!  Let 'em<br><br>go drown like Pip, that jumped from a whale-boat.  Shame! shame!"<br><br><br><br>During all this, Queequeg lay with closed eyes, as if in a dream.<br><br>Pip was led away, and the sick man was replaced in his hammock.<br><br><br><br>But now that he had apparently made every preparation for death; now<br><br>that his coffin was proved a good fit, Queequeg suddenly rallied;<br><br>soon there seemed no need of the carpenter's box: and thereupon,<br><br>when some expressed their delighted surprise, he, in substance, said,<br><br>that the cause of his sudden convalescence was this;--at a critical<br><br>moment, he had just recalled a little duty ashore, which he was<br><br>leaving undone; and therefore had changed his mind about dying: he<br><br>could not die yet, he averred.  They asked him, then, whether to live<br><br>or die was a matter of his own sovereign will and pleasure.  He<br><br>answered, certainly.  In a word, it was Queequeg's conceit, that if a<br><br>man made up his mind to live, mere sickness could not kill him:<br><br>nothing but a whale, or a gale, or some violent, ungovernable,<br><br>unintelligent destroyer of that sort.<br><br><br><br>Now, there is this noteworthy difference between savage and<br><br>civilized; that while a sick, civilized man may be six months<br><br>convalescing, generally speaking, a sick savage is almost half-well<br><br>again in a day.  So, in good time my Queequeg gained strength; and at<br><br>length after sitting on the windlass for a few indolent days (but<br><br>eating with a vigorous appetite) he suddenly leaped to his feet,<br><br>threw out his arms and legs, gave himself a good stretching, yawned<br><br>a little bit, and then springing into the head of his hoisted boat,<br><br>and poising a harpoon, pronounced himself fit for a fight.<br><br><br><br>With a wild whimsiness, he now used his coffin for a sea-chest; and<br><br>emptying into it his canvas bag of clothes, set them in order there.<br><br>Many spare hours he spent, in carving the lid with all manner of<br><br>grotesque figures and drawings; and it seemed that hereby he was<br><br>striving, in his rude way, to copy parts of the twisted tattooing on<br><br>his body.  And this tattooing had been the work of a departed<br><br>prophet and seer of his island, who, by those hieroglyphic marks, had<br><br>written out on his body a complete theory of the heavens and the<br><br>earth, and a mystical treatise on the art of attaining truth; so that<br><br>Queequeg in his own proper person was a riddle to unfold; a wondrous<br><br>work in one volume; but whose mysteries not even himself could read,<br><br>though his own live heart beat against them; and these mysteries were<br><br>therefore destined in the end to moulder away with the living<br><br>parchment whereon they were inscribed, and so be unsolved to the<br><br>last.  And this thought it must have been which suggested to Ahab<br><br>that wild exclamation of his, when one morning turning away from<br><br>surveying poor Queequeg--"Oh, devilish tantalization of the gods!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 111<br><br><br><br>The Pacific.<br><br><br><br><br><br>When gliding by the Bashee isles we emerged at last upon the great<br><br>South Sea; were it not for other things, I could have greeted my dear<br><br>Pacific with uncounted thanks, for now the long supplication of my<br><br>youth was answered; that serene ocean rolled eastwards from me a<br><br>thousand leagues of blue.<br><br><br><br>There is, one knows not what sweet mystery about this sea, whose<br><br>gently awful stirrings seem to speak of some hidden soul beneath;<br><br>like those fabled undulations of the Ephesian sod over the buried<br><br>Evangelist St. John.  And meet it is, that over these sea-pastures,<br><br>wide-rolling watery prairies and Potters' Fields of all four<br><br>continents, the waves should rise and fall, and ebb and flow<br><br>unceasingly; for here, millions of mixed shades and shadows, drowned<br><br>dreams, somnambulisms, reveries; all that we call lives and souls,<br><br>lie dreaming, dreaming, still; tossing like slumberers in their beds;<br><br>the ever-rolling waves but made so by their restlessness.<br><br><br><br>To any meditative Magian rover, this serene Pacific, once beheld,<br><br>must ever after be the sea of his adoption.  It rolls the midmost<br><br>waters of the world, the Indian ocean and Atlantic being but its<br><br>arms.  The same waves wash the moles of the new-built Californian<br><br>towns, but yesterday planted by the recentest race of men, and lave<br><br>the faded but still gorgeous skirts of Asiatic lands, older than<br><br>Abraham; while all between float milky-ways of coral isles, and<br><br>low-lying, endless, unknown Archipelagoes, and impenetrable Japans.<br><br>Thus this mysterious, divine Pacific zones the world's whole bulk<br><br>about; makes all coasts one bay to it; seems the tide-beating heart<br><br>of earth.  Lifted by those eternal swells, you needs must own the<br><br>seductive god, bowing your head to Pan.<br><br><br><br>But few thoughts of Pan stirred Ahab's brain, as standing like an<br><br>iron statue at his accustomed place beside the mizen rigging, with<br><br>one nostril he unthinkingly snuffed the sugary musk from the Bashee<br><br>isles (in whose sweet woods mild lovers must be walking), and with<br><br>the other consciously inhaled the salt breath of the new found sea;<br><br>that sea in which the hated White Whale must even then be swimming.<br><br>Launched at length upon these almost final waters, and gliding<br><br>towards the Japanese cruising-ground, the old man's purpose<br><br>intensified itself.  His firm lips met like the lips of a vice; the<br><br>Delta of his forehead's veins swelled like overladen brooks; in his<br><br>very sleep, his ringing cry ran through the vaulted hull, "Stern all!<br><br>the White Whale spouts thick blood!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 112<br><br><br><br>The Blacksmith.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Availing himself of the mild, summer-cool weather that now reigned<br><br>in these latitudes, and in preparation for the peculiarly active<br><br>pursuits shortly to be anticipated, Perth, the begrimed, blistered<br><br>old blacksmith, had not removed his portable forge to the hold again,<br><br>after concluding his contributory work for Ahab's leg, but still<br><br>retained it on deck, fast lashed to ringbolts by the foremast; being<br><br>now almost incessantly invoked by the headsmen, and harpooneers, and<br><br>bowsmen to do some little job for them; altering, or repairing, or<br><br>new shaping their various weapons and boat furniture.  Often he would<br><br>be surrounded by an eager circle, all waiting to be served; holding<br><br>boat-spades, pike-heads, harpoons, and lances, and jealously watching<br><br>his every sooty movement, as he toiled.  Nevertheless, this old man's<br><br>was a patient hammer wielded by a patient arm.  No murmur, no<br><br>impatience, no petulance did come from him.  Silent, slow, and<br><br>solemn; bowing over still further his chronically broken back, he<br><br>toiled away, as if toil were life itself, and the heavy beating of<br><br>his hammer the heavy beating of his heart.  And so it was.--Most<br><br>miserable!<br><br><br><br>A peculiar walk in this old man, a certain slight but painful<br><br>appearing yawing in his gait, had at an early period of the voyage<br><br>excited the curiosity of the mariners.  And to the importunity of<br><br>their persisted questionings he had finally given in; and so it came<br><br>to pass that every one now knew the shameful story of his wretched<br><br>fate.<br><br><br><br>Belated, and not innocently, one bitter winter's midnight, on the<br><br>road running between two country towns, the blacksmith half-stupidly<br><br>felt the deadly numbness stealing over him, and sought refuge in a<br><br>leaning, dilapidated barn.  The issue was, the loss of the<br><br>extremities of both feet.  Out of this revelation, part by part, at<br><br>last came out the four acts of the gladness, and the one long, and as<br><br>yet uncatastrophied fifth act of the grief of his life's drama.<br><br><br><br>He was an old man, who, at the age of nearly sixty, had postponedly<br><br>encountered that thing in sorrow's technicals called ruin.  He had<br><br>been an artisan of famed excellence, and with plenty to do; owned a<br><br>house and garden; embraced a youthful, daughter-like, loving wife,<br><br>and three blithe, ruddy children; every Sunday went to a<br><br>cheerful-looking church, planted in a grove.  But one night, under<br><br>cover of darkness, and further concealed in a most cunning<br><br>disguisement, a desperate burglar slid into his happy home, and<br><br>robbed them all of everything.  And darker yet to tell, the<br><br>blacksmith himself did ignorantly conduct this burglar into his<br><br>family's heart.  It was the Bottle Conjuror!  Upon the opening of<br><br>that fatal cork, forth flew the fiend, and shrivelled up his home.<br><br>Now, for prudent, most wise, and economic reasons, the blacksmith's<br><br>shop was in the basement of his dwelling, but with a separate<br><br>entrance to it; so that always had the young and loving healthy wife<br><br>listened with no unhappy nervousness, but with vigorous pleasure, to<br><br>the stout ringing of her young-armed old husband's hammer; whose<br><br>reverberations, muffled by passing through the floors and walls, came<br><br>up to her, not unsweetly, in her nursery; and so, to stout Labor's<br><br>iron lullaby, the blacksmith's infants were rocked to slumber.<br><br><br><br>Oh, woe on woe!  Oh, Death, why canst thou not sometimes be timely?<br><br>Hadst thou taken this old blacksmith to thyself ere his full ruin<br><br>came upon him, then had the young widow had a delicious grief, and<br><br>her orphans a truly venerable, legendary sire to dream of in their<br><br>after years; and all of them a care-killing competency.  But Death<br><br>plucked down some virtuous elder brother, on whose whistling daily<br><br>toil solely hung the responsibilities of some other family, and left<br><br>the worse than useless old man standing, till the hideous rot of life<br><br>should make him easier to harvest.<br><br><br><br>Why tell the whole?  The blows of the basement hammer every day grew<br><br>more and more between; and each blow every day grew fainter than the<br><br>last; the wife sat frozen at the window, with tearless eyes,<br><br>glitteringly gazing into the weeping faces of her children; the<br><br>bellows fell; the forge choked up with cinders; the house was sold;<br><br>the mother dived down into the long church-yard grass; her children<br><br>twice followed her thither; and the houseless, familyless old man<br><br>staggered off a vagabond in crape; his every woe unreverenced; his<br><br>grey head a scorn to flaxen curls!<br><br><br><br>Death seems the only desirable sequel for a career like this; but<br><br>Death is only a launching into the region of the strange Untried; it<br><br>is but the first salutation to the possibilities of the immense<br><br>Remote, the Wild, the Watery, the Unshored; therefore, to the<br><br>death-longing eyes of such men, who still have left in them some<br><br>interior compunctions against suicide, does the all-contributed and<br><br>all-receptive ocean alluringly spread forth his whole plain of<br><br>unimaginable, taking terrors, and wonderful, new-life adventures; and<br><br>from the hearts of infinite Pacifics, the thousand mermaids sing to<br><br>them--"Come hither, broken-hearted; here is another life without the<br><br>guilt of intermediate death; here are wonders supernatural, without<br><br>dying for them.  Come hither! bury thyself in a life which, to your<br><br>now equally abhorred and abhorring, landed world, is more oblivious<br><br>than death.  Come hither! put up THY gravestone, too, within the<br><br>churchyard, and come hither, till we marry thee!"<br><br><br><br>Hearkening to these voices, East and West, by early sunrise, and by<br><br>fall of eve, the blacksmith's soul responded, Aye, I come!  And so<br><br>Perth went a-whaling.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 113<br><br><br><br>The Forge.<br><br><br><br><br><br>With matted beard, and swathed in a bristling shark-skin apron, about<br><br>mid-day, Perth was standing between his forge and anvil, the latter<br><br>placed upon an iron-wood log, with one hand holding a pike-head in<br><br>the coals, and with the other at his forge's lungs, when Captain Ahab<br><br>came along, carrying in his hand a small rusty-looking leathern bag.<br><br>While yet a little distance from the forge, moody Ahab paused; till<br><br>at last, Perth, withdrawing his iron from the fire, began hammering<br><br>it upon the anvil--the red mass sending off the sparks in thick<br><br>hovering flights, some of which flew close to Ahab.<br><br><br><br>"Are these thy Mother Carey's chickens, Perth? they are always flying<br><br>in thy wake; birds of good omen, too, but not to all;--look here,<br><br>they burn; but thou--thou liv'st among them without a scorch."<br><br><br><br>"Because I am scorched all over, Captain Ahab," answered Perth,<br><br>resting for a moment on his hammer; "I am past scorching; not easily<br><br>can'st thou scorch a scar."<br><br><br><br>"Well, well; no more.  Thy shrunk voice sounds too calmly, sanely<br><br>woeful to me.  In no Paradise myself, I am impatient of all misery in<br><br>others that is not mad.  Thou should'st go mad, blacksmith; say, why<br><br>dost thou not go mad?  How can'st thou endure without being mad?  Do<br><br>the heavens yet hate thee, that thou can'st not go mad?--What wert<br><br>thou making there?"<br><br><br><br>"Welding an old pike-head, sir; there were seams and dents in it."<br><br><br><br>"And can'st thou make it all smooth again, blacksmith, after such<br><br>hard usage as it had?"<br><br><br><br>"I think so, sir."<br><br><br><br>"And I suppose thou can'st smoothe almost any seams and dents; never<br><br>mind how hard the metal, blacksmith?"<br><br><br><br>"Aye, sir, I think I can; all seams and dents but one."<br><br><br><br>"Look ye here, then," cried Ahab, passionately advancing, and leaning<br><br>with both hands on Perth's shoulders; "look ye here--HERE--can ye<br><br>smoothe out a seam like this, blacksmith," sweeping one hand across<br><br>his ribbed brow; "if thou could'st, blacksmith, glad enough would I<br><br>lay my head upon thy anvil, and feel thy heaviest hammer between my<br><br>eyes.  Answer!  Can'st thou smoothe this seam?"<br><br><br><br>"Oh! that is the one, sir!  Said I not all seams and dents but one?"<br><br><br><br>"Aye, blacksmith, it is the one; aye, man, it is unsmoothable; for<br><br>though thou only see'st it here in my flesh, it has worked down into<br><br>the bone of my skull--THAT is all wrinkles!  But, away with child's<br><br>play; no more gaffs and pikes to-day.  Look ye here!" jingling the<br><br>leathern bag, as if it were full of gold coins.  "I, too, want a<br><br>harpoon made; one that a thousand yoke of fiends could not part,<br><br>Perth; something that will stick in a whale like his own fin-bone.<br><br>There's the stuff," flinging the pouch upon the anvil.  "Look ye,<br><br>blacksmith, these are the gathered nail-stubbs of the steel shoes of<br><br>racing horses."<br><br><br><br>"Horse-shoe stubbs, sir?  Why, Captain Ahab, thou hast here, then,<br><br>the best and stubbornest stuff we blacksmiths ever work."<br><br><br><br>"I know it, old man; these stubbs will weld together like glue from<br><br>the melted bones of murderers.  Quick! forge me the harpoon.  And<br><br>forge me first, twelve rods for its shank; then wind, and twist, and<br><br>hammer these twelve together like the yarns and strands of a<br><br>tow-line.  Quick!  I'll blow the fire."<br><br><br><br>When at last the twelve rods were made, Ahab tried them, one by one,<br><br>by spiralling them, with his own hand, round a long, heavy iron bolt.<br><br>"A flaw!" rejecting the last one.  "Work that over again, Perth."<br><br><br><br>This done, Perth was about to begin welding the twelve into one, when<br><br>Ahab stayed his hand, and said he would weld his own iron.  As, then,<br><br>with regular, gasping hems, he hammered on the anvil, Perth passing<br><br>to him the glowing rods, one after the other, and the hard pressed<br><br>forge shooting up its intense straight flame, the Parsee passed<br><br>silently, and bowing over his head towards the fire, seemed invoking<br><br>some curse or some blessing on the toil.  But, as Ahab looked up, he<br><br>slid aside.<br><br><br><br>"What's that bunch of lucifers dodging about there for?" muttered<br><br>Stubb, looking on from the forecastle.  "That Parsee smells fire like<br><br>a fusee; and smells of it himself, like a hot musket's powder-pan."<br><br><br><br>At last the shank, in one complete rod, received its final heat; and<br><br>as Perth, to temper it, plunged it all hissing into the cask of water<br><br>near by, the scalding steam shot up into Ahab's bent face.<br><br><br><br>"Would'st thou brand me, Perth?" wincing for a moment with the pain;<br><br>"have I been but forging my own branding-iron, then?"<br><br><br><br>"Pray God, not that; yet I fear something, Captain Ahab.  Is not this<br><br>harpoon for the White Whale?"<br><br><br><br>"For the white fiend!  But now for the barbs; thou must make them<br><br>thyself, man.  Here are my razors--the best of steel; here, and make<br><br>the barbs sharp as the needle-sleet of the Icy Sea."<br><br><br><br>For a moment, the old blacksmith eyed the razors as though he would<br><br>fain not use them.<br><br><br><br>"Take them, man, I have no need for them; for I now neither shave,<br><br>sup, nor pray till--but here--to work!"<br><br><br><br>Fashioned at last into an arrowy shape, and welded by Perth to the<br><br>shank, the steel soon pointed the end of the iron; and as the<br><br>blacksmith was about giving the barbs their final heat, prior to<br><br>tempering them, he cried to Ahab to place the water-cask near.<br><br><br><br>"No, no--no water for that; I want it of the true death-temper.<br><br>Ahoy, there!  Tashtego, Queequeg, Daggoo!  What say ye, pagans!  Will<br><br>ye give me as much blood as will cover this barb?" holding it high<br><br>up.  A cluster of dark nods replied, Yes.  Three punctures were made<br><br>in the heathen flesh, and the White Whale's barbs were then tempered.<br><br><br><br>"Ego non baptizo te in nomine patris, sed in nomine diaboli!"<br><br>deliriously howled Ahab, as the malignant iron scorchingly devoured<br><br>the baptismal blood.<br><br><br><br>Now, mustering the spare poles from below, and selecting one of<br><br>hickory, with the bark still investing it, Ahab fitted the end to the<br><br>socket of the iron.  A coil of new tow-line was then unwound, and<br><br>some fathoms of it taken to the windlass, and stretched to a great<br><br>tension.  Pressing his foot upon it, till the rope hummed like a<br><br>harp-string, then eagerly bending over it, and seeing no strandings,<br><br>Ahab exclaimed, "Good! and now for the seizings."<br><br><br><br>At one extremity the rope was unstranded, and the separate spread<br><br>yarns were all braided and woven round the socket of the harpoon; the<br><br>pole was then driven hard up into the socket; from the lower end the<br><br>rope was traced half-way along the pole's length, and firmly secured<br><br>so, with intertwistings of twine.  This done, pole, iron, and<br><br>rope--like the Three Fates--remained inseparable, and Ahab moodily<br><br>stalked away with the weapon; the sound of his ivory leg, and the<br><br>sound of the hickory pole, both hollowly ringing along every plank.<br><br>But ere he entered his cabin, light, unnatural, half-bantering, yet<br><br>most piteous sound was heard.  Oh, Pip! thy wretched laugh, thy<br><br>idle but unresting eye; all thy strange mummeries not unmeaningly<br><br>blended with the black tragedy of the melancholy ship, and mocked it!<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 114<br><br><br><br>The Gilder.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Penetrating further and further into the heart of the Japanese<br><br>cruising ground, the Pequod was soon all astir in the fishery.<br><br>Often, in mild, pleasant weather, for twelve, fifteen, eighteen, and<br><br>twenty hours on the stretch, they were engaged in the boats, steadily<br><br>pulling, or sailing, or paddling after the whales, or for an<br><br>interlude of sixty or seventy minutes calmly awaiting their uprising;<br><br>though with but small success for their pains.<br><br><br><br>At such times, under an abated sun; afloat all day upon smooth, slow<br><br>heaving swells; seated in his boat, light as a birch canoe; and so<br><br>sociably mixing with the soft waves themselves, that like<br><br>hearth-stone cats they purr against the gunwale; these are the times<br><br>of dreamy quietude, when beholding the tranquil beauty and brilliancy<br><br>of the ocean's skin, one forgets the tiger heart that pants beneath<br><br>it; and would not willingly remember, that this velvet paw but<br><br>conceals a remorseless fang.<br><br><br><br>These are the times, when in his whale-boat the rover softly feels a<br><br>certain filial, confident, land-like feeling towards the sea; that he<br><br>regards it as so much flowery earth; and the distant ship revealing<br><br>only the tops of her masts, seems struggling forward, not through<br><br>high rolling waves, but through the tall grass of a rolling prairie:<br><br>as when the western emigrants' horses only show their erected ears,<br><br>while their hidden bodies widely wade through the amazing verdure.<br><br><br><br>The long-drawn virgin vales; the mild blue hill-sides; as over these<br><br>there steals the hush, the hum; you almost swear that play-wearied<br><br>children lie sleeping in these solitudes, in some glad May-time, when<br><br>the flowers of the woods are plucked.  And all this mixes with your<br><br>most mystic mood; so that fact and fancy, half-way meeting,<br><br>interpenetrate, and form one seamless whole.<br><br><br><br>Nor did such soothing scenes, however temporary, fail of at least as<br><br>temporary an effect on Ahab.  But if these secret golden keys did<br><br>seem to open in him his own secret golden treasuries, yet did his<br><br>breath upon them prove but tarnishing.<br><br><br><br>Oh, grassy glades! oh, ever vernal endless landscapes in the soul; in<br><br>ye,--though long parched by the dead drought of the earthy<br><br>life,--in ye, men yet may roll, like young horses in new morning<br><br>clover; and for some few fleeting moments, feel the cool dew of the<br><br>life immortal on them.  Would to God these blessed calms would last.<br><br>But the mingled, mingling threads of life are woven by warp and woof:<br><br>calms crossed by storms, a storm for every calm.  There is no steady<br><br>unretracing progress in this life; we do not advance through fixed<br><br>gradations, and at the last one pause:--through infancy's unconscious<br><br>spell, boyhood's thoughtless faith, adolescence' doubt (the common<br><br>doom), then scepticism, then disbelief, resting at last in manhood's<br><br>pondering repose of If.  But once gone through, we trace the round<br><br>again; and are infants, boys, and men, and Ifs eternally.  Where lies<br><br>the final harbor, whence we unmoor no more?  In what rapt ether sails<br><br>the world, of which the weariest will never weary?  Where is the<br><br>foundling's father hidden?  Our souls are like those orphans whose<br><br>unwedded mothers die in bearing them: the secret of our paternity<br><br>lies in their grave, and we must there to learn it.<br><br><br><br>And that same day, too, gazing far down from his boat's side into<br><br>that same golden sea, Starbuck lowly murmured:--<br><br><br><br>"Loveliness unfathomable, as ever lover saw in his young bride's<br><br>eye!--Tell me not of thy teeth-tiered sharks, and thy kidnapping<br><br>cannibal ways.  Let faith oust fact; let fancy oust memory; I look<br><br>deep down and do believe."<br><br><br><br>And Stubb, fish-like, with sparkling scales, leaped up in that same<br><br>golden light:--<br><br><br><br>"I am Stubb, and Stubb has his history; but here Stubb takes oaths<br><br>that he has always been jolly!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 115<br><br><br><br>The Pequod Meets The Bachelor.<br><br><br><br><br><br>And jolly enough were the sights and the sounds that came bearing<br><br>down before the wind, some few weeks after Ahab's harpoon had been<br><br>welded.<br><br><br><br>It was a Nantucket ship, the Bachelor, which had just wedged in her<br><br>last cask of oil, and bolted down her bursting hatches; and now, in<br><br>glad holiday apparel, was joyously, though somewhat vain-gloriously,<br><br>sailing round among the widely-separated ships on the ground,<br><br>previous to pointing her prow for home.<br><br><br><br>The three men at her mast-head wore long streamers of narrow red<br><br>bunting at their hats; from the stern, a whale-boat was suspended,<br><br>bottom down; and hanging captive from the bowsprit was seen the long<br><br>lower jaw of the last whale they had slain.  Signals, ensigns, and<br><br>jacks of all colours were flying from her rigging, on every side.<br><br>Sideways lashed in each of her three basketed tops were two barrels<br><br>of sperm; above which, in her top-mast cross-trees, you saw slender<br><br>breakers of the same precious fluid; and nailed to her main truck was<br><br>a brazen lamp.<br><br><br><br>As was afterwards learned, the Bachelor had met with the most<br><br>surprising success; all the more wonderful, for that while cruising<br><br>in the same seas numerous other vessels had gone entire months<br><br>without securing a single fish.  Not only had barrels of beef and<br><br>bread been given away to make room for the far more valuable sperm,<br><br>but additional supplemental casks had been bartered for, from the<br><br>ships she had met; and these were stowed along the deck, and in the<br><br>captain's and officers' state-rooms.  Even the cabin table itself<br><br>had been knocked into kindling-wood; and the cabin mess dined off the<br><br>broad head of an oil-butt, lashed down to the floor for a<br><br>centrepiece.  In the forecastle, the sailors had actually caulked<br><br>and pitched their chests, and filled them; it was humorously added,<br><br>that the cook had clapped a head on his largest boiler, and filled<br><br>it; that the steward had plugged his spare coffee-pot and filled it;<br><br>that the harpooneers had headed the sockets of their irons and filled<br><br>them; that indeed everything was filled with sperm, except the<br><br>captain's pantaloons pockets, and those he reserved to thrust his<br><br>hands into, in self-complacent testimony of his entire satisfaction.<br><br><br><br>As this glad ship of good luck bore down upon the moody Pequod, the<br><br>barbarian sound of enormous drums came from her forecastle; and<br><br>drawing still nearer, a crowd of her men were seen standing round her<br><br>huge try-pots, which, covered with the parchment-like POKE or stomach<br><br>skin of the black fish, gave forth a loud roar to every stroke of the<br><br>clenched hands of the crew.  On the quarter-deck, the mates and<br><br>harpooneers were dancing with the olive-hued girls who had eloped<br><br>with them from the Polynesian Isles; while suspended in an<br><br>ornamented boat, firmly secured aloft between the foremast and<br><br>mainmast, three Long Island negroes, with glittering fiddle-bows of<br><br>whale ivory, were presiding over the hilarious jig.
