Meanwhile,<br><br>others of the ship's company were tumultuously busy at the masonry of<br><br>the try-works, from which the huge pots had been removed.  You would<br><br>have almost thought they were pulling down the cursed Bastille, such<br><br>wild cries they raised, as the now useless brick and mortar were<br><br>being hurled into the sea.<br><br><br><br>Lord and master over all this scene, the captain stood erect on the<br><br>ship's elevated quarter-deck, so that the whole rejoicing drama was<br><br>full before him, and seemed merely contrived for his own individual<br><br>diversion.<br><br><br><br>And Ahab, he too was standing on his quarter-deck, shaggy and black,<br><br>with a stubborn gloom; and as the two ships crossed each other's<br><br>wakes--one all jubilations for things passed, the other all<br><br>forebodings as to things to come--their two captains in themselves<br><br>impersonated the whole striking contrast of the scene.<br><br><br><br>"Come aboard, come aboard!" cried the gay Bachelor's commander,<br><br>lifting a glass and a bottle in the air.<br><br><br><br>"Hast seen the White Whale?" gritted Ahab in reply.<br><br><br><br>"No; only heard of him; but don't believe in him at all," said the<br><br>other good-humoredly.  "Come aboard!"<br><br><br><br>"Thou art too damned jolly.  Sail on.  Hast lost any men?"<br><br><br><br>"Not enough to speak of--two islanders, that's all;--but come aboard,<br><br>old hearty, come along.  I'll soon take that black from your brow.<br><br>Come along, will ye (merry's the play); a full ship and<br><br>homeward-bound."<br><br><br><br>"How wondrous familiar is a fool!" muttered Ahab; then aloud, "Thou<br><br>art a full ship and homeward bound, thou sayst; well, then, call me<br><br>an empty ship, and outward-bound.  So go thy ways, and I will mine.<br><br>Forward there!  Set all sail, and keep her to the wind!"<br><br><br><br>And thus, while the one ship went cheerily before the breeze, the<br><br>other stubbornly fought against it; and so the two vessels parted;<br><br>the crew of the Pequod looking with grave, lingering glances towards<br><br>the receding Bachelor; but the Bachelor's men never heeding their<br><br>gaze for the lively revelry they were in.  And as Ahab, leaning over<br><br>the taffrail, eyed the homewardbound craft, he took from his pocket a<br><br>small vial of sand, and then looking from the ship to the vial,<br><br>seemed thereby bringing two remote associations together, for that<br><br>vial was filled with Nantucket soundings.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 116<br><br><br><br>The Dying Whale.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Not seldom in this life, when, on the right side, fortune's favourites<br><br>sail close by us, we, though all adroop before, catch somewhat of the<br><br>rushing breeze, and joyfully feel our bagging sails fill out.  So<br><br>seemed it with the Pequod.  For next day after encountering the gay<br><br>Bachelor, whales were seen and four were slain; and one of them by<br><br>Ahab.<br><br><br><br>It was far down the afternoon; and when all the spearings of the<br><br>crimson fight were done: and floating in the lovely sunset sea and<br><br>sky, sun and whale both stilly died together; then, such a sweetness<br><br>and such plaintiveness, such inwreathing orisons curled up in that<br><br>rosy air, that it almost seemed as if far over from the deep green<br><br>convent valleys of the Manilla isles, the Spanish land-breeze,<br><br>wantonly turned sailor, had gone to sea, freighted with these vesper<br><br>hymns.<br><br><br><br>Soothed again, but only soothed to deeper gloom, Ahab, who had<br><br>sterned off from the whale, sat intently watching his final wanings<br><br>from the now tranquil boat.  For that strange spectacle observable in<br><br>all sperm whales dying--the turning sunwards of the head, and so<br><br>expiring--that strange spectacle, beheld of such a placid evening,<br><br>somehow to Ahab conveyed a wondrousness unknown before.<br><br><br><br>"He turns and turns him to it,--how slowly, but how steadfastly, his<br><br>homage-rendering and invoking brow, with his last dying motions.  He<br><br>too worships fire; most faithful, broad, baronial vassal of the<br><br>sun!--Oh that these too-favouring eyes should see these too-favouring<br><br>sights.  Look! here, far water-locked; beyond all hum of human weal<br><br>or woe; in these most candid and impartial seas; where to traditions<br><br>no rocks furnish tablets; where for long Chinese ages, the billows<br><br>have still rolled on speechless and unspoken to, as stars that shine<br><br>upon the Niger's unknown source; here, too, life dies sunwards full<br><br>of faith; but see! no sooner dead, than death whirls round the<br><br>corpse, and it heads some other way.<br><br><br><br>"Oh, thou dark Hindoo half of nature, who of drowned bones hast<br><br>builded thy separate throne somewhere in the heart of these<br><br>unverdured seas; thou art an infidel, thou queen, and too truly<br><br>speakest to me in the wide-slaughtering Typhoon, and the hushed<br><br>burial of its after calm.  Nor has this thy whale sunwards turned his<br><br>dying head, and then gone round again, without a lesson to me.<br><br><br><br>"Oh, trebly hooped and welded hip of power!  Oh, high aspiring,<br><br>rainbowed jet!--that one strivest, this one jettest all in vain!  In<br><br>vain, oh whale, dost thou seek intercedings with yon all-quickening<br><br>sun, that only calls forth life, but gives it not again.  Yet dost<br><br>thou, darker half, rock me with a prouder, if a darker faith.  All<br><br>thy unnamable imminglings float beneath me here; I am buoyed by<br><br>breaths of once living things, exhaled as air, but water now.<br><br><br><br>"Then hail, for ever hail, O sea, in whose eternal tossings the wild<br><br>fowl finds his only rest.  Born of earth, yet suckled by the sea;<br><br>though hill and valley mothered me, ye billows are my<br><br>foster-brothers!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 117<br><br><br><br>The Whale Watch.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The four whales slain that evening had died wide apart; one, far to<br><br>windward; one, less distant, to leeward; one ahead; one astern.<br><br>These last three were brought alongside ere nightfall; but the<br><br>windward one could not be reached till morning; and the boat that had<br><br>killed it lay by its side all night; and that boat was Ahab's.<br><br><br><br>The waif-pole was thrust upright into the dead whale's spout-hole;<br><br>and the lantern hanging from its top, cast a troubled flickering<br><br>glare upon the black, glossy back, and far out upon the midnight<br><br>waves, which gently chafed the whale's broad flank, like soft surf<br><br>upon a beach.<br><br><br><br>Ahab and all his boat's crew seemed asleep but the Parsee; who<br><br>crouching in the bow, sat watching the sharks, that spectrally played<br><br>round the whale, and tapped the light cedar planks with their tails.<br><br>A sound like the moaning in squadrons over Asphaltites of unforgiven<br><br>ghosts of Gomorrah, ran shuddering through the air.<br><br><br><br>Started from his slumbers, Ahab, face to face, saw the Parsee; and<br><br>hooped round by the gloom of the night they seemed the last men in a<br><br>flooded world.  "I have dreamed it again," said he.<br><br><br><br>"Of the hearses?  Have I not said, old man, that neither hearse nor<br><br>coffin can be thine?"<br><br><br><br>"And who are hearsed that die on the sea?"<br><br><br><br>"But I said, old man, that ere thou couldst die on this voyage, two<br><br>hearses must verily be seen by thee on the sea; the first not made by<br><br>mortal hands; and the visible wood of the last one must be grown in<br><br>America."<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye! a strange sight that, Parsee:--a hearse and its plumes<br><br>floating over the ocean with the waves for the pall-bearers.  Ha!<br><br>Such a sight we shall not soon see."<br><br><br><br>"Believe it or not, thou canst not die till it be seen, old man."<br><br><br><br>"And what was that saying about thyself?"<br><br><br><br>"Though it come to the last, I shall still go before thee thy pilot."<br><br><br><br>"And when thou art so gone before--if that ever befall--then ere I<br><br>can follow, thou must still appear to me, to pilot me still?--Was it<br><br>not so?  Well, then, did I believe all ye say, oh my pilot!  I have<br><br>here two pledges that I shall yet slay Moby Dick and survive it."<br><br><br><br>"Take another pledge, old man," said the Parsee, as his eyes lighted<br><br>up like fire-flies in the gloom--"Hemp only can kill thee."<br><br><br><br>"The gallows, ye mean.--I am immortal then, on land and on sea,"<br><br>cried Ahab, with a laugh of derision;--"Immortal on land and on sea!"<br><br><br><br>Both were silent again, as one man.  The grey dawn came on, and the<br><br>slumbering crew arose from the boat's bottom, and ere noon the dead<br><br>whale was brought to the ship.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 118<br><br><br><br>The Quadrant.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The season for the Line at length drew near; and every day when Ahab,<br><br>coming from his cabin, cast his eyes aloft, the vigilant helmsman<br><br>would ostentatiously handle his spokes, and the eager mariners<br><br>quickly run to the braces, and would stand there with all their eyes<br><br>centrally fixed on the nailed doubloon; impatient for the order to<br><br>point the ship's prow for the equator.  In good time the order came.<br><br>It was hard upon high noon; and Ahab, seated in the bows of his<br><br>high-hoisted boat, was about taking his wonted daily observation of<br><br>the sun to determine his latitude.<br><br><br><br>Now, in that Japanese sea, the days in summer are as freshets of<br><br>effulgences.  That unblinkingly vivid Japanese sun seems the blazing<br><br>focus of the glassy ocean's immeasurable burning-glass.  The sky<br><br>looks lacquered; clouds there are none; the horizon floats; and this<br><br>nakedness of unrelieved radiance is as the insufferable splendors of<br><br>God's throne.  Well that Ahab's quadrant was furnished with coloured<br><br>glasses, through which to take sight of that solar fire.  So,<br><br>swinging his seated form to the roll of the ship, and with his<br><br>astrological-looking instrument placed to his eye, he remained in<br><br>that posture for some moments to catch the precise instant when the<br><br>sun should gain its precise meridian.  Meantime while his whole<br><br>attention was absorbed, the Parsee was kneeling beneath him on the<br><br>ship's deck, and with face thrown up like Ahab's, was eyeing the same<br><br>sun with him; only the lids of his eyes half hooded their orbs, and<br><br>his wild face was subdued to an earthly passionlessness.  At length<br><br>the desired observation was taken; and with his pencil upon his ivory<br><br>leg, Ahab soon calculated what his latitude must be at that precise<br><br>instant.  Then falling into a moment's revery, he again looked up<br><br>towards the sun and murmured to himself: "Thou sea-mark! thou high<br><br>and mighty Pilot! thou tellest me truly where I AM--but canst thou<br><br>cast the least hint where I SHALL be?  Or canst thou tell where some<br><br>other thing besides me is this moment living?  Where is Moby Dick?<br><br>This instant thou must be eyeing him.  These eyes of mine look into<br><br>the very eye that is even now beholding him; aye, and into the eye<br><br>that is even now equally beholding the objects on the unknown,<br><br>thither side of thee, thou sun!"<br><br><br><br>Then gazing at his quadrant, and handling, one after the other, its<br><br>numerous cabalistical contrivances, he pondered again, and muttered:<br><br>"Foolish toy! babies' plaything of haughty Admirals, and Commodores,<br><br>and Captains; the world brags of thee, of thy cunning and might; but<br><br>what after all canst thou do, but tell the poor, pitiful point, where<br><br>thou thyself happenest to be on this wide planet, and the hand that<br><br>holds thee: no! not one jot more!  Thou canst not tell where one drop<br><br>of water or one grain of sand will be to-morrow noon; and yet with<br><br>thy impotence thou insultest the sun!  Science!  Curse thee, thou<br><br>vain toy; and cursed be all the things that cast man's eyes aloft to<br><br>that heaven, whose live vividness but scorches him, as these old eyes<br><br>are even now scorched with thy light, O sun!  Level by nature to this<br><br>earth's horizon are the glances of man's eyes; not shot from the<br><br>crown of his head, as if God had meant him to gaze on his firmament.<br><br>Curse thee, thou quadrant!" dashing it to the deck, "no longer will I<br><br>guide my earthly way by thee; the level ship's compass, and the level<br><br>deadreckoning, by log and by line; THESE shall conduct me, and show<br><br>me my place on the sea.  Aye," lighting from the boat to the deck,<br><br>"thus I trample on thee, thou paltry thing that feebly pointest on<br><br>high; thus I split and destroy thee!"<br><br><br><br>As the frantic old man thus spoke and thus trampled with his live and<br><br>dead feet, a sneering triumph that seemed meant for Ahab, and a<br><br>fatalistic despair that seemed meant for himself--these passed over<br><br>the mute, motionless Parsee's face. And damn me,<br><br>Ahab, but thou actest right; live in the game, and die in it!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 119<br><br><br><br>The Candles.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Warmest climes but nurse the cruellest fangs: the tiger of Bengal<br><br>crouches in spiced groves of ceaseless verdure. It will sometimes burst from out that<br><br>cloudless sky, like an exploding bomb upon a dazed and sleepy town.<br><br><br><br>Towards evening of that day, the Pequod was torn of her canvas, and<br><br>bare-poled was left to fight a Typhoon which had struck her directly<br><br>ahead. "The corpusants! the corpusants!<br><br><br><br>All the yard-arms were tipped with a pallid fire; and touched at each<br><br>tri-pointed lightning-rod-end with three tapering white flames, each<br><br>of the three tall masts was silently burning in that sulphurous air,<br><br>like three gigantic wax tapers before an altar.<br><br><br><br>"Blast the boat! let it go!" cried Stubb at this instant, as a<br><br>swashing sea heaved up under his own little craft, so that its<br><br>gunwale violently jammed his hand, as he was passing a lashing.<br><br>"Blast it!"--but slipping backward on the deck, his uplifted eyes<br><br>caught the flames; and immediately shifting his tone he cried--"The<br><br>corpusants have mercy on us all!"<br><br><br><br>To sailors, oaths are household words; they will swear in the trance<br><br>of the calm, and in the teeth of the tempest; they will imprecate<br><br>curses from the topsail-yard-arms, when most they teeter over to a<br><br>seething sea; but in all my voyagings, seldom have I heard a common<br><br>oath when God's burning finger has been laid on the ship; when His<br><br>"Mene, Mene, Tekel Upharsin" has been woven into the shrouds and the<br><br>cordage.<br><br><br><br>While this pallidness was burning aloft, few words were heard from<br><br>the enchanted crew; who in one thick cluster stood on the forecastle,<br><br>all their eyes gleaming in that pale phosphorescence, like a far away<br><br>constellation of stars. But do they only have mercy on long<br><br>faces?--have they no bowels for a laugh?  And look ye, Mr.<br><br>Starbuck--but it's too dark to look. Yes, our three masts will yet be as three spermaceti<br><br>candles--that's the good promise we saw."<br><br><br><br>At that moment Starbuck caught sight of Stubb's face slowly beginning<br><br>to glimmer into sight.  Glancing upwards, he cried: "See! see!" and<br><br>once more the high tapering flames were beheld with what seemed<br><br>redoubled supernaturalness in their pallor.<br><br><br><br>"The corpusants have mercy on us all," cried Stubb, again.<br><br><br><br>At the base of the mainmast, full beneath the doubloon and the<br><br>flame, the Parsee was kneeling in Ahab's front, but with his head<br><br>bowed away from him; while near by, from the arched and overhanging<br><br>rigging, where they had just been engaged securing a spar, a number<br><br>of the seamen, arrested by the glare, now cohered together, and hung<br><br>pendulous, like a knot of numbed wasps from a drooping, orchard twig.<br><br>In various enchanted attitudes, like the standing, or stepping, or<br><br>running skeletons in Herculaneum, others remained rooted to the deck;<br><br>but all their eyes upcast.<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye, men!" cried Ahab.  "Look up at it; mark it well; the white<br><br>flame but lights the way to the White Whale!  Hand me those mainmast<br><br>links there; I would fain feel this pulse, and let mine beat against<br><br>it; blood against fire!  So."<br><br><br><br>Then turning--the last link held fast in his left hand, he put his<br><br>foot upon the Parsee; and with fixed upward eye, and high-flung right<br><br>arm, he stood erect before the lofty tri-pointed trinity of flames.<br><br><br><br>"Oh! thou clear spirit of clear fire, whom on these seas I as Persian<br><br>once did worship, till in the sacramental act so burned by thee, that<br><br>to this hour I bear the scar; I now know thee, thou clear spirit, and<br><br>I now know that thy right worship is defiance.  To neither love nor<br><br>reverence wilt thou be kind; and e'en for hate thou canst but kill;<br><br>and all are killed.  No fearless fool now fronts thee.  I own thy<br><br>speechless, placeless power; but to the last gasp of my earthquake<br><br>life will dispute its unconditional, unintegral mastery in me.  In the<br><br>midst of the personified impersonal, a personality stands here.<br><br>Though but a point at best; whencesoe'er I came; wheresoe'er I go;<br><br>yet while I earthly live, the queenly personality lives in me, and<br><br>feels her royal rights.  But war is pain, and hate is woe.  Come in<br><br>thy lowest form of love, and I will kneel and kiss thee; but at thy<br><br>highest, come as mere supernal power; and though thou launchest<br><br>navies of full-freighted worlds, there's that in here that still<br><br>remains indifferent.  Oh, thou clear spirit, of thy fire thou madest<br><br>me, and like a true child of fire, I breathe it back to thee."<br><br><br><br>[SUDDEN, REPEATED FLASHES OF LIGHTNING; THE NINE FLAMES LEAP<br><br>LENGTHWISE TO THRICE THEIR PREVIOUS HEIGHT; AHAB, WITH THE REST,<br><br>CLOSES HIS EYES, HIS RIGHT HAND PRESSED HARD UPON THEM.]<br><br><br><br>"I own thy speechless, placeless power; said I not so?  Nor was it<br><br>wrung from me; nor do I now drop these links.  Thou canst blind; but<br><br>I can then grope.  Thou canst consume; but I can then be ashes.  Take<br><br>the homage of these poor eyes, and shutter-hands.  I would not take<br><br>it.  The lightning flashes through my skull; mine eye-balls ache and<br><br>ache; my whole beaten brain seems as beheaded, and rolling on some<br><br>stunning ground.  Oh, oh!  Yet blindfold, yet will I talk to thee.<br><br>Light though thou be, thou leapest out of darkness; but I am darkness<br><br>leaping out of light, leaping out of thee!  The javelins cease; open<br><br>eyes; see, or not?  There burn the flames!  Oh, thou magnanimous! now<br><br>I do glory in my genealogy.  But thou art but my fiery father; my<br><br>sweet mother, I know not.  Oh, cruel! what hast thou done with her?<br><br>There lies my puzzle; but thine is greater.  Thou knowest not how<br><br>came ye, hence callest thyself unbegotten; certainly knowest not thy<br><br>beginning, hence callest thyself unbegun.  I know that of me, which<br><br>thou knowest not of thyself, oh, thou omnipotent.  There is some<br><br>unsuffusing thing beyond thee, thou clear spirit, to whom all thy<br><br>eternity is but time, all thy creativeness mechanical.  Through thee,<br><br>thy flaming self, my scorched eyes do dimly see it.  Oh, thou<br><br>foundling fire, thou hermit immemorial, thou too hast thy<br><br>incommunicable riddle, thy unparticipated grief.  Here again with<br><br>haughty agony, I read my sire.  Leap! leap up, and lick the sky!  I<br><br>leap with thee; I burn with thee; would fain be welded with thee;<br><br>defyingly I worship thee!"<br><br><br><br>"The boat! the boat!" cried Starbuck, "look at thy boat, old man!"<br><br><br><br>Ahab's harpoon, the one forged at Perth's fire, remained firmly<br><br>lashed in its conspicuous crotch, so that it projected beyond his<br><br>whale-boat's bow; but the sea that had stove its bottom had caused<br><br>the loose leather sheath to drop off; and from the keen steel barb<br><br>there now came a levelled flame of pale, forked fire. 'tis an<br><br>ill voyage! ill begun, ill continued; let me square the yards, while<br><br>we may, old man, and make a fair wind of it homewards, to go on a<br><br>better voyage than this."<br><br><br><br>Overhearing Starbuck, the panic-stricken crew instantly ran to the<br><br>braces--though not a sail was left aloft. And with one blast of his breath he extinguished<br><br>the flame.<br><br><br><br>As in the hurricane that sweeps the plain, men fly the neighborhood<br><br>of some lone, gigantic elm, whose very height and strength but render<br><br>it so much the more unsafe, because so much the more a mark for<br><br>thunderbolts; so at those last words of Ahab's many of the mariners<br><br>did run from him in a terror of dismay.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 120<br><br><br><br>The Deck Towards the End of the First Night Watch.<br><br><br><br>AHAB STANDING BY THE HELM.  STARBUCK APPROACHING HIM.<br><br><br><br><br><br>We must send down the main-top-sail yard, sir.  The band is working<br><br>loose and the lee lift is half-stranded. This is a nasty night, lad."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 122<br><br><br><br>Midnight Aloft.--Thunder and Lightning.<br><br><br><br><br><br>THE MAIN-TOP-SAIL YARD.--TASHTEGO PASSING NEW LASHINGS AROUND IT.<br><br><br><br><br><br>"Um, um, um.  Stop that thunder!  Plenty too much thunder up here.<br><br>What's the use of thunder?  Um, um, um.  We don't want thunder; we<br><br>want rum; give us a glass of rum.  Um, um, um!"<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 123<br><br><br><br>The Musket.<br><br><br><br><br><br>During the most violent shocks of the Typhoon, the man at the<br><br>Pequod's jaw-bone tiller had several times been reelingly hurled to<br><br>the deck by its spasmodic motions, even though preventer tackles had<br><br>been attached to it--for they were slack--because some play to the<br><br>tiller was indispensable.<br><br><br><br>In a severe gale like this, while the ship is but a tossed<br><br>shuttlecock to the blast, it is by no means uncommon to see the<br><br>needles in the compasses, at intervals, go round and round.  It was<br><br>thus with the Pequod's; at almost every shock the helmsman had not<br><br>failed to notice the whirling velocity with which they revolved upon<br><br>the cards; it is a sight that hardly anyone can behold without some<br><br>sort of unwonted emotion.<br><br><br><br>Some hours after midnight, the Typhoon abated so much, that through<br><br>the strenuous exertions of Starbuck and Stubb--one engaged forward<br><br>and the other aft--the shivered remnants of the jib and fore and<br><br>main-top-sails were cut adrift from the spars, and went eddying away<br><br>to leeward, like the feathers of an albatross, which sometimes are<br><br>cast to the winds when that storm-tossed bird is on the wing.<br><br><br><br>The three corresponding new sails were now bent and reefed, and a<br><br>storm-trysail was set further aft; so that the ship soon went through<br><br>the water with some precision again; and the course--for the present,<br><br>East-south-east--which he was to steer, if practicable, was once more<br><br>given to the helmsman.  For during the violence of the gale, he had<br><br>only steered according to its vicissitudes.  But as he was now<br><br>bringing the ship as near her course as possible, watching the<br><br>compass meanwhile, lo! a good sign! the wind seemed coming round<br><br>astern; aye, the foul breeze became fair!<br><br><br><br>Instantly the yards were squared, to the lively song of "HO! THE FAIR<br><br>WIND! OH-YE-HO, CHEERLY MEN!" the crew singing for joy, that so<br><br>promising an event should so soon have falsified the evil portents<br><br>preceding it.<br><br><br><br>In compliance with the standing order of his commander--to report<br><br>immediately, and at any one of the twenty-four hours, any decided<br><br>change in the affairs of the deck,--Starbuck had no sooner trimmed<br><br>the yards to the breeze--however reluctantly and gloomily,--than he<br><br>mechanically went below to apprise Captain Ahab of the circumstance.<br><br><br><br>Ere knocking at his state-room, he involuntarily paused before it a<br><br>moment. It's a fair<br><br>wind that's only fair for that accursed fish.--The very tube he<br><br>pointed at me!--the very one; THIS one--I hold it here; he would have<br><br>killed me with the very thing I handle now.--Aye and he would fain<br><br>kill all his crew. Thou know'st what to say."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 124<br><br><br><br>The Needle.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Next morning the not-yet-subsided sea rolled in long slow billows of<br><br>mighty bulk, and striving in the Pequod's gurgling track, pushed her<br><br>on like giants' palms outspread. Yoke on the further billows; hallo! a tandem, I drive the<br><br>sea!"<br><br><br><br>But suddenly reined back by some counter thought, he hurried towards<br><br>the helm, huskily demanding how the ship was heading.<br><br><br><br>"East-sou-east, sir," said the frightened steersman.<br><br><br><br>"Thou liest!" smiting him with his clenched fist.  "Heading East at<br><br>this hour in the morning, and the sun astern?"<br><br><br><br>Upon this every soul was confounded; for the phenomenon just then<br><br>observed by Ahab had unaccountably escaped every one else; but its<br><br>very blinding palpableness must have been the cause.<br><br><br><br>Thrusting his head half way into the binnacle, Ahab caught one<br><br>glimpse of the compasses; his uplifted arm slowly fell; for a moment<br><br>he almost seemed to stagger. Thou hast before now heard of such a thing, I<br><br>take it."<br><br><br><br>"Aye; but never before has it happened to me, sir," said the pale<br><br>mate, gloomily.<br><br><br><br>Here, it must needs be said, that accidents like this have in more<br><br>than one case occurred to ships in violent storms.  The magnetic<br><br>energy, as developed in the mariner's needle, is, as all know,<br><br>essentially one with the electricity beheld in heaven; hence it is<br><br>not to be much marvelled at, that such things should be.  Instances<br><br>where the lightning has actually struck the vessel, so as to smite<br><br>down some of the spars and rigging, the effect upon the needle has at<br><br>times been still more fatal; all its loadstone virtue being<br><br>annihilated, so that the before magnetic steel was of no more use<br><br>than an old wife's knitting needle.  But in either case, the needle<br><br>never again, of itself, recovers the original virtue thus marred or<br><br>lost; and if the binnacle compasses be affected, the same fate<br><br>reaches all the others that may be in the ship; even were the<br><br>lowermost one inserted into the kelson.<br><br><br><br>Deliberately standing before the binnacle, and eyeing the<br><br>transpointed compasses, the old man, with the sharp of his extended<br><br>hand, now took the precise bearing of the sun, and satisfied that the<br><br>needles were exactly inverted, shouted out his orders for the ship's<br><br>course to be changed accordingly. But as ever before, the pagan harpooneers remained<br><br>almost wholly unimpressed; or if impressed, it was only with a<br><br>certain magnetism shot into their congenial hearts from inflexible<br><br>Ahab's.<br><br><br><br>For a space the old man walked the deck in rolling reveries.  But<br><br>chancing to slip with his ivory heel, he saw the crushed copper<br><br>sight-tubes of the quadrant he had the day before dashed to the deck.<br><br><br><br>"Thou poor, proud heaven-gazer and sun's pilot! yesterday I wrecked<br><br>thee, and to-day the compasses would fain have wrecked me.  So, so.<br><br>But Ahab is lord over the level loadstone yet.  Mr. Starbuck--a lance<br><br>without a pole; a top-maul, and the smallest of the sail-maker's<br><br>needles.  Quick!"<br><br><br><br>Accessory, perhaps, to the impulse dictating the thing he was now<br><br>about to do, were certain prudential motives, whose object might have<br><br>been to revive the spirits of his crew by a stroke of his subtile<br><br>skill, in a matter so wondrous as that of the inverted compasses.<br><br>Besides, the old man well knew that to steer by transpointed needles,<br><br>though clumsily practicable, was not a thing to be passed over by<br><br>superstitious sailors, without some shudderings and evil portents.<br><br><br><br>"Men," said he, steadily turning upon the crew, as the mate handed<br><br>him the things he had demanded, "my men, the thunder turned old<br><br>Ahab's needles; but out of this bit of steel Ahab can make one of his<br><br>own, that will point as true as any."<br><br><br><br>Abashed glances of servile wonder were exchanged by the sailors, as<br><br>this was said; and with fascinated eyes they awaited whatever magic<br><br>might follow. Owing to a confident<br><br>reliance upon other means of determining the vessel's place, some<br><br>merchantmen, and many whalemen, especially when cruising, wholly<br><br>neglect to heave the log; though at the same time, and frequently<br><br>more for form's sake than anything else, regularly putting down upon<br><br>the customary slate the course steered by the ship, as well as the<br><br>presumed average rate of progression every hour. I'll see Mr. Stubb about it."<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 126<br><br><br><br>The Life-Buoy.<br><br><br><br><br><br>Steering now south-eastward by Ahab's levelled steel, and her<br><br>progress solely determined by Ahab's level log and line; the Pequod<br><br>held on her path towards the Equator. Yet the grey Manxman--the oldest<br><br>mariner of all--declared that the wild thrilling sounds that were<br><br>heard, were the voices of newly drowned men in the sea.<br><br><br><br>Below in his hammock, Ahab did not hear of this till grey dawn, when<br><br>he came to the deck; it was then recounted to him by Flask, not<br><br>unaccompanied with hinted dark meanings. In the sea, under<br><br>certain circumstances, seals have more than once been mistaken for<br><br>men.<br><br><br><br>But the bodings of the crew were destined to receive a most plausible<br><br>confirmation in the fate of one of their number that morning.  At<br><br>sun-rise this man went from his hammock to his mast-head at the fore;<br><br>and whether it was that he was not yet half waked from his sleep (for<br><br>sailors sometimes go aloft in a transition state), whether it was<br><br>thus with the man, there is now no telling; but, be that as it may,<br><br>he had not been long at his perch, when a cry was heard--a cry and a<br><br>rushing--and looking up, they saw a falling phantom in the air; and<br><br>looking down, a little tossed heap of white bubbles in the blue of<br><br>the sea.<br><br><br><br>The life-buoy--a long slender cask--was dropped from the stern, where<br><br>it always hung obedient to a cunning spring; but no hand rose to<br><br>seize it, and the sun having long beat upon this cask it had<br><br>shrunken, so that it slowly filled, and that parched wood also<br><br>filled at its every pore; and the studded iron-bound cask followed<br><br>the sailor to the bottom, as if to yield him his pillow, though in<br><br>sooth but a hard one.<br><br><br><br>And thus the first man of the Pequod that mounted the mast to look<br><br>out for the White Whale, on the White Whale's own peculiar ground;<br><br>that man was swallowed up in the deep. "How was it?"<br><br><br><br>It seemed that somewhat late on the afternoon of the day previous,<br><br>while three of the stranger's boats were engaged with a shoal of<br><br>whales, which had led them some four or five miles from the ship; and<br><br>while they were yet in swift chase to windward, the white hump and<br><br>head of Moby Dick had suddenly loomed up out of the water, not very<br><br>far to leeward; whereupon, the fourth rigged boat--a reserved<br><br>one--had been instantly lowered in chase.  After a keen sail before<br><br>the wind, this fourth boat--the swiftest keeled of all--seemed to<br><br>have succeeded in fastening--at least, as well as the man at the<br><br>mast-head could tell anything about it.  In the distance he saw the<br><br>diminished dotted boat; and then a swift gleam of bubbling white<br><br>water; and after that nothing more; whence it was concluded that the<br><br>stricken whale must have indefinitely run away with his pursuers, as<br><br>often happens.  There was some apprehension, but no positive alarm,<br><br>as yet.  The recall signals were placed in the rigging; darkness came<br><br>on; and forced to pick up her three far to windward boats--ere going<br><br>in quest of the fourth one in the precisely opposite direction--the<br><br>ship had not only been necessitated to leave that boat to its fate<br><br>till near midnight, but, for the time, to increase her distance from<br><br>it. I take back the<br><br>coat and watch--what says Ahab?  We must save that boy."<br><br><br><br>"He's drowned with the rest on 'em, last night," said the old Manx<br><br>sailor standing behind them; "I heard; all of ye heard their<br><br>spirits."<br><br><br><br>Now, as it shortly turned out, what made this incident of the<br><br>Rachel's the more melancholy, was the circumstance, that not only was<br><br>one of the Captain's sons among the number of the missing boat's<br><br>crew; but among the number of the other boat's crews, at the same<br><br>time, but on the other hand, separated from the ship during the dark<br><br>vicissitudes of the chase, there had been still another son; as that<br><br>for a time, the wretched father was plunged to the bottom of the<br><br>cruellest perplexity; which was only solved for him by his chief<br><br>mate's instinctively adopting the ordinary procedure of a whale-ship<br><br>in such emergencies, that is, when placed between jeopardized but<br><br>divided boats, always to pick up the majority first. Nor does it unfrequently occur, that Nantucket<br><br>captains will send a son of such tender age away from them, for a<br><br>protracted three or four years' voyage in some other ship than their<br><br>own; so that their first knowledge of a whaleman's career shall be<br><br>unenervated by any chance display of a father's natural but untimely<br><br>partiality, or undue apprehensiveness and concern.<br><br><br><br>Meantime, now the stranger was still beseeching his poor boon of<br><br>Ahab; and Ahab still stood like an anvil, receiving every shock, but<br><br>without the least quivering of his own.<br><br><br><br>"I will not go," said the stranger, "till you say aye to me. The firmaments of air and sea were<br><br>hardly separable in that all-pervading azure; only, the pensive air<br><br>was transparently pure and soft, with a woman's look, and the robust<br><br>and man-like sea heaved with long, strong, lingering swells, as<br><br>Samson's chest in his sleep.<br><br><br><br>Hither, and thither, on high, glided the snow-white wings of small,<br><br>unspeckled birds; these were the gentle thoughts of the feminine air;<br><br>but to and fro in the deeps, far down in the bottomless blue, rushed<br><br>mighty leviathans, sword-fish, and sharks; and these were the strong,<br><br>troubled, murderous thinkings of the masculine sea.<br><br><br><br>But though thus contrasting within, the contrast was only in shades<br><br>and shadows without; those two seemed one; it was only the sex, as it<br><br>were, that distinguished them.<br><br><br><br>Aloft, like a royal czar and king, the sun seemed giving this gentle<br><br>air to this bold and rolling sea; even as bride to groom.  And at the<br><br>girdling line of the horizon, a soft and tremulous motion--most seen<br><br>here at the Equator--denoted the fond, throbbing trust, the loving<br><br>alarms, with which the poor bride gave her bosom away.<br><br><br><br>Tied up and twisted; gnarled and knotted with wrinkles; haggardly<br><br>firm and unyielding; his eyes glowing like coals, that still glow in<br><br>the ashes of ruin; untottering Ahab stood forth in the clearness of<br><br>the morn; lifting his splintered helmet of a brow to the fair girl's<br><br>forehead of heaven.<br><br><br><br>Oh, immortal infancy, and innocency of the azure!  Invisible winged<br><br>creatures that frolic all round us!  Sweet childhood of air and sky!<br><br>how oblivious were ye of old Ahab's close-coiled woe!  But so have I<br><br>seen little Miriam and Martha, laughing-eyed elves, heedlessly gambol<br><br>around their old sire; sporting with the circle of singed locks which<br><br>grew on the marge of that burnt-out crater of his brain.<br><br><br><br>Slowly crossing the deck from the scuttle, Ahab leaned over the side<br><br>and watched how his shadow in the water sank and sank to his gaze,<br><br>the more and the more that he strove to pierce the profundity.  But<br><br>the lovely aromas in that enchanted air did at last seem to dispel,<br><br>for a moment, the cankerous thing in his soul.  That glad, happy air,<br><br>that winsome sky, did at last stroke and caress him; the step-mother<br><br>world, so long cruel--forbidding--now threw affectionate arms round<br><br>his stubborn neck, and did seem to joyously sob over him, as if over<br><br>one, that however wilful and erring, she could yet find it in her<br><br>heart to save and to bless.  From beneath his slouched hat Ahab<br><br>dropped a tear into the sea; nor did all the Pacific contain such<br><br>wealth as that one wee drop.<br><br><br><br>Starbuck saw the old man; saw him, how he heavily leaned over the<br><br>side; and he seemed to hear in his own true heart the measureless<br><br>sobbing that stole out of the centre of the serenity around.  Careful<br><br>not to touch him, or be noticed by him, he yet drew near to him, and<br><br>stood there.<br><br><br><br>Ahab turned.<br><br><br><br>"Starbuck!"<br><br><br><br>"Sir."<br><br><br><br>"Oh, Starbuck! it is a mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky.  On<br><br>such a day--very much such a sweetness as this--I struck my first<br><br>whale--a boy-harpooneer of eighteen!  Forty--forty--forty years<br><br>ago!--ago!  Forty years of continual whaling! forty years of<br><br>privation, and peril, and storm-time! forty years on the pitiless<br><br>sea! for forty years has Ahab forsaken the peaceful land, for forty<br><br>years to make war on the horrors of the deep!  Aye and yes, Starbuck,<br><br>out of those forty years I have not spent three ashore.  When I think<br><br>of this life I have led; the desolation of solitude it has been; the<br><br>masoned, walled-town of a Captain's exclusiveness, which admits but<br><br>small entrance to any sympathy from the green country without--oh,<br><br>weariness! heaviness!  Guinea-coast slavery of solitary<br><br>command!--when I think of all this; only half-suspected, not so<br><br>keenly known to me before--and how for forty years I have fed upon<br><br>dry salted fare--fit emblem of the dry nourishment of my soil!--when<br><br>the poorest landsman has had fresh fruit to his daily hand, and<br><br>broken the world's fresh bread to my mouldy crusts--away, whole<br><br>oceans away, from that young girl-wife I wedded past fifty, and<br><br>sailed for Cape Horn the next day, leaving but one dent in my<br><br>marriage pillow--wife? wife?--rather a widow with her husband alive!<br><br>Aye, I widowed that poor girl when I married her, Starbuck; and<br><br>then, the madness, the frenzy, the boiling blood and the smoking<br><br>brow, with which, for a thousand lowerings old Ahab has furiously,<br><br>foamingly chased his prey--more a demon than a man!--aye, aye! what a<br><br>forty years' fool--fool--old fool, has old Ahab been!  Why this<br><br>strife of the chase? why weary, and palsy the arm at the oar, and the<br><br>iron, and the lance? how the richer or better is Ahab now?  Behold.<br><br>Oh, Starbuck! is it not hard, that with this weary load I bear, one<br><br>poor leg should have been snatched from under me?  Here, brush this<br><br>old hair aside; it blinds me, that I seem to weep.  Locks so grey did<br><br>never grow but from out some ashes!  But do I look very old, so very,<br><br>very old, Starbuck?  I feel deadly faint, bowed, and humped, as<br><br>though I were Adam, staggering beneath the piled centuries since<br><br>Paradise.  God!  God!  God!--crack my heart!--stave my<br><br>brain!--mockery! mockery! bitter, biting mockery of grey hairs, have<br><br>I lived enough joy to wear ye; and seem and feel thus intolerably<br><br>old?  Close! stand close to me, Starbuck; let me look into a human<br><br>eye; it is better than to gaze into sea or sky; better than to gaze<br><br>upon God.  By the green land; by the bright hearth-stone! this is the<br><br>magic glass, man; I see my wife and my child in thine eye.  No, no;<br><br>stay on board, on board!--lower not when I do; when branded Ahab<br><br>gives chase to Moby Dick.  That hazard shall not be thine.  No, no!<br><br>not with the far away home I see in that eye!"<br><br><br><br>"Oh, my Captain! my Captain! noble soul! grand old heart, after all!<br><br>why should any one give chase to that hated fish!  Away with me! let<br><br>us fly these deadly waters! let us home!  Wife and child, too, are<br><br>Starbuck's--wife and child of his brotherly, sisterly, play-fellow<br><br>youth; even as thine, sir, are the wife and child of thy loving,<br><br>longing, paternal old age!  Away! let us away!--this instant let me<br><br>alter the course!  How cheerily, how hilariously, O my Captain, would<br><br>we bowl on our way to see old Nantucket again!  I think, sir, they<br><br>have some such mild blue days, even as this, in Nantucket."<br><br><br><br>"They have, they have.  I have seen them--some summer days in the<br><br>morning.  About this time--yes, it is his noon nap now--the boy<br><br>vivaciously wakes; sits up in bed; and his mother tells him of me, of<br><br>cannibal old me; how I am abroad upon the deep, but will yet come<br><br>back to dance him again."<br><br><br><br>"'Tis my Mary, my Mary herself!  She promised that my boy, every<br><br>morning, should be carried to the hill to catch the first glimpse of<br><br>his father's sail!  Yes, yes! no more! it is done! we head for<br><br>Nantucket!  Come, my Captain, study out the course, and let us away!<br><br>See, see! the boy's face from the window! the boy's hand on the<br><br>hill!"<br><br><br><br>But Ahab's glance was averted; like a blighted fruit tree he shook,<br><br>and cast his last, cindered apple to the soil.<br><br><br><br>"What is it, what nameless, inscrutable, unearthly thing is it; what<br><br>cozening, hidden lord and master, and cruel, remorseless emperor<br><br>commands me; that against all natural lovings and longings, I so keep<br><br>pushing, and crowding, and jamming myself on all the time; recklessly<br><br>making me ready to do what in my own proper, natural heart, I durst<br><br>not so much as dare?  Is Ahab, Ahab?  Is it I, God, or who, that<br><br>lifts this arm?  But if the great sun move not of himself; but is as an<br><br>errand-boy in heaven; nor one single star can revolve, but by some<br><br>invisible power; how then can this one small heart beat; this one<br><br>small brain think thoughts; unless God does that beating, does that<br><br>thinking, does that living, and not I.  By heaven, man, we are turned<br><br>round and round in this world, like yonder windlass, and Fate is the<br><br>handspike.  And all the time, lo! that smiling sky, and this<br><br>unsounded sea!  Look! see yon Albicore! who put it into him to chase<br><br>and fang that flying-fish?  Where do murderers go, man!  Who's to<br><br>doom, when the judge himself is dragged to the bar?  But it is a<br><br>mild, mild wind, and a mild looking sky; and the air smells now, as<br><br>if it blew from a far-away meadow; they have been making hay<br><br>somewhere under the slopes of the Andes, Starbuck, and the mowers are<br><br>sleeping among the new-mown hay.  Sleeping?  Aye, toil we how we may,<br><br>we all sleep at last on the field.  Sleep?  Aye, and rust amid<br><br>greenness; as last year's scythes flung down, and left in the half-cut<br><br>swaths--Starbuck!"<br><br><br><br>But blanched to a corpse's hue with despair, the Mate had stolen<br><br>away.<br><br><br><br>Ahab crossed the deck to gaze over on the other side; but started at<br><br>two reflected, fixed eyes in the water there.  Fedallah was<br><br>motionlessly leaning over the same rail.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 133<br><br><br><br>The Chase--First Day.<br><br><br><br><br><br>That night, in the mid-watch, when the old man--as his wont at<br><br>intervals--stepped forth from the scuttle in which he leaned, and<br><br>went to his pivot-hole, he suddenly thrust out his face fiercely,<br><br>snuffing up the sea air as a sagacious ship's dog will, in drawing<br><br>nigh to some barbarous isle.  He declared that a whale must be near.<br><br>Soon that peculiar odor, sometimes to a great distance given forth by<br><br>the living sperm whale, was palpable to all the watch; nor was any<br><br>mariner surprised when, after inspecting the compass, and then the<br><br>dog-vane, and then ascertaining the precise bearing of the odor as<br><br>nearly as possible, Ahab rapidly ordered the ship's course to be<br><br>slightly altered, and the sail to be shortened.<br><br><br><br>The acute policy dictating these movements was sufficiently<br><br>vindicated at daybreak, by the sight of a long sleek on the sea<br><br>directly and lengthwise ahead, smooth as oil, and resembling in the<br><br>pleated watery wrinkles bordering it, the polished metallic-like<br><br>marks of some swift tide-rip, at the mouth of a deep, rapid stream.<br><br><br><br>"Man the mast-heads!  Call all hands!"<br><br><br><br>Thundering with the butts of three clubbed handspikes on the<br><br>forecastle deck, Daggoo roused the sleepers with such judgment claps<br><br>that they seemed to exhale from the scuttle, so instantaneously did<br><br>they appear with their clothes in their hands.<br><br><br><br>"What d'ye see?" cried Ahab, flattening his face to the sky.<br><br><br><br>"Nothing, nothing sir!" was the sound hailing down in reply.<br><br><br><br>"T'gallant sails!--stunsails! alow and aloft, and on both sides!"<br><br><br><br>All sail being set, he now cast loose the life-line, reserved for<br><br>swaying him to the main royal-mast head; and in a few moments they<br><br>were hoisting him thither, when, while but two thirds of the way<br><br>aloft, and while peering ahead through the horizontal vacancy between<br><br>the main-top-sail and top-gallant-sail, he raised a gull-like cry in<br><br>the air.  "There she blows!--there she blows!  A hump like a<br><br>snow-hill!  It is Moby Dick!"<br><br><br><br>Fired by the cry which seemed simultaneously taken up by the three<br><br>look-outs, the men on deck rushed to the rigging to behold the famous<br><br>whale they had so long been pursuing.  Ahab had now gained his final<br><br>perch, some feet above the other look-outs, Tashtego standing just<br><br>beneath him on the cap of the top-gallant-mast, so that the Indian's<br><br>head was almost on a level with Ahab's heel.  From this height the<br><br>whale was now seen some mile or so ahead, at every roll of the sea<br><br>revealing his high sparkling hump, and regularly jetting his silent<br><br>spout into the air.  To the credulous mariners it seemed the same<br><br>silent spout they had so long ago beheld in the moonlit Atlantic and<br><br>Indian Oceans.<br><br><br><br>"And did none of ye see it before?" cried Ahab, hailing the perched<br><br>men all around him.<br><br><br><br>"I saw him almost that same instant, sir, that Captain Ahab did, and<br><br>I cried out," said Tashtego.<br><br><br><br>"Not the same instant; not the same--no, the doubloon is mine, Fate<br><br>reserved the doubloon for me.  I only; none of ye could have raised<br><br>the White Whale first.  There she blows!--there she blows!--there<br><br>she blows!  There again!--there again!" he cried, in long-drawn,<br><br>lingering, methodic tones, attuned to the gradual prolongings of the<br><br>whale's visible jets.  "He's going to sound!  In stunsails!  Down<br><br>top-gallant-sails!  Stand by three boats.  Mr. Starbuck, remember,<br><br>stay on board, and keep the ship.  Helm there!  Luff, luff a point!<br><br>So; steady, man, steady!  There go flukes!  No, no; only black water!<br><br>All ready the boats there?  Stand by, stand by!  Lower me, Mr.<br><br>Starbuck; lower, lower,--quick, quicker!" and he slid through the air<br><br>to the deck.<br><br><br><br>"He is heading straight to leeward, sir," cried Stubb, "right away<br><br>from us; cannot have seen the ship yet."<br><br><br><br>"Be dumb, man!  Stand by the braces!  Hard down the helm!--brace up!<br><br>Shiver her!--shiver her!--So; well that!  Boats, boats!"<br><br><br><br>Soon all the boats but Starbuck's were dropped; all the boat-sails<br><br>set--all the paddles plying; with rippling swiftness, shooting to<br><br>leeward; and Ahab heading the onset.  A pale, death-glimmer lit up<br><br>Fedallah's sunken eyes; a hideous motion gnawed his mouth.<br><br><br><br>Like noiseless nautilus shells, their light prows sped through the<br><br>sea; but only slowly they neared the foe.  As they neared him, the<br><br>ocean grew still more smooth; seemed drawing a carpet over its waves;<br><br>seemed a noon-meadow, so serenely it spread.  At length the<br><br>breathless hunter came so nigh his seemingly unsuspecting prey, that his<br><br>entire dazzling hump was distinctly visible, sliding along the sea as<br><br>if an isolated thing, and continually set in a revolving ring of<br><br>finest, fleecy, greenish foam.  He saw the vast, involved wrinkles of<br><br>the slightly projecting head beyond.  Before it, far out on the soft<br><br>Turkish-rugged waters, went the glistening white shadow from his<br><br>broad, milky forehead, a musical rippling playfully accompanying the<br><br>shade; and behind, the blue waters interchangeably flowed over into<br><br>the moving valley of his steady wake; and on either hand bright<br><br>bubbles arose and danced by his side.  But these were broken again by<br><br>the light toes of hundreds of gay fowl softly feathering the sea,<br><br>alternate with their fitful flight; and like to some flag-staff<br><br>rising from the painted hull of an argosy, the tall but shattered<br><br>pole of a recent lance projected from the white whale's back; and at<br><br>intervals one of the cloud of soft-toed fowls hovering, and to and<br><br>fro skimming like a canopy over the fish, silently perched and rocked<br><br>on this pole, the long tail feathers streaming like pennons.<br><br><br><br>A gentle joyousness--a mighty mildness of repose in swiftness,<br><br>invested the gliding whale.  Not the white bull Jupiter swimming away<br><br>with ravished Europa clinging to his graceful horns; his lovely,<br><br>leering eyes sideways intent upon the maid; with smooth bewitching<br><br>fleetness, rippling straight for the nuptial bower in Crete; not<br><br>Jove, not that great majesty Supreme! did surpass the glorified White<br><br>Whale as he so divinely swam.<br><br><br><br>On each soft side--coincident with the parted swell, that but once<br><br>leaving him, then flowed so wide away--on each bright side, the whale<br><br>shed off enticings.  No wonder there had been some among the hunters<br><br>who namelessly transported and allured by all this serenity, had<br><br>ventured to assail it; but had fatally found that quietude but the<br><br>vesture of tornadoes.  Yet calm, enticing calm, oh, whale! thou<br><br>glidest on, to all who for the first time eye thee, no matter how<br><br>many in that same way thou may'st have bejuggled and destroyed<br><br>before.<br><br><br><br>And thus, through the serene tranquillities of the tropical sea,<br><br>among waves whose hand-clappings were suspended by exceeding rapture,<br><br>Moby Dick moved on, still withholding from sight the full terrors of<br><br>his submerged trunk, entirely hiding the wrenched hideousness of his<br><br>jaw.  But soon the fore part of him slowly rose from the water; for<br><br>an instant his whole marbleized body formed a high arch, like<br><br>Virginia's Natural Bridge, and warningly waving his bannered flukes<br><br>in the air, the grand god revealed himself, sounded, and went out of<br><br>sight.  Hoveringly halting, and dipping on the wing, the white<br><br>sea-fowls longingly lingered over the agitated pool that he left.<br><br><br><br>With oars apeak, and paddles down, the sheets of their sails adrift,<br><br>the three boats now stilly floated, awaiting Moby Dick's<br><br>reappearance.<br><br><br><br>"An hour," said Ahab, standing rooted in his boat's stern; and he<br><br>gazed beyond the whale's place, towards the dim blue spaces and wide<br><br>wooing vacancies to leeward.  It was only an instant; for again his<br><br>eyes seemed whirling round in his head as he swept the watery circle.<br><br>The breeze now freshened; the sea began to swell.<br><br><br><br>"The birds!--the birds!" cried Tashtego.<br><br><br><br>In long Indian file, as when herons take wing, the white birds were<br><br>now all flying towards Ahab's boat; and when within a few yards began<br><br>fluttering over the water there, wheeling round and round, with<br><br>joyous, expectant cries.  Their vision was keener than man's; Ahab<br><br>could discover no sign in the sea.  But suddenly as he peered down<br><br>and down into its depths, he profoundly saw a white living spot no<br><br>bigger than a white weasel, with wonderful celerity uprising, and<br><br>magnifying as it rose, till it turned, and then there were plainly<br><br>revealed two long crooked rows of white, glistening teeth, floating<br><br>up from the undiscoverable bottom.  It was Moby Dick's open mouth and<br><br>scrolled jaw; his vast, shadowed bulk still half blending with the<br><br>blue of the sea.  The glittering mouth yawned beneath the boat like<br><br>an open-doored marble tomb; and giving one sidelong sweep with his<br><br>steering oar, Ahab whirled the craft aside from this tremendous<br><br>apparition.  Then, calling upon Fedallah to change places with him,<br><br>went forward to the bows, and seizing Perth's harpoon, commanded his<br><br>crew to grasp their oars and stand by to stern.<br><br><br><br>Now, by reason of this timely spinning round the boat upon its axis,<br><br>its bow, by anticipation, was made to face the whale's head while yet<br><br>under water.  But as if perceiving this stratagem, Moby Dick, with<br><br>that malicious intelligence ascribed to him, sidelingly transplanted<br><br>himself, as it were, in an instant, shooting his pleated head<br><br>lengthwise beneath the boat.<br><br><br><br>Through and through; through every plank and each rib, it thrilled<br><br>for an instant, the whale obliquely lying on his back, in the manner<br><br>of a biting shark, slowly and feelingly taking its bows full within<br><br>his mouth, so that the long, narrow, scrolled lower jaw curled high<br><br>up into the open air, and one of the teeth caught in a row-lock.  The<br><br>bluish pearl-white of the inside of the jaw was within six inches of<br><br>Ahab's head, and reached higher than that.  In this attitude the<br><br>White Whale now shook the slight cedar as a mildly cruel cat her<br><br>mouse.  With unastonished eyes Fedallah gazed, and crossed his arms;<br><br>but the tiger-yellow crew were tumbling over each other's heads to<br><br>gain the uttermost stern.<br><br><br><br>And now, while both elastic gunwales were springing in and out, as<br><br>the whale dallied with the doomed craft in this devilish way; and<br><br>from his body being submerged beneath the boat, he could not be<br><br>darted at from the bows, for the bows were almost inside of him, as<br><br>it were; and while the other boats involuntarily paused, as before a<br><br>quick crisis impossible to withstand, then it was that monomaniac<br><br>Ahab, furious with this tantalizing vicinity of his foe, which placed<br><br>him all alive and helpless in the very jaws he hated; frenzied with<br><br>all this, he seized the long bone with his naked hands, and wildly<br><br>strove to wrench it from its gripe.  As now he thus vainly strove,<br><br>the jaw slipped from him; the frail gunwales bent in, collapsed, and<br><br>snapped, as both jaws, like an enormous shears, sliding further aft,<br><br>bit the craft completely in twain, and locked themselves fast again<br><br>in the sea, midway between the two floating wrecks.  These floated<br><br>aside, the broken ends drooping, the crew at the stern-wreck clinging<br><br>to the gunwales, and striving to hold fast to the oars to lash them<br><br>across.<br><br><br><br>At that preluding moment, ere the boat was yet snapped, Ahab, the<br><br>first to perceive the whale's intent, by the crafty upraising of his<br><br>head, a movement that loosed his hold for the time; at that moment<br><br>his hand had made one final effort to push the boat out of the bite.<br><br>But only slipping further into the whale's mouth, and tilting over<br><br>sideways as it slipped, the boat had shaken off his hold on the jaw;<br><br>spilled him out of it, as he leaned to the push; and so he fell<br><br>flat-faced upon the sea.<br><br><br><br>Ripplingly withdrawing from his prey, Moby Dick now lay at a little<br><br>distance, vertically thrusting his oblong white head up and down in<br><br>the billows; and at the same time slowly revolving his whole spindled<br><br>body; so that when his vast wrinkled forehead rose--some twenty or<br><br>more feet out of the water--the now rising swells, with all their<br><br>confluent waves, dazzlingly broke against it; vindictively tossing<br><br>their shivered spray still higher into the air.*  So, in a gale, the<br><br>but half baffled Channel billows only recoil from the base of the<br><br>Eddystone, triumphantly to overleap its summit with their scud.<br><br><br><br><br><br>*This motion is peculiar to the sperm whale.  It receives its<br><br>designation (pitchpoling) from its being likened to that preliminary<br><br>up-and-down poise of the whale-lance, in the exercise called<br><br>pitchpoling, previously described.  By this motion the whale must<br><br>best and most comprehensively view whatever objects may be encircling<br><br>him.<br><br><br><br><br><br>But soon resuming his horizontal attitude, Moby Dick swam swiftly<br><br>round and round the wrecked crew; sideways churning the water in his<br><br>vengeful wake, as if lashing himself up to still another and more<br><br>deadly assault.  The sight of the splintered boat seemed to madden<br><br>him, as the blood of grapes and mulberries cast before Antiochus's<br><br>elephants in the book of Maccabees.  Meanwhile Ahab half smothered in<br><br>the foam of the whale's insolent tail, and too much of a cripple to<br><br>swim,--though he could still keep afloat, even in the heart of such a<br><br>whirlpool as that; helpless Ahab's head was seen, like a tossed<br><br>bubble which the least chance shock might burst.  From the boat's<br><br>fragmentary stern, Fedallah incuriously and mildly eyed him; the<br><br>clinging crew, at the other drifting end, could not succor him; more<br><br>than enough was it for them to look to themselves.  For so<br><br>revolvingly appalling was the White Whale's aspect, and so<br><br>planetarily swift the ever-contracting circles he made, that he<br><br>seemed horizontally swooping upon them.  And though the other boats,<br><br>unharmed, still hovered hard by; still they dared not pull into the<br><br>eddy to strike, lest that should be the signal for the instant<br><br>destruction of the jeopardized castaways, Ahab and all; nor in that<br><br>case could they themselves hope to escape.  With straining eyes,<br><br>then, they remained on the outer edge of the direful zone, whose<br><br>centre had now become the old man's head.<br><br><br><br>Meantime, from the beginning all this had been descried from the<br><br>ship's mast heads; and squaring her yards, she had borne down upon<br><br>the scene; and was now so nigh, that Ahab in the water hailed<br><br>her!--"Sail on the"--but that moment a breaking sea dashed on him<br><br>from Moby Dick, and whelmed him for the time.  But struggling out of<br><br>it again, and chancing to rise on a towering crest, he<br><br>shouted,--"Sail on the whale!--Drive him off!"<br><br><br><br>The Pequod's prows were pointed; and breaking up the charmed circle,<br><br>she effectually parted the white whale from his victim.  As he<br><br>sullenly swam off, the boats flew to the rescue.<br><br><br><br>Dragged into Stubb's boat with blood-shot, blinded eyes, the white<br><br>brine caking in his wrinkles; the long tension of Ahab's bodily<br><br>strength did crack, and helplessly he yielded to his body's doom: for<br><br>a time, lying all crushed in the bottom of Stubb's boat, like one<br><br>trodden under foot of herds of elephants.  Far inland, nameless wails<br><br>came from him, as desolate sounds from out ravines.<br><br><br><br>But this intensity of his physical prostration did but so much the<br><br>more abbreviate it.  In an instant's compass, great hearts sometimes<br><br>condense to one deep pang, the sum total of those shallow pains<br><br>kindly diffused through feebler men's whole lives.  And so, such<br><br>hearts, though summary in each one suffering; still, if the gods<br><br>decree it, in their life-time aggregate a whole age of woe, wholly<br><br>made up of instantaneous intensities; for even in their pointless<br><br>centres, those noble natures contain the entire circumferences of<br><br>inferior souls.<br><br><br><br>"The harpoon," said Ahab, half way rising, and draggingly leaning on<br><br>one bended arm--"is it safe?"<br><br><br><br>"Aye, sir, for it was not darted; this is it," said Stubb, showing<br><br>it.<br><br><br><br>"Lay it before me;--any missing men?"<br><br><br><br>"One, two, three, four, five;--there were five oars, sir, and here<br><br>are five men."<br><br><br><br>"That's good.--Help me, man; I wish to stand.  So, so, I see him!<br><br>there! there! going to leeward still; what a leaping spout!--Hands<br><br>off from me!  The eternal sap runs up in Ahab's bones again!  Set the<br><br>sail; out oars; the helm!"<br><br><br><br>It is often the case that when a boat is stove, its crew, being<br><br>picked up by another boat, help to work that second boat; and the<br><br>chase is thus continued with what is called double-banked oars.  It<br><br>was thus now.  But the added power of the boat did not equal the<br><br>added power of the whale, for he seemed to have treble-banked his<br><br>every fin; swimming with a velocity which plainly showed, that if<br><br>now, under these circumstances, pushed on, the chase would prove an<br><br>indefinitely prolonged, if not a hopeless one; nor could any crew<br><br>endure for so long a period, such an unintermitted, intense straining<br><br>at the oar; a thing barely tolerable only in some one brief<br><br>vicissitude.  The ship itself, then, as it sometimes happens, offered<br><br>the most promising intermediate means of overtaking the chase.<br><br>Accordingly, the boats now made for her, and were soon swayed up to<br><br>their cranes--the two parts of the wrecked boat having been<br><br>previously secured by her--and then hoisting everything to her side,<br><br>and stacking her canvas high up, and sideways outstretching it with<br><br>stun-sails, like the double-jointed wings of an albatross; the Pequod<br><br>bore down in the leeward wake of Moby-Dick.  At the well known,<br><br>methodic intervals, the whale's glittering spout was regularly<br><br>announced from the manned mast-heads; and when he would be reported<br><br>as just gone down, Ahab would take the time, and then pacing the<br><br>deck, binnacle-watch in hand, so soon as the last second of the<br><br>allotted hour expired, his voice was heard.--"Whose is the doubloon<br><br>now?  D'ye see him?" and if the reply was, No, sir! straightway he<br><br>commanded them to lift him to his perch.  In this way the day wore<br><br>on; Ahab, now aloft and motionless; anon, unrestingly pacing the<br><br>planks.<br><br><br><br>As he was thus walking, uttering no sound, except to hail the men<br><br>aloft, or to bid them hoist a sail still higher, or to spread one to<br><br>a still greater breadth--thus to and fro pacing, beneath his slouched<br><br>hat, at every turn he passed his own wrecked boat, which had been<br><br>dropped upon the quarter-deck, and lay there reversed; broken bow to<br><br>shattered stern.  At last he paused before it; and as in an already<br><br>over-clouded sky fresh troops of clouds will sometimes sail across,<br><br>so over the old man's face there now stole some such added gloom as<br><br>this.<br><br><br><br>Stubb saw him pause; and perhaps intending, not vainly, though, to<br><br>evince his own unabated fortitude, and thus keep up a valiant place<br><br>in his Captain's mind, he advanced, and eyeing the wreck<br><br>exclaimed--"The thistle the ass refused; it pricked his mouth too<br><br>keenly, sir; ha! ha!"<br><br><br><br>"What soulless thing is this that laughs before a wreck?  Man, man!<br><br>did I not know thee brave as fearless fire (and as mechanical) I<br><br>could swear thou wert a poltroon.  Groan nor laugh should be heard<br><br>before a wreck."<br><br><br><br>"Aye, sir," said Starbuck drawing near, "'tis a solemn sight; an<br><br>omen, and an ill one."<br><br><br><br>"Omen? omen?--the dictionary!  If the gods think to speak outright to<br><br>man, they will honourably speak outright; not shake their heads, and<br><br>give an old wives' darkling hint.--Begone!  Ye two are the opposite<br><br>poles of one thing; Starbuck is Stubb reversed, and Stubb is<br><br>Starbuck; and ye two are all mankind; and Ahab stands alone among the<br><br>millions of the peopled earth, nor gods nor men his neighbors!  Cold,<br><br>cold--I shiver!--How now?  Aloft there!  D'ye see him?  Sing out for<br><br>every spout, though he spout ten times a second!"<br><br><br><br>The day was nearly done; only the hem of his golden robe was<br><br>rustling.  Soon, it was almost dark, but the look-out men still<br><br>remained unset.<br><br><br><br>"Can't see the spout now, sir;--too dark"--cried a voice from the<br><br>air.<br><br><br><br>"How heading when last seen?"<br><br><br><br>"As before, sir,--straight to leeward."<br><br><br><br>"Good! he will travel slower now 'tis night.  Down royals and<br><br>top-gallant stun-sails, Mr. Starbuck.  We must not run over him<br><br>before morning; he's making a passage now, and may heave-to a while.<br><br>Helm there! keep her full before the wind!--Aloft! come down!--Mr.<br><br>Stubb, send a fresh hand to the fore-mast head, and see it manned<br><br>till morning."--Then advancing towards the doubloon in the<br><br>main-mast--"Men, this gold is mine, for I earned it; but I shall let<br><br>it abide here till the White Whale is dead; and then, whosoever of ye<br><br>first raises him, upon the day he shall be killed, this gold is that<br><br>man's; and if on that day I shall again raise him, then, ten times<br><br>its sum shall be divided among all of ye!  Away now!--the deck is<br><br>thine, sir!"<br><br><br><br>And so saying, he placed himself half way within the scuttle, and<br><br>slouching his hat, stood there till dawn, except when at intervals<br><br>rousing himself to see how the night wore on.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 134<br><br><br><br>The Chase--Second Day.<br><br><br><br><br><br>At day-break, the three mast-heads were punctually manned afresh.<br><br><br><br>"D'ye see him?" cried Ahab after allowing a little space for the<br><br>light to spread.<br><br><br><br>"See nothing, sir."<br><br><br><br>"Turn up all hands and make sail! he travels faster than I thought<br><br>for;--the top-gallant sails!--aye, they should have been kept on her<br><br>all night.  But no matter--'tis but resting for the rush."<br><br><br><br>Here be it said, that this pertinacious pursuit of one particular<br><br>whale, continued through day into night, and through night into day,<br><br>is a thing by no means unprecedented in the South sea fishery.  For<br><br>such is the wonderful skill, prescience of experience, and invincible<br><br>confidence acquired by some great natural geniuses among the<br><br>Nantucket commanders; that from the simple observation of a whale<br><br>when last descried, they will, under certain given circumstances,<br><br>pretty accurately foretell both the direction in which he will<br><br>continue to swim for a time, while out of sight, as well as his<br><br>probable rate of progression during that period.  And, in these<br><br>cases, somewhat as a pilot, when about losing sight of a coast, whose<br><br>general trending he well knows, and which he desires shortly to<br><br>return to again, but at some further point; like as this pilot stands<br><br>by his compass, and takes the precise bearing of the cape at present<br><br>visible, in order the more certainly to hit aright the remote, unseen<br><br>headland, eventually to be visited: so does the fisherman, at his<br><br>compass, with the whale; for after being chased, and diligently<br><br>marked, through several hours of daylight, then, when night obscures<br><br>the fish, the creature's future wake through the darkness is almost<br><br>as established to the sagacious mind of the hunter, as the pilot's<br><br>coast is to him.  So that to this hunter's wondrous skill, the<br><br>proverbial evanescence of a thing writ in water, a wake, is to all<br><br>desired purposes well nigh as reliable as the steadfast land.  And as<br><br>the mighty iron Leviathan of the modern railway is so familiarly<br><br>known in its every pace, that, with watches in their hands, men time<br><br>his rate as doctors that of a baby's pulse; and lightly say of it,<br><br>the up train or the down train will reach such or such a spot, at<br><br>such or such an hour; even so, almost, there are occasions when these<br><br>Nantucketers time that other Leviathan of the deep, according to the<br><br>observed humor of his speed; and say to themselves, so many hours<br><br>hence this whale will have gone two hundred miles, will have about<br><br>reached this or that degree of latitude or longitude.  But to render<br><br>this acuteness at all successful in the end, the wind and the sea<br><br>must be the whaleman's allies; for of what present avail to the<br><br>becalmed or windbound mariner is the skill that assures him he is<br><br>exactly ninety-three leagues and a quarter from his port?  Inferable<br><br>from these statements, are many collateral subtile matters touching<br><br>the chase of whales.<br><br><br><br>The ship tore on; leaving such a furrow in the sea as when a<br><br>cannon-ball, missent, becomes a plough-share and turns up the level<br><br>field.<br><br><br><br>"By salt and hemp!" cried Stubb, "but this swift motion of the deck<br><br>creeps up one's legs and tingles at the heart.  This ship and I are<br><br>two brave fellows!--Ha, ha!  Some one take me up, and launch me,<br><br>spine-wise, on the sea,--for by live-oaks! my spine's a keel.  Ha,<br><br>ha! we go the gait that leaves no dust behind!"<br><br><br><br>"There she blows--she blows!--she blows!--right ahead!" was now the<br><br>mast-head cry.<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye!" cried Stubb, "I knew it--ye can't escape--blow on and<br><br>split your spout, O whale! the mad fiend himself is after ye! blow<br><br>your trump--blister your lungs!--Ahab will dam off your blood, as a<br><br>miller shuts his watergate upon the stream!"<br><br><br><br>And Stubb did but speak out for well nigh all that crew.  The<br><br>frenzies of the chase had by this time worked them bubblingly up,<br><br>like old wine worked anew.  Whatever pale fears and forebodings some<br><br>of them might have felt before; these were not only now kept out of<br><br>sight through the growing awe of Ahab, but they were broken up, and<br><br>on all sides routed, as timid prairie hares that scatter before the<br><br>bounding bison.  The hand of Fate had snatched all their souls; and<br><br>by the stirring perils of the previous day; the rack of the past<br><br>night's suspense; the fixed, unfearing, blind, reckless way in which<br><br>their wild craft went plunging towards its flying mark; by all these<br><br>things, their hearts were bowled along.  The wind that made great<br><br>bellies of their sails, and rushed the vessel on by arms invisible as<br><br>irresistible; this seemed the symbol of that unseen agency which so<br><br>enslaved them to the race.<br><br><br><br>They were one man, not thirty.  For as the one ship that held them<br><br>all; though it was put together of all contrasting things--oak, and<br><br>maple, and pine wood; iron, and pitch, and hemp--yet all these ran<br><br>into each other in the one concrete hull, which shot on its way, both<br><br>balanced and directed by the long central keel; even so, all the<br><br>individualities of the crew, this man's valor, that man's fear; guilt<br><br>and guiltiness, all varieties were welded into oneness, and were all<br><br>directed to that fatal goal which Ahab their one lord and keel did<br><br>point to.<br><br><br><br>The rigging lived.  The mast-heads, like the tops of tall palms, were<br><br>outspreadingly tufted with arms and legs.  Clinging to a spar with<br><br>one hand, some reached forth the other with impatient wavings;<br><br>others, shading their eyes from the vivid sunlight, sat far out on<br><br>the rocking yards; all the spars in full bearing of mortals, ready<br><br>and ripe for their fate.  Ah! how they still strove through that<br><br>infinite blueness to seek out the thing that might destroy them!<br><br><br><br>"Why sing ye not out for him, if ye see him?" cried Ahab, when, after<br><br>the lapse of some minutes since the first cry, no more had been<br><br>heard.  "Sway me up, men; ye have been deceived; not Moby Dick casts<br><br>one odd jet that way, and then disappears."<br><br><br><br>It was even so; in their headlong eagerness, the men had mistaken<br><br>some other thing for the whale-spout, as the event itself soon<br><br>proved; for hardly had Ahab reached his perch; hardly was the rope<br><br>belayed to its pin on deck, when he struck the key-note to an<br><br>orchestra, that made the air vibrate as with the combined discharges<br><br>of rifles.  The triumphant halloo of thirty buckskin lungs was heard,<br><br>as--much nearer to the ship than the place of the imaginary jet, less<br><br>than a mile ahead--Moby Dick bodily burst into view!  For not by any<br><br>calm and indolent spoutings; not by the peaceable gush of that mystic<br><br>fountain in his head, did the White Whale now reveal his vicinity;<br><br>but by the far more wondrous phenomenon of breaching.  Rising with<br><br>his utmost velocity from the furthest depths, the Sperm Whale thus<br><br>booms his entire bulk into the pure element of air, and piling up a<br><br>mountain of dazzling foam, shows his place to the distance of seven<br><br>miles and more.  In those moments, the torn, enraged waves he shakes<br><br>off, seem his mane; in some cases, this breaching is his act of<br><br>defiance.<br><br><br><br>"There she breaches! there she breaches!" was the cry, as in his<br><br>immeasurable bravadoes the White Whale tossed himself salmon-like to<br><br>Heaven.  So suddenly seen in the blue plain of the sea, and relieved<br><br>against the still bluer margin of the sky, the spray that he raised,<br><br>for the moment, intolerably glittered and glared like a glacier; and<br><br>stood there gradually fading and fading away from its first sparkling<br><br>intensity, to the dim mistiness of an advancing shower in a vale.<br><br><br><br>"Aye, breach your last to the sun, Moby Dick!" cried Ahab, "thy hour<br><br>and thy harpoon are at hand!--Down! down all of ye, but one man at<br><br>the fore.  The boats!--stand by!"<br><br><br><br>Unmindful of the tedious rope-ladders of the shrouds, the men, like<br><br>shooting stars, slid to the deck, by the isolated backstays and<br><br>halyards; while Ahab, less dartingly, but still rapidly was dropped<br><br>from his perch.<br><br><br><br>"Lower away," he cried, so soon as he had reached his boat--a spare<br><br>one, rigged the afternoon previous.  "Mr. Starbuck, the ship is<br><br>thine--keep away from the boats, but keep near them.  Lower, all!"<br><br><br><br>As if to strike a quick terror into them, by this time being the<br><br>first assailant himself, Moby Dick had turned, and was now coming for<br><br>the three crews.  Ahab's boat was central; and cheering his men, he<br><br>told them he would take the whale head-and-head,--that is, pull<br><br>straight up to his forehead,--a not uncommon thing; for when within a<br><br>certain limit, such a course excludes the coming onset from the<br><br>whale's sidelong vision.  But ere that close limit was gained, and<br><br>while yet all three boats were plain as the ship's three masts to his<br><br>eye; the White Whale churning himself into furious speed, almost in<br><br>an instant as it were, rushing among the boats with open jaws, and a<br><br>lashing tail, offered appalling battle on every side; and heedless of<br><br>the irons darted at him from every boat, seemed only intent on<br><br>annihilating each separate plank of which those boats were made.  But<br><br>skilfully manoeuvred, incessantly wheeling like trained chargers in<br><br>the field; the boats for a while eluded him; though, at times, but by<br><br>a plank's breadth; while all the time, Ahab's unearthly slogan tore<br><br>every other cry but his to shreds.<br><br><br><br>But at last in his untraceable evolutions, the White Whale so crossed<br><br>and recrossed, and in a thousand ways entangled the slack of the<br><br>three lines now fast to him, that they foreshortened, and, of<br><br>themselves, warped the devoted boats towards the planted irons in<br><br>him; though now for a moment the whale drew aside a little, as if to<br><br>rally for a more tremendous charge.  Seizing that opportunity, Ahab<br><br>first paid out more line: and then was rapidly hauling and jerking<br><br>in upon it again--hoping that way to disencumber it of some<br><br>snarls--when lo!--a sight more savage than the embattled teeth of<br><br>sharks!<br><br><br><br>Caught and twisted--corkscrewed in the mazes of the line, loose<br><br>harpoons and lances, with all their bristling barbs and points, came<br><br>flashing and dripping up to the chocks in the bows of Ahab's boat.<br><br>Only one thing could be done.
