Seizing the boat-knife, he critically<br><br>reached within--through--and then, without--the rays of steel;<br><br>dragged in the line beyond, passed it, inboard, to the bowsman, and<br><br>then, twice sundering the rope near the chocks--dropped the<br><br>intercepted fagot of steel into the sea; and was all fast again.<br><br>That instant, the White Whale made a sudden rush among the remaining<br><br>tangles of the other lines; by so doing, irresistibly dragged the<br><br>more involved boats of Stubb and Flask towards his flukes; dashed<br><br>them together like two rolling husks on a surf-beaten beach, and<br><br>then, diving down into the sea, disappeared in a boiling maelstrom,<br><br>in which, for a space, the odorous cedar chips of the wrecks danced<br><br>round and round, like the grated nutmeg in a swiftly stirred bowl of<br><br>punch.<br><br><br><br>While the two crews were yet circling in the waters, reaching out<br><br>after the revolving line-tubs, oars, and other floating furniture,<br><br>while aslope little Flask bobbed up and down like an empty vial,<br><br>twitching his legs upwards to escape the dreaded jaws of sharks; and<br><br>Stubb was lustily singing out for some one to ladle him up; and while<br><br>the old man's line--now parting--admitted of his pulling into the<br><br>creamy pool to rescue whom he could;--in that wild simultaneousness<br><br>of a thousand concreted perils,--Ahab's yet unstricken boat seemed<br><br>drawn up towards Heaven by invisible wires,--as, arrow-like, shooting<br><br>perpendicularly from the sea, the White Whale dashed his broad<br><br>forehead against its bottom, and sent it, turning over and over, into<br><br>the air; till it fell again--gunwale downwards--and Ahab and his men<br><br>struggled out from under it, like seals from a sea-side cave.<br><br><br><br>The first uprising momentum of the whale--modifying its direction as<br><br>he struck the surface--involuntarily launched him along it, to a<br><br>little distance from the centre of the destruction he had made; and<br><br>with his back to it, he now lay for a moment slowly feeling with his<br><br>flukes from side to side; and whenever a stray oar, bit of plank, the<br><br>least chip or crumb of the boats touched his skin, his tail swiftly<br><br>drew back, and came sideways smiting the sea.  But soon, as if<br><br>satisfied that his work for that time was done, he pushed his pleated<br><br>forehead through the ocean, and trailing after him the intertangled<br><br>lines, continued his leeward way at a traveller's methodic pace.<br><br><br><br>As before, the attentive ship having descried the whole fight, again<br><br>came bearing down to the rescue, and dropping a boat, picked up the<br><br>floating mariners, tubs, oars, and whatever else could be caught at,<br><br>and safely landed them on her decks.  Some sprained shoulders,<br><br>wrists, and ankles; livid contusions; wrenched harpoons and lances;<br><br>inextricable intricacies of rope; shattered oars and planks; all<br><br>these were there; but no fatal or even serious ill seemed to have<br><br>befallen any one.  As with Fedallah the day before, so Ahab was now<br><br>found grimly clinging to his boat's broken half, which afforded a<br><br>comparatively easy float; nor did it so exhaust him as the previous<br><br>day's mishap.<br><br><br><br>But when he was helped to the deck, all eyes were fastened upon him;<br><br>as instead of standing by himself he still half-hung upon the<br><br>shoulder of Starbuck, who had thus far been the foremost to assist<br><br>him.  His ivory leg had been snapped off, leaving but one short sharp<br><br>splinter.<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye, Starbuck, 'tis sweet to lean sometimes, be the leaner who<br><br>he will; and would old Ahab had leaned oftener than he has."<br><br><br><br>"The ferrule has not stood, sir," said the carpenter, now coming up;<br><br>"I put good work into that leg."<br><br><br><br>"But no bones broken, sir, I hope," said Stubb with true concern.<br><br><br><br>"Aye! and all splintered to pieces, Stubb!--d'ye see it.--But even<br><br>with a broken bone, old Ahab is untouched; and I account no living<br><br>bone of mine one jot more me, than this dead one that's lost.  Nor<br><br>white whale, nor man, nor fiend, can so much as graze old Ahab in his<br><br>own proper and inaccessible being.  Can any lead touch yonder floor,<br><br>any mast scrape yonder roof?--Aloft there! which way?"<br><br><br><br>"Dead to leeward, sir."<br><br><br><br>"Up helm, then; pile on the sail again, ship keepers! down the rest<br><br>of the spare boats and rig them--Mr. Starbuck away, and muster the<br><br>boat's crews."<br><br><br><br>"Let me first help thee towards the bulwarks, sir."<br><br><br><br>"Oh, oh, oh! how this splinter gores me now!  Accursed fate! that the<br><br>unconquerable captain in the soul should have such a craven mate!"<br><br><br><br>"Sir?"<br><br><br><br>"My body, man, not thee.  Give me something for a cane--there, that<br><br>shivered lance will do.  Muster the men.  Surely I have not seen him<br><br>yet.  By heaven it cannot be!--missing?--quick! call them all."<br><br><br><br>The old man's hinted thought was true.  Upon mustering the company,<br><br>the Parsee was not there.<br><br><br><br>"The Parsee!" cried Stubb--"he must have been caught in--"<br><br><br><br>"The black vomit wrench thee!--run all of ye above, alow, cabin,<br><br>forecastle--find him--not gone--not gone!"<br><br><br><br>But quickly they returned to him with the tidings that the Parsee was<br><br>nowhere to be found.<br><br><br><br>"Aye, sir," said Stubb--"caught among the tangles of your line--I<br><br>thought I saw him dragging under."<br><br><br><br>"MY line! MY line?  Gone?--gone?  What means that little word?--What<br><br>death-knell rings in it, that old Ahab shakes as if he were the<br><br>belfry.  The harpoon, too!--toss over the litter there,--d'ye see<br><br>it?--the forged iron, men, the white whale's--no, no, no,--blistered<br><br>fool! this hand did dart it!--'tis in the fish!--Aloft there!  Keep<br><br>him nailed--Quick!--all hands to the rigging of the boats--collect<br><br>the oars--harpooneers! the irons, the irons!--hoist the royals higher--a<br><br>pull on all the sheets!--helm there! steady, steady for your life!<br><br>I'll ten times girdle the unmeasured globe; yea and dive straight<br><br>through it, but I'll slay him yet!<br><br><br><br>"Great God! but for one single instant show thyself," cried Starbuck;<br><br>"never, never wilt thou capture him, old man--In Jesus' name no more<br><br>of this, that's worse than devil's madness.  Two days chased; twice<br><br>stove to splinters; thy very leg once more snatched from under thee;<br><br>thy evil shadow gone--all good angels mobbing thee with warnings:--<br><br>what more wouldst thou have?--Shall we keep chasing this murderous<br><br>fish till he swamps the last man?  Shall we be dragged by him to the<br><br>bottom of the sea?  Shall we be towed by him to the infernal world?<br><br>Oh, oh,--Impiety and blasphemy to hunt him more!"<br><br><br><br>"Starbuck, of late I've felt strangely moved to thee; ever since that<br><br>hour we both saw--thou know'st what, in one another's eyes.  But in<br><br>this matter of the whale, be the front of thy face to me as the palm<br><br>of this hand--a lipless, unfeatured blank.  Ahab is for ever Ahab,<br><br>man.  This whole act's immutably decreed.  'Twas rehearsed by thee<br><br>and me a billion years before this ocean rolled.  Fool!  I am the<br><br>Fates' lieutenant; I act under orders.  Look thou, underling! that<br><br>thou obeyest mine.--Stand round me, men.  Ye see an old man cut down<br><br>to the stump; leaning on a shivered lance; propped up on a lonely<br><br>foot.  'Tis Ahab--his body's part; but Ahab's soul's a centipede,<br><br>that moves upon a hundred legs.  I feel strained, half stranded, as<br><br>ropes that tow dismasted frigates in a gale; and I may look so.  But<br><br>ere I break, yell hear me crack; and till ye hear THAT, know that<br><br>Ahab's hawser tows his purpose yet.  Believe ye, men, in the things<br><br>called omens?  Then laugh aloud, and cry encore!  For ere they drown,<br><br>drowning things will twice rise to the surface; then rise again, to<br><br>sink for evermore.  So with Moby Dick--two days he's floated--tomorrow<br><br>will be the third.  Aye, men, he'll rise once more,--but only to<br><br>spout his last!  D'ye feel brave men, brave?"<br><br><br><br>"As fearless fire," cried Stubb.<br><br><br><br>"And as mechanical," muttered Ahab.  Then as the men went forward, he<br><br>muttered on: "The things called omens!  And yesterday I talked the<br><br>same to Starbuck there, concerning my broken boat.  Oh! how valiantly<br><br>I seek to drive out of others' hearts what's clinched so fast in<br><br>mine!--The Parsee--the Parsee!--gone, gone? and he was to go<br><br>before:--but still was to be seen again ere I could perish--How's<br><br>that?--There's a riddle now might baffle all the lawyers backed by<br><br>the ghosts of the whole line of judges:--like a hawk's beak it pecks<br><br>my brain.  I'LL, I'LL solve it, though!"<br><br><br><br>When dusk descended, the whale was still in sight to leeward.<br><br><br><br>So once more the sail was shortened, and everything passed nearly as<br><br>on the previous night; only, the sound of hammers, and the hum of the<br><br>grindstone was heard till nearly daylight, as the men toiled by<br><br>lanterns in the complete and careful rigging of the spare boats and<br><br>sharpening their fresh weapons for the morrow.  Meantime, of the<br><br>broken keel of Ahab's wrecked craft the carpenter made him another<br><br>leg; while still as on the night before, slouched Ahab stood fixed<br><br>within his scuttle; his hid, heliotrope glance anticipatingly gone<br><br>backward on its dial; sat due eastward for the earliest sun.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>CHAPTER 135<br><br><br><br>The Chase.--Third Day.<br><br><br><br><br><br>The morning of the third day dawned fair and fresh, and once more the<br><br>solitary night-man at the fore-mast-head was relieved by crowds of<br><br>the daylight look-outs, who dotted every mast and almost every spar.<br><br><br><br>"D'ye see him?" cried Ahab; but the whale was not yet in sight.<br><br><br><br>"In his infallible wake, though; but follow that wake, that's all.<br><br>Helm there; steady, as thou goest, and hast been going.  What a<br><br>lovely day again! were it a new-made world, and made for a<br><br>summer-house to the angels, and this morning the first of its<br><br>throwing open to them, a fairer day could not dawn upon that world.<br><br>Here's food for thought, had Ahab time to think; but Ahab never<br><br>thinks; he only feels, feels, feels; THAT'S tingling enough for<br><br>mortal man! to think's audacity.  God only has that right and<br><br>privilege.  Thinking is, or ought to be, a coolness and a calmness;<br><br>and our poor hearts throb, and our poor brains beat too much for<br><br>that.  And yet, I've sometimes thought my brain was very calm--frozen<br><br>calm, this old skull cracks so, like a glass in which the contents<br><br>turned to ice, and shiver it.  And still this hair is growing now;<br><br>this moment growing, and heat must breed it; but no, it's like that<br><br>sort of common grass that will grow anywhere, between the earthy<br><br>clefts of Greenland ice or in Vesuvius lava.  How the wild winds blow<br><br>it; they whip it about me as the torn shreds of split sails lash the<br><br>tossed ship they cling to.  A vile wind that has no doubt blown ere<br><br>this through prison corridors and cells, and wards of hospitals, and<br><br>ventilated them, and now comes blowing hither as innocent as fleeces.<br><br>Out upon it!--it's tainted.  Were I the wind, I'd blow no more on<br><br>such a wicked, miserable world.  I'd crawl somewhere to a cave, and<br><br>slink there.  And yet, 'tis a noble and heroic thing, the wind! who<br><br>ever conquered it?  In every fight it has the last and bitterest<br><br>blow.  Run tilting at it, and you but run through it.  Ha! a coward<br><br>wind that strikes stark naked men, but will not stand to receive a<br><br>single blow.  Even Ahab is a braver thing--a nobler thing than THAT.<br><br>Would now the wind but had a body; but all the things that most<br><br>exasperate and outrage mortal man, all these things are bodiless, but<br><br>only bodiless as objects, not as agents.  There's a most special, a<br><br>most cunning, oh, a most malicious difference!  And yet, I say again,<br><br>and swear it now, that there's something all glorious and gracious in<br><br>the wind.  These warm Trade Winds, at least, that in the clear<br><br>heavens blow straight on, in strong and steadfast, vigorous mildness;<br><br>and veer not from their mark, however the baser currents of the sea<br><br>may turn and tack, and mightiest Mississippies of the land swift and<br><br>swerve about, uncertain where to go at last.  And by the eternal<br><br>Poles! these same Trades that so directly blow my good ship on; these<br><br>Trades, or something like them--something so unchangeable, and full<br><br>as strong, blow my keeled soul along!  To it!  Aloft there!  What<br><br>d'ye see?"<br><br><br><br>"Nothing, sir."<br><br><br><br>"Nothing! and noon at hand!  The doubloon goes a-begging!  See the<br><br>sun!  Aye, aye, it must be so.  I've oversailed him.  How, got the<br><br>start?  Aye, he's chasing ME now; not I, HIM--that's bad; I might<br><br>have known it, too.  Fool! the lines--the harpoons he's towing.  Aye,<br><br>aye, I have run him by last night.  About! about!  Come down, all of<br><br>ye, but the regular look outs!  Man the braces!"<br><br><br><br>Steering as she had done, the wind had been somewhat on the Pequod's<br><br>quarter, so that now being pointed in the reverse direction, the<br><br>braced ship sailed hard upon the breeze as she rechurned the cream in<br><br>her own white wake.<br><br><br><br>"Against the wind he now steers for the open jaw," murmured Starbuck<br><br>to himself, as he coiled the new-hauled main-brace upon the rail.<br><br>"God keep us, but already my bones feel damp within me, and from the<br><br>inside wet my flesh.  I misdoubt me that I disobey my God in obeying<br><br>him!"<br><br><br><br>"Stand by to sway me up!" cried Ahab, advancing to the hempen basket.<br><br>"We should meet him soon."<br><br><br><br>"Aye, aye, sir," and straightway Starbuck did Ahab's bidding, and<br><br>once more Ahab swung on high.<br><br><br><br>A whole hour now passed; gold-beaten out to ages.  Time itself now<br><br>held long breaths with keen suspense.  But at last, some three points<br><br>off the weather bow, Ahab descried the spout again, and instantly<br><br>from the three mast-heads three shrieks went up as if the tongues of<br><br>fire had voiced it.<br><br><br><br>"Forehead to forehead I meet thee, this third time, Moby Dick!  On<br><br>deck there!--brace sharper up; crowd her into the wind's eye.  He's<br><br>too far off to lower yet, Mr. Starbuck.  The sails shake!  Stand over<br><br>that helmsman with a top-maul!  So, so; he travels fast, and I must<br><br>down.  But let me have one more good round look aloft here at the<br><br>sea; there's time for that.  An old, old sight, and yet somehow so<br><br>young; aye, and not changed a wink since I first saw it, a boy, from<br><br>the sand-hills of Nantucket!  The same!--the same!--the same to Noah<br><br>as to me.  There's a soft shower to leeward.  Such lovely<br><br>leewardings!  They must lead somewhere--to something else than common<br><br>land, more palmy than the palms.  Leeward! the white whale goes that<br><br>way; look to windward, then; the better if the bitterer quarter.  But<br><br>good bye, good bye, old mast-head!  What's this?--green? aye, tiny<br><br>mosses in these warped cracks.  No such green weather stains on<br><br>Ahab's head!  There's the difference now between man's old age and<br><br>matter's.  But aye, old mast, we both grow old together; sound in our<br><br>hulls, though, are we not, my ship?  Aye, minus a leg, that's all.<br><br>By heaven this dead wood has the better of my live flesh every way.<br><br>I can't compare with it; and I've known some ships made of dead trees<br><br>outlast the lives of men made of the most vital stuff of vital<br><br>fathers.  What's that he said? he should still go before me, my<br><br>pilot; and yet to be seen again?  But where?  Will I have eyes at the<br><br>bottom of the sea, supposing I descend those endless stairs? and all<br><br>night I've been sailing from him, wherever he did sink to.  Aye, aye,<br><br>like many more thou told'st direful truth as touching thyself, O<br><br>Parsee; but, Ahab, there thy shot fell short.  Good-bye,<br><br>mast-head--keep a good eye upon the whale, the while I'm gone.  We'll<br><br>talk to-morrow, nay, to-night, when the white whale lies down there,<br><br>tied by head and tail."<br><br><br><br>He gave the word; and still gazing round him, was steadily lowered<br><br>through the cloven blue air to the deck.<br><br><br><br>In due time the boats were lowered; but as standing in his shallop's<br><br>stern, Ahab just hovered upon the point of the descent, he waved to<br><br>the mate,--who held one of the tackle-ropes on deck--and bade him<br><br>pause.<br><br><br><br>"Starbuck!"<br><br><br><br>"Sir?"<br><br><br><br>"For the third time my soul's ship starts upon this voyage,<br><br>Starbuck."<br><br><br><br>"Aye, sir, thou wilt have it so."<br><br><br><br>"Some ships sail from their ports, and ever afterwards are missing,<br><br>Starbuck!"<br><br><br><br>"Truth, sir: saddest truth."<br><br><br><br>"Some men die at ebb tide; some at low water; some at the full of the<br><br>flood;--and I feel now like a billow that's all one crested comb,<br><br>Starbuck.  I am old;--shake hands with me, man."<br><br><br><br>Their hands met; their eyes fastened; Starbuck's tears the glue.<br><br><br><br>"Oh, my captain, my captain!--noble heart--go not--go not!--see, it's<br><br>a brave man that weeps; how great the agony of the persuasion then!"<br><br><br><br>"Lower away!"--cried Ahab, tossing the mate's arm from him.  "Stand<br><br>by the crew!"<br><br><br><br>In an instant the boat was pulling round close under the stern.<br><br><br><br>"The sharks! the sharks!" cried a voice from the low cabin-window<br><br>there; "O master, my master, come back!"<br><br><br><br>But Ahab heard nothing; for his own voice was high-lifted then; and<br><br>the boat leaped on.<br><br><br><br>Yet the voice spake true; for scarce had he pushed from the ship,<br><br>when numbers of sharks, seemingly rising from out the dark waters<br><br>beneath the hull, maliciously snapped at the blades of the oars,<br><br>every time they dipped in the water; and in this way accompanied the<br><br>boat with their bites.  It is a thing not uncommonly happening to the<br><br>whale-boats in those swarming seas; the sharks at times apparently<br><br>following them in the same prescient way that vultures hover over the<br><br>banners of marching regiments in the east.  But these were the first<br><br>sharks that had been observed by the Pequod since the White Whale had<br><br>been first descried; and whether it was that Ahab's crew were all<br><br>such tiger-yellow barbarians, and therefore their flesh more musky to<br><br>the senses of the sharks--a matter sometimes well known to affect<br><br>them,--however it was, they seemed to follow that one boat without<br><br>molesting the others.<br><br><br><br>"Heart of wrought steel!" murmured Starbuck gazing over the side, and<br><br>following with his eyes the receding boat--"canst thou yet ring<br><br>boldly to that sight?--lowering thy keel among ravening sharks, and<br><br>followed by them, open-mouthed to the chase; and this the critical<br><br>third day?--For when three days flow together in one continuous<br><br>intense pursuit; be sure the first is the morning, the second the<br><br>noon, and the third the evening and the end of that thing--be that<br><br>end what it may.  Oh! my God! what is this that shoots through me,<br><br>and leaves me so deadly calm, yet expectant,--fixed at the top of a<br><br>shudder!  Future things swim before me, as in empty outlines and<br><br>skeletons; all the past is somehow grown dim.  Mary, girl! thou<br><br>fadest in pale glories behind me; boy!  I seem to see but thy eyes<br><br>grown wondrous blue.  Strangest problems of life seem clearing; but<br><br>clouds sweep between--Is my journey's end coming?  My legs feel<br><br>faint; like his who has footed it all day.  Feel thy heart,--beats<br><br>it yet?  Stir thyself, Starbuck!--stave it off--move, move! speak<br><br>aloud!--Mast-head there!  See ye my boy's hand on the<br><br>hill?--Crazed;--aloft there!--keep thy keenest eye upon the boats:--<br><br>mark well the whale!--Ho! again!--drive off that hawk! see! he<br><br>pecks--he tears the vane"--pointing to the red flag flying at the<br><br>main-truck--"Ha! he soars away with it!--Where's the old man now?<br><br>see'st thou that sight, oh Ahab!--shudder, shudder!"<br><br><br><br>The boats had not gone very far, when by a signal from the<br><br>mast-heads--a downward pointed arm, Ahab knew that the whale had<br><br>sounded; but intending to be near him at the next rising, he held on<br><br>his way a little sideways from the vessel; the becharmed crew<br><br>maintaining the profoundest silence, as the head-beat waves hammered<br><br>and hammered against the opposing bow.<br><br><br><br>"Drive, drive in your nails, oh ye waves! to their uttermost heads<br><br>drive them in! ye but strike a thing without a lid; and no coffin and<br><br>no hearse can be mine:--and hemp only can kill me!  Ha! ha!"<br><br><br><br>Suddenly the waters around them slowly swelled in broad circles; then<br><br>quickly upheaved, as if sideways sliding from a submerged berg of<br><br>ice, swiftly rising to the surface.  A low rumbling sound was heard;<br><br>a subterraneous hum; and then all held their breaths; as bedraggled<br><br>with trailing ropes, and harpoons, and lances, a vast form shot<br><br>lengthwise, but obliquely from the sea.  Shrouded in a thin drooping<br><br>veil of mist, it hovered for a moment in the rainbowed air; and then<br><br>fell swamping back into the deep.  Crushed thirty feet upwards, the<br><br>waters flashed for an instant like heaps of fountains, then brokenly<br><br>sank in a shower of flakes, leaving the circling surface creamed like<br><br>new milk round the marble trunk of the whale.<br><br><br><br>"Give way!" cried Ahab to the oarsmen, and the boats darted forward<br><br>to the attack; but maddened by yesterday's fresh irons that corroded<br><br>in him, Moby Dick seemed combinedly possessed by all the angels that<br><br>fell from heaven.  The wide tiers of welded tendons overspreading his<br><br>broad white forehead, beneath the transparent skin, looked knitted<br><br>together; as head on, he came churning his tail among the boats; and<br><br>once more flailed them apart; spilling out the irons and lances from<br><br>the two mates' boats, and dashing in one side of the upper part of<br><br>their bows, but leaving Ahab's almost without a scar.<br><br><br><br>While Daggoo and Queequeg were stopping the strained planks; and as<br><br>the whale swimming out from them, turned, and showed one entire flank<br><br>as he shot by them again; at that moment a quick cry went up.  Lashed<br><br>round and round to the fish's back; pinioned in the turns upon turns<br><br>in which, during the past night, the whale had reeled the involutions<br><br>of the lines around him, the half torn body of the Parsee was seen;<br><br>his sable raiment frayed to shreds; his distended eyes turned full<br><br>upon old Ahab.<br><br><br><br>The harpoon dropped from his hand.<br><br><br><br>"Befooled, befooled!"--drawing in a long lean breath--"Aye, Parsee!<br><br>I see thee again.--Aye, and thou goest before; and this, THIS then is<br><br>the hearse that thou didst promise.  But I hold thee to the last<br><br>letter of thy word.  Where is the second hearse?  Away, mates, to the<br><br>ship! those boats are useless now; repair them if ye can in time, and<br><br>return to me; if not, Ahab is enough to die--Down, men! the first<br><br>thing that but offers to jump from this boat I stand in, that thing I<br><br>harpoon.  Ye are not other men, but my arms and my legs; and so obey<br><br>me.--Where's the whale? gone down again?"<br><br><br><br>But he looked too nigh the boat; for as if bent upon escaping with<br><br>the corpse he bore, and as if the particular place of the last<br><br>encounter had been but a stage in his leeward voyage, Moby Dick was<br><br>now again steadily swimming forward; and had almost passed the<br><br>ship,--which thus far had been sailing in the contrary direction to<br><br>him, though for the present her headway had been stopped.  He seemed<br><br>swimming with his utmost velocity, and now only intent upon pursuing<br><br>his own straight path in the sea.<br><br><br><br>"Oh!  Ahab," cried Starbuck, "not too late is it, even now, the third<br><br>day, to desist.  See!  Moby Dick seeks thee not.  It is thou, thou,<br><br>that madly seekest him!"<br><br><br><br>Setting sail to the rising wind, the lonely boat was swiftly impelled<br><br>to leeward, by both oars and canvas.  And at last when Ahab was<br><br>sliding by the vessel, so near as plainly to distinguish Starbuck's<br><br>face as he leaned over the rail, he hailed him to turn the vessel<br><br>about, and follow him, not too swiftly, at a judicious interval.<br><br>Glancing upwards, he saw Tashtego, Queequeg, and Daggoo, eagerly<br><br>mounting to the three mast-heads; while the oarsmen were rocking in<br><br>the two staved boats which had but just been hoisted to the side, and<br><br>were busily at work in repairing them.  One after the other, through<br><br>the port-holes, as he sped, he also caught flying glimpses of Stubb<br><br>and Flask, busying themselves on deck among bundles of new irons and<br><br>lances.  As he saw all this; as he heard the hammers in the broken<br><br>boats; far other hammers seemed driving a nail into his heart.  But<br><br>he rallied.  And now marking that the vane or flag was gone from the<br><br>main-mast-head, he shouted to Tashtego, who had just gained that<br><br>perch, to descend again for another flag, and a hammer and nails, and<br><br>so nail it to the mast.<br><br><br><br>Whether fagged by the three days' running chase, and the resistance<br><br>to his swimming in the knotted hamper he bore; or whether it was some<br><br>latent deceitfulness and malice in him: whichever was true, the White<br><br>Whale's way now began to abate, as it seemed, from the boat so<br><br>rapidly nearing him once more; though indeed the whale's last start<br><br>had not been so long a one as before.  And still as Ahab glided over<br><br>the waves the unpitying sharks accompanied him; and so pertinaciously<br><br>stuck to the boat; and so continually bit at the plying oars, that<br><br>the blades became jagged and crunched, and left small splinters in<br><br>the sea, at almost every dip.<br><br><br><br>"Heed them not! those teeth but give new rowlocks to your oars.  Pull<br><br>on! 'tis the better rest, the shark's jaw than the yielding water."<br><br><br><br>"But at every bite, sir, the thin blades grow smaller and smaller!"<br><br><br><br>"They will last long enough! pull on!--But who can tell"--he<br><br>muttered--"whether these sharks swim to feast on the whale or on<br><br>Ahab?--But pull on!  Aye, all alive, now--we near him.  The helm!<br><br>take the helm! let me pass,"--and so saying two of the oarsmen helped<br><br>him forward to the bows of the still flying boat.<br><br><br><br>At length as the craft was cast to one side, and ran ranging along<br><br>with the White Whale's flank, he seemed strangely oblivious of its<br><br>advance--as the whale sometimes will--and Ahab was fairly within the<br><br>smoky mountain mist, which, thrown off from the whale's spout, curled<br><br>round his great, Monadnock hump; he was even thus close to him; when,<br><br>with body arched back, and both arms lengthwise high-lifted to the<br><br>poise, he darted his fierce iron, and his far fiercer curse into the<br><br>hated whale.  As both steel and curse sank to the socket, as if<br><br>sucked into a morass, Moby Dick sideways writhed; spasmodically<br><br>rolled his nigh flank against the bow, and, without staving a hole in<br><br>it, so suddenly canted the boat over, that had it not been for the<br><br>elevated part of the gunwale to which he then clung, Ahab would once<br><br>more have been tossed into the sea.  As it was, three of the<br><br>oarsmen--who foreknew not the precise instant of the dart, and were<br><br>therefore unprepared for its effects--these were flung out; but so<br><br>fell, that, in an instant two of them clutched the gunwale again, and<br><br>rising to its level on a combing wave, hurled themselves bodily<br><br>inboard again; the third man helplessly dropping astern, but still<br><br>afloat and swimming.<br><br><br><br>Almost simultaneously, with a mighty volition of ungraduated,<br><br>instantaneous swiftness, the White Whale darted through the weltering<br><br>sea.  But when Ahab cried out to the steersman to take new turns with<br><br>the line, and hold it so; and commanded the crew to turn round on<br><br>their seats, and tow the boat up to the mark; the moment the<br><br>treacherous line felt that double strain and tug, it snapped in the<br><br>empty air!<br><br><br><br>"What breaks in me?  Some sinew cracks!--'tis whole again; oars!<br><br>oars!  Burst in upon him!"<br><br><br><br>Hearing the tremendous rush of the sea-crashing boat, the whale<br><br>wheeled round to present his blank forehead at bay; but in that<br><br>evolution, catching sight of the nearing black hull of the ship;<br><br>seemingly seeing in it the source of all his persecutions; bethinking<br><br>it--it may be--a larger and nobler foe; of a sudden, he bore down<br><br>upon its advancing prow, smiting his jaws amid fiery showers of foam.<br><br><br><br>Ahab staggered; his hand smote his forehead.  "I grow blind; hands!<br><br>stretch out before me that I may yet grope my way.  Is't night?"<br><br><br><br>"The whale!  The ship!" cried the cringing oarsmen.<br><br><br><br>"Oars! oars!  Slope downwards to thy depths, O sea, that ere it be<br><br>for ever too late, Ahab may slide this last, last time upon his<br><br>mark!  I see: the ship! the ship!  Dash on, my men!  Will ye not<br><br>save my ship?"<br><br><br><br>But as the oarsmen violently forced their boat through the<br><br>sledge-hammering seas, the before whale-smitten bow-ends of two<br><br>planks burst through, and in an instant almost, the temporarily<br><br>disabled boat lay nearly level with the waves; its half-wading,<br><br>splashing crew, trying hard to stop the gap and bale out the pouring<br><br>water.<br><br><br><br>Meantime, for that one beholding instant, Tashtego's mast-head hammer<br><br>remained suspended in his hand; and the red flag, half-wrapping him<br><br>as with a plaid, then streamed itself straight out from him, as his<br><br>own forward-flowing heart; while Starbuck and Stubb, standing upon<br><br>the bowsprit beneath, caught sight of the down-coming monster just as<br><br>soon as he.<br><br><br><br>"The whale, the whale!  Up helm, up helm!  Oh, all ye sweet powers of<br><br>air, now hug me close!  Let not Starbuck die, if die he must, in a<br><br>woman's fainting fit.  Up helm, I say--ye fools, the jaw! the jaw!<br><br>Is this the end of all my bursting prayers? all my life-long<br><br>fidelities?  Oh, Ahab, Ahab, lo, thy work.  Steady! helmsman, steady.<br><br>Nay, nay!  Up helm again!  He turns to meet us!  Oh, his<br><br>unappeasable brow drives on towards one, whose duty tells him he<br><br>cannot depart.  My God, stand by me now!"<br><br><br><br>"Stand not by me, but stand under me, whoever you are that will now<br><br>help Stubb; for Stubb, too, sticks here.  I grin at thee, thou<br><br>grinning whale!  Who ever helped Stubb, or kept Stubb awake, but<br><br>Stubb's own unwinking eye?  And now poor Stubb goes to bed upon a<br><br>mattrass that is all too soft; would it were stuffed with brushwood!<br><br>I grin at thee, thou grinning whale!  Look ye, sun, moon, and stars!<br><br>I call ye assassins of as good a fellow as ever spouted up his ghost.<br><br>For all that, I would yet ring glasses with ye, would ye but hand<br><br>the cup!  Oh, oh! oh, oh! thou grinning whale, but there'll be plenty<br><br>of gulping soon!  Why fly ye not, O Ahab!  For me, off shoes and<br><br>jacket to it; let Stubb die in his drawers!  A most mouldy and over<br><br>salted death, though;--cherries! cherries! cherries!  Oh, Flask, for<br><br>one red cherry ere we die!"<br><br><br><br>"Cherries?  I only wish that we were where they grow.  Oh, Stubb, I<br><br>hope my poor mother's drawn my part-pay ere this; if not, few coppers<br><br>will now come to her, for the voyage is up."<br><br><br><br>From the ship's bows, nearly all the seamen now hung inactive;<br><br>hammers, bits of plank, lances, and harpoons, mechanically retained<br><br>in their hands, just as they had darted from their various<br><br>employments; all their enchanted eyes intent upon the whale, which<br><br>from side to side strangely vibrating his predestinating head, sent a<br><br>broad band of overspreading semicircular foam before him as he<br><br>rushed.  Retribution, swift vengeance, eternal malice were in his<br><br>whole aspect, and spite of all that mortal man could do, the solid<br><br>white buttress of his forehead smote the ship's starboard bow, till<br><br>men and timbers reeled.  Some fell flat upon their faces.  Like<br><br>dislodged trucks, the heads of the harpooneers aloft shook on their<br><br>bull-like necks.  Through the breach, they heard the waters pour, as<br><br>mountain torrents down a flume.<br><br><br><br>"The ship!  The hearse!--the second hearse!" cried Ahab from the<br><br>boat; "its wood could only be American!"<br><br><br><br>Diving beneath the settling ship, the whale ran quivering along its<br><br>keel; but turning under water, swiftly shot to the surface again, far<br><br>off the other bow, but within a few yards of Ahab's boat, where, for<br><br>a time, he lay quiescent.<br><br><br><br>"I turn my body from the sun.  What ho, Tashtego! let me hear thy<br><br>hammer.  Oh! ye three unsurrendered spires of mine; thou uncracked<br><br>keel; and only god-bullied hull; thou firm deck, and haughty helm,<br><br>and Pole-pointed prow,--death-glorious ship! must ye then perish,<br><br>and without me?  Am I cut off from the last fond pride of meanest<br><br>shipwrecked captains?  Oh, lonely death on lonely life!  Oh, now I<br><br>feel my topmost greatness lies in my topmost grief.  Ho, ho! from all<br><br>your furthest bounds, pour ye now in, ye bold billows of my whole<br><br>foregone life, and top this one piled comber of my death!  Towards<br><br>thee I roll, thou all-destroying but unconquering whale; to the last<br><br>I grapple with thee; from hell's heart I stab at thee; for hate's<br><br>sake I spit my last breath at thee.  Sink all coffins and all hearses<br><br>to one common pool! and since neither can be mine, let me then tow to<br><br>pieces, while still chasing thee, though tied to thee, thou damned<br><br>whale!  THUS, I give up the spear!"<br><br><br><br>The harpoon was darted; the stricken whale flew forward; with<br><br>igniting velocity the line ran through the grooves;--ran foul.  Ahab<br><br>stooped to clear it; he did clear it; but the flying turn caught him<br><br>round the neck, and voicelessly as Turkish mutes bowstring their<br><br>victim, he was shot out of the boat, ere the crew knew he was gone.<br><br>Next instant, the heavy eye-splice in the rope's final end flew out<br><br>of the stark-empty tub, knocked down an oarsman, and smiting the sea,<br><br>disappeared in its depths.<br><br><br><br>For an instant, the tranced boat's crew stood still; then turned.<br><br>"The ship?  Great God, where is the ship?"  Soon they through dim,<br><br>bewildering mediums saw her sidelong fading phantom, as in the<br><br>gaseous Fata Morgana; only the uppermost masts out of water; while<br><br>fixed by infatuation, or fidelity, or fate, to their once lofty<br><br>perches, the pagan harpooneers still maintained their sinking<br><br>lookouts on the sea.  And now, concentric circles seized the lone<br><br>boat itself, and all its crew, and each floating oar, and every<br><br>lance-pole, and spinning, animate and inanimate, all round and round<br><br>in one vortex, carried the smallest chip of the Pequod out of sight.<br><br><br><br>But as the last whelmings intermixingly poured themselves over the<br><br>sunken head of the Indian at the mainmast, leaving a few inches of<br><br>the erect spar yet visible, together with long streaming yards of the<br><br>flag, which calmly undulated, with ironical coincidings, over the<br><br>destroying billows they almost touched;--at that instant, a red arm<br><br>and a hammer hovered backwardly uplifted in the open air, in the act<br><br>of nailing the flag faster and yet faster to the subsiding spar.  A<br><br>sky-hawk that tauntingly had followed the main-truck downwards from<br><br>its natural home among the stars, pecking at the flag, and<br><br>incommoding Tashtego there; this bird now chanced to intercept its<br><br>broad fluttering wing between the hammer and the wood; and<br><br>simultaneously feeling that etherial thrill, the submerged savage<br><br>beneath, in his death-gasp, kept his hammer frozen there; and so the<br><br>bird of heaven, with archangelic shrieks, and his imperial beak<br><br>thrust upwards, and his whole captive form folded in the flag of<br><br>Ahab, went down with his ship, which, like Satan, would not sink to<br><br>hell till she had dragged a living part of heaven along with her, and<br><br>helmeted herself with it.<br><br><br><br>Now small fowls flew screaming over the yet yawning gulf; a sullen<br><br>white surf beat against its steep sides; then all collapsed, and the<br><br>great shroud of the sea rolled on as it rolled five thousand years<br><br>ago.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>Epilogue<br><br><br><br>"AND I ONLY AM ESCAPED ALONE TO TELL THEE"<br><br>Job.<br><br><br><br>The drama's done.  Why then here does any one step forth?--Because<br><br>one did survive the wreck.<br><br><br><br>It so chanced, that after the Parsee's disappearance, I was he whom<br><br>the Fates ordained to take the place of Ahab's bowsman, when that<br><br>bowsman assumed the vacant post; the same, who, when on the last day<br><br>the three men were tossed from out of the rocking boat, was dropped<br><br>astern.  So, floating on the margin of the ensuing scene, and in full<br><br>sight of it, when the halfspent suction of the sunk ship reached me,<br><br>I was then, but slowly, drawn towards the closing vortex.  When I<br><br>reached it, it had subsided to a creamy pool.  Round and round, then,<br><br>and ever contracting towards the button-like black bubble at the axis<br><br>of that slowly wheeling circle, like another Ixion I did revolve.<br><br>Till, gaining that vital centre, the black bubble upward burst; and<br><br>now, liberated by reason of its cunning spring, and, owing to its<br><br>great buoyancy, rising with great force, the coffin life-buoy shot<br><br>lengthwise from the sea, fell over, and floated by my side.  Buoyed<br><br>up by that coffin, for almost one whole day and night, I floated on a<br><br>soft and dirgelike main.  The unharming sharks, they glided by as if<br><br>with padlocks on their mouths; the savage sea-hawks sailed with<br><br>sheathed beaks.  On the second day, a sail drew near, nearer, and<br><br>picked me up at last.  It was the devious-cruising Rachel, that in<br><br>her retracing search after her missing children, only found another<br><br>orphan.<br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br><br>End of this Project Gutenberg etext of Moby Dick, by Herman Melville<br><br><br><br>
